Bramwell Tovey, who has made these concerts his calling card in the last few seasons, performed his customary dual role as conductor and master of ceremonies, making amusing observations about the music and briefly interviewing the evenings soloist, the violinist James Ehnes.

title: Back to Being Just a Senator, Clinton Inspects Crop Damage
description: ARCADIA, N.Y.  The big black Ford Explorer rumbled down the gravel road on Wednesday and came to a stop. Out climbed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, who started walking toward an orchard, alongside local farmers.

title: Fire Unexpectedly Worsens; Big Sur Is Ordered to Evacuate
description: BIG SUR, Calif.  Facing a stubborn fire, California officials ordered the evacuation of Big Sur on Wednesday as flames flared on nearby mountaintops and moved steadily toward this coastal retreat.

title: Kozy Shack in Snack Lineup for the Mets
description: THE newest acquisition for the New York Mets has a thick body with some jiggle to it.

title: 2 Sides in Con Ed Talks Each Held a Strong Hand
description: Labor negotiations often take place in a fishbowl, with the two sides huddled behind closed doors to hammer out agreements across big conference tables. So it was with the four-year contract between Consolidated Edison and its leading union that emerged before daybreak on Wednesday after marathon overnight talks at the State Labor Department headquarters downtown.

title: Mbekis Shame
description: Sometimes stubbornness gets measured in blood, and sometimes the wounds of race are blinding.

title: A Spa for Those Women Concerned About Pelvic Fitness
description: THESE are the generations of cosmetic medicine:

title: The Rivalry, Triangulated
description: The Red Sox face the Yankees in a four-game series starting tonight, but in an odd twist it turns out to be Bostons second-most important series of the week. The Red Sox just finished three games with the Tampa Bay Rays, the team with the best record in baseball and one theyve been chasing in the standings for most of the season. Does Tampas ascendancy steal any of the luster of the Boston-New York rivalry?

title: Music at the Museum
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art will feature classical music and rock in its concert series this fall. In addition to Itzhak Perlman, above left, the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra playing Saint-Sanss Carnival of the Animals and the farewell season of the Guarneri String Quartet, artists including Patti Smith, above right, Richie Havens and Lesley Gore will be featured. Music from Mali, Mexico, Spain and Turkey will also be performed.

title: Rays Intrude on Rite of Summer in A.L. East
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  When the Boston Red Sox face the Yankees in July, one of them is usually leading the American League East, the other not far behind.

title: A Less Dirty Tour With a New Cast of Characters
description: A year ago I wrote that the Tour de France was in such disrepute that a mob of citizens should pick up wooden pitchforks and run the scoundrels out of town.

title: Assisted Suicide of Healthy 79-Year-Old Renews German Debate on Right to Die
description: FRANKFURT  When Roger Kusch helped Bettina Schardt kill herself at home on Saturday, the grim, carefully choreographed ritual was like that in many cases of assisted suicide, with one exception.

title: For Nascar Fans, High Price of Gas Is Not Only Catalyst for Cutting Back Travel
description: LOUDON, N.H.  Steven and Nancy Swiantek sat on the roof of their recreational vehicle before the start of a Nascar Sprint Cup race Sunday. The panorama was magnificent, but their perch cost more than it used to.

title: Scruggss Son Sentenced in Bribery Case
description: Zach Scruggs, son of Mississippi lawyer Richard F. Scruggs, was sentenced to 14 months in prison on Wednesday for his part in a scheme to bribe a judge.

title: Who Loves a Parade?
description: The parade of a sports team through Manhattan is supposed to mean something. The Canyon of Heroes is the dream of any athlete who plays here. Players who have been shredded by the news media and booed by the fans know that, if they can get through it all, there's that reward awaiting them. If you can make it there, it's all worth it. We save our parades for cultural celebrations, athletes and war heroes. That sounds about right.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Wednesday about the delivery of Barry Bondss 756th home run ball to the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum misstated the number of votes cast in an online contest held by Marc Ecko, the fashion designer who purchased the ball and asked people to vote on what to do with it. About 10 million votes  not 10,000 million  were recorded.

title: Shopping for House Gifts With Simon Doonan
description: SIMON DOONAN, the creative director of Barneys New York, was dressed in a style reflecting the ideas in his newest book, Eccentric Glamour: Creating an Insanely More Fabulous You.

title: Broadways Lights Will Stay On
description: After two and a half months of talks Actors Equity Association, the union representing actors and stage managers, reached a tentative agreement on Wednesday with the Broadway League, which represents producers and theater owners, averting a strike.

title: Avery Taking His Popular Style to Dallas
description: Sean Avery, the controversial forward whose name could be found as often in tabloid gossip columns as on the sports pages during his season and a half with the Rangers, signed a four-year, $15.5 million contract with the Dallas Stars on Wednesday.

title: Human Security and State Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Foraging for Berries, the Summer Special on Natures Produce Aisle
description: IVE been feasting on wild black raspberries every day as I walk down to the stream with my dog, Wolfie, at our family farm in Maryland. The wild brambles seem to grow best along the sunny edge of the meadow where it meets the trees near the water.

title: Recognition for a People Who Faded as Japan Grew
description: NIBUTANI, Japan  The Ainu had lived on Japans northernmost island for centuries, calling their home Ainu Mosir, or Land of Human Beings. Here, they had fished, hunted, worshiped nature and established a culture that yielded Yukar, an oral poem of Homeric length.

title: Beijing, or 'What's Next?'
description: EUGENE, Ore.  After finishing their events at the Olympic track and field trials taking place at Hayward Field, athletes pass through a narrow, 50-foot long chute in an adjoining tent called the mixed zone. The mixed zone forms a media gauntlet; reporters shout questions and the competitors, on their way to doping tests, pause to reply. A rich and varied parade passes through: swaggering pop-muscled sprinters and polite pony-tailed female distance runners; the chosen ones who have finished in the top three and thus copped a berth in Beijing (as well as shoe-company bonuses), and the despondent ones who have failed in their bids and are thus relegated to at least four more years of American sports oblivion.

title: Bush Keeps Up Pressure on Iran
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush said Wednesday that the United States still strongly preferred diplomacy as it confronts rising tensions and uncertainty over Iran, but that, as always, all options are on the table.

title: In One Room, a Slam; in the Other, Down Five
description: The European Team Championships finished in Pau, France, last Saturday. The winner of the open event was Norway, represented by Terje Aa, Jorgen Molberg, Boye Brogeland, Espen Lindqvist, Geir Helgemo and Boerre Lund. (Brogeland and Helgemo also played on the winning Bermuda Bowl world championship team last October.) Russia was second, 12 victory points behind, and Germany was third, another victory point back.

title: To Beat the Heat, Learn to Sweat It Out
description: You already know that if you exercise outside on hot and humid days, you should drink plenty of water. And you are probably well aware of the risk of heat stroke given the countless reports about the warning signs.

title: A Voice From the 80s to Deliver Driving Directions
description: It was bound to happen sooner or later: Generation X nostalgia and modern technology have come together in the Knight Rider Global Positioning System from Mio Technology.

title: Ex-Leader at Spoleto Calls Ouster Political
description: SPOLETO, Italy  Francis Menotti broke a long silence on Wednesday and accused Italian politicians of callously throwing him out of the festival founded by his father, the composer Gian Carlo Menotti.

title: One New World, Two Big Ideas
description: Wayland, Mass.

title: Mongolia Enforces Martial Law in Capital Amid Political Unrest
description: BEIJING  Armed soldiers enforced martial law on the streets of Mongolias capital on Wednesday, a day after five people were killed as hundreds angered by election results rioted, Mongolian state news media reported.

title: New Money Prevents Layoffs at Fermilab
description: With an infusion of money, the Fermi National Accelerator Laboratory will avoid layoffs of 80 employees and resume work on a project to investigate ephemeral particles known as neutrinos.

title: Obama Picks Up Fund-Raising Pace
description: In the wake of Senator Barack Obamas decision last month to bypass public financing for the general election, his campaign is embarking on a spree of pricey fund-raising events across the country.

title: Longer Lashes in a Tube? Maybe Not
description: CALL it the Great Eyelash Coup. In November 2007, at the request of the Food and Drug Administration, United States marshals seized 12,682 tubes  about $2 million worth  of Age Intervention Eyelash, a lash enhancer then sold by Jan Marini Skin Research. The F.D.A. considered it an unapproved and misbranded drug in part because it contained bimatoprost, which is approved for glaucoma treatment but not for cosmetic use.

title: The Village Voice Avoids a Strike
description: Employees at the free weekly The Village Voice avoided a strike by agreeing to a three-year contract Wednesday morning with Village Voice Media, The New York Press reported. We got a deal 3 oclock this morning, said Tom Robbins, a Voice columnist and shop steward for the United Auto Workers Local 2110. We won a good victory for unions. He added that the contract did not require union members to pay any portion of the premiums of their health care, and it also calls for a raise. The contract was unanimously ratified by the membership on Wednesday morning. We had a celebratory drink of a little Scotch, Mr. Robbins said, and then went home.

title: Charge Filed Against Chief of Truck Firm After Crash
description: The president of a New Jersey company that owns the dump truck that crashed in Chinatown last week has been charged with unlicensed collection of trade waste, officials said on Wednesday.

title: Suspect in 8 Deaths Is Held on Murder Charge
description: EDWARDSVILLE, Ill.  An Illinois man thought to be responsible for the deaths of eight people in Illinois and Missouri made a brief court appearance on Wednesday afternoon and was ordered held on a charge of murder.

title: Georgia Bars Insurance Firm Over Violations
description: Regulators in Georgia have barred a California company from doing business in their state, saying it violated rules adopted in 2007 to prevent the sale of misleading or unsuitable life insurance policies to military personnel.

title: Dress Blues
description: IF you can dream it, you can do it, Alber Elbaz of Lanvin proclaimed last month to the fashion Web site The Daily, in reference to denim, of all things. Clearly his collaboration with the Swedish label Acne on a denim collection (due out in November) has made the man giddy. When you think about it, he said, you can do anything with jeans, even jewelry!

title: Texas Ranch Moves From Raid Toward Runway
description: Do we have to call it polygamy chic?

title: 500 Square Feet of Outsize Furniture
description: Large tomato-red ceramic pots filled with boxwood line the gravel path to the entrance of Berns Fry Ltd., an antiques shop just opened in Bridgehampton, N.Y. Inside, furnishings in beige and white play off earth-tone walls.

title: Seven-Year Hitch
description: EUGENE, Ore.  Has it already been seven years? Has that much time passed since Alan Webb broke Jim Ryuns high school record here, making the mile relevant again and breathing life into the expiring interest in American distance running? Seven years?

title: What We Learned in the War
description: As we slink off into the long holiday weekend, lets see if we can tout up the lessons learned from Wesleygate.

title: Sanity on Nuclear Weapons
description: To the Editor:

title: Australia in Sonoma
description: SONOMA, Calif.

title: Washingtons Boyhood Home Is Found
description: George Washingtons boyhood home has been found.

title: Tip of the Week: Look Up Books at Your Library From Home
description: Summer is a great time to catch up on your reading. You might even be able to look up books available at your library  before you leave the house  with the WorldCat database at www.worldcat.org. Type in a title and follow the screens to supply your address so you can find the book in the library nearest you. WorldCat, a global network that logs 1.2 billion items, can also look for DVDs and CDs and has plug-ins available for Firefox and Facebook.

title: The 60s Begin to Fade as Liberal Professors Retire
description: MADISON, Wis.  When Michael Olneck was standing, arms linked with other protesters, singing We Shall Not Be Moved in front of Columbia Universitys library in 1968, Sara Goldrick-Rab had not yet been born.

title: Tour de Torture: Who Is Prepared to Suffer the Most?
description: GIRONA, Spain  A coach once told me, Go until you see Jesus. Another told me, Pedal until you taste blood. Everybody in the Tour de France will suffer; the winner will probably be the one who is prepared to suffer the most.

title: The Paris Accord
description: PARIS

title: Correction: Coming Soon to YouTube: My Face-Lift
description: The Skin Deep column last Thursday, about doctors who remunerate patients for posting recommendations or videos of their procedures on the Internet, misstated the affiliation of Dr. Kathy Faber-Langendoen, a professor of bioethics and medicine who said that she sees nothing wrong in patients voluntarily surrendering their privacy for a doctors discount. She is with the SUNY Upstate Medical University in Syracuse, not SUNY in Syracuse.

title: Iraq Hints at Delay in U.S. Security Deal
description: BAGHDAD  Declaring that there will not be another colonization of Iraq, Iraqs foreign minister raised the possibility on Wednesday that a full security agreement with the United States might not be reached this year, and that if one was, it would be a short-term pact.

title: A Hungry 50 Cent, Working Hard for the Money
description: 50 Cent first appeared conquerable back in September, when he released Curtis, his third album, the same day Kanye West released Graduation, his third, and Mr. West outsold him by more than 250,000 copies. 50 Cent had long been hip-hops terrorizer, a combination of bully and hall monitor, but in the wake of this defeat, he became something he hadnt been in quite some time: an underdog.

title: A Tale of Real Estate, Life and Possibly Arson
description: Four years ago, Kathleen McClearys husband had a job offer in a consulting firm working for the Department of Homeland Security. They had been living in Oregon, which they loved, but, according to Ms. McCleary, it was one of the states that led the country in unemployment in the tech market, in which her husband worked.

title: Loving the Team You Hate
description: My mother always says theres a fine line between love and hate, because both emotions stir such deep and abiding passions in us. Since mothers are right about 99 percent of the time, I assume mine is right about the love/hate thing.

title: Eating for a Competitive Edge
description: Leanness doesn't come easy, even for Olympians, if the results of a recent survey of their weight control strategies are any indication - and male athletes deal with their weight issues more poorly than women.

title: Channeling the Voices of Africas Lost Children
description: In 2004, when the Rev. Uwem Akpan applied to the graduate program in creative writing at the University of Michigan, his folder attracted a lot of attention. He was both a Nigerian and a Jesuit priest, and the program was unused to applicants from either category. And though Father Akpans talent was abundantly evident, if a little raw, Eileen Pollack, the director of the program, recalled recently, there was some hesitation on the part of the admissions committee. There were discussions about having a priest be part of workshops where students would be writing about sex and drugs, Ms. Pollack said.

title: Fund Manager Who Faked His Suicide Surrenders
description: Samuel Israel III tricked his investors, lied to his lawyers and misled the police. But in the end, he listened to his mother.

title: As Saloon Swinger, Wopat Tries a Little Tenderness
description: Un-Frank-like, meaning not in the Sinatra manner, said Tom Wopat, describing his approach to Thats Life at the Metropolitan Room. Swinging lightly and joking his way through the 1966 hit that Frank Sinatra turned into a vocal punching bag, Mr. Wopat treated it as an offhanded sparring match between the urge to triumph and the impulse to throw in the towel. Thats alliteration, he joked, after singing the lines, Ive been a puppet, a pirate, a pauper, a poet, a pawn and a king.

title: Martinez Fails in Early Going, And Bullpen Flounders Late
description: ST. LOUIS  It has been more than a month since Luis Castillo strained his left hip flexor. It has been nearly two weeks since Castillo met with Manager Jerry Manuel and said he wanted to play every day. But it has been two days since Castillo last started, and he, as well as Manuel, is wondering whether it is time to go on the disabled list.

title: Off the Showroom Floor and Into Your Living Room
description: Dune, the TriBeCa store known for sleek, modern furniture, will have a floor sample sale July 11 to 26. Showroom pieces will be reduced up to 80 percent. New furniture ordered during the sale will be reduced 20 percent; custom orders will be 10 percent off. Floor samples include an Oval cabinet in white lacquer ($5,325, reduced from $10,650), above; a Hippo armchair in synthetic leather with a base of satin-finish aluminum ($1,593, down from $3,187); a two-seater Airframe sofa in red wool ($1,665, formerly $8,327); and a glass-top Gamma coffee table ($1,450, formerly $4,845). Dune, 88 Franklin Street (Church Street), (212) 925-6171.

title: Aiming to Sell the World on Fitness
description: GAMBETTOLA, Italy  Technogym, the worlds second-largest maker of exercise equipment, has a strategy for fighting the declining dollar: promote exercise as a necessary luxury.

title: A Singular Sink With a Single Purpose
description: For the seasoned chef  or anyone who thinks a regular kitchen sink isnt enough  Kohler has introduced the Crevasse rinsing sink ($1,350). Thirty-three inches long and just eight inches wide, it is intended to make food preparation and cleanup more efficient: one button next to the sink triggers a cold-water rinse, and a second activates a more forceful wash of water once preparations are done, simultaneously running the garbage disposal. (The sink doesnt come with a disposal, but it accommodates a standard-size one.) A silicon baffle device helps waste slide easily into the disposal, eliminating the need to push scraps down the drain with a fork or, worse, a finger. Information: (800) 456-4537 or kohler.com.

title: State Finds Fund Misuse at 19 Child Care Centers
description: The state comptroller, Thomas P. DiNapoli, said on Wednesday that his office had uncovered numerous instances of child care centers in New York City misspending public funds. He said his office had referred 19 child care centers to local prosecutors for possible criminal investigation.

title: U.S. Lifts Moratorium on New Solar Projects
description: DENVER  Under increasing public pressure over its decision to temporarily halt all new solar development on public land, the Bureau of Land Management said Wednesday that it was lifting the freeze, barely a month after it was put into effect.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column on Wednesday about the Broadway debut of Kristin Scott Thomas later this year in a production of The Seagull by Anton Chekhov misidentified the creator of the new version of the play, which appeared in London last year and will be performed in New York. He is Christopher Hampton  not Ian Rickson, who is the director.

title: The Show May Go On
description: The Wilmette Theater hopes to come to the rescue of a beleaguered production of Ragtime, which was canceled by the Wilmette Park District in suburban Chicago because of racial epithets in the script. The theater has invited the troupe of 40 homeless actors to perform a scaled-down concert version in its 198-seat theater in Wilmette, Ill. Sam Samuelson, a co-owner of the theater and an actor who performed in a national tour of the musical, said, Were moving heaven and earth to make this happen. The theater has asked the licensing agent, Music Theater International, for permission to put on two shows on July 10. The play is based on the E. L. Doctorow novel of the same name.

title: McCain and Obama Differ on Same-Sex Marriage Initiative
description: Senators Barack Obama and John McCain are at odds over a California ballot initiative that would amend the states Constitution to ban same-sex marriage.

title: Politics Failed, but Fuel Prices Cut Congestion
description: Soaring gas prices and higher tolls seem to be doing for traffic in New York what Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs ambitious congestion pricing was supposed to do: reducing the number of cars clogging the citys streets and pushing more people to use mass transit.

title: Martnez Fails in Early Going, and Bullpen Flounders Late
description: ST. LOUIS  When it comes to foiling home runs by Cardinals third basemen, there is no one better than Endy Chavez, whose over-the-fence grab of Scott Rolens deep drive in the 2006 National League Championship Series will live on in memory banks and highlight reels for generations.

title: McCain Orders Shake-Up of His Campaign
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John McCains presidential campaign has gone through its second shake-up in a year. Responding to Republican concerns that his candidacy was faltering, Mr. McCain put a veteran of President Bushs 2004 campaign in charge of day-to-day operations, and stepped away from a plan to have the campaign run by 11 regional managers, Mr. McCains aides said Wednesday.

title: At Wimbledon, Federer Returns to Form
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal were not playing each other on the English grass  at least not yet  but it certainly seemed as if they were sending each other messages on Wednesday as each took his turn on the grandest stage in tennis.

title: Massachusetts: Be Green, Its the Law
description: Massachusetts will invest in renewable energy, require utility companies to obtain energy from sources other than fossil fuels, and provide grants to help cities and towns improve energy efficiency under a measure signed into law by Gov. Deval Patrick. The law, the Green Communities Act of 2007, passed the legislature unanimously. It requires that electric companies lease solar panels to consumers, much as a cable company provides a cable box. The state, in turn, will compensate companies that invest in solar power. It also requires utility companies in Massachusetts, which deregulated utilities years ago, to enter into long-term contracts with clean-energy companies.

title: France: Reclassification of Certain Wines Challenged
description: The world of St.-milion wine was thrown into turmoil when a local court ruled that the latest reclassification of these Bordeaux wines, made in 2006, was not impartial and should be annulled. The French government organization that controls the classification, or ranking, of wine, the Institut National de lOrigine et de la Qualit, or National Institute of Origin and Quality, said it was studying the ruling. It could decide to appeal or reclassify each chateaus wines again. We have to understand what is being criticized in our 2006 reclassification so we can decide our next move, a spokesman said. The owner of Chteau Troplong Mondot, which was promoted to premier grand cru class B in the 2006 reclassification, said the winery might have to reprint its labels just as it was putting the 2006 vintage into bottles, Agence France-Presse reported. Wines in many regions of Bordeaux are reclassified roughly every 10 years to promote improved wines and demote others. It is unclear whether the ruling, if it is upheld, will affect pre-2006 classifications.

title: Hoff Sees an Olympic Pool Lined With Gold
description: OMAHA  In one corner stood Katie Hoff, who is listed at 5 feet 9 inches but appeared as tall and regal as Lady Liberty after setting an American record in the 200-meter freestyle Wednesday night to earn her third individual Olympic berth.

title: Shakira Signs With Live Nation
description: Shakira, above, has become the latest pop star to leave a major record company for Live Nation, the international touring giant that has begun signing marquee names for lucrative all-purpose contracts. After months of speculation Shakira, the 31-year-old Colombian singer of Lebanese descent who is a strong international touring draw, has signed a 10-year deal that encompasses tours, recordings, sponsorship and merchandise. Neither Shakiras representatives nor Live Nation would disclose the value of the deal, but people close to the negotiations, who spoke anonymously because they were not authorized to discuss them, said that depending on Shakiras performance over the 10 years, it would probably be worth $70 million to $100 million. Shakiras contract with Epic Records calls for three more albums  one in English, one in Spanish and a compilation  but the touring and other rights of the Live Nation deal would begin immediately.

title: Balkan Tale: Blood Ties, and Ties to Home
description: The playwright Jovanka Bach, the American daughter of immigrants from Montenegro, who died of cancer in 2006, wrote incisively about Balkan culture. Her trilogy about Serbian identity under Tito and Yugoslavias dissolution begins with Name Day and A Thousand Souls. It concludes at the Barrow Group Theater with Marko the Prince, an ambitious portrait of Sabor, a fictional shell-shocked village on the border of Bosnia and Serbia in the summer of 1992 during the bitter conflict between Bosnian Muslims and Orthodox Serbs. Using the plays elaborate framework and wealth of personalities  as well as echoes of the Serbian epic poem about Prince Marko  Ms. Bach aimed to dispel notions of ancestral obligation and long-held prejudices.

title: Lawyer Seeks Testimony About Donaghys Cooperation
description: The lawyer for Tim Donaghy, the disgraced former N.B.A. referee, wants a retired federal agent to testify in court about the information Donaghy provided the government.

title: European Plan Would Expand Health Care Access Within the Bloc
description: PARIS  People living within the European Union will be able to receive most health care treatment anywhere in the 27-nation bloc without getting prior authorization if a long-awaited proposal published on Wednesday becomes law.

title: John Pont, Who Coached Indiana to Rose Bowl, Dies at 80
description: John Pont, the personification of the football-coaching lifer who was best remembered for taking Indiana University to the 1968 Rose Bowl, the first bowl game in team history, died Tuesday at his home in Oxford, Ohio. He was 80.

title: NBC Show Draws Fire
description: The American Academy of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry said that NBC should end The Baby Borrowers, a reality television show that separates babies and toddlers from their parents and places them temporarily with teenage strangers. A childs sense of security should not be gambled with, said Robert Hendren, the president of the academy. NBC has said that the Baby Borrowers is a social experiment that can educate teenagers on the responsibilities of parenting. The parents are able to monitor their children through video cameras.

title: Jailed Embezzler Ordered to Pay Thousands in Civil Penalty
description: A Bronx judge has entered a $930,000 civil judgment against a bookkeeper who stole from a Riverdale prep school and is now serving a three- to six-year sentence in state prison for grand larceny.

title: Tatum ONeal Pleads Guilty
description: The actress Tatum ONeal, below, who was arrested in June on a charge of cocaine possession, pleaded guilty to disorderly conduct in Manhattan on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported. Judge Elisa Koenderman of Manhattan Criminal Court ordered Ms. ONeal, 44, to spend two half-day sessions in a drug treatment program and pay a $95 fee. If she follows through, the case will be dismissed.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A listing of holiday closings in some editions on Tuesday and Wednesday misstated the New York City subway schedule for Friday, Independence Day. The subway will operate on a Saturday  not a Sunday  schedule. (As correctly noted, city buses will operate on a Sunday schedule.)

title: Lottery Numbers
description: July 2, 2008

title: Hostage Rescue Is Happy Coincidence for McCain in Colombia
description: MEXICO CITYSenator John McCain congratulated President Alvaro Uribe of Colombia on Wednesday for the Colombian governments rescue of 15 hostages, including three Americans, held by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, a Marxist-inspired insurgency that Mr. McCain repeatedly criticized this week during a trip to Latin America.

title: Steelworkers Merge With British Union
description: The United Steelworkers signed a merger agreement on Wednesday with the largest labor organization in Britain and Ireland to create what union leaders said would be the worlds first global union.

title: Summer of 94, With Boy, Girl, Love and Dope Sales
description: For Luke Shapiro (Josh Peck) the summer of 1994 is a notably eventful time. In retrospect he will no doubt see it as the season when his life, as they say in the movies, changed forever. The movie he is in, The Wackness, written and directed by Jonathan Levine, makes a good-faith effort to steer clear of such clichs, and succeeds and fails in roughly equal measure.

title: McNamee's Lawyers Seek Dismissal of Defamation Suit
description: Lawyers for Brian McNamee, Roger Clemenss former trainer, filed a motion in federal court Wednesday night to have a defamation lawsuit brought by Clemens dismissed.

title: Drivers Walkout Has Ripple Effect Across City
description: They were ready to pour the concrete for the fifth floor of a luxury condominium building in Lower Manhattan when more than 400 concrete-truck drivers went on strike.

title: Shooting Is Done; Editing Is Next
A Tiny Thumb Drive With Big Capacity and a Safety Leash
description: Now that thumb drives like the one-inch Imation Atom are small enough to ingest, perhaps parents should talk to their children about the dangers of eating flash memory.

title: Obama Strives to Retain Some Flexibility on His Iraq Policy
description: Senator Barack Obama said Thursday that he might refine his plans for a phased withdrawal from Iraq after meeting with military commanders there later this summer. But later, he hastily held a second news conference: to emphasize his commitment to withdrawing all combat troops from Iraq within 16 months of taking office.

title: Judge Orders Fence Struck in Brooklyn
description: A Brooklyn judge on Wednesday ordered the removal of an 18-foot-tall, 200-foot-long metal fence that separates the Red Hook Recreation Area from the Henry Street Basin. City lawyers had argued that the fence was built illegally and impeded access to the Red Hook waterfront.

title: R. C. Seamans Jr., NASA Figure, Dies at 89
description: Robert C. Seamans Jr., NASAs nuts-and-bolts manager of the Apollo moon-landing program, who later served as secretary of the Air Force and then as the first administrator of the federal energy research agency, died Saturday at his home in Beverly Farms, Mass. He was 89.

title: Those Cellphone Termination Fees Seem to Be on the Way Out
description: The handcuffs may not be coming off cellphone owners, but they are getting looser.

title: Closures on Friday for Fourth of July
description: NEW YORK

title: Qualifier Steps Out of the Office and Onto the Track
description: By day, Lesley Higgins works as a compliance director on Gov. David Patersons staff in New York City, making sure laws are followed and paperwork is filed.

title: Correction
description: In describing an encounter between Barack Obama and a schoolboy in Zanesville, Ohio, Maureen Dowds column on Wednesday used a campaign pool report. The report said that Mr. Obama had declined to bump fists with the boy. The campaign now says that the boy was trying to get Mr. Obama to autograph his hand, but the candidate declined, citing the possible reaction of the boys mother.

title: Coldplay Remains No. 1
description: After a big opening, Coldplays new album, Viva la Vida or Death and All His Friends (Capitol), lost two thirds of its sales in its second week out, but it is still the No. 1 album in the country, selling 249,000 more copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Lil Waynes Tha Carter III (Cash Money/Universal) was No. 2 with 209,000, and Disneys Camp Rock soundtrack, with the teenage stars Demi Lovato and the Jonas Brothers, was No. 3 with 169,000 sales. The new Mtley Cre album, Saints of Los Angeles (Mtley), opened at No. 4 with 99,000, and Three 6 Mafias new Last 2 Walk (Hypnotize Minds/Columbia) bowed at No. 5 with 77,000. Shinedowns new release, The Sound of Madness (Atlantic), was No. 8 with 50,000 sales.

title: Bush Asks for Help, Abroad and at Home, in Sending Aid to Africa
description: WASHINGTON  Amid signs that his quest for more aid to Africa is in danger of unraveling, President Bush called Wednesday for Congress to renew his global AIDS initiative and urged other nations to live up to their own promises to fight poverty and disease on the continent.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Wednesday about coercive interrogation methods taught at Guantnamo Bay that were copied from a 1957 journal article about Chinese techniques misstated the given name of the author of the article. He was Albert D. Biderman, not Alfred.

title: Australia: Retail Sales Rose in May
description: Australian retail sales rose in May at the fastest rate in six months. Sales increased 0.7 percent from April, the Bureau of Statistics said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about Leona Helmsleys instructions that her charitable trust, valued at $5 billion to $8 billion, be used for the care and welfare of dogs misstated the amount of the inheritance that two of Mrs. Helmsleys grandchildren were granted after being left out of her will. It was a combined total of $6 million, not $6 million each.

title: Not Just Hartfords Problems
description: Connecticuts capital city is in trouble. Shootings in Hartford have injured more than 100 people this year and killed at least six. A former deputy mayor was beaten and robbed while walking to breakfast. Gov. M. Jodi Rell has brought in state police to help, but that promises only temporary relief. In the last few years, troopers have been summoned repeatedly while little has been done to address Hartfords more fundamental problems.

title: Early Retirees in New Ventures, Mostly for Fun
description: RISK-AVERSE? Clueless as to what P.&.L means? You, too, can be an entrepreneur.

title: A Handset Has the Beats, and Shares Them
description: Partygoers rejoice! The Nokia N78, Nokias latest multimedia phone, has a built-in FM transmitter that allows you to share your favorite whale-call-based dance tracks with the group over the home stereo or car radio. Then, when your friends kick you out, its integrated G.P.S. mapping gets you home.

title: The Imprecise Meaning of War
description: Unless Congress closes a gaping hole in the law against war profiteering, companies ripping off taxpayers in the Iraq and Afghanistan wars may never be fully prosecuted. This is because the latest conflicts are not declared wars.

title: As Phelps Sulks, His Runner-Up Celebrates
description: OMAHA  What a contrast. Michael Phelps won his third event of the United States Olympic trials Wednesday night  the 200-meter butterfly, which he has dominated since 2001. But he fell short of the world record and acted almost as if he had lost.

title: When Lawmakers Change Their Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: Power Remedies for Dirty Grout
description: KAREN KARL, a homeowner in Montville, N.J., was at war with her kitchen floor.

title: Palestinian Kills 3 With Construction Vehicle
description: JERUSALEM  The Palestinian driver of a large construction vehicle went on a deadly rampage along a central Jerusalem thoroughfare on Wednesday, crushing several cars and ramming into buses and pedestrians before an off-duty soldier and a police officer clambered up to the cabin and fatally shot him.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Wednesday about second-quarter reports on the Manhattan real estate market misstated the period of time over which average co-op prices fell by 8 percent, according to Prudential Douglas Elliman. It was since the previous quarter, not the previous year.

title: L.A. Times Newsroom to Shrink by 150 Jobs
description: The Los Angeles Times announced Wednesday that it would eliminate 150 newsroom jobs  more than one-sixth of the staff  and publish 15 percent fewer pages, in the deepest of a series of cuts at Tribune Company newspapers as the company tries to stay afloat.

title: Churchs Troubles Typify Ground Zero Delays
description: The story of the tiny St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church and its efforts to rebuild after the collapse of the World Trade Center is one of well-intentioned promises that led to endless negotiations, design disputes, delays and mounting costs.

title: Camera Packs Features at a Less-Hefty Price
description: This week, the latest salvo landed in the pitched battle between Nikon and Canon for the hearts, minds and wallets of serious photographers.

title: A Supreme Court on the Brink
description: In some ways, the Supreme Court term that just ended seems muddled: disturbing, highly conservative rulings on subjects like voting rights and gun control, along with important defenses of basic liberties in other areas, including the rights of detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba. The key to understanding the term lies in the fragility of the courts center. Some of the most important decisions came on 5-to-4 votes  a stark reminder that the court is just one justice away from solidifying a far-right majority that would do great damage to the Constitution and the rights of ordinary Americans.

title: In Turnabout, Russia to Allow Permits for BP Workers
description: MOSCOW  In a sign of apparent backpedaling by officials here, the Russian government said on Wednesday that it would expedite work permits for the chief executive of a BP joint venture, and five other senior staff members.

title: Accountant Charged in $2.8 Million Theft From Company
description: When John Hoeffner, an accountant, filed papers to incorporate a company called Mr. John, he had no plans to specialize in the portable toilet business, prosecutors said on Wednesday.

title: Legacy of $8 Billion? For Us? Dogs Take the News in Stride
description: Froggy, a 5-month-old Yorkshire and cairn terrier mix, stared at the front-page article, sniffed it dutifully and wandered off Wednesday for better sniffing elsewhere in the Washington Square Park dog run.

title: Big Job Cuts Announced at American
description: American Airlines expects to cut nearly 7,000 employees by the end of the year, or about 8 percent of its worldwide work force, as it reduces flights and grounds aircraft because of high fuel costs, the airline told employees Wednesday.

title: When You Carry Precious Cargo on Your Back
description: HIKING with backpacking gear is a matter of balancing weight and necessity. Add a baby and the equation gets complicated.

title: The Times Wins 3 Loeb Awards for Reporting
description: The New York Times has won three Gerald Loeb Awards for reporting on subjects that ranged from the rural factories of China to the rarefied boardrooms of Wall Street.

title: See Spot Run. Now Find Out Where He Went.
description: MAYBE you have a dog. Maybe you have teenagers, too.

title: Lead Poisoning Cases Decline
description: Childhood lead poisoning declined by 15 percent last year, the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene reported on Wednesday, reaching the lowest rate ever recorded in New York City.

title: Police Detail a Killing Spree Across 2 States
description: EDWARDSVILLE, Ill.  Shunning the handgun he carried by his side, Nicholas T. Sheley killed his victims with cruder tools  a weathervane, perhaps a bar stool  the authorities said Wednesday, as he traveled from Illinois to Missouri on a murderous tear that left eight people dead, including a 93-year-old man and a 2-year-old boy.

title: Britain: Sales Drop for Big Retailer
description: The Marks & Spencer Group, hurt by a slump in British consumer spending, said sales had dropped the most since 2005 and ousted Steven Esom, its top food executive, after his unit had the worst quarter in at least a decade. Marks & Spencer shares fell 25 percent in London trading to a seven-year low. The executive chairman of Marks & Spencer, Stuart Rose, above, said the loss came amid the biggest price war weve probably had in the last 20 years.

title: Bruyneel on the Sidelines, No Regret in Sight
description: When an international sports court upheld doping charges against Floyd Landis this week, reaffirming his disqualification as the 2006 Tour de France winner, it was a reminder of the dark cloud that still hovers over cycling as this years Tour begins on Saturday. That cloud hovers even over its past champions. "I know already now that Im not going to miss being in the race," says Johan Bruyneel, the hard-driving and strategic Belgian-born team director whose U.S. Postal Service and Discovery Channel teams won the Tour de France eight times in the last nine years. "Thats a feeling Ive had for the last three years. It basically wasnt fun anymore. The fun was winning the race, not being in the race."

title: Its Not Easy Picking a Path to Enlightenment
description: Stockbridge, Mass.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Arts, Briefly column on Tuesday about new monetary awards for artists whose work promotes human rights omitted a co-founder. Along with the philanthropic group ArtVenture, the human rights group Article 19 is establishing and publicizing the awards.

title: Federal Report Recommends Improvements in Reporting Deaths of Immigrant Detainees
description: The federal immigration agency should report all deaths in detention promptly, not only to the inspector general for the Department of Homeland Security, but also to state authorities where required by law, the inspector general has recommended after a special review of the deaths of two immigrant detainees.

title: The Struggles of Detroit Ensnare Its Workers
description: DETROIT  Their pickups and sport utility vehicles are not selling, and now General Motors, Ford Motor and Chrysler have to pay thousands of auto workers not to make them.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Wednesday about Senator Barack Obamas goal of expanding religious organizations roles in delivering social services misspelled the surname of a Harvard law professor who has advised the Obama campaign on the issue. She is Martha Minow, not Minnow.

title: Pair Regain Speed Mark in Ascent of El Capitan
description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif.  As two rock climbers scrambled over the uppermost lip of Yosemites El Capitan and disappeared from view, the small group of spectators that had gathered 3,000 feet below erupted in cheers. Then they quickly quieted down.

title: Panel Questions State Dept. Role in Iraq Oil Deal
description: Bush administration officials knew that a Texas oil company with close ties to President Bush was planning to sign an oil deal with the regional Kurdistan government that ran counter to American policy and undercut Iraqs central government, a Congressional committee has concluded.

title: U.S. Is in No Shape to Give Advice, Medvedev Says
description: MOSCOW  Russias new president, Dmitri A. Medvedev, less swaggering than his predecessor but as touchy about criticism from abroad, said in an interview that an America in essentially a depression was in no position to lecture other countries on how to conduct their affairs.

title: Keeping Graphics in Their Place
description: Q. It seems easy enough to add images into a Microsoft Word file, but how can these graphics be pasted down so that they do not slip all over the place when text is added?

title: Armed With a New Label, Funk Singer Unleashes a New Act
description: Nikka Costa has made three records since 2001, and each time she comes around she leaves an impression. She is small, white, medium glamorous, Californian, late 30s, but a performer before anything else: before an audience she goes deep and sexy and ugly, singing hard and on pitch, screaming hard and on pitch, hips like a boomerang, knees on the floor. Its not as good as your favorite James Brown footage, but theres something happening there, something physical and wrigglingly alive.

title: The Luckiest Girl
description: This years college graduates owe their success to many factors, from hectoring parents to cherished remedies for hangovers. But one of the most remarkable of the new graduates, Beatrice Biira, credits something utterly improbable: a goat.

title: On a New Quest, a Tiny Order Leaves Brooklyn
description: Brother Jay McGowan always found it hard to explain to New Yorkers just exactly what he did as a member of the Little Brothers of the Gospel. Other religious groups run schools, hospitals or parishes, managing staffs and budgets.

title: Colombia Plucks Hostages From Rebels Grasp
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  Colombian commandos in disguise spirited 15 hostages to freedom on Wednesday, including Ingrid Betancourt, a French-Colombian politician held for six years, and three American military contractors.

title: A Lucrative Deal for Rush Limbaugh
description: Talk was never cheap for Rush Limbaugh, but now it is getting a lot more expensive.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on June 23 about television coverage of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan referred incorrectly to the amount of network newscast time devoted to coverage, according to figures compiled by Andrew Tyndall, a television consultant. Mr. Tyndalls figures refer specifically to coverage of the wars, not to coverage of all subjects related to those countries.

title: At Midlife, Called to a New Field
description: THE most important piece of farm equipment at Grazin Angus Acres is not the windmill that Dan Gibson, the farms founder, hopes will one day help him operate off the grid. Nor is it the eggmobile, home to more than 300 handsome, rust-colored pastured Buff Orpington hens, whose droppings enrich the grasses that the farms 200 head of Angus cattle graze on.

title: When Planning a Garden, Spin the Color Wheel
description: Q. I have a small backyard garden. How can I get a handle on the out-of-control color scheme in my flowerbeds?

title: Digital Pens to Write on Any Paper
description: In gadget-head circles, one of this summers most buzzworthy new products is the Pulse pen: a ballpoint that simultaneously records both your handwriting and the sound of the words you are transcribing. Both are transferred to a Windows PC when you return home  seemingly perfect for lecture-hall students, journalists and note-takers of any kind.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Tuesday about a dispute over the storage of Iraqi Baath Party documents at the Hoover Institution misquoted Thomas S. Blanton, director of the National Security Archive at George Washington University. In discussing who should have access to the documents, which indicate how loyal many Iraqis were to Saddam Husseins regime, he said, How do you have accountability, but not revictimize the victims? He did not say, How do you have accountability, but not revictimize the victimizers?

title: Publicis to Buy Kekst Public Relations Firm
description: Publicis Groupe, the large advertising conglomerate, said Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire Kekst & Company, a public relations firm based in New York that has been behind the scenes of some of the largest and most contested takeovers in history.

title: Judge Rejects Bushs View on Wiretaps
description: WASHINGTON  A federal judge in California said Wednesday that the wiretapping law established by Congress was the exclusive means for the president to eavesdrop on Americans, and he rejected the governments claim that the presidents constitutional authority as commander in chief trumped that law.

title: Frances Terrorism Strategy Faulted
description: PARIS  Frances much-praised system of using sweeping arrests and aggressive interrogations and prosecutions to combat terrorism prevents suspects from receiving a fair trial, according to a human rights report released Wednesday.

title: Dont Teach Our Children Crime
description: Under the Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention Act of 1974, the states agreed to humanize their often Dickensian juvenile justice systems in exchange for increased federal aid. This promising arrangement collapsed in the 1990s during hysteria about an adolescent crime wave that never materialized. The states intensified all kinds of punishments for children and sent large numbers to adult jails where, research has shown, they are more likely to be battered, traumatized and transformed into hard-core, recidivist criminals.

title: Steinbrenner Swings at Struggling Offense
description: Word quickly made its way to Yankee Stadium on Wednesday that Hank Steinbrenner, the teams co-chairman, was displeased with the Yankees recent lackluster play, particularly on offense. The Yankees are not exactly pleased, either.

title: Corrections
description: Metro

title: A Campfire Atmosphere for Chats About Quarterly Earnings
description: Blurring or erasing the line between home and work is the idea behind Coalesse, a new division of Steelcase, the office furniture manufacturer. Its first line of furnishings, which promote a less rigid, more attractive workspace  at home or in the office  includes the Bob lounge chair (starting at $2,928), above right, and table (starting at $1,258), by PearsonLloyd Design in London.

title: Another Chinese Athlete Is Barred for Life After Drug Test
description: For the second time in less than a week, Chinese authorities announced that one of their Olympic athletes had tested positive for a banned substance and was subsequently barred from his sport for life.

title: Catholic Aid for Abortion Creates Stir in Virginia
description: The Roman Catholic bishop of Richmond, Va., apologized this week after workers from a Catholic organization helped a teenager in its care have an abortion.

title: India, the Guru Chants
description: AT the finale of the Armani mens wear presentation in Milan 10 days ago, the lights in the theater suddenly went dark. When they flashed on again, the runway was filled with models striking poses in the Indian-inspired dhotis, band-collared jackets and vivid silks that were a major theme of the collection. Out went the lights again as the models hustled to get into yoga poses on the floor. When the illumination returned, all the pretties were facing the head of the runway, where Giorgio Armani was bathed in a pool of light, arms raised as if he were a fashion guru.

title: Charges Against Ex-A.I.G. Executive Dropped
description: Federal prosecutors have dropped criminal charges against a former executive at AIG Global Investment in connection with a supposed scheme to bribe Azerbaijan officials over the privatization of the State Oil Company of the Azerbaijan Republic.

title: Price of Oil Rises Again, Rattling the Markets
description: HOUSTON  A sharp increase in oil prices on Wednesday sent shudders through anxious financial markets already worried about the prospect of a global economic slowdown.

title: Chinese Tennis No Longer Overlooks Zheng
description: SHANGHAI  As a child athlete, Zheng Jie was always looked down upon  literally  for her diminutive size, passed by in favor of the taller, faster girls that Chinas tennis establishment thought were the answer to the burgeoning arms race in the womens game, where power and size have been the trends for a generation.

title: The Quad Countdown: No. 57 Nevada
description: Location: Reno, Nev.

title: New Health Reform Group to Spend $40 Million
description: It could be a version of the Harry and Louise television commercial that helped kill Hillary Rodham Clintons health care plan in 1994, only this time, it will be in favor of reform.

title: Hoff and Phelps Swim Ahead of the Competition
description: Katie Hoff set an American record in the 200-meter individual medley and Michael Phelps won the 200-meter butterfly at the United States Olympic trials.

description: Todays vocabulary lesson, from Wikipedia:

title: Disturbing the Peace
description: Flipping through the coming weekends Book Review, youll find a quadrant of faces  two pairs, each featuring a mug shot and a present-day photograph. The images are from Breach of Peace: Portraits of the 1961 Mississippi Freedom Riders, by Eric Etheridge (Atlas, $45), a book chronicling a remarkable moment in civil rights history that merits a few more words than the 30 we were able to give it in print.

title: The Sunny Side of the Street Has a Cul-de-Sac
Correction
description: An earlier version of the article referred to the author as a professor of mathematics. He is in fact a visiting professor of mathematics at the California Institute of Technology.

title: Drake & Scull Plans $326 Million I.P.O.
description: Drake & Scull International plans to raise $326 million for regional expansion and acquisitions from a Dubai initial public share sale this month, Bloomberg News reported.

title: ForeScout Brings in $8 Million from Previous Investors
description: ForeScout Technologies has raised $8 million from previous investors, Venture Beat reported. The firm makes a security platform combining clientless network access control and intrusion prevention, and saw 80 percent growth last year.

title: Highbridge Said to Seek $1 Billion for Fund
description: Hedge fund Highbridge Capital Management is attempting to raise $1 billion for a fund focused on buying bank assets that have been pummeled by the credit crisis, The New York Post reported citing an unnamed investor who was considering committing funds.

title: More Firms Pull Asian I.P.O.s as Markets Slide
description: Two more firms shelved plans for initial public offerings in Asia, adding further gloom to a market which recently showed signs of a revival after a dismal start to the year. The news comes on the heels of the shelving of Koreas SK C&Cs potential $1.2 billion I.P.O. due to averse market conditions.

title: Korean IT Firm Cancels Stock Offering
description: SK C&C, a provider of information technology services that is part of Koreas SK conglomerate, has withdrawn its initial public offering, citing weak stock market conditions. The choppy markets have contributed to a sharp decline in the volume of new listings across Asia in the first half, Finance Asia reported.

title: In Turnabout, Russia to Allow Permits for BP Workers
description: In a sign of apparent backpedaling by officials here, the Russian government said on Wednesday that it would expedite work permits for the chief executive of a BP joint venture, and five other senior staff members.

description: Federal prosecutors have dropped criminal charges against a former executive at AIG Global Investment in connection with a supposed scheme to bribe Azerbaijan officials over the privatization of the State Oil Company of the Azerbaijan Republic.

title: Taylor Nelson Rejects 4th WPP Merger Bid
description: Taylor Nelson Sofres has rejected a fourth unsolicited takeover offer from WPP Group. Taylor, the British market-research company, previously agreed to merge with Germanys GfK, Bloomberg News said.

title: I.B.M. Hops Onto Platform to End Legal Fight
description: In a deal that will eliminate a legal tussle, International Business Machines has agreed to buy Platform Solutions. The move also removes a potential competitor for I.B.M.s mainframe business.

title: MTN Mergers Fate Lies in Ambani Family Feud
description: In a high-stakes case of sibling rivalry, a consortium led by Indian billionaire Anil Ambani is considering taking a majority stake in South African mobile operator MTN to help thwart a potential legal challenge to the deal from his brother, Mukesh Ambani, The Financial Times reported.

title: Youku.com Lines Up $30 Million
description: Youku.com has secured $30 million in a financing round led by Maverick Capital, Variety reported. One of Chinas leading online video sites, it will use the funding for expansion.

title: BHP Clears Most U.S. Hurdles in Rio Tinto Pursuit
description: BHP Billiton said on Thursday that U.S. antitrust authorities had largely cleared its effort to acquire rival Rio Tinto for $170 billion.

title: London Theater Journal: You Scream, They Jump Higher at Into the Hoods
description: After the usual announcement had been made about shutting off cell phones, the sweatsuit-clad man on the stage of the Novello Theater told the audience  no, commanded it  to yell their heads off as often as possible. I want you guys to just lose it, said Mr. Gee, who is a poet by profession. The louder the screams, said Mr. G, the higher the dancers on stage would have to jump: It was written in the small print on the performers contracts.

title: Energy Recovery I.P.O. Excites Market
description: Energy Recovery, Julys first initial public offering, spiced up a generally barren market for new stocks on Wednesday. Shares of the company, which makes devices used in water desalination, were priced at $8.50 apiece, near the high end of the expected range of $7 to $9. They rose to $10 on the Nasdaq.

title: Former Airbus Executive Placed Under Formal Investigation
description: Airbuss former chief executive, Gustav Humbert, has been placed under formal investigation as part of a probe into allegations of insider trading at European aerospace group EADS, a Paris judicial source told Reuters on Wednesday.

title: Premier May Drop Just Group Bid
description: Premier Investments may drop its A$809 million ($778 million) hostile takeover bid for Australian specialty clothing retailer Just Group after the latter cut earnings forecasts, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Endeavour to Get Boost from Barclays
description: In a bid to repair its reputation following a 40 percent loss on its $1 billion Endeavour Fund, Endeavour Capital will launch a new fund with a little help from Barclays, The Wall Street Journal reported citing people familiar with the matter.

title: Talking Deals in a Rough Market
description: Whats on the minds of deal-makers in these tough times?

title: American, B.A., Iberia Said to Explore Joint Venture
description: AMRs American Airlines, British Airways and Iberia are gearing up to apply for antitrust immunity in order to form a joint venture that could create a trans-Atlantic aviation giant, The Financial Times reported.

title: Morgan Stanley to Sell More of MSCI Stake
description: Morgan Stanley will sell half its remaining stake in MSCI, a company best known for its international stock indexes that went public last year, for about $850 million, The Financial Times reported.

description: From The Onion:

title: Markets Still Prove Inhospitable to Capital Raising
description: As companies like Taylor Wimpey are forced to abandon necessary fundraising efforts, some analysts told The Telegraph that the equity markets are being rocked by the worst conditions in 20 years.

title: ABN Amro Units Sold to Deutsche Bank
description: The Belgian-Dutch financial services group Fortis will sell about 10 percent of ABN Amros Dutch operations to Deutsche Bank for 709 million euros ($1.12 billion).

title: Weather Channel Sale Prospects Said to Clear Up Soon
description: Landmark Communicationsis expected to announce the sale of The Weather Channel to a group made up of NBC Universal, Blackstone Group and Bain Capital within two days, Reuters reported citing unnamed sources.

title: Private Equity Circling Huawei Unit
description: Bain Capital, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Silver Lake and the buyout arm of Goldman Sachs are among the private equity funds that have made it to the next round of bidding for a significant stake in the mobile services unit of Chinas Huawei, The Financial Times reported, citing people familiar with the auction.

title: Microsoft, Yahoo Mull Media Partner Options: Sources
description: Microsoft and Yahoo have been holding separate talks with other potential media partners after their negotiations with each other broke down, Reuters reported citing unnamed sources.

title: Morgan Stanleys Shapiro to Retire
description: The head of Morgan Stanleys commodities trading shop is stepping down, The New York Post reported. John Shapiro, who helped launch Morgans energy-trading operation, has told executives he plans to retire at the end of the year.

description: Carl C. Icahn has hit a bump along the hedge-fund road.

description: Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Deutsche Bank appear to have benefited as hedge funds shift their prime-brokerage business in a flight to quality.

description: As the one-year anniversary of Hexion Specialty Chemicals bid for Huntsman nears, the union of two large chemical makers is close to collapse.

description: Despite a declaration by UBS chairman that the Swiss bank is done raising capital, the firm may post an additional $6.9 billion in write-downs and need to seek more funds, a Citigroup analyst wrote on Thursday.

title: The Early Word: Shake-Up or Gear-Up?
description: No matter how his campaign characterizes it  one adviser called it an example of growing pains  Senator John McCains decision to change the leadership structure of his presidential bid puts him on an altered course that could affect the outcome in November.

description: Samuel Israel III, the fugitive hedge fund fraudster, was on the phone with his mother just before turning himself in to the police on Wednesday.

title: Higher Gas Prices and Tolls Cut Congestion
description: Soaring gas prices and higher tolls seem to be doing for traffic in New York what Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs ambitious congestion pricing was supposed to do: reducing the number of cars clogging the citys streets and pushing more people to use mass transit.

title: Fire Under North Pole Ice  More Views
description: Its worth posting the voices of a few more scientists to address persistent questions here about a possible connection between retreating Arctic Ocean sea ice and seabed volcanic activity two miles below  including a Vesuvius-size eruption in 1999.

description: Harold McGee is the author of On Food & Cooking: The Science & Lore of the Kitchen; he writes a column, The Curious Cook, for The Times.

description: Penn National Gaming said Thursday that it has terminated its $6.1 billion sale to two private equity firms, after agreeing that completing the deal would not be possible without a lengthy litigation process.

title: Call It By Its Name
description: Christopher Hitchens agreed to let himself be waterboarded and then wrote about it for Vanity Fair. The headline: Believe Me, Its Torture. (Vanity Fairs Web site also posts the video of Hitchens being waterboarded.)

description: One clear lesson can be drawn from Wednesdays brazen rescue in Colombia: The warning to beware of heavy machinery while on certain prescription drugs also applies to the arrival of extraordinarily good news.

description: This looks like it will be a busy and interesting weekend in England. Ive been in the paddock a bare 2 hours or so and already there have been three pieces of interesting, if not entirely unexpected news.

description: Last week DealBook met Joshua Persky, an out-of-work investment banker, who had become so frustrated in his six-month job search that he decided to get a little creative. He stood on a street corner in Midtown Manhattan for five days handing out resumes wearing a sandwich board that said, Experienced MIT Grad For Hire.

description: There has been some speculation recently about what is being called an internal Facebook valuation  a value the company has assigned to its own common stock that is dramatically lower than the $15 billion valuation set so publicly last year by Microsofts investment.

title: Recipes of the Day: Slow-Grilled Chicken With Lemon and Chipotle-Peach Salsa
description: One of the potential downsides of hosting a Fourth of July party in the backyard is that the griller may have less fun than everyone else. Its not that grilling isnt enjoyable; but sometimes theres too much fussing going on in front of that grill. This is a recipe that requires minimal effort, and theres almost no risk of incinerating the meat.

title: The Safest Places to Drive
description: The July Fourth weekend is often one of the deadliest in terms of car accidents, but some towns are safer than others. A new report compiled by insurance giant Allstate has ranked the car safety of various towns compared to national accident rates.

title: Summer Reading
description: BAGHDAD  If your reading preferences lean towards something more serious than the latest paperback thriller, you might want to consider these non-fiction books on Iraq. The following list, culled in part from The New York Times annual list of 100 notable books, is recommended reading for an understanding of Iraqs history, current events inside the country and the American war.

title: The Save of Euro 2008: Domenech Keeps His France Job
description: Frances Euro 2008 postmortem is over. Seventeen days after their dismal campaign ground to halt  17 days of rumors and speculation  the French Football Federation voted on the future of manager Raymond Domenech. And with 18 of 19 ballots cast in favor, Domenech somewhat miraculously kept his job.

title: Getting Real
description: Bill Harley, the children's singer-storyteller whose recordings once provided the in-car soundtrack for most of our family vacations, will be in Washington, D.C., next week.  Looks like I may be going alone.  Julia is at sleepaway camp, and Emilie will be in day camp. Much as she regrets it, she doesn't think she can give up a half day of painting pottery for the experience of walking down memory lane with Mom.  Funny how you cling to your children's memories long after they've moved on.   In the back of my closet, I have a box filled with baby and toddler clothes that I will never give away. I have our board book copies of "The Runaway Bunny" and "Miffy Goes to School," and the pajamas and bathrobe  elastic waistband busted, terrycloth threadbare  that I bought for my first time on the maternity ward.   I often grow impatient with the girls for holding onto every scrap of paper that crosses their desks at school. I (secretly) plot ways to get rid of art projects, I throw out the birthday cards from not-so-good friends; I made Julia, recently, banish all her postcards and brochures and playbills into a folder I instructed her to label "Momentoes." (I also dictated the spelling.)   And yet, as a "joke," I recently ordered a copy of Sesame Street's "1 2 3 Count With Me" DVD because I realized I could no longer recall all the words to the numbers song sung by The Count.  "The Counting," Julia used to call him, when I used to sing her his song, on rainy days, pushing her ahead of me on a kickboard at the public pool, at a time when nearly her whole body fit on a kickboard.   The girls think it's pretty weird that I bought myself a Sesame Street DVD. They don't remember the video of it that they once had, because it had a European format and we'd had to give it away when we moved to the U.S. from France. The most painful thing about that move was the sense that we were leaving Julia's early childhood and Emilie's babyhood behind. It plunged me into something like a state of mourning. Trying to fall asleep, I would replay in my head our final days in Paris, the stroller moving up and down the sidewalks curbs, Emilie on her back looking up at the trees in the Champ de Mars while Julia stood behind her on one of those little platforms that siblings were always riding on there. With time, the mournful feeling faded. My sense of where our life was located changed. But there was no denying that that particular moment in our life was forever gone.  How cruel it is, the way children grow up.  I used to hate it, starting back around the time that I was 11, like Julia, when my father would fall into fond remembrances about my toddler years.   "Don't you remember ?" he would ask with a pained voice, a strained look about the eyes, the knowledge temporarily forgotten that (as he would recall himself to say, seconds later) you can't really remember things from before around the age of three.  "Pity," he would say.  What was the pity? I wanted to live in the present.   When I went away to college, my mother put all the stuffed animals I'd once kept on my bed in an old suitcase. She showed them to me proudly when I came home on break.  "What do you want me to do with them?" I asked.  "I don't know " she said. "I thought you might want to  look at them, or something."  I did not want to see them. Because they looked old, and  it pains me even now to say it  ugly.   "Once you are Real you can't become unreal again. It lasts for always, " the Skin Horse says in The Velveteen Rabbit.     " You become. It takes a long time. That's why it doesn't happen often to people who break easily, or have sharp edges, or who have to be carefully kept. Generally, by the time you are Real, most of your hair has been loved off, and your eyes drop out and you get loose in the joints and very shabby. But these things don't matter at all, because once you are Real you can't be ugly, except to people who don't understand."    The Skin Horse is a sage in the world of stuffed animals. But where humans are concerned, "Mary Poppins" got it right: there is only a set period of time in which you can hear the starlings speak, before your brain tunes out such exquisite perceptions and fixes instead on the attentional demands of everyday life.  (Interesting tidbit: I learned at M.I.T. the other week that, rather than being born with insufficiently developed neural pathways, babies are actually born with too many circuits, and normal development, in part, consists of winnowing them down. "There are too many wires  it's as though the brain has been wired for too many contingencies, and they get whittled down over time," said Jeff Lichtman, a professor of molecular and cellular biology at Harvard. "It's as though we're wired for what we could be.")   My daughters' very early years brought me a reprieve from the dead zone of adulthood. I could hear their voices in my head before they actually learned to speak; their thoughts, their "words," coming out of my mouth, were utterly real to me, as were to all of us the stories I invented about the perfidy of our then-cat, Poochie, a Mafioso-type who had to leave France under suspicion of tax improprieties.  The girls made me tell those stories over and over. And I did it for years, and made up songs, too. But then, one morning, recounting for the nth time Poochie's escapades in the Bush White House, and neglecting to look over my shoulder, I scraped the entire length of another school mom's minivan with my car.  It was a wake-up call. I had to concentrate, inhabit the present, with all its details and demands. And so I did.   Was it at that point that they started to grow up and away from me? Or was it I, trying to be a real adult, who pulled away?  The questions haunt me these days, as I sit awaiting the mail, hoping against hope for a letter home from Julia.
