Ten years later, she fell in love with her Ukrainian husband, Andrey, and the couple now have a 6-year-old son. Ms. Gavrylchenko commutes from Brooklyn on the Q train each weekday morning to her job as an office manager. Though she returns to Russia often, and her son spends every summer with relatives in Ukraine, New York City is definitely my home, she said. Ive tried living in other places.

title: Governor of Florida Is Rebuffed on Gambling
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.  The Florida Supreme Court ruled Thursday that Gov. Charlie Crist overstepped his authority when he negotiated a deal last year that let the Seminole Tribe of Florida install slot machines and offer table games like blackjack and baccarat at its Florida casinos.

title: Medication Gets Hamm a Warning
description: The gymnast Morgan Hamm, who last month made his third United States Olympic team, was given a public warning Thursday by the United States Anti-Doping Agency for using anti-inflammatory medication without receiving clearance to use that banned drug.

title: With a Trip to Philadelphia, Mets Get to See Where They Stand
description: ST. LOUIS  More than 10 weeks have passed since the Mets and the Phillies last played each other, but the stakes have not changed. Their four-game series, which begins Friday night in Philadelphia, will provide a good litmus test before the Mets close out the first half of the season. They entered Thursday trailing the Phillies by four and a half games, making it nearly impossible for them to leapfrog Philadelphia in the standings by the time the series ends Monday.

title: The Westin Verasa Napa Residences and Karina Bay Resort & Marina
description: The Westin Verasa Napa Residences

title: Fighting Inflation, Europeans Raise Rate
description: FRANKFURT  For the European Central Bank, dedicated to slaying the dragon of inflation, the moment of truth arrived Thursday. The bank raised its benchmark interest rate a quarter of a percentage point to 4.25 percent, making good on a promise last month that it would act to curb food and fuel prices.

title: Schuettler Earns Semifinal Date With Nadal
description: It took nearly 24 hours but Rafael Nadal finally learned which unlikely, stubble-faced veteran he will be facing in the Wimbledon semifinal.

title: McCain Winds Up Latin Trip in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  From the white roses he laid before a likeness of Mexicos blessed saint, the Virgin of Guadalupe, to the endorsement he gave for an overhaul of American immigration laws, Senator John McCain used a visit to Mexico on Thursday to appeal to residents of both sides of the border: Mexicans and, more urgently, their voting relatives and other Latinos in the United States.

title: Two Subplots in Guantnamos Long Legal Story
description: The long legal story of the Bush administrations effort to prosecute detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, now has two fast-moving subplots. Either one could soon write something of a final chapter.

title: The Rest of the Lincoln Center Invasion
description: Here is scheduling information about Die Soldaten and other productions of the Lincoln Center Festival. In addition to the Park Avenue Armory, at 67th Street, the site of Die Soldaten, other festival locations include Avery Fisher Hall; the Rose Theater, Broadway and 60th Street; the Gerald W. Lynch Theater at John Jay College, 899 10th Avenue, at 58th Street, Clinton; and the Stanley H. Kaplan Penthouse in the Rose Building, 165 West 65th Street, 10th floor. Tickets range from $20 to $270 ($150 to $270 for the Beckett Marathon); free tickets for preperformance symposiums at the Kaplan Penthouse are available an hour before the sessions at the Rose Building. Tickets and information: (212) 721-6500; lincolncenter.org.

title: To Improve Backdrop, Fireworks Move South
description: The city is moving the Macys Fourth of July fireworks display from Manhattan to Brooklyn this year for a simple reason: TV.

title: Mets Easily Clobber Cardinals, but Phillies Loom as True Test
description: ST. LOUIS  The Mets will begin a new series Friday against a new opponent, in a new city, and only then will they be better equipped to credit the source of their surging offense  the Cardinals pitching staff or their own rejuvenation?

title: Springtime for a New Musical
description: The Tony Award winner Idina Menzel, who spent time on Broadway in Wicked and Rent, will appear from July 11 to July 13 in a new musical at Vassar College, in the Martel Theater of the Vogelstein Center for Drama and Film. The show, Nero, is by Steven Sater and Duncan Sheik, the award-winning creators of Spring Awakening, and is part of the Powerhouse Theater summer season at the college. The cast will also feature Jeffrey Carlson (Taboo) and Lea Michele (Spring Awakening).

title: Fox Dances to the Top
description: Two hours of So You Think You Can Dance made Fox the top-rated network on Wednesday night, as 8.7 million viewers tuned in to the dancing competition from 8 to 10, according to Nielsens estimates. Although that tally was lower than CBSs rerun of Criminal Minds at 9 (9 million), Dance was by far the most popular show that night among adults 18 to 49. NBCs Baby Borrowers came closest, garnering the nights second-highest ratings in that demographic. That 9 oclock reality show, however, earned only 6.8 million total viewers. For the night, NBC was runner-up to Fox in the 18-to-49 set, and CBS finished second in total viewers. At 10 CBSs CSI: NY rerun won its time slot with 8.4 million viewers, compared with 5 million for NBCs Celebrity Circus and 5.6 million for ABCs Primetime: Crime. ABC ranked fourth for the night; it aired repeats from 8 to 10.

title: Freeing Ingrid Betancourt
description: There is every reason to celebrate the daring rescue from FARC guerrillas of the Colombian-French politician Ingrid Betancourt, three American military contractors and 11 members of the Colombian security forces. The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia still holds many more hostages. But the operation by undercover Colombian commandos  who tricked the rebels into handing over the captives without a shot  offered further evidence that the guerrilla group is in disarray.

title: Webb Moves On to 1,500-Meter Semifinals
description: EUGENE, Ore.  Before the start of the men's 400-meter final on Thursday, the miler Alan Webb approached LaShawn Merritt, a fellow Virginian, and told the quarter miler, "Run all the way through that line."

title: As Tour Nears, Cycling Attempts to Push Past Scandals
description: BREST, France  When 180 riders from 20 teams line up for the start of the 95th Tour de France in this coastal city in Brittany on Saturday, they will embark on a 2,212-mile journey of uncertainty: for themselves as riders, for the Tour as an event and for cycling as a sport.

title: Hansen Falls to Fourth in Swimming Trials Biggest Upset
description: OMAHA  As swimmers in the 200-meter breaststroke, the first event of the night session, hit the pool deck at the United States Olympic swimming trials, fans of Longhorn Aquatics in the end zone seats high above the starting blocks held up placards reading Brendan in support of Brendan Hansen, the 2004 Olympic bronze medalist and former world record holder in the event.

title: 3,344 People May Not Know Art but Know What They Like
description: If you ask 100 people to guess the number of jelly beans in a big glass jar, few will come close. The average of their guesses, however, will be almost exactly right.

title: All Wrapped Up in a Debate Over True Patriotism
description: You couldnt help but notice this taxicab as it headed across town a couple of days ago. Large American flags were clipped to the windows, one each on the drivers and passenger sides. That was eye-catching enough. Even more unusual was the driver. Around his shoulders, hed draped a shawl-size American flag. You dont see that every day.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Wednesday about a legal victory for Richard A. Grasso, former chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, misstated, in some copies, the total amount he was paid. It was $139.5 million, not $187.5 million. The article also misidentified, in one reference, the court that dismissed the final two claims in a lawsuit challenging his pay package. It is the New York State Supreme Court, Appellate Division  not the New York State Court of Appeals. And the article misspelled part of the name of the law firm representing Mr. Grasso. It is Williams & Connolly, not Connelly.

title: Footnotes
description: Noah Haidle, Liz Flahive and the Pulitzer Prize winner David Lindsay-Abaire are the first playwrights to receive three-year grants from the Bank of America to write plays for the Manhattan Theater Club. ...The newest members of the Musicians Hall of Fame will include Booker T. and the MGs, the Memphis Horns and the Muscle Shoals Rhythm Section, the musician and producer Al Kooper, the producer Billy Sherrill and Buddy Hollys band, the Crickets. ... This summer there will be two Spiegeltents at the South Street Seaport. One will hold Dsir, a theatrical circus premiere, while the other will feature the return of Absinthe, a cabaret show that appeared in 2006. The shows runs from Aug. 6 to Nov. 2. ... Eddie Vedder of Pearl Jam is going on a solo tour, beginning Aug. 1, that includes Boston, Chicago, Milwaukee, Montreal, Newark, New York, Toronto and Washington. Liam Finn is the opening act. ... Political Idol, a spoof of the upcoming presidential election, returns to the Triad Theater for a four-week run on July 23. In this updated version, Barack Obama and John McCain hold auditions to select vice presidential running mates.

title: Baseball Delayed Tests for Half of 04
description: A high-ranking official of Major League Baseball provided inaccurate information to investigators the sport had hired to look into the use of performance-enhancing drugs, according to letters made public Thursday.

title: An American Nest Returns to Its Historic Perch in Germany
description: BERLIN  When the new United States Embassy opens here on Friday it will mark the end not only of nearly four years of construction, but also of the final chapter in more than a decade of an often bitter process between the city and American diplomats, punctuated in the final stages by hard jabs from local architecture critics.

title: Independence Day
description: NEW YORK

title: A Hand From a Fan That Isnt a Problem
description: The baseball fans who have earned 15 minutes of fame by stretching out a hand in the middle of a game make for a list of rogues and walking curses, depending on your point of view.

title: Encore, Director
description: George Manahan, below, has renewed his contract as music director of the New York City Opera through 2012. Mr. Manahan began in the post in the 1997-98 season and is now overseeing City Operas schedule for 2008-9, when he is scheduled to conduct performances of Stravinskys Rakes Progress and Brittens Death in Venice. He is scheduled to conduct Szymanowskis King Roger in the 2010-11 season.

title: Blazes in California Take a Toll on Fireworks
description: MARINA, Calif.  Lis and Robert Billingsley  retirees, volunteers and proud American Legion members  said they had exactly one word to describe sales this holiday period at the fireworks stand they run here for the Legion.

title: China Agrees to More Talks on Tibet
description: BEIJING  China agreed Thursday to hold another round of discussions with envoys of the Dalai Lama before the end of the year, but officials declined to say if the two sides made any progress after the negotiations that ended this week.

title: Copying Issue Raises Hurdle for Bush Pick
description: WASHINGTON  As chief counsel to the Senate Judiciary Committee, Michael E. ONeill helped steer the Supreme Court nominations of John G. Roberts Jr. and Samuel A. Alito Jr. through the confirmation process. An expert on judicial nominations, Mr. ONeill later spoke with pride to a legal magazine about helping place some difficult federal judicial nominees onto the lower federal courts.

title: In a Bright Side to the Slowdown, Shopping Bargains Abound
description: Anyone who has managed to forget about fuel prices long enough to enjoy a little retail therapy knows some steep discounts are available these days.

title: Children Without Childhoods
description: Notwithstanding the coyly suggestive title, Very Young Girls is very far from exploitative. Adopting a confessional, direct-to-camera interview style for most of its running time, this unvarnished vrit documentary about teenage prostitutes in New York City resolutely resists the urge to dramatize. The heartbreaking stories are drama enough.

title: CORRECTIONS: FOR THE RECORD
description: An article last Friday about a bill introduced in the New York City Council that would make it illegal to scale or jump from a building 25 feet or taller rendered incorrectly a comment from the councilman who sponsored the legislation and misstated his middle initial. He is Peter F. Vallone Jr., not Peter J., and he said, We dont want our city to become Disneyland for BASE jumpers or climbers  not base jumpers. (The acronym refers to the sport of jumping from fixed objects in four categories  buildings, antennas, spans and earth.)

title: The Brutality of War, on a Big Stage
description: A FOREST of aluminum greets a visitor to the normally cavernous drill hall of the Park Avenue Armory. The thicket of metal forms the backside of what is essentially a giant, horseshoe-shaped set of bleachers filling much of the space.

title: Outlook Darker as Jobs Are Lost
description: The nations employers eliminated tens of thousands of jobs in June for the sixth consecutive month in a steady chipping away of the work force that seems likely to leave the economy very weak through Election Day.

title: 9/11 Health Official Is Ousted
description: The federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention decided not to reappoint the official who has coordinated health programs for ground zero workers, Congressional aides who spoke with him said on Thursday.

title: Five Snubbed Runners Drop Arbitration Case
description: After threatening to take legal action to gain entry into the mens 10,000-meter run on Friday at the Olympic track and field trials, a group of athletes canceled an arbitration hearing set for Thursday afternoon. Their lawyer said they feared reprisals from the sports national governing body.

title: Lax Real Estate Decisions Hurt Starbucks
description: Starbucks wants to get back to its roots to help turn around its ailing fortunes. It brought back the pioneering chief executive Howard Schultz to run the coffee chain day to day, and it has introduced a new blend, Pike Place Roast, that harks back to the location of its first Seattle store.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Tuesday, about a promotion for Star Wars toys, misattributed a quotation about George Lucas, the creator of Star Wars, in some copies. It was Howard Roffman, president of Lucas Licensing, who said, Sometimes George works in strange ways. The comment was not by Greg Ahearn, senior vice president for marketing and e-commerce for Toys R Us in the United States.

title: The Gifts That Song Can Bring
description: So there you are, going about your life, worried about your job, or the price of gas, or whether you can afford next months health insurance premium. And then for one reason or another you come across We Are Together, a documentary about the bright-eyed, golden-voiced children who live at Agape, an orphanage in South Africa.

title: The Yankees Are Silenced, and Girardi Lets Them Hear It
description: Joe Girardi and his coaches tore into their players after a lifeless 7-0 loss to the Boston Red Sox Thursday night. Girardi, the first-year manager of the Yankees, closed the clubhouse doors for 31 minutes, three times the allotted period for cooling off, yet the steam seemed to still be rising from his crewcut as he marched to the interview room.

title: The Nuts and Bolts of an Antiquing Trip
description: Rhinebeck and Hyde Park are a two-hour drive from Manhattan, on the Palisades Parkway and the New York State Thruway. Hudson is a half-hour or so north of Rhinebeck or, straight from Manhattan, a two-hour drive on the Thruway and the Taconic State Parkway.

title: When Cash Conquers All, Who Cares About Love?
description: Distilling the essence of the sleazy reality game show: thats both the joke and the touch of genius in I Love Money, which begins Sunday on VH1. (Its already available at vh1.com.) The show brings together 17 veterans of this channels booze-and-silicone-soaked hook-up competitions Flavor of Love, Rock of Love and I Love New York and puts them in a Mexican beach house to compete for the only thing that really matters: cash, in this case a check for $250,000.

title: Economic Problems in Britain Mimic Those in U.S.
description: PARIS  A housing market in shambles, inflation at the highest level in years and signs that the economy is headed for, or already in, recession. Sound familiar?

title: India Curbs Corn and Steel Exports
description: India banned corn exports and curbed shipments of steel, seeking to increase domestic supplies and cool the fastest inflation in 13 years as world commodity prices soar. Indias corn ban adds to curbs on exports of rice, wheat and cooking oil as the government seeks to tame price increases that have driven interest rates to a six-year high. The nation increased corn shipments more than sixfold in the last year as the global price doubled. Shipments from India totaled a record 2.5 million tons in the year that ended June 30 as feed makers in Southeast Asia sought cheaper alternatives to supplies from the United States. Exports were 400,000 tons in the previous year.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Looking for Liberty
description: Providence, R.I.

title: And Bring the Sunscreen
description: Summer is the time to slather exposed skin with sunscreen  the thicker, the higher the S.P.F., the better. Yet consumers are confused about which sunscreens work and which could be harmful to humans and the environment. The Food and Drug Administration could help quiet this growing debate by issuing clear safety standards for sunscreens now, while the sun is shining.

title: Beyond Fear and Loathing
description: Even if Alex Gibneys new documentary, Gonzo, were not subtitled The Life and Work of Dr. Hunter S. Thompson, there would be little doubt about its subject. Thompson, who committed suicide in 2005, survives to some degree in the popular imagination because of his self-burnished reputation for wild excess. Embodied on the screen by Bill Murray (in Art Linson s underrated Where the Buffalo Roam from 1980) and Johnny Depp (in Terry Gilliams overblown Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas from 1998) and travestied as the conspiratorial Uncle Duke in Garry Trudeaus Doonesbury comic strip, Thompson remains a durable icon of countercultural bad craziness.

title: Correction: Oooooh, Canada
description: An article last Friday about the international fireworks competition at La Ronde, an amusement park in Montreal, misidentified the Metro line that includes Papineau station, a good connecting point to get to La Ronde. It is the Green Line, not the Orange.

title: A Tale of Two Minds, Spinning Out of Control
description: The talented actor Terry Kinney turns feature-film director to guide a regiment of equally appealing performers  Alan Alda, Matthew Broderick, Virginia Madsen, Lois Smith, Dylan Baker, Bobby Cannavale  through their respectable if pedestrian paces in the comedy-drama hybrid Diminished Capacity. Adapted by Sherwood Kiraly from his novel of the same title, the sleepy proceedings turn on two relatives  a Chicago newspaper editor, Cooper (Mr. Broderick), and his Missourian Uncle Rollie (Mr. Alda)  whose lives have been upended by their failing and flickering minds.

title: London Swings as a Dynamo for Selling Art
description: LONDON  The transformation of London, a sleepy backwater for two decades, into an art capital that rivals New York has never been more apparent than in this past fortnight of auctions, with record prices fetched for works by artists ranging from Monet to Francis Bacon.

title: Along the Hudson, Searching for Old
description: THERE was a hand-painted Bakelite dresser set in the prettiest soft mint green ($36). A wine rack made from an 1880s postmasters desk ($1,600). A Baltic mahogany Biedermeier cabinet and mirror ($9,500). I love country-weekend antiquing. Buying is not required but is occasionally possible.

title: Bold Colombia Rescue Built on Rebel Groups Disarray
description: BOGOT, Colombia  At 5 a.m. on Wednesday, the sun had yet to peek through the jungle canopy in this countrys Guaviare Department when the guerrillas told their captives to gather their belongings. A call had come in from a top adviser to Alfonso Cano, their new supreme commander. He said to move. Immediately.

title: From Urban Hotelier to Gentleman Farmer
description: HAVING a farm for a weekend getaway suits someone like Michael Overington, who likes nothing better than to end a full week as director of real estate and construction for the Ian Schrager Company with yet another to-do list: mowing the pasture, mending a fence, tinkering with the mechanical systems in the familys farmhouse in Frenchtown, N.J.

title: Untouchables Enjoy a Night of Fashion
description: Tabla drums warbled and lights beat down as the woman glided down the runway, her sari billowing loosely and her hair pulled tight. As fashion shows go, the sashay-spin-repeat sequence was fairly routine.

title: A New York Slice of America, July 3: 128 Riders United
description: THE R68A subway car is shiny and modern-looking, with seats in two shades of orange  few of which can be glimpsed when the car is crowded. And the second-to-last R68A of the Q train that pulled out of DeKalb Avenue at 8:27 a.m. on Thursday felt near capacity.

title: Huddled Statues, Working to Be Free
description: Eleven years ago, a woman who had immigrated from South America several years earlier went to Battery Park with her sister to see the Statue of Liberty. At her sisters urging, she brought along a Statue of Liberty costume that she made for the previous Halloween, a papier-mch mask and a canvas sheet she had sprayed green. At the park, her sister took a picture of her fully regaled, and almost immediately, strangers started crowding around.

title: E.U. Hears From a Bee Gee
description: Robin Gibb, above, of the Bee Gees was one of a number of composer-songwriters who told the European Commission in Brussels on Thursday that standardizing music royalties across Europe could hurt musicians and the songs they write, The Associated Press reported. The commission, the executive arm of the European Union, is finishing an antitrust investigation into how royalties are collected. Mr. Gibb, representing the European Composer and Songwriter Alliance, argued that if major online services are able to negotiate lower regionwide fees, artists may get less for their songs despite seeing them distributed more widely. On a fundamental scale its a human right that someone who writes a piece of work should have control of it, he said in a statement, adding that a change could discourage newer songwriters from producing tomorrows hits.

title: Reprising a Sister Act After a Five-Year Wait
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Standing on the now-patchy grass of Centre Court on Thursday and smiling at her family in the players box with delight and a bit of relief in her eyes, Serena Williams was also looking at the only woman left who can stop her from winning a third Wimbledon title.

title: Storm-Tossed Visionary of Light
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Arts J. M. W. Turner is a beast of a show. With nearly 150 works in oil and watercolor spanning more than half a century, it will either win you over or wear you out. Or it will alternate, gallery by gallery, or wall by wall, as the art swings between overblown and moving, inspired and mechanical.

title: Jewish Museum Gets $1 Million
description: Steven Spielbergs Righteous Persons Foundation is giving $1 million to the National Museum of American Jewish History in Philadelphia to build a five-story building in the citys historic section. Mr. Spielberg helped establish the Righteous Persons Foundation in 1994 after directing his Oscar-winning Holocaust film, "Schindlers List."

title: American Flags as Big as Fields
description: On the field before the All-Star Game, Major League Baseball plans to assemble the largest gathering of Hall of Fame players in baseball history. And as fans salute their heroes, the former players will join the crowd in saluting the American flag  one that is roughly 75 feet by 150 feet, as long as a 15-story building is tall, spread horizontally over the Yankee Stadium turf.

title: Few Emblems of Americas Remain on Their Avenue
description: The Americas have nearly vanished from Avenue of the Americas.

title: Fund Manager Turned Fugitive Is Sent to Prison
description: Samuel Israel III, the convicted hedge fund manager who fled after faking a suicide last month, went to prison on Thursday, 24 days late.

title: Penn National Gaming Cancels Its Sale to Private Equity Firms
description: Another big corporate buyout fell apart Thursday, as Penn National Gaming announced that it had terminated its $6.1 billion sale to two private equity firms.

title: Britains Services Sector Contracted in June
description: Britains services sector contracted last month by the most since October 2001 and banks said they would curb lending further in the third quarter. An index based on sales and business conditions at about 700 service companies fell to 47.1 in June from 49.8 a month earlier, the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply said. A reading below 50 shows contraction. The figures are really bad news, said Alex Garatti, British economist for Natixis, after the services figures were released. It shows the U.K. is really suffering from tightening financial conditions and the slowdown in housing. A separate Bank of England survey showed that banks planned to reduce the availability of credit to consumers and businesses this quarter.

title: Criminal Charges Against Continental in Deadly Concorde Crash
description: PARIS  A prosecutor said Thursday that Continental Airlines and two of its employees had been ordered to stand trial on involuntary manslaughter charges related to the crash of a Concorde supersonic airliner in 2000 near Paris in which 113 people died.

title: The College Reunion, Where Time Leaps by Decades
description: IT was 2 in the morning as I padded down the dormitorys hall in my flip-flops, catching a whiff of stale beer and moldy carpet in the air. In the brightly lit coed bathroom, a classmate wearing boxers and little else was brushing his teeth. It was an awkward moment. Not because of his state of undress, but because it was 20 years since wed turned our tassels to the left side of the mortarboard, and he wasnt wearing his name tag. I was at a loss.

title: Corrections
description: Front Page

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in some editions on Thursday about the halting or slowing of work at construction sites in New York City because of a strike by concrete-truck drivers misidentified, in some copies, the site described in the first three paragraphs, where workers had been ready to pour concrete for the fifth floor before the strike and the number of workers had fallen to 50 from 75. The project is a luxury condominium building in Lower Manhattan, not a new building for New York Law School. (That project, which has also been delayed because of the strike, is across the street from the residential building).

title: The Meaning of a Day
description: It makes sense to think of the Fourth of July as the start of a season and not as a one-day holiday moored off by itself. But it takes the clat of a single, explosive day to capture the sense of release, the promise, of the Declaration of Independence.

title: U.S. Pushes U.N. Sanctions on Zimbabwe and Mugabe
description: UNITED NATIONS  Seeking to force President Robert Mugabe into negotiations with the opposition, the United States on Thursday formally proposed United Nations Security Council sanctions on Zimbabwe. The proposed sanctions include an international arms embargo and punitive measures against the 14 people the United States deemed most responsible for undermining Zimbabwes presidential election through violence.

title: Renewing a Rivalry While Looking Up at the Rays
description: It looked so good on the season schedule  four straight dates in early July, BOS@NYY. Mark it down. Save the date. Be there. Why then did it feel so anticlimactic Thursday night  at least judging by the feeble efforts from one side?

title: Theater Listings
description: DAMN YANKEES Since 1994 New York City Centers Encores! series has celebrated lesser-known musicals like Face the Music and Juno through concert readings. Last year Encores! added its first summer show, a better-known musical in a fully staged production for a longer run, presenting Gypsy. Clearly the experiment paid off: Gypsy reopened on Broadway in March and recently won three Tony Awards.

title: Victor Remer, Childrens Aid Society Leader, Dies at 88
description: Victor Remer, a social worker who as executive director of the Childrens Aid Society for 15 years in the 1960s and 70s pushed the agency in grittier, more urgent directions, including addressing the problems of young people convicted of minor crimes, died on June 17 at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.

title: Inexperience May Feed the Bubbles
description: It has long been widely believed  at least among some experienced investors  that it is the inexperienced ones who are most likely to get swept into the euphoria of a bubble and to buy when prices are the most absurd.

title: New and Not Improved
description: Senator Barack Obama stirred his legions of supporters, and raised our hopes, promising to change the old order of things. He spoke with passion about breaking out of the partisan mold of bickering and catering to special pleaders, promised to end President Bushs abuses of power and subverting of the Constitution and disowned the big-money power brokers who have corrupted Washington politics.

title: The Boss Recalls a Fortuneteller
description: Over here on E Street, we will miss her, Bruce Springsteen wrote on his Web site (brucespringsteen.net) about Madam Marie, a New Jersey boardwalk fortuneteller he made famous in his 1973 song 4th of July, Asbury Park (Sandy), The Associated Press reported. Marie Castello, who was 93, died June 27. Id sit across from her on the metal guardrail bordering the beach and watched as she led the day trippers into the small back room where she would unlock a few of the mysteries of their future, Mr. Springsteen wrote. She always told me mine looked pretty good  she was right.

title: Target: Barack Obama. Strategy: What Day Is It?
description: Despite a three-month head start, Senator John McCain has struggled to solidify lines of attack against Senator Barack Obama for the general election, Republican operatives say and some of his own advisers acknowledge, running into problems that bedeviled Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons primary campaign against Mr. Obama.

title: 9 Terrorism Suspects Detained in Indonesia After a Raid Uncovers Bombs
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesian police transferred nine terrorism suspects, bound and wearing black hoods, to the capital, Jakarta, on Thursday after their arrest in southern Sumatra.

title: Trial Ordered in Concorde Crash That Killed 113
description: PARIS  A prosecutor said Thursday that Continental Airlines and two of its employees had been ordered to stand trial on involuntary manslaughter charges related to the crash of a Concorde supersonic airliner in 2000 near Paris in which 113 people died.

title: Roves Third Term
description: Al Gore never claimed that he invented the Internet. Howard Dean didnt scream. Hillary Clinton didnt say she was staying in the race because Barack Obama might be assassinated. And Wesley Clark didnt impugn John McCains military service.

title: Global Markets Fall as Oil Hits New High
description: PARIS -- Global stocks fell Thursday as the price of oil rose above $145 a barrel for the first time.

title: Age and John McCain, All Kidding Aside
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinas Legacy: Let a Million Museums Bloom
description: XIAN, China  This year, in a drive to promote awareness of Chinas national heritage, the government introduced a free-admission policy at the countrys public museums. Officially the cultural establishment greeted the news with smiles.

title: Flights Begin From China to Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  The first nonstop, cross-strait weekend flights from China landed in Taiwan on Friday morning, in the latest breakthrough in cross-strait relations that are rapidly warming under the islands new president, Ma Ying-jeou.

title: No-Tears Visiting
description: YOU love your country house. You love to entertain. For the longest time youve been inviting your nephew and his family to spend a weekend with you. He has finally set a date to visit  with his wife and two children, an 18-month-old girl and a 4-year-old boy. Reality starts to set in as you look around at all the breakables, the unfenced pond and the balcony with just one metal bar for a railing.

title: Japan Sees a Chance to Promote Its Energy-Frugal Ways
description: KUMAGAYA, Japan  With its towering furnaces and clanging conveyer belts carrying crushed rock, Taiheiyo Cements factory looks like an Industrial Revolution relic. But it is actually a model of modern energy efficiency, harnessing its waste heat to generate much of its own electricity.

title: 2 Supervisors Are Arrested After Sweep at Meat Plant
description: Two supervisors at a kosher meatpacking plant in Iowa where hundreds of illegal immigrants were rounded up in May were arrested Thursday on criminal immigration charges.

title: Italy: Census of Gypsies Raises Fears
description: The governments plans to fingerprint Gypsies living in camps in Italy, including children, drew criticism from a Catholic human rights group in Rome that warned that it would set a dangerous precedent. We are very worried about discrimination according to race or religion, said Marco Impagliazzo, president of the group, the Community of SantEgidio. title: Plan to Film at Jail Is Denied

The county is under a federal court order to improve conditions at the jail. Dallas County Sheriff Lupe Valdez, who had approved of the documentary, said she was disappointed. We had hoped that the documentary would be a great opportunity to make the jail more transparent, she said in a statement. The jurors said their investigation into the clinic of the doctor, George Tiller, right, did not yield sufficient evidence of a crime, but they noted that a review of medical records revealed a number of questionable late-term abortions that might not have met a common interpretation of the words in state law, which limits abortions of viable fetuses to pregnant women who would otherwise face substantial and irreversible impairment of a major bodily function. description: There was an Independence Day long ago when little Antoinette Tolas pedaled her decorated bicycle down Victory Boulevard with the rest of the kindergarten students from Public School 26 in Travis, a nook of a town on the western shore of Staten Island.

title: To Label or Not to Label
description: In the eyes of J. K. Rowling, labeling books for appropriate ages doesnt make sense. The author, famous for the Harry Potter series, signed the online petition of NotoAgeBanding.org, adding her name to a list of those of other well-known childrens writers, including Anthony Horowitz, Terry Pratchett, Alan Garner, Quentin Blake, Anne Fine, Jacqueline Wilson and Michael Rosen, The Guardian of London reported. The petition asserts that an age-guidance figure on childrens books is ill conceived, damaging to the interests of young readers and highly unlikely to make the slightest difference to sales. Research commissioned by the Childrens Book Group of the Publishers Association two years ago, however, suggested that 86 percent of consumers favored such labeling.

title: Questions of Size and Taste for Queens Houses
description: To the Bukharian Jews of Central Asia, a big house is an essential tradition: a place to shelter multiple generations, to hold large parties, memorials and holiday dinners, to reaffirm a communitys unity.

title: In Montana, Obama Tries to Rally Support on Iraq
description: BUTTE, Mont.  As he finished a weeklong tour of states that have voted Republican in recent presidential races, Senator Barack Obama said on Friday that the nation had hit a crossroads and weve got to make a fast turn, urging voters at an Independence Day celebration to support his candidacy if they wanted to end the war in Iraq.

title: Emergency at Pompeii
description: The Italian government declared a yearlong state of emergency at Pompeii on Friday to try to rescue one of the worlds most important cultural treasures from decades of neglect, The Associated Press reported. The government said in a statement that it would appoint a special commissioner for Pompeii, the Roman city buried by an eruption of Mount Vesuvius in A.D. 79 and now a Unesco World Heritage site. Archaeologists and art historians have long complained about the poor upkeep of the Pompeii treasures. Some 2.5 million tourists visit Pompeii each year, and many have expressed shock at the conditions.

title: Free-Spirited Jennings Is a Serious Contender in the 1,500
description: EUGENE, Ore.  Gabe Jennings, whose skill as a middle-distance runner has been matched, some say undermined, by his eccentricity, appears to have returned to the form that produced a first-place finish in the 1,500 meters at the 2000 Olympic trials.

title: Yankees Call the Shots on a Homer Promotion
description: David Ortiz of the Red Sox was supposed to be the only competitor in the Call Your Shot promotion in the Home Run Derby during the All-Star Game festivities. But the Yankees balked at the notion that one of the marquee players from their rivals would be given the chance to imitate Babe Ruth at Yankee Stadium, so the format was changed.

description: EUGENE, Ore.  Kara Gouchers emotions hit two extremes in the span of two races Friday night at the United States Olympic track and field trials.

title: Fires on Second Front Force Californians Out
description: LOS ANGELES  A fast-moving fire in Goleta, Calif., just north of Santa Barbara, has forced nearly 2,000 residents from their homes, as a shift in winds and the availability of timber fuel combined on Friday to trump fires to the north as the states first priority.

title: Its All in the Wood
description: What is it that makes a Stradivarius violin, below, so special? Growth rings in the wood. At least that is the latest theory of some Dutch scientists, cbcnews.ca reported. Researchers at the Leiden University Medical Center in the Netherlands who put 300-year-old Stradivarius instruments through a CT scanner, published their research in the online journal plosone.org. Many music lovers believe that the violins constructed by Antonio Stradivari and Guarneri del Ges produce the best tonal expressiveness and projection. Despite three centuries of technological advances, modern violin makers have been unable to duplicate the sound. The scientists, who tweaked a computer program used to analyze scans measuring lung density in patients with emphysema, said the sound difference may result from important variations in wood over the centuries.

title: Coda Is Heard for a Daytime Jazz Club in Harlem
description: Gordon Polatnicks business plan, he concedes, was heavy on the things that fueled his daydreams and too light on almost everything else.

description: EUGENE, Ore.  For all the excitement generated by the 100 meters during the first weekend of the United States Olympic track and field trials, the mens 200 meters holds even bigger potential for this weekend. It kicked off with the first round Friday night, but the real fireworks will come after the ones from July 4 have faded.

description: IF you fear losing too much in stocks and earning too little in cash or ultra-safe bonds, then high-yield corporate debt may be worth considering.

title: Need Help Finding Your Bliss? Hire a Coach
description: BOULDER, Colo.  A 43-year-old man is weary of teaching high school but has no clue how else to make a living. A 67-year-old man wants to leave banking but does not want to retire before leaving a more positive mark on the world. A 52-year-old woman is an emergency room doctor who loves her work but pines for more downtime.

title: Obama Sets Off a Debate on Ties Between Religion and Government
description: On Tuesday, Senator Barack Obama did his best to reclaim for Democrats the idea of partnerships between government and grass-roots religious groups  and except for six little words he did a very smooth job.

description: SAN FRANCISCO  Gavin Newsom, the popular and telegenic mayor of San Francisco, declared this week that he was forming an exploratory committee to consider a run for governor in 2010.

description: This year, word got out about a Visa debit card aimed at people who wanted to borrow money from their 401(k) accounts. With plastic in hand, they could withdraw the funds from an A.T.M. or spend them at any merchant that accepted Visa, just as they could with a regular bank debit card.

description: WASHINGTON  Federal officials say they are preparing to propose a series of regulatory changes to enhance American competitiveness overseas, attract foreign investment and give American investors a broader selection of foreign stocks.

title: Europe Delays Decision on Mining Company Merger
description: European Union regulators extended an investigation into BHP Billitons hostile bid for the Rio Tinto Group because of serious doubts about the combination, which would control more than a third of the worlds iron ore production. The European Commission, in charge of antitrust rulings, will review the proposed $163 billion acquisition for an additional 90 working days and announce a decision by Nov. 11, it said in a statement in Brussels on Friday. The antitrust division of the United States Justice Department gave partial approval Thursday. The takeover also needs agreement from Australia and South Africa.

title: The Senate Stalls on Medicare
description: Before leaving town for the Fourth of July recess, Senate Republicans thwarted a vote on a sensible Medicare bill that would benefit doctors and patients at the expense of overpaid private health plans.

title: Flights Begin From China to Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan  The first regular nonstop weekend flights between China and Taiwan landed here Friday, in the latest breakthrough in cross-strait relations that are rapidly improving under the islands new president, Ma Ying-jeou.

title: Duhon Is Added, Signaling End for Marbury
description: Chris Duhon has agreed to a two-year deal with the Knicks, paving the way for the franchise to cut ties with Stephon Marbury, their troublesome starting point guard.

title: Colombia Releases Video of Jungle Rescue
description: BOGOT, Colombia  The captives emerged from a coca field looking confused, despondent even, as the rebels tied plastic handcuffs on their wrists before putting them on a helicopter in a video released here on Friday of the rescue this week of 15 hostages in the Colombian jungle.

title: Burial Exposes Racial Rift in Texas
description: The corpse of a white woman whose 2007 killing barely made headlines is now at the center of a peculiar racial conflict over the desegregation of the cemeteries in a rural Texas county.

title: Williamses Rivalry Is Close and Compelling, if Not Classic
description: WIMBLEDON, England  On Friday, Venus and Serena Williams were side by side on the English grass, applauding each others winners and then pirouetting in unison as they waved to the crowd after advancing to the final of the womens doubles at Wimbledon.

title: Credit Card Overhauls Seem Likely
description: Consumer advocates say regulation of the credit card industry has long been without teeth. But as card holders struggle under the weight of big balances, high interest rates and fees, their pleas to lawmakers for help may well mean that the industry will face some significant regulation by early next year.

title: Argentina Export Tax Sets Off Political Furor
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Argentinas lower house of Congress was preparing to vote late Friday night on whether to approve a government tax program for agricultural exports in the latest chapter of a bitter battle between farmers and the government of President Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner.

title: New Head of Development Bank Puts Focus on Russia
description: Western countries need to be ambitious and patient in fostering democracy in Russia and the strategic region arching from the Balkans to Central Asia, according to the new president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

title: Good Guys, Bad Guys and Spies, All Wrapped in Edutainment
description: WASHINGTON  If I told you what secret documents I had in my briefcase, I said in response to a jocular inquiry from a fellow visitor at the International Spy Museum here this week, Id have to kill you. And if I did that, I added silently, I might end up in a homicide exhibit at the National Museum of Crime & Punishment, which opened in May a few blocks away. After spending a morning there, I wasnt sure I was ready to return.

title: New York Public Library Displaying a Draft of Jeffersons Vision for the U.S.
description: One of early Americas most important documents  written in an angry frame of mind  is on display at the New York Public Library.

title: Despair Drives Suicide Attacks by Iraqi Women
description: BAQUBA, Iraq  Wenza Ali Mutlaq walked a bit uncertainly up the long street near the main government offices here on June 22, the hot wind stirring her heavy black abaya. She passed the concrete barricades put up to ward off suicide car bombers and made her way alone, almost haphazardly.

title: Ex-Guardian Must Repay $403,000 to Judges Estate
description: A Brooklyn lawyer and a onetime legal guardian to John L. Phillips Jr., the so-called kung fu judge and the owner of the Slave Theater in Bedford-Stuyvesant, has been ordered to repay the Phillips estate $403,000 that she improperly kept for herself or misused, according to a judges ruling.

title: Georgia: 2 Killed in South Ossetia
description: A firefight between Georgian troops and soldiers from the separatist province of South Ossetia left two people dead and at least 11 wounded, a spokeswoman for the separatist government said. Each side blamed the other for inciting the encounter, which occurred a day after reports that an explosion killed a police chief in South Ossetia. Georgian officials also said Thursday that Dmitry Sanakoyev, whom Georgia considers the legitimate leader of South Ossetia, narrowly escaped an assassination attempt. Russia, which backs South Ossetia, accused Georgia of escalating the conflict.

title: Jesse Helms Dies at 86; Conservative Force in the Senate
description: Jesse Helms, the former North Carolina senator with the courtly manner and mossy drawl who turned his hard-edged conservatism against civil rights, gay rights, foreign aid and modern art, died early Friday. He was 86.

title: Corrections: For the Record

title: French Women Keep Their Championship
description: France retained the European Womens Team Championship on home soil in Pau on June 27, ahead of Italy and Spain.

description: OTTAWA  Private equity buyers apparently salvaged a record $52 billion deal for Bell Canada on Friday by postponing its closing date until later this year and canceling dividend payments.

title: A Spitzer Legacy in Albany
description: It seems so long ago that Albany was agog over efforts by aides of Eliot Spitzer, then the governor, to release damaging information about taxpayer-funded travel by Joseph Bruno, then the Senate majority leader. But the investigation of this small matter has lasted longer than the participants (Mr. Spitzer resigned in March after a call-girl scandal and Mr. Bruno gave up his leadership post last month). And Troopergate has raised a troubling issue about how the state government now investigates its own.

title: Bush Welcomes 72 New U.S. Citizens

description: A Gunfighters Pledge, which will be shown on the Hallmark Channel on Saturday, is a generic western in which the hero literally wears a white hat, saves a pretty widow and seeks revenge and redemption through the barrel of a gun. Theres nothing distinctive about Pledge, but it hits enough western notes to satisfy those with an insatiable hunger for the genre.

title: On Day Care, Google Makes a Rare Fumble
description: Two months ago, Google held a series of secret focus groups with employees who have children in Googles day care facilities. The purpose was to gauge their reaction to the companys plan to raise the amount it charged for in-house day care by 75 percent.

title: As Gas Prices Soar, Elderly Face Cuts in Aid

title: Congolese Politician Goes Before International Court
description: THE HAGUE  When Jean-Pierre Bemba, a rich and powerful Congolese politician, visited his family in Brussels in late May, he had no inkling that he would be grabbed by the Belgian police, thrown in jail and put before an international tribunal.

title: A Red Carpet for Abba
description: All four members of the group Abba appeared together in Stockholm on Friday at the Swedish premiere of the film Mamma Mia!, delighting fans with their first public appearance together in years, Reuters reported. Benny Andersson, Bjorn Ulvaeus, Anni-Frid Lyngstad and Agnetha Faltskog walked down the red carpet at a movie theater to the cheers of several thousand fans.The movie follows Mamma Mia! the musical, which toured worldwide and features 22 Abba songs, including Dancing Queen, Take a Chance on Me and The Winner Takes It All. The four, who shot to fame when they won the 1974 Eurovision Song Contest, last performed together in public in 1986, although there were reports that they sang together at a private birthday party for a friend in 1999.

title: Grants to Compose
description: The Signature Theater in Arlington, Va., has received a $300,000 grant to commission musicals by young composers, The Washington Post reported. This Shen Family Foundation donation follows a $1 million gift two years ago. Its hard for people to find a place to work on their musicals, said Eric Schaeffer, Signatures artistic director. Signature will establish a Next Generation program that gives each composer a $25,000 commission and a summer-workshop production of the musical in progress. The workshops will begin next July.

The sparse furnishings in the front rooms are covered by a patina of cigarette ash, gobs of dried paint and coffee cans filled with paintbrushes. Hundreds of paintings lean against walls and are piled against the porch windows.

title: A Musical Missionary Returns, Joyful Spirit Intact
description: At 86 the visionary musical sage Jon Hendricks, who along with Ella Fitzgerald and Eddie Jefferson originated the jazz style called vocalese  the setting of swing and jazz instrumentals with playful scat lyrics  is as voluble as ever. Since the late 1950s, when he was a co-founder of the vocal trio Lambert, Hendricks and Ross, this verbal conjurer and scat-singing virtuoso has remained a dedicated popularizer of a form that the Manhattan Transfer refined to a high buff in which polish undercuts raw spontaneity.

title: Another Santana Start Wasted, This One in Phillies Last At-Bat
description: PHILADELPHIA  Johan Santana had thrown 95 pitches through eight innings against the Phillies on Friday night, and he said he was mentally and physically prepared to continue. But on a muggy night, in a tight game, against a first-place team, before a packed crowd at Citizens Bank Park, those were 95 stressful pitches, and thus too many, Manager Jerry Manuel said, for him to let Santana pitch the ninth.

title: Lost and Found
description: Lost scenes from the classic 1927 silent film Metropolis, above, were shown for the first time in decades on Thursday, The Associated Press reported. The print, which was scratched, was discovered in April in the Museum of Cinema in Buenos Aires. Paula Felix-Didier, the museums director, said it was the only copy of the German director Fritz Langs complete film. This is the version Fritz Lang intended, said Martin Koerber, a curator at the Deutsche Kinemathek film museum in Berlin. Metropolis, written by Lang and his actress wife, Thea von Harbou, depicts a 21st-century world divided between a class of underworld workers and the thinkers above who control them. Soon after its initial release, distributors cut Langs three-and-a-half-hour masterpiece into a shorter version.

title: Storm Strengthens in Atlantic
description: Tropical Storm Bertha, the second named system of the Atlantic hurricane season, strengthened as it moved across the open ocean, officials at the National Hurricane Center in Miami said. The storm was centered about 385 miles west- southwest of the Cape Verde Islands. The system was moving west-northwest around 16 miles per hour and may move toward Bermuda over the next five days, forecasters said. Bertha is not an overly well-organized storm right now, said Ken Reeves, a meteorologist. If its ever going to affect the U.S., it wouldnt be until next weekend at the earliest. The system had sustained winds of 50 m.p.h., compared with 40 m.p.h. when it formed near the Cape Verde Islands on Thursday.

title: Film of Passing Strange
description: Spike Lee will film the Tony Award-winning musical Passing Strange, Entertainment Weekly reported on its Web site, ew.com. Mr. Lee is to film three performances of the show, featuring the singer-songwriter Stew, above left with Daniel Breaker: two with audiences and one without. The shows producers are financing the filming, and while no distribution deal has been set, there is speculation that the film will be shown on cable television. The musical centers on a young black musician who sets off on a journey to find the real after being raised in a churchgoing middle-class Los Angeles neighborhood. Passing Strange, which won the Tony for best book of a musical, is at the Belasco Theater.

description: ST. LOUIS  Two days ago, Senator Barack Obama said he had not been clear enough in explaining his Iraq policy. Today, there was a different rationale.

title: They Were Wed
description: The stories of two British women who married American soldiers of World War II, and who are members of the Astoria Crumpets, a social club for British war brides.

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu, July 6
description: On this holiday weekend, Sundays breakfast menu of talk show guests is a bit limited.

title: Mussina and Molina: Package Deal
description: The All-Star teams will be announced on Sunday, and when he spoke with Red Sox Manager Terry Francona this weekend, Yankees Manager Joe Girardi stumped for Mike Mussina.

title: Your Comments on my Truth Commission Column
description: My Sunday column argues for a Truth Commission, with subpoena power, to investigate torture, improper detention and other abuses in the aftermath of 9/11. This should not be a bipartisan commission with Democrats and Republicans, like the 9/11 Commission, but rather a non-partisan commission with prominent figures who dont have strong party ties. I would welcome a strong representation of generals, admirals and intelligence figures, along with leaders from law and other fields. Perhaps Sandra Day OConnor or Brent Scowcroft could chair it.

title: U.S. Track Trials: Gays Injury Ignites Selection Debate
description: EUGENE, Ore.  It was no wonder Dan OBrien inserted himself into the debate over how the United States picks its Olympic track and field team, considering he was the world champion in the decathlon who stayed home from the 1992 Games because he flubbed the pole vault at the trials. OBriens gaffe was even more noticeable because of the Dan & Dave advertising campaign Reebok had already launched featuring OBrien and his rival Dave Johnson.

title: Lobster Risotto
description: About 6 cups lobster stock (recipe here)

title: Lyla Bashan, Michael Andrews
description: Lyla Jamil Bashan, the daughter of the Rev. Dana E. St. Claire and the stepdaughter of the Rev. Scott K. Larson of Burbank, Calif., was married in Malibu, Calif., on Monday to Michael Richard Andrews, a son of Julie A. Andrews and Richard K. Andrews of Gilbert, Ariz. The brides mother, a minister of Maylaigh Ministries, a nondenominational religious organization in Burbank, officiated at Point Dume, overlooking the Pacific. On Friday, the brides mother led another ceremony for friends and family at Le Kliff, a restaurant in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico.

title: When Ex-Employees Vent, or Reinvent
description: AS layoffs around the country continue to make headlines, some among the newly unemployed are venting their frustrations by posting their stories and grievances online, on blogs and other Web sites. Others are using the occasion as an impetus to start their own businesses.

title: Correction: Berlin, the Big Canvas
description: An article on June 22 about the art and food scenes in Berlin referred incompletely to the artists responsible for the work Wrapped Reichstag in Berlin. While Christo started the project alone in 1971, by the time of its completion in 1995, he was also crediting his wife, Jeanne-Claude.

title: Rethink the Use of Tasers
description: To the Editor:

title: Summer Reading
description: When I was in graduate school, I dug a small garden, just some tomatoes, sweet corn, lettuce and a few other things. I intended to sit by it and do the heavy reading for my graduate work. I had grown used to books  literary criticism mostly  from which one looks up quite a lot and sees the weeds infesting the carrots and feels the need to do something. The books would drive me to the garden and the sun would drive me back to reading in the shade. That was the plan.

title: Summers Last Call
description: IN my family, there are some who practice the All Along method  Didnt get the grant? You didnt want it all along, Got dumped? We hated him all along  and whose proficiency in this method probably explains why they are nine times happier than I am. Me, I can temper  even exalt  a bad experience only by thinking of it as narrative, as story, and seeing in its grief what typifies many a good story, which is transformation.

title: Sky Lark
description: There comes a time in family life when the kids need their own rooms. One solution is to add on. Rarely, though, does your average middle-income household hire one of the worlds leading architects to do the job.

title: Letters: Smoking, Drinking, Writing, Womanizing, Smoking, Drinking . . .
description: Most people focus on the beauty and glamour of the period setting, or the smoking/drinking/sexism that seems so ancient and yet is so recent, but the greatness of Mad Men (Alex Witchel, June 22) is that people are and always will be people. You can watch a Jane Austen adaptation or a Merchant-Ivory drama and get caught up in the costumes and paraphernalia, but in truth, the fascination lies in how little is different: We still hope and long, deceive and get caught. When the newlywed Pete Campbell (Vincent Kartheiser) says he thought marriage would be magical, but instead his wife is just another stranger, he is not some 1960 period oddity; he is speaking to all of our childish desires for fulfillment without effort.

title: Are You Ready for the Next Disaster?
description: Mother Nature goes to extremes in the summer, spoiling the gift of good weather with hurricanes, heat waves, fires and floods. This year she started early. On May 2, Cyclone Nargis laid waste to large parts of Myanmar. According to the latest counts, the disaster left 2.4 million people destitute, more than 50,000 missing and at least 84,000 dead. On May 12, Chinas Sichuan Province suffered an earthquake measuring 7.9 on the Richter scale. Chinas state media reported that more than five million people lost their homes; an estimated 80,000 people, many of them children, were killed.

title: Correction
description: A review and subheading on June 22 about The Two Kinds of Decay, by Sarah Manguso, misstated the nature of the disease from which Manguso suffered. Chronic Idiopathic demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy, like Guillain-Barr syndrome, which it resembles, is a neurological disease, not a blood disease.

title: Works That Tell Stories of Indian Life and Times
description: New Narratives: Contemporary Art From India is the second such major survey to be presented at a New Jersey museum within the past year.

title: 36 Hours in Pittsburgh
description: PITTSBURGH has undergone a striking renaissance from a down-and-out smokestack to a gleaming cultural oasis. But old stereotypes die hard, and Pittsburgh probably doesnt make many peoples short list for a cosmopolitan getaway. Too bad, because this city of 89 distinct neighborhoods is a cool and  dare I say, hipcity. There are great restaurants, excellent shopping, breakthrough galleries and prestigious museums. The convergence of three rivers and surrounding green hills also make it a surprisingly pretty urban setting. And if the Pirates are in town, head over to PNC Park. Besides the game, the ballpark offers a great excuse to explore downtown Pittsburgh and the river views.

title: McCain Battles a Nemesis, the Teleprompter
description: LAS VEGAS Senator John McCain was performing relatively smoothly as he unveiled his energy plan.

title: Room to Decorate
description: JUDSON VANN felt confident that it would be easy to find a decent Manhattan rental. After all, his monthly budget for a studio or one-bedroom was a realistic $2,000, and it later rose to $2,500.

title: Mussina Wins Again After Rivera Saves Himself
description: From the start of the perilous ninth inning, Mike Mussina could tell something was wrong with Mariano Rivera. Pitches he might miss by an inch or two were sailing a foot away from their targets. For the first time in his career, Rivera hit two batters in a game. Mussina had a victory in the balance, and as he watched from the Yankees clubhouse, he was nervous.

title: Saving on a Visit to Washington
description: You cant beat Washington for its impressive list of cultural freebies: the Smithsonians 19 museums (the worlds largest museum complex, it includes the National Portrait Gallery and the National Air and Space Museum), the Library of Congress and the Lincoln Memorial to name a few. Destination D.C. (www.washington.org), the citys tourism office, is making Washington even more affordable with its Staying Power promotion. Guests who reserve a three-night stay, including a Thursday or a Sunday night, at one of the participating hotels, which include the Marriott Key Bridge and the Beacon Hotel (rates range from $71 to $199), will receive a 30 percent discount on their total stay. There is also a list of 100 free  and almost free  things to do in Washington on the Web sites home page.

title: Up Front
description: Geoffrey Wolff, who reviews Ethan Canins new novel in this issue, is a writer whose books include the memoir Duke of Deception and a biography of John OHara, The Art of Burning Bridges. Wolff started out as a book critic, however.

title: Letter: Lower East Side Art
description: To the Editor: I was delighted to read in From Pickles to Paintings (June 22) that the Lower East Side is seeing a resurgence of galleries, with many open on Sundays and having less high-brow attitudes than is too often the case.

title: Transloosely Literated
description: A books journey from one language into another can be perilous. The Russian title for J. D. Salingers classic tale of adolescence translates as Above the Precipice in the Rye. A clerk in a Yokohama bookshop once told John Steinbecks wife that yes, he had a copy of Steinbecks Angry Raisins. Has this bumpy road gotten any smoother in recent years? Let the following quiz be your guide.

description: MARLTON, N.J.

description: OMAHA  In a little more than 30 seconds, Davis Tarwater saw four years of hard work, as well as his heart, sink to the bottom of the Qwest Center pool.

description: PHILADELPHIA  The Mets inconsistencies this season have been reflected in their pitching, hitting and defense, but another aspect, too: fan voting for the All-Star Game at Yankee Stadium on July 15.

title: Emily Storey, Matthew Walsh
description: Emily Zilpha Storey, the daughter of Karen Storey of Berkeley, Calif., and James Storey of Oakland, Calif., was married on Saturday to Matthew Thomas Walsh, a son of Elizabeth Hawkins-Walsh and Dr. Thomas Walsh of Arlington, Va. The Rev. M. L. Agnew, performed the ceremony at St. Anns Episcopal Church in Kennebunkport, Me.

title: Creative Plates at a Good Price in Barcelona
description: TINY white flowers dot the tuna tartare at the austere Gresca restaurant. At first you think they are just garnish, a bright, pretty contrast to the ruby heap of diced fish. Then you taste them: garlic. The blossoms are a clever way to add flavor to the silky flesh without overpowering its sweetness. But then, youve come to expect cleverness on the plate. This is Barcelona, after all.

title: Reviving a Legend
description: WHEN Tina Fabrique was 12 and growing up in Harlem, her mother took her to see Ella Fitzgerald perform.

description: Rabbi Amy Idit Jacques and Steven M. Davidoff are to be married on Sunday by Rabbi Devora Green at the Athletic Club of Columbus in Ohio.

description: BEIJING

title: If Youre Open to Growth, You Tend to Grow
description: WHY do some people reach their creative potential in business while other equally talented peers dont?

title: Livin La Vida Local
description: In the early 1950s, a doll called Scribbles shook up the toy industry. Her face had no features of its own but could be sketched on with a special marker, washed clean and drawn on again. Creepy as this may sound, shes a handy metaphor for creating a self in an uncertain environment like the one in Rachel Kushners multilayered and absorbing first novel, Telex From Cuba. Here a little American girl plays with her Scribbles the way Madame Defarge knits, while the international drifters around her settle in to bury pasts that include murder, adultery and neurotic meltdown. Meanwhile, Cuba itself is being remade; President Prio is replaced by the Americans favorite, Batista, and the Castro brothers gather revolutionaries in the hills of Oriente Province.

title: Buddhas Caves
description: DUNHUANG, China

title: Peter Budinger, David Scarpelli
description: Peter Alexander Budinger, a son of Mary Budinger of Pelham, N.Y., and the late Dr. John Budinger, was married on Monday to David Charles Scarpelli, a son of Dr. Bella Clutario Scarpelli and Dr. Emile Scarpelli of Orangeburg, N.Y. Richard G. Ow, a deputy marriage commissioner, officiated at San Francisco City Hall.

title: Digging for Summer
description: DURING my childhood in the late 1960s and early 70s, the ritual of eating a steamer used to be an all-day affair that began with a long drive from Yonkers to Sherwood Island State Park in Connecticut. The tide tables had been consulted in the planning, so the water would be high when my extended familys procession emerged from four-door sedans and station wagons with fake wood panels  some of us slightly carsick  laden with the days supplies.

description: Vineland

title: Towns Grease the Wheels to Save Fuel
description: EVEN though government agencies are exempt from the tax portion of the price of motor fuel, they are feeling the pinch of high fuel costs. Motivated in equal measure by budget considerations, environmental concerns and the desire for American energy independence, a handful of local governments have begun to fuel their vehicles with waste vegetable oil.

title: Susan Jane Adamcik, Daniel Boston
description: Dr. Susan Jane Adamcik, a daughter of Mary Elizabeth Adamcik and Robert J. Adamcik of the Villages, Fla., was married in St. Petersburg, Fla., on Saturday to Daniel Ward Boston, a son of Mary Anne Boston and Ward Boston III of St. Petersburg. Msgr. J. B. Caverly officiated at St. Raphaels Roman Catholic Church, where he is pastor.

title: The Quandary of a Superpower as Others Race to Catch Up
description: THIS Fourth of July weekend could not be more propitious for taking stock of America and its place in the world. The experiment that declared independence in 1776, and fought and bought its way across a continent, became by the 20th century the worlds richest and most powerful nation ever. But what about the 21st century?

description: Film

title: At $100 for Tank of Gas, Some Choke on Fill It
description: With gasoline prices high and rising, a new financial milestone has arrived: the $100 tank of gas.

title: The Dysfunctional Jameses
description: House of Wits seems an odd title, suggesting elegant repartee and playful badinage  more Oscar Wilde or Nol Coward  for what is billed as an intimate portrait of the James family. Certainly they could be witty (Alice, the only daughter, was especially sharp); they competed as children at the family dinner table to tell the best stories, jumping from their chairs and gesticulating passionately; and two of them, the two geniuses of the family, grew up to live on their wits. But wits is not how I think of them, either before or after reading this book. House of horrors would be nearer the mark, in this version. Paul Fisher refers to the James home as a chamber of horrors, a plague ship and the James family bog. His big project is to tell the James family story as a traumatic saga of dysfunction, competition, anxiety, aspirations often thwarted, confusion, repression, breakdown and sadness, of lifelong struggles to get away and an inexorable pull back to the powerful family bond. The lives of all the children are shaped by the fathers peculiarities: The young Jameses grew up borne on the shifting currents of Henrys emotions and desires, and buffeted by them. Resenting or hating the home, driven away from it by wanderlust, ambition and desire for independence, yet always locked into it and haunted by what Alice James called ghost microbes, the Jameses were doomed, in Fishers words, to be always running away from Jameses only to collide with Jameses again.

title: Aina Hunter, Marjorie Williams
description: Aina Hunter and Marjorie Ann Williams were married at their house in Granville, Mass., on Saturday. The ceremony was led by Nuala Archer, a friend of the couple who received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Damon Will, and Does, Run Into Walls for Yanks
description: Johnny Damon puts himself on the line. He did it the night the Red Sox fell behind, three games to none, in 2004. He did it Thursday night after Joe Girardi went off.

title: When Old Glory Grows Old
description: LIKE many objects of significance, it didnt look like much. Outside the Staten Island Borough Hall, in a patch of yellow pansies, sat what was once a United States mailbox. It was painted red, white and blue, it bore the words Retired U.S. Flags, and for the last half-decade it has been a depository for worn-out Stars and Stripes.

title: Larchmont-Mamaroneck Merger Plan Aims at Taxes
description: An article last Sunday about a proposal to merge the Village of Larchmont with the Town of Mamaroneck misstated the title of Stephen V. Altieri. He is the Mamaroneck town administrator, not the town supervisor.

title: New 3-Acre Dog Run Doesnt Please Owners
description: An article last Sunday about a new dog park in Ward Acres Park misstated the annual fees charged for resident and nonresident owners to take their dogs there. They are $50 per dog for residents and $100 per dog for nonresidents, not a flat $50 for residents and $100 for nonresidents.

title: Twisted Sisters
description: SIERRA AND BIANCA CASADY, the two sisters who form the indie-rock band CocoRosie, were playing dress-up in Sierras apartment in the Montmartre district of Paris one afternoon last fall. They were preparing for a concert later that week at the Paris Olympia, which marked the end of a four-month European tour. Splayed open on Sierras living-room floor were two large blue Samsonite suitcases that spewed forth, rummage-sale-style, some of the outfits and stage props Bianca had brought back with her from New York for their Olympia gig.

title: First 1973, and Then 88. Now, This Year.
description: Producers and grape-growers cite 1988 as the second most important year in Long Island wine history. That is when a conference, Maritime Climate Winegrowing: Bringing Bordeaux to Long Island,  was held to mark the 15th anniversary of the founding of the pioneering Hargrave Vineyard in Cutchogue in 1973 (perhaps the most important year).

title: Two Husbands
description: My husband and I met when I was a 19-year-old college student from upstate New York and he was a worldly man of 28, with a job, an apartment and a car. We were married a year and a half later. Of course there were rough spots in our long marriage  job pressures (his), illness (mine), money problems (ours). We got through them, sometimes a little chastened but with our deep need for each other strengthened. Of all the ways that Howard changed me, a shy, studious teenager when we met, the most important was that he made me laugh.

title: With Rulon Gardner
description: Rulon Gardner, 37, is the most famous amateur wrestler of his generation. His victory over the Russian Aleksandr Karelin to win the gold medal in Greco-Roman wrestling at the Sydney Olympics in Australia in 2000 became known as the Miracle on the Mat. After winning a bronze medal at the Athens Games in 2004, Gardner retired. His brushes with death in snowmobile, motorcycle and airplane accidents have added to his legend over the years. Gardner, who was a broadcaster for NBC last month at the Olympic wrestling trials, lives in Salt Lake City. GREG BISHOP

title: Formula Ones Hamilton Faces Criticism
description: LONDON  After only 25 Grand Prix races, and barely halfway through his second year in Formula One, Lewis Hamilton faces what may be the most critical test of his career Sunday in his home race, the British Grand Prix at Silverstone.

title: Stories of 11 Disasters Told in Artifacts
description: On March 14, 1886, the luxury liner Oregon was struck by a smaller boat and started to sink five miles off Fire Island. The captain waited eight hours before abandoning his ship, which was outfitted with satinwood panels, parquet floors and the incandescent lamps that had recently been invented by Thomas Edison. Everyone remained so calm that, history has it, the crew served hot tea and toast to the passengers as they awaited rescue.

title: Home Screening
description: Since I became a father, I have read stories about parents and their children with a humiliating lack of emotional armor. Right after our son was born, someone gave me a copy of Scott Bergs biography of Charles Lindbergh. I thought it was wonderful until the Lindberghs baby was kidnapped, and then my stomach knotted up so badly I had to put the book away. Instead I read Knut Hamsuns Hunger, a story of a homeless writer almost starving to death, and it was like a light comedy by comparison.

description: The lineup sheet in the Yankees clubhouse Saturday listed three bench players: two catchers and Johnny Damon, who is in no shape to play after damaging his left shoulder while crashing into the outfield wall Friday.

title: Police Kill 9 Inmates During Prison Riot in Syria
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian military police officers fired on Islamist inmates early on Saturday during a riot at a prison outside Damascus, the Syrian capital, leaving at least nine inmates dead, human rights officials here said.

title: An American Family
description: UP in the Bronx near Yankee Stadium, an odd little footnote to American history began playing out quietly last August when I packed my belongings into a U-Haul truck and headed north from small-town Virginia.

title: For a Wife and a Husband, a Win and a Loss
description: EUGENE, Ore.  Kara Gouchers emotions hit two extremes in the span of two races Friday night at the United States Olympic track and field trials. She surged ahead in the final half-lap to win the first major race of her career in the 5,000 meters, but her celebration did not last as she watched her husband, Adam Goucher, fail to make the Olympic team in the 10,000.

Cutler helped chronicle the political maneuverings of George Stephanopoulos and James Carville, the savvy architects of Bill Clintons presidential run against President George H. W. Bush. Then he climbed into the stands at Hayward Field in his bare feet and celebrated with what appeared to be random spectators.
