description: With the season a little more than halfway over, this is a particularly easy time for baseball fans to imagine the numbers players are on pace to produce. Although injuries and slumps are never taken into consideration, it is still the point of the year when baseball fans traditionally begin to look at milestones that may be on the horizon.

title: But Can You Call It a Woody?
description: HOW much wood would a woodchuck chuck if a woodchuck could drive an S.U.V.? About 25 pounds, says Robert Beam. Thats how much wood it takes to fill the hopper of his 1988 Isuzu Trooper, which he has converted to run on wood chips.

title: Correction: The Week Ahead: June 29-July 5
description: A picture caption with a television entry in the Week Ahead column last Sunday misstated the title of the documentary about the case of Schapelle Corby, the Australian woman convicted and imprisoned in Bali for smuggling drugs, who was shown in a scene. It is Ganja Queen, not Ganga Queen.

title: You Had a Friend in Albany
description: LAST month, Joseph Bruno, the upstate Republican who was the New York State Senate majority leader for more than a decade, announced he was retiring amid speculation concerning a federal investigation of his outside business activities. Democrats in New York City were thrilled by the news  but they are about to find out that Mr. Bruno was their best friend in Albany, and life without him wont be easy.

title: Caroline Klein, Timothy Michaud
description: Caroline Jo Klein, a daughter of Barbara and Dennis Klein of Brookfield, Wis., was married on Saturday to Timothy Joseph Michaud, a son of April and Ernest Michaud of Lancaster, Mass. The Rev. Douglas Leonhardt, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Blessed Teresa of Calcutta Church in North Lake, Wis.

title: Jokes Inside, Jeers Without
description: A LITTLE after 5 p.m. two weeks ago, about 20 aspiring comedians sat in the dark, spare back room of the New York Comedy Club at 24th Street and Third Avenue, trying to psyche themselves up to be, in the words of the clubs in-house coach and cheerleader, the second coming of Pryor or Woody Allen.

title: For the Up-and-Down Mets, a Win Includes a Little of Both
description: PHILADELPHIA  The Mets have alternated losing and winning over their last eight games, giving up ground in the standings as quickly as they gained it back. So in keeping with the dominant theme of the season, it was fitting that, even on a night when they made progress by roaring back to defeat the first-place Phillies, 9-4, the Mets faced two potential setbacks when John Maine and Ryan Church left the game because of health concerns.

title: Inside the List
description: PLUM CRAZY: If its summer, there must be a new Stephanie Plum novel on the list. Plum, of course, is the spunky bounty-hunter heroine of Janet Evanovichs popular mystery series and a mainstay of the fiction best-seller list. Fearless Fourteen, the latest title in the series, jumps straight to No. 1 in its first week here  a feat duplicated, amazingly, by each of the eight novels that preceded it, going all the way back to Hot Six in July 2000. And unlike Sue Grafton, who has a built-in finale to her alphabet series (Z Is for ... Zombies? Zinfandel?), Evanovich can keep churning out her numbered titles ad infinitum. But she could evidently use a little help from her fans: her Web site right now is featuring a Name Book Fifteen contest.

title: Ancient Tablet Ignites Debate on Messiah and Resurrection
description: JERUSALEM  A three-foot-tall tablet with 87 lines of Hebrew that scholars believe dates from the decades just before the birth of Jesus is causing a quiet stir in biblical and archaeological circles, especially because it may speak of a messiah who will rise from the dead after three days.

title: Hardcover Business Best Sellers
The Mamma Mia! Factor, Times Three
description: THERES a lot of noise and flash in Mamma Mia!  both the show and the movie. But the three women responsible  for both the show and the movie  seemed restrained enough as they sat down to what one of them called a proper English tea on Central Park South last month.

title: Morgans Hotel Sets Reopening After Face-Lift
description: Morgans, the New York boutique hotel founded by Ian Schrager in 1984 and now owned by Morgans Hotel Group, is scheduled to reopen in September, after undergoing a four-month, $9 million renovation. The designer, Andre Putman, is reinterpreting her black-and-white interior by adding gradations of black, white and gray tones, above, which were used everywhere from the lobby to the 113 guest rooms. Original black-and-white photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe will adorn guest-room walls, and the lobby will have a living-room feel, with custom-made wool rugs and vintage chairs bought in Parisian flea markets. Nightly rates start at $449 (www.morganshotel.com).

description: WITH the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq composite index down about 20 percent from their recent highs, this sure looks like a bear market.

description: Ralph Branca, the former Brooklyn Dodgers pitcher, keeps telling his son-in-law to come back home, baby.

title: Living to Throw Despite the Injuries
description: Javelin throwers put so much strain on their throwing shoulder and elbow that their bodies often rebel. So it is no surprise that Brian Chaput tore the ulnar collateral ligament in his right elbow and underwent Tommy John surgery in 2000. And 2005. And 2006.

title: Catch-22 of Urban Renewal
description: FOR more than 30 years, Theodora Skipitares, a theater director and performance artist, and a hardy band of her neighbors, who are painters, photographers and a writer of experimental novels, struggled to make a home in a loft building on East Third Street, on one of the most troubled stretches of the Bowery.

title: Letters: The New Pariahs?
description: Noah Feldmans informative article (June 22) ignores a crucial historical fact that explains much about Western Europes current dilemma with its Muslim immigrants. Great Britain, France and the Netherlands, until after World War II, ruled large colonial empires, concentrated in Africa and Asia, that included many Muslim subjects. These people, the ancestors of todays outsiders, did not ask to become colonials but were brought up learning the language and culture of their mother countries, abandoning much of their own culture for that of the mother country. For example, many of the far-flung countries once under British rule are now English-speaking and play cricket. That their descendants want to live in the mother country should be no surprise.

title: Affirmative Distraction
description: Aspen, Colo.

title: File-Sharing Fetish
description: In 1996, as Hollywood was lionizing the pornographer Larry Flynt as the author of the real sexual revolution, the Internet was trying to decide what to do about porn.

title: A Political Agitator Finds a Double-Edged Weapon
description: Perhaps for the first time in his life, Senator Barack Obama may have reason to commiserate with the likes of Bill OReilly, Rush Limbaugh and George Allen. They surely could tell him a few stories about what it is like when Mike Stark has you in his sights.

title: Marcella Ridgway and Will Kinzel
description: Marcella Kathleen Ridgway and Will Chambers Kinzel were married on Monday at St. Patricks Roman Catholic Church in Cork, Ireland. The Rev. Thomas Clancy performed the ceremony in the church, where the brides great-grandparents were married in February 1888.

title: Did Bob Marley Grow Up in a Water Park?
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.

title: Andrea Scribner, Ahsim Khan
description: Andrea Mae Scribner and Ahsim Raza Khan are to be married Sunday evening at the Crowne Plaza in Warwick, R.I. Imam Talal Eid, a Muslim cleric, is to officiate. Next Saturday evening, they will celebrate again with a ring ceremony and a reading of vows at the Ritz-Carlton Grand Cayman in the Cayman Islands.

title: Getting a Handle on Apartment Noise
description: APARTMENT-HUNTING parents are often more worried about incoming than outgoing sound, brokers say, but those interested in minimizing future conflict can keep some strategies in mind.

title: You Can Go Home Again, and Write About It
description: Shirley

title: Perseverance and Chance Led to Reversal in 88 Murders
description: IF Karlene Kovacs had not attended a small family dinner on Easter in 1991, Martin H. Tankleff probably would not have become a free man in 2007.

title: As Records Change by the Minute, the Womens 800 Stays Standing
description: OMAHA  This spring, Mark Schubert, the United States national team coach and general manager, called the Olympic champion Janet Evans, whom he coached at Southern California and on various national teams. Evanss world record in the 800-meter freestyle is the last one remaining that was set before 2000. With swimmers in the latest fast suits setting records left and right, Schubert braced Evans for the inevitable  that her record was going to fall, too.

title: Dysfunctional Since Before It Was Cool
description: TO facilitate an Internet search for his work, the playwright Christopher Durang lists the following keywords on his personal Web site: satire, parody and funny  as well as glaucoma drops, butter and zippers. To enter christopherdurang.com, you must click on a photo of a screaming Liv Ullmann.

title: Ranking System Is Questioned After a Wealthy Russians Rise
description: Every three months, the World Chess Federation publishes new rankings. On the current list, which was released on Tuesday, there were 102 grandmasters and one master  Vladimir Afromeev of Russia, who was No. 78.

title: If Music Be the Food of Fortune
description: SPRINGFIELD, N.Y.

title: Three Ways Till Sunday
description: This is a plan for a weekend of simple excess, starting on Friday night and culminating in a hearty Sunday breakfast or lunch. It requires only the basic ingredients of American summer, East Coast professional division: lobster, corn, potatoes, butter, rice, steak, eggs. It calls for guests and a soundtrack of big-band jazz or country music. It rewards sparkling wine.

title: Correction: Windows Could Use a Rush of Fresh Air
description: The Digital Domain column last Sunday, about the future of Microsoft Windows software, misstated the given name of Microsofts senior vice president overseeing research. He is Rick Rashid, not Rich.

title: Closer Look at Things Organic
description: Helene Romeo, a dietitian, and Sherene De Palma, a former corporate lawyer, have joined forces to create Near and Natural, a charming market and cafe in Bedford Village that is as organic as is practicably possible. Also busy raising seven children under the age of 12, the young mothers are on a mission to stock their shelves with delicious, nutritious food that has traveled a minimum number of miles to get there  and to educate the public about a new model for eating.

title: Out of the Fire, and Back on the Griddle
description: Many diners are larger, and there are many with shinier chrome exteriors. But few are as well loved as ORourkes, which has anchored the north end of Middletowns Main Street since its debut in 1941.

title: Endless Summer, Indeed
description: LOCH ARBOUR

title: Landscape Artist
description: Robert Macfarlane is looking for his wild in England, Ireland and Wales, territory that for most of us evokes words like manicured, turf or, at the very least, domesticated. His book about a series of pilgrimages to the moors, islands, lochs, capes and holloways that season the British Isles might seem quaint or even confusing (a holloway?) to those whose notion of wildness demands rock, altitude and ice, as he puts it.

title: Numerology
description: My cousin, bound for a top liberal arts college in the fall, was amused when I told her I was reviewing a book about big ideas in mathematics, from the classical to the contemporary. Dont they already know everything about math? she asked. You know, theres algebra ... and then calculus ... and thats it, right?

title: For an Army General, a New Rebuilding Effort
description: The decision to put a two-star general in charge of N.B.A. referees was not necessarily about restoring integrity, regaining public trust or creating a fresh, independent vision for a besieged officiating program.

title: Sapna Shah, Srinivasan Iyer
description: Sapna Padmakant Shah, a daughter of Kokila P. Shah and Dr. Padmakant M. Shah of Albertson, N.Y., was married Saturday to Srinivasan Iyer, the son of Chandra Iyer and Rajagopal Iyer of Bayside, N.Y. Pandit Nikhil Trivedi, a Hindu priest, officiated at the Huntington Hilton in Melville, N.Y., with Pandit Hariharan Iyer, another Hindu priest, taking part.

title: Thai Museum at Angkor Draws Tourists, and Criticism
description: SIEM REAP, Cambodia  There is no question that Angkor and its famed temples are among the worlds archaeological treasures, providing a window into the Cambodian dynasty that flourished there from the ninth century to the 15th century. But tourists who flock to the site in northwestern Cambodia say something is missing; few artifacts remain to help them imagine the customs and rituals of the ancient empire.

title: Lisa Toff, Adam Richman
description: Lisa Nicole Toff, a shoe designer, and Adam Richman, a musician, are to be married on Sunday afternoon at the Tribeca Rooftop, a party space in Manhattan. Cantor Kevin Wartell is to officiate.

title: Letter: Ballpark Food
description: To the Editor: Peter Meehan had me from hello with his smart and funny culinary review of the nations baseball parks in his Buy Me Some Sushi and Baby Back Ribs (June 8).

title: Ladders of Memory and a House With a Past
description: The Company Where Ladders Are Born

title: Letters: The Tort War, Unresolved
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: Reminders of Paris in Londons Truly English Food
description: Two photographs with an article on June 22 about three memorable restaurants in London were transposed. The picture at bottom right of Page 7 was of Devon cockles and mussels steamed in cider at Hereford Road; the picture at top right on Page 10 with the continuation of the article was of Hereford beef burger and parsley salad at Great Queen Street.

title: Miku Inoue, Benjamin Parisi
description: Miku Inoue and Benjamin Joseph Parisi were married on Saturday at the Harvard United Methodist Church in Downsville, N.Y. The Rev. Dale L. Ashby, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony. On June 22, the couple had a traditional Shinto ceremony at the Temmangu Shrine in Osaka, Japan.

title: All-Williams Wimbledon Final Is All Venus
description: WIMBLEDON, England  Sisters for life and doubles partners later in the afternoon, Venus and Serena Williams put most of that aside for nearly two hours on Saturday at Wimbledon, smacking serves and ground strokes in each others direction with a vengeance and an accuracy that have often been lacking in their previous family reunions.

title: Cashing In on Obama and McCain
description: JOHN McCAIN and Barack Obama are not the only winners to emerge from the long presidential primary season.

title: A New Condominium Isnt Ready on Time
description: Q We signed a contract on a preconstruction condominium in November 2006. The developers told us that it would be finished in April of this year, with early June being the latest. As these dates have passed, they have not been upfront with us on the progress of construction. Furthermore, I found out that the offering plan has been amended four times, and our attempts to get a copy of those amendments have been fruitless.

title: Offering a Carbon-Free Way to Get Around
description: WEST HARTFORD

title: Retiring Thrower Lifts Javelin to a Work of Art
description: EUGENE, Ore.  At age 46, Roald Bradstock did not qualify for Sundays final in the javelin at the United States Olympic track and field trials. As a consolation, he apparently did retire holding the world record for throwing fish across state lines.

title: Out of My Shell Over You
description: After Nicola Kraus kissed David Wheir for the first time, her mother had a question for her: Is he your lobster?

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Sunday about people outside the traditional political world who use the Web to attack candidates and their campaigns misspelled the surname of a strategist for Senator Barack Obama in some editions. He is Dan Carol, not Carrol. The error also appeared in the Quotation of the Day.

title: An American in China
description: This summer, widespread Beijing fatigue is an inevitability. But its high-flying Olympic Beijing that may become overfamiliar, a city thats appeared before our very eyes as in a scene from The Matrix. This is not Michael Meyers town. The Beijing he has called home is being systematically eradicated, and this book is his testament.

title: How a Promotion Can Test a Friendship
description: Q. A good friend at work has been promoted and is now your boss. Is this the end of the friendship?

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Front Page

title: Hidden Doings
description: I struck up a close friendship with a man. We take longs walks or simply talk for hours.

title: Redemption Politics
description: We all know that politics makes strange bedfellows, but how odd it must have been to have sat in on the recent meeting between Barack Obama and evangelical leaders, including Franklin Graham, the conservative minister who once called Islam a very evil and wicked religion. Yet there they were, Obama and the evangelicals in Chicago on June 10, searching for  and apparently finding  considerable common ground. In the last few weeks, Obama has announced several outreach projects (including one named after Joshua, who, unlike Moses, was able to lead his people to the promised land). For their part, evangelical leaders, unpersuaded by John McCains episodic proclamations of faith, are wise, or perhaps even prophetic, to consider all the options.

title: Playgrounds That Welcome Wheelchairs
description: THE first time Lisa Vaccino took her children to Hannahs Dream, a playground in New Haven designed for disabled children, she immediately noticed a difference in her son, Johnny, 5, who has cerebral palsy.

title: Elves and Killer Beanstalks From Directors Personal Hell
description: The common thread running through the films of Guillermo del Toro, from his 1993 horror feature debut, Cronos, to his 2006 Oscar-winning parable, Pans Labyrinth, is his deep affection for gruesome-looking beasts. Theres nothing I enjoy more than creating fables about monsters, human or otherwise, Mr. del Toro said in a recent phone interview from London.

title: Program Aims to Curb Violence by Inmates
description: Valhalla

title: Paperback Business Best Sellers
When Watercolor Came Into Its Own
description: Watercolor painting is an amateurs medium, beloved of the Sunday painter. And yet it is also among the hardest of artistic techniques to master, for unlike oil or even acrylic painting, where the paint stays where you put it, water-soluble paint is runny and difficult to control. Mistakes cannot easily be painted over, either, for the paper is absorbent and adding more paint often results in a watery mess.

title: So Thats What the Fat Lady Sang
description: DURING a long career in North America, Lotfi Mansouri, the Iranian-born opera director and manager, ran two prestigious houses, the Canadian Opera Company in Toronto and the San Francisco Opera; commissioned works; directed scores of productions; cultivated singers; and still had time to make his mark in Europe.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Sunday about new American economic sanctions to be imposed on Zimbabwe following that countrys presidential runoff election on June 27, which was widely criticized as fraudulent and coercive, misspelled the surname of the director of the business and human rights program of Human Rights Watch, who said the sanctions could have a significant impact on Zimbabwes mining industry. He is Arvind Ganesan, not Ganesam.

title: Stephanie Hsu, Tom Cheung
description: Stephanie Maria Hsu, a daughter of Teresa and Ronald Hsu of Tacoma, Wash., was married on Friday to Tom Cheung, the son of the late Shiu-Ying Cheung and the late Yu-Cho Cheung, who lived in New York. The Rev. John Hsu, an Evangelical minister, officiated at Salish Lodge and Spa in Snoqualmie, Wash. In May, the couple had a Chinese cultural ceremony and wedding banquet at the East Market Restaurant in New York.

title: Displaced and Adrift in Los Angeles
description: THE Exiles, a film about American Indians living on the edge of downtown Los Angeles in the 1950s, is both a chronicle and a casualty of neglect: a movie about a forsaken community that itself became a lost object. Directed by Kent Mackenzie, a first-time filmmaker who had just graduated from the University of Southern California, it is a poetic and empathetic hybrid of fiction and documentary. The nonprofessional actors play versions of themselves: young Indians, newly relocated from reservations and adrift in working-class Bunker Hill.

title: Ambitions Expand at Canco Lofts
description: The In the Region article in New Jersey and Manhattan copies last Sunday about the Canco Lofts condominium development in Jersey City described incorrectly some aspects of the penthouse apartment bought by Shawn Cox and Dan Moore, which was shown in the photograph. It has three bedrooms, not two, and it reaches 27 feet in height, not 17.

title: Paperback Row
description: FAIR GAME: How a Top Spy Was Betrayed by Her Own Government, by Valerie Plame Wilson. (Simon & Schuster, $15.) The columnist Robert Novak ended Valerie Plame Wilsons career when he identified her as a C.I.A. officer in 2003, and she wrote this book both to settle scores and to support her family. After reviewing the manuscript, the C.I.A. demanded many deletions; the book includes the censors marks as well as an afterword by a reporter who uses the public record to fill in gaps. Fair Game, Janet Maslin wrote in The Times, shows Wilson as an ambitious, gung-ho professional.

title: The Noise Children Make
description: APARTMENT dwellers in New York City have long endured the trauma of jackhammers, Manolo Blahniks, recycling trucks, sirens, canines and air-conditioning systems.

title: Its My Party, Come Out to Pay
description: When invited by a friend to dinner celebrating his or her own birthday at a restaurant, are the invitees obligated to split the tab and not allow the birthday celebrator to pay?

title: The Generations of History (and Historians)
description: To the Editor:

title: Trying to Stem Exodus of the Islands Young
description: Edgewood

title: The Political Mind
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article today in Sunday Business about missed opportunities to reduce Americas dependence on imported oil refers to a 1990 effort by Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, to block higher mileage requirements for vehicles and notes that Mr. Helms did not return calls seeking comment. The section went to press on Thursday, before Mr. Helmss death Friday morning.

title: Back in Kabul, Never at Peace
description: My first trip to Kabul was in 2001. I arrived as Northern Alliance soldiers were fighting Taliban gunmen in and around the Afghan capital. Those who resisted were killed, and those captured were more likely to be executed than taken prisoner. There was a power vacuum in Kabul, a brief moment when one set of rulers fled and the next had not yet taken over. This can be a liberating time for a photographer. There were no clear rules, no central authority that might restrict you from taking pictures. Ive returned to Afghanistan nearly every year since then.

title: High on the View as Much as the Cocktails
description: WHO cares if a bar has an upscale hotel attached to it? Unless youve got big bucks, youre not staying there anyway. You dont have any luggage for others to lug. And who needs an ice machine when youve got a bartender?

title: After The Wire, Moving On to Battles Beyond the Streets
description: MARTINSBURG, W.Va.

title: Airlines Cutting Flights From Bradley Airport
description: WINDSOR LOCKS

title: Who Wants to Drive a Millionaire?
description: LETS take the easy question first: Is the Koenigsegg CCX worth 669,000 euros, or $1.05 million in our currently scrawny American currency? For most owners of mere $200,000 Ferraris  let alone mortals with $20,000 minivans  the answer is an emphatic no.

title: Telex From Cuba
description: January 1958

title: Katherine Blumm, Michael de Zayas
description: Katherine Elias Blumm, the daughter of Wallis and Harvey Blumm of Manhattan, was married there on Wednesday to Michael Brian de Zayas, a son of Eileen and Alfredo de Zayas of Miramar, Fla. Blanca Martinez, a staff member in the office of the city clerk, officiated at the Municipal Building in Manhattan.

title: Employers Fight Tough Measures on Immigration
description: Under pressure from the toughest crackdown on illegal immigration in two decades, employers across the country are fighting back in state legislatures, the federal courts and city halls.

title: Scorched Earth
description: The Salton Sea is a lake, saltier than the ocean, that lies about 85 miles east of San Diego. Fish and birds flock there for sustenance; they also die there in huge numbers, victims of the lakes high saline content and, some say, its toxicity. A bleak landscape, baking under the remorseless sun of the Colorado Desert, its a strange, lonesome place. And in her new novel, The God of War, Marisa Silver has filled it with strange, lonesome people.

title: Yasmin Ramirez, William Lipton
description: Yasmin Ramirez and William Barnett Lipton were married on Monday in Brooklyn, at the home of Judge Margarita Lpez Torres of Surrogates Court in Brooklyn, who officiated. On Friday, Nina Browne, a friend of the couple who is a student at the One Spirit Interfaith Seminary in Manhattan, led a religious ceremony in Brooklyn.

title: Christine Boyle, Robert Ciccone
description: Christine Frances Boyle, the daughter of Frances Boyle and John Boyle of Manhattan, was married in North Eastham, Mass., on Saturday to Robert Victor Ciccone, a son of Natalie Ciccone and Dr. J. Richard Ciccone of Rochester, N.Y. The Rev. John F. Andrews, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of the Visitation, where he is pastor.

title: Letter: Less Baggage
description: To the Editor: Regarding Checking Baggage? Not at These Prices (June 15): My husband and I have traveled for two-week trips to China, Italy and India over the last three years. We have come to realize that you should take half the amount of clothing and twice the amount of money.

title: A Side Competition in Beijing: Island vs. Mainland
description: KAOHSIUNG, Taiwan  From six table tennis tables at the Olympic training center here comes the rhythmic clack-clack-clack of ball against paddle against tabletop.

title: Lonely at the Top
description: Lonely at the Top

title: Out of the Midday Sun
description: If it were not for the subtitle of Peter Clarkes sharp new history, The Last Thousand Days of the British Empire: Churchill, Roosevelt, and the Birth of the Pax Americana, readers could be excused for looking at the books title and having no idea what period of time was under consideration. Could it be the years leading up to 1997, when the British finally relinquished Hong Kong? Or perhaps the early 1960s, when Nigeria and the crowns beloved Jamaica gained independence?

title: Medicine Show
description: When journalists are young, many are drawn to the beautiful and exceptional, the objects of millions longing. Older, their empathy turns toward those who are sick, diminished, facing the blank wall of death. So it is that Julie Salamon, who in 1991 published a surpassingly brilliant chronicle of the excesses of Hollywood, The Devils Candy, about the director Brian De Palma and the making of the flop The Bonfire of the Vanities, 17 years later has moved her focus from the final cut to the final exit and given us a book on Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: Alexis Sherman and Eric Arinsburg
description: Alexis Beth Sherman, a daughter of Judith E. Sherman and Richard M. Sherman of Northridge, Calif., was married on Saturday evening to Eric Robert Arinsburg, the son of Elaine R. Arinsburg and Larry Arinsburg of New City, N.Y. Rabbi Brett Krichiver officiated at the Beverly Wilshire Hotel in Beverly Hills, Calif., with Cantor Linda Kates taking part.

title: Ancestral Journeys
description: The attributes of Arab identity have proved quite a challenge for Americans in the last decade. Throughout the 20th century most United States citizens went along quite happily without expending a thought to, say, the difference between Sunni and Shiite Muslims. This was of a piece with a general climate of nonchalance about all things foreign. In a speech in Brasilia in 1982, Ronald Reagan infamously offered a toast to the people of Bolivia, a gaffe that probably did him more good than harm on his home turf. Since 9/11, the days of willful ignorance about the Arab world are gone forever, or at least there is a pretense they are. Now, just when it looked as if more or less everyone, politicians included, was close to getting the Sunni-Shiite thing down, along comes Amin Maalouf with his lovely, complex memoir, Origins, to remind us that Arab identity is as fluid, unsettled and ever-changing as the Mediterranean Sea where it kisses the shores of Lebanon, his country of origin, and France, where he has lived for the last 30 years.

title: House of Wits
description: THE VOYAGE OF THE ATLANTIC

title: Growing Into a Home, and a Country
description: MOHAMMED ALI shares his name with a legend, never saw his future wife during the first seven years of their courtship, and didnt start to work seriously on his writing until he already had his first book contract. But given prices in Brooklyn these days, the truly startling part of his story is that his two-bedroom Prospect Heights apartment, with hardwood floors, three exposures and roof rights, cost only $78,000.

title: A Plane? More Like a Flying Magazine
description: ON a recent US Airways flight from New York to Jamaica, coach passengers nursing their drinks were greeted with ads on their tray tables promoting General Motors OnStar navigation system.

title: Departing Rights Official Raised Volume on Issues
description: GENEVA  She has been doing a job with a mandate that many would call impossible: to safeguard human rights around the globe. Yet as Louise Arbour steps down after four years as the United Nations high commissioner for human rights, she is not entirely pessimistic.

title: Fennie Wu and Jason Low
description: Fennie Wu, the daughter of Bi Zhu Wu of Rego Park, Queens, and the late Wei Neng Wu, was married on Saturday to Jason Kee Low, a son of Susu Lam Low and Benjamin Kee Low, also of Rego Park. Justice Doris Ling-Cohan of State Supreme Court in Manhattan, for whom the bridegroom was a law clerk in 2005, officiated at Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Weighing the Risk
description: TWO weeks ago, over the objections of his lawyer and the Central Intelligence Agency, The Times named the interrogator who used shrewd psychology, not rough stuff, to get Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the mastermind of the 9/11 attacks, to talk.

title: An Ideal Husband
description: This weekend, we celebrate our great American pastime: messy celebrity divorces.

title: Daniella Liben, Adam Pally
description: Daniella Anne Liben, a daughter of Sindy Liben and Barry Liben of Livingston, N.J., was married on Thursday evening to Adam Saul Pally, the son of Caryn Pally and Dr. Steven Pally, also of Livingston. Rabbi Stanley Asekoff officiated at Pier 60 at Chelsea Piers in New York.

title: American Energy Policy, Asleep at the Spigot
description: JUST three years ago, with oil trading at a seemingly frothy $66 a barrel, David J. OReilly made what many experts considered a risky bet. Outmaneuvering Chinese bidders and ignoring critics who said he overpaid, Mr. OReilly, the chief executive of Chevron, forked over $18 billion to buy Unocal, a giant whose riches date back to oil fields made famous in the film There Will Be Blood.

title: The Newest Alison, in a 1740 Inn
description: FIRST there was Alison on Dominick Street, which opened almost 20 years ago in Manhattan. Later, Alison Price Becker added Alison by the Beach on Townline Road on the western border of East Hampton. Then, after closing both spots, she opened Alison Restaurant in Bridgehampton. In May, Ms. Becker moved it farther east to the Maidstone Arms in East Hampton.

title: On Rio Nio, Fish Gone Wild for Colorful Flower Ties
description: UPALA, Costa Rica  The trees on the banks of the Rio Nio, with names like roble de sabana, corteza and mimosa, flower with many yellow and pink blooms. When the wind blows, the blossoms drift into the river, where machaca, a type of tenacious and sharp-toothed fish, seize upon the nectar-rich flowers.

title: House Is New, but Style Is Classic
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.

title: Shedding the Safe Label
description: Storrs

title: Goes With Bikini, Tankini, Martini
description: Summer has officially arrived and for the next few months, beach cover-ups are a girls best friend. This seasons versions depart from the elaborately beaded and embroidered tunics of past years, switching over to bright patterns and light cottons. Many double nicely as dresses; all of them travel well from lavish pool party to simple country lake.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: GAMING THE VOTE Why Elections Arent Fair (and What We Can Do About It). By William Poundstone. Hill & Wang, $25.

title: Long Island Senator Emerges on Top After Many Years of Working the Room
description: For years, when Republican state senators met privately in their elegant, high-ceilinged conference room in the Capitol, most senior members clustered around the rooms center table, close to Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader.

title: A Panoramic Subject for Artists
description: The views from Boscobel are astonishing. But so are the views inside this historic home, situated on a 68-acre estate on the east bank of the Hudson River opposite the Military Academy at West Point. Here, throughout the summer, you will find a selection of 19th-century American paintings that reflect some of the same meandering beauty that surrounds the estate today.

title: A Ban on Cockfighting, but Tradition Lives On
description: CHAPARRAL, N.M.  After two weeks of preparation, 150 officers, backed up by a helicopter, slipped into this sleepy desert town. Their focus was not illegal immigration or drug smuggling, but a less pressing crime: cockfighting.

title: Electronic Papyrus: The Digital Book, Unfurled
description: CONSUMERS like large displays on the mobile devices they use for reading an e-mail message or an e-book, but they also like to tuck those devices into their pockets. But the bigger the screen on a cellphone or an e-reader, the sooner it outgrows pocket size.

title: Three Paintings Reported Stolen From Armory
description: New Rochelle

title: Iran Says Its Nuclear Policy Has Not Changed
description: PARIS  Irans nuclear policy has not changed, an Iranian government spokesman said Saturday in Tehran, confirming that Iran would not comply with Security Council resolutions requiring it to stop enriching uranium.

title: Wartime Rations
description: I want to hate David Benioff. Hes annoyingly handsome. Hes already written a pair of unputdownable books, one of which was made into Spike Lees most heartbreaking film, The 25th Hour  for which Benioff was asked to write the screenplay, leading to a second career in Hollywood. (They should just get it over with and put the man in the movies already.) He takes his morning orange juice next to Amanda Peet. And hes still in his 30s. See what I mean?

title: Oil Climbs as Stocks Fall. Sound Familiar?
description: In a pattern that has been repeated for weeks, oil prices rose and the stock market fell.

title: Short-Straw Economics
description: Youre a professor of public policy at Berkeley and a former U.S. secretary of labor in the Clinton administration  what can you tell us about the gas-pump crisis as we set out on the road this July 4th weekend? Now that gas is at $4 a gallon, people are deserting their cars for trains and buses and, where available, light rail. We havent seen a transition on this scale away from cars ever before.

title: After 2,000 Years, a Croatian Port Town Still Seduces
description: ZADAR may be Croatias most underrated destination. This Roman-era city on the northern Dalmatian coast  where a non-euro economy is easier on the dollar  has a youthful zeal, a rich architectural legacy and easy access from various points in Europe, thanks to carriers like Ryanair, SkyEurope and Germanwings. There are dozens of nearby islands to explore, and an hour or so drive from Zadar takes you to no fewer than five national parks, where youll find lakes, waterfalls, mountains and secluded wilderness areas.

title: In Williamsburg Store, Customers Find Art Among the Wrenches
description: It is easy to miss the mechanical birds in the window, with flapping wings of scrap metal and wood and tail feathers of flattened spoons. The two-foot-long threaded bolt also blends in with its surroundings, but the 24-foot-long BMX bicycle hanging from the ceiling is a good hint that there is more to this hardware store than hammers and drills.

title: Marla Somerstein and Jason Neufeld
description: Marla Beth Somerstein, a daughter of Susan and Barry Somerstein of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married there on Saturday evening to Jason Eric Neufeld, a son of Sylvie and Alan Neufeld of North Miami Beach, Fla. Rabbi Michael Resnick officiated at the Pier Top of the Hyatt Regency Pier 66.

title: Grown in New Jersey (Mostly)
description: If youve wondered where the butcher, baker and candlestick maker have gone  having disappeared from much of Main Street America  youll find them at the Montclair Farmers Market, where theyve set up shop.

title: Selling His Soul for the Part
description: THERES a moment in an episode of Will & Grace when Sean Hayess Jack tries to resist a plea from Megan Mullalys Karen to masquerade as her ex-husband for a parent-teacher conference. He runs the emotional gamut from giggly gay guy to vulnerable young man still smarting from memories of being teased as a sissy in grade school. Suddenly, frenetically, he executes a razzle-dazzle few seconds of soft-shoe, hiding the hurt behind his smile.

title: A Support Group Is My Higher Power
description: THE object of the Jewish womens support group I belong to (even though Im not Jewish) is camaraderie of a particular kind: each of us has a child, a teenager, who has fallen apart.

title: Aili McConnon, Geoffrey Adamson
description: Aili Mary McConnon, the daughter of Dr. Mari-Ann Ott McConnon of Brampton, Ontario, and the late Dr. Joseph K. McConnon, was married on Saturday evening to Geoffrey Peter McKay Adamson, the son of Nora F. Adamson and Dr. Peter A. Adamson of Toronto. The Rev. Jason van Veghel-Wood, an Anglican minister, performed the ceremony at Trinity College Chapel of the University of Toronto.

title: On a Bus for the Homeless, a Push to Forgive the Fare
description: THE great complex of homeless shelters on Wards Island, with 838 residents, has a rhythm distinct from that of the city at large. Dorms open around 5 p.m, curfews generally take effect around 10 p.m, and the crowd on the island swells and shrinks in time with those rhythms.

title: Export Tax That Angers Farmers Advances in Argentina
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  After a marathon session that lasted through the night, Argentinas lower house of Congress on Saturday narrowly approved agricultural export tax increases that the government imposed four months ago.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: Comedy

title: A Bright Palette of Row Houses
description: SIXTY-EIGHTH STREET between Second and Third Avenues is one of those nearly anonymous streets that get little attention. It has a giant apartment house on the north side and 16 overlooked row houses on the south. title: The Urge to End It All
description: There is but one truly serious philosophical problem, Albert Camus wrote, and that is suicide. How to explain why, among the only species capable of pondering its own demise, whose desperate attempts to forestall mortality have spawned both armies and branches of medicine in a perpetual search for the Fountain of Youth, there are those who, by their own hand, would choose death over life? Our contradictory reactions to the act speak to the conflicted hold it has on our imaginations: revulsion mixed with fascination, scorn leavened with pity. It is a cardinal sin  but change the packaging a little, and suicide assumes the guise of heroism or high passion, the stuff of literature and art.

In those days, many of the youngsters in the neighborhood collected autographs of ballplayers, some famous and some not so famous. Most of us did it for memory  and not for money. We hunted ballpark entrances and hotel lobbies, where we could take our pads and scrapbooks to catch players in town to play New Yorks Yankees and Giants, and the Brooklyn Dodgers. Only day games were played at the time, so many players got up early and spent pregame hours sitting and schmoozing in the lobby, and maybe doing crossword puzzles.

title: Second Acts

The offense in the case of the first two narratives, which tried to pass off fantasy as fact, was merely ethical. But in the case of Bright Shiny Morning, which brims with facts but is lacking in credible fantasies, the failure is artistic  and thus, from a certain perspective, far more grievous. Freys memoirs, despite or because of their being made up, were at least somewhat stimulating in places. His novel, which isnt made up enough, is stupefying.

title: A Soaked Rider Overcomes Tourmalet
description: 7 hours after the end of the tape.  Today's ride: 105 soggy miles from Pau to Hautacam, along the route of next week's 10th stage of the Tour de France, up four climbs, two rated third-category in degree of difficulty and two rated "beyond category."   I'll be in better shape tomorrow morning to describe the whole tape experience for you in more detail -- and will post video and photos I shot during the ride to flesh it all out -- but here's what I can tell you now, in my somewhat exhausted state.  The ride was really an epic experience, in large part due to the horrible weather. It was rainy and cold throughout, particularly on the way up both of the big climbs, to the Col du Tourmalet about 60 miles in, and then to Hautacam at the end. As I mentioned in an earlier post, I was hoping to climb the mountains while being able to see them, and to descend them on dry roads, but, given that the weather in the Pyrenees is often a factor in mountain stages of the Tour de France, in a way this was probably the most appropriate way to ride the course.  The one outstanding feature of the event that made it enjoyable even when the suffering was at its most intense was the way local people lined the route from start to finish to cheer on every cyclist with the same fervor you'd expect from fans of the actual Tour.   Despite a really upset stomach from quite early on, I made it to the finish line, in the middle of a rain cloud at the top of Hautacam, in 8 hours 5 minutes -- which officially placed me 3182nd out of more than 7,500 cyclists who started the race, and 961st in my age group.   I think I probably would have done a bit better but for the stomach ailment -- which was probably caused by some combination of nerves and the failure to eat carefully enough during the last week or so (its hard to be in France and pass on the wine every night). Feeling queasy made it nearly impossible for me to eat properly during the ride (I could only force down two and a half Power Bars and about 7 gels all day).   A bit more experience with riding in the impromptu pacelines that formed again and again all throughout the course would have helped too. While I was soon both tired and desperate enough to get over my fear of riding too close to the wheels of the riders in front of me, and accepted the splattering of mud on my contacts as the price of getting some relief from the wind by drafting, a couple of times I did find myself isolated between groups on flat parts of the course, riding into the wind, and thus working harder to get to the climbs than I would've liked.  As everyone who had done it before told me, the ride was very fast at the start -- everyone treating it like a race zoomed off from the line and looked to make time before the base of Tourmalet. I shot off too, going fast, at least for me, and covered the 60 miles to Campan, where the climb really begins, in 3 hours 15 minutes. The climb of Tourmalet itself, which seemed to be much harder today than it was earlier in the week -- not surprising given 60 more miles of riding to get there plus the wind and rain -- felt like it was taking three hours, but ended up taking me only about 2 hours, from Campan, or about 15 minutes longer than it did on Tuesday. I'd chalk that up to the mad adrenaline of riding uphill surrounded by thousands of other riders.  By the way, just before I got to Tourmalet, I had the odd and very nice experience of meeting a reader of the blog who was also taking part in the Etape in the middle of a paceline, and we rode together part of the way and then also chatted at the rest stop at La Mongie -- where I did indeed stop, in a vain quest for a bathroom -- later on.   The hardest part of the day in many ways was the descent of Tourmalet, but not because -- as I'd expected and feared -- there were other riders were bombing down the hill all around me. Given the conditions, people were pretty restrained, but, since the mountain was completely shrouded in a rain cloud at the top, for much of the descent I could only see a few dozen yards and had to essentially just follow the riders in front of me on the partly invisible road toward the bends beyond which there was nothing but mist and fog.  The final climb to Hautacam was, as I'd expected, vicious, since that road snakes up the mountain in a mix of moderate and remarkably steep gradients. But, well, you know the end of the story already. Eventually I slogged my way to the top, handed in my timing transponder and got a medal.  I should also add that, except for one rider who suffered an injury, all the cyclists in the Velo Echappe group also finished the course, and that five of my fellow Tourists du Mont Blanc were on Hautacam at the same time as me (one already on his way back down). One of them, Tom, actually survived the nightmare of a puncture at high-speed on the descent of Tourmalet, and managed to repair his tire and still be standing in the line to ride back down to his car from the top of Hautacam when I got there. (Later, at the hotel, he was so unfazed by the experience that he was talking about taking on another kind of mountain climbing next: of Mont Blanc itself, with his wife.)  Phil Cavell, who built the temporary footbed that kept my toes from going numb for the first time on any ride over 30 miles, also rode the Etape and finished it nearly an hour ahead of me. (For those following the saga of my troubled right foot, the new footbed did help stave off numbness but ultimately it just wasn't broken in enough to feel totally comfortable while climbing and descending. So, I switched back to my original insoles for the ascent of Hautacam, but the lack of numbness for any part of the day obviously means that Phil has started me on the way to a permanent solution.)  I didn't see the guys from the BBC, who started close by me in the journalist peloton, after the first few miles, but I heard later that one of them had a flat that might be why only one of their names is on the list of finishers.   I'll have video and photographs for you in the morning. Thanks for the support and for all the congratulations.

title: Sarah Kane Premiere Leads Soho Rep Season
description: Sarah Kanes bleak and controversial drama Blasted, which drew outrage from audiences and critics when it had its premiere in 1995 at the Royal Court Theater Upstairs in London, will make its New York debut at SoHo Rep as the first show in that theaters 2008-9 season, the artistic director Sarah Benson has announced. Also planned for next season are Sixty Miles to Silver Lake, a two-hander about the relationship between a boy and his father, by Dan LeFranc and directed by Anne Kauffman (The Thugs), and Rambo Solo, the latest work from Nature Theater of Oklahoma, which presented No Dice at Soho Rep last year. In Rambo Solo the actor Zachary Oberzan examines his obsession with the story of Rambo: First Blood as the company tries to recount the action-adventure plot in all its cinematic glory. Ms. Kane, who also wrote 4:48 Psychosis, committed suicide in 1999 at the age of 28 but made a lasting impression. A headline over a review by the critic Jack Tinker of The Daily Mail in London called Blasted, a three-character drama involving rape and cannibalism, a disgusting feast of filth. But Harold Pinter,  Caryl Churchill and other playwrights defended it. The American premiere will star Marin Ireland, Reed Birney and Louis Cancelmi, with Ms. Benson directing. Performances are scheduled to begin Oct. 2.

title: Joan Sutherland Is Hospitalized After a Bad Fall

Her husband, the conductor Richard Bonynge, told reporters that Ms. Sutherland, right, was expected to be hospitalized for eight weeks. The couple were to travel to Australia to visit family and to allow Mr. Bonynge to prepare for performances later this month with Opera Australia. He is scheduled to conduct Lucia di Lammermoor, the same work Ms. Sutherland sang in 1959 at the Royal Opera House in London in a performance that was widely considered a breakthrough.

title: Wax Likeness of Hitler Is Attacked in Berlin
description: Opening day of the Madame Tussauds wax museum in Berlin on Saturday did not exactly go off without a hitch. A visitor shoved a guard and another employee out of the way, then ripped the head off a wax sculpture of Hitler, right, The Associated Press reported. The man was taken into custody, and the statue was temporarily removed from display. The inclusion of a Hitler likeness at the attraction had drawn criticism in the German news media before the opening, but Madame Tussauds officials said they felt strongly that Hitler was an important figure in German history and should be included. The statue was cordoned off, and the display included a sign asking visitors to refrain from taking photographs or posing with Hitler, out of respect for those who died in World War II. Visitors are permitted to photograph and pose with the collections 75 other figures.

title: Restoration and Visitors Center for Poe Cottage
description: A Bronx cottage built in 1812 and once home to Edgar Allan Poe will undergo a $250,000 face-lift. The work, to begin in the spring, will include interior painting, plasterwork and restoring shutters and shingles, The Associated Press reported. The five-room Poe Cottage, at Kingsbridge Road and the Grand Concourse, is managed by the Bronx Historical Society, and was moved to its current site, about 450 feet north of the original location, in 1913 when the house was threatened by plans to widen Kingsbridge Road. Poe lived in the house from 1846 to 1849 and wrote Annabel Lee and The Bells, among other works, while living there. His wife, Virginia, died there in 1847. In addition to the cottage restoration, Poe Park will also soon have a new $4.2 million visitors center, above, designed by the architect Toshiko Mori. The shape of the center was inspired by Poes poem The Raven, and includes an upraised V-shaped roof and dark gray shingles.

title: When Pursuing Happiness Means Taking to the Skies

He travels too much for work; she scrapbooks; they debate whether to buy a new truck or take an anniversary trip to the Maldives. If this were in Us Weekly it would be called American Muslims: Theyre Just Like Us.

title: Texas: Settlement in Habitat for Humanity Dispute

The affiliate, which operates as a separate nonprofit group but uses the Habitat name, contended that the agreement gave Habitat International too much control over its assets and operations. The settlement affirms Habitat Internationals control over the Habitat name and subjects the affiliate to the agreement but not to any changes made in the next three years unless it opts to accept them. The settlement also outlines a process for ending the affiliates relationship with Habitat International after three years should it choose to do so.

title: NBC Leads on Sunday
description: For the third consecutive Sunday, NBC led in the ratings among adults 18 to 49, thanks to coverage of the Olympic trials, followed by Dateline. According to Nielsens estimates, the two broadcasts gave NBC a slight edge over ABC for the night in the 18-to-49 set, but neither fared especially well in total viewers. The Olympic hopefuls attracted just 5.7 million viewers from 7 to 9, while Dateline earned 7.4 million from 9 to 11. Meanwhile, a two-hour Extreme Makeover: Home Edition from 8 to 10 (6.5 million) buoyed ABCs all-repeat lineup. ABC finished second in the 18-to-49 set but third in total viewers behind CBS, once again the nights most-watched network. CBS drew the largest audiences early in the night with 60 Minutes at 7 (8.1 million) and Million Dollar Password at 8 (7.5 million). A rerun of CBSs Cold Case at 9 brought 6.8 million viewers, while Numb3rs at 10 had 5.7 million. With reruns of its animated comedy lineup, Fox finished a distant fourth in total viewers but third, ahead of CBS, in the 18-to-49 set.

As a concession to its five-hour duration, he adopted a time-honored way of presenting it, with Part 1 (the first two acts, La Prise de Troie) on Saturday evening, and Part 2 (the final three acts, Les Troyens  Carthage) on Sunday afternoon.

The episodes could include musical performances, comedy skits, games and taped segments, reminiscent of classic variety shows like The Sonny and Cher Variety Hour. The four broadcast networks each bid for the Osbourne project, which will be produced by FremantleMedia North America. Mike Darnell, the president of alternative programming for Fox, said he believed that variety shows were primed for a comeback. Mr. Osbourne, who rose to fame as the lead singer for Black Sabbath in the 1970s, starred alongside his family on The Osbournes from 2002 to 2005. Ms. Osbourne is currently a judge on the NBC summer competition Americas Got Talent.

title: Retrial for Czech Artists
description: An appeals court has ordered a retrial for seven artists who hacked into a Czech television weather broadcast to show a fake nuclear explosion in the Czech mountains, The Associated Press reported. Members of the Ztohoven art group, based in Prague, admitted tampering with equipment so that viewers watching a live shot of the Krkonose Mountains in June last year saw a flash of bright light and a mushroom cloud rising on the horizon. In March the artists were acquitted of spreading false information, but the state prosecutor appealed the verdict. An appeals court in Hradec Kralove overturned the decision last week in a ruling made public on Monday, said Michal Strnad, a court spokesman. The court ordered a new trial but did not yet set a date. If found guilty, the artists face maximum jail terms of three years. The group claimed its project wanted to show how reality could be manipulated by the media. Czech Television called such stunts improper and said they could incite panic.

Our Constitution ambiguously divides war powers between the president (who is the commander in chief) and Congress (which has the power of the purse and the power to declare war). The founders hoped that the executive and legislative branches would work together, but in practice the two branches dont always consult. And even when they do, they often dispute their respective powers.

The legislation, proposed last year by a European Telecommunications commissioner, Viviane Reding, will allow regulators in the 27-member European Union to split the high-speed networks and telephone services of dominant phone companies into separate units. Telecommunications companies have opposed the legislation, which requires approval from the entire European Parliament and national governments to become law, warning that it risks of harming investments in new fiber-optic networks and does not bolster competition.

The suit seeks unspecified damages against the banks, none of which could be reached Monday for comment.

The photo archive of Mr. Treticks work, at stanleytretick.com, was created by the writer Kitty Kelley, a close friend of the photographers and the legal representative of his estate, which is making the work available to historians and libraries and for sale to collectors. During the Kennedy years Mr. Tretick was given special access to the family. One of his most famous pictures shows John Kennedy Jr. as a toddler playing under his fathers desk in the Oval Office, above. The photo was taken a month before President Kennedy was assassinated. Later Mr. Tretick became close to Senator Robert F. Kennedy and covered his presidential campaign in 1968. He covered the Senate Watergate hearings and shot stills for many films, including All the Presidents Men, Reds and The Candidate.

Among them were police officials, inspectors and the owner and manager of the club, News Divine, a dance club and drinking den that admitted children as young as 14. title: Wax Hitler Figure to Be Repaired
description: The new Madame Tussauds museum in Berlin said a wax figure of Adolf Hitler whose head was ripped off would be put back on display once it is repaired, Agence France-Press reported. On Saturday, just after the museum opened, a former police officer evaded security guards and tore the head off the figure, which depicts Hitler looking grim and defeated seated behind a desk in a re-creation of his bunker. The incident has attracted widespread news coverage and commentary, including accusations that the museums decision to include a Hitler figure was in bad taste and was made only to generate publicity. A spokeswoman for Madame Tussauds told the news agency the statue would return to its place in the museums history section as soon as possible. Adolf Hitler represents a defining moment in German history that cannot be denied, she said, adding that the display was created with sensitivity and respect. The 41-year-old who was arrested, identified only as Frank L., told reporters that he came up with the idea over drinks with friends, who dared him to do it; he said he now regretted it. I did not do it for money, nor for fame, he told the online edition of the newspaper Die Welt (welt.de), though I suppose I will now be famous for a while.

title: Maine: Woman Appeals Annulment of Her Adoption
description: The adoption of a woman by her lesbian partner 17 years ago in Maine has been annulled, and the woman has filed an appeal in the State Supreme Court, according to recently unsealed documents. The case involves Olive F. Watson, 60, the granddaughter of the founder of I.B.M. and the daughter of Thomas J. Watson Jr., the companys longtime chief executive. In 1991, Ms. Watson adopted Patricia Ann Spado, now 60, in Maine, where the women spent several weeks each summer at the Watson compound on the island of North Haven. The purpose of the adoption, Ms. Spado said in court documents, was to allow her to qualify as an heir to Ms. Watsons fortune. A year after the adoption, the women broke up. Now, with both of Ms. Watsons parents dead, Ms. Spado is seeking to qualify as Mr. Watsons 19th grandchild and a beneficiary of his trusts. The Watson family, including Olive, is fighting Ms. Spados claim. In April, the probate judge who granted the adoption annulled it on the grounds that the women did not meet residency requirements. Ms. Spados lawyers filed an appeal on July 2.

title: Brazil: Embraer Overcomes Bottleneck

Fifty-two planes were shipped from April through June, compared with 36 a year earlier, the company said. Embraer, as the company is known, reiterated plans to deliver as many as 215 jets this year. Production bottlenecks slowed deliveries in late 2006 and in early 2007. Embraer remedied the problem by replacing suppliers, adding about 4,500 workers and purchasing more machinery. Demand for its Phenom business jets helped its backlog climb to a record $20.7 billion. Its stock rose 4.8 percent.

Mr. Leoni-Sceti, who will take over on Oct. 1 as the chief executive of EMI Music, is the latest in a string of recruits from outside the music business. The company, which has sustained heavy losses in recent years, releases music by the Beatles, Coldplay, Norah Jones and others. Born in Rome, Mr. Leoni-Sceti currently serves as an executive vice president at Reckitt Benckiser, which owns brands including Lysol and Woolite. In an interview on Monday, he said he believed that understanding music consumers was crucial to turning around the company. Understanding where they will need music in the future, where they will go, how they will interact with it, Mr. Leoni-Sceti said, and try to position the company so that you are there first.

description: A front-page article on Tuesday about alcohol and drug abuse among combat veterans of Iraq and Afghanistan described incorrectly the circumstances under which a former marine convicted of vehicular manslaughter, Anthony Klecker, was forced to leave an inpatient treatment program for alcoholism and combat stress. According to the prosecutor, Mr. Klecker was removed from the program because he twice got into heated arguments with other patients, not because he pulled a pocket knife on another patient. While Mr. Klecker did possess a pocket knife, he did not threaten anyone with it and it was not a factor in his having to leave the program, the prosecutor said.

description: PITTSBURGH  The Iraqi governments decision to raise the possibility of making a scheduled withdrawal of American troops a part of an agreement on their future status in Iraq poses special complications for Senator John McCain, whose opposition to a timetable for withdrawal is central to his candidacy.

title: Rebirth of the Cool
description: Is your refrigerator running?  I'm not kidding -- is it?   My old refrigerator provided constant (and unpleasant) white noise throughout our house while we fretted over whether it was more "green" to keep it (and thus not contribute more waste to landfill) or to replace it with a more energy-efficient model. The refrigerator made the decision for us by dying a sudden death; its Energy Star replacement is silent and has cut our electricity bills significantly. Refrigerators -- and dishwashers, washers and dryers -- have gotten sleeker and more functional in recent years, the manufacturers motivated in part by late '90s legislation that mandated 30 percent increases in energy efficiency. (Though the recent appearance of televisions in refrigerator doors gives me pause.)   But another energy-sucking appliance has fallen behind: the air conditioner.   (Photo: Courtesy of Modern Fan) There are many alternatives to air conditioning, from ceiling fans (there are lots of stylish ones these days, including the high design group available at Modern Fan to good old-fashioned awnings, which you may be surprised to learn can reduce household cooling energy by as much as 26 percent in hot climates and 33 percent in cold climates.   Major corporations like Credit Suisse and Morgan Stanley have ventured back even further, using blocks of ice  albeit really huge blocks of ice  to cool their corporate headquarters.   Quaint, no? But so incredibly logical. And of course, the D.I.Y. crowd are tinkering away in their respective garages to create geeky but wonderful alternatives like the one I found on the quirky site instructables.com: an air conditioner made from an ice cream box, an 80-millimeter fan and a 12-volt transformer.   But most of us simply trudge off to Best Buy or Circuit City as soon as temperatures spike and buy the most powerful thing we can afford, more concerned with sweating less than with altering the course of global warming. Air conditioners, those clunky, typically inefficient creatures, have gotten short shrift in the realm of energy efficient appliances: consumers have been well-educated about the cost- and energy-saving benefits of Energy Star-rated dishwashers, dryers and frontloading washers, but as common as central air is, the lowly air conditioner exists in our collective imagination as the hulking, droning, aesthetically challenging thing that it often still is.   A more human-centered design approach has resulted in some interesting alternatives, often focusing on maintaining a comfortable temperature for the individual rather than the whole house (or office). This approach abandons the premise of central air conditioning in favor of what is sometimes termed "personal climate control." Both at home, where we tend to stay in certain areas for extended periods of time, and at work, where temperature control is often among the top five worker complaints, this idea makes good sense.   DeLonghi delivers a near-anthropomorphic version with the Pinguino, a compact, portable unit designed to cool only the room you are occupying. (Photo: Courtesy of Herman Miller) Herman Miller, a furniture company known for its commitment to energy and waste reduction, earth-friendly materials and sustainable architecture (its Michigan headquarters were designed by the green building pioneer William McDonough), offers an even smaller device for workspaces designed to keep its owner cool  or warm, depending on the season.   (Photo: Courtesy of Herman Miller) Part of the company Be Collection, the tiny C2 heats and cools but uses less than 1.5 amps of AC current, which is approximately 90 percent less energy than a typical space heater.   (Photo: Courtesy of SunFrost) The award for the oddest but well-intentioned attempt (and most appropriate for use in long-haul trucks and insane asylums of yore) goes to the Sleep Genie by Sun Frost. Acknowledging the challenge of cooling in hotter climates, Sun Frost proposes installing a very small air conditioner within a very small area, like the insulated space around one's bed shown here.   Great. You may be cooler, but now you're claustrophobic.   Sun Frost's concept is not inherently different from DeLonghi's or Herman Miller's, though its execution speaks to a larger issue: a general lack of innovation. Instead of re-imagining what an air conditioner could be (something portable, something that took a different form, something that ran on an alternative energy source), they simply took the existing form and shrank it.   This seems to me indicative of so much that's happening right now with other big-ticket items like homes and cars. Lower gas prices, for example, do not solve the problem of decreasing supply and increased demand for oil. Home designs that neglect to address things like natural light and ventilation are not contributing to quality of life, let alone reducing heating and cooling costs. The gas/driving issue requires a tremendous commitment to not only alternative fuels but alternative behaviors (i.e., walking, carpooling, mass transit); as for housing, the challenges are formidable, yet a quick look back to vernacular precedents like shotgun houses that encourage ventilation, and window orientation that encourages passive heating and cooling, would help point things in the right direction.   What is everyone waiting for?

title: Starting Businesses as an Encore for Women
description: Over the past holiday weekend, I visited my mother at the beach town in New Jersey where she spends her summers enjoying the pace of seaside living. It is still unusual for me to see my mother this way because until she retired a few years ago, she worked every summer day running our family business, a motel she managed with my father and then took over when he passed away nearly 20 years ago.
