title: Blogtalk: Obama's F.I.S.A. Vote
description: It should come as no surprise to Senator Barack Obama that his vote today in favor of expanding the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act is drawing cries of outrage from many corners of the liberal blogosphere. After all, the senator's own campaign Web site had become a focal point for his supporters to express their displeasure with Mr. Obama's stance on the bill.  That was the case again today. Carl from Ft. Worth, Texas, posted a message on Mr. Obama's Web site this afternoon. The subject line read: "Obama just lost my vote." He continued:  "I am disgusted. Obama will NOT receive my vote in November, regardless of whether it means McCain wins (at least HE'S being honest with us). Once again, Dems picked the wrong guy in the primaries. Time to leave the party I guess."   Other comments struck much the same theme. Patrick in Chicago wrote "Can I get my money back this candidate appears to be defective" and Christopher from San Francisco put it simply "Senator Obama, you fail."  Ouch.  (Recall that Mr. Obama tried to calm his critics last week with a statement on his site emphasizing that his position on the surveillance plan, "...was not an easy call.")  Armando Llorens, who blogs under the name Big Tent Democrat, at TalkLeft.com took issue with the comments Mr. Obama made yesterday saying that his support for the bill was not politically motivated, but rather represents a genuine policy disagreement with more liberal elements of the Democratic Party:  "I do not believe Barack Obama. I will go further. I do not want to believe him. Because the alternative is worse. Because if Obama believes the BS he said about the FISA Capitulation bill, then he is not fit to be President. If Barack Obama really believes this about the FISA Capitulation bill, then he is as dangerous as George W. Bush."   Mr. Obama's vote for the bill, which provides legal immunity for phone companies that participated in the government's wiretapping program, represents a reversal for the presumptive Democratic nominee. He previously opposed that provision. Senator John McCain, the presumptive Republican nominee, was not present for the vote.   The F.I.S.A. bill passed 69 to 28 in the Senate today, and a number of prominent Democratic senators, including Majority Leader Harry Reid of Nevada, Chuck Schumer of New York, Chris Dodd of Connecticut and Mr. Obama's former rival, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, voted against it. (Here's the official tally of individual votes.)  In a statement released by her Senate office today Mrs. Clinton said: "While this legislation does strengthen oversight of the administration's surveillance activities over previous drafts, in many respects, the oversight in the bill continues to come up short." The statement continues:  "...even as we considered this legislation, the administration refused to allow the overwhelming majority of Senators to examine the warrantless wiretapping program. This made it exceedingly difficult for those senators who are not on the Intelligence and Judiciary Committees to assess the need for the operational details of the legislation, and whether greater protections are necessary. The same can be said for an assessment of the telecom immunity provisions.  On an issue of such tremendous importance to our citizens  and in particular to New Yorkers  all senators should have been entitled to receive briefings that would have enabled them to make an informed decision about the merits of this legislation. I cannot support this legislation when we know neither the nature of the surveillance activities authorized nor the role played by telecommunications companies granted immunity."    Blogging on Open Left, Matt Stoller wrote: "It's interesting to consider how Clinton would have voted were she the nominee, and there's no way to know now." But, he added, "kudos to Clinton. It's ironic so far I suppose that Clinton is of late a more reliable ally than Obama, at least on this issue."   Senator Obama received some support from the blogger HatchInBrooklyn who posted on the popular liberal site, DailyKos, that "it's time to put the 'Obama Caved On FISA' talk to an end":  "The FISA bill is obviously imperfect, but I do not believe that a serious Presidential candidate can afford to vote 'no' on legislation that is intended to help prevent terrorist attacks. If Obama were to oppose the bill as a whole, he would be handing McCain -- who didn't even bother to show up and vote today -- a huge opening to scare voters and paint Obama as weak on terrorism."   "No. No no no no no. No," replied Josh Orton of MyDD. "Democrats must always stand against Republicans on national security - because Republicans have proven miserable failures on national security, and yet still try to politically intimidate Democrats by painting them as weaklings yearning to surrender."  Moe Lane at the conservative blog, Red State, appeared to relish Mr. Obama's stand on the F.I.S.A. bill: "the netroots went with the equivocator. Barack Obama brazenly lied to them about his intent to filibuster FISA, and they support him anyway. And now they have to go give him some more money, so that he can lie to them some more."

title: Words and Bridges
description: "Where's that confounded bridge?"  -- Led Zeppelin, "The Crunge"   Cloudy afternoon today, perfect weather for some more work on the song. Sometimes you see something better when the light is indirect and less intense.  I have direction on both a verse and a chorus for what's provisionally called "It's All Talk" and some words that are telling me where to go (maybe telling someone else where to go also). But there is something missing that I need to address soon. It'll be a part, or parts, that will help me keep my interest in the song by taking the melody and chords to a whole 'nother place, hopefully doing the same for the attention span of anyone who hears it.   Now, "Louie Louie," by Richard Berry, does not have a bridge. And it's a great, maybe the great, rock and roll song. So bridges are not necessary in the pursuit of a superior song. But they can be a great aid to the songwriter who feels like there's a missing piece that can tie the song together structurally, who wants to pack more song into the song.   When I played in Rittenhouse Square as an impressionable teen rocker, I noticed that my bandmate Mitch Easter wrote tunes that inevitably had a third (or fourth) part, loosely connected to the bulk of the composition.   These sections would drive the band off into another zone entirely, eventually wending their way back to the verses and choruses. Sometimes the melody would stay the same over different chords, sometimes vice versa. Lyrically it was pretty open, too; it could shift to another person's perspective altogether, or it could plumb a different and metaphorical "depth" of the theme of the words. You could infuse it with tempo shifts, key changes and lead guitar breaks, and somehow return to the comfort of the established structure.   I've spent the rest of my natural-born adult career adding this fine key to progress to almost all my songs. They are often the most melodic sections, and often they've arrived simply by starting to roll the recording tape at home and seeing where my hands take the chords after the chorus. I've tried on occasion to write the bridge-free song, but I'm not real keen on what I came up with; they seem monochromatic and unfinished.  Usually, a fair amount of time goes into tweaking the front and back end of the bridge. You want to aim for a smooth takeoff and especially a soft landing with your chord progression, or the transitions will be irritating to the ear of the casual listener. Often you have to work backwards for a few chords from the end of the bridge, just to see how to try to connect them seamlessly.  The one in "Molly Says" was a lot different before Greg Edward, who produced "The Sound of Music" for the dB's in 1987, got a hold of it. It was already the second attempt at a bridge in the song, and Greg left the front alone but retooled the ending so it broke open wide and into a short backward guitar solo. I think it was very succinct, where my earlier attempts had been fussy and overcomplicated.        ("Molly" has a dwindling structure for its verses. Each one is two lines shorter than its predecessor. So by the time the bridge comes up, it's time to send the song off on a tangent. Lyrically, I've moved to the concept of "Molly says, in a number of ways, I remind her of her old man." I tried to flesh it out as smartly as I could. Greg didn't feel that the bridge needed to be quite as long, so he truncated it very nicely.)  Bridges can set up nice, if temporary, modulations into other keys. And they can drag a song's momentum down to a crawl by making the drummer play half-time. A good bridge alone cannot save a bad song, but a bad bridge can ruin a good one.  That said, I am not sure what sort of bridge to put into this song that will make sense. The new regimen of odd little passing chords suggests that the bridge might want to be streamlined and free of filigree. It might benefit from some long, slow lines that iron out the choppiness of the chorus rhythm, so I'll try that. And I'd still like to try making a little "song within a song" and see if that's relevant.  But I'm as far away from a guitar right now as I can be -- mine's packed in a truck in New Jersey, I think. I can use my right forearm as a guitar neck if I want to make chords with my left hand's fingers -- fortunately, I'm alone in a hotel room, since it looks a little awkward. At least I don't draw the frets on my arm anymore like I did as a kid.   That kind of desperate move is not really pressing right now. Tomorrow, I'll have my road gear accessible before and after sound check, and that can be where I do my bridge construction.  ****  Meanwhile, I can do a little touch-up on the lyrics I have so far. The situation that was the impetus for the words is still ongoing, but the resolution seems predestined now, which wasn't the case when I started writing the song. Does that change the feeling of the words, now that I know what I'm doing? Maybe a little. I can write it from the end, too, like a bridge. It helps to know the end of the story, but I'd like to make sure there's some of the initial insecurity somewhere inside the first part of the lyrics.   (Photo: A plate of lyrics (Peter Holsapple)) Here are some of my keepers (transcribed from a paper plate I used while camping):   It's all talk, it's all talk What I'm hearing is all talk Take it all with a grain of salt 'Til something happens, I will  Promises made, promises broken Half of what's said is left unspoken Did I hear what I think you said Or was it something else instead?  Oh, the silences you keep Are they special, just for me? And what exactly do you do with your time That it makes it more important than mine?  It's all talk, it's all talk And when it was, it was small talk Handshake and a back pat Couldn't get any smaller than that  I'll do my job and I'll do my best It's up to you to do the rest What you see, well, that's just me But I'll try to be what you want me to be  It's what you want, it's what you have. It's what you need, you understand. It don't come easy and at a price Just come clean and try to play nice.  Well, it's a start.  Several years ago, I was let out of my contract with a major unnamed publishing company with the warning that my songs were too personal. That was a blessing to know. In my efforts to fudge the details in a lyric line, I still need to get the thought across to someone listening. This new song is highly personal, but my hope is that I can make it a little more universal. It could be anyone's situation, and I need to get that across. Anyone who has ever had to go at it with a boss should be able to relate to what I'm saying.  It's not a very sunshiny song, is it.

title: Mountain Madness
description: (Photo: Mount McKinley. (Michael DeYoung/Alaska Stock))   For nearly two weeks, a friend of mine had been trying to reach the roof of North America, a place no bigger than a dining room rug, about 200 miles south of the Arctic circle. He's a restless soul, briskly roaming the world in search of thin air before he gets too worn and cautious in late middle-age.   Last I checked, he was pinned at high camp by the kind of storms that keep nearly half of the 1,400 people who attempt to climb Mount McKinley from succeeding. Winds, 60 to 70 miles an hour. Temperatures, even in the first weeks of summer, hovering near zero.   Then came sudden news  a 51-year-old man had died on Denali, as most Alaskans call the mountain. He made it to the top on the Fourth of July, and then collapsed  the first climber ever to die on the mountain's summit. He was buried in a frozen grave at 20,320 feet.  It took a few hours before I confirmed the name of the dead climber. I was relieved, of course, that it was not my friend, but I found no comfort in the details of the death.   The victim, James Nasti from Naperville, Ill., was an experienced mountaineer, with no history of heart trouble, and had shown no signs of altitude sickness. He belonged to a club whose members try to reach the highest point in all 50 states. For James Nasti, Denali was number 49.  Whenever anyone dies in the mountains, I have the same, inevitable conversation with climbing friends. It happened just a month ago, when a 31-year-old man died in a snowstorm during a day hike on Mount Rainier, a big volcano whose summit I've sworn off after a scary climb a couple of years ago.   We always start with this question: How did they mess up? We look for obvious mistakes and easy answers: a rope not properly attached, a crevasse that should never have been crossed and, most often, a weather forecast that went unheeded.   A wise group of Rainier climbing veterans, including some of the first Americans to make it up Mount Everest, have a saying whenever they tell war stories: There are old climbers and bold climbers, but no old, bold climbers.  With mountaineering fatalities, the cases without apparent human error are the most maddening, and troubling.   So it was on Denali. James Nasti was on a guided climb, led by world-class alpinists. By all accounts, he had been cautious, and was in great shape for his age. The weather was fine. He had done nothing foolish, taken no missteps. Having reached the highest point in North America, one of the premier mountaineering achievements in the world, he simply fell back and died, the 101st death on the mountain since 1932. An autopsy, if his body is ever removed, may yet provide some answers.   Then, on Monday, while people were still puzzling over Nasti's collapse, came word of another sudden and seemingly inexplicable death.   A 20-year-old climber from Indonesia, Pungkas Tri Baruno, died near a 17,200-foot base camp while descending from Denali's summit. He stopped walking, stopped breathing, fell to the snow and died, just like James Nasti.  These men, Baruno and Nasti, will soon join the other names on the granite memorial at Denali's base. It doesn't provide much of a consistent narrative, but it does give you a sense of the odds.   For every death on the mountain, about 500 people will make the summit. An 11-year-old boy and a 76-year-old man  the youngest and oldest summiteers  have looked out from that glorious place in the Alaska Range where you run out of earth.   Death can come from crossing the street, or eating a tomato. My first literary agent, a wonderful woman with a full life ahead of her, was killed by a bus in Manhattan. Why not experience the heightened sense of living that comes from getting closer to the edge  controlled risk, in the mountains or on a wild river? So goes my internal palaver whenever I think of what happened on Denali.   The other side of the argument is about loved ones, the people who are left behind.   In his book "Into Thin Air," Jon Krakauer chronicled the deadly 1996 season on Everest, a story of hubris and tragic miscalculations that has since been told from multiple points of view, by various survivors. Climbing Everest, Krakauer wrote, is "an intrinsically irrational act."  One of the dead was Scott Fischer, a guide from Seattle. Fischer was charismatic, with chiseled good looks that seemed to come from the mountain gods, an alpine stud in the eyes of his clients. He also had two young kids, who went to the same elementary school as my children.   When Fischer died I saw a mountaineering death, for the first time, from a different point of view: that of the surviving children.   In reading about Jim Nasti's death on the summit of Denali, then, the thing that stayed with me were the details about his family. The calculus of risk is different for everyone. But on the Fourth of July, atop the nation's highest mountain, one man's personal glory was swiftly transformed.  He was mountaineer, a great one for a moment  and then he was a father of three boys gone, a husband no more.

title: McCain Ad Has a Familiar Ring
description: The closing line of Senator John McCains most recent advertisement  Dont hope for a better life; vote for one  is supposed to be a dig at Senator Barack Obamas mantra of hope. But the line is hardly original; as the liberal blog Talking Points Memo noted this week, the slogan was also used in a spot for the Conservative Party of Margaret Thatcher in the late 1970s.

title: Sex, Drugs and Insurance
description: The normally voluble Senator John McCain found himself at a loss for words Wednesday when he was asked aboard his campaign bus on its way to Portsmouth, Ohio, whether he thought it was fair that some health insurance companies covered Viagra but not birth control.

title: Your Comments on my Genocide Column
description: My Thursday column asks: Is genocide really that bad? Perhaps not surprisingly, I think it is. Sure, lots more people may die from disease or chaos and banditry, but genocide seems to me the ultimate human crime and thus deserves a top priority response.

title: Munsons Baseball Memorabilia
description: A slide show of Thurman Munson memorabilia that will be auctioned by his widow.

title: A New York Man Dies in Hot Car, and His Son Is Charged
description: PEEKSKILL, N.Y.  Some days, the middle-aged bus driver would drop his frail parents off at the Muddy Cup coffee house in Beacon, where the three lived together in a big, brown Victorian house with bubble-gum pink trim. Other days, the driver, Theodore Pressman, would bring the couple into the Atrium Caf and Deli less than a quarter mile from his job with a transportation company here, set them up with tea or coffee, and return a few hours later.

title: Tip of the Week: Turning Flickr Photos Into Desktop Wallpaper
description: If you hate to be without your Flickr photos while doing other things on the computer, you can still keep them close. Johns Background Switcher (www.johnsadventures.com/software/backgroundswitcher), a free application for Windows, or Desklickr for the Mac (desklickr.isnot.tv) can grab your Flickr images from the Web and turn them into ever-changing desktop wallpaper.

title: Dow Chemical in Bhopal
description: To the Editor:

title: Standing the Heat
description: Foxs finale of Hells Kitchen led Tuesday nights ratings among adults 18 to 49, concluding a strong fourth season of the series, which was up by an average of 15 percent in that demographic from last summer. Although the finale drew just a modest audience of 8.8 million in total viewers, according to Nielsens estimates, the show still dominated its 9 oclock competitors among the 18-to-49 set. The competition included Americas Got Talent on NBC, the nights most-watched show, with 12.4 million total viewers. For the night over all, NBC averaged the most total viewers, drawing decent ratings at both 8 and 10 with Celebrity Family Feud (7.5 million) and a repeat of Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (7.2 million). But NBC trailed among adults 18 to 49, behind Fox and ABC, which tied for first. ABCs 8 oclock reality show Wipeout nearly matched Hells Kitchen in the 18-to-49 set, while attracting 10.6 million total viewers. ABCs 9 and 10 oclock offerings, I Survived a Japanese Game Show (6.8 million) and Primetime: The Outsiders (7.1 million), also fared better than Foxs 8 oclock game show, The Moment of Truth (5 million).

title: Cholesterol Drugs for 8-Year-Olds
description: We were appalled when we first heard that the American Academy of Pediatrics has recommended that some children as young as 8 be given drugs to reduce their cholesterol levels  and that they could end up taking these drugs for the rest of their lives. After reading the academys report, we are now more dismayed about what this recommendation says about childrens health.

title: Yahoo Is Inviting Partners to Build on Its Search Power
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Unable to beat Google in the Web search business on its own, Yahoo is trying a new approach.

title: Stepping Out in Public to the Beat of a Chat on Civics
description: I have an idea that if I bide my time, Ill get to see site-specific dancing outside every major building and monument in New York. The World Financial Center, the New York Stock Exchange, the United States Custom House: my first visit to each of these was to see dancing outside them. And this happy tourism is the intention of Sitelines, the performance series organized by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council as part of the River to River Festival. That suits the sightseer in me very well; as a recent resident here I know there are still city highlights for me to discover and others that I pass without knowing their identities.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 20 about the pressures on Chinese athletes to win Olympics medals misstated the scope and date of a doping scandal involving athletes who had trained under Ma Junren, a legendary Chinese coach. Six were withdrawn from Olympics competition in 2000  not "many" in the late 1990s. The article also overstated what is known about their suspected substance abuse. While China never officially confirmed why they were withdrawn, the six were found to have unacceptably high blood levels of recombinant human erythropoietin, or EPO, a banned drug that enhances the performance of endurance athletes by accelerating production of oxygen-carrying red blood cells. They did not test positive for steroids.

title: Shielding Devices From Big Zaps
description: ALTHOUGH summer has just begun, the weather in many parts of the country has been unduly hot, accompanied by thunderstorms, lightning and power failures. Fluctuations in electrical service, whether because appliances cycle on and off or because of a lightning strike or damage to power lines, can lead to power surges that can damage sophisticated electronics in home appliances.

title: At the Beach, Comfort of Home
description: ANY beachgoer knows how frustrating it can be to lug an unwieldy cooler full of sandwiches and drinks across the sand for a day in the sun, only to have the ice inside melt and the cold drinks become less than refreshing later in the day. This summers lineup of beach-worthy ice chests solves both of those problems, with rugged wheels for easier transport, telescoping handles for one-hand portability and multiday insulation technology that keeps ice frozen for days and saves trips to the store.

title: Needing Pitching, Yankees Opt to Keep Young Talent
description: Hal Steinbrenner has not publicly committed to keeping Brian Cashman as the general manager of the Yankees. But for months, he has supported Cashmans philosophy of building the Yankees through the farm system, low-risk trades and occasional free-agent spending.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on June 28 about the classical pianist Leonard Pennario erroneously credited a distinction to Miklos Rozsa, who composed a concerto for Mr. Pennario. Mr. Rozsa, an Academy Award winner for his scores for the movies Spellbound, A Double Life and Ben-Hur, was nominated in 1960 for a Grammy Award for the soundtrack album from Ben-Hur, but he never won a Grammy.

title: An Open-Source Cellphone (Tinkerers, Have a Ball)
description: Few of us want to get our hands dirty messing with the operating system in our cellphones, but sometimes its nice to know you could if the need arose. The Neo FreeRunner from Openmoko is a completely open-source cellphone with a few interesting high-end features.

title: Hunts Point Residents Sue Over a Smell
description: Claiming that odors from two nearby sewage plants have at times made them nauseous, forced them to stay indoors and possibly even caused medical problems, a group of residents in the South Bronx is suing the city and the owner of one of the plants.

title: Ups and Downs for Older Cities in Population Report
description: In a modest reversal, Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, San Diego and some of the nations other older cities registered small gains in population in the year ending July 2007, while others slowed their declines, according to census figures released Thursday.

title: Officials Investigate 3 Alabama Counties in Voter Fraud Accusations
description: MARION, Ala.  Federal and state authorities are looking into accusations of voting fraud in three largely black counties of Alabama, including Perry and Lowndes Counties, which played a historic role in the struggle for black voting rights in the 1960s.

title: A Writer to Bet On
description: Salman Rushdie is considered the favorite to win the Best of the Booker award on Thursday, at least among oddsmakers surveyed by Reuters. The award coincides with the 40th anniversary of one of the worlds most sought-after literary prizes. Mr. Rushdie, whose 1988 novel, The Satanic Verses, angered some Muslims and prompted death threats against him, was the overwhelming 1-to-8 front-runner for Midnights Children, which won the Booker Prize in 1981. His competition includes J. M. Coetzee and Nadine Gordimer, each a Nobel Prize winner, among others. Nick Weinberg of the bookmakers Ladbrokes said Mr. Rushdie had attracted 90 percent of all wagers on the Best of the Booker award.

title: The Audacity of Listening
description: We have to have a talk about Barack Obama.

title: Kennedy Returns to Help Pass Medicare Bill
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy made an extraordinary return to the Senate on Wednesday to deliver Democrats a decisive victory on a signature health care issue despite his own treatment for brain cancer.

description: Johan Santana was the starter Wednesday, which meant that it was about time for the teams eight position players to paw at the snooze button and count on Santana to win another game all by himself.

description: PARIS  There are relationships for which a novel is a more adequate form than journalism. Their twists, and attendant psyches, demand an act of the imagination to render them. Into that category falls the recurrent charged drama of Anthony Lake and Richard Holbrooke.

description: DAKAR, Senegal  Seven international peacekeepers were killed and 22 wounded in a brazen day ambush by heavily armed men in trucks and on horseback in the Sudanese province of Darfur, United Nations officials said Wednesday.

description: Bloomberg L.P., the financial news and data company founded by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, announced a revamping on Wednesday intended to play up its growing assets in television, radio and Internet content.

description: An article in some copies on June 27 about elite young basketball players who were filmed in 2006 for a documentary misidentified the Oregon hometown of one player, Kyle Singler. He is from Medford, not Portland.

description: In years to come, when the oil-and-gas billionaire David H. Koch attends a gala performance of New York City Ballet or City Opera at Lincoln Center, the building he enters in black tie will bear his name.

description: East Rutherford, N.J.

description: Some of my tried-and-true favorites appear below, along with a few new varieties to try in a midsummer garden.

title: The Government and Your Laptop
description: The Department of Homeland Security is routinely searching laptops at airports when Americans re-enter the United States from abroad. The government then pores over or copies the laptops contents  including financial records, medical data and e-mail messages. These out-of-control searches trample the privacy rights of Americans, and Congress should rein them in.

title: After 3rd Climber, Times Alters Its Buildings Facade
description: The New York Times began removing dozens of the distinctive horizontal ceramic rods that sheathe its year-old building in Midtown Manhattan on Wednesday afternoon, hours after a man climbed up the side of the skyscraper. It was the third time such a stunt had occurred in the last five weeks.

title: Surgery Cancels Tour
description: Victor Willis, the original lead singer of the Village People, who performed dressed as a helmeted policeman, underwent surgery at a San Diego hospital on Monday to remove nodules from his vocal cords, a spokeswoman told Reuters. As a result of the surgery, Mr. Willis, who wrote the hits Y.M.C.A. and Macho Man, has been forced to cancel a solo American tour. The spokeswoman told Reuters that she expected him to make a full recovery and that a new tour could begin as soon as October.

title: Easley Focusing on Hot Streak, Not on Where Hell Fit In
description: Damion Easley was in the Mets lineup Wednesday against the San Francisco Giants, batting fifth and playing second base. He was happy to have a chance to extend his hot streak and was not worried about his future.

title: Indian Bank Says Its Time to Take On Acquisitions
description: LONDON  ICICI Bank, one of the largest in India, is considering acquisitions to expand outside its home market at a time when many foreign rivals are struggling because of tight credit markets, two of the banks executives said in an interview on Wednesday.

title: Container Gardens Have Their Own Needs
Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a demand by New York City taxi drivers that the Taxi and Limousine Commission impose a fuel surcharge on fares misspelled the given name of a taxi owner-operator in some editions. He is Loubert Alexander, not Lubert.

title: Interpublic Tries Once Again to Group Media Operations
description: The Interpublic Group of Companies, the worlds third-largest advertising agency holding company, is reorganizing its media operations again in another sign of the growing importance of tasks like deciding where marketers place ads, how much they pay and how they apportion ads between the traditional and digital media.

title: Pentagon Gives Boeing New Chance at Contract
description: The Pentagon announced on Wednesday that it would reopen bidding on a $35 billion contract for midair refueling tankers, allowing Boeing to continue its effort to wrest the business from a partnership of Northrop Grumman and the European parent of its rival Airbus.

title: For Knitting Factory, Westward Ho (Brooklyn, Too)
description: Jared Hoffman has a vision for the Knitting Factory: smaller, leaner and outside of Manhattan. Far outside.

title: Global Warming Talks Leave Few Concrete Goals
description: Nearly everyone had something to cheer about on Wednesday after the major industrial powers and a big group of emerging nations pledged to pursue deep cuts in emissions of heat-trapping gases in coming decades.

title: Waiting Until Very End for a Tour Breakthrough
description: CHTEAUROUX, France  On the longest stage of this years Tour de France, it all came down to the last 80 yards.

title: F.D.A. Revises Its Letter for Nonapproval of Drugs
description: Drug makers whose products are not ready for approval in the United States will soon get the word from regulators in a new format intended partly to avoid scaring investors.

title: A U.S.B. Microphone for Podcasts, or Solo Side Projects
description: Once upon a time, all that singer-songwriters needed was a six-string and a dream. Now they could also use a G-Track U.S.B. microphone.

title: City Will Explore Broad Bike-Sharing Plan
description: The city took a tentative step this week toward fulfilling the dream of a certain kind of urban idealist, saying that it will explore the possibility of creating a bike-sharing program that could make hundreds or even thousands of bicycles available for public use.

title: Victory in Different Race
description: Annette Bening, below, who has been nominated for an Academy Award three times, has been elected to the governing board of the organization that gives out the Oscars, according to Reuters. Ms. Bening, 50, who is married to Warren Beatty, joins the 43-member Board of Governors of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. It draws up the rules and regulations for administering the awards.

title: Reversal at the Top
description: Lil Wayne and Coldplay switch places on the Billboard chart this week: Lil Waynes Tha Carter III (Cash Money/Universal Motown), which was No. 2 for two weeks, returns to the top spot in its fourth week of release, with sales of 156,000, according to Nielsen SoundScan. That was 25 percent fewer than Tha Carter had the week before, but Coldplays Viva la Vida or Death and All His Friends (Capitol) had a bigger drop. It sold 149,000, a weekly loss of 40 percent, sending the album to No. 2 after two weeks in the lead. Disneys soundtrack to Camp Rock remains at No. 3 with 116,000, and the next two spots on the chart are new. G-Unit, the rap crew led by 50 Cent, sold 102,000 copies of T.O.S. (Terminate on Sight) (G-Unit/Interscope), bowing at No. 4, and John Mayers live album, Where the Light Is (Columbia), is No. 5 with 75,000. Down the chart, the Kansas City rapper Tech N9nes Killer (Strange) opened at No. 12, and Alkaline Trios Agony & Irony (Epic) opened at No. 13.

title: Using Star Power to Repair Nigerias Image
description: LAGOS, Nigeria  Its hard to rehabilitate a country  especially Nigeria, best known these days for violence in the oil-producing Niger Delta.

title: Churchs Concussion Spurs Union to Request Guidelines
description: The players union plans to approach Major League Baseball about developing formal leaguewide guidelines for managing concussions, a high-level union official said Wednesday.

title: Rooms to Stop the Young From Straying
description: FOR Keith and Tracy Tobias, the parents of three teenagers in La Quinta, Calif., turning an old workshop behind their house into a movie theater for their children was an obvious move. Were very social and our kids have grown up with that, Ms. Tobias said. Were a party family. In fact, the couples reasons had to do with more than their love of fun. The Tobiases were looking for a way to keep their children at home.

title: A More Confident Iraq Becomes a Tougher Negotiating Partner for the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush administrations quest for a deal with Iraq that would formally authorize an unlimited American troop presence there well beyond President Bushs tenure appears to be unraveling. The irony is that it may be a victim of the administrations successes in the war.

title: Fatigue Is a 2nd Danger for California Firefighters
description: CONCOW, Calif., July 9  For the men from the Lathrop-Manteca firehouse gathered near a smoldering subdivision called Camelot, the weariness hangs like smoke around them. The extent and intensity of the fires that have gouged the landscape across the state is something they have never seen.

title: A Designer Dips Into Nostalgia for an Assisted Living Center
description: Brett Beldock, a Manhattan interior designer, was thinking about El Morocco and the Monkey Bar when she designed the interiors of a new assisted living facility, the Lodge at Otter Creek, in Middlebury, Vt. That was their heyday, Ms. Beldock said, referring to the facilitys intended residents. She also was imagining a preppy New England vernacular, with framed botanicals, woodland creatures and the like. These nostalgic touchstones collide in oversize, graphic imagery meant to soothe and elate the inhabitants.

title: The Baroque, the Modern and the Harpsichord
description: The concert presented by the Washington Square Music Festival on Tuesday night was technically the second of its season; an event in June, part of the citywide Make Music New York celebration, featured blues and Celtic folk acts. But this was the more auspicious occasion, for the festival, founded in 1953 by the violinist Alexander Schneider and the Washington Square Association, celebrates its 50th anniversary this month.

title: Good Intentions, Vague Promises
description: This weeks summit meeting of major industrialized nations in Japan yielded two important firsts on global warming. For once, the Bush administration was not in full foot-dragging mode, joining in a pledge to halve global greenhouse gases by midcentury. And the big emerging nations, including China and India, agreed to long-range (if unspecified) cuts in emissions.

title: Redstone Says No to Anointing His Daughter
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho  Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman and controlling shareholder of Viacom and CBS, is usually a ubiquitous figure here at the investment bank Allen & Companys annual conference, but even in his absence Mr. Redstone is likely to be the talk of this longtime playground for the well-heeled.

title: A Candidate Plans Early for a Runoff
description: Starting in December, real estate interests  which have helped bankroll so many city campaigns  will be severely restricted from giving contributions to political candidates. That is a big problem for Melinda R. Katz, a candidate for city comptroller. As chairwoman of the City Councils Land Use Committee, Ms. Katz has taken in hundreds of thousands of dollars from the real estate industry.

title: City to Test Peak Rates for Parking Meters
description: Call it congestion parking.

title: Suit Says Man Was Arrested for Nasty E-Mail Message He Didnt Write
description: In April 2007, William Hallowell, an assistant in the library at the Riverdale Country School in the Bronx, sent e-mail messages to his boss. He apologized for not having been at work because of some family problems, and he wrote that he was resigning, because he also needed more time to study.

title: With Another Standout Effort, Ponson Is Fitting in Nicely for Yankees
description: The Yankees gave out 20,000 novelty mustaches Wednesday, celebrating their whiskered All-Star hopeful, Jason Giambi. In the clubhouse before the game, the media-relations director, Jason Zillo, placed a mustache in each players locker. Respecting tradition, he avoided the days starting pitcher, Sidney Ponson.

title: The Mustache is the Man
description: Much has been written lately about Jason Giambis new facial hair. On Monday, Giambi got two mustache-related boosts for his all-star candidacy: the American Mustache Institute officially offered its support for him, and the Yankees issued a press release urging fans to Support the Stache.

title: Foreign Investors Pile Up More Pieces of Americana
description: The hunt for the great American trophy asset is on.

title: U.S. Candidates Use Irans Missile Tests as a Chance for a Foreign Policy Debate
description: PORTSMOUTH, Ohio  Irans saber-rattling missile tests quickly became a flash point in the presidential election on Wednesday as Senator John McCain and Senator Barack Obama each seized on the tests to try to validate their differing policies on Iran.

title: Cutting Out the Middlemen, Shoppers Buy Slices of Farms
description: CAMPTON TOWNSHIP, Ill.  In an environmentally conscious tweak on the typical way of getting food to the table, growing numbers of people are skipping out on grocery stores and even farmers markets and instead going right to the source by buying shares of farms.

title: Would You Buy a New Car From Eva Longoria?
description: In the 1950s, a marketing type called James Vicary caused national hysteria when he announced he could get people to buy Coca-Cola by flashing a Drink Coke sign on a screen so quickly that viewers couldnt tell, implanting the urge in their subconscious.

title: A New Tour of an Ancient Town
description: A worker, above, removes fake condensation from a display of a woman in a thermal bath at Herculaneum, below, in one of more than 70 multimedia installations at the new Virtual Archaeological Museum there. The museum offers a 3-D virtual tour of that ancient Roman town, south of Naples, which was destroyed along with Pompeii in the A.D. 79 eruption of Mount Vesuvius.

title: New Book Looks at the Worlds Coolest Hotel Rooms
description: The Hotel Bsico in Playa del Carmen, Mexico, is made from materials recycled from public schools, cantinas and 50s-era oil refineries. It looks a bit like a container ship and has a gutsy, raw appeal. Each room features a vintage Polaroid camera handcuffed to the bed, an amenity that reduces the chocolate-on-the-pillow turn-down service to a quaint archaism. The place is included in the The Worlds Coolest Hotel Rooms (Collins Design; $29.95), a nifty guidebook compiled by Bill Tikos, an Australian cool hunter  90s-speak for a trend spotter (see thecoolhunter.net).

title: Munsons Widow Decides Time Is Right for Auction
description: With each passing year, Diana Munson would regard the home office of her husband, Thurman, with growing sadness. The accumulated memorabilia in the room, with its Yankee-blue carpeting and suede walls, overwhelmed her and anyone who entered.

title: What Next, Bikinis in Winter?
description: LI EDELKOORT, a trend forecaster, recently made a prediction at the Royal Institute of British Architects in London that people will someday begin to wear scarves, sweaters and hats during the warmer months as a way to reinterpret the way they dress in a more unconventional way, Womens Wear Daily reported this week.

title: Corrections
description: The Talking Business column on Saturday, about Googles day care center, misstated the title of Susan Wojcicki, who has been an advocate for the companys day care efforts. She is vice president for product management, not product measurement.

title: America Gets to Know Obama, and Vice Versa
description: BUTTE, Mont.  Senator Barack Obama marveled at the view here in Big Sky Country. He discovered that the gumbo in New Orleans was far tastier than in Chicago. And he was pleasantly surprised that he loved Austin, Tex., and its music  but who doesnt?

description: To the Editor:

title: Obama Urges Backers to Address Clinton Debt
description: Senator Barack Obama asked a roomful of his loyal donors in New York on Wednesday night to help his primary foe Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton pay off part of the $23 million in debt she ran up trying to beat him.

title: Iraq Military Commander Survives Suicide Bomb Attack
description: BAGHDAD  Violence claimed the lives of at least 20 Iraqis on Wednesday, including eight who were killed in a suicide attack against Iraqs top military commander in the northern city of Mosul. The commander escaped unharmed.

title: Love Your Sunglasses (Should I Know You?)
description: THE Ilori store in SoHo must be one of the only sunglass emporiums with a V.I.P. room. Lounging there with a flute of Mot, nibbling dark chocolate, shoppers can ponder just the right accessory to create the allure that they are Somebodies.

title: Spy Cases Raise Concern on Chinas Intentions
description: WASHINGTON  Gregg W. Bergersen was a Navy veteran who liked to gamble on occasion but spent far more time worrying about how to earn some serious money after he left his career as an analyst at the Defense Department.

description: DENVER  A persistent thread among conspiracy theorists and true-crime bloggers who for years have pondered the murder of JonBenet Ramsey, the child beauty queen found strangled in her familys home in nearby Boulder more than 11 years ago, is that the police and prosecutors inadequately investigated whether her killer was a member of the family.

title: General Misled Lawmakers on KBR Work, Senator Says
description: WASHINGTON  A top Democratic senator on Wednesday accused an Army general of misleading Congress about problems with a major defense contractor in Iraq, and said he had asked Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates to investigate.

title: The Sharpest Shorts Are Abbreviated Pants

Michael Macko, the new fashion director of Details, was paying utmost attention to Raf Simonss collection of avant-garde rompers when his eye strayed to the front row. There he saw the photographer J. D. Ferguson in elegant tropical-weight gray wool pants, cut off crudely above the knee.

The move pushed GfK, the preferred merger partner of Taylor Nelson Sofres, to scramble to put together a higher bid.

title: Wachovia Hires a Treasury Insider to Lift It Out of Its Banking Woes
description: From his perch inside the Treasury Department, Robert K. Steel has wrestled with the troubles plaguing Americas financial industry. Now he will confront those problems up close at the Wachovia Corporation, one of the nations largest banks.

title: The Pain of the G-8s Big Shrug
description: Is genocide really that bad?

title: Noteworthy Sales at the Conran Shop and Angel Street, a Charity Thrift Shop
description: Conrans summer sale starts Thursday and continues through Aug. 3, with discounts of up to 60 percent. Items on sale include the Mary Chair, upholstered in fabric or leather ($2,400, reduced from $3,200), and the Chab coffee table, left, with a removable serving tray (about $627, formerly $895); quantities are limited. The Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street (First Avenue), (866) 755-9079.

title: Curlin Off Steroid and on Roll Once Again
description: Curlin was named Horse of the Year in 2007, an accomplishment perhaps attained with the help of the anabolic steroid Winstrol, his owner, Jess Jackson, has acknowledged. Now, Jackson is hoping to prove that Curlin is not merely a chemically enhanced colt, but a true champion.

title: John Simon, Tireless Editor of Grants Papers, Dies at 75
description: John Y. Simon, a Civil War scholar whose mammoth effort in editing of the papers of Ulysses S. Grant created a new standard for the organization of historical documents, died on Tuesday in Carbondale, Ill. He was 75.

title: Small Business Is Latest Focus in Health Fight
description: As the number of people without health insurance continues to rise, many states and Congress have begun to focus on one of the biggest causes: the growing number of small business owners and their workers who are unable to afford coverage.

title: Drug Industry to Announce Revised Code on Marketing
description: WASHINGTON  The pens, pads, mugs and other gifts that drug makers have long showered on doctors will be banned from pharmaceutical marketing campaigns under a voluntary guideline that the industry is expected to announce Thursday.

title: The Real Thing
description: In his book A Few Seconds of Panic; A 5-foot-8, 170-pound, 43-year-old Sportswriter Plays in the N.F.L., published this month by Penguin Press ($25.95), Stefan Fatsis writes about suiting up with the Denver Broncos for a summer of place-kicking. His skills on the field improved to the point that he could drill 40-yard field goals, but more meaningful to readers is that he used his deep access to provide an insightful and sometimes amusing look at the inner workings of pro football. Fatsis recently talked to us about what he learned along the way.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on Tuesday about alcohol and drug abuse among combat veterans of Iraq and Afghanistan misstated the circumstances under which a former marine convicted of vehicular manslaughter, Anthony Klecker, was forced to leave an inpatient treatment program for alcoholism and combat stress. According to the prosecutor, Mr. Klecker was removed from the program because he twice got into heated arguments with other patients, not because he pulled a pocket knife on another patient. (Mr. Klecker did possess a pocket knife, the prosecutor said, but never threatened anyone.)

title: Samba Lines at the Gym
description: LOS ANGELES

title: DVDs That Do All the Work to Back Up Your Photo and Video Vaults
description: Hard drives are fast becoming huge photo and video archives, but not everyone has the foresight or patience to install a backup system in case that drive takes a dive. Memorex eliminates the need for a dedicated backup program with its SimpleSave Photo & Video Backup DVDs, which include the necessary software right on the recordable disc.

title: Abu Dhabi Buys 90% Stake in Chrysler Building
description: The government of Abu Dhabi bought a 90 percent stake in the Chrysler Building on Tuesday for $800 million from German real estate investors and Tishman Speyer.

title: Senate Approves Bill to Broaden Wiretap Powers
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate gave final approval on Wednesday to a major expansion of the governments surveillance powers, handing President Bush one more victory in a series of hard-fought clashes with Democrats over national security issues.

title: That Veteran Hair Band, in Front of the Music for Once, With Successors in Tow
description: There were two types of pornography on offer during Mtley Cres performance at the Nikon at Jones Beach Theater on Tuesday night. The first was traditional: fleeting images of women in various acts of intimacy, spliced into videos playing on screens adjacent to the stage while the band muscled through hits like Same Ol Situation (S.O.S.) and Girls, Girls, Girls.

title: Philosophy for Song
description: Leonard Cohen, above, made his first appearance in 23 years at the Montreux Jazz Festival on Tuesday night, Agence France-Presse reported. Natty in a pinstripe suit, gray shirt and hat, Mr. Cohen, nearly 74, joked with the crowd about his decision to tour again after a long layoff. Its been a long time since Ive stood up on the stage, about 14 years he said. Since then Ive taken a lot of Prozac and also studied religion and philosophy, but cheerfulness kept breaking through, he said, drawing laughter in leading to a song called Aint No Cure for Love.

title: Greek Myth as Potpourri of Multicultural Flavors
description: HOLSTEBRO, Denmark  A hush fell in the red room, the largest performing space in the former barn here that the experimental Odin Teatret has called home since 1966. The theaters founder and director, Eugenio Barba, welcomed the 32 members of the Gambuh Desa Batuan Ensemble, who had just arrived from Bali and were sitting on the floor in sarongs. They were to play the roles of Medea and her kinsmen in The Marriage of Medea, a new production presented last month by the Odin in a town festival.

title: Senate Panel Close to Deal on Donations of Artwork
description: Responding to pleas from museums, members of the Senate Finance Committee have agreed in principle to loosen stringent limits on partial gifts, in which collectors claim tax deductions for donating artwork in increments to museums even though the art may remain in their living rooms.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about potential changes to the ownership of the Pittsburgh Steelers misspelled the surname of a wealthy businessman who has been approached about investing in or buying the team. He is Stanley Druckenmiller, not Drunkenmiller.

title: For 198 Young Players, a Taste of Championship-Level Play
description: The first Youth North American Bridge Championships, for players under the age of 20 and having fewer than 5,000 master points on July 1, took place in Atlanta last Thursday through Sunday. The event was a great learning experience for the 198 youngsters ages 5 to 19 who participated.

title: Jesse Jackson Apologizes for Remarks on Obama
description: WASHINGTON  The Rev. Jesse Jackson apologized on Wednesday for critical and crude comments he made about Senator Barack Obama, remarks in which he accused Mr. Obama of talking down to black people.

title: The Afterlife of Windows XP
description: Q. Now that Windows XP is retired, will Microsoft still put out security patches for the system?

title: California Heat Hampers Firefighters
description: With scores of wildfires already burning, California residents and the firefighters trying to protect their homes prepared Wednesday for two more days of extreme heat and low humidity that could make the job even more difficult.

title: Ralph Burgard, Advocate for Arts Programs, Dies at 81
description: Ralph Burgard, a leader in the movement to create arts programs in communities around the country, died on July 3 at his home in Duxbury, Mass. He was 81.

title: Stewart Will Leave Gibbs Team and May Drive for Haas
description: Tony Stewart, the irascible Nascar driver who has brought titles and trouble to Joe Gibbs Racing since entering the Cup series in 1999, will leave the organization at the end of this season.

title: Sliding Double Bed Makes Maximum Use of Minimum Space
description: The SimpleDoubleDeux Bed, left, consists of two interlocking molded plywood platforms that slide together to form a single bed and apart to create a double bed. It is the brainchild of Daniel Jauslin, a principal in Drexler Guinand Jauslin Architects in Zurich, who needed a bed small enough to fit in his 9-by-12-foot guest room but big enough for two guests.

title: Paradise Found
description: Adam and Eve: the Broadway show? A musical based on Paradise Lost, John Miltons 17th-century epic poem that tells the story of the fall of Satan and temptation in the Garden of Eden, will open on Broadway this fall, its producers announced on Wednesday. The musical, Angels, which will be directed by Rich Fowler, was written by Ken Lai and Marcus Cheong. Robert Cuccioli, Jessica Grov and Nicholas Rodriguez will star. Before arriving on Broadway, Angels will appear at the Strand Theater in Shreveport, La., for a two-week engagement.

title: Tour of Embraces Makes a Stop in Manhattan
description: The line started outside on 34th Street, entered the lobby and snaked up the stairs to the balcony. It veered left at the aisle, then downstairs again to the rear orchestra section.

title: A King and a Spy
description: Two prominent theater entities  the Acting Company, which was founded by John Houseman in the 1970s, and the Guthrie Theater, the prestigious regional theater in Minneapolis  are joining forces to present a co-production and national tour of Henry V. The production, to be directed by Davis McCallum, will tour in repertory with the world premiere of The Spy, by James Fenimore Cooper, which was adapted by Jeffrey Hatcher and will be directed by John Miller-Stephany, associate artistic director of the Guthrie. The Acting Companys 36th national tour will begin at the Guthrie on Jan. 10. The production of Henry V will be at the New Victory Theater in New York from Feb. 25 to March 8.

title: Hedge Fund Manager Describes Rock Bottom
description: One by one, John Devaney sold his treasures, hoping to forestall what was in the end inevitable. He sold his Renoir and his Gulfstream, his home and his helicopter. Even his cherished yacht  gone.

title: Before You Pilfer That Cupcake ...
description: DEAR Colleague:

title: The Day of the Jackal, Tinker, Tailor, Bourne, Avalanche and Dr. Hero
description: There are rules for writing books like Christopher Reichs Rules of Deception. And Mr. Reich helpfully spells them out. In a brief promotional video clip, an increasingly common feature on Amazon.com book listings, Mr. Reich says:

title: Sharp Fall for Stocks Amid Angst in Lending
description: Half an hour was all it took for a dreary day on Wall Street to turn dire.

title: Dozens Stuck in Midair at the Bronx Zoo
description: About three dozen cable car passengers on a sightseeing ride were stranded for nearly five hours on Wednesday night at the Bronx Zoo after an emergency mechanism caused the ride to shut down, leaving riders dangling over the African Plains exhibit and other parts of the zoo.

title: Apples Latest Opens a Developers Playground
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  When Apple opens its online App Store for iPhone software on Thursday, Steven P. Jobs will be making an attempt to dominate the next generation of computing as it moves toward Internet-connected mobile devices.

title: Generations and Genres Mix at a Tap-Dance Party
description: Tap City 2008, a festival presented by the American Tap Dance Foundation, is a bit like a party where you dont know a soul but the room is overflowing with communal love and gratitude. The eighth installment opened on Tuesday night at Symphony Space with Tap Forward, a program highlighting contemporary choreography and the presentation of two Hoofer Awards (to Tina Pratt and Derick K. Grant), as well as the Preservation Award (to the teacher and tap historian Ann Kilkelly).

title: Shopping for Glassware With John Pomp
description: JOHN POMP fell in love with glass in the early 90s, when he was a student at the Columbus College of Art and Design in Ohio. Like any passion, it drove him to reckless acts. He would break into the school at night when the studio was closed, he said, and sit there until 4 in the morning and blow glass.

title: Masters of the Universe, on the Couch
description: To the Editor:

title: Kennedy Casts Key Vote as Medicare Bill Passes
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Edward M. Kennedy returned to the Senate on Wednesday for the first time since being sidelined with cancer and was greeted by a bipartisan barrage of whoops, cheers and applause before savoring a legislative triumph.

title: Iran Reports Missile Test, Drawing Rebuke
description: PARIS  Irans Revolutionary Guards test-fired nine missiles in war-game maneuvers on Wednesday, including at least one the government in Tehran described as having the range to reach Israel.

title: WPP Group Seeks to Buy Taylor Nelson Sofres
description: PARIS  WPP Group, the advertising and marketing company, said Wednesday that it had made a hostile bid for the British market research company Taylor Nelson Sofres, aiming to upset that companys plans to merge with a rival, GfK.

title: Veering From the Standard, Returning to the Spirit
description: Pilobolus, like any dance company, has several styles. Some of its works are visions of imaginary biology, some are human dramas, some are about clowning. But since its early years the purest Pilobolus experiences have involved metamorphosis. We see both physicality and illusion. Bodies become imagery, and one image merges into another, organically, poetically, inexplicably.

title: Division at G-8 Over Climate Goal
description: RUSUTSU, Japan  Rich nations and emerging powers on Wednesday declared climate change one of the great global challenges of our time. But they set no short-term goals for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, with the largest developing countries demanding more action by wealthy nations before moving.

title: Frenzy Crosses Atlantic
description: Ingrid Betancourt, below, the Colombian-French politician who was held hostage by guerrillas in a Colombian jungle for six years, has been on a full-court press with the European news media after her dramatic rescue last week. Now the American media will have their turn, beginning with NBC News, which announced on Wednesday that it had been granted the first United States television interview with Ms. Betancourt since her rescue. Ann Curry, the NBC news anchor, conducted the interview, scheduled for broadcast on the NBC Nightly News on Wednesday night and on Today on Thursday. And Ms. Betancourts American publisher, Ecco, a division of HarperCollins, quickly made plans to release a new paperback version of her 2001 memoir, Until Death Do Us Part, in August. The book, an attack on political corruption in Colombia, was published under the title The Rage in My Heart in France, and became a best seller there. Susanna Lea, Ms. Betancourts longtime literary agent in Paris, said in an e-mail message that Ms. Betancourt was thinking of writing a book and a play too.

title: And Boy Could He Pitch
description: With the All Star Game next week in Yankee Stadium, well see baseballs greatest stars. One thing we likely wont see is a pitcher batting, because, as weve been told relentlessly, pitchers cant hit.

title: Knicks Introduce Their Newest Guard
description: Nothing in Chris Duhons rsum suggests budding stardom. He was a second-round draft pick four years ago, a part-time starter for most of his career and a negligible player on an occasionally decent Chicago Bulls team.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The By the Numbers chart on Monday with coverage of Rafael Nadals victory over Roger Federer in their Wimbledon final reversed the winners hit statistic for the players. Federer had 89, and Nadal had 60.

title: Militant Gains in Pakistan Said to Draw Fighters
description: WASHINGTON  American military and intelligence officials say there has been an increase in recent months in the number of foreign fighters who have traveled to Pakistans tribal areas to join with militants there.

title: With New Device, Metro-North Moves Toward Cashless Ticketing
description: Railroad cars are filled with passengers listening to iPods, typing on laptops and talking on cellphones. Buying a ticket onboard, though, is usually a pretty analog affair: Conductors punch holes in multicolored sheets called duplexes, separate the back page from the front page and collect coins and bills from passengers.

title: Steve & Barrys, a Retailer, Files for Bankruptcy Protection
description: Steve & Barrys, the fashion retailer, filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday but said its 276 stores would remain open while the company continued to look for a buyer or sold some of its assets.

title: Petty Welcomes Investor Into the Family Business
description: Sometimes, even American originals have to sell a piece of themselves.

title: After Selling the Company, Remorse
description: Christopher A. Baker had two goals when he started his company, MailCode, in 1989: to build a successful business and to sell it one day. He achieved both.

title: Build a Wiffle Ball Field and Lawyers Will Come
description: GREENWICH, Conn.

title: 6 Die in Attack on U.S. Post in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  Gunmen opened fire on Turkish security guards outside the United States Consulate in Istanbul on Wednesday, the Turkish authorities said, and at least three police officers and three assailants were killed in a brief gun battle. Officials said that a fourth assailant escaped.

title: Stern Looks, Sharp Curves
description: IN the beginning, at the new Jil Sander store, there was nothing, and it was good. It was clean, German and perfect; a high, white space tiled with four-foot slabs of Carrara marble and a wall of vertical mirrors rotating slowly for a wavy Venetian-blind effect, like that once used on The Price Is Right.

title: In Albanian Feuds, Isolation Engulfs Families
description: SHKODER, Albania  Christian Luli, a soft-spoken 17-year-old, has spent the past 10 years imprisoned inside his familys small, spartan house, fearful he will be shot dead if he walks outside the front door.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about Senator Barack Obamas decision to give his acceptance speech at a Denver stadium instead of at the Democratic convention hall misidentified the city where he was shown taking a break between campaign events. He was in St. Louis  not Charlotte, N.C., which he had to skip because of mechanical problems with his plane.

title: Seeding Now for Late Bounty
description: ITS been a great summer so far.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the influence of the television series Gossip Girl on fashion retailing misidentified which character is the so-called queen bee among the Manhattan private-school students depicted in the show. She is Blair Waldorf (portrayed by Leighton Meester), not Serena van der Woodsen (played by Blake Lively).

title: Again, a Lunchtime Glimpse of Bush in Chat Mode
description: RUSUTSU, Japan  It would not be a G-8 without a microphone mishap.

title: Siphoning G.M.s Future
description: WHO shot General Motors? The companys stock is at its lowest level in 50 years, and its market valuation has plunged to $5.9 billion, less than that of the Hershey candy-bar company. The automaker is weighing yet another round of layoffs  and maybe even a fire sale of venerable brands like Buick and Pontiac.

title: From Day to Night
description: Lisa Ling, below, a former co-host of The View on ABC, will return to that network as a contributor to Nightline, ABC said on Wednesday. Ms. Ling is already a special correspondent for The Oprah Winfrey Show and the National Geographic Channel. Her first segment for Nightline, on the rapid growth of luxury retirement communities, will be shown on Thursdays episode, beginning at 11:35 p.m.

title: Prospect of Obama at Brandenburg Gate Divides German Politicians
description: BERLIN  With the pillars of the Brandenburg Gate looming in the background, tens of thousands of adoring Berliners turn out to greet Senator Barack Obama with wild cheering. It may have seemed like the perfect campaign stop on the candidates highly anticipated European tour, an ideal way to burnish his foreign policy credentials.

title: The Fake Steve Jobs Is Giving Up Parody Blog
description: The once-mysterious blogger known as Fake Steve Jobs is turning off his iPhone for good.

title: Prosecution Plays Down Cooperation of Donaghy
description: Since admitting last August to providing inside information to gamblers and helping them pick N.B.A. games, the disgraced former referee Tim Donaghy has shared considerable information with federal investigators. His cooperation means that he is more likely to receive a sentence around 33 months instead of the 25 years he could have faced.

title: Spacewalk Outside Soyuz to Determine Malfunction
description: In an audacious spacewalk scheduled for Thursday, two Russian astronauts aboard the International Space Station are to saw away insulation from the Soyuz capsule that is to be used for their ride home later this year, remove a live explosive bolt that is part of the capsules re-entry apparatus and take it back into the station.

title: Moving Messages to Gmail
description: Q. Is there any way to import the old messages from both my expiring college account and Hotmail into a new Gmail account  besides forwarding each one individually?

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on June 28 about Charles Parkhurst, a museum director who helped return art stolen by the Nazis, misstated the date of his death. It was June 25, not June 26. The obituary also misstated the given name of a surviving daughter. She is Bruce Huntington Parkhurst, not Ruth. It also misstated the name of his second wife. She is Rima Parkhurst  not Rima Zevin Julyan, her former name.

title: Cancer-Specific Products: An Unnecessary Balm?
description: FOR the last seven years that Kairol Rosenthal, 35, has battled thyroid cancer with hormone pills, radiation, surgery and grit, she has had to contend with 101-degree fevers, heart palpitations and a lack of appetite so pronounced she has to force herself to eat.

title: Namb Finishes Setting the Table
description: Namb, the Santa Fe company known for its sculptural metal salt and pepper shakers and crystal candlesticks, is introducing four collections of ceramic dinnerware next month. The company began producing dinnerware with contemporary, organic lines earlier this year, said Robert Varakian, its chief executive, because so many dinnerware companies have focused on traditional shapes and decals.

title: A Vain Pursuit, or a Triumph of Will?
description: Since late May Play Magazine has brought you "The Climb by Rob Mackey, about his training for, and ultimate ascent of, a mountain stage of the Tour de France. Rob made it on Sunday, finishing the 105-mile course in just over eight hours. As Rob chronicled his progress, a debate arose -- a divide, really -- among those following his quest and commenting on his blog. Some contended that this was an indulgent, expensive drop-in on a serious pursuit that missed the point of what cycling is really about; others found it an inspiring example of what anyone can do with a little determination and hard work; some simply said it sounded like a blast.

title: Citing Fuel Costs, Northwest Plans to Cut 2,500 Jobs
description: Northwest Airlines said on Wednesday that it would cut 2,500 jobs, including pilots, flight attendants, mechanics and other employees, reflecting its reduction in flights in the wake of high fuel prices.

title: New Owner for Arena Team
description: In an area with two N.F.L. franchises, New Yorks Arena Football League team has toiled in the shadows.

title: My, How Theyve Grown
description: Not every fad in aerobic fitness fizzles. Here are a few with staying power, some that may surprise you.

title: Raiding Other Repertories to Bring a Sound to Stage
description: Calefax, a Dutch reed ensemble that gave a lively, inventive program at the Frick Collection on Tuesday, has discovered one of the great paradoxes of concert programming: If you want to ensure a free hand in choosing repertory, assemble a band for which little music has been written. Relatively few works are scored for the groups combination of oboe, saxophone, clarinet, bass clarinet and bassoon, so the musicians have raided other repertories and made their own captivating if sometimes peculiar arrangements.

title: When Perfect Is Not the Goal
description: THERE are signs that Manhattan societys recent fastidiousness about home renovation  the mania for right angles, the fetishizing of ancillary elements like hinges and drawer pulls  may be on the wane. In one corner of the East Village, a neighborhood increasingly colonized by well-heeled homesteaders, a crumbly brick town house built in the early 19th century has undergone the slightest of face-lifts.

title: As Outbreak Affects 1,000, Experts See Flaws in Law
description: More than 1,000 people in 41 states and the District of Columbia have now been sickened in the nations salmonella outbreak, in what officials said Wednesday was the largest food-borne outbreak in the last decade. And some food safety experts this week tied problems in tracing the source of the contamination to what they say are shortcomings in the Bioterrorism Act of 2002.

title: A Return and a Departure
description: Darkness and Light is an engrossing work that seems at once a return to pure Pilobolus essence and a complete departure from basic Pilobolism.

title: Respond to Todays Column: The Audacity of Listening
description: We invite you to leave your responses to the Thursday, July 10 column.

title: Prisoners of the Kanun
description: A code of behavior that says that blood must be paid with blood has trapped many Albanians in their homes.

title: On the Road With Obama
description: Barack Obama is acquainting himself more deeply with his country and has been surprised by some of his findings.

title: A Couple of the Doctors Turned a Little Green
description: More of your late night humor (send via the comment link below):

title: Big Birthday News Today
description: Aired Wednesday night on NBC: The Democratic Party announced this week that Barack Obama will give his acceptance speech at an 80,000-seat stadium and that they will not serve fried food at the Democratic convention. Which begs the question: Where are they going to find 80,000 Americans who dont eat fried food?

title: Childish History Lessons
description: Cracked.com asked its readers to draw historical events as if depicted by 5-year-olds. Heres some of what they came up with:

title: Novartis Pays $980 Million for Speedel Stake
description: Novartis has taken a majority stake in Speedel Holding and offered to buy the rest in a deal valuing the company at 1.01 billion Swiss francs ($980 million), Bloomberg News reported.

title: Man Increases Assets to $79.5 Billion
description: Man Group has reported a 6.6 percent rise in assets under management to $79.5 billion in the past three months, Bloomberg reported.

title: Macquarie Teams With Seek for Recruitment Site
description: Macquarie Group and Seek will invest a combined $105 million in Zhaopin, owner of Chinas third-biggest recruitment Web site, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Wynn May List in Hong Kong to Raise $3 Billion
description: Steve Wynn is mulling a secondary listing for his casino and hotel group in Hong Kong, MarketWatch said, citing a media report. The move could raise as much as $3 billion and would likely be the largest listing on the Hong Kong bourse this year.

title: Dimdim Sources $6 Million
description: Dimdim, an open-source Web conferencing provider, has raised $6 million in Series B funding, according to media reports.

title: Intel Capital Invests $37.7 Million in Sulfurcell
description: German thin-film solar cell manufacturer Sulfurcell closed on a $133.7 million round, which was led by Intel Capital with a $37.7 million contribution.

title: Fourth EADS Executive Detained in Trading Inquiry
description: French police on Wednesday detained an executive of EADS, the parent of Airbus, as part of an insider trading probe, according to his attorney.

title: HSBC Appoints New Head of Global Markets for India
description: HSBC has appointed Hitendra Dave head of global markets for India, FinanceAsia reported.

title: The Mark of Twain
description: Politics | Would Mark Twain have been a critic of waterboarding? You bet, says Roy Blount Jr. in an essay. In 1902, Twain wrote of the torturing of Filipinos by the awful water-cure.' So its not just sarcastic social comics like Stewart and Colbert who are in Twains debt. His influence was such that he was our original superstar.  Time

title: Great Wall Revs Up I.P.O.
description: Chinas securities regulator intends next Monday to review an application for a Shanghai initial public offering. by Great Wall Motor, which could raise up to $82 million, Reuters reported.

title: Sequoia Goes to Bat for Challenge Games
description: Challenge Games has received $4.5 million from Sequoia Capital and announced a multi-year licensing deal with MLB Advanced Media, the interactive media and Internet company of Major League Baseball.

title: Sandelman Said to Restructure Master Fund
description: New York-based hedge fund Sandelman Partners, which manages about $4 billion of assets, told investors in its largest fund that they cannot have their money back soon, The Wall Street Journal said on Thursday.

title: Cohen Backs Buyout of Former ABN Amro Fund
description: Sir Ronald Cohen, co-founder of Apax Partners, is backing the management buyout of ABN Amros former hedge fund arm a mere two and a half years after the Dutch bank bought the business, The Financial Times reported.

title: Thiels Clarium On Track for Strong Year
description: Clarium Capital Management, the $6.4 billion fund founded by Peter Thiel in 2002, returned a 57.9 percent at the end of June, according to performance data obtained by The New York Post. The company is now on track for one of its best years ever.

title: Bank of America May Assume All Countrywide Debt, Analyst Says
description: Bank of America is primed to assume all debt of the former Countrywide Financial, independent research firm CreditSights said, a move that would alleviate worries of Countrywide bondholders.

title: Will Activision and Vivendi Try to Steal Take-Two?
description: The $19 billion merger of Activision and Vivendi Games has ignited speculation that the merged company could now set its sights on Take-Two Interactive Software, which has been fending off a $2 billion hostile takeover attempt by Electronic Arts.

title: Dow Chemical to Buy Rohm and Haas for $15.3 Billion
description: Dow Chemical said Thursday that it has agreed to buy Rohm and Haas, the old-line specialty chemical maker, for about $15.3 billion in cash, one of the largest deals this year and one made with the help of Warren E. Buffett and the Kuwaiti government.

title: ICICI Bank Considers Deals Abroad
description: ICICI Bank, one of the largest in India, is considering acquisitions to expand outside its home market at a time when many foreign rivals are struggling because of tight credit markets, two of the banks executives said in an interview on Wednesday.

title: Warren Buffetts Odd Sun Valley Deal
description: Barely one day in, the Sun Valley conference has already helped to produce a multibillion-dollar merger deal  but not the kind you might expect.

title: Fortis Board to Meet Amid Reports C.E.O. Could Be Forced Out
description: The board of Fortis will meet to discuss the investor response to its capital-raising plans, the bank said in a statement. The move comes amid reports that its chief executive, Jean-Paul Votron, could be forced out, MarketWatch reported.

title: Petty Welcomes Investor Into the Family Business
description: Richard Petty is one of the great sporting icons, who transformed his business, who takes over an event just by being there, with a black Charlie 1 Horse cowboy hat looming over his bladelike face. He turned 71 on July 2 but has learned a new trick  selling a majority of the family business, Petty Enterprises, to Boston Ventures, a private equity firm.

title: GLG Hires Two Morgan Stanley Traders to Replace Coffey
description: GLG Partners has brought in two senior traders from Morgan Stanley to replace Greg Coffey, the fund manager whose surprise resignation in April prompted $2 billion of redemptions.

title: Government Said to Hold Talks on Fannie and Freddie
description: With shares of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac continuing to decline, the Bush administration has held talks about a contingency plan should the mortgage giants falter, The Wall Street Journal reported citing three people familiar with the matter.

title: Blackstone Said to Plan Wind-Farm Investment
description: Blackstone Group, the New York-based private equity firm, plans to invest more than 1 billion euros ($1.57 billion) in a project to build wind farms in the North Sea to generate electricity, people familiar with the matter told Reuters.

title: Chanticleer Adds Hooters Franchises
description: Investment firm Chanticleer Holdings has added 45 Hooters franchises to its portfolio via an agreement to acquire Texas Wings Inc. in a deal valued at $106 million, The Daily Deal reported.

title: Foreign Investors Pile Up More Pieces of Americana
description: The hunt for the great American trophy asset is on. The global commodities boom and the dollars decline have unleashed a wave of big money buys of prized American assets by newly flush foreign investors, according to The New York Times.

title: After Herbie, Another Kind of Home
description: In the first installment of The Sandwich Generation, documentary filmmaker Julie Winokur and her husband Ed Kashi, a photojournalist, chronicle their optimistic, resolute efforts to care for her ailing father, Herbie Winokur, age 85, after moving from San Francisco to Montclair, N.J.

title: Hedge Fund Manager Describes Rock Bottom
