title: Faces of Lower Manhattan
description: Among the Lower Manhattan personalities in Trinity Church's exhibition are Berta and Roshel, who run a food cart; Fausto, a high school student; and Chimere, who works at a cafe.  See the Slide Show Trinity Church, established in 1697, sits in a landmark Gothic structure at Broadway and Wall Street, completed in 1846. The congregation has seen it all: British rule, American independence, Civil War riots, Wall Street's ascendancy, countless ticker-tape parades, and of course, 9/11.   The church's neighborhood, Lower Manhattan, has witnessed a surprising rebirth in the nearly seven years since the destruction of the World Trade Center. A new exhibition, "Familiar Faces: Portraits of Our Neighbors," which opened last week and remains on view through Sept. 14, shows 16 life-size portraits of people working or living in Lower Manhattan, accompanied by their personal stories. (The accompanying slide show includes 15 of the images; one subject consented to being photographed for the exhibition but did not want his image disseminated more widely.)  Curated by Greg Goings, the exhibition was organized by the Trinity Museum inside the church. From Monday to Friday, the museum is open 9 to 11:45 a.m. and 12:45 to 5 p.m.; on Saturday, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; and on Sunday, 12:30 to 5 p.m. (After Labor Day, the museum will close at 3:45 p.m. daily.)   The curator's introduction to the exhibition quotes Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, who wrote, "I have an affection for a great city. I feel safe in the neighborhood of man, and enjoy the sweet security of the streets."  The exhibition goes on to explain:   What we found was inspirational. We learned that the barista we buy coffee from is also a writer. We met a high school student with a passion for playing guitar. And we discovered a professional boxer in action at a gym around the corner on Greenwich Street. In the 16 people represented here, there are many stories, and we know that we have only scratched the surface. We hope to meet many more of our neighbors in the future. The next time you see a familiar face in this neighborhood or the neighborhood you come from, say hello. ... you never know the stories you might hear or the friends you might make.

title: Futility Vehicle
description: This is a story of selfishness and greed, of self-centeredness, envy and the ignorant folly of a person too short-sighted to realize she should count herself lucky because her college education didn't have to be paid for with the milk of a goat.   The tale could be called: I Can No Longer Afford to Drive My Car.  The vehicle in question is a Land Rover. (2004 Land Rover. Vinyl interior. 33,000 miles. No sun roof. If you're interested.)  It is a big black behemoth that stands more than six feet tall, weighs 6,724 pounds and gets, according to E.P.A. calculations, 11 miles to the gallon in the city, assuming you don't go uphill, stop at stop signs or run the air conditioning.   If you do any of these things, the gas mileage, according to my calculations, falls by about half.  "You always exaggerate," my husband Max always complains.  I don't think I do.  I haven't actually made a formal study of the Land Rover's gas mileage. I've simply stopped driving the car to anywhere other than our metro stop (1.5 miles; about a quarter tank of gas) or the supermarket (.88 miles, maybe an eighth of a tank of gas) or the gas station. Last Sunday, needing to transport a camp trunk, we drove it to Virginia, which was costly (96 miles, perhaps 1,800 tanks of gas), but highly worthwhile, because the driveway leading up to the camp's welcome area was gravelly and steep.  "She loves this terrain," Max said, patting the dashboard.  Why on earth did we buy a car like this?   Well, a lot of people once did. In fact, until late 2004, a lot of people went out of their way to buy precisely these monsters because - if you can believe it - the government actually offered a tax break for buying a car that weighed over 6,000 pounds if you were self-employed and needed it to transport heavy work machinery. Like farm equipment. Or a laptop.   But that's not why we bought ours.   We bought our Land Rover because our friends had one. They were fun, attractive, athletic kinds of people, and it seemed to us that that they had a fun, attractive, athletic kind of a car. A swashbuckling kind of a car. With its extra-high roof rack, its khaki-colored interior, its front end that looked like the face of a panther, their Land Rover looked like it could take you away from Safeway and out on safari.  Our car -- a 1997 Ford Explorer, grabbed on impulse right off the used car lot (wide-bodied seats! cup holders everywhere!) in our first, jet-lagged, giddy days on the ground in America after almost six years overseas -- had died.   And at a time in our lives when our greatest risk-taking consisted in eating off salad bars (Stop! Think of the girls! a voice rang out in my ears today, as my hand hovered, ever so briefly, over the shrimp salad), the Land Rover made life an adventure. The windshield was so high! The blind spot was so wide! The back window so very useless, blocked almost entirely by the spare tire that hung, jauntily, sportily, on the outside! Merely shifting into reverse was an adrenaline rush.   If the Explorer was a car for getting fat in, slurping Big Gulps as your butt expanded to fill the velvety seats, the Land Rover was a car for beating back middle age. Honked at by, say, a mean-looking guy in a convertible as you paused to let traffic pass before making a right turn on red, you could smile, approximate sight through the rear-view mirror and think, Go ahead, make my day. I could crush you like a bug. (Which you could. Which you'd nearly done to a number of smaller cars that had had the misfortune to park right behind you.)  You felt untouchable.   Oh, how are the mighty fallen now.  These days, the Land Rover spends all week in the garage next to the metro station. Every weekend, it sits outside our house, its great cat face gone dim.  I've been feeling quite sorry for it.  But last weekend, I came up with a plan.  Our friends, the friends who inspired the Land Rover purchase, recently bought a beautiful new home. It has a guest house. We're invited to come and stay anytime.   Thinking this over on the long, costly ride back from Virginia on Sunday, I suddenly had a vision: We could park the Land Rover in our backyard. We could take out the seats, put in twin beds and a mini Portosan, and, ipso-presto: we could have a guest house, too.  "An in-law suite," Max enthused.  This encouraged me.  I thought on: Why not, finally, enlarge Emilie's room? We could put the car on stilts, remove the back door, line it up outside her window and give her the additional play space -- already carpeted -- that she needs. (She wants a tree house, too. Easy-peasy: Run up a ladder, and open a door.)  Alternatively: We've long wanted a larger dining room. But bumping out the back of the house is too expensive. We could, instead, ram it in. Drive the car, at top speed, into the dining room. Its trunk could be built-in buffet space. All-American, with a sporty, permanent tailgate theme.  Or: the government could just buy back our Land Rover. They could make us a gun-buyback kind of a deal. We'd bring the car in, no questions asked. Perhaps it could be recycled for use in the Iraqi desert. ("She loves the sand.") We'd get a little reward  the downpayment, perhaps, on a Prius or a Mini Cooper.  I think that these are good ideas.  I think that any one of these very visible, easily replicable, greatly inspiring, teachable examples of large-scale recycling could go a long way toward repaying our debt to society for having bought the big gas guzzler in the first place. At the very least, they should earn us a tax break.   What, you have a problem with the idea of our government subsidizing selfish, wasteful, short-sighted people?  Don't make me laugh.

title: Futility Vehicle
description: This is a story of selfishness and greed, of self-centeredness, envy and the ignorant folly of a person too short-sighted to realize she should count herself lucky because her college education didnt have to be paid for with the milk of a goat.

title: A Lifetime Embracer in Midtown
description: Mata Amritanandamayi, known as Amma, or Mother, draws thousands around the globe with her hugs.

title: Coming Soon: Hope For Your Home
description: The name of TLCs newest housing television show is a comment on the gloomy economy.

title: Olympic Sharpshooters
description: The Army Marksmanship Unit is a squad dedicated to training and employing Olympic-level shooters.

title: Planet Green Renews Greensburg, Introduces Series By ABC News
description: Greensburg, the landmark series for the new Planet Green cable channel about the rebuilding of a Kansas town that was virtually wiped off the map by a tornado, will return for a second season.

title: Lax on Its List of Bundlers, the Obama Campaign Names Names
description: Senator Barack Obamas campaign published the names of a whopping 181 new bundlers of campaign contributions this evening, adding to its existing list of 328 elite fund-raisers, after The New York Times made an inquiry earlier in the day about how complete the list was.

title: U.S. Weighs Takeover of Two Mortgage Giants
description: WASHINGTON  Alarmed by the growing financial stress at the nations two largest mortgage finance companies, senior Bush administration officials are considering a plan to have the government take over one or both of the companies and place them in a conservatorship if their problems worsen, people briefed about the plan said on Thursday.

title: Former City Worker Accused of Taking Bribes for Rent Subsidies
description: A former city housing agency supervisor has been arrested on charges that she took bribes of $5,000 to $6,000 from more than a dozen tenants to provide them with federal rent subsidy vouchers that should have gone to needy families.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some editions last Friday with vignettes of a cross section of people riding the Q train on a summer morning misidentified the Brooklyn terminus for the Q. It is in Coney Island, not Brighton Beach.

title: A College Reunion, Where Time Leaps by Decades
description: The Havens column last Friday about Oxford, Miss., misstated the Web site for the Colonels Quarters, a B&B there. It is www.thecolonelsquarters.com.

title: On the Flight Path
description: WHO Julie Kenney, 44, and her husband, Steve, 47, owners of a building company, and their three sons, from Mobile, Ala. WHAT 3-bedroom house WHERE Dauphin Island, Ala.

title: Like Bogey, but With a Really Big Fist
description: There are moments in Hellboy 2: The Golden Army, Guillermo del Toros profligate sequel to Hellboy, capable of delighting even the most jaded, comic-book-weary summer-blockbuster conscript. (That would be me.) Lately we have seen plenty of big, asphalt-smashing street battles between hero and nemesis  Tim Roth and Edward Norton, hopped up on military growth hormones, hurling cars across Harlem in The Incredible Hulk; Charlize Theron and Will Smith enacting some kind of meteorological superhero S & M in Hancock  but nothing quite like the scene in which Ron Perlmans Hellboy, a baby in one hand and an oversize gun in the other, mixes it up with a giant, angry plant.

title: Two Friends, and the Dream of a Lofty Park Realized
description: FACEBOOK has not been a factor in its success: At age 80ish, 30 feet tall, 22 blocks long and making a first impression best described as rusty, the High Line is not a looker. Nor is it human. But so far, the $170 million High Line renaissance, the park-in-the-sky reclamation project that marries a defunct elevated freight railway to an on-trend vision for Manhattans underachieving West Side, has attracted roughly 15,000 human friends to its Web site.

title: River Rim Ranch and Encanto Villas & Residence Club
description: River Rim Ranch

title: Book for Epic Match
description: It could take an entire book to deconstruct the epic mens Wimbledon final in which Rafael Nadal, above, beat Roger Federer on Sunday. Or so one publisher, Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, is betting. The company has commissioned a book on the match, Strokes of Genius, by L. Jon Wertheim, a veteran Sports Illustrated reporter, to be published next year. Wertheim will deliver the definitive book on the most defining match in tennis history, a spokeswoman for Houghton Mifflin said in an e-mail message.

title: Governor Rockefellers Contribution to the Arts
description: To the Editor:

title: Despair and Poetry at Margins of Society
description: The critic and historian Norman M. Klein has called Los Angeles the most photographed and least remembered city in the world. Given the truth of this, the restoration and long-delayed commercial release of The Exiles, a 1961 film about a largely forgotten corner of that deceptively bright city, is nothing less than a welcome act of defiant remembrance.

title: Britain Leaves Interest Rate at 5%
description: The Bank of England, seeking to maneuver between accelerating inflation and a slowing economy, left its main interest rate target unchanged at 5 percent on Thursday.

title: Evaluating Anxiety From an Early Age
description: Dr. Daniel Pine, a psychiatrist, directs the research program on mood and anxiety disorders of children and adolescents at the National Institute of Mental Health in Bethesda, Md. The research seeks to identify the genetic and environmental factors underlying these mental illnesses so clinicians can identify who might be prone to them, spot early symptoms and tailor treatments more precisely to individual patients.

title: Fox Dances to the Top
description: Another two-hour edition of So You Think You Can Dance lifted Fox to No. 1 in the ratings on Wednesday, drawing an average of 8.7 million viewers from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. Although the reality dance-off did not attract the nights largest audience  a distinction won by CBSs 10 oclock repeat of CSI: NY (8.9 million)  it easily outperformed its competitors that night among adults 18 to 49. NBCs Baby Borrowers came closest at 9, making NBC No. 2 for the night in that age group. At 10, NBCs Celebrity Circus delivered 5.1 million viewers. CBS ranked second for the night in total viewers but third in the 18-to-49 set behind NBC. ABC finished fourth.

title: A Tenacious Matriarch Who Wont Go Quietly
description: The Stone Angel, a film of tightly assembled bits and pieces that dont fit comfortably together despite clever dashes of magical realism connecting past and present, wants to be a Canadian equivalent of epic soap operas like Giant and The Notebook and, yes, even Gone With the Wind.

title: Petraeus Wins Confirmation for New Post
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Thursday confirmed Gen. David H. Petraeus of the United States Army as commanding officer of the Central Command, the military headquarters responsible for Iraq and Afghanistan, among other areas of operation.

title: OPEC Leader Issues Warning About Iran and Oil Supply
description: VIENNA  The head of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries warned on Thursday that oil prices would experience an unlimited increase in the event of a military conflict involving Iran because the groups members would be unable to make up the lost production.

title: Rushdie Honored, Again
description: Twenty seven years after its initial publication, Midnights Children by Salman Rushdie has received yet another accolade: on Thursday it won the Best of the Booker prize, based on an online poll in which it was pitted against five other shortlisted titles. The prize was created in celebration of the 40th anniversary of one of the worlds most prestigious literary awards.

title: Old Boy
description: Harold (Spencer Breslin) is a chubby 13-year-old afflicted by hemorrhoids, crotchetiness and a flagrant case of male pattern baldness. If the milk of hilarity just blew out your nostrils, have I got the movie for you! If not, you should know that this would-be comedic conceit is the single, repetitive, aggressively tedious joke behind Harold  unless you count the participation of Cuba Gooding Jr. as a jive-talking janitor, and of course you never do.

title: Mississippi Mayor Is Indicted on Civil Rights Charges
description: Mayor Frank Melton of Jackson, Miss., was indicted Wednesday on federal civil rights charges related to the unannounced demolition of a duplex that he said was a crack house.

title: G.M. Chief Dismisses Crisis Talk as Inaccurate
description: DETROIT  The chief executive of General Motors did his best to strike down rumors on Thursday that the automaker might seek bankruptcy protection soon.

title: Lottery Numbers
Four Detained After Deadly Istanbul Attack
description: ISTANBUL  The Turkish police said Thursday they had detained four people in connection with an investigation into a shooting at the United States consulate in Istanbul a day earlier that left six people dead and two injured.

title: In Do-Over, Pirates Make the Yankees Buckle Under
description: PITTSBURGH  It was perfectly sunny during batting practice Thursday at PNC Park, not a blip of rain on the radar. Joe Girardi, the Yankees manager, thought back to the last time the Yankees tried to play here, and how that game began against the Pittsburgh Pirates left-hander Paul Maholm.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about Markus Naslunds free-agent signing with the Rangers included an erroneous achievement for him. He was not on Swedens gold-medal winning Olympic hockey team in 2006.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the exhibition The Real Men and Women of Madison Avenue and Their Impact on American Culture at the New York Public Librarys Science, Industry and Business Library on Madison Avenue, referred incorrectly to the site. While it is part of the New York Public Library system, it is a research library, not a branch library.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: The Pursuit of Justice vs. the Pursuit of Peace
description: DAKAR, Senegal  When Luis Moreno-Ocampo, prosecutor of the International Criminal Court, reported to the United Nations Security Council last month, he painted a dire tableau of death, rape and dispossession in Darfur, saying the entire state apparatus was involved in a five-year campaign of terror there. His target, it seemed, was Sudans president.

title: Court Rejects Clean Air Rules
description: A federal appeals court struck down the regulatory cornerstone of the Bush administrations efforts at controlling air pollution on Friday, agreeing with the utility industry that the Environmental Protection Agency had exceeded its authority when it established the 2005 Clean Air Interstate Rule.

title: Lost, Lonely Souls Adrift, Randomly Crossing Paths
description: If youve ever studied the patrons in a seedy Los Angeles burger joint and felt a queasy sense of vertigo, it is the same sinking, slightly panicky sensation I had while watching Jason Freelands film Garden Party.

title: Film Series
description: ALL THE REAL AMERICANS (Thursday) A series devoted to the still unfolding oeuvre of the gifted regionalist David Gordon Green (George Washington) begins with screenings of his most recently released film, Snow Angels (2007), with Sam Rockwell as a small-town alcoholic grasping at religion as he feels his wife (Kate Beckinsale) and daughter (Grace Hudson) pulling away from him. The program, which will include all of Mr. Greens features, continues through July 24. Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, Fort Greene, Brooklyn, (718) 636-4100, bam.org; $11. (Dave Kehr)

title: Court Cases and Demonstrations Put a New Government to the Test in Thailand
description: BANGKOK  Just five months after a military junta handed back power through a parliamentary election, Thailands latest try at democracy is being severely tested by street demonstrations and a barrage of court cases.

title: Rethinking Money Market Funds
description: A money market fund is usually considered one the safest places to put cash. But lately such funds have become surprisingly dangerous  not for investors, but for the financial companies that run them.

title: Gerald Tsai, Innovative Investor, Dies at 79
description: Gerald Tsai Jr., a fund manager and financier who pioneered the creation of performance funds in the 1950s and 60s and later turned a canning company into the financial services giant Primerica, died Wednesday in Manhattan. He was 79.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: A Fragmented World, Not Far From This One
description: BECKET, Mass.  Hofesh Shechter. Its a name to remember. The Israeli-born Mr. Shechter, whose company made its first appearance in the United States at the Jacobs Pillow Dance Festival here on Wednesday night, is one of the most inventive new choreographic voices to turn up in quite a while. And in two pieces, Uprising and In Your Rooms, he shows that physical invention as part of a fiercely contemporary universe: pounding soundscapes, brilliantly moody lightscapes, changes of scene as abrupt as flickering television channels.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: When Family and Job Come Into Conflict, a Policemans Lot Is Not a Happy One
description: Within the first few minutes of Flashpoint, a new action series beginning Friday on CBS that may be too languid for its own good, a special-ops cop named Ed Lane (Hugh Dillon) blithely telegraphs his sentiments on work-family balance. Ed has a shaved head and an intense face that suggests he has seen a lot of bad things go down in dark places; he probably wears aviator glasses when he sleeps.

title: Deal for Anheuser-Busch Is Said to Be Near
description: In a reversal of its previous hostility to the idea, Anheuser-Busch is in active talks to sell itself to the Belgian brewer InBev in a friendly deal, people briefed on the matter said Thursday night.

title: In Deepening Ad Decline, Sales Fall 8% at Magazines
description: As the economy stumbled in the second quarter, magazine ad sales fell more than 8 percent, with the steepest drops in ads for vehicles and for computers and related equipment, according to a report released Thursday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the Pentagons decision to reopen bidding for the contract to build an Air Force tanker plane referred incorrectly to a Congressional panel scheduled to begin hearings on the contract that day. It was the House Armed Services Air and Land Forces Subcommittee, not a Senate committee.

title: Freed Colombian Grapples With Recalling and Releasing Pain, and Resuming Life
description: PARIS  Ingrid Betancourt fears the collapse she knows is coming.

title: Leaders of Actors Union Call Offer Unacceptable
description: LOS ANGELES  Leaders of the Screen Actors Guild declined a final offer for a new labor contract late Thursday, prompting an alliance of Hollywood production companies to demand that the union put the offer before its entire membership for a vote.

title: Bobby Durham, 71, Drummer Who Played With Jazz Greats, Dies
description: Bobby Durham, a drummer whose precise, understated style made him much sought after as a sideman by jazz greats like Duke Ellington, Lionel Hampton, Oscar Peterson and Ella Fitzgerald, died Monday in Genoa, Italy. He was 71 and had homes near Genoa and Basel, Switzerland.

title: When London and Paris Looked to the Nile for Inspiration
description: WHEN LONDON AND PARIS

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Tuesday with an article about staff rivalries within Senator John McCains presidential campaign misstated the date that the photograph of three aides aboard his plane was taken. It was Feb. 1, during the primary season, not last Friday.

title: Robert Downey Jr. to Play Sherlock Holmes
description: In the first role he has signed up for since Iron Man, Robert Downey Jr., left, will forsake his high-tech suit for a woolen cloak and cap. Mr. Downey has agreed to play the lead role in the film Sherlock Holmes, which will be directed by Guy Ritchie for Warner Brothers, Variety reported. The film is scheduled to begin shooting in October, with a screenplay by Anthony Peckham based on the detective stories of Arthur Conan Doyle and on a comic book, also called Sherlock Holmes. Most of the movie will be filmed in London. In the role, which Variety said would plumb Holmess brawn as well as his brains, Mr. Downey will have some competition. Columbia Pictures is also preparing a movie based on Holmes, this one a comedy with Sacha Baron Cohen as the title character and Will Ferrell as his sidekick, Dr. Watson.

title: Rice Warns Iran That U.S. Will Defend Allies
description: MOSCOW  The confrontation between Iran and the United States seemed to sharpen on Thursday as Iran said it tested missiles for a second day and Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said the United States would defend its allies and protect its interests against an attack.

title: An Interpreter Speaking Up for Migrants
description: WATERLOO, Iowa  In 23 years as a certified Spanish interpreter for federal courts, Erik Camayd-Freixas has spoken up in criminal trials many times, but the words he uttered were rarely his own.

title: Stranded Zoo Visitors Got a Taste of Captivity
description: The baboons were walking free at the Bronx Zoo on Wednesday night. The humans were in cages  trapped in storm-tossed Skyfari gondolas high above the wildlife, the lookers turned into the looked-at, and vice versa.

title: Museum Investigated in Purchase of Painting
description: Two committees of the Association of Art Museum Directors are examining ethical questions that have been raised about the Denver Art Museums purchase of an 1892 painting by Thomas Eakins in April, The Denver Post reported, citing Tyler Greens Modern Art Notes blog. The acquisition was financed through an unusual arrangement with Philip Anschutz, the Denver billionaire and art collector. In return for a financial donation, The Post said, Mr. Anschutz received a 50 percent ownership stake in the painting, as well as a comparable stake in a painting already in the museums collection.

title: Chevron Reports Oil Output Slips
description: The Chevron Corporation said Thursday that second-quarter oil output fell to the lowest level since 2005 as record energy prices reduced the companys share of output in countries like Nigeria and Indonesia.

title: Posada Is Returning to the Position He Prefers
description: PITTSBURGH  Jorge Posada is scheduled to catch for the Yankees twice this weekend in Toronto. That would not make news in any other season, but this year has been different for Posada. He finds himself defending his worthiness to play the position where he has spent almost 1,400 games.

title: With Tatis Starring, Mets Are Regaining Their Swagger
description: On a day when the Shea Stadium crowd serenaded the hottest hitter on the hottest team in baseball by twice chanting his last name, it was useful to recall a quiet morning in March in Port St. Lucie, Fla. Fernando Tatis, burdened by visa problems, had yet to join the Mets in spring training, but nevertheless someone wearing his No. 17 jersey was on the field, participating in workouts.

title: Clinton and Obama Mend Fences by Raising Funds
description: It was not quite a screwball comedy at the New York Hilton and Towers Thursday morning, but Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama put on a bit of a show before hundreds of donors at a political breakfast.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Grand Jury Files No Charges Against Officer in Fatal Shooting
description: A grand jury voted not to file charges against a police officer who fatally shot a driver in a road rage incident last fall and did not turn himself in until 19 hours later, the Manhattan district attorney said Thursday.

title: Magic Love
description: Death Defying Acts, a fictionalized love story involving Harry Houdini, could be a sweet little discovery if only the relationship at the core of it were more convincing. Not the one between Guy Pearce as Houdini and Catherine Zeta-Jones as the woman he becomes entangled with. What doesnt click here is the relationship between Ms. Zeta-Jones and Saoirse Ronan, who plays her daughter.

title: A Celebration of Sand, in Vast Quantities or One Grain at a Time
description: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y.  Lots of people spend summer days walking, sitting and lying on it, but beyond worrying about how to keep it out of their shoes, hair and cars, does anyone give it much thought? Sand: Memory, Meaning and Metaphor, a baggy compendium of artworks made of or about sand at the Parrish Art Museum here, offers a chance to meditate on the surprisingly many meanings of one of the worlds cheapest and  when it is in the right place, like a beach at the east end of Long Island  most precious materials.

title: All Grown Up, and Glad to Drop By
description: GRETCHEN and Michael Harrisons Tree Top Ranch is 200 acres off the Pacific Coast Highway north of San Francisco, dominated by redwood, Douglas fir and pine trees. It has a five-acre olive grove; apple, peach and pear trees; and a pond with a Finnish hot tub on its bank.

title: Turkish Premier, in Iraq, Highlights a Warming Trend
description: BAGHDAD  Turkeys prime minister visited Baghdad on Thursday, only the second foreign head of a neighboring state to visit Iraq since the American invasion.

title: Longer Walk for Lattes? Starbucks Plan Resonates
description: Are there too many Starbucks outlets in New York City?

title: No Charge for Officer in 07 Killing
description: A grand jury decided not to indict a police officer who killed a driver in a road-rage confrontation last fall but left and did not report the shooting for 19 hours, the Manhattan district attorney said Thursday.

title: Iraqis to Get Settlement From Britain Over Abuse
description: LONDON  Britains Defense Ministry agreed on Thursday to pay compensation to the family of an Iraqi hotel receptionist who died in the custody of British troops in Basra in September 2003, and to nine other Iraqis detained with him who the ministry said suffered substantive breaches of their human rights.

title: A Child Jockeys Rise on the Steppes of Mongolia
description: KHUI DOLOON KHUDAG, Mongolia  The boy rode the stallion in a trot around the camp, cooling it down after a long gallop across the steppe. He was humming his favorite Mongolian hip-hop songs, by groups like Tatar, Flash and Guy 666.

title: Zimbabwe Rivals Tentatively Begin Talks on Political Crisis
description: JOHANNESBURG  Zimbabwes ruling party began preliminary discussions with the opposition on Thursday in an effort to settle a political crisis in which both sides have staked a claim to the nations presidency.

title: For Rangel, Four Rent-Stabilized Apartments
description: While aggressive evictions are reducing the number of rent-stabilized apartments in New York, Representative Charles B. Rangel is enjoying four of them, including three adjacent units on the 16th floor overlooking Upper Manhattan in a building owned by one of New Yorks premier real estate developers.

title: Some Retailers Post Solid Gains
description: Price reductions, the federal government and Mother Nature helped retailers gain solid sales growth last month.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about biofuels in the European Union misidentified the position held by a German official who commented on the likelihood that European governments would back away from targets for biofuel use. Jochen Homann is a state secretary in Germanys economics ministry; he is not the countrys economics minister, a position held by Michael Glos.

title: High Cost of Driving Ignites Online Classes Boom
description: NEWTOWN, Pa.  First, Ryan Gibbons bought a Hyundai so he would not have to drive his gas-guzzling Chevy Blazer to college classes here. When fuel prices kept rising, he cut expenses again, eliminating two campus visits a week by enrolling in an online version of one of his courses.

title: Art in Review
description: DANICA PHELPS

title: McCain Adviser Refers to Nation of Whiners
description: BELLEVILLE, Mich.  Senator John McCain has spent the week trying to tell people that he feels their economic pain. So it was more than a little unhelpful when one of his top economic advisers was quoted Thursday as saying that the United States was only in a mental recession and that it had become a nation of whiners.

title: Georgia: Ambassador to Russia Recalled
description: Georgia recalled its ambassador to Russia for consultations after the Russian Foreign Ministry announced that a Russian military aircraft had flown over a breakaway, pro-Moscow region of Georgia this week. The flight, and Georgias response, further escalated tensions between Russia and Georgia, a former Soviet republic, as Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice visited Tbilisi, Georgias capital.

title: Making Mean Girls a Bit Less Mean
description: It was bound to happen. From Medea to Becky Sharp, from Heathers and Mean Girls to Blair Waldorf of Gossip Girl, alpha females have had a long and glorious run. But too much attention  and cautionary parental guides  poisoned the fun. Now there is a reality competition whose sole object is to make mean girls nice.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on June 24 about Kermit Love, a costume designer and co-creator of Sesame Street characters including Big Bird, referred incorrectly to the television monitor Mr. Love placed inside the Big Bird costume so the operator could see the programs set. The monitor was installed after the initial use of the figure; it was not part of the original design.

title: In Image of Irans Power, Theres Less Than Meets the Eye
description: A photograph showing four Iranian missiles heading skyward in unison was apparently digitally altered by Iranian state media, the news agency Agence France-Presse said Thursday.

title: The Life of a World-Class Sex Kitten
description: The mythologizing of the 60s gets a lusty, Germanic twist in Eight Miles High, a full-bodied take on the life of the world-class sex kitten Uschi Obermaier (Natalia Avelon). Directed by Achim Bornhak from a screenplay written with Olaf Kraemer, the movie follows, with refreshing lack of judgment and titillating brio, the berbohemian peregrinations of a wild child born to a drab Munich household but destined for flamboyant London orgies and spectacular third-world slumming.

title: Finding Energy in the Beat of Street Ball
description: Who knew it would take Jay-Zs Dead Presidents to get Ron Artest going?

title: Shares of Lehman Brothers Take a Beating
description: Lehman Brothers, Wall Streets favorite punching bag, took another beating on Thursday as jittery investors fretted over problems at home-loan giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and absorbed regulators statements that they would not bail out all financial institutions.

title: Serenity Prayer Stirs Up Doubt: Who Wrote It?
description: Generations of recovering alcoholics, soldiers, weary parents, exploited workers and just about anybody feeling beaten down by life have found solace in a short prayer that begins, God grant me the serenity to accept the things I cannot change.

title: Rhode Island: Juvenile Punishment
description: The State Supreme Court ruled unanimously that 17-year-olds tried as adults for a brief period when the law treated them as such should have their cases transferred to family court. The ruling applies to about 500 cases between July 1, 2007, and early November. Attorney General Patrick Lynch said his office would seek to try four 17-year-olds who were convicted on capital charges as adults and would go through the remaining 96 or so felony cases to determine whether they should also be tried in Superior Court. The 400 or so misdemeanors will remain in Family Court. The change in law was intended to save money by transferring juvenile offenders to the state prison. But it failed to take into account that juveniles must be housed in protective custody under prison policy, which is more expensive.

title: Government Rule Makers Looking at Pensions
description: NORWALK, Conn.  As cities and states struggle with ballooning retirement costs, accounting rule makers started an ambitious project Thursday to force state and local governments to issue better numbers and reveal the true cost of their pension promises.

title: Faust on Third, Lost Soul at Bat
description: Attention, Yankees fans. Do you yearn for the era when ballplayers made headlines for feats on the field rather than in the bedroom or the courtroom? Do you fervently wish the world still gnashed its teeth as New Yorks pinstriped paragons strolled to yet another championship? Do you pine for those glorious yesteryears when giants like Joe DiMaggio and Mickey Mantle bestrode the Bronx?

title: The Justice Department, Blind to Slavery
description: Washington

title: On Biggest Stage, More Room for Excess
description: FanFests, slam dunk contests, skills competitions, concerts (sometimes mixed with team practices), home run derbys and 3-point shootouts have rendered All-Star Games into one of many events held during a midseason break.

title: Citing New Report, Lawyers for Canadian Detainee Denounce Abuse
description: OTTAWA  A secret government report indicates that Omar Khadr, a Canadian who has been held at the Guantnamo Bay detention camp in Cuba since he was 16, has been abused by interrogators, his American military lawyer said Thursday.

title: Architect Supports Changes to Times Tower
description: The architect Renzo Piano said on Thursday that he supported plans by officials of The New York Times to alter the facade of the newspapers year-old tower, which he designed, to prevent people from scaling the veil of ceramic rods that sheathe the tower, as three men have done in the past five weeks.

title: Progress in the Drug Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Hard Look at Tough Times for an Italian Marriage
description: Silvio Soldinis film Days and Clouds suggests that Italys middle class is as much under siege as that of the United States. In both countries, it appears, job security isnt what it used to be, and corporate downsizing is plunging affluent families into sudden financial tailspins.

title: Setback for White House on Visitor Logs
description: WASHINGTON The Bush administration was dealt a setback on Friday in its efforts to keep records of White House visitors under wraps when an appeals court refused to throw out a lawsuit seeking access to the material.

title: G.E. May Spin Off Its Consumer and Industrial Unit
description: As it seeks to cut costs and bolster its flagging share price, General Electric may be willing to dispense with the business from which it sprang: the light bulb.

title: The Eerie Splendor of Devils Tower
description: IT was evening in northeastern Wyoming, a Monday in early May at Devils Tower National Monument, and I was 500 feet in the air. My hands were jammed in a crack, feet seeking grip on a wall that dropped straight away to talus and dirt far below.

title: A Web of Cynicism
description: Embracing superficiality in both subject and style, August is a low-key drama in high-tech clothing. Set in New York City in August 2001, in the tense climate of a dot-com startup where stock price and corporate morale are plummeting, the movie unspools with an unrelieved cynicism and a metallic aftertaste.

title: Toyota Scales Back Production of Big Vehicles
description: DETROIT  Toyota acknowledged Thursday that, like its rival automakers in Detroit, it misjudged the drastic swing in the American market away from larger vehicles.

title: Obama and McCain Lag in Naming Bundlers Who Rake in Campaign Cash
description: Senators Barack Obama and John McCain have long been among the most outspoken critics of the influence of money in politics.

title: Recalling a Cheerful Man Made Angry by Hypocrisy
description: For a while, way back in the days of the Hollywood blacklist, Eliot Asinof fronted for Walter Bernstein. Before we go further, some of you may need a brief primer.

title: An Itty-Bitty Brother From Another Planet
description: In Meet Dave, the latest in a long line of disposable Eddie Murphy vehicles, the star talks funny, walks funny and enters a bathroom stall for some rather less humorous noisy business. In yet another potty scene (this movie knows its target audience), he stands with his legs apart as dollar bills float and coins (ouch) tumble from his posterior, excreting money like a slot machine thats racked up three 7s. He poops money for laughs, though of course what hes really doing is pooping laughs for money. Talk about filthy lucre.

title: Correction
description: The Havens column last Friday about Oxford, Miss., misstated the Web site for the Colonels Quarters, a B&B there. It is www.thecolonelsquarters.com.

title: Help Closer to Home
description: One proven way to prevent borderline young offenders from becoming serious criminals is to treat them  and their families  in community-based counseling programs instead of shipping them off to juvenile facilities that are often hundreds of miles away from home. Early data suggests that New York Citys alternative-placement programs are cutting recidivism rates.

title: Kennedys Big Day
description: It was the worst of days, it was the best of days. On Wednesday, Senate Democrats capitulated to the Bush administration on wiretapping  with Barack Obama joining the coalition of the craven.

title: Comrades in Chaos, Invading Iraq
description: Restraint can be as important to a serious television drama as it is to art collecting or the dinner table. Particularly when the subject is as raw as war, sentimentality or florid emotionalism can offend and even repel viewers. Its exercise can be a sign of respect and sensitivity, but it can also seem smug, a veiled form of one-upmanship.

title: Amid Political Uncertainty, Total Cancels Investments in Iran
description: PARIS  Total, the French oil giant, has decided to back away from planned investments in Iran because of political uncertainty, a company official said Thursday.

title: Summers Night
description: The last couple of nights Ive stood at the edge of the pasture watching the fireflies. They rise from the grass, flickering higher and higher until one of them turns into the blinking lights of a jet flying eastward far above the horizon. I can feel, rather than see, the bats working around the house and in the coves between the trees, feeding on insects that are invisible but fully audible to them.

title: A Hint of New Life to a McCain Birth Issue
description: In the most detailed examination yet of Senator John McCains eligibility to be president, a law professor at the University of Arizona has concluded that neither Mr. McCains birth in 1936 in the Panama Canal Zone nor the fact that his parents were American citizens is enough to satisfy the constitutional requirement that the president must be a natural-born citizen.

title: A Painters Social Network, Traced in Her Photographs
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn.  Elizabeth Peytons endearing, jewel-like portraits are frequently, and transparently, based on photographic ephemera: newspaper images, film stills, vintage black-and-white prints. Her own snapshots, taken over the last two decades with 35-millimeter, Polaroid and, most recently, digital cameras, are an important but rarely acknowledged source.

title: Corrections
description: Business Day

title: The Candidates Speak Off the Cuff, and Trouble Quickly Follows
description: At this rate, both John McCain and Barack Obama may want to rethink their fondness for town-hall-style meetings. Both have embroiled themselves in controversies this week as a result of departing from scripted campaign speeches and speaking off the cuff.

title: Ral Esparza Joins Speed-the-Plow Cast
description: Ral Esparza, the Tony-nominated star of The Homecoming, will join the cast of Speed-the-Plow, the acerbic David Mamet play returning to Broadway in October. Mr. Esparza has signed on to play the role of Charlie Fox, a Hollywood producer, opposite Jeremy Piven, who will play the production executive Bobby Gould. The role of Karen, the ditsy secretary played by Madonna in the original 1988 production, has yet to be cast.

title: Guilty Plea in Case of Illegal Shelters
description: Douglas Steger, the former owner of the American Financial Capital Corporation, a business that raised money for hedge funds, pleaded guilty to a tax shelter conspiracy on Thursday and agreed to cooperate in a federal investigation.

title: After Crash, Tour Has a New Leader
description: SUPER-BESSE, France  The yellow jersey is never safe at the Tour de France, not even in the last mile.

title: Weathering the Storm
description: BY some bit of celestial sense of humor, the algorithms and biorhythms that determine where people buy second homes are often the same ones that determine where hurricanes are prevalent. And while our houses are at the mercy of Mother Nature, we are not without tools for making sure those homes weather the storm.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,110 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Thursday:

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Saving Pets Isnt a Whim
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a new supercomputer intended to increase the speed of molecular simulations misstated the number of processors in the machine and misspelled the name of a chemical simulation software company. The computer has 512 specialized processors working simultaneously, not 517, and the companys name is Schrdinger, not Schrdinger.

title: Voice Seeking Answers for Parents About a School Collapse Is Silenced
description: BEIJING  Three weeks after the earthquake in Sichuan Province, five bereaved fathers whose children died in collapsed schools sought help from a local human rights activist named Huang Qi.

title: Back From War, but Still Engaged in a Battle
description: To the Editor:

title: With Luck, a Rocky Landing
description: ADRSPACH, Czech Republic  Exactly a decade has passed since a man called Oxygen first hurled himself across Amerika. Known for his jumping ability, Oxygen, a lanky Czech, catapulted to legend status by leaping a nearly 10-foot-wide abyss separating two 100-foot sandstone spires.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Yankees' Rivera a Non-Starter for A.L. All-Stars
description: Anyone hoping to see Yankees closer Mariano Rivera start the All-Star Game at Yankee Stadium on Tuesday night will probably have to simulate it for themselves on PlayStation. While the idea of honoring Rivera by starting him has gained some traction in the news media, an American League official said it was doubtful that would occur.

title: A Pointless Departure
description: Just why John Howard was denied reappointment as head of the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health is a mystery that deserves to be cleared up. But whatever the reasons for it, the timing of his departure  in the waning months of the Bush administration  could hardly have been worse. Programs often slip badly as an administration winds down, and we fear that without Dr. Howards leadership, the agencys exemplary work on behalf of ground zero workers will stall.

title: New Line Executives Form a New Studio
description: Five months after Time Warner announced that New Line Cinema would cease to operate as a full-service, stand-alone unit, its founder, Robert Shaye, and former co-chairman, Michael Lynne, announced on Thursday that they had formed a new studio, Unique Features. They said in a statement that they hoped to produce two to three movies a year. Warner Brothers has a three-year first-look agreement with Unique Features, and will handle domestic and international marketing and distribution for those films produced under the arrangement.

title: Ballots Stuffed, All-Star Voting 2.0 Ends
description: As the deadline for the All-Star Games final vote drew nearer, Nick Ferraros work grew more frantic. Since noon Tuesday, Ferraro, a lifelong Phillies fan, had camped out on the left-field concourse of Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia alongside three fellow fanatics with the sole purpose of putting outfielder Pat Burrell into next Tuesdays game.

title: Calling All Architects
description: The Smithsonian Institution has invited architects to submit their qualifications to design the National Museum of African American History and Culture, scheduled to open in 2015 in Washington. The request for proposals is the first step in the process to hire an architect for the Smithsonians 19th museum, which will be on a five-acre site on the National Mall. The request, posted on Thursday on fedbizopps.gov, describes the process and the criteria by which the firms will be judged. A board of experts drawn primarily from the Smithsonian will review the proposals, which are due by Sept. 19. An architect is to be named in the spring. The design process is expected to take up to three years, with construction set to begin in 2012. The architects must demonstrate an appreciation of African-American history and culture, the request says, and must complete the full design within three years.

title: Scaffolding Dismantled From Guggenheim
description: Construction workers have begun dismantling the scaffolding that has encased the Guggenheim Museum on the Upper East Side of Manhattan for nearly three years. Restoration architects and mechanical engineers have worked to repair the curving, eggshell exterior of the building, which was designed by Frank Lloyd Wright and celebrates its 50th anniversary this fall.

title: With Alou Out, the Mets Seem Ready to Go Shopping
description: If this is how it ends, Moises Alous time with the Mets will be remembered less for his glorious September last season than for four visits to the disabled list and unfulfilled expectations. Alou signed with the team anticipating another World Series championship, or at least trips to the playoffs, but his latest injury  a torn left hamstring  may signal the end of his career.

title: Minimum Wage Increases Faster Than Median Wage
description: In the last few years, the minimum wage in New York State has increased almost 40 percent, while the median pay for hourly workers has risen much more slowly, not even keeping pace with inflation, according to a report released Thursday by the federal Department of Labor.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the increasing appetite of foreign investors for American assets misstated the size of Abu Dhabis newly purchased stake in the Chrysler Building. As an article in The Metro Section reported, the Abu Dhabi Investment Council bought 90 percent of the building, not 75 percent. (The council bought a 75 percent stake from an investment fund owned by Prudential Real Estate Investors and a 15 percent stake from a group led by Tishman Speyer Properties.)

title: Lustrous Visions, Cut From Stone
description: Despite signs to the contrary, conspicuous consumption is not what it used to be. Most exhibitions of decorative arts from the past, especially Europes monarchical age, drive that fact home in thrilling, and sometimes off-putting, fashion. But few shows do so with quite the dazzling vehemence of Art of the Royal Court: Treasures in Pietre Dure From the Palaces of Europe, a stealth blockbuster at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Closing on Broadway: Two Traffic Lanes
description: In a surprising reshaping of the urban landscape, the city is creating a public esplanade along a portion of one of its most prominent streets, Broadway in Midtown, setting aside the east side of the roadway for a bicycle lane and a pedestrian walkway with cafe tables, chairs, umbrellas and flower-filled planters.

title: Book Cites Secret Red Cross Report of C.I.A. Torture of Qaeda Captives
description: WASHINGTON  Red Cross investigators concluded last year in a secret report that the Central Intelligence Agencys interrogation methods for high-level Qaeda prisoners constituted torture and could make the Bush administration officials who approved them guilty of war crimes, according to a new book on counterterrorism efforts since 2001.

title: Dow Chemical Buying a Rival for $15.3 Billion
description: Dow Chemical said Thursday that it had agreed to buy Rohm & Haas, a specialty chemical maker, for about $15.3 billion in cash.

title: The Day of the New Surveillance Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Olympic Sponsors to Benefit Under a Tougher Stance in China
description: BEGINNING on Friday, the Chinese government will begin restricting advertising space in Beijing, giving preference to the official sponsors of the Olympic Games.

title: The Ultimate Outsider Under a Purple Umbrella
description: Over the years Neal Medlyn has channeled superstars like Phil Collins, R. Kelly and Beyonc. This week he is back at it with a Prince extravaganza, Neal Medlyns Unpronounceable Symbol, which opened at Performance Space 122 on Wednesday.

title: The End of the Road for Passing Strange
description: Passing Strange, the Broadway musical that will soon be filmed by Spike Lee, will end its run at the Belasco Theater after the Sunday matinee performance on July 20. The show, about a black musician who wanders the world in search of meaning, only to find it within, began previews on Broadway on Feb. 8 and opened on Feb. 28. The two performances Mr. Lee will record in front of a live audience are on July 19 at 2 and 8 p.m.

title: Senate Passes Bill to Help Troubled Homeowners
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Friday afternoon approved a major package of housing legislation, including a rescue plan aimed at helping hundreds of thousands of troubled borrowers avoid foreclosure by refinancing their mortgages.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Norman Marcus, the lawyer responsible for much of the language in New York Citys zoning regulations, referred incorrectly to the citys Board of Standards and Appeals, which granted a zoning variance that Mr. Marcus criticized in 1964. The board still exists; it is not defunct.

title: Trade Secrets
description: The problem with The Reflecting Pool, an investigative drama that mucks around with 9/11 conspiracy theories, is not that its ideas are silly. Strictly from an imaginative point of view, there is something unnerving about the weirdly elegant way the towers fell. And not just the north and south buildings but also the adjacent 7 World Trade Center, a smaller edifice, suffering much less damage, that collapsed in an identical manner but received far less coverage from  whats the phrase Im looking for?  oh yes: a complicit, propaganda-foisting media/industrial complex in the pocket of the Bush administration and the Jews and the oil industry!

title: A Good Old-Fashioned Thrill Ride
description: B. DEREK SHAW is not into seat belts. Which is cool if its 1957 and youre joy-riding in your new Chevy. Not so cool if youre about to rocket 90 feet into the sky before hurtling back to earth at breakneck speed, with a tangle of yellow pinewood the only thing separating your face from the concrete.

title: Justices Are Asked to Reconsider
description: Eighty-five House Republicans asked the Supreme Court to reconsider its June 25 ruling barring the death penalty for the rape of a child because the ruling was based on inaccurate information. In a letter written at the behest of Representative Roy Blunt of Missouri, the Republican whip, the lawmakers noted that the five justices in the majority based their decision in part on the assumption that there was no federal death penalty for the rape of a child, and that therefore putting someone to death for the crime violated evolving standards of decency by which the court weighs application of capital punishment. In fact, Congress revised the sex-crimes section of the Uniform Code of Military Justice in 2006 to add child rape to the military death penalty.

title: New York City Waterfalls, Friend of the Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: McCains Health Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Fish Affect California Water Supply
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The federal Fish and Wildlife Service this week underscored the imminent threat of extinction facing the delta smelt, a two-inch-long fish native to the Sacramento River delta, when it announced it was considering whether to declare the fish endangered.

title: Russia: Soyuz Team Pulls Explosive Bolt
description: Two Russian astronauts successfully removed an explosive bolt from their Soyuz capsule during a daring spacewalk. The astronauts, Sergei Volkov and Oleg Kononenko, performed the spacewalk, cutting away at insulation with a serrated knife and removing one of the explosive bolts that unlatch the Soyuzs descent capsule from the propulsion module. The Soyuz separates from the module during descent, but during the last two returns to Earth, a latch assembly has not disengaged. That sent the capsules into a harrowing ballistic entry that exerted greater than usual G-forces on those inside. The bolt was removed for examination back on Earth.

title: Loan-Agency Woes Swell From a Trickle to a Torrent
description: The word began spreading across Wall Street trading desks on Monday morning: Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the giant companies at the heart of the nations housing market, might be in trouble.

title: 25 Northeast Getaways
description: An article last Friday about 25 getaways in the Northeast included outdated information about a destination in Millbrook, N.Y. The Institute for Ecosystem Studies changed its name to the Cary Institute of Ecosystem Studies earlier this year, and it no longer includes the Gifford Garden among its features for visitors.

title: Six Flags Subterranean Style, or Something Like It
description: Like any conscientious movie critic, I do what I can to avoid clichs, and since I am only human I dont always succeed. But I have long vowed never to stoop to what I regard as the lowest kind of hackery, which is to describe a motion picture as a thrill ride, a heckofa ride or any other kind of ride.

title: Echoes of an Earlier Time on a Glimmering Lake
description: LONG before there was a Baseball Hall of Fame, Cooperstown was a pilgrimage site as the home of James Fenimore Cooper, the early 19th-century superstar author whose wildly popular novels, including The Deerslayer and The Last of the Mohicans, put a haze of romance on an upstate New York frontier that had already vanished.

title: Housing-Rescue Bill Advances in Senate
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate moved ahead with a housing-rescue bill on Thursday just as the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac seemed to be reeling and in dire need of a helping hand.

title: Democrats Dig In as G.O.P. Presses for Oil Exploration in Protected Areas
description: WASHINGTON  House Democratic leaders took a hard line Thursday against opening up restricted areas to oil production as Republicans threatened to try to keep Congress in session this summer unless they got a vote on new drilling opportunities.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Dorian Leigh, a prominent model in the 1940s and 1950s, misidentified the college she attended. It was Randolph-Macon Womans College in Lynchburg, Va., which changed its name to Randolph College in 2007. She did not attend Randolph-Macon College in Ashland, Va. Because of an editing error, the obituary also omitted the name of her second husband. He was Roger Mehle.

title: First an Election, Then a New Visitor Center
description: It is a nice bit of historic symmetry for the long-awaited opening of the new Capitol Visitor Center.

title: Court Cases and Demonstrations Put a New Government to the Test in Thailand
description: BANGKOK  Just five months after a military junta handed back power through a parliamentary election, Thailands latest try at democracy is being severely tested by street demonstrations and a barrage of court cases.

title: Pelfrey Hits His Spots, Igniting Mets Surge
description: The quotation jumped off the page in Mike Pelfreys Wednesday newspaper. Carlos Beltrn on the morning after Pelfreys latest revelation of a start, his seven shutout innings against the Giants, his out-classing of the Sports Illustrated cover boy, Tim Lincecum:

title: On the Beach, Under a Tiffany-Blue Sky
description: There are two unorthodox things about this summers most adorable chick-lit book: Its a work of nonfiction, and its written by a guy. Michael Tonellos Bringing Home the Birkin, the story of one mans relentless assault on the worlds horsiest luxury-goods label, may break the mold a bit, but it does a fine job of fulfilling this genres basic requirements. Its smart. Its fizzy. Its amusingly snarky, with attitude to burn. The genres four basic food groups are ambition, romance, travel and partying, and Mr. Tonello dishily delivers (he adores alliteration) them all.

title: The Voices in Your Head Will Not Be Your Own
description: There have been suicides in your neighborhood, even one in your building. And theres something strange about the spot on the sidewalk where the man who jumped from his apartment landed. A storm is brewing too. And there are hushed voices in your head, guiding you through your memories and accompanying you on your day. Your very strange day.

title: MoMA Buys a Suite of 3 Johns Paintings
description: MOMA BUYS A SUITE

title: The Talibans Rising Tide
description: The swelling forces of Taliban and Al Qaeda fighters in Pakistans border region pose a grave threat to American and NATO troops in Afghanistan. They also pose a grave threat to the Pakistani people. Pakistans Taliban militias, like their Afghan counterparts, are trying to impose their harsh medieval version of Islamic law. More than a thousand Pakistanis have been killed in terrorist attacks in the past year, mostly in the border areas where radical Islamic fighters are strongest.

title: Pistorius Will Try to Qualify in Rome
description: The double-amputee sprinter Oscar Pistorius will resume his bid to qualify for the Olympics on Friday at a Golden Gala in Rome featuring a large cast of standouts honing their form for the Beijing Games.

title: U.S. Tries to Help 3 Scholars Barred From Leaving Gaza
description: GAZA  American consular officials drove from Jerusalem to the Gazan border on Thursday in an unusual effort to interview three Gazan Fulbright scholars who Israel says are too dangerous to allow into the country.

title: E.P.A. Refuses to Regulate Greenhouse Gases
description: The administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency on Friday disavowed any obligation to regulate greenhouse gases under existing law, saying that to do so would involve an unprecedented expansion of the agencys authority that would have a profound effect on virtually every sector of the economy.

title: Stoppard Overwhelmed by Worlds Problems
description: Tom Stoppard, 71, says that he has a case of playwrights block, and that the cause is the worlds problems. So much is in the foreground now, huge, important subjects, that you kind of goggle at them  O.K., shall I do global warming or shall I do Iraq, maybe Ill do Afghanistan, and nothing gets written, this Czech-born British writer told Reuters at a literary festival in Paraty, a Brazilian town. Mr. Stoppards last play, Rock n Roll, was about love, revolution and music in the 1960s.

title: Striking Concrete Haulers Reach Tentative Contract
description: The union local representing striking concrete truck drivers in New York City announced on Thursday night that it had reached a tentative contract with the citys concrete producers.

title: Jackson Barks, but Does He Still Have Bite?
description: It used to be called the Jesse Jackson problem: Democratic presidential candidates fearing they would lose black votes if they got on Mr. Jacksons bad side, given the influence he accrued as a civil rights activist and his history-making races for the White House in 1984 and 1988.

title: Sherman Lee, Who Led Cleveland Museum, Dies at 90
description: Sherman E. Lee, an expert on Asian art who as director of the Cleveland Museum of Art for a quarter of a century elevated it to the top echelon of American museums, died Wednesday in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 90.

title: A Wrestling Match That Was Meant to Be
description: Wrestling shoes spill out of a suitcase, near a diploma and a yearbook. Personalized Olympic business cards are stacked next to a pile of dirty laundry. An Olympic flag hangs opposite a Terminator 2 poster.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about recommendations for wider cholesterol screening in children and more aggressive use of cholesterol-lowering drugs misstated part of the new guidelines. They say that drug treatment should be considered for children 8 and older who have LDL, or bad cholesterol, of 190 milligrams per deciliter. If a child has a family history of early heart disease or two other risk factors, drug treatment may be started when LDL is 160 milligrams per deciliter, and if a child has diabetes, at 130 milligrams per deciliter. The guidelines for children with 190 milligrams per deciliter do not mention other risk factors.

title: A Stand-Up Comic in Drag, Bursting Protective Bubbles
description: Taylor Mac is wearing something akin to rags when we first meet him in The Be(a)st of Taylor Mac at the Here Arts Center, and before long he has made a mess of the stage as well. But the sloppier things get, the more you marvel at how assured and in control this brash, genial performer is.

title: World War I on Their Minds, 60s Pop in Their Hearts
description: In the once-upon-a-time fairy tale called La France, a World War I movie like none other, French soldiers move through darkly verdant landscapes worthy of Henri Rousseau. There are no lions or dreaming guitarists in this nocturnal green world, only shadows, phantoms, twinkling stars and discordant harmonies created by the whirring animals and exploding bombs. There are, however, several stringed instruments, and every so often, when this already strange land seems ready to settle into eerie silence, these soldiers break out their instruments and into jangling, plaintive song.

title: Wrote 28; Accumulated Many More
description: Larry McMurtrys fragmentary Books: A Memoir has little to say about the matter of writing them, other than that by the mid-1970s this process ceased to engage him as much as buying, selling and collecting them and, ultimately, creating what he calls a book town in Archer City, Tex., modeled on the Welsh village of Hay-on-Wye. This is, he concedes, a passion that may separate him from some of his readers.

title: Theater Listings
description: EAST TO EDINBURGH The annual Edinburgh Festival Fringe, which begins on Aug. 3 in Scotland, will include a wide assortment of productions, more than 2,000, some of which may eventually find their way to New York. The recently ended theater season here included several hits from Edinburgh, like the National Theater of Scotlands production of Black Watch by Gregory Burke; Enda Walshs dark comedy The Walworth Farce; and James Bralys comic solo show Life in a Marital Institution (which is running through Aug. 15 at the SoHo Playhouse).

title: Old Port Towns Appeal Reaches Beyond Northwest
description: JEANNE and Kevin Clark bought a vacation home in Nevada City, Calif., about 20 years ago. They had planned to relocate to Nevada City, a historic gold-rush town northeast of Sacramento, after their careers as high school teachers in Southern California.

title: Folk Tales From the Seattle Woods
description: Lots of indie rock bands are naming themselves after woodland mammals these days, but Fleet Foxes actually sing about the forest. The band, from Seattle, specializes in what Gram Parsons called cosmic American music, and its melodic country-rock recalls a host of like-minded bands, from old (Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young) to new (My Morning Jacket, Band of Horses). The songs on its recent self-titled debut album are as strangely familiar as campfire hymns, and at the Bowery Ballroom on Wednesday night a sold-out crowd sang along to almost all of them.

title: For Short Sellers, It Doesnt Get Much Better
description: Blood is in the water, and short sellers, often viewed as the sharks of Wall Street, are circling.

title: Detainees, as Lawyers, Test Tribunal System
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba  Walid bin Attash, a detainee with a wry smile who is charged as a planner of the Sept. 11 attacks, had a question.

title: Regal Visions
description: The Metropolitan Museums Art of the Royal Court offers the first in-depth survey of the arts and crafts of pietre dure, or works inlaid with finely cut semiprecious stones.

title: Elizabeth Peyton at the Aldrich Museum
description: Admirers can view Elizabeth Peytons snapshots, an important but rarely acknowledged source of her paintings, at the Aldrich Museum.

title: Sand: Memory, Meaning and Metaphor
description: A baggy compendium of artworks made of or about sand at the Parrish Art Museum. Ken Johnson reviews.

title: HBO Talks About Sex Sequel, Sopranos Movie
description: Given the enormous box office success of Sex and the City, talk of a sequel is not surprising. And on Thursday HBO confirmed that Warner Bros. and New Line Cinema are already at work on No. 2.

title: HBO Orders Three Pilots, Including One Set In Post-Katrina New Orleans
description: HBO has given the green light to three television pilots: a comedy based on a book about the sexual exploits of a Capitol Hill staffer, a look at post-Katrina New Orleans by the creator of The Wire, and a drama about Atlantic City in the 1920s.

title: The Quad Countdown: No. 49 Mississippi State
description: Location: Starkville, Miss.

title: An Imminent Victory for Net Neutrality Advocates
description: UPDATED| 2:00 p.m. Added comments from Friday news conference

title: Tretiak on N.H.L.-K.H.L. Agreement': Hopefully, Well Find a Compromise [UPDATED]
description: [Update Friday: Nashville forward Alexander Radulov has reportedly signed a three-year contract with Salavat Yulaev Ufa, the current Russian champions, according to a report in the Russian paper Sport-Express and first carried in English by the web site Fourth Period. Radulov, 22, reportedly has one year left on his contract with the Predators. Under the preliminary agreement reached last month and confirmed Thursday in Zurich between NHL and KHL officials not to poach players under contract, Radulov may have to stay in Nashville. No reaction yet from NHL, KHL, Predators or Salavat officials.]

title: A weekly roundup of the latest from the T Web site
description: By Bruce Pask

title: Beheading Hitler
description: The guy who decapitated the wax figure of Der Fuhrer at Madame Tussauds in Berlin is being hailed as a German national hero, like the legendary Claus Schenk Graf von Stauffenberg, who led a failed assassination attempt against Hitler in 1944. The vandal did it on a dare at a pub. A beer hall Putsch?  Time.com

title: Helphire to Raise $89.1 Million in Stock Sale
description: Britains Helphire is set to raise $89.1 million through a placing and open offer. The vehicle rental and accident management group has also announced the retirement of chief executive Mark Jackson, The Financial Times reported.

title: Because of Weis, Silence and Shame at Notre Dame
description: A brief roundup of things Ive read, and which in turn you may be interested in reading. The kids are calling this linking.

title: Atomic Moguls Raises $1 Million for Sports Fans Fantasies
description: Atomic Moguls, a company that focuses on fantasy sports games, recently attracted $1 million in fresh capital to fund the release of about 1,000 sports applications between now and Labor Day.

title: A First Look at the iPhone Apps Store
description: Well, the iPhone Apps Store went live last night, and its just crazy, insane fun. Ive just downloaded about 30 programs to play with on the iPhone 3G. As I predicted, its just a blast.

title: Zurich Pulls Out of R.B.S. Auction
description: Zurich Financial Services has withdrawn from the 7 billion pound ($13.8 billion) auction for Royal Bank of Scotlands insurance assets, The Financial Times reported. The decision raises further questions about whether the bank will be able to divest of the operations.

title: Nuveen Chief Steps Down
description: Timothy Schwertfeger, the longtime Nuveen Investments chief, has left the company, The Chicago Tribune reported. Mr. Schwertfeger sold the investment management firm to Madison Dearborn Partners last year.

title: Two Korean Companies Get I.P.O. Green Light
description: POSCO Engineering & Construction, the construction arm of steel giant POSCO, and Daewoo Capital have each been given a green light for initial public offerings in Seoul that will raise up to $1.48 billion in total, The Financial Times reported.

title: Cohen Takes Millennium Global Stake
description: One day after reports said that he backed out of the buyout of International Asset Management, Sir Ronald Cohen has bought a stake in Millennium Global, one of Londons oldest hedge fund managers, The Financial Times said.

title: No Loans Made to Investment Firms in Past Week
description: In a sign that there may have been some improvements in credit strains, Wall Street investment firms did not borrow from the Federal Reserves emergency lending program during the past week while commercial banks scaled back, The Associated Press reported.

title: UniCredit Enlists Trio to Run Investment Banking
description: Italys UniCredit has named Andreas Bohn, Bernhard Brinker and Piergiorgio Peluso as co-heads of investment banking, Bloomberg reported.

title: Restaurant Chain Auction Said to Be Off the Table
description: An auction of restaurant chain Dave & Busters may not have had enough flavor to continue. The process to sell the Wellspring Capital Management-owned group began early this year, but has been silent for the past several weeks, sources told The Daily Deal.

title: Investor Chief Plans Buying Spree
description: While announcing first-half results, Investor chief executive Brje Ekholm said the company is planning to start acquiring companies within the next six to 18 months, The Financial Times reported.

title: Taylor Wimpey Rises on Private Equity Rumor
description: Shares in Britains Taylor Wimpey Plc rose as much as 18 percent on a report in Building magazine that it may sell a third of the company to a U.S. private equity investor, Bloomberg News said.

title: NAB Could Acquire ABNs Australia, New Zealand Businesses
description: National Australia Bank is in talks with ABN Amro to acquire its Australian and New Zealand wholesale and investment banking businesses in what would be a 1 billion Australian dollar ($962 million) deal, The Financial Times reported.

title: $20 Billion Worth of Asian I.P.O.s Shelved in First Half
description: Asian I.P.O.s worth about $20 billion have been shelved this year due to turmoil in the market and bankers are beginning to fear a rush in the second half should conditions improve, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Citi Sells German Business for $7.7 Billion
description: Citigroup will sell its German retail business to Frances Credit Mutuel for $7.7 billion, it said on Friday, part of a global reorganization of the U.S. bank.

title: Sanofi Makes Official Bid for Zentiva
description: Sanofi-Aventis has made a formal $2.02 billion offer to buy the rest of Zentiva, challenging PPF Groups bid for the Czech drugmaker, Bloomberg reported.

title: Dog Days of Summer for Two Big Hedge Funds
description: June has been a cruel month for two high-profile hedge funds. New York-based Prentice Capital Management and London-based Tosca Holdings have each suffered steep declines, The Wall Street Journal reported.

title: Shinsei Buys G.E.s Japanese Consumer-Finance Unit
description: General Electric has agreed to sell its Japanese consumer-finance business to Shinsei Bank for 580 billion yen ($5.4 billion), according to reports citing undisclosed sources.

title: Facing Bankruptcy, Midwest Said to Set Union Bargaining Deadline
description: Midwest Air Group has set Friday as a deadline to reach new deals with its union pilots and crew as it scrambles to avoid a Chapter 11 filing, Dealscape reported.

title: Regulator Said to Plan Capital Rules for UBS, Credit Suisse
description: Switzerlands Federal Banking Commission has outlined plans to impose higher capital requirements on UBS and Credit Suisse in the wake of their massive losses in the credit crisis, The Financial Times reported.

title: New Comfort for U.S. Acquirers Abroad?
description: Last months Justice Department opinion related to Halliburton may allow United States-based buyers of foreign firms to avoid risk under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act  but theres a catch, Compliance Week reports.

title: IMG Bid Said to Miss the Mark
description: Terry Semels attempt to buy management and marketing firm IMG is apparently over before it even began, The New York Post reported.

title: Trulia Raises $15 Million

title: London Theater Journal: Afterlife is a Rare Misfire from Michael Frayn
description: Its hard to imagine a grander entrance than that made by Roger Allam in Michael Frayns Afterlife, which I saw Thursday night at the National. Mr. Frayn; his long-time collaborator, the director Michael Blakemore, and a top-of-the-line design team have made it seem as if Mr. Allam himself summons into being the grand flight of cathedral stairs he descends. And the imposing two-story doors that admit him. And the brass fanfare that heralds his arrivals and departures. And the light that turns from sun to shadow in an instant. And, oh, pretty much the whole universe.

title: Anheuser and InBev Enter Friendly Talks

InBev has raised its offer to $70 a share, more than the $65 it had originally offered, a person close to the talks said on Friday.

The esplanade, which the city is calling Broadway Boulevard, will run from 42nd Street to Herald Square. Scheduled to open in mid-August, it will change that section of Broadway from a four-lane to a two-lane street.
