title: Mexican Hotels Offer Summer Bargains
description: Mexico is full of summer travel deals, particularly in the luxury market. Aqua Cancn (www.feel-aqua.com) is offering a three-night package starting at $1,605 per couple that includes airport transfers, breakfast, a three-course dinner and a couples massage, through Dec. 20. The Casa Dorada Los Cabos Resort and Spa (www.casadorada.com) is offering suites starting at $306 per night (a 40 percent saving) through Oct. 10. For those who would like something away from the ocean and high up in the hills, the Hotel Spa Ixtapan (www.spamexico.com) is offering a mother-daughter discount, which entails one full-price payment of $1,299 and one discounted rate of $600 (for seven nights), through Oct. 4. Prices include meals, yoga and other fitness classes, and 21 spa treatments or services. And Sandos Hotels and Resorts is offering nightly ratesfrom $95 to $110 at three of its properties, for travel completed by Aug. 24 (www.sandoshotels.com). All prices are based on double occupancy.

title: Running a Home on Yankee Ingenuity

For Mig Halpine, $135 or so a barrel simply means a faster payback for our solar panels  three giant jet-black sheets tilted to catch the sun behind the house in Bethany, Conn., that he shares with his wife, Calico Harington, and their children, Miles, 13, and Ella, 11.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions last Sunday about plans to build two hotels in Midtown Manhattan misidentified the community board whose territory includes one proposed site, at 120 West 41st Street, and the Broadhurst Theater on West 44th Street, which would sell 9,480 square feet in air rights to the hotel developer. Both properties are within the boundaries of Community Board 5, not 4. The article also referred incorrectly to the status of the hotel proposal. title: Scoops of Sweetness
description: Not much has changed at the Snowflake Ice Cream Shoppe in Riverhead since Herb and Joan Kunitz opened it in 1953. A neon ice cream cone still glows on its roof. Customers inch along single file at the inside counter and emerge to sit on pink wooden benches or lean on car hoods, sugar cone in hand. And, according to the current owner, Stuart Feldschuh, everyone tells the same Snowflake story.

title: Short on Subway Stops, Long on Christmas Lights
description: ABOUT three years ago, Christian Zaino, an undergraduate at New York University, found that the history of Dyker Heights, his southwest Brooklyn neighborhood near the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, had not yet been fully documented. So he made it the topic of his senior thesis, poring over archived stories from the daily Brooklyn Eagle and joining up with the Dyker Heights Civic Association as the neighborhood historian. Though the thesis has not yet been published, it has brought Mr. Zaino, now a medical student, a certain authorial distinction. I wrote the entire Wikipedia article, he said recently.

title: A Tasty Density
description: Prospect Heights is among the citys smaller neighborhoods, but it is home to numerous attractions (the Brooklyn Public Library, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, the Brooklyn Museum) and to a vibrant dining scene. There is room for the Garden Cafe, a tiny institution since 1986, and for James, a promising restaurant that opened last month.

description: I am in love with a nameless little girl made of charcoal dust. She is the sparingly drawn heroine of Wave, Suzy Lees wordless picture book about a day at the beach, and she bursts from the page with vitality.

description: ITS dispiriting indeed to watch the United States financial system, supposedly the envy of the world, being taken to its knees. But thats the show were watching, brought to you by somnambulant regulators, greedy bank executives and incompetent corporate directors.

Weeks has scored 58 runs this season, including nine in the last six games. Last season, he hit 30 points higher after the All-Star Game than he did before the break and more than doubled his home run output.

title: Beloved Yankee Remembered as an Example
description: TORONTO  Bobby Murcer never played for a championship Yankees team. But like Don Mattingly, it made no difference to his legacy. Murcer was beloved by players for his good nature and revered as an embodiment of what the Yankees try to represent. He was competitive and classy, tough and tender, all at once.

title: Passing the Torch
description: A desperate search is under way these days among authors for the epic sports event, suitable for immortalizing in a book. Desperate, because the supply is finite, and it is also dwindling. These rare milestones occurred within a short period of time: after the rise of mass media, which broadened audiences exponentially and gave people a stake in such spectacles, but before 24-hour saturation coverage left little to write about afterward. It helped if malevolent ideologies, like Nazism or Communism, were involved. Or race, particularly when, if belatedly and begrudgingly, baseball diamonds, track-and-field stadiums and boxing rings were among the few places where people of color were actually allowed to win.

title: Boston: Achilles Project

But there it is, just a short stroll from the new Institute of Contemporary Art, housed in a former warehouse. There, clothing is treated as art and shoppers take in the scene against a backdrop of music and kung fu flicks.

Now we know how one of the greatest of all filmmakers  the man who so radically changed cinema in 1959 with his debut feature, Breathless  became an intolerable gasbag. That probably wasnt Brodys aim in writing this exhaustive, and sometimes exhausting, critical biography. As Brody, a film critic and editor at The New Yorker, makes clear in the preface, he still believes in Godards relevance, claiming that the resolutely not-retired filmmaker, who has lived in Rolle, Switzerland, for the past 30 years, continues to work at an extraordinarily high level of artistic achievement.

title: Will Little Havana Go Blue?
description: On the surface, political life in Cuban Miami seems unchanged. Little Havana is still partly a Disney version of a displaced Cuba and partly a genuine community hub, where families who have long since left for suburbia still come for nostalgic weekend lunches. At the Versailles Restaurant, the community newspapers preaching no compromise with Castro are all that are on offer. For almost four decades, the Versailles has been an obligatory stop for Washington politicians courting the Cuban-American community, visits that, as photographs in the restaurant attest, have often involved putting on a white guayabera, the four-pocket dress shirt that often replaces a coat and tie in the Caribbean. This familiar theater of intransigence  a staple of South Florida life at least since the Bay of Pigs invasion in 1961, when C.I.A.-backed Cuban exiles tried to overthrow the new Communist regime  is ubiquitous. Some Cuban-Americans point hopefully to a softening in the Spanish-language, Cuba-focused radio outlets that now dominate the South Florida market. But for an outsider, what is striking is the degree to which the hard-line stance endures, since it might have been supposed that 50 years of failure to influence events on the island might have led to the conclusion that the hard-line position needed to be reconsidered. Most officeholders in Florida and, for that matter, most national politicians continue to at least pay lip service to the dream of a post-Communist Cuba, even though, early this year, Fidel Castro succeeded in seamlessly handing over power to his brother Ral  testimony, if any was needed, to the stability of the regime.

title: In Novels for Girls, Fashion Trumps Romance
description: A WHILE back, Naomi Johnson, a communications professor at Longwood University in Virginia, sent me her doctoral thesis, which she described as a feminist analysis of the new wave of teenage romance novels. I dont read lots of dissertations, and almost tossed this one when the words ontological, objectivist and constructivist appeared in the same sentence, on Page 38. But I kept at it, because one of the series for teenagers that Dr. Johnson analyzed was the best-selling Clique books, which my 14-year-old daughter, Annie, loves and we buy the moment the newest one hits the bookstore.

title: Here Comes the Neighborhood
description: Even by New York City standards, its quite a sight. On a 17,000-square-foot vacant lot just west of the Museum of Modern Art, a mini-suburb of contemporary houses is being built  practically overnight. But thats exactly the point of Home Delivery: Fabricating the Modern Dwelling. The exhibition, which opens July 20, examines factory-produced, or prefab, houses from 1833 to today, through 60 projects shown inside the museum and five full-scale houses outside. These houses address issues of mass production, digital fabrication, sustainability and portability, using a variety of manufacturing techniques and aiming at several points along the price spectrum.

This tale of the decline and fall of the house of Salina, a family of Sicilian aristocrats, first appeared in 1958, but it reads more like the last 19th-century novel, a perfect evocation of a lost world.

title: Paperback Row
description: PEELING THE ONION, by Gnter Grass. Translated by Michael Henry Heim. (Harvest/Harcourt, $15.) This memoir by Grass, who won the Nobel Prize in 1999, takes him from his childhood in Danzig (now Gdansk) to the publication of The Tin Drum in 1959. The autobiography created controversy because it disclosed for the first time that Grass, the teller of truth about Germanys Nazi past, had been drafted into the Waffen SS in 1944, when he was 17. Memory is like an onion, Grass writes, and this book removes several layers: I practiced the art of evasion. Our reviewer, John Irving, found Grasss honesty about his dishonesty to be breathtaking and concluded that the memoir is as good as the very best of Grasss novels.

title: Circling the Square
description: The Chinese character rou, meaning flesh or meat, is a three-sided figure with two sets of diagonal slashes inside, meant to resemble a flayed carcass. Its an instantly memorable, if unpalatable, image, and the same is true of the Chinese title of Ma Jians new novel. Rou Tu (tu means earth or land) translates, awkwardly, as Meat Earth or perhaps Land of Flesh. Its not difficult to see why Mas English-language publishers chose Beijing Coma instead. But once youve heard it, its as difficult to forget Rou Tu as it is to shake the image of one of the narrators comrades crushed by a tank on Changan Avenue in Beijing on June 4, 1989: Her face was completely flat. A mess of black hair obscured her elongated mouth.

title: The Long War of Genaro Garca Luna
description: When Genaro Garca Luna, Mexicos top police official, arrived in Tijuana in January, the city was in the middle of a storm of violence that he found, as he put it to me with clipped understatement soon after his visit, surprising. First, three local police officers were murdered in a single night, apparently in retaliation for a bust that a drug-cartel boss warned them not to carry out. A few days later, federal police officers tried to storm a trafficker safe house in a quiet Tijuana neighborhood and ended up in a shootout. Five gunmen held off dozens of police officers and soldiers for more than three hours. By the time the police made it inside the house, six kidnap victims from a rival cartel being held there had been executed. The traffickers had skinned off some of the victims faces to conceal their identities.

title: Pill-Popping Pets
description: Max retrieves Frisbees. He gobbles jelly beans. He chases deer. He is  and this should be remembered when discussions of cases like his blunder into the thickets of cognitive ethology, normative psychology and intraspecies solipsism  a good dog. A 3-year-old German shepherd, all rangy limbs and skittering paws, he patrols the hardwood floors and wall-to-wall carpets of a cul-de-sac home in Lafayette, Calif., living with Michelle Spring, a nurse, and her husband, Allan, a retired airline pilot. Max fields tennis balls with his dexterous forelegs and can stand on his hindquarters to open the front door. He loves car rides and will leap inside any available auto, even ones belonging to strangers. Housebroken, he did slip up once indoors, but everybody knows that the Turducken Incident simply wasnt his fault. Hes agile, Allan says. Hes healthy. Hes a good-looking animal. Michelle adds, We love him to death. That is why they had no choice, she says. The dog simply had to go on psychoactive drugs.

What brings the two sides together is the fabulous foods part of the establishments title.

The machine hisses, Mr. Vines opens it and sizes up his handiwork: a cotton weapon in his quest to revive his long-challenged city.

title: Out of the Kitchen, Into the Field

Nearly a century later, Clays statement rings vibrantly true. There are 80 percent more women who are farmers than there were 20 years ago in the United States, even as the number of farms has decreased, according to the Department of Agriculture. In the Northeast alone, nearly 20,000 farms are run by women, some of whom are shown on the following pages. Whether raising heritage livestock, combing the woods for exotic morsels or coaxing delicacies from the ground, these women forge new bonds between field and table, strengthening the connection between things we love to eat and the stewardship that makes them possible.

title: Neighborhood Storytelling

description: Following are excerpts of a transcript of an interview conducted by The New York Times's Adam Nagourney and Michael Cooper with Senator John McCain in Hudson, Wis., on July 11. The answers are transcribed verbatim; some of the questions are paraphrased. The other people Mr. McCain refers to, who were in the room, are his wife, Cindy; Mark Salter, a senior adviser; Brook Buchanan, his press secretary; and John Taylor, an economic adviser.

title: Bon Jovi in Central Park
description: The New Jersey rockers played to 50,000 fans on the Great Lawn.

title: Forest With a Good Heart
description: A Northport, N.Y., mans Enchanted Forest started with dinosaurs he made for his children.

title: Drama Freaks
description: A look at the 2008 International Thespian Festival at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln.

title: Obama Picks Senators as Iraq Partners
description: SAN DIEGO  When Senator Barack Obama travels to Iraq later this summer to get a firsthand look at conditions there, he said he would be accompanied by two colleagues who have bipartisan wisdom when it comes to foreign policy.

title: In news roundup, Russians invade U.S.; A villa with a view in Thailand; Best places to invest
description: Headlines from the world of property:

title: When Lifes a Mini-Ball
description: Because of an editing error, an article on June 29 about Dwayne Garner, a regular contestant in a weekly vogueing competition in the West Village, misstated the year when, at age 14, he first visited Greenwich Village. It was 2002, not 1992.

title: The Quad Countdown: No. 47 Connecticut
description: Location: Storrs, Conn.

title: The Week Ahead: July 13-19
description: Dance

title: Hallelujah, Im a Bum
description: Sure, times are tough. But being a bum in New York isnt as bad as it used to be, if you believe the data generator at the job search site Indeed.com:

title: They Float Away on Chairs; Some Think Theyre Off Their Rockers
description: From todays Week in Review on cluster ballooning with lawn chairs:

title: Op-Classic, 2004: Saving Fannie Mae
description: Every week, the Opinion section presents an essay from The Times's archive by a columnist or contributor that we hope sheds light on current news or provides a window on the past.

title: Palpitations Over Pills for Kids
description: Cholesterol-lowering statin drugs, the most prescribed pills in the world, have become a family affair.

title: CNN Previews Black in America
description: CNN is almost ready to unwrap its four-hour documentary series Black in America.

title: The Morning Skate: Vinnys Loot, Radulovs Thoughts and Sundins Fire
description: We mentioned on Friday (although, thanks to the Radulov biz, it now seems like three weeks ago) that Lightning VP Brian Lawton said Vinny Lecavaliers new deal was not as advertised in media reports. Those reports had him signing a a nine-year, $77 million extension.

title: The Early Word: Being John McCain
description: In a 45-minute interview with The New York Times, Senator John McCain declared himself a conservative Republican, though, as he put it, in the Theodore Roosevelt mold. The conversation between Mr. McCain, the presumptive Republican nominee and The Timess Adam Nagourney and Michael Cooper, covered a range of topics, including his religious views, what its like to run against Senator Barack Obama and how he manages internal strife within his campaign team.

title: Swedish Models
description: Europe | A British columnist says Sweden has succeeded where Britain has failed, in adopting social democratic ideas of British thinkers like Leonard Hobhouse and John Maynard Keynes. Curious strange, then, that a cherished conservative idea like private school choice should be flourishing in Sweden too (partly thanks to the D.I.Y. ethos of Ikea).  Guardian, Economist

title: PBS To Show Ken Burns National Parks Series Next Year
description: The Associated Press reports: Documentary filmmaker Ken Burns new series celebrating Americas national parks and detailing their history will air in fall 2009, PBS said Saturday.

title: Well Get Those Horrible Rumor Mongers Yet
description: As the financial system has more and more weaknesses  I never thought Id see the day when Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were deemed risky borrowers  the search for someone to blame has intensified.

title: HBO Premieres Generation Kill
description: Sunday at 9, HBO premieres Generation Kill, a seven-part mini-series about the invasion of Iraq based on a book by Evan Wright, a Rolling Stone reporter embedded in the elite First Reconnaissance Battalion of the United States Marines as they rode from Kuwait into Baghdad.

title: No Manny In Home Run Derby
description: Manny Ramirez of the Red Sox grew up in Washington Heights, near Yankee Stadium, and surpassed 500 homers this season. So Ramirez would have been a natural fit to participate in the Home Run Derby at the Stadium on Monday. But Ramirez declined the opportunity. Alex Rodriguez of the Yankees, Ramirezs friend and an even better fit for the event, declined weeks ago.

title: Agent Says Cherepanov Wont Join Rangers This Season
description: Rangers fans who think theyll be seeing Alexei Cherepanov in Broadway Blue this coming season will have to think again, it seems.

title: The Obnoxious French
description: Travel | An international survey rates the French the most obnoxious tourists from Europe, behind only Indians and the last-place Chinese as worst in the world. Surprise: even though (as Obama notes) Americans typically cant speak foreign languages, they top the list of tourists credited with at least trying. Time

title: Nomadic Roots
description: At the Nadam festival, where Mongolians celebrate nomadic traditions, recent riots are casting a shadow over the festivities.

title: Nomadic Roots
description: At the Nadam festival, where Mongolians celebrate nomadic traditions, recent riots are casting a shadow over the festivities.

title: Other Stops
description: More campaign-related opinion for Sunday, July 13:

title: The Amazin Mets
description: In a roundabout way, this little run by the Mets pitching staff reminds me of their former manager Willie Randolph. Whenever something a little unique, a little out of the ordinary would happen, Randolph would inevitably respond to a question on the matter by saying that he had seen it before. Usually, he had. But others, he hadnt. So Im only left to wonder what he might have said after Saturdays game, when the Mets did something that no other team  repeat: no other team  has done in the modern baseball era, since 1900, by allowing three or fewer hits in five consecutive games.

title: The Mood Swings of Talk Radio
description: Listening to talk radio while driving up I-95 after watching the Phillies lose to the Diamondbacks yesterday was a reminder of what a long season it can be. Even after losing, the Phillies were a half-game ahead of a Mets team that had just won eight in a row. And it has only been a few months since the Phillies stormed past the Mets in the final week of last season.

title: Anheuser Approves $52 Billion Sale to InBev
description: Update: Anheusers board has approved the companys sale to InBev for $52 billion.

title: Usain Bolt Gets  Gasp!  Faster
description: Usain Bolt, the world-record holder in the 100 meters, turned in the fastest time in the world this year in the 200 during a meet in Athens. Bolt won in 19.67 seconds, powering away from Brendan Christian of Antigua, who was a distant second in 20.36.

title: Schwarzenegger Suggests Hes Open to Post Under Obama
description: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California, who has endorsed Senator John McCain and called his fellow Republican a role model, suggested in an interview broadcast Sunday that he would be willing to serve as an energy and environment czar under Senator Barack Obama should he win the presidency.

title: Obama Reaches Out to Latino Voters
description: SAN DIEGO  Senator Barack Obama proposed a tax credit of up to 50-percent for small business owners who offer health insurance to their employees, borrowing an idea from his former rival in an effort to attract Latino voters to his presidential candidacy.

title: Happy Birthday, Milton
description: LONDON, July 11  I am writing from London where I am attending the Ninth International Milton Symposium which also marks John Miltons quatercentenary. (He was born December 9, 1608, and died in 1674.) In a sense its just a big birthday party for a big birthday, although none of us is likely be honored by a party at which some 200 people from all around the world give papers celebrating our achievements, either during our lifetimes or after we have been dead for centuries.

title: Political Satire, but Obama Isnt Laughing
description: Updated SAN DIEGO - As he flies around the country, Senator Barack Obama has a fondness for magazines. The New Yorker is often among the titles at the front of his campaign plane.

title: Look whos talking
description: So John Reich, the director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, has found a villain in the fall of IndyMac. Not management, which kept making Alt-A and builders loans even as the housing bubble popped, but  Chuck Schumer, for expressing doubt about IndyMacs finances.

title: Presenting Young, in Interviews and on the Job
description: On Friday, I appeared (for a few brief moments) on the Today show to talk about ways to shed years from your rsum when youre over 40 and fear that your age might be an obstacle to getting noticed or hired. The segment was built around the story of Lisa Johnson Mandell, a 49-year-old entertainment reporter who was profiled in The Wall Street Journal when she jump-started her job search by removing old jobs and dates from her rsum, updating her appearance and creating a well-designed video blog.

title: McCain: Im the Underdog
description: Theres nothing like a pep talk by the commander-in-chief to fire up thetroops. Putting that theory into practice, Senator John McCain visited his southwest regional campaign headquarters, in his home state of Arizona, on Sunday afternoon and portrayed his Democratic rival, Senator Barack Obama of Illinois, as the clear favorite in the presidential race.

title: Spending $1 Billion to Restore Fiscal Sanity
description: Gaffes have commanded presidential campaign headlines lately, including Carleton S. Fiorinas remarks on Viagra and health insurance, and the Rev. Jesse Jacksons vulgar criticism of Senator Barack Obama. Peter G. Peterson wants people to focus on what he considers real news: the nation is going broke.

title: Bending the Rules
description: Cheating his way through a round of 18 holes, Bill Pennington learns a few pointers and gets a lesson in honest play.

title: A Yankee Space, for a Day
description: When the United States players found their lockers in the Yankees clubhouse for Sundays Futures Game at Yankee Stadium, many wondered whose locker they were using. The Yankees had blue curtains over Derek Jeters and Mariano Riveras locker so those were off-limits.

title: CBS Schedules Town Hall Meeting With Candidates, But Only McCain Will Commit
description: CBS has agreed to broadcast a town-hall-style meeting with the presidential candidates next month, Kate Zernike reports in Saturdays New York Times.

title: Porting A Comic Superhero To MTV2
description: George Gene Gustines reports:

title: NBCs Female-Friendly Unit Appeals to Wal-Mart
description: Women@NBCU, a new unit that offers advertisers access to female-friendly assets of NBC Universal, has landed its first major client: Wal-Mart.

title: Yankees End Road Trip on Sour Note
description: TORONTO  It was not an opinion widely shared in the clubhouse. Most of the Yankees said they had simply succumbed to a tough pitcher on his game. But for Andy Pettitte, who lost to the Toronto Blue Jays on Sunday, 4-1, the final game of a lackluster trip was cause for concern.

title: At Sun Valley, a Party for Those Who Move the Moguls
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho  As dusk settled on the Pioneer Mountains last Thursday, the party was just beginning: a group of close to 100 people with name tags, mostly men, mingled, drank beer and told stories of their day on the golf course or at other diversions, like fly fishing or skeet shooting.

title: Sarkozy Helps to Bring Syria Out of Isolation
description: PARIS  Leaders of 43 nations with nearly 800 million inhabitants inaugurated a Union for the Mediterranean on Sunday, meant to bring the northern and southern countries that ring the sea closer together through practical projects dealing with the environment, climate, transportation, immigration and policing.

title: Advertising in Europe Softens, and More Goes to the Internet
description: PARIS  Not long ago, European advertising executives seemed confident that they could ride out the storm in the United States economy and the global rise in food and energy costs.

title: Treasury Acts to Shore Up Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
description: WASHINGTON  Alarmed by the sharply eroding confidence in the nations two largest mortgage finance companies, the Bush administration on Sunday asked Congress to approve a sweeping rescue package that would give officials the power to inject billions of federal dollars into the beleaguered companies through investments and loans.

title: A Great Teammate to the End
description: Bobby Murcer created three distinct, intertwined sets of memories.

title: Say, Is That You, Figaro? You Seem a Bit Different
description: KATONAH, N.Y.  In order to be funny, even a good joke has to be told just right. This general principle applies to comic opera as well. And for musical felicities, comic vitality and sheer entertainment, Rossinis Barbiere di Siviglia may be the funniest opera ever written.

title: Tip of the Week: Prepare to Miss Approach Shots
description: Mike LaBauve, one of the nations top golf teachers, sees a lot of amateur golfers miss greens with their approach shots, and he is always surprised when they seem unprepared for those results.

title: Planned Guns N Roses Deal Underscores Power of Video Games to Sell Songs
description: A decade and a half after releasing its previous album, Guns N Roses plans to put out a new song in September  on the video game Rock Band 2. MTV expects to announce on Monday that the sequel to its popular Rock Band game will include Shacklers Revenge, a track from the Guns N Roses album that has been in the works for more than a decade, said people familiar with the deal who spoke on condition of anonymity because the arrangement has yet to be announced.

title: S.E.C. Warns Wall Street: Stop Spreading the False Rumors
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Sunday that it and other regulators would begin examining rumor-spreading intended to manipulate securities prices.

title: To Reach Mothers, Wal-Mart Signs Deal With an NBC Unit
description: Forget about support groups, posses and circles of friends. The first advertising sales deal for a new unit of NBC Universal  signed with Wal-Mart Stores  is all about the momtourage.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Ruth Greenglass, who gave damning testimony in the 1950s atomic espionage trial of her sister-in-law Ethel Rosenberg, misstated her age at the time of her death, in April. She was 83, not 84.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the Army Marksmanship Unit, a squad dedicated to training and employing Olympic-level shooters, referred incorrectly to shooters from the Army on this years United States team for the Beijing Games. At least one woman will participate; the Armys team will not be men only. (Libby Callahan, a member of the Army Reserve but not of the Army Marksmanship Unit, is a member.)

title: Bronislaw Geremek, Who Helped End Communist Control of Poland, Is Dead at 76
description: Bronislaw Geremek, a pivotal figure in the fight to end Communist rule in Poland and one of the leading statesmen of the democratic era that followed, died on Sunday. He was 76.

title: Mother Exhales After Sons Release in Colombia
description: Jo Rosano was sitting with her husband in a hotel room near the Cathedral of Notre Dame in Paris on the evening of July 2 when her five and a half years of despair began to ease.

title: Young Stars Have Seen Players Swindled
description: As players and officials at the Futures Game on Sunday spoke hopefully about the players imminent major league stardom, they also spoke regretfully about the recent news that the F.B.I. was looking into whether major league personnel improperly pocketed money earmarked for Latin American teenagers.

title: Obama Girls Get Their 15 Minutes
description: During the campaign of 2004, The New York Times  scraping the bottom of the barrel over a long Labor Day weekend  sent me to cover John Edwardss vice presidential campaign. Right after I took my seat on the campaign plane somewhere in Ohio, all nervous and out of sorts, 4-year-old Jack Edwards came tearing past the Secret Service and into the back of the plane with a rubber knife, slashing the air and shouting, Im going to kill my daddy.

title: Corrections
description: OBITUARIES

title: Prospects Are Mindful of Olympics Approach
description: There was much more than pride at stake for the United States team in the Futures Game at Yankee Stadium on Sunday. The 24 players were vying for spots on the Olympic team that will compete next month in Beijing, and Sunday was a final opportunity to persuade USA Baseball officials to select them for the roster.

title: Go to R.E.M. Show, See Art in Dresden
description: Those attending an R.E.M. performance in Dresden, Germany, will get free admission to select art museums. The bands 40-date European tour stops there on Tuesday. Tickets for the concert, on the banks of the Elbe River, can also be used to gain entry to any museum in Dresdens state art collections, with the exception of the Historic Green Vault, according to a statement from Dirk Burghardt, managing director of the State Art Collections. Current exhibitions include Georg Baselitz: Printed Works From 1964 to 1983 and Max Liebermann in the Dresden Gallery.

title: In India, Magazines That Translate Well
description: NEW DELHI  Hairstyles to crave and hints on how to get over heartbreak. This months must-have lip gloss and a new nine-iron that will make your golfing buddies jealous.

title: From One of the Worlds Best, a Lesson in the Art of Thievery
description: Two players, Nick Nickell and Mike Passell, will be inducted into the American Contract Bridge Leagues Hall of Fame on Thursday in Las Vegas at the start of the Summer North American Championships.

title: In Japan, Buddhism May Be Dying Out
description: OGA, Japan  The Japanese have long taken an easygoing, buffetlike approach to religion, ringing out the old year at Buddhist temples and welcoming the new year, several hours later, at Shinto shrines. Weddings hew to Shinto rituals or, just as easily, to Christian ones.

title: Worlds Within the World of Balmy Central Park
description: In dance, outdoor settings are tough to negotiate, and Central Park is especially tricky: no choreographer wants a dancer to look like an ant. In the first SummerStage dance event, on Friday evening at Rumsey Playfield, Rennie Harris Puremovement demonstrated the right way to overcome the challenge, and Francesca Harper Project the wrong way.

title: Schwarzenegger Weighs Post Under Obama
description: Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California, who has endorsed Senator John McCain and called his fellow Republican a role model, suggested in an interview broadcast Sunday that he would be willing to serve as an energy and environment czar under Senator Barack Obama should he win the presidency.

title: Red Roof, White Socks and Blue Ribbon Beer?
description: The latest recordings by a couple of popular country music acts will never hit the Billboard charts but, to paraphrase the title of a song from the movie -"Nashville"- it dont worry them.

title: Government as the Big Lender
description: The desperate worry over the health of huge financial institutions with country cousin names  Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac  reflects a reality that has reshaped major spheres of American life: the government has in recent months taken on an increasingly dominant role in assuring that Americans can buy a home or attend college.

title: Ian McKellen Confronts Anglican Church on Gays
description: Ian McKellen accused the Anglican Church of homophobia during an appearance on a BBC television program, the British newspaper The Guardian reported. Mr. McKellen, far right, the actor and a founding member of the Stonewall gay-rights group, made the comments while appearing on The Andrew Marr Show with Gene Robinson (pictured with Mr. McKellen), the gay Episcopal bishop from New Hampshire whose 2003 consecration has caused division within the church. According to The Guardian Mr. McKellen said that religious authorities and some leaders of Britains armed forces and schools shared similar negative attitudes toward gay people: They root around in the Bible for the bits that seem to be relevant. Mr. McKellen and Bishop Robinson will host the British premiere of an American 2007 documentary about homosexuality and religion, For the Bible Tells Me So. The screening will be held in London on Monday, two days before the start of the Lambeth Conference, a meeting of Anglican bishops held every 10 years and hosted by the Archbishop of Canterbury, Rowan Williams.

title: The Prowess of the Painter in a Hunters Paradise
description: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo.  Nearly every car here has Wyoming license plates, but you can tell which are not driven by locals. Like mine, they hurriedly pull to the side of the road or even stop dead center, their drivers gawking as thunderously dumb-looking bison amble alongside. At dusk a moose brings traffic to a standstill by grazing on a shrub.

title: A Playground Where Creativity Can Run Wild
description: It began as a six-foot-long robot named Simon. Then over the course of a few minutes, Kamai Pugh, 7, took Simon apart and transformed the array of blue blocks and foam noodles into a childs vision of a miniature park with swing sets, a weighing scale, a balance beam, a swimming pool and finally, a lime-green airplane.

title: Democrats Look to Lobbyist to Finance Convention
description: In terms of lobbyists, few are more connected  both west of the Mississippi and in the corridors of power in Washington  than Steve Farber, a Denver lawyer whose political contacts have thrust him into a central fund-raising role for the Democratic National Convention.

title: A Scholars Sticky Web Includes His Sister, His Secretive Love and His Pal Nixon
description: Late in Palace Council the books hero, Eddie Wesley, asks a White House staff member about the effect that he, Eddie, has had on President Richard M. Nixon. He is told that his name does not come up in White House conversation. People have other things on their minds, Eddie, the staffer says deflatingly. Not everything is about you.

title: The Character of Optimism
description: The late Tony Snow  how odd it is to write late before Tonys name, and how sad  was an editorial writer and columnist, the host of Fox News Sunday for seven years and of a radio talk show for three, and a speechwriter in the White House of the first president Bush and press secretary for the second. We were twice colleagues (at the first Bush White House and at Fox), and throughout our two decades together in Washington compatriots and friends.

title: Lieberman Finds Middle a Tricky Path
description: WASHINGTON  Joseph I. Lieberman, lapsed Democrat of Connecticut, strolled into the weekly lunch of the Senate Democrats last Tuesday, unaccompanied by a food taster.

title: Pakistan Marble Helps Taliban Stay in Business
description: ZIARAT, Pakistan  The mountain of white marble shines with such brilliance in the sun it looks like snow. For four years, the quarry beneath it lay dormant, its riches captive to tribal squabbles and government ineptitude in this corner of Pakistans tribal areas.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article last Monday about the United States Olympic swimming trials, including the accomplishments of Dara Torres at age 41, misstated the age of a Canadian swimmer from the 1972 Games. Brenda Holmes was 14, not 44, when she competed for Canada.

title: In Bid for Yahoo, Microsoft Turns More Aggressive
description: Shareholders searching for dtente in the battle between Yahoo and Microsoft are unlikely to find it in Microsofts new proposal to buy Yahoos search business, one the Internet company swiftly rejected on Saturday.

title: Anheuser-Busch Agrees to Be Sold to InBev
description: Anheuser-Busch agreed on Sunday night to sell itself to the Belgian brewer InBev for about $52 billion, people briefed on the matter said, putting control of the nations largest beer maker and a fixture of American culture into a European rivals hands.

title: My Plan for Iraq
description: CHICAGO  The call by Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki for a timetable for the removal of American troops from Iraq presents an enormous opportunity. We should seize this moment to begin the phased redeployment of combat troops that I have long advocated, and that is needed for long-term success in Iraq and the security interests of the United States.

title: Lincolns Legacy Brought Forth in Dance
description: DURHAM, N.C.  How do you make a dance about Abraham Lincoln without falling into clich, bombast or sentimentality? How do you do this when you are a 56-year-old black American artist, the son of migrant farm workers, who has grown into a polarizing postmodern heavyweight, with all the baggage and history that entails? How do you begin to approach a work that at its heart is about America itself?

title: Man Arrested After Attack in Istanbul Is Charged
description: ISTANBUL  One of the suspects detained in connection with the armed attack on the United States Consulate in Istanbul last week was formally charged with membership in an illegal organization, the semiofficial Anatolian News Agency reported on Sunday.

title: Castillo Set to Return, but to a Crowded Spot
description: With a team that has spent much of the season plugging holes in the roster, Mets Manager Jerry Manuel could be in a rare situation next week, at least when it comes to second base. All of a sudden, it seems as if he is going to have options to choose from.

title: Violence Comes Uncomfortably Close to a Gay Shelter
description: For the people who live at a residence for gay and transgender youth in Astoria, Queens, the cramped four-room apartment they share is a congenial harbor, a place where they do not have to worry about the prejudices and dangers they often face on the streets.

title: A Mystery Graffiti Artist Is Given a Name
description: The Mail on Sunday, the British newspaper, says that it has discovered the identity of Banksy, the mysterious graffiti artist, the BBC reported. A 34-year-old named Robin Gunningham has been identified as Banksy, based on a photograph taken in 2004 showing a man next to a spray can in Jamaica. The newspaper said that it had found former acquaintances who identified the man in the picture as Mr. Gunningham. The photograph first appeared online and then in The Evening Standard in 2004. A New Yorker article in 2007 also investigated the legitimacy of the image, which was taken by a Peter Dean Rickards, a Jamaican photographer. An antigraffiti officer in Bristol, England, where Banksy is speculated to be from, said he believed the photograph to be authentic as well. But a spokeswoman for Banksy refused to comment on the report. Ill say what I always say, she told the BBC. I never confirm or deny these stories.

title: About Those Town-Hall Meetings...
description: HUDSON, Wis.  At nearly every town-hall meeting that John McCain conducts with voters these days, he stops to point out someone missing from the room: Barack Obama.

title: Reunion Leads to the Rediscovery of Leonards Form
description: SOUTHPORT, England  Justin Leonards face was turned toward the sun Sunday, a freshening wind off the Irish Sea blowing across his left shoulder. He was smiling, squinting straight down the fairway and talking out loud to himself.

title: Rule of the Week: Observing a Moved Marker
description: Dave, Kevin and Jack arrive at the par-3 finishing hole, tied for the lead in the club championship. Daves tee shot falls to rest out of bounds. Re-teeing, he hits a second ball on the green. Kevins tee shot lands in a bunker. Jacks shot rolls onto the green, 20 feet past the hole.

title: Bush Lifts Drilling Moratorium, Prodding Congress
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush lifted a presidential moratorium on drilling for oil and natural gas on the Outer Continental Shelf on Monday, hoping to prod Congress to act to clear the way for exploration along the countrys coastline in response to soaring energy prices.

title: Where Credit Is Due
description: To the Editor:

title: Fannie, Freddie and You
description: And now weve reached the next stage of our seemingly never-ending financial crisis. This time Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are in the headlines, with dire warnings of imminent collapse. How worried should we be?

title: Troops in Afghanistan Need Help, Obama Says
description: SAN DIEGO  Senator Barack Obama is proposing that the United States deploy about 10,000 more troops to battle resurgent forces in Afghanistan, a plan intended to shift the American military focus from the Iraq war to the marked rise in violence from the Taliban.

title: Chihuahuas in Headdresses? I Cringe, You Cringe
description: The so-called reaction video  in which people record themselves watching something with the goal of capturing a visceral reaction  has turned into a YouTube staple. The genre took off last year with people reacting to a gross-out pornography clip. More recently, people have taped themselves reacting to something called the pain Olympics (it involves self-mutilation; perhaps best not to ask).

title: Cozy Bistro Where Traditional Trumps Nouvelle
description: Oui, there will be tricolor bunting. Balloons? Certainement. And when La Marseillaise is played, diners will be asked to stand. But here is the surprise about Monday evenings celebration of Bastille Day at Chez Napolon, the diminutive, cozy, venerable Manhattan bastion of La Belle France at 365 West 50th Street: The bistro will be open.

title: Citys Gas Squad Keeps the Pumps Honest
description: With gas prices hitting record highs almost daily, the thought of a station giving out even a drop of free fuel might seem absurd. But the Mobil station on the corner of East Houston Street and Avenue C was doing just that on Friday morning.

title: Favorite Takes a Tumble as Biggest Climbs Await
description: BAGNRES-DE-BIGORRE, France  The first two steep climbs in the Pyrenees essentially ended in a draw Sunday while Cadel Evans, a race favorite, had a fearsome fall that apparently did not seriously injure him but did crack his helmet and shred parts of his uniform.

title: Sudanese Protest War Crimes Case Against President at Scripted Rally in Capital
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Thousands of people took to the streets of Sudans tense capital on Sunday in a carefully choreographed protest against the expected request by the International Criminal Court to arrest President Omar Hassan al-Bashir on war crimes charges.

title: Maria Shriver Hosts Womens Conference
description: A conference on womens issues may be a staple production of first lady offices around the nation, but few pack the celebrity punch of the annual event of Maria Shriver, left, in Long Beach, Calif. Last years Womens Conference featured the wives of presidential candidates, and this year the speaker list will be a Hollywood mix: actors, policymakers, multimillionaires and models. Attendees, according to Ms. Shrivers office, will include Sally Field, Michael J. Fox, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, Warren Buffett, Caroline Kennedy, Heidi Klum, Jennifer Lopez, Mehmet Oz and Gloria Steinem, among others. This is the fifth conference held by Ms. Shriver, the wife of Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday, about a spacewalk to remove a live explosive bolt from the Soyuz space capsules re-entry apparatus, described incorrectly the system that malfunctioned when the last two Soyuz capsules returned to Earth. There are 10  not five  explosive bolts (two in each of the five latch assemblies that secure a propulsion module to the descent capsule). The malfunction, which led to ballistic descents subjecting those inside to higher than normal G forces, appears to have occurred in the fifth of the five latch assemblies, not in the fifth of five explosive bolts.

description: To the Editor:

description: Accounts

title: Spending $1 Billion to Restore Fiscal Sanity
description: Gaffes have commanded presidential campaign headlines lately, including Carleton S. Fiorinas remarks on Viagra and health insurance, and the Rev. Jesse Jacksons vulgar criticism of Senator Barack Obama. Peter G. Peterson wants people to focus on what he considers real news: the nation is going broke.

title: Q & A with Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: Rivera Is Eager to Preserve Another Stadium Memory
description: Sometime on Sunday night, Mariano Rivera said, he would peek ahead to the near future and focus on the All-Star Game. Maybe Rivera, the Yankees closer, would do it when the team flew to New York from Toronto. Or maybe Rivera would ponder his role in the game once he rested his head on a pillow.

title: Back-to-School Shopping Ads Take Cues From Hollywood
description: The saying that you cannot tell the players without a scorecard is being refreshed for the back-to-school shopping season: you may need a copy of Variety or The Hollywood Reporter to distinguish between ad campaigns for two giant retailers.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on Wednesday about Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign debt referred incorrectly to the significance of that debt when compared with other presidential candidates who had financial problems. At least two other losing presidential candidates, Mitt Romney, in 2008, and Steve Forbes, in 1996, had more total debt, including what they loaned their campaigns. Mrs. Clinton did not amass more personal and campaign debt than any other candidate en route to losing the nomination.

title: Do You, Bette, Take Boo for a Life of Misery That Well Laugh At?
description: Little blessings! titters one of the female characters in satisfaction in The Marriage of Bette and Boo, Christopher Durangs carousel of horrors masquerading as a bubbly comedy. Little blessings? You would need a superpowered microscope to detect the glimmers of benevolence, charity or happiness glinting amid the misery in this breezy cavalcade of scenes from a dreadful marriage, first produced in 1985. It should be noted that the affable woman who makes that exclamation about lifes sweet gifts has just gone deaf, and this affliction is among the cheerier events in the play.

The photographs of famous British personalities from the 20th century are by Bern Schwartz, an American businessman who had a second career as a photographer and died in 1978. Now through January, 30 of them are on view in Bern Schwartz: Portraits of the 1970s.

title: Governors Island Invites Entertainment Proposals
description: The Governors Island Preservation and Education Corporation on Monday will invite proposals for an entertainment and dining operation and for art studios and exhibition space on the island, just off the tip of Manhattan. The entertainment and dining element is to be in a temporary structure like a large tent, the corporation said, in a parking lot near the Governors Island ferry landing. The performance space is expected to seat 500 to 800. The artists studio and exhibition program will be placed in Building 110, an 1870 structure near the ferry landing. The program will not allow any residential use. The proposals would cover five years, starting in 2009, though renewals are possible. Leslie Koch, president of the corporation, said these submissions, called requests for proposals, reflect a focus on the arts, the role the island can play in the culture of New York City.

A police spokesman said he believed the victims deaths were caused by carbon monoxide fumes on or near a bus. Agence France-Press reported that six others were hospitalized. title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An obituary on Thursday about John Y. Simon, editor of the papers of Ulysses S. Grant, misstated the publication schedule for Volumes 29 and 30 of the papers. They are to be released this year, not in 2009. The obituary also referred incorrectly to the Grant papers as a model for other presidential papers. The Princeton University Press published the first volume of the Woodrow Wilson papers in 1966 and the first volume of the Thomas Jefferson papers in 1950, so the Grant papers, with the first volume in 1967, were not an influence on those volumes. And the obituary misstated the length of Mr. Simons tenure at Southern Illinois University. He taught for 44 years, not 34. (As the obituary noted, he began teaching there in 1964.)

Watching The Merry Wives of Windsor (in the afternoon) and King Lear (at night), I felt a bit the way I did when I was five or six, and my grandfather, an English professor, would read Charles and Mary Lambs Tales from Shakespeare to me.
