title: Republicans Pick a Party Rebel to Run for Fossellas Seat
description: In a dramatic reversal of fortunes, former Assemblyman Robert A. Straniere was endorsed for Congress last night by the Staten Island Republican Party. That backing comes just four years after Mr. Straniere, then a 24-year incumbent, was defeated in a tense Republican primary and shunned by many of the islands officials.

title: Man on a Mission: Intervention With Attitude
description: First consider the title  The Cleaner  in all its banner can-do-ism. What does it remind you of? Phonically The Cleaner, which begins on Tuesday on A&E, is like The Closer, sure, but more broadly it borrows from many masters of basic cable.

title: 64 All-Stars and 1 Baseball Monument
description: The stage will be a part of Tuesday nights All-Star Game, a big part, in fact. There will be 64 All-Stars assembled at Yankee Stadium, but the building itself will be studied as intently as any of the players.

title: Lifes Second Act (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: New Vision for Schools Proposes Broad Role
description: Randi Weingarten, the New Yorker who is rising to become president of the American Federation of Teachers, says she wants to replace President Bushs focus on standardized testing with a vision of public schools as community centers that help poor students succeed by offering not only solid classroom lessons but also medical and other services.

title: When Midsummer Had Two Classics
description: From 1959 to 1962, something very strange happened in baseball.

title: Minneapolis Troupe Comes to Town, With Four New York Premieres in Tow
description: Zenon Dance Company of Minneapolis is celebrating 25 years of activity. During those years it has toured from Russia to Micronesia, from California to Maine; and it has worked with more than 60 choreographers, several of whom (Bill T. Jones, Tere OConnor, Doug Varone) are very well-known in modern dance. Its visit to Dance Theater Workshop over the weekend, as part of the SummerDANZ season, was by no means its first to New York.

title: North Koreas Stacked Deck
description: Vienna, Va.

title: Hazards: ID Tags Interfering With Medical Care
description: Radio frequency identification tags, the tiny devices that let people drive through tolls without stopping and make life harder for shoplifters, are increasingly being used by hospitals  to monitor the quality of blood products, for example.

title: Les Crane, Talk-Show Host, Dies at 74
description: Les Crane, a provocative talk-show host who was the first to challenge the primacy of Johnny Carson on late-night television  and lose  died Sunday in Greenbrae, Calif., north of San Francisco. He was 74 and lived in Belvedere, Calif.

title: His Service Ended, but the Battles Raged On
description: He tells me he wishes he were younger so he could fight in Iraq. I enjoy killing, he says.

title: N.B.A. Says Second Referee Is Not Involved
description: The N.B.A. has dismissed a published report that loosely implied that a second referee might have been involved in a gambling scheme.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on Sunday about some left-wing voters dissatisfaction with Senator Barack Obama misstated the political affiliation of Ralph Nader, who is also seeking the presidency. Mr. Nader is running as an independent; he is not the candidate of the Green Party, which nominated Cynthia McKinney on Saturday.

title: Drillings Lure
description: President Bushs decision on Monday to lift the moratorium on offshore oil drilling first imposed by his father 18 years ago is designed to ratchet up the pressure on Congress to do likewise. Congress should resist. Offshore drilling will not bring short-term relief from $4-a-gallon gasoline, nor can it play much more than a marginal role in any long-term strategy for energy independence. The oil companies already have access to substantial unexplored resources.

title: In France, Syrian Stirs Tensions
description: PARIS  President Bashar al-Assad of Syria was a guest of honor at Frances annual Bastille Day parade here on Monday, a day after he attended the inaugural meeting of a new Mediterranean-oriented association in a sign that his diplomatic isolation is ending but one that angered many because of Syrias links to Iran and militant groups.

title: Do You Want Sweat With That?
description: AT the All-Star Game tonight at Yankee Stadium, fans will, as they tend to do at baseball games, eat hot dogs. These hot dogs will probably arrive encased in foil. They will be sanitary. They will meet every possible health standard. And they will bear little resemblance to the hot dogs I sold long ago at another legendary New York ballpark, Ebbets Field.

title: Take Two Prozac and E-Mail Me in the Morning
description: Ah, the promise of e-mail! The minute I started giving out my address to my patients, I fantasized about how much time I would save on routine phone calls and how clear and unambiguous the communication would be.

title: Mandela Life Story in Graphic Comic Book
description: He has already been serenaded by Amy Winehouse at a concert in London; now Nelson Mandela can add another perk to his 90th-birthday celebration, which officially takes place on Friday. W. W. Norton & Company has announced that it has acquired North American publishing rights to Nelson Mandela: The Authorized Comic Book. The graphic biography of Mr. Mandela, the former South African leader, was created by the Nelson Mandela Foundation in Johannesburg with Verne Harris, head of the foundations Center of Memory and Dialogue. Norton previously collaborated with the Nelson Mandela Childrens Foundation in 2000 on Nelson Mandelas Favorite African Folk Tales, which won an N.A.A.C.P. award. The new book uses interviews and archival material and chronicles Mr. Mandelas life story. The book features illustrations by several young black artists. Norton plans to publish the work in July 2009.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An answer in the Q&A column on the Circuits pages on Thursday about plans by Microsoft to stop issuing security updates for consumer versions of its Windows XP operating system misstated the date of the change. Microsoft will stop the updates on April 8, 2014  not on April 14, 2009.

title: Court Clears eBay in Suit Over Sale of Counterfeit Goods
description: EBay scored an important victory in an American court on Monday on how much vetting it is required to do of its auction listings, but the decision was in contrast to recent European court rulings.

title: Europe Moves to Cut Charges for Text Messages
description: BERLIN  The European Commission, in a new move to gain favor with consumers by lowering the cost of cellphone service, plans on Tuesday to propose caps on the charges for sending text messages across European borders.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with an article about General Electrics quarterly earnings may have left the incorrect impression that G.E. was selling appliances in Iran. While the picture, from The Associated Press, showed the companys products in a Tehran appliance store, General Electric said that the sales were unauthorized and that the company had stopped supplying the distributor who provided the appliances to the Tehran store.

title: Spanish Bank Pays $2.6 Billion for British Lender
description: LONDON  In a sign that the tight credit market might lead to consolidation in Britains banking industry, Banco Santander of Spain on Monday agreed to buy the mortgage lender Alliance & Leicester for 1.26 billion, or $2.6 billion.

title: The Vampires Are Coming, but Only After Months of Warnings
description: HBOs new vampire series from Alan Ball, the Oscar-winning writer behind American Beauty and the hit series Six Feet Under, will not start until September. But for a select group of horror film enthusiasts, the story has been under way for weeks.

title: Children and Cholesterol (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: South Korea Recalls Envoy to Japan
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea announced Monday that it was recalling its ambassador to Tokyo to protest Japans renewed claim to a string of islets that have been the focus of a protracted territorial dispute.

title: Appointments With Red Ink
description: Vikram S. Pandit summoned 60 executives to Armonk, N.Y., last Tuesday to present his plan to buck up Citigroup, the beleaguered bank he runs.

title: Israel: Setback for Governing Coalition
description: The governing coalition of Prime Minister Ehud Olmert came under further strain when the Labor Party, a main coalition partner, joined a no-confidence motion in Parliament. Dissolution of the government would require 61 votes in the 120-seat legislature; the motion was defeated by 47 to 42. Labor recently threatened to vote no confidence in the government over Mr. Olmerts refusal to step aside pending the outcome of a corruption investigation. That crisis was averted when Mr. Olmert agreed to hold a leadership election in his Kadima Party by late September, paving the way for his eventual replacement. Labor voted no confidence on Monday over a minor matter involving several ministerial appointments.

title: The Luxurious Growth
description: We all know the story of Dr. Frankenstein, the scientist so caught up in his own research that he arrogantly tried to create new life and a new man. Today, if you look at people who study how genetics shape human behavior, you find a collection of anti-Frankensteins. As the research moves along, the scientists grow more modest about what we are close to knowing and achieving.

title: Humbling or Heartwarming, Its No Wedding Cake Walk
description: As if walking down the aisle werent stress enough, a new reality series offers another way to up your wedding ante: have professional choreographers create a custom dance number for you to perform for your guests. Rock the Reception, which will be shown on TLC starting Tuesday night, each week will follow two engaged couples from initial meeting with choreographers through practice sessions and the final postnuptial performance.

title: Not Just Any Water Will Do for Mosquitoes
description: One thing that makes Aedes aegypti, the mosquito that spreads the dengue fever virus, such a huge problem for human health is its egg-laying habits.

title: European Official Calls for Unity Ahead of Trade Talks
description: BRUSSELS  One week ahead of crucial talks on global trade, the European Union negotiator, Peter Mandelson, rejected on Monday sharp criticisms from the French president, Nicolas Sarkozy, and called for unity in advance of the discussions.

title: Group Calls for Inquiry Into Death of Detainee
description: MIAMI  Just days before the funeral on Saturday of her oldest child, Jacqueline Fleury was still $2,000 short of his burial expenses.

title: Despite F.A.A.s Flight Limits, Airport Delays Worsen
description: WASHINGTON  New air traffic tactics unveiled this year by the Federal Aviation Administration intended to make the airports in New York run more smoothly have proved helpful, but only at times: Over all, delays at Newark Liberty and La Guardia are worse.

title: Detainees Lawyers Make Claim on Sleep Deprivation
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba  A week before what could be the first American war crimes trial since World War II, defense lawyers claimed on Monday that an accused detainee might have been subjected to a program of systematic sleep deprivation that they said would constitute torture.

title: Adopting an Open-Door Policy With His Constituents, but Passing on the Doors
description: From a distance, the scene was an election-year stereotype: a local politician talking to constituents on a street corner. But as Assemblyman Hakeem Jeffries greeted commuters outside a subway station in Brooklyn on a recent weekday evening, Anthony Gordon sensed something different.

title: In Quest for Less Stress, Its Auto Over Airplane
description: TUCSON

title: If We Want Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Shell Canada Pays $5.9 Billion for Gas Company
description: OTTAWA  Duvernay Oil, a natural gas company based in Alberta, agreed on Monday to be acquired by a larger rival, Shell Canada, for $5.9 billion.

title: Corrections
description: National

title: A New Frontier for Title IX: Science
description: Until recently, the impact of Title IX, the law forbidding sexual discrimination in education, has been limited mostly to sports. But now, under pressure from Congress, some federal agencies have quietly picked a new target: science.

title: Anheuser-Busch Agrees to Be Sold to InBev
description: Anheuser-Busch agreed on Sunday night to sell itself to the Belgian brewer InBev for about $52 billion, putting control of the nations largest beer maker and a fixture of American culture into a European rivals hands.

title: The British Open Favorite? There Really Isnt One
description: SOUTHPORT, England  Because Tiger Woods is absent from one of golfs four majors for the first time since the 1996 P.G.A. Championship, speculation abounds about the impact his absence will have on the 137th British Open that starts Thursday at Royal Birkdale Golf Club.

title: Whoopi to Join Xanadu
description: She wont be wearing roller skates, but Whoopi Goldberg, below, has signed on for the role of Calliope in the Broadway musical Xanadu, the shows producers announced on Monday. Ms. Goldberg, the actress and comedian who won a Tony Award as a producer of Thoroughly Modern Millie, will join the cast for a six-week run beginning on July 29. Ms. Goldberg also appears on the ABC daytime talk show The View, which will be on hiatus during most of her Xanadu run.

title: Fourth Guilty Plea Arranged in Escort Ring Tied to Spitzer
description: A holistic health counselor who worked as a part-time booker for the prostitution ring that ensnared former Gov. Eliot Spitzer has verbally accepted a plea agreement and is expected to plead guilty next month to lighter charges than those faced by her fellow defendants, her lawyer said Monday.

title: Liking Ike Even More
description: To the Editor:

title: One More Battle for a Vintage Warship
description: LZARO CRDENAS, Mexico  In its glory days, the United States Navy destroyer John Rodgers was among the most decorated warships of World War II. Now, hull rusting and big guns whitened by bird droppings, the abandoned destroyer finds itself in what could be its final battle, one that could turn the historic ship into a museum or, alternatively, a heap of scrap.

title: Despite Scrapes and Bruises, Evans Wears Yellow
description: ARGELS-GAZOST, France  When Cadel Evans crashed halfway through Sundays first stage in the Pyrenees, cracking his helmet and ripping open his jersey, shorts and skin in several places, he thought his Tour de France was over.

title: More Cuts Expected at General Motors
description: DETROIT  General Motors is expected to reveal a wide-ranging plan on Tuesday to address its deteriorating sales and liquidity by cutting more jobs and taking other steps aimed at reviving its turnaround effort.

title: For Students in Kenya, Medicine Seems to Improve Attention Span
description: Malaria medicine as Ritalin?

title: The Future of Fannie and Freddie
description: Distasteful as it may seem in the moment to taxpayers, who will be on the hook if losses result, Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson is taking the right approach to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the faltering mortgage giants. The question is: Will it be enough?

title: Decision Is Near in Sensational London Trial of Privacy Suit by a Consenting Adult
description: LONDON  After a week of testimony, a sensational trial that has centered on the sadomasochistic activities of Max Mosley, the overseer of grand prix motor racing, went to the judge on Monday without the testimony of the woman who ignited the affair by concealing a video camera in her brassiere.

title: Dubai Sheik Buys Boeing Jets for New Airline
description: Leave it to the sheik to steal the show.

title: Leaving Iraq, the Obama Way
description: To the Editor:

title: For Queens Community, Sale of Anheuser-Busch Is Hard to Take
description: John Dooley sidled up to the bar at his favorite neighborhood pub on Monday afternoon and, like a cuckolded lover, vowed to remain true to his beloved despite the sudden betrayal he felt.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: A listing on Friday about a movie series that is paying tribute to the Japanese actor Tatsuya Nakadai, at Film Forum in the South Village misstated the admission price. It is $11, not $10.50.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Music

title: Thunder and Lightning on the Keys, With Some Intermittent Sunshine
description: By any measure, the International Keyboard Institute & Festival is the grandest offering in the procession of hybrid seminars and concert series that make up the summer schedule at Mannes College the New School for Music. It runs two weeks, more then twice the length of the other institutes. Its daily schedule is packed with master classes (four most days) and concerts (two every evening), as well as a competition.

title: Exams for Octogenarians (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Department Is Criticized on Disputes Over Wages
description: The Government Accountability Office sharply criticizes the Wage and Hour Division of the Labor Department in two reports to be issued on Tuesday, saying it mishandled many overtime and minimum-wage complaints and delayed investigating hundreds of cases for a year or more.

title: Poll Shows Racial Division on Obamas Candidacy
description: Americans are sharply divided by race heading into the first election in which an African-American will be a major-party presidential nominee, with blacks and whites holding vastly different views of Senator Barack Obama, the state of race relations and how black Americans are treated by society, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Rules for Filming on the Streets of New York
description: New rules about when filmmakers and photographers must obtain permits when they shoot on New York City streets have been made official, The Associated Press reported. Under the new rules, productions must have permits and at least $1 million in insurance if they plan to leave less than eight feet of open space on a sidewalk or take over a lane of traffic. The announcement was made on Monday by Katherine Oliver, commissioner of the Mayors Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting, and the rules take effect on Aug. 13. Permits and insurance are required for shoots that involve vehicles or equipment other than hand-held devices or cameras on tripods. The rules are in response to a lawsuit by Rakesh Sharma, an Indian documentary filmmaker who was detained by police in 2005 after using a hand-held video camera in Midtown. They wont apply to casual photographers.

title: Taking a Cue From Ants on Evolution of Humans
description: To reach Edward O. Wilsons office on the Harvard campus, one must first push through a door with a sign warning the public not to enter. Then, enter a creaky old elevator and press two buttons simultaneously. This counterintuitive procedure transports one into a strange realm.

title: Similar Styles, Yet Worlds Apart in the Standings
description: Ichiro Suzuki and Kosuke Fukudome share a heritage, a position, a quirky left-handed hitting style and can even trade notes on a feisty manager. And on Tuesday, they will add another thing in common when they start in the All-Star Game.

title: F.A.A. Installing Stoplights to Cut Runway Collisions
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Aviation Administration will install stoplights on runways at 20 airports over the next three years, in a major push to cut the risk of runway collisions, the agency announced Monday. In addition, the F.A.A. will test instruments that tell pilots every time they arrive at a taxiway or runway.

title: A Traveler Armed With Snacks Makes Friends Easily
description: AS the owner of a restaurant, I have a goal to find out what people across the globe like to eat. It inspires me and helps me add to our own menu selections. Most recently, I crossed the Pacific for a fabulous trip to China to soak up the culture and the cuisine.

title: In a Life Without Role Models, an Actor Finds a Lot of Roles
description: Its hard not to love 1970s funk and soul, and Don Reed effectively conjures the music and the era in his autobiographical one-man comedy, East 14th: True Tales of a Reluctant Player, now at New World Stages. Raised in Oakland, Calif., in that decade, Mr. Reed had a polarized upbringing: his mother divorced his father, a pimp, and married a Jehovahs Witness, who took Don on early-morning evangelical tours of the area. At the same time Mr. Reed would often stay, with his brothers, Daryl and Tony, for stretches at his fathers, before moving there.

title: A Pianist Offers Bold Ideas About a Standard by Bach
description: According to Johann Nikolaus Forkel, who wrote the first biography of Bach, that composers Goldberg Variations were commissioned by the Russian diplomat Count Hermann Carl von Keyserlingk. An insomniac, the count reportedly wanted Bach to write a musical sedative that Johann Gottlieb Goldberg (a talented young harpsichordist who lived with Keyserlingk) could play to soothe his restless nights.

title: A New Way to Study How Muscles Work
description: The muscles in the body have big jobs to do, but like most big jobs, theyre broken down into manageable units. In striated muscle  the kind found in biceps, for instance  the basic units are sarcomeres, just a few microns long, which expand and contract by the millions.

title: Watson and Links: Hardly Love at First Sight
description: SOUTHPORT, England  Almost as soon as the wheels of the plane touch down anywhere on the old sod, something comes over Tom Watson. It happens from Carnoustie to Turnberry, Muirfield to Troon, Birkdale and back. Whether the city or village is located in Scotland or England matters not, only that the golf is played on a links course.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Tuesday about a new three-dimensional chat service from Google misidentified the university whose students helped test the service. It is Arizona State University, not the University of Arizona.

title: Abortion Proposal Sets Condition on Aid
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush administration wants to require all recipients of aid under federal health programs to certify that they will not refuse to hire nurses and other providers who object to abortion and even certain types of birth control.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on Saturday about opposition to a plan to name a new research center at the University of Chicago after the economist Milton Friedman misstated the name of a research organization at Stanford University. It is the Hoover Institution, not Hoover Institute.

title: Charles H. Joffe, Movie Producer, Is Dead at 78
description: Charles H. Joffe, a co-producer of Woody Allens movies and the business expert in the talent agency that managed the budding careers of a host of high-profile comedians that also included Robin Williams, Billy Crystal and David Letterman, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 78 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Unsolicited, Waste Giant Seeks to Buy a Competitor
description: Waste Management, the nations largest waste disposal company, offered to buy Republic Services on Monday for $6.2 billion, hoping to stop its smaller rival from merging with another competitor, Allied Waste Industries.

title: Hamilton Delights, but Morneau Prevails in the Derby
description: Josh Hamilton drew some laughter when he said he could be the first player to hit a home run that left Yankee Stadium. During a prodigious display, Hamilton nearly achieved that goal in the Home Run Derby on Monday night.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a CNBC television interview with Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman and controlling shareholder of Viacom and CBS, in which he said that his daughter, Shari, was no longer the companys heir apparent, misidentified the source of the information that a deal had been reached in principle to buy out his daughters interest and have her leave the boards of the two companies. That information was provided by people close to the negotiations who declined to be identified because the talks were continuing. Mr. Redstone did not make those points during his interview with David Faber of CNBC.

title: At the Uneasy Intersection of Bloggers and the Law
description: There is no better way to get a blogger talking than by telling him what he cannot publish  although you might forgive a government prosecutor for thinking otherwise.

title: Efforts on 2 Fronts to Save a Population of Ferrets
description: WALL, S.D.  A colony that contains nearly half of the black-footed ferrets in the country and which biologists say is critical to the long-term health of the species has been struck by plague, which may have killed a third of the 300 animals.

title: Calm Down or Else
description: The children return from school confused, scared and sometimes with bruises on their wrists, arms or face. Many wont talk about what happened, or simply cant, because they are unable to communicate easily, if at all.

title: Packer Is Leaving CBS After 27 Seasons
description: Billy Packers 34th Final Four was his last.

title: Attention, Subway Riders: Pick Up After Yourselves
description: The citys subwaymeisters are making another stab at trying to get New Yorkers not to be such slobs. That isnt quite how New York City Transit officials would phrase it. But that is what they are up to: going after the slobs.

title: Drugs to Build Bones May Weaken Them
description: New questions have emerged about whether long-term use of bone-building drugs for osteoporosis may actually lead to weaker bones in a small number of people who use them.

title: Waiting for Godot, but Not for Long
description: A revival of Samuel Becketts classic play Waiting for Godot will arrive on Broadway in 2009, Playbill.com reported. The production, to be directed by Garry Hynes, will first appear at the Seattle Repertory Theater in January and then move on to New York. The producers of the Broadway revival include Elizabeth I. McCann, Joey Parnes and the Seattle Repertory Theater. The actor Bill Irwin will star in the Seattle Repertory staging.

title: Killings in Newark Drop, but a Sense of Fear Persists
description: NEWARK  After decades in which Newark has been notorious for soaring crime rates and lurid murders, law enforcement and city officials say a sea change is occurring: In roughly the first half of the year, the number of killings dropped by close to 40 percent compared with the same period last year.

title: Big Tour, Little Tour, Everything in Between
description: VIENNA  At the start line, children in team caps and jerseys waved promotional flags as they crowded around the steps to our team bus. They were looking for autographs, a team water bottle, a free team cap, a handshake or a snapshot. They knew our names, had our team cards and had watched us on television through the week as we raced through their countryside. We have been in Austria, racing the Tour of Austria, and the Tour de France has seemed very secondary.

title: Beijing May Be Calling for Another Barcelona Star
description: First it was Lionel Messi. Then Ronaldinho. Now, perhaps, Samuel Etoo.

title: A Star in the Making Takes His Place at the Top of the Order
description: The flashbulbs, Dan Uggla said, will look like lightning bolts sizzling across Yankee Stadium. When Cliff Lee of the Cleveland Indians throws the first pitch of the All-Star Game on Tuesday night, Hanley Ramrez will have arrived.

title: 'Big Brother' Lifts CBS
description: The 10th edition of Big Brother got under way on another low-rated summer Sunday of network television, drawing 6.3 million viewers and helping to lift CBS to No. 1 in the nights ratings, according to Nielsens estimates. The 8 oclock premiere fared just better than the debut of that reality seriess eighth season last summer (5.9 million) but not as well as the February premiere of Big Brother 9 (6.6 million). CBSs 60 Minutes earned the nights largest audience with 8 million viewers at 7. ABC finished second for the night with a lineup of repeats, while NBC was third, trailing far behind early in the night but improving from 9 to 11 with its broadcast of Miss Universe 2008. That international beauty contest averaged 6.6 million viewers from 9 to 11, winning the 10 oclock time slot by a wide margin but falling just short of its audience in 2007, when the pageant was held in May (7.2 million). Fox, with its lineup of animated comedy reruns, ranked fourth for the night but led over all in the demographic of adults 18 to 49.

title: Charged With Genocide
description: The truth can be difficult. That doesnt make it any less true. And so we support the decision by the prosecutor at the International Criminal Court to bring charges of genocide against Sudans president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, for his role in masterminding Darfurs horrors.

title: In Deep-Sea Rock, a Place for CO2
description: As everyone knows, the world has a carbon dioxide problem, and there are many suggestions for dealing with it. One is sequestration, keeping the gas out of the atmosphere through long-term storage.

title: Catching a War Criminal in the Act
description: Servian, France

title: 10 Months After Fossett Vanished, Adventurers Mount New Searches
description: LAS VEGAS  In a sign that last Septembers disappearance of the multimillionaire adventurer Steve Fossett has taken on at least a faint air of Amelia Earhart-like legend, two groups of volunteers are assembling this summer to comb rugged terrain on the Nevada-California border in search of his remains.

title: InBev Looks to Expand Budweisers Reach
description: FRANKFURT  Now that a Belgian brewer has conquered the King of Beers, it wants to take Budweiser global.

title: New York Extends Benefits for Jobless
description: New York State began notifying out-of-work residents on Monday that they may be eligible to collect an additional 13 weeks of unemployment checks. All told, the extended benefits could go to more than 250,000 New Yorkers, the state labor commissioner said on Monday.

title: Sales Expected to Fall 20% in Semiconductor Equipment
description: Semiconductor equipment sales are likely to fall 20 percent this year, according to a midyear forecast by Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International, an industry group, that was released on Monday.

title: Judge Hints at Harsh Sentence in Adoption Fraud Case
description: Judith Leekin adopted 11 children in New York City under four different names, and moved with them a decade ago to Florida. There, she is accused of abusing them  charges she is fighting  but she pleaded guilty in May to a fraudulent adoption scheme that netted her $1.68 million in government subsidies, money that prosecutors say she used to support a lavish lifestyle.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Friday about a government report showing a slower pace of wage increases for hourly workers in New York State over the last few years compared with the rise in the minimum wage misidentified, in one reference, the measure of overall wages that was cited. It was the median  not the average  hourly wage.

title: Want Obama in a Punch Line? First, Find a Joke
description: Whats so funny about Barack Obama? Apparently not very much, at least not yet.

title: Arrest Is Sought of Sudan Leader in Genocide Case
description: PARIS  The prosecutor at the International Criminal Court formally requested an arrest warrant on Monday for Sudans president, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, on charges of genocide, war crimes and crimes against humanity committed during the past five years of bloodshed in the Darfur region of his country.

title: Portugal Holds on to Words Few Can Grasp
description: LISBON  The latest brouhaha involving cultural property is unfolding here  and not, for a change, over stolen vases or precious war booty, but a poets correspondence. As usual, its a window onto a nations character. The elderly heirs of Fernando Pessoa, the exalted Portuguese writer, plan this fall to auction Pessoas correspondence with Aleister Crowley, the early-20th-century British mystic, mountaineer, writer and practitioner of black magic. Portugals culture minister is among those who have shown distress in recent days about the letters leaving the country.

title: Actors in 'W' Film Arrested in Bar Fight
description: Josh Brolin and Jeffrey Wright were arrested early on Saturday morning in Shreveport, La., after a bar fight, The Associated Press reported. The two were arrested along with five crew members of W, a new movie about President Bush, directed by Oliver Stone, which began filming in the city in May. In the film Mr. Brolin plays Mr. Bush, and Mr. Wright plays former Secretary of State Colin L. Powell. The Times of Shreveport reported that Mr. Brolin was booked and posted a $334 cash bond to be released. Police could not immediately say whether he or the others had been released.

title: Where Surgeons Are in Short Supply, One Country Trains a Team of Saviors
description: The Africa chic that has taken hold in the West in recent years is all well and good, but on that continent or any other, there is no substitute for solutions generated from within. Birth of a Surgeon, on Tuesday on PBSs Wide Angle series, tells an admirable story of midwives and other women in Mozambique who are being trained to perform Caesarean sections and other types of surgery to counteract a severe shortage of doctors.

title: Microsoft Wants Games to Appeal to the Masses
description: LOS ANGELES  Ever since Microsoft waded into the video game wars with the introduction of the original Xbox in 2001, the company has spared little expense in attempting to establish its bona fides with hardcore gamers. From the physical appearance of the first Xbox  hulking, extruded black plastic  to the testosterone-laden, shoot- em-up essence of Microsofts signature game franchise, Halo, Microsofts first, perhaps only, priority has been to reach out to the young men at gamings historical roots.

title: Awareness: 2 Questions to Identify Future Smokers
description: Want to know how likely it is that sixth graders will take up smoking? Ask them how easy it would be to get a cigarette.

title: To Set Tone, Exelon Plans Huge Cut in Emissions
description: Exelon, the electric company based in Chicago, will promise on Tuesday to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 2020 by an amount larger than its total emissions in 2008, in a bid to shape the debate on carbon dioxide rules and to get a jump on compliance.

title: Two Leaders to Step Down at Tribune Newspapers

The play, Saturn Returns, will be directed by Nicholas Martin and will star Robert Eli, John McMartin, James Rebhorn and Rosie Benton. It deals with one man, played by three actors, who at pivotal moments in his life faces three women, all played by Ms. Benton. Previews at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater are to begin on Oct. 16; the official opening date is Nov. 10. Following Saturn Returns, the new musical Happiness will open in early spring 2009. It has a book by John Weidman, music by Scott Frankel and lyrics by Michael Korie; Susan Stroman will direct and choreograph.

title: Ken Burns to Document the Nation's Parks
description: A new documentary by the filmmaker Ken Burns, detailing the history of Americas national parks, is scheduled to run in fall 2009 on PBS, The Associated Press reported. The 12-hour, six-part film titled The National Parks: Americas Best Idea will be narrated by Peter Coyote. Tom Hanks and Andy Garcia are among several actors who will lend their voices to the film. It will be produced by Mr. Burns and Dayton Duncan, who wrote a book for the series as well. The film is also produced by Florentine Films and the public television station WETA in Washington. Mr. Burnss previous documentaries include The Civil War and Baseball.

title: Corrections: For The Record

It used a xylophone and a marimba, not two xylophones. The error was pointed out in a letter dated June 9 from Alan Abel, who was a percussionist in the band. The show will open with the Metropolis Ensemble, a local chamber group, performing a new arrangement of Stravinsky titled The Rite: Remixed. The concert will also be broadcast live by NPR.

title: Comic-Con Program

Highlights of the convention, which is in its 39th year, include a first look at the film Watchmen, about flawed superheroes, based on Alan Moores graphic novel mini-series; Universals Wolfman; Up, a new movie by Pixar; Terminator Salvation, the fourth film in the series; and The Spirit, directed by Frank Miller. The program also includes a day devoted to the Star Wars franchise. News about books based on the movies and about a planned TV series will be announced, and there will be panels on cloning and costuming for a galaxy far, far away. The complete schedule is posted on the conventions Web site, comic-con.org.

The priests, the Rev. Zhang Jianlin and the Rev. Zhang Li, are members of an underground church and were held by authorities in Xuanhua in Hebei Province, the foundation said. A police officer reached by telephone in Xuanhua said he had no knowledge of the priests. The foundation said the priests had wanted to join thousands of Catholics in making a pilgrimage in May to a shrine in Sheshan.

title: Cycles of Hay and Dance Survive in Suburbia
description: Heres another video dispatch from my little spot on this pale blue dot. I promised to provide views of four seasons here in the Hudson River Valley (e.g., sticky snow). I pretty much missed spring thanks to endless news, but at least now provide a glimpse of the transition to summer. Its a dance that constitutes one of the rare rituals that still connect people here to the seasons transitions. What rituals and traditions persist on your dot? Down the dirt road from my house, theres a white barn with a loft thats empty only once each year  in mid June. Its now already partly stacked with hay harvested and baled on the hilltop fields nearby, set aside to feed several dozen head of Angus beef cattle through the winter when theyre not freely grazing. That brief moment of June emptiness is filled with music and dancing:

title: The $131.09 Perlstein Paperback
description: I had never gotten around to reading Before the Storm, Rick Perlsteins 2001 book on Barry Goldwater and the rise of the conservative movement. So when Perlsteins follow-up, Nixonland, came out this spring, I decided to read them in sequence. But when I visited Amazon last week I found that Before the Storm was available only through five used booksellers, at prices ranging from $131.09 to $184.02. I could imagine paying that kind of money for an autographed Augie March or a first-edition Faulkner, but a Perlstein paperback? How did the booksellers arrive at these figures, which seemed prohibitively high and oddly precise (would it have been $131.10 had one fewer page been dog-eared by the original owner)? And why wouldnt at least one seller have tried to undercut the others? I e-mailed the store proprietors to find out.

After reading Sway and having a series of conversations with its authors, I am suddenly questioning things. Am I right to believe a certain colleague is a star, or am I merely attributing characteristics to him based on his reputation? Am I sticking with a project long after I know its doomed for fear of accepting a loss? Have I been blind to a persons talent because I am held sway by a first impression and interpret all facts in a way that supports that mistaken impression?

One person involved in the case on the Tiffany side told me at the time that 95 percent of everything on eBay that was supposedly made by Tiffany was, in fact, fraudulent.) I hope they dont party too hard at eBay not only because Tiffany is sure to appeal but also because it has lost three similar cases in Europe, brought by Rolex, Hermes and Louis Vuitton. No, the real problem here stems from eBays attitude toward its customers: namely, the site had no real responsibility toward rectifying wrongs  of any sort  that occur during an eBay transaction.

title: Let's Get Rid of Darwinism
description: (The third part in a series celebrating Charles Darwin.)   Charles Darwin was a giant. He did not merely write "On the Origin of Species"  one of the most important books ever written by anyone  in which he describes how evolution by natural selection works, and what some of its consequences and implications are. He also wrote  and this list is not exhaustive a treatise on the formation of coral reefs that is still thought to be correct; a definitive monograph on barnacles, both extinct and extant; a book about how earthworms make soil; a now-classic text on carnivorous plants (the ones, like Venus fly-traps, that ensnare and digest insects); a book about the strange ways that orchids get themselves fertilized; and an account of the five years he spent aboard the ship HMS Beagle, which has become a classic of travel writing.   As if that wasn't enough, he proposed sexual selection  the idea that decorations and ornaments, like peacocks' tails, evolve because females in many species prefer to mate with the most beautiful males. Sexual selection has since become a major field of research in its own right.   In short, Darwin did more in one lifetime than most of us could hope to accomplish in two. But his giantism has had an odd and problematic consequence. It's a tendency for everyone to refer back to him. "Why Darwin was wrong about X"; "Was Darwin wrong about Y?"; "What Darwin didn't know about Z"  these are common headlines in newspapers and magazines, in both the biological and the general literature. Then there are the words: Darwinism (sometimes used with the prefix "neo"), Darwinist (ditto), Darwinian.  Why is this a problem? Because it's all grossly misleading. It suggests that Darwin was the beginning and the end, the alpha and omega, of evolutionary biology, and that the subject hasn't changed much in the 149 years since the publication of the "Origin."   He wasn't, and it has. Although several of his ideas  natural and sexual selection among them  remain cornerstones of modern evolutionary biology, the field as a whole has been transformed. If we were to go back in a time machine and fetch him to the present day, he'd find much of evolutionary biology unintelligible  at least until he'd had time to study genetics, statistics and computer science.   Oh, there would be so much to tell him! A full list would take me weeks to write out. But the obvious place to begin would be the discoveries of genetics, especially DNA. We'd have to explain that cells in each organism contain a code describing how to build that organism, written in chemical form  DNA  that evolutionary forces are constantly rewriting. Indeed, the study of DNA allows us to see the action of natural selection on a molecule-by-molecule basis. We can see the genes where natural selection acts to prevent evolutionary change, those where it drives change and those where it has no effect at all.  Then there's the fusion of genetics with natural selection, which has enormously expanded our understanding of how natural selection can work. For example, it has led to the discovery that natural selection does not just shape individuals  the length of a beak, the color of a fin. It can also act on family groups, and thus drive the evolution of cooperation and other altruistic behaviors.   The reason is that evolutionary success can now be measured in terms of the number of genes an individual contributes to the next generation. Anyone who dies without reproducing does not directly contribute any. But because individuals have some genes in common with their family members, they can make an indirect genetic contribution if they help their relations to reproduce instead of reproducing themselves. Such "kin selection" is thought to have contributed to the evolution of the social insects  especially, ants, bees, wasps and termites  where only a few individuals reproduce and everyone else looks after the offspring.  We'd want to discuss evolution beyond natural selection  the other forces that can sometimes cause (or prevent) evolutionary change. For although natural selection is the only creative force in evolution  the only one that can produce complex structures such as wings and eyes  it is not the only force that affects which genes will spread, and which will vanish.   And, and, and.   What would he make of it all?   I think his reaction would be a mix of satisfaction and astonishment. Satisfaction: that natural selection has turned out to be such a powerful idea, explaining such a wide range of phenomena. Astonishment: for the same reason. He would, I think, be fascinated by the weird natural history that has been discovered in the past 150 years  such as Wolbachia, bacteria that pervert the reproduction of insects for their own ends. (Wolbachia can have a number of effects, but one of the most common is to kill all a female's sons. The reason is that sons don't transmit Wolbachia, so from Wolbachia's point of view, they are a waste of space.) I'm not sure he'd enjoy analyzing DNA sequences  he might find it a bit too abstracted from the living organism  but I think he'd be delighted to learn the results. I think he would be shocked by how much we know about the so-called model organisms  worms, toads, fruit flies, mice, humans and the bacterium E. coli  and how little we know about everything else. And I think he'd be startled by the nature of scientific research  the scale of the enterprise, the cost, the pressures to publish and the degree of specialization that results. His brand of science  20 years of thinking about a problem before publishing  could not be done today.   But I digress. To return to my argument: I'd like to abolish the insidious terms Darwinism, Darwinist and Darwinian. They suggest a false narrowness to the field of modern evolutionary biology, as though it was the brainchild of a single person 150 years ago, rather than a vast, complex and evolving subject to which many other great figures have contributed. (The science would be in a sorry state if one man 150 years ago had, in fact, discovered everything there was to say.) Obsessively focusing on Darwin, perpetually asking whether he was right about this or that, implies that the discovery of something he didn't think of or know about somehow undermines or threatens the whole enterprise of evolutionary biology today.  It does not. In the years ahead, I predict we will continue to refine our understanding of natural selection, and continue to discover new ways in which it can shape genes and genomes. Indeed, as genetic data continues to flood into the databanks, we will be able to ask questions about the detailed workings of evolution that it has not been possible to ask before.  Yet all too often, evolution  insofar as it is taught in biology classes at all  is taught as the story of Charles Darwin. Then the pages are turned, and everyone settles down to learn how the heart works, or how plants make energy from sunshine, or some other detail. The evolutionary concepts that unify biology, that allow us to frame questions and investigate the glorious diversity of life  these are ignored.  Darwin was an amazing man, and the principal founder of evolutionary biology. But his was the first major statement on the subject, not the last. Calling evolutionary biology "Darwinism," and evolution by natural selection "Darwinian" evolution, is like calling aeronautical engineering "Wrightism," and fixed-wing aircraft "Wrightian" planes, after those pioneers of fixed-wing flight, the Wright brothers. The best tribute we could give Darwin is to call him the founder  and leave it at that. Plenty of people in history have had an -ism named after them. Only a handful can claim truly to have given birth to an entire field of modern science.   **********  NOTES:  A full account of the range of Darwin's activities and accomplishments can be found in any biography. Many publications are guilty of the "Was Darwin wrong?" trope, and some of the biggest quarrels in modern evolutionary biology have concerned the validity of "non-Darwinian" evolution. A number of popular accounts discuss aspects of modern evolutionary biology; one of the best is "The Ancestor's Tale," by Richard Dawkins. Much has been written about male-killing by Wolbachia; see, for example, Jiggins, F. M., Hurst, G. D. D., Dolman, C. E., and Majerus, M. E. N. 2000. "High-prevalence male-killing Wolbachia in the butterfly Acraea encedana." Journal of Evolutionary Biology 13: 495-501.  This article was inspired (as so many others have been) by a conversation with Oliver Morton  many thanks, as always. Thanks, too, to Dan Haydon, Gideon Lichfield, Dmitri Petrov, Daniel Richler and Jonathan Swire for insights, comments and suggestions.

title: Peter Martins Inducted in Dance Hall of Fame
description: Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief of New York City Ballet, was inducted into the Hall of Fame of the National Museum of Dance in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., on Monday. Mr. Martins, left, who has led City Ballet since 1990, was honored for his work as an influential figure in dance for nearly three decades. Mr. Martins, who was born in Denmark, joined New York City Ballet as a principal dancer in 1970 and has choreographed nearly 80 ballets.

title: Death Row Sold
description: The independent label Global Music Group confirmed that it has bought Death Row Records for $24 million, The Associated Press reported. Global Music Group, based in New York, purchased the hip-hop label, including its current roster of artists and back catalog, on June 24. The company takes ownership of albums like The Chronic by Dr. Dre, All Eyez on Me by Tupac Shakur and Doggystyle by Snoop Dogg. Death Row was previously owned by Suge Knight, but was fraught with management problems. In 2005 Mr. Knight was ordered to pay $107 million to Lydia Harris, a Los Angeles producer who contended that she helped found the label with her husband. The next year Mr. Knight and Death Row filed for bankruptcy.

title: Check That Vote

States also need strong audit laws to ensure that machine totals are vigilantly checked against the paper records. That is the only way that voters will be able to trust electronic voting.
