title: In Paris, Burgers Turn Chic
description: PARIS

title: In Decade of Unlimited Rides, MetroCard Has Transformed How the City Travels
description: The unlimited-ride MetroCard turned 10 this month, a milestone for a thin piece of plastic that has helped usher in a boom in mass transit ridership.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some editions on July 7 about the Manhattan Special, a coffee soda made in Brooklyn since 1895 that is enjoying a comeback in specialty markets, referred incorrectly to Louis Passaro, the grandfather of the current owners. While he was indeed in charge of distribution, he did not eventually take over the operation.

title: Bush Emphasizes His Opposition to Timetable for Iraq Withdrawal
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush said Tuesday that Iraq wanted to include an aspirational goal for the departure of most foreign troops there in any agreement authorizing future American operations, but he reiterated his opposition to what he called an artificial timetable for withdrawal.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted July 7 through July 14 with 1,796 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 1,534 said they were registered to vote. Interviews were conducted in English or Spanish.

title: Congress, Overriding Bush, Blocks Pay Cut for Doctors
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush on Tuesday vetoed a bill protecting doctors from a Medicare pay cut, but both houses of Congress swiftly overrode the veto with large bipartisan majorities, so the bill is now law.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article by The Associated Press in some editions on Friday about the New York Police Departments decision to appeal a judges order to release internal stop-and-frisk data on pedestrians to the New York Civil Liberties Union omitted a comment from Jesse Levine, a lawyer for the city. He said the departments database on these street stops was available to all in the National Archive of Criminal Justice Data.

title: Knicks Rookie Gallinari sidelined by a Sore Back
description: Danilo Gallinari sat out the Knicks practice Tuesday because of a sore back and is listed as questionable for Wednesdays Summer League game in Las Vegas. Gallinari, the sixth pick in the June draft, hurt his back in his N.B.A. debut Monday in a collision with Clevelands Robert Traylor. The team does not consider the injury to be serious.

title: Rule Readied to Prevent Airliner Explosions
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly 12 years to the day that T.W.A. Flight 800 exploded off Long Island, killing all 230 people aboard, the secretary of transportation will go to the site of the planes reconstructed fuselage on Wednesday and announce a final rule designed to prevent more accidents caused by explosions in fuel tanks.

title: 10-Year Sentence in Scheme to Bilk Adoption System
description: Calling a former Queens womans acts diabolical in nature, a federal judge in Manhattan sentenced her to more than 10 years in prison on Tuesday for a fraudulent scheme in which she adopted 11 disabled children under four aliases, while collecting $1.68 million meant for their care to support a lavish lifestyle.

title: Archie McCardell, Harvester Chief Who Clashed With Union, Dies at 81
description: Archie R. McCardell, whose gruff, bottom-line approach as the new chief of the International Harvester Company in the late 1970s drew praise from Wall Street but the enmity of labor, culminating in a bitter five-and-a-half-month strike, died Friday in Casper, Wyo., where he lived. He was 81.

title: Grilled Lamb on Rosemary Skewers
description: Time: 20 minutes, plus time to heat grill

title: ProTour Series Crumbles as 17 Teams Withdraw
description: PAU, France  The International Cycling Unions ProTour series of races, which was started in 2004 by the sports governing body to ensure that the best teams all competed in the top races, essentially came apart Tuesday.

title:
Blazing a Trail
From a Reservation
Into Ownership
description: OHSWEKEN, Ontario  On a sunny afternoon two weeks ago, Curt Styres sat in the grandstand here at Ohsweken Speedway talking above the roar of a tractor grooming the dirt track. He recalled a night this May when he had been driving the tractor, as he usually does before stock car races.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a public esplanade that will replace two lanes of Broadway in a section of Midtown Manhattan with a bicycle lane and pedestrian walkway misstated the location of a similar, smaller plaza in Manhattan. It is at 14th Street and Ninth Avenue, not Eighth.

title: Countrywide Settles Lending Suit in Pennsylvania
description: Countrywide Home Loans has agreed to pay $325,000 to the Chapter 13 bankruptcy trustee in Pittsburgh, settling a matter that accused the lender of abusive practices in almost 300 mortgage loans overseen by the court.

title: Dow Falls Below 11,000, Despite Drop in Oil Prices
description: Stocks ended a volatile session in the red on Tuesday, despite a sharp drop in oil prices, after economic policy makers issued dour predictions and skepticism arose about the governments efforts to shore up the nations financial sector.

title: Oysters and Skewers at the New Whole Foods
description: The newest Whole Foods supermarket, a 69,000-square-foot store in TriBeCa, offers some features that are new for the chain.

title: Turkey: Kurdish Rebels Killed
description: Turkish soldiers killed 22 Kurdish separatist rebels in a three-day operation near the border with Iraq, the army said in a statement. The security forces said in the statement that among those killed was a senior member of the Kurdistan Workers Party, which is fighting for autonomy for the predominantly Kurdish region of southeastern Turkey, but no name was provided.

title: Fed Chief Bleak on Economic Outlook
description: WASHINGTON  A sense of economic gloom gripped Washington on Tuesday as President Bush urged Americans not to lose faith, the Federal Reserve chairman offered a mostly bleak assessment of the difficulties ahead for the economy, and the administrations latest effort to help the housing sector faced tough questioning in Congress.

title: Google and Yahoo Defend Ad Alliance at a Hearing
description: WASHINGTON

title: Obama Plays a Part in Contests in Georgia
description: ATLANTA  Vernon Jones, a black Democrat who voted for George W. Bush twice and then used Senator Barack Obamas image on his campaign literature, led a crowded field on Tuesday in a primary race to challenge Senator Saxby Chambliss, a Republican.

title: Off the Menu
description: Looking Ahead

title: Red Bulls Reyna to Announce Retirement
description: Red Bulls midfielder Claudio Reyna is expected to announce his retirement at a news conference Wednesday afternoon in Newark. Reyna, who has often been injured, has not played in a game for the Red Bulls since May 25 as he struggled with a back injury.

title: Wagner Adds Another Blemish to Season
description: Billy Wagner was not asked to pitch in the ninth inning, only the eighth. He was asked to retire one hitter, not two, not three, and a left-handed hitter at that. In All-Star Games, nothing goes as planned for Wagner, and it did not again as Tuesday night was about to turn into Wednesday morning.

title: Australia: Catholics Youth Gathering Begins
description: World Youth Day, an event that the Roman Catholic Church describes as the largest gathering of young people on the planet, began in a festive atmosphere in Sydney, with more than 140,000 people attending a Mass on a wharf, above. The Mass was the formal beginning of six days of celebrations for Pope Benedict XVI, who arrived in Australia on Sunday.

title: Spitzer Charged Campaign for Hotel Bills, Raising Questions on His Use of Funds
description: ALBANY  Two payments to the Mayflower Hotel in Washington were included in former Gov. Eliot Spitzers campaign filings, which were released on Tuesday afternoon.

title: Corrections
description: Front Page

title: For Sale in ... Victoria, British Columbia
description: WHAT

title: Selig Says Instant Replay Is a Possibility for This Seasons Playoffs
description: Commissioner Bud Selig said there was a possibility that instant replay would be used during the postseason. If Major League Baseball adopted instant replay, it would be used on fair and foul calls and for plays that happen over or near the outfield fence.

title: Homes at Risk, More Owners Consider Taking in Boarders
description: BALTIMORE  When Barbara Terry fell behind on her mortgage payments earlier this year, she did the previously unthinkable. Through a local housing organization, she and her daughter, Imani, 9, rented part of their single-family house to a stranger.

title: Ramos Gin Fizz
description: Adapted from Imbibe! by David Wondrich (Perigee, 2007)

title: Suicide Bombers Kill 33 Iraqi Recruits
description: BAGHDAD  After the explosions and fireballs consumed dozens of fellow Iraqi Army recruits in Baquba on Tuesday, a dazed Fawad Hamid found himself on a stretcher at a hospital, his chest perforated by ball bearings from explosive belts worn by the two teenage attackers.

title: At Oceana, the Voyage Continues
description: I RARELY hear people chattering about Oceana anymore. They dont mention it as a special-occasion restaurant they yearn to try. They dont mention it as a favorite they circle back to.

title: Pakistan Post Was Not in U.S. Records
description: WASHINGTON  The killing of 11 Pakistani paramilitary soldiers by American airstrikes last month might have been prevented if the precise location of a border checkpoint had been in an American database used to prevent accidental attacks on friendly forces, according to American and Pakistan officials.

title: In Spain, a Bright and Narrow Space
description: MADRID

title: Putting Your Fruit Where Your Heart Is
description: What does a stalk of celery, a peapod, a strawberry say to you? To the folks who make Food Tees, organic cotton T-shirts, tanks, sweatshirts and baby clothes, there are messages in each and every vegetable and fruit. And they print them on their products.

title: Brakes and Other Headaches at an Aircraft Show
description: FARNBOROUGH, England  Problems linked to the braking system of Boeings delayed 787 Dreamliner and a lack of orders from Western airlines darkened the mood Tuesday at the Farnborough International Airshow, the aerospace industrys showcase annual event.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about a nearly 40 percent drop in killings in Newark so far this year compared with the same period in 2007 misspelled the given name of the citys mayor. He is Cory A. Booker, not Corey.

title: Sprint Said to Talk About Partnership
description: Sprint Nextel, the wireless carrier, is in early talks to form a partnership with SK Telecom of South Korea to share information about mobile phones and other technology, according to people briefed on the talks.

title: Actors Speak Against Plan to Redevelop St. Vincents
description: Since April, dozens of speakers have stepped before the open microphones of the Landmarks Preservation Commission during hearings to praise the quality of health care at St. Vincents Hospital Manhattan. But on Tuesday, two celebrity neighbors did not have kudos in mind.

title: The Tasty Twig, a Barbecue Tradition
description: LAMB on rosemary skewers has to be one of the oldest recipes in the world. In ancient times, the meat could just as easily have been goat, or something wilder, and fish was no doubt also a candidate. The idea of cutting branches of rosemary and using them as skewers must certainly have occurred to humans soon after they figured out how to build fires.

title: Incompetence and Corruption Haunt Crane Work
description: The trial in federal court in 2006 was a union corruption case that in several days of testimony touched on a certain looseness in the way New York City had long handed out its licenses to operate cranes.

title: Two New Restaurants: Kafana and Wildwood Barbeque
description: NEW PLACES

title: Solzhenitsyn Novel Is Translated
description: An uncut edition of The First Circle, a critically acclaimed and controversial novel by Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, will be released in English by Harper Perennial, The Associated Press reported. The novel, set in a gulag, was banned by Soviet officials when it was completed in 1964. In 1968 a shorter English version was released over Mr. Solzhenitsyns objections. A new, complete English version of the text was approved several years ago, but its translator, Harry T. Willetts, died in 2005, delaying publication. Mr. Solzhenitsyn, now 89 and living in Moscow, won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1970 and returned to his homeland in the 1990s after two decades in exile.

title: Steinbrenner, 78, Appears to Hugs, Kisses and Cheers
description: An emotional George Steinbrenner, the Yankees principal owner, delivered four baseballs to the mound as part of the pregame ceremonies for the All-Star Game. It was Steinbrenners first visit to Yankee Stadium since opening day.

title: Deal for Showtime and Weinstein Company
description: The Weinstein Company has signed an exclusive, seven-year agreement with the cable channel Showtime, Reuters reported. The deal, which begins in 2009, calls for Showtime to broadcast as many as 95 Weinstein films, including coming releases like Rob Marshalls adaptation of the Broadway musical Nine and Quentin Tarantinos World War II-era epic, Inglorious Bastards. The deal, whose financial terms were not disclosed, flies in the face of recent moves by MGM, Lionsgate and Paramount Pictures, which announced in April that they were canceling their Showtime agreements and creating a rival pay channel. ... Weinstein also announced Tuesday that its publishing unit had acquired Larry Kings autobiography, What Am I Doing Here? The book, which will be written with Cal Fussman, a writer at large for Esquire, and distributed by Hachette, is to be released on Fathers Day.

title: Immigrants Eager to Vote Sue to Hasten Citizenship
description: Lawyers representing a Latino advocacy group told a federal judge on Tuesday that tens of thousands of people in and around New York City, most of them Latino, were at risk of being disenfranchised in the November elections because the federal government was taking so long to process their citizenship applications.

title: A 1913 Law Dies to Better Serve Gay Marriages
description: BOSTON  Massachusetts may have been the first state to legalize same-sex marriage for its residents, but when California last month invited out-of-state gay and lesbian couples to get married, the potential economic benefits did not go unnoticed here. Now Massachusetts wants to extend the same invitation.

title: For Half a Cent, a Call That Informs, and Annoys
description: At Newswalk, a 168-unit condominium building in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, doormen have for years let residents know they have packages by putting little yellow sticky notes on their mailboxes. They still do that, but now many residents receive automated phone calls or e-mail alerts, too.

title: A.L. Wins in Lengthy Farewell to Stadium
description: It was tense, it was exciting and it was long, but, in the end, the final scenes from the All-Star Game proved to be as predictable as ever. The American League was better than the National League, again. Regardless of how many twists and turns this marathon game took, the A.L. prevailed, 4-3, in 15 innings.

title: Bulgarian Folk, Trippily Seasoned and Mashed
description: Are there any Bulgarians in the audience tonight? asked Jeremy Barnes of A Hawk and a Hacksaw, trying to get a witness. Weak, possibly fraudulent applause. It was Monday night at Le Poisson Rouge, and there were small-b bohemians in the house, but not too many Bulgarians.

title: As the Economy Heads South, Office Rents Go North
description: The economy is in a downturn; job losses in Manhattan in financial services and related industries are expected to exceed 20,000; and the capital markets remain in turmoil. And yet some landlords are demanding higher rents than ever.

title: Court Backs Bush on Military Detentions
description: President Bush has the legal power to order the indefinite military detentions of civilians captured in the United States, the federal appeals court in Richmond, Va., ruled on Tuesday in a fractured 5-to-4 decision.

title: Fox Anchor Is Considering Leaving Show
description: Brit Hume, the political anchor and Washington managing editor of the Fox News Channel, intends to step down from his nightly newscast after the presidential election, three of his friends and colleagues said this week.

title: Lessons Abound for a Winner and a Runner-Up at the Open
description: SOUTHPORT, England  The tall Irish golfer had just rounded the corner behind the clubhouse at Royal Birkdale Golf Club when he stopped like a wedge shot into a soft green. Brought up short by the sight of two reporters walking his way, Padraig Harrington, the defending British Open champion, made a decisive U-turn and began retracing his steps, looking for a convenient doorway to escape the oncoming news media.

title: Arthur Weinstein, Starter of Nightclubs, Dies at 60
description: In the glittery, manic, often ostentatiously naughty 1970s and 80s, Arthur Weinstein was king of the night. His kingdom was a new breed of nightclubs that transcended disco balls, tired formulas and strobe lights to become ultrahip destinations for those deemed worthy of entering.

title: World Youth Day Opens in Sydney
description: SYDNEY  World Youth Day, the event the Roman Catholic church describes as the largest gathering of young people on the planet, began Tuesday, with 100,000 people attending a mass on a disused wharf overlooking the sparkling waters of Sydney harbor.

title: With Warning, G.M. Takes Wide Cost Cuts
description: DETROIT  With concern growing among investors about a possible bankruptcy filing, General Motors on Tuesday announced sweeping cost cuts and other measures to bolster its tenuous cash position.

title: New Breath Test Policy Shadows Detectives Case
description: About 2 a.m. on Sunday, an off-duty detective who had been out with his buddies saw a group beating a man outside a Queens nightclub. Armed with a 9-millimeter pistol, he intervened.

title: Kurds Protest Iraqi Election Law
description: BAGHDAD  The entire bloc of Kurdish lawmakers walked out of Iraqs Parliament on Tuesday to protest a proposed provincial election law, contending that part of it was unconstitutional.

title: Entertainment Events
description: Music

title: Where to Eat? Ask Your iPhone
description: IF you were searching for a restaurant that would please almost anyone, Dressler, in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, might well be it.

title: Between Sureness and Self-Pity Stands a Vulnerable Vanya
description: Almost any actress can drab herself down to be plain Sonya in Chekhovs Uncle Vanya. Cute Amy Ryan played her on Broadway, up against Laura Linney as Yelena, every mans dream woman. But not every pretty face can pull off Yelenas goddess act.

title: Worker Dies After Truck Hits Crane in Queens
description: A construction worker was killed on Tuesday when he was knocked off a small crane after a large truck hit it, the police said. The worker fell about 15 feet to the ground.

title: Behind Walls of Warehouses, a Trove of Artwork
description: At the same time that art museums and galleries have developed larger collections, they have fewer options to expand. Perhaps inevitably, an art services industry that has sprung up in the dark warehouses of New York Citys boroughs is also growing.

title: In All-Star Parade, Playing Games Before Ball
description: All along the route of Tuesdays All-Star Game parade (official Major League Baseball crowd prediction: More than one million spectators are expected to line Sixth Avenue), spectators were lined up one and two deep at the barricades. On some streets, they were even three deep. That was generally at corners where people trying to cross got stuck in jams.

title: They Get It
description: MISSOULA, Mont.

title: China Says Algae Cleared for Sailing
description: BEIJING  Olympic athletes competing in waters off the east coast of China can literally expect smooth sailing in August, a Chinese official said Tuesday.

title: S.E.C. Unveils Measures to Limit Short-Selling
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, under pressure to respond to the tumult in the financial industry, announced emergency measures on Tuesday to curb certain kinds of short-selling that aims at Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, as well as Wall Street banks.

title: U.S. Envoy to Join Meeting With Iranian
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush has authorized the most significant American diplomatic contact with Iran since the Islamic Revolution in 1979, sending the State Departments third-ranking official to Geneva for a meeting this weekend on Irans nuclear program, administration officials said Tuesday.

title: Congress Overrides Bushs Veto on Medicare
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush cast a futile veto on Tuesday, rejecting a bill that would protect doctors from cuts in their Medicare payments. But hours later, the House and Senate voted to override the veto, making the Medicare measure the fourth bill to become legislation over Mr. Bushs opposition.

title: Profit Rises 25% at Intel on Strong Global Demand
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Finally, some good news for Wall Street.

title: What You Get for ... $700,000
description: Scottsville, Va.

title: Afghanistan: Pakistan Talks Halted
description: The Afghan government has suspended a series of meetings with Pakistan, accusing the Pakistani military and intelligence agencies of being behind a rash of recent terrorist attacks in Afghanistan. The Council of Ministers passed a resolution on Monday to halt the meetings after investigations revealed the involvement of Pakistani agencies in a number of attacks, including an assassination attempt on President Hamid Karzai in April, suicide bombings and the execution of Afghan civilians, according to a presidential spokesman, Homayun Hamidzada.

title: As Children Grow, Activity Quickly Slows
description: Young children spend an extraordinary amount of time moving about: an average of three hours a day at age 9, new research shows.

title: Grilled Squid With Snail Butter
description: Time: 20 minutes

title: Medal-Winning Hungarian Canoeist Dies From Heart Failure
description: Gyorgy Kolonics of Hungary, a gold medalist in canoeing at the 1996 and 2000 Olympics, died Tuesday after collapsing while training for the Beijing Games, The Associated Press reported.

title: William T. Sanders, 82, Anthropologist, Is Dead
description: William T. Sanders, an anthropologist whose influential studies of early civilizations in Mexico and Central America included a vast and invaluable aerial survey of ancient archaeological sites, died July 2 in State College, Pa. He was 82.

title: Fox Edges Past CBS With Repeats
description: In what was largely a battle of repeats on Monday, Fox edged past CBS for first place in the ratings as reruns of Bones and House led their time slots by slim margins. According to Nielsens estimates, the two Fox shows delivered 6.3 million and 7.4 million viewers at 8 and 9 p.m. CBSs sitcom Two and a Half Men fared slightly better in its half-hour at 9 (8.2 million), but the networks ratings were weighed down by two episodes of the comedies The Big Bang Theory, at 8 (5.3 million) and 9:30 (6.4 million), with How I Met Your Mother at 8:30 (5.1 million). NBC ranked third for the night as American Gladiators attracted just 5 million viewers at 8. It was followed by Nashville Star at 9 (5.9 million) and Dateline at 10 (6.3 million). CBSs CSI: Miami repeat easily led the 10 p.m. hour (7.7 million), while The Mole on ABC struggled with just 3.6 million viewers. ABC finished fourth for the night as a clip show of The Mole at 9 earned only 3 million and a special, The Bachelor: Where Are They Now, at 8, just 4.9.

title: Correction: Restless Pioneers, Seeding Brooklyn
description: An article and an accompanying list last Wednesday about Brooklyn restaurants that have involved the entrepreneurs Alan Harding and Jim Mamary misstated the name of one Mr. Harding opened in Red Hook and the year it opened, and erroneously included one item on its menu. The restaurant was The Old Pioneer, not Pioneer Bar-B-Que; it opened in 2004, not 2005, and it did not sell barbecue.

title: Melted Cheese Sliders
description: Adapted from the Stanton Social

title: Snail Butter, Please Hold the Snails
description: WHEN I was growing up, my parents were so obsessed with eating snails  la bourguignonne that one summer while vacationing in Burgundy, they paid my sister and me 5 centimes a snail to collect them from the garden of the little house we were staying in. We placed them in a bucket and secured them with a screen top. The grown-ups then starved and purged the gastropods before cooking them a few days later  drowned in garlic parsley snail butter, of course.

title: Hey, Grown-Ups, Let the Kids Play Wiffle Ball!
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: Brooklyn Pioneers
description: To the Editor:

title: Detainee Challenges Guantnamo by Describing Life There
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba  Salim Hamdan moved slowly to the witness chair.

title: McCain Names More Top Fund-Raisers, Including Lobbyists
description: Senator John McCain released an updated list of his top money collectors on Tuesday, revealing that nearly a fifth of those who have brought in the largest amounts for him, more than $500,000 each, are lobbyists or work for firms that engage in lobbying.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Rocky Aoki, who founded the Benihana chain of steakhouses, misstated the length of the sentence he received in an insider-trading case. It was three years probation, not three months probation.

title: Record Gulf Dead Zone Is Expected
description: Scientists from the Louisiana Universities Marine Consortium predicted that this years summer dead zone off the Louisiana coast would be the largest ever and would threaten commercial and recreational fishing in the Gulf of Mexico. The scientists, who attributed the dead zone in large part to agricultural chemicals carried into the Mississippi and Atchafalaya Rivers by this years severe Midwest floods, predicted it would cover about 8,800 square miles, roughly the size of New Jersey. The previous record, in 2002, was almost 8,500 square miles; last year, the dead zone covered almost 8,000 square miles. The scientists said high nutrient levels in the water stimulate the growth of algae whose eventual decomposition depletes oxygen to the point that most marine life cannot survive.

title: Toughening of Sex Law Is Rejected by Court
description: A New Jersey appellate court panel dealt a blow on Tuesday to scores of municipalities in the state that had sought to toughen Megans Law in recent years by restricting where sex offenders could live. The panel said that such local ordinances conflicted with the states landmark law.

title: Letters: Refrigerated Red
description: To the Editor:

title: Between Presidents, a Dangerous Gap
description: NOW that we have presumptive presidential nominees from the two major political parties, we need to turn our attention to the transition that will take place six months from now. One of the observations of the 9/11 commission was that the deeply flawed presidential transition of 2000 and 2001 created a dangerous period of vulnerability.

title: Rule Drafted for Carbon Trapping
description: WASHINGTON  The Environmental Protection Agency announced on Tuesday a first draft of a rule that will govern injecting carbon dioxide into underground storage.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about Representative Charles B. Rangels defense of his use of four rent-stabilized apartments in Harlem overstated the response from the Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, a government watchdog group. The group said it planned to ask the House ethics committee to examine whether Mr. Rangels arrangement violated a ban on members accepting gifts of more than $100, and also planned to file a complaint with the Federal Election Commission. It did not take those actions on Friday.

title: Bruno Says He Will Leave State Senate by Weeks End
description: ALBANY  Joseph L. Bruno, the longtime majority leader of the State Senate who unexpectedly relinquished his leadership post late last month and announced that he would not seek re-election, said Tuesday that he plans to leave the Senate altogether by the end of this week.

title: Blurry Peek at Questioning of a Guantnamo Inmate
description: OTTAWA  The video is blurry and the soundtrack muffled, but the technical shortcomings of the video recordings released Tuesday did not obscure the emotions of Omar Khadr as he was interrogated at the Guantnamo Bay detention center in Cuba.

title: Jet Lag Is No Sweat, but Just Try to Beat the Heat and the Smog
description: Air pollution. Heat and humidity. Time zone changes. All have been cited as potential issues at next months Beijing Olympics. And the fear is that any of them can throw a superior athlete into dissolution, allowing an inferior athlete to win a competition.

title: Ten Years for Joe's Pub
description: Since it opened in October 1998 in a corner of the Public Theater once used as administrative offices, Joes Pub has become one of the premier nightclubs of New York, known for eclectic programming including the American debuts of Amy Winehouse, the Congolese band Konono No. 1 and many others. This fall the club will celebrate its 10th anniversary with 300 shows from September through December, bringing back many Joes Pub favorites. Among the acts booked are Keren Ann, Ute Lemper, Sandra Bernhard, Gilberto Gil, Allen Toussaint, Erin McKeown, Carmen Consoli, Plastic People of the Universe and Michael John LaChiusa. Also planned is an Artists in Conversation series with Olu Dara, Sam Lipsyte, Ethan Iverson and others. Tickets go on sale Thursday at noon: (212) 967-7555 or joespub.com.

title: Anger and Dismay at the Sale of a City Treasure
description: ST. LOUIS  With the shades inside a tavern on Pestalozzi Street drawn to block the early morning sun, Dave Liszewski, a third-shift worker at Anheuser-Busch, nursed a bottle of Bud Light and a hollowed sense of pride.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Major Setback for Clean Air
description: Nobody could ever seriously accuse the Bush administration of being too aggressive when it comes to enforcing the nations environmental laws. But it was partly on those grounds that a federal court last week struck down the Clean Air Interstate Rule, a regulation aimed at reducing soot and smog and one of the few creative initiatives to emerge from the Environmental Protection Agency in the last seven years.

title: Cannes Winner to Open New York Film Festival
description: The 46th New York Film Festival will open with the North American premiere of The Class (Entre les Murs), the Film Society of Lincoln Center announced on Tuesday. The film, by Laurent Cantet, won the Palme dOr at the Cannes Film Festival this year. Other highlights of the New York festival include In the Realm of Oshima, a celebration of the life and career of the Japanese New Wave director Nagisa Oshima. The French writer, theorist and filmmaker Guy Debords 1978 film, In girum imus nocte et consumimur igni (a palindrome that translates to We Spin Around the Night Consumed by the Fire), will be featured as part of the annual Views From the Avant-Garde program. The festival will run from Sept. 26 to Oct. 12, with the Oshima and Debord films showing at the Walter Reade Theater. Other festival films will be at the Ziegfeld Theater while Alice Tully Hall, its regular home, undergoes renovations. Tickets go on sale Sept. 7.

title: Heirloom to Commodity, Gehrigs Jacket Is Sold
description: Dave Ennis waited nervously at the Javits Convention Center in Manhattan on Tuesday to see how high bids would go for an artifact that had been in his family for decades  a heavy wool warm-up jacket belonging to Lou Gehrig, the one he most likely wore the day he stopped playing in 1939.

title: A Fiery New Incarnation of a Monster of a Mother
description: Its really not a good idea to mess with Violet Weston, the fire-breathing dragon lady of Pawhuska, Okla., who presides over a feast of family combat in August: Osage County. As all who have seen Tracy Lettss celebrated comedy-drama on Broadway no doubt vividly recall, Violet does not brook much interference when it comes to indulging her favorite pastimes.

title: Britain: Burberrys First-Quarter Sales Rose 22%
description: The Burberry Group, a luxury goods retailer, said first-quarter sales rose 22 percent on shipments of autumn and winter goods to wholesale distributors in emerging markets. Sales climbed to 211 million ($422 million) in the three months through June from 167 million a year earlier, the company said. Wholesale revenue jumped 45 percent excluding currency movements. Burberry, based in London, added shops in Budapest and the Azerbaijani capital of Baku during the quarter, helping to double emerging-markets revenue.

title: Democrats See a Need for Further Economic Stimulus
description: Many economists have concluded that a second dose of government stimulus spending is required to prevent a broad economic unraveling and provide relief to millions of Americans grappling with joblessness, plunging home prices and tight credit.

title: A Red Carpet Day That Is Up Close and Personal
description: Imagine driving through a Midtown intersection, looking to your left and seeing Derek Jeter riding in the back of a flatbed truck, waving and winking.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about a pledge by leaders of the worlds richest nations to halve greenhouse gas emissions by 2050 misstated the title of Philip E. Clapp, an environmental analyst who commented on the pledge, and misstated the name of his organization. Mr. Clapp is deputy managing director of the Pew Environment Group, not director of the Pew Environmental Group.

title: Enlivening Classical Series With Brazilian Spices
description: When the Brazilian pianist Jos Feghali won the gold medal at the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition in 1985, you might have assumed that stardom would follow. Not exactly: like many Cliburn winners before and since, Mr. Feghali has had a respectable career. But a household name he is not, save perhaps in Fort Worth, where the Cliburn competition is based, and where Mr. Feghali has been an artist in residence at Texas Christian University since 1990.

title: In Manhattan, Sliders for All Tastes
description: SLIDERS have an identity crisis. The three-bite burgers probably belong on an analysts couch, not on a plate.

title: Seeing Bad Loans, Investors Flee From Bank Shares
description: On Wall Street, the run is on.

title: Paterson Has Raised $3.3 Million Since March
description: ALBANY  Gov. David A. Paterson has raised $3.3 million since taking office, by tapping into a broad array of special-interest groups and casting aside the self-imposed fund-raising limits of his predecessor, Eliot Spitzer, according to reports made public on Tuesday.

title: So Popular and So Spineless
description: Much ink has been spilled lately decrying the decline in American popularity around the world under President Bush. Polls tell us how China is now more popular in Asia than America and how few Europeans say they identify with the United States. I am sure there is truth to these polls. We should have done better in Iraq. An America that presides over Abu Ghraib, torture and Guantnamo Bay deserves a thumbs-down.

title: Canada Expels an American Deserter From the Iraq War
description: OTTAWA  An American Army deserter who sought refuge in Canada from the war in Iraq was expelled Tuesday to the United States. The deserter, Robin Long, a native of Boise, Idaho, is believed to be the first from the Iraq war returned by the Canadian government.

title: Art Auctions on Cruise Ships Lead to Anger, Accusations and Lawsuits
description: When most people think of art auctions, they think of Christies or Sothebys in New York or London, not a cruise ship. But over the last two decades, auctioning fine art on cruises, often to first-time bidders who have never met a reserve or inspected a provenance, has become big business.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the history and growth of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the two government-chartered mortgage companies, misstated their tax status. They are exempt from state and local taxes; they are not exempt from federal taxes.

title: The Daily News and The Post Talk Business
description: Rupert Murdoch, whose News Corporation owns The New York Post, and Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the real estate developer and owner of The Daily News, who for years have been bitter tabloid competitors, are considering the unthinkable: cooperation.

title: Seeing Oil Bubble, a Contrarian Bets on an Indian Airline
description: NEW DELHI  Wilbur L. Ross Jr.s latest deal, an $80 million investment in the flailing Indian airline SpiceJet, announced on Tuesday, is hardly earth shaking, but the idea behind it is typically contrarian.

title: Olympians and Superpowers, and the Games They Played in a Roman Arena
description: The best way to enjoy David Maranisss Rome 1960: The Olympics That Changed the World is to ignore its hyperbolic subtitle and plunge like a 10-meter platform diver into the games themselves.

title: Bernanke Is Pessimistic, but Bush Urges a Deep Breath
description: WASHINGTON  Warning of the risks of a further slowdown and higher inflation, Ben S. Bernanke, chairman of the Federal Reserve, offered a gloomy assessment of the economy on Tuesday as President Bush, speaking a few blocks away, urged Americans to have faith in the countrys financial foundation.

title: Nine to Five to Broadway
description: What a way to make a living.

title: NATO Hires a Coke Executive to Retool Its Brand
description: BRUSSELS  During the cold war, when Western and Warsaw Pact tanks massed on either side of the Iron Curtain, the idea of a brand for NATO would have been ludicrous because everyone knew why it was important.

title: New York States Public Integrity Panel
description: To the Editor:

title: Sheeps Milk Ricotta From an Outpost of Tuscany
description: For much of the year, Jody and Luisa Somers, who own Dancing Ewe Farm in Granville, N.Y., near Saratoga Springs, make ricotta from the whey left over from making their richly complex Tuscan-style cows milk caciotta cheese.

title: Barack Obama Walks Into a Bar ...
description: To the Editor:

title: Whos Got an Extra Ticket? With Strong Demand, Not Many
description: With a healthy demand for tickets during this years All-Star weekend, even the scalpers were running low Tuesday evening.

title: Smoked Salmon Sliders
description: Time: 20 minutes

title: Belgian Prime Minister Offers to Resign
description: BRUSSELS  After just four months, the crisis that had prompted fears that Belgium would split returned with a vengeance on Tuesday when the prime minister offered to quit after failing to broker a deal between the countrys main linguistic groups.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a dispute over rival cookbooks that both have recipes for concealing pured vegetables in food for children contained outdated information about a lawyer who did not return calls on behalf of Jessica Seinfeld, author of Deceptively Delicious, who is being sued by Missy Chase Lapine, author of The Sneaky Chef. The lawyer, who was not identified, was no longer representing Ms. Seinfeld at the time he was asked to comment. (Her new lawyer, Orin Snyder, has since told The Times that he filed a motion on June 17 that argues for dismissal of the lawsuit on the grounds that it is opportunistic and baseless.)

title: Heros Welcome Expected in Lebanon for Captive of Israel
description: Perhaps Israels most reviled prisoner, Samir Kuntar, will return to a heros welcome when he crosses into Lebanon this week, 29 years after he left its shores in a rubber dinghy to kidnap Israelis from the coastal town of Nahariya.

title: Blair Cancels Visit to Gaza After Israel Warns of Threat
description: JERUSALEM  Tony Blair, the international envoy for Palestinian development, canceled a visit to Gaza on short notice on Tuesday after being tipped off by the Israeli security services about a threat to his convoy, an Israeli official said.

title: May We Mock, Barack?
description: WASHINGTON

title: Poll Finds Obama Isnt Closing Divide on Race
description: Americans are sharply divided by race heading into the first election in which an African-American will be a major-party presidential nominee, with blacks and whites holding vastly different views of Senator Barack Obama, the state of race relations and how black Americans are treated by society, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Radomski Gives Evidence in Clemens Case
description: Kirk Radomski, the former steroids dealer, has turned over additional documentary evidence to federal authorities that raises questions about Roger Clemenss suspected use of performance-enhancing drugs, according to a lawyer with knowledge of the matter.

title: G.O.P. Resistance May Delay Housing Legislation
description: WASHINGTON  Democratic Congressional leaders on Tuesday pushed back their timetable for approving emergency housing legislation after Republicans voiced growing skepticism and, in some cases, angry opposition to the Bush administrations proposal to rescue Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the government-chartered mortgage finance companies.

title: Obama and McCain Duel Over Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  The war in Iraq has distorted Americas foreign policy, cost it thousands of lives, tarnished its image and emptied its treasury, Senator Barack Obama said on Tuesday. The presumptive Democratic presidential nominee pledged that he would swiftly end the war and reorient Americas approach to the world to address the challenges of terrorism, nuclear proliferation, climate change and energy dependence.

title: Corrections
description: A review on Monday of Il Barbiere di Siviglia, at the Caramoor International Music Festival, misstated the voice range of Matthew Trevio, who portrayed Don Basilio. He is a bass, not a tenor.

title: Opposition, From Both Parties, Over Bailout Plan
description: WASHINGTON  The Bush administrations plan to rescue the nations two largest mortgage finance companies ran into sharp criticism in Congress on Tuesday as some lawmakers questioned the open-ended request for money that could be used to help the companies.

title: Hamilton Finds Stadium Longer Than Long Shots
description: At its core, it is a club of failures  Babe Ruth, Mickey Mantle, Josh Gibson, Jimmie Foxx, Hank Greenberg. But in baseball lore, it is a club of players who flirted with one of the few marks in the game that still seems insurmountable.

title: Demoted Lehman Officer Leaves for Credit Suisse
description: Erin Callan, whose rise and fall at Lehman Brothers transfixed Wall Street, has resigned to join Credit Suisse.

title: Dental Decay in Albany
description: Tucked inside the first batch of bills that Gov. David Paterson signed last week was a law involving state dentists that Joel Miller, a Republican assemblyman from Poughkeepsie, called nothing more than proof that corruption is alive and well in the State Legislature.

title: European Economies Sag, but Euro Remains Strong
description: FRANKFURT  Europe, which held the worlds economic storms at bay for the last year, has finally succumbed.

title: Vision Insurer to Ask Justices to Restore Its Tax Exemption
description: The countrys largest eye-care insurance program plans to ask the Supreme Court to decide whether the Internal Revenue Service properly revoked its tax exemption in 2003, company executives said Tuesday.

title: All-Stars Leave Their Rivalries in the Clubhouse
description: As a first baseman, Kevin Youkilis of the Red Sox is the greeter on the bases, even during games against the Yankees. His fans may not like to hear it, but when the teams met recently, Youkilis told Derek Jeter he was eager to be his teammate.

title: Ah, the Heat, the Crowd, the Park and the Booze
description: The phenomenon can be a little startling to newcomers, though it is one that more seasoned New Yorkers most likely no longer see, possibly because they are still recovering from the night before.

title: Who Spread False Tales of Heroism?
description: Widespread  and, we suspect, self-induced  amnesia among high officials of the Bush administration and its Defense Department has made it impossible for House investigators to determine whether top officials helped spread two bogus stories of heroism used to bolster support for the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Germany Convicts 3 in 2004 Plot to Kill Iraqi Leader
description: BERLIN  A state court in Germany on Tuesday convicted three men who it said were members of a terrorist organization of plotting to kill the Iraqi prime minister on a visit to Berlin in 2004.

title: Motor Heads Take a Detour, With Cartoon Carburetors
description: PBS, as you may have heard, is now in the animated sitcom business, and I can anticipate what youre going to say next: Oh, no, not another cartoon version of Lady Windermeres Fan. Instead the network has pilfered from NPR, spinning the popular radio program Car Talk into a half-hour of television every Wednesday. The series is called Click & Clacks As the Wrench Turns, and stars graphically rendered versions of the famous Click & Clack brothers, Tom and Ray Magliozzi of Cambridge, Mass., who have been solving carburetor and girlfriend problems on their national radio program for over a decade. (Other titles the Magliozzis considered: Transmission Impossible and Ken Burns Presents Car Talk.)

title: Papelbon Learns Fans Will Be Fans in the Bronx
description: There was never more evidence of the conflicted loyalties of an All-Star Game than in the eighth inning at Yankee Stadium on Tuesday night.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 2 about an agreement by New York Citys Health and Hospitals Corporation to increase the monitoring of patients at a Brooklyn hospitals psychiatric ward after a videotape surfaced showing a patient collapsing on the floor and dying referred incorrectly to a lawsuit accusing the hospital of neglect. It is still pending in federal court; it has not been settled.

title: Obama and McCain Duel Over Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama said on Tuesday that the addition of tens of thousands of combat troops to Iraq last year had significantly reduced violence in the country. But he said that positive developments there had not changed his mind about the need to pull troops from Iraq so America could focus more on the deteriorating situation in Afghanistan.

title: Microsoft Goes Mainstream, and Other News of the Gamer World
description: LOS ANGELES  Ever since Microsoft waded into the video game wars with the introduction of the original Xbox in 2001, the company has spared little expense in trying to establish its bona fides with hard-core gamers. From the physical appearance of the first Xbox  hulking, extruded black plastic  to the testosterone-laden, shoot-em-up essence of its signature game franchise, Halo, Microsofts first, perhaps only, priority has been to reach the young men at gamings historical roots.

title: McCain on Iraq and Afghanistan
description: Senator John McCain responds to Senator Barack Obama on foreign policy in Albuquerque.

title: Q & A With Samuel Etoo
description: Samuel Etoo is one of the most prolific goal scorers in the European game. He currently is on the roster of Barcelona in Spain, but it is possible that he could have a new address by the time European season begins next month. Etoo, a Cameroon international, is scheduled to begin training with Barcelona for the season in La Liga under a new coach, Pep Guardiola, on Saturday.

title: The Quad Countdown: No. 44 Colorado
description: Location: Boulder, Colo.

title: The All-Star Game That Wont End
description: This the longest All-Star Game ever, by time of game, and it has matched the longest in terms of innings, with 15. Incredible.

title: All-Star Game
description: The American League took the final All-Star Game at Yankee Stadium, 4-3.

title: After All-Star Slide, Justin Morneau Can Dream
description: Playing 10 innings of an All-Star Game gives a player the license to dream. At least, that is how it was early Wednesday morning for Justin Morneau of the Minnesota Twins. Minutes after sliding across the plate with the winning run in a 4-3, 15-inning victory for the American League, Morneau realized what the victory could mean.

title: Awkward, but Position Players Were Ready to Pitch
description: It was only dugout chatter. But if Scott Kazmir had had to throw a few more pitches early Wednesday morning, Evan Longoria told his teammates, he could have replaced him on the mound in the All-Star Game.

title: Night Starts Out Badly for Uggla, and Stays That Way
description: Dan Uggla's chance in the All-Star spotlight started poorly Tuesday night and stayed on that path well into Wednesday morning.

title: Walden Eyeing $500 Million Fund for Asian Investments
description: Walden International plans to launch a global fund early next year to raise up to $500 million as it steps up investment in China and India, Reuters reported citing a top official.

title: UBS to Raise Pay for Wealth Management Advisers
description: In an effort to safeguard its wealth-management business, UBS is sweetening deals for its financial advisers, many of whom have recently defected.

title: YouSendIt Gets $14 Million in Funding
description: YouSendIt has secured a $14 million series C financing round from existing investors Sigma Partners, Alloy Ventures, Sevin Rosen Funds and Cambrian Ventures along with new investor Emergence Capital, Computer Technology Review said.

title: Rome: Correggio Steals the Show in Villa Borghese
description: by Alison Smale

title: Walgreen Begins $1.3 Billion Debt Offering
description: Walgreen started its first public debt offering in over two decades on Tuesday, The Chicago Tribune reported. The move was intended to establish long-term funding for some recent acquisitions.

title: Centro Properties Sells U.S. Malls for $714 Million
description: Centro Properties Group, caught in the global credit crunch, said it is selling some of its United States shopping malls for $714 million to pay down debt, sending its shares up as much as 35 percent Tuesday.

title: CapitaLand Creates $1 Billion Real Estate Fund
description: CapitaLand has set up a $1 billion private equity fund to invest in commercial property projects in China, Bloomberg reported.

title: South Korea Court Convicts Ex-Samsung Boss
description: A South Korean court convicted former Samsung Chairman Lee Kun-hee on Wednesday for evading taxes and fined him 110 billion won ($109 million), but said his crimes did not justify a prison term.

title: Grey Wolf Shareholders Reject Basic Energy Deal
description: Grey Wolf shareholders voted down the companys proposed purchase of Basic Energy Services, which could open the door to a possible takeover of Grey Wolf by Canadas Precision Drilling Trust instead, The Globe and Mail reported.

title: Continental Rejects Schaefflers 11.2 Billion Offer
description: Germanys Continental has rejected an 11.2 billion euro ($17.8 billion) takeover bid by automotive parts maker Schaeffler, The Financial Times reported. Further, Continental called the smaller companys method of stakebuilding unlawful.

title: BlueBay Shares Jump on Increased Assets
description: Shares in BlueBay Asset Management climbed as much as 21 percent on Wednesday aided by new investments in the hedge fund managers long-only funds which helped drive a sharp rise in assets under management, MarketWatch reported.

title: Madison Dearborn Said to Target $10 Billion Fund
description: Madison Dearborn Partners, the Chicago-based buyout firm, aims to reach a $10 billion target for a private equity fund, with help from sovereign wealth funds, The Deal reported, citing an unidentified source.

title: Dim Outlook Clouds Macao Casino Listing
description: Warring octogenarian siblings are not the only headache for investors as a casino company with roots in Macaos lurid past makes its stock market debut this week.

title: Tough Times for Euronext-Listed Funds
description: Many private equity funds that floated on Euronext Amsterdam during last years buyout boom are now languishing well below their listing prices and are fighting to address the lack of trading liquidity that has damaged their shares and scared off new investors.

title: Co-op Buys Somerfield for $3.2 Billion
description: Co-operative Group has agreed to buy rival Somerfield for 1.57 billion pounds ($3.2 billion) in a deal that will create a tougher competitor for Britains four biggest supermarket chains.

title: London Drama That Inspires a National Dialogue
description: LONDON  Some plays you feel in your muscles. Though theres plenty of artfully awkward talk in Harper Regan, Simon Stephenss arresting new drama at the National Theater here, it wasnt the words being spoken that made me conscious of the tension in my body.

title: Seeing Bad Loans, Investors Flee From Bank Shares
description: On Wall Street, the run is on. Bank stocks spun wildly on Tuesday in another bruising day for financial companies. Goaded by bearish analysts, investors seem to be abandoning American banks in droves.

title: Two Buyout-Backed Firms File for Chapter 11
description: Two private equity-backed ventures found themselves in bankruptcy court this week, The Deal reported. On Monday, Western Nonwoven, backed by a unit of Cerberus Capital Management, filed for Chapter 11 protection, followed the next day by Pierre Foods, a portfolio company of Madison Dearborn Partners.

title: UBS Creating Structure to Buy Back $3.5 Billion in Debt
description: UBS is actively developing a structure to buy back $3.5 billion worth of debt from some investors locked out of the collapsed auction-rate securities market.

title: Citis Nikko Sale: A Harbinger of Bigger Deals to Come?
description: In what could be a sign of bigger moves to come, Citigroups Nikko Citi Holdings will sell group investment firm Nikko Antfactory as soon as next month, said MarketWatch citing a report on the Web site of Japanese business daily Nikkei.

title: Sprint and SK Telecom Said to Discuss Partnership
description: Sprint Nextel, the wireless carrier, is in early talks to form a partnership with SK Telecom of South Korea to share information about mobile phones and other technology, according to people briefed on the talks.

title: AOL Talks with Microsoft or Yahoo Said to Pick Up
description: Time Warners discussions to merge or sell its AOL Internet division with Microsoft or Yahoo have taken on new urgency ahead of Yahoos Aug. 1 shareholders meeting, a source familiar with the discussions told Reuters on Tuesday.

title: An Argument for Clearer Capital Rules, Not a Fed Role
description: Writing in Wednesdays Wall Street Journal, Carnegie Mellon University professor of economics and author of A History of the Federal Reserve, Allan H. Meltzer intones, Investment banks dont need the Fed to regulate them. Some clear rules on capitalization would suffice.

title: Anger and Dismay at the Sale of a City Treasure
description: With the shades inside a tavern on Pestalozzi Street drawn to block the early morning sun, Dave Liszewski, a third-shift worker at Anheuser-Busch, nursed a bottle of Bud Light and a hollowed sense of pride.

title: Goldman Is Questioned Over Wall Street Rumors
description: Goldman Sachss chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, has reportedly received a couple of unusual phone calls recently  and the folks doing the dialing wanted to know if rumors are true about, well, rumors.

title: When I.P.O.s Dry Up
description: This year is shaping up to be a barren one for initial public offerings, much to the dismay of venture capitalists, who have fewer options for harvesting their investments, not to mention the Wall Street underwriters that are twiddling their thumbs. Investment Dealers Digest looks at the causes of the drought and its broader effects.

title: Fitch Foresees More Airline Failures in 2009
description: Rising energy prices and weak cash flow may result in multiple bankruptcies and liquidation for U.S. airlines in 2009, rating agency Fitch Ratings said on Tuesday, according to Reuters.

title: Opposition, From Both Parties, Over Bailout Plan
description: The Bush administrations plan to rescue the nations two largest mortgage finance companies ran into sharp criticism in Congress on Tuesday as some lawmakers questioned the open-ended request for money that could be used to help the companies.

title: Cleveland-Cliffs to Buy Alpha Natural for $10 Billion
description: Cleveland-Cliffs, North Americas largest producer of iron-ore pellets, agreed to buy coal mining company Alpha Natural Resources for $10 billion as demand from emerging economies pushes fuel prices to records.

title: Intelligent? See Ya!
description: The social news-sharing site Reddit has all kinds of topics you can click to customize your experience  from geek to lolcats to Ron Paul to bacon. But heres what you get when you click on intelligent:

title: Otherwise It Was Business as Usual
description: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: In a speech yesterday, Barack Obama called for African-Americans to be better parents. Obama said, Not all black children can be raised by Angelina Jolie.

title: Michael J. Fox to Return to TV on Rescue Me
description: Actor Michael J. Fox, semi-retired from show business due to Parkinsons disease, will return to television next spring as a guest star on the firefighting drama Rescue Me, the FX cable network said on Tuesday, Reuters reports.

title: William Petersen Leaving CSI
description: The Associated Press reports:

title: The Early Word: McCain Tackles Education Reform
description: The conflicts in Iraq and Afghanistan as well as the economy have dominated the discussion on the campaign trail, often eclipsing other issues. Today Senator John McCain will use a speech to the N.A.A.C.P. convention in Cincinnati to focus on a challenge that has received less air time: education.

title: Incompetence and Corruption Haunt Construction Industry
description: While crane accidents are far from routine, they have cast a spotlight on some industry flaws that have been all but habitual  job-site payoffs, union corruption and weak city oversight  at a time when New Yorks building boom has made the crane a ubiquitous presence, William K. Rashbaum reports.

title: Answers About Rent Stabilization
description: Below is a first set of answers from Joel E. Abramson, a longtime housing lawyer who answered questions from City Room readers this week about rent stabilization in New York City. We are no longer accepting questions for this feature.

title: The Best of YouTube: Barcelona, 1992
description: The 1992 Summer Olympics in Barcelona brought the return to the Games of South Africa after apartheid and a united Germany, and the final appearance of the Soviet Union, competing as the awkwardly named Unified Team.

title: Freddie Mac, When Are You Coming Back?
description: Dont bail out Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. They dont need it, writes Franklin D. Raines, the former chairman and chief executive of Fannie Mae and the director of the Office of Management and Budget in the Clinton administration, on the op-ed page of The Washington Post. He writes:

title: Living With Music: A Playlist by Camille Paglia
description: Camille Paglia is the University Professor of Humanities and Media Studies at the University of the Arts in Philadelphia and a columnist at Salon.com. Her most recent book is Break, Blow, Burn: Camille Paglia Reads 43 of the Worlds Best Poems.

title: Plugging into a Little Good Will
description: On this blog I often draw attention to bad service and service foibles, and in the comments submitted to this blog readers complain even more. So I like to try from time to time to salute and spotlight good service, as I did when I recounted the restaurant Cremas diligence in returning an iPhone accessory to a friend of mine who had left it there.

title: Mens Basketball: Canada Edges Korea to Advance
description: Canada rallied from a 16-point halftime deficit and pipped South Korea at the wire, 79-77, on Wednesday to advance to the quarterfinals of the mens Olympic basketball qualifiers.

title: Detective in Nightclub Shooting Is Restored to Full Duty
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly this morning restored to full duty an off-duty detective who shot a gunman outside a Queens nightclub. The detective had been given a breath test for alcohol after the early Sunday morning shooting, which showed that he had a blood-alcohol level of 0.09 percent, a fraction over the 0.08 legal limit for driving.

title: In Two War Dispatches, a Familiar Message
description: For those arguing for a shifting of American attention from Iraq to Afghanistan  a growing crowd these days  this mornings news provided a pair of bold story lines to follow.

title: Enlisting U.S. Brand Power in Belgium
description: As St. Louis shakes its head in disbelief over the sale of Anheuser-Busch to a Belgian beer giant, Mental Floss listed several more not-so-American brands out there, starting with Miller Brewing Company. Meanwhile, a military alliance headquartered in the same European country is trying to harness the brand-making power of the United States. NATO, which is determined to revamp its image, has hired a marketing executive from Coca-Cola, The New York Times reported today.

title: Dont Worry  Youll All Get Your Money
description: Aired Tuesday night on NBC: Before we begin, I want to thank you all for standing in line in such an orderly manner. Dont worry  youll get all your money you have deposited. Please be patient!

title: London Theater Journal: Up in Flames
description: Is flaming the new flying? Time was you couldnt go to a big West End musical without coming across some flashy flying object: a jaunty motor car, a witch, a self-satisfied nanny. But these days the producers of singing spectacles seem bent on playing with fire. A wall of fire (alternating with water) threatens to singe the eyebrows off the audience in the curtain numbers of Never Forget, the new jukebox musical built around the songs of the boy band Take That at the Savoy Theater.

title: Thats Good Enough for Me
description: Aired Tuesday night on CBS:Well, you know, were in the middle of a banking crisis. Today on television, President Bush assured Americans that he is taking steps to resolve the financial crisis. Well, thats good enough for me. Come on, lets go to the park.

title: New MoveOn Ad: Timeline
description: For all the talk about how outside groups may not play as much of a role this presidential election season as they did in the last one, the groups do seem to keep popping out new ads. Heres the latest from MoveOn, calling for a timetable for a troops withdrawal from Iraq (and relying on reports that Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki wants such a timetable) and criticizing Senator John McCain for his stated openness to a long-term, peace-time, American troop presence in Iraq.

title: A Promising Start for a D.J.-Turned-Chat-Show-Host
description: The ratings for a debut episode arent always indicative of a shows eventual success, but the producers of The Wendy Williams Show must be feeling good about their first-day Nielsen numbers.

title: Wells Fargo Sits High in the Saddle
description: John Stumpf is sounding confident  which is quite a rarity for a banking chief these days.

description: How Yeats was inspired to write his poem. Video is from the exhibit at the National Library of Ireland. (Produced by Martello Media)

description: Sigh. Lets go through this one  more  time, a reporter at McClatchys Washington bureau began a blog post. It was time to counter claims last week that the removal of hundreds of tons of natural uranium from Iraqs main nuclear site proved that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction:

title: The Blossoming of Original Shows on Cable
description: When the police drama The Shield debuted on FX in 2002, it became the No. 1 series on basic cable. It was the impetus for many other basic cable networks to improve their original programming, said John Landgraf, the president of FX, at the Television Critics Association press tour on Tuesday.

title: New York on $5 or $500 a Day
description: What were looking at on the Web today

title: Saving Medicare
description: So Congress has overridden Bushs veto on the Medicare bill. This is huge news. As I tried to explain last week, its not really about maintaining doctors payments  some fudge would have been found to avoid drastic cuts. Its about rolling back Medicare privatization  and its a big win for reformers against the insurance companies.

title: An Assault on Decency
description: Public reaction was fast and furious to a surveillance video shown last year on local news broadcasts in New York City. It showed a 101-year-old woman on a walker battered and bloodied in the vestibule of her apartment building by a mugger who made off with $33 and a set of house keys. Who could watch the attack on Rose Morat, headed home from church in broad daylight, and not think of their own mother or grandmother? She was gritty, good-humored  and boy, did she look good for her age.

title: A Classic Racetrack Gets a Makeover
description: LAKEVILLE, CONN.  Last Saturday, the American Le Mans Series raced at Lime Rock Park, as it had the year before and the year before that.

title: 4 Are Charged With Child Welfare Fraud
description: Updated, 1:15 p.m. | The United States attorneys office in Manhattan plans to announce this afternoon the arrests of four people  two officials of the Administration for Childrens Services, one employee of a nonprofit foster care agency in Brooklyn and one independent contractor who had his office in that agency  on charges that prosecutors say stem from the embezzlement of money intended to assist needy children.

title: TV Background Noise Disrupts Child Play
description: Many parents watch the news or other shows as children play nearby. But new research shows that even when the television is just background noise, it may be disruptive to a childs normal development.

title: Vets Ad: Finish the Job in Iraq
description: The advocacy group, Vets for Freedom, is hitting the airwaves with a new television commercial today, part of its $1.5 million general election advertising and grassroots push touting the Bush administrations Iraq policy.

title: Boom Bust
description: Mick Sussmans fascinating post yesterday about the prices of used books sent me scurrying to do a little research of my own. Since Mick had me thinking about the vagaries of market valuation, and since the stock market closed below 11,000 yesterday on continued worries about housing and inflation, I headed to Amazon and shot fish in a barrel: I looked for Dow 36,000, the 2000 book by James Glassman and Kevin Hassett that was seen as propagandistic hype even when it was published, at the height of the tech bubble. On the day it was released, the Dow closed at 10,681.06. Thats essentially the same as yesterdays close, and substantially higher once you adjust for inflation. So theres a little thrill of schadenfreude in seeing that used copies of the book are available starting at 47 cents.

title: Burger Chefs
description: Could it be that Daniel Boulud and Laurent Tourondel succeeded where McDonalds failed?

title: The Next Candidate: You
description: Oh, man, I was laughing so hard at the cleverness of this Web video.

title: Energy Action From Bottom Up: Kansas City, Scouts, Buses
description: I just finished a Skype video chat with about 80 people from the new Climate Protection Partnership within the Greater Kansas City Chamber of Commerce. Over 150 companies, with something like 100,000 employees, have joined the group, which is committed to reducing greenhouse-gas emissions from the metropolitan region of some 2 million people. The session provided fresh evidence that progress on curbing energy demand and greenhouse gases may well come from the bottom up before it comes from the top down. The evidence cited by a participant involved Girl Scouts and school buses. Whats happening around your dot that gives you hope, or concern?

title: Recipe of the Day: Basic Grilled or Broiled Butterflied Leg of Lamb
description: I cannot possibly write about grilling lamb  as I do in todays Minimalist column  without including this all-time favorite. As I point out in the column, shoulder is the best cut of lamb for skewering; its fattiness keeps it moist. But for a big, impressive piece of meat, you cant beat boneless leg. And because of its uneven thickness, you can get rare, medium, and even well-done meat on the same piece; and even well-cooked lamb is delicious.

title: Water Polo Diary: And Now, Introducing Our Veterans
description: Betsey Armstrong is the goalkeeper for the U.S.A. womens water polo team, which is favored to win the gold medal in the Olympics this summer. Armstrong is an Ann Arbor, Mich., native and a 2005 Michigan graduate who helped Team U.S.A. win gold at the 2007 Pan American Games. title: Tracing Family Roots in Vilnius
description: In much of Europe, the Old Town is the only town that matters. Centuries-old stone houses, crammed into shoulder-width alleyways that swerve at random and wind uphill toward ancient churches dedicated to forgotten saints  this is, to many of us, what Europe is all about. But Old Towns often give me pause: Will the quaintness mask a lack of vitality? Is it a museum for tourists, or a place where locals live, work and play? And if the Old Town is boring, will the New Town  the less-densely populated, less charming sprawl outside the medieval city walls  be any better?

title: Goodbye Ghosts, Hello Hefty Price Tag

The original stadium, as we learned over the long course of the evening, was erected around 2000 B.C. and for many years served as a sacred burial ground and an astronomical calendar. Oh, sorry. Thats Stonehenge. In any case, the Yankee Stadium of all those sepia-toned montages was the old Yankee Stadium, predating the extensive renovation in the mid-1970s. The old Yankee Stadium was a very different place. It did not have instant replay, Moonie weddings or Reggie Jackson.

title: All-Star Game Proves to Be a Hit
description: Major League Baseballs 2008 All-Star Game, which lasted a record-tying 15 innings, led Tuesday nights television ratings by a wide margin. Although the game didnt end until 1:37 a.m. Eastern time, Nielsens time-zone-adjusted estimates show the first three hours of Foxs live broadcast drew an average of 14.5 million viewers during prime time, 2 million more than a year ago and the games best result in six years. NBC was runner-up, thanks largely to Americas Got Talent, which attracted 12.5 million viewers at 9 p.m., more than twice the audience for CBSs Big Brother in the hour (6.1 million). NBC also earned a modest 7.9 million for Celebrity Family Feud at 8 and 6.3 million for a rerun of Law & Order: Special Victims Unit at 10. Among adults 18 to 49, however, NBC trailed ABC, whose new series Wipeout continued to fare well in the 8 p.m. hour (8.5 million). Later in the night ABCs I Survived a Japanese Game Show lagged behind with 5.8 million viewers at 9, while ABCs Primetime: Family Secrets delivered 7 million at 10. CBS was fourth overall, faring best during the 8 p.m. hour with a repeat of NCIS (7.7 million).

The soundtrack to Disneys Camp Rock featuring the Jonas Brothers keeps the No. 3 spot with 88,000 copies. Becks Modern Guilt (Interscope) sold 84,000 to debut at No. 4 while Kid Rocks Rock N Roll Jesus (Atlantic) climbs two spots to No. 5 with 61,000 copies. The soundtrack to the film Mamma Mia! title: Lamps With the Virtuous Glow of Recycled Plastic
description: Heath Nashs recycled plastic lamps are much harder to make than youd think, he said. Im working with as many as seven different colors, in two layers, that have to be arranged to get the right translucency in the right place, while balancing the colors. Mr. Nash, who lives in Cape Town, was inspired to create the lamps after meeting a Zimbabwean man named Robert Mondongwe who made flowers out of plastic bottles. The flowers, Mr. Nash thought, were the design element he had been searching for, because they looked and felt like a South African product. The lamps, which he hired Mr. Mondongwe to help him produce, come in multicolored and all-white plastic, left, and range in price from $450 to $4,950. Each one takes as long as three months to make, because every component, from the wires to the flowers, is handmade. Available at Amaridian, 31 Howard Street (Crosby Street), (917) 463-3719 or amaridianusa.com.
