title: Greys Anatomy Will Keep Heigl
description: Katherine Heigl, below, will remain on Greys Anatomy next season, despite speculation that she wanted to free herself from her commitment to the series, Stephen McPherson, the president of ABC Entertainment, said Wednesday. Ms. Heigl, 29, who plays the resident Izzie on the medical drama, said last month that she had removed herself from the running for an Emmy nomination because she felt she was not given the material this season to warrant one. The comment fueled talk that Ms. Heigl, a star of Knocked Up and 27 Dresses, wanted to leave the show to pursue movie projects. On Wednesday Mr. McPherson called the turmoil unfortunate but dismissed talk that she would leave the cast. Theres an unbelievable story line for her this year, which is really central to everything thats going to go on this season, he said. Greys Anatomy ranked among the Top 10 shows last season, with an average of 15.6 million viewers.

title: A Big Party Without the Guest of Honor
description: FLINT, Mich.  A 100th birthday party, one would think, is cause for special celebration.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Representative Charles B. Rangels defense of his use of four rent-stabilized apartments in Harlem, and a correction in this space on Wednesday, omitted the source of an assertion about actions that Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington, a government watchdog group, is taking in the case. CongressDailyPM, a news service that covers Capitol Hill, reported last Friday that the watchdog group planned to ask the House ethics committee to examine whether Mr. Rangels arrangement violated a ban on members accepting gifts of more than $100, and also planned to file a complaint with the Federal Election Commission. Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics confirmed those plans early this week.

title: Gore Calls for Carbon-Free Electric Power
description: WASHINGTON  Former Vice President Al Gore said on Thursday that Americans must abandon electricity generated by fossil fuels within a decade and rely on the sun, the winds and other environmentally friendly sources of power, or risk losing their national security as well as their creature comforts.

title: Digging in to That Antiquarian Funk
description: The French band Les Primitifs du Futur comes at you with a wink. To call its music cartoonish isnt so misleading. It incorporates a saw and a theremin; several kinds of extinct romanticism involving the accordion; the sweet, high clank of a xylophone; and a stout alto saxophonist who plays as if he were born in 1900 and scat-sings with a bravado that spills over into comedy. The band was also co-founded 22 years ago by the American expatriate Robert Crumb, who sees the world as a cartoon.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about complaints by customers who bought works of art, like prints attributed to Salvador Dal, at auctions aboard cruise ships misstated the year in which Albert Field, a Dal expert, died. It was 2003, not 1998.

title: Pope Warns on Environment
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Pope Benedict XVI used his first major address at the Roman Catholic Churchs youth festival here on Thursday to warn that the world was being scarred and its natural resources used up by humanitys insatiable consumption.

title: Intrigue on an Ill-Fated Train, Moscow-Bound
description: Transsiberian is a handsomely remodeled variation of a cherished genre you might call the mystery-train movie. Updated by the director Brad Anderson (The Machinist), who wrote the screenplay with Will Conroy, it skillfully manipulates familiar tropes: innocents abroad, ominous glowering foreigners, conspiracy and duplicity, erotic intrigue. Until it fizzles in an anticlimactic train crash, it is extremely entertaining.

title: Where Cowboy Hats Meet Birkenstocks
description: JAMES A. MANGUM and his wife, Sidney Spires, stopped into Marathon, Tex., last September while researching Mr. Mangums third western-themed novel, Stalking Azazel. That night, they met a group of Marathoners gathered around a residents outdoor pizza oven, drinking beer and watching the sun set behind the Del Norte Mountains. Two weeks later, they bought a $60,000, 600-square-foot cottage next door.

title: Plucky Apes Help to Save the Planet of the Humans
description: Journalism is all about having the courage to write the truth even if it will get you mocked by your relatives and co-workers, so here goes: Space Chimps is hilarious.

title: An Emperors Art: Small, Refined, Jewel Toned
description: WASHINGTON  Muraqqa is the Persian term for a patched garment traditionally worn by Sufi mystics as a sign of poverty and humility. Yet it is also the word for a gilded and lavishly calligraphed album. This type of muraqqa, a luxury object from the Mughal empire in India, is a patchwork of imagery: portraits of emperors and courtiers, Eastern mystics and Western religious figures; examples of plant and animal life.

title: Jumby Bay Estate Homes and Icon Brickell
description: Jumby Bay Estate Homes

title: Chief Struggles to Revive Merrill Lynch
description: John A. Thain never said that turning around Merrill Lynch would be easy. We have not seen the bottom, he declared in December, when he took the reins of the troubled Wall Street giant.

title: Oils Decline Pulls Stocks in Tokyo Lower
description: Most Japanese stocks fell on Friday, led by oil explorers after crude prices fell to a one-month low. Brokerage firms and banks gained amid confidence that they would fare better than their rivals in the United States and Europe.

title: Defrauded Fund Investors Sue Goldman
description: Samuel Israel III bilked his investors out of $250 million, but they are hoping to recoup some of their money from one of Wall Streets deepest pockets: Goldman Sachs.

title: A Daughter of Indias Underclass Rises on Votes That Cross Caste Lines
description: LUCKNOW, India  Kumari Mayawati, a daughter of so-called untouchables and Indias most maverick politician, stunned the nation last year when she won majority control of Indias largest state with an inventive political coalition that fused votes from up and down the ancient Hindu caste pyramid.

title: Got a Fix? Please, Call the Fed
description: BERGEN, Norway  If only Americans were more like Norwegians.

title: Boom Times Take Root in Dubai
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Bathed in the glow of the skylines glitter, the centerpiece of Dubais financial hub seems equal to the thrusting ambitions of the foreign investment bankers rushing to set up shop here.

title: House Republicans Block Democratic Effort on Oil Leases, Calling the Bill a Sham
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans on Thursday blocked a Democratic effort to pressure energy companies into drilling for oil on lands they already leased from the federal government, calling the legislation a sham.

title: Electrical Risks at Iraq Bases Are Worse Than Said
description: WASHINGTON  Shoddy electrical work by private contractors on United States military bases in Iraq is widespread and dangerous, causing more deaths and injuries from fires and shocks than the Pentagon has acknowledged, according to internal Army documents.

title: A River Perch Where Words Flow
description: JOHN CASEY was navigating the Delaware River alone when he sighted a cabin on the bank of the Milford, Pa., side. I remember going by in a canoe and saying, I want that,  said Mr. Casey, a novelist and professor of English at the University of Virginia in Charlottesville.

title: Google Earnings Are Below Forecasts, and Shares Fall
description: SAN FRANCISCO Google, the search giant, gave an uncharacteristic disappointment to investors on Thursday, failing to meet at least some of Wall Streets expectations for its second-quarter performance.

title: Rule, Britannia, but Maybe Not Over Scotland
description: LONDON  Stuck in a chronic sports slump, Britons are eternally searching for a homegrown tennis star with a fighting chance of winning Wimbledon. Their latest was 21-year-old Andy Murray, who earlier this summer demonstrated traditional British come-from-behind pluck in advancing to the quarterfinals. (He lost to the eventual champion, Rafael Nadal.)

title: Morgan Reports a Drop of 53% in Quarterly Net
description: JPMorgan Chase said Thursday that its second-quarter income dropped 53 percent, as credit card and home loan losses spread to borrowers with the strongest credit histories.

title: Argentina Blocks Farm Export Tax
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Argentinas Senate narrowly rejected the agricultural export tax increases that caused a nationwide farmer rebellion when the countrys vice president sided with agriculture producers early Thursday and cast the deciding vote against the measure.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the expectation of wind and rain at the British Open misidentified the location in Scotland where Ernie Els, who is playing in the tournament, won amid similar conditions in 2002. It was Muirfield, not Turnberry.

title: Tales From Divided Berlin, Where Angst Ate the Soul
description: In Julian Schnabels grimly majestic concert film Lou Reeds Berlin, Mr. Reed wears the deadpan smirk of a Zen master who has endured unusually punishing Buddhist training. His look isnt that of a blissed-out monk newly returned from mountaintop meditations. It is the grimly amused seen-it-all stare of a voyeuristic chronicler of drug-fueled sadomasochistic rituals in the grittier corners of cities that never sleep. This is the real world, Mr. Reed seems to signal, while strumming tough minimalist riffs on his guitar and singing in a quavering, gravelly monotone: Get used to it, boys and girls.

title: In Thailand, Two Lovers Among a Tsunamis Ruins
description: Everything is, for a good long while, very nice indeed in Wonderful Town. Written and directed by Aditya Assarat, this lucid debut unfolds in a comfy patch of southern Thailand nestled in a lush green valley near the sea. Takua Pa, the place is called, and a woman named Na (Anchalee Saisoontorn) calls it home.

title: Homes Data Gets a Lift, by a Fluke
description: Permits and groundbreakings for new homes unexpectedly rose in June after a months-long downturn in residential construction, the government said Thursday.

title: Two Acts With One Favorite Pastime
description: Fat pillows of viscous smoke reflected in the spotlights as Snoop Dogg took the stage on Wednesday night at Keyspan Park at Coney Island. Anybody smoke chronic? he asked, avuncularly.

title: Joseph McCrindle, 85, Connoisseur of Art, Is Dead
description: Joseph F. McCrindle, an art collector who amassed a trove of old master drawings and who founded and edited the Transatlantic Review to showcase young writers, died July 11 at his home in Manhattan. He was 85.

title: Winfield and Steinbrenner and Reconciling the Past
description: The Hall of Famers son, 13 years old and over 6 feet tall and with a strikingly familiar face, shagged flies in the Home Run Derby on Monday night at Yankee Stadium. He rode in the Sixth Avenue parade of baseball legends and heard fans call out his fathers name, which happens to be his name, too. He went into the Yankees clubhouse and was shown where the old man dressed.

title: Comings and Goings for Old Faces
description: WASHINGTON  During the four years he spent as President Bushs body man, or personal aide, Blake Gottesman acquired an eclectic set of job skills. He emerged from the experience schooled at reading presidential moods, expert at handling Mr. Bushs Scottish terrier Barney, and adept at carting around the mundane necessities of presidential life, including Sharpies for autograph-signing, hand sanitizer for shooing away germs and money to pay the rare restaurant tab.

title: Radioheads Google Experiment
description: No lights, no camera, but there was action when Radiohead collaborated with Google to promote its latest video. For its song House of Cards off the album In Rainbows, the band made a video using lasers and computer data but not cameras or lights. Google is presenting the video, right, on its site (code.google.com/radiohead) as well as offering fans a short film to show how it was made. The search engine is also allowing amateur developers to download some of the data and create their own variation of the video under a license that allows remixes. According to Google, 64 lasers rotating and shooting landscapes in a 360-degree radius 900 times per minute produced all the exterior scenes in the video, which also uses 3-D technology. Radiohead released the In Rainbows album online in October as a pay-what-you-want digital download.

title: Mediate Starts Strong at British Open
description: SOUTHPORT, England  The wind roared and the rain poured on the opening round of the 137th British Open, but neither could stop golfs improbable feel-good story from crossing eight time zones, the Atlantic, and an ocean of improbability to land atop the leader board at the worlds oldest major championship.

title: In Boston Harbor, but a World Away
description: BY many measures, the view from the arched doorway of the cobblestone home on Bumpkin Island, off the Massachusetts coast, has most likely not changed much since the 19th century, when hay farmers lived there.

title: Rangel to Ask Ethics Panel for Inquiry to Clear Him
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Charles B. Rangel said on Thursday that he would ask the House ethics committee to look into whether he had violated any rules by using a Congressional letterhead to raise money for a new educational center at City College that was named after him.

title: Yankees Nearing Deal With Sexson
description: The Yankees have reached a preliminary agreement with Richie Sexson and hope he can help them against left-handed pitchers. Sexson, a first baseman who was released July 10 by the Seattle Mariners, was batting .344 with 5 home runs in 71 at-bats against left-handers this season.

title: Watsons Experience With Wind Pays Off
description: SOUTHPORT, England  Tom Watson demonstrated once again just how important experience and golf course savvy are when confronted with British Open conditions that mystified many younger golfers on Thursday.

title: In Urban Wilderness, Tracking Hoots in the Night
description: ONE night in Central Park, when the screech owls were teaching their babies how to fly, a group of birders were scanning the canopy of a white oak tree at the Loch, the stream that meanders through Frederick Law Olmsteds designed wilderness.

title: Cry the High-Minded Hero in Brutal Japanese-Occupied Manchuria
description: In keeping with the grandeur of its title, The Human Condition, adapted by Masaki Kobayashi from Jumpei Gomikawas six-volume novel, is anything but modest in scope and ambition. First released in Japan, in three parts, between 1959 and 1961, the film is a sprawling, crowded 10-hour epic of love, war, heroism and cruelty. Shot in a wide-screen format called Grandscope and set mainly in Manchuria during the Japanese occupation, it seems intent on leaving nothing out. Mountains, forest, marshlands; marriage, combat, hard labor; the call of duty and the obligations of conscience  that over-reaching title turns out to be a pretty fair description of whats on screen.

title: Crime and Journalism
description: Embedded for three years with the notorious Noonan crime family in Manchester, England, the journalist Donal MacIntyre  the British answer to Geraldo Rivera  became a willing conduit for the outsize egos and self-serving confessions of its members.

title: Federal Report Finds Poor Conditions at Cook County Jail
description: CHICAGO  People awaiting trial here at the Cook County Jail, one of the nations largest local jails, have endured vastly inadequate medical care, beatings at the hands of jail workers and dilapidated, dangerous building conditions often left unrepaired for months, federal authorities said on Thursday.

title: A Town Is as Divided as Favre and the Packers
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  A sign near the front door of Brett Favres Steakhouse here reads Thanks, Boss 4 a great career. All of the blocky white letters are neatly aligned, reflecting none of the chaos that has consumed this town for the past few weeks.

title: I.B.M. Income Rose 22%, Beating Forecasts
description: SAN FRANCISCO  I.B.M. reported Thursday that its net income rose 22 percent in the second quarter to $2.77 billion, or $1.98 cents a share, from the quarter a year-ago quarter.

title: No Friend of the Workers
description: It should surprise no one, at this point, that an arm of the Bush administration charged with protecting Americans rights or safety is not doing its job. Even so, a government report and a Congressional hearing this week painted a disturbing picture of a Labor Department that simply is not standing up for workers.

title: Little-Known Arbiter of Regency Taste Was a Man of the World
description: The name Thomas Hope may not be familiar, but his furniture designs are: American craftsmen have been reinterpreting Hope prototypes  in the neoclassical style known as English Regency  for 200 years. His life and work are examined in an exhibition that opened this week at the Bard Graduate Center in Manhattan.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Looser Olympic Security in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  With three weeks until the start of the Olympics, Beijing officials are imposing increasingly stringent security rules there while Hong Kong, the host of all six Olympic equestrian events, is promising a more relaxed approach.

title: Sacramone Is Still Waiting for That Call
description: NEW WAVERLY, Tex.  This week, for what she said feels like the millionth time, Alicia Sacramone headed to Martha and Bela Karolyis ranch, the home of the training center for the womens gymnastics national team.

title: Funerals in Israel for Two Soldiers
description: JERUSALEM  With solemn speeches and military salutes, thousands of mourners on Thursday buried the two Israeli soldiers whose remains were returned in a long-awaited exchange with the Lebanese militia Hezbollah on Wednesday.

title: Senate Democrats Gain Ground in Search for Campaign Cash
description: ALBANY  Senate Democrats are in their strongest financial position in years as they set out to win control of the chamber this fall, campaign finance reports filed this week show.

title: An Old-World Feel on the St. Lawrence
description: QUEBEC CITY celebrates its 400th anniversary this year. Founded in 1608 as Kebec (Algonquin for place where the river narrows) by Samuel de Champlain, Quebec City was the first permanent French settlement in North America.

title: Warning on Tomatoes Is Withdrawn
description: The Food and Drug Administration revoked its warning against eating certain kinds of raw tomatoes on Thursday, even though officials said they had yet to pinpoint the source of the nations largest food-borne outbreak of illness in the last decade.

title: 19 Stories Below Manhattan, a 640-Ton Machine Drills a New Train Tunnel
description: Apparently, you dont need a windshield to drive through a rock wall.

title: Taking America Seriously
description: To the Editor:

title: Tour de France Team Out After Test
description: NARBONNE, France  The Tour de France, already diminished by the absence of some of the worlds best cyclists because of doping violations, was thrown into turmoil yet again Thursday when an Italian rider who had won two stages of this years race was kicked out of the competition for failing a drug test.

title: Giants Seat Licenses Priced From $1,000 to $20,000
description: The Giants laid out on Thursday the prices for personal seat licenses in the teams new stadium, a roster of one-time fees that start at $1,000 each for 26,179 upper-deck seats and rise to $20,000 apiece for 4,162 lower-level field seats.

title: First Flights: Getting a Big-City Start in Birding
description: With its acres of asphalt and roaring traffic, New York City might not seem like an especially good place for novice bird-watchers to hone their skills. On the contrary, experienced birders say, the city is one of the best spots in the world to observe birds, and its density of avian life can make learning to find and identify them easy.

title: Where Tourists Roam, a Port of Call Snags an Angler
description: KINGS WHARF, Bermuda  Only a fool would cast a fishing lure from the ninth-floor balcony of an anchored 923-foot cruise ship. But when a pack of voracious jacks explodes under a school of bait  even if it is 70 vertical feet to the water  the temptation can be too much.

title: East End Farmers Market Sold, With a Zabar Picked to Run It
description: The Amagansett Farmers Market, a fixture on eastern Long Island for more than half a century, has been sold and will be operated by Eli Zabar, Mr. Zabar said on Thursday.

title: Dance Move at the Library
description: The dance division at New York Public Library has announced a new step for one of its curators. Jan Schmidt has been appointed curator of the Jerome Robbins Dance Division at the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, the library announced. Ms. Schmidt, who served most recently as acting curator, began her career at the library in 1989 as a specialist in the dance division. Since then she has produced original documentations of hundreds of dance performances by companies and artists like New York City Ballet, Dance Theater of Harlem, Martha Graham Dance Company, American Ballet Theater and Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, and she has worked to preserve dance on film and acquire archive materials.

title: A Women Only Restroom Renovation Tips the Balance at Grand Central
description: Feminist lore is full of stories of the times when womens rooms were lacking  near the United States Senate floor until the 1990s, near the House floor until the 1960s, in the Supreme Court justice robing room until 1993. But now the dynamic has flipped, at least in a quaint little nook of Grand Central Terminal.

title: As Price of Grain Rises, Catfish Farms Dry Up
description: LELAND, Miss.  Catfish farmers across the South, unable to cope with the soaring cost of corn and soybean feed, are draining their ponds.

title: Cholesterol Drugs for Children? 3 Perspectives
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.A. Lifts Tomato Warning
description: The Food and Drug Administration revoked its warning against eating certain kinds of raw tomatoes Thursday, even though officials said they had yet to pinpoint the source of the nations largest foodborne outbreak in the last decade.

title: 4 Cleared in Madrid Train Bombing
description: MADRID  A Spanish court overturned the convictions of four men and upheld the acquittal of a fifth on Thursday in the convoluted legal proceedings relating to the 2004 Madrid commuter train bombings that killed 191 people in the deadliest attacks by Islamic militants on European soil.

title: For Rangers, First Stop on Schedule Is Prague
description: A revamped Rangers team will play its home opener against the nearly-as-retooled Chicago Blackhawks on Oct. 10, after opening the season with two games against the Tampa Bay Lightning in Prague on Oct. 4 and 5.

title: France: Gaz and Suez to Merge
description: The French government issued a decree allowing for the privatization of Gaz de France, enabling the utility to merge with Suez and form one of the largest utilities in the world. The new law allows for the transfer into the private sector of the majority stake held by the state in Gaz de France. Shareholders of Gaz de France and Suez approved the merger Wednesday, almost two and a half years after it was first announced by the French government. The move is scheduled to take effect July 22 when GDF Suez and Suez Environnement begin publicly trading. Some 65 percent of Suez Environnement is being spun off to existing Suez shareholders who own the unit.

title: Deal Seeks to Offer Drug for Malaria at Low Price
description: The Clinton Foundation announced Thursday that it had brokered an agreement among several drug makers that it hoped would ensure a steady supply of a crucial malaria medicine at reasonable prices for the worlds poor.

title: The Nightmare Disbelief of a Prisoner Under Siege
description: Forget Oz, the soft-core S&M soap opera on Home Box Office, which pretended to offer an authentic portrayal of life behind bars. The high-security mens prison in Felon is the real thing. Here is where Wade Porter (Stephen Dorff), a decent, hardworking builder with his own construction crew, lands after accidentally killing a man and discovers a world in which unimaginable brutality has free rein.

title: Drawing New Strength From Older Power Sources
description: DURHAM, N.C.  Laura Deans Tympani came at the end of the American Dance Festivals packed Past/Forward program on Wednesday night: four choreographers, two-plus hours and a wealth of modern dance history. Fatigue had begun to set in, and the thought of plunging into another theatrical creation was daunting.

title: Summer Wind
description: For the past few hours, the wind has been rising and falling, the precursor of a storm coming in from the west. When the wind climbs, a kind of elation blows through the house  its the hushing sound of the leaves outside and the way the breeze sweeps the floors and lifts the curtains and slams the doors. The dogs snap to and look around when it gusts. And when the wind drops, it seems to drop us  the dogs and me  into the trough of an ordinary summer day.

title: Paris Hustler Past His Prime Takes Stock
description: Jacques Nolots film Before I Forget begins with the image of a blank screen with a small dot at the center that slowly expands into a round black hole, a stark image of the void that looms more prominently as we age.

title: Cooling Off on Dubious Eco-Friendly Claims
description: PARIS

title: Canada: Barrick Bids for Cadence
description: The Barrick Gold Corporation, the worlds largest gold producer, raised its bid for the oil and natural gas explorer Cadence Energy by 13 percent to widen its advantage over a competing bid. The all-cash offer of 410 million Canadian dollars ($409 million), or 6.75 Canadian dollars a share, was submitted to Cadences board, Barrick said. Barrick, based in Toronto, said on July 14 that it had proposed an all-cash offer of 354 million Canadian dollars. The competing bid came from Daylight Resources Trust, which offered 301 million Canadian dollars for Cadence on May 26. Cadence and Daylight Resources are both based in Calgary.

title: 134 Miles of Yankee Charm
description: GREEN hills, a rocky coast and white-steepled Colonial towns  thats the definition of southern New England, and every summer traffic thickens as travelers swarm in search of it. The territory is small and the crowds are dense, yet still some of the loveliest spots in Connecticut, Rhode Island and southern Massachusetts somehow elude the crush and remain known only to insiders.

title: Its the Summer of Lyles Discontent
description: SOUTHPORT, England  It seemed understandable on the first day of the British Open that Boo Weekley, a Floridian who grew up in steamy climes near the Gulf of Mexico, was feeling out of his element.

title: Starbucks to Close 11 Stores in New York by Mid-2009
description: Starbucks said on Thursday that 11 of the 600 coffee shops it planned to shut by mid-2009 would be in New York City. Still, those closings would leave New Yorkers with 225 Starbucks to choose from.

title: Lottery Numbers
Their Camp, Our Getaway
description: THE first year we brought a child to summer camp on Lake Winnipesaukee in New Hampshire, in 1994, we had no idea where we actually were, or where our daughter, then 12, was going.

title: A Madman Is Loose (and Hes the Good Guy)
description: If the insanely inventive and entertaining Mad Detective werent so weird  and in Cantonese  hordes of action geeks would be lining the block to see it. Jointly directed by that one-man Hong Kong film factory Johnnie To and his periodic collaborator Wai Ka Fai (who wrote the kinky screenplay with Au Kin Yee), it turns on the kind of gimmick  a detective whos daft, clairvoyant or both  that could have been cooked up by Quinn Martin, the television genius who, with hit 1970s shows like Cannon, stoked the vogue for the kind of off-the-beat, quirk-ridden private eyes that are still clogging network TV and basic cable.

title: Solar Energy Projects
description: To the Editor:

title: New Offshore Bank Limits for U.S. Clients, UBS Says
description: WASHINGTON  Faced with a federal investigation into its private banking practices, the Swiss banking giant UBS said on Thursday that it would stop offering offshore banking services to clients in the United States.

title: Wistful Singer, Jo Stafford, Is Dead at 90
description: Jo Stafford, the wistful singing voice of the American home front during World War II and the Korean War, died on Wednesday at her home in Century City, Calif. She was 90.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 10 about the growing market for perfume in China misstated the title of Luciano Bertinelli, who distributes fragrances in China with the help of a local partner, and also misspelled part of the name of his company. He is chief executive and managing director, not just managing director, and the company is Salvatore Ferragamo Parfums, not Perfums. A researcher for The New York Times Magazine discovered the errors last week.

title: In the Berkshires, Some Heavy Hitters, Some Smaller Sluggers
description: GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass.  Theater festivals are a major summertime magnet in the Berkshires, especially the big four: the Williamstown Theater Festival, Shakespeare & Company, the Barrington Stage Company and the Berkshire Theater Festival. Those events drew more than 150,000 people in 2007; thousands more caught performances at smaller locations. Add in the audiences at museums in Williamstown and North Adams, dance at Jacobs Pillow and concerts at Tanglewood, and cultural attractions are estimated to have brought in $100 million to Berkshire County here last year.

title: Rise Seen in Medical Efforts to Treat the Very Old
description: When Hazel Homer was 99, more than one doctor advised that there was little to be done about her failing heart except wait for it to fail a final time. But Mrs. Homer was not interested in waiting to die of what many would call old age.

title: U.S. Considers Opening a Diplomatic Post in Iran
description: PARIS  The Bush administration is considering establishing an American diplomatic presence in Iran for the first time since relations were severed during the 444-day occupation of the American Embassy in Tehran nearly three decades ago, European and American officials said on Thursday.

title: That Old Lady in Dubuque Is Smarter Than You Think
description: You know, they even get it in Dubuque.

title: Using Bombs to Stave Off War
description: Li-On, Israel

title: Obama Raises $52 Million in June, Keeping Campaign on Pace to Its Goal
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obamas campaign said Thursday that it collected $52 million in June, the second-best fund-raising month of the year, through an aggressive mix of small and large contributions that produced more than twice the amount raised by Senator John McCain.

title: Paul Byard, 68, Dies; Architect Renovated Landmarks
description: Paul Spencer Byard, a land-use lawyer who returned to school in his late 30s to be an architect and who became an important figure in the renovation of some of New Yorks most prominent landmarks, died on Tuesday at his home in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. He was 68.

title: U.S. Businessman Questioned in Olmert Corruption Case
description: JERUSALEM  Lawyers for Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel began their cross-examination on Thursday of a Long Island businessman and fund-raiser at the heart of a corruption case involving Mr. Olmert, trying to chip away at the witnesss credibility and taking aim at the state prosecutors and police.

title: Boy-Band Manager Ordered to Repay $300 Million
description: Boy bands have returned  the Backstreet Boys are on tour and the New Kids on the Block are soon to be  but a former manager of such groups is not so lucky. Lou Pearlman has been ordered to pay $300 million in restitution to the victims of his decades-long investment fraud, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Pearlman, who is serving a 25-year sentence, may not have the funds to pay the order the judge asked lawyers on Wednesday to draw up. Investigators have been unable to recover many assets from Mr. Pearlman, who pleaded guilty in March to charges of money laundering and conspiracy. Mr. Pearlman is the former manager of the Backstreet Boys and N Sync.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about plans by the nonprofit Second Stage Theater to buy a Broadway house, the Helen Hayes, misstated the capacity of the theater. It can hold up to 597 seats, not 499. The article also misstated the relationship that Roundabout Theater Company, another nonprofit, has with the American Airlines Theater. The company leases the theater; it does not own it. (The Roundabout does own another Broadway stage, Studio 54.) And because of an editing error, the article misidentified the theater where Xanadu is now playing. It is at the Helen Hayes, not the Marquis Theater.

title: Police Fatally Shoot Man on Upper East Side
description: A police officer responding to a complaint about a dispute on a quiet block of the Upper East Side shot and killed a man on Thursday night, after the man left the apartment armed with a knife and refused officers demand that he drop it, the authorities said on Friday.

title: More Kids Dying
description: Despite a decline in overall drug use, the rate at which young Americans between the ages of 15 and 24 have been dying from drug overdoses has jumped dramatically  more than doubling between 1999 and 2005. In the same period, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, accidental poisoning deaths in this age group, mostly drug overdoses, have jumped from 849 to 2,355.

title: The Pain Beneath the Pounds
description: A struggling anorexic and her physical opposite form an unlikely friendship in disFIGURED, a funny, awkward and often uncomfortable drama eager to confront the pain beneath the pounds.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 5 about the entrepreneurs who envision the comeback of the dirigible misidentified the country of origin of the CycloCrane, a semirigid airship that was envisioned as a cargo hauler. It was the United States, not Germany. The article also referred incorrectly to the gas used in the Hindenburg zeppelin, which burned and crashed in Lakehurst, N.J., in 1937. While it was designed to use helium, the Hindenburg flew with hydrogen from the beginning because of an American embargo on helium. It did not switch from helium to hydrogen.

title: Paterson, at N.A.A.C.P., Warns of Racisms Power
description: CINCINNATI  David A. Paterson, in his first major speech to a national audience since becoming governor of New York, said on Thursday that even as black Americans rejoice about the possibility that Senator Barack Obama could become president, they cannot lose sight of the serious social and economic ills that plague their community and should remain mindful of the racism that still exists.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about Tom Watsons rich history at the British Open misspelled, in some editions, the name of the course at Turnberry in Scotland where he defeated Jack Nicklaus in 1977. It is the Ailsa Course, not Ailso.

title: A Seat at the Table
description: We welcome the news that President Bush has decided to send one of his top diplomats to talks on Irans nuclear program. That is quite a change from just a few months ago when Mr. Bush denounced as appeasement any effort to talk to terrorists and radicals.

title: France: LOral Cuts Sales Forecast
description: LOral, the cosmetics maker, said 2008 sales would be lower than it projected after second-quarter growth was the slowest in more than three years. Sales in the three months ended June 30 increased 1 percent to 4.29 billion euros ($6.8 billion) from 4.25 billion euros a year earlier as consumer spending faltered in the United States and Western Europe, the company said. Cosmetics sales fell 1.3 percent in Western Europe and 5.8 percent in North America. LOral , based in Paris, forecast sales growth of more than 6 percent this year, a revision from its previous forecast of 6 to 8 percent.

title: Art in Review
description: EDWARD HOPPER

title: A Mixed Take by McCain Camp on Obamas Trip to War Zones
description: GRAND HAVEN, Mich  For months, Senator John McCain and other Republicans have been criticizing Senator Barack Obama for not having visited Iraq in a long time, even running a daily tally that is now well past 900 days.

title: For Bloomberg, Another $10 Billion or So Doesnt Count for Much
description: If Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs net worth has nearly doubled to perhaps as much as $20 billion, that means:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about Kay Ryan, the countrys new poet laureate, misstated the year she won the Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize. It was 2004, not 1994.

title: CBS Chiefs to Face Questions in Rather Suit
description: The chief executive of CBS and the former president of CBS News have agreed to answer questions from lawyers for Dan Rather, who has accused the network of violating his contract by giving him little to do after forcing him off the CBS Evening News in 2005.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Sweden: Profit Down at Electrolux
description: Electrolux, the European appliance maker, reported second-quarter profit that missed analysts estimates and reduced its full-year earnings forecast after sales declined in the United States and Europe. Electrolux, based in Stockholm, said net income fell to 99 million kronor ($16.5 million) from 545 million kronor a year earlier on costs to close factories and upgrade products. The chief executive, Hans Straaberg, above, predicted European and North American markets would shrink this year. Electrolux cut its earnings outlook twice this year.

title: In Surprise, 2 Tech Titans Disappoint
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Like two straight-A students who uncharacteristically fail an exam, the technology titans Google and Microsoft issued quarterly results on Thursday that disappointed investors.

title: Gore Urges Change to Dodge an Energy Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  Former Vice President Al Gore on Thursday urged the United States to wean the nation from its entire electricity grid to carbon-free energy within 10 years, warning that drastic steps were needed to avoid a global economic and ecological cataclysm.

title: Opportunity Knocks
description: The Doorman, a mockumentary about the people who run Manhattan nightlife, has solid-gold satire at its cocaine-stained fingertips. The scene fairly satirizes itself: sycophants and fashion victims, air kisses and ego trips, ditzy Americans and dubious Europeans.

title: Correction
description: A map accompanying an Op-Ed article on the Fourth of July, about the Declaration of Independence, misstated the location of one of the earliest copies of the document. The copy in Dallas is housed at the Dallas Public Library, not City Hall.

title: Strike Kills 2 Afghan Tribal Leaders, NATO Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  American Special Forces troops and Afghan commandos killed two influential tribal leaders and a number of their followers in western Afghanistan in a joint airborne operation on Wednesday night, military officials said Thursday. But as with some previous operations, there were differing accounts over whether the strike also killed Afghan civilians.

title: Theater Listings
description: THEATER

title: Showdown in Gotham Town
description: Dark as night and nearly as long, Christopher Nolans new Batman movie feels like a beginning and something of an end. Pitched at the divide between art and industry, poetry and entertainment, it goes darker and deeper than any Hollywood movie of its comic-book kind  including Batman Begins, Mr. Nolans 2005 pleasurably moody resurrection of the series  largely by embracing an ambivalence that at first glance might be mistaken for pessimism. But no work filled with such thrilling moments of pure cinema can be rightly branded pessimistic, even a postheroic superhero movie like The Dark Knight.

title: Puttin on the Put-On, With Tunes
description: Nobody you ever heard of is in it. There arent really any characters to speak of, just four performers in everyday clothes acting like everyday people. (Everyday people who break into song and dance a lot.) The set consists of four mismatched chairs, a keyboard and a turkey burger. The darn thing does not even have a proper name.

title: Robert Lewis Shayon, 95, Is Dead; Elevated Radio
description: Robert Lewis Shayon, who wrote and produced groundbreaking radio programs in the 1940s, including the You Are There series for CBS, and who later became a longtime television critic for The Saturday Review and an Ivy League professor  all without a college education of his own  died at his home in Frankfort, Ky., on June 28. He was 95.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on July 9 about John M. Templeton, the philanthropist and pioneer in global mutual funds, attributed an erroneous distinction to him. Several natives of Winchester, Tenn., where Mr. Templeton was born, attended college before he did. Mr. Templeton, a 1934 graduate of Yale, was not the first person in town to go to college.

title: Cable Series in Running for Emmys
description: LOS ANGELES  The nominations for televisions biggest award, the Emmy, were released on Thursday morning, adding more fuel to the argument that much of the best creative work in the medium is now being done on cable, and to the perception that shows do not necessarily need big audiences to be celebrated by the television academy.

title: Film Series
description: INGMAR BERGMAN: FILM IS THE GREAT ADVENTURE (Friday through Sunday) The IFC Center continues its matinee program, Weekend Classics, with a retrospective devoted to this brooding Swede. This weeks offering is the rarely screened Port of Call, in which several characteristic Bergman themes emerge for the first time. Nine-Christine Jonsson stars as a suicidal young woman living in an anguished relationship with her mother; diving off a pier, she is rescued by a strapping young stevedore (Bengt Eklund) who seems to represent all of the health and vitality that have eluded her. At 11 a.m., IFC Center, 323 Avenue of the Americas, at West Third Street, Greenwich Village, (212) 924-7771, ifccenter.com; $11.50. (Dave Kehr)

title: Trial for Vaccine Against H.I.V. Is Canceled
description: Plans for a large human trial of a promising government-developed H.I.V. vaccine in the United States were canceled Thursday because a top federal official said scientists realized that they did not know enough about how H.I.V. vaccines and the immune system interact.

title: Prosecutor to Pursue Rebels in Next Case on Darfur Crisis
description: UNITED NATIONS  Days after seeking an arrest warrant for the Sudanese president, the prosecutor at the International Criminal Court said on Thursday that his next case on the conflict in Darfur would focus on the rebels thought to be responsible for a deadly attack on international peacekeepers in September.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Maybe You Wont Want That Boarder to Leave
description: To the Editor:

title: Life Penalties
description: Late into Take comes a teasing suggestion that much of what weve seen thus far has been imagined, to some extent, in the minds of its ill-fated characters. Subjective or not, the movie is a bore and an eyesore. If there is anything the cinema needed less than another angst-ridden, cross-cutting tragedy about crime, fate, memory and redemption, its the kind shot in an ugly monochromatic palette suggesting a world drained of emotions and filmmakers parched of imagination.

title: For Children Caught in a Tug of War, an Anchor
description: CENTERPORT, N.Y.

title: Talks Signal Mideast Shift
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  After years of escalating tensions and bloodshed, the talk in the Middle East is suddenly about talking. The shift is still relatively subtle, but hints of a new approach in the waning months of the Bush administration are fueling hopes of at least short-term stability for the first time since the invasion of Iraq in 2003.

title: The Sound of La Vida Dominicana
description: MIAMI

title: Martnezs Groin Is Sore, So Mets Juggle Rotation
description: CINCINNATI  The Mets were one of only eight clubs scheduled to play on Thursday, but the shorter All-Star break gave them the flexibility to deal with Pedro Martnezs latest setback with minimal disruption to their rotation.

title: China to Bar Entertainers It Deems Threat
description: BEIJING  Foreign entertainers who have taken part in activities that China deems a threat to its sovereignty will not be allowed to perform here, according to new rules posted Thursday on the Web site of the Ministry of Culture.

title: Prefabricated Houses, at the Modern
description: The Modern makes a convincing case that prefabricated housing was both a central theme of Modernist history and a dream that remains very much alive today.

title: Treasures From the Mughal Empire
description: A show at the Sackler Gallery in Washington showcases 82 rarely seen paintings commissioned by Mughal emperors.

title: Music at Estate Romana  A Reward for Braving Romes Heat
description: Its time for me to gush, once again, about Estate Romana  the fabulous annual 2 month-long summer music festival that brings this normally sleepy city to life on warm summer evenings. For a city that is generally not the least bit diverse, the diversity of music during summer time makes your head spin. Each year there is more than the last, and each year it is more interesting.

title: The Quad Countdown: No. 42 Nebraska
description: Location: Lincoln, Neb.

title: Insatiable Consumption
description: Aired Thursday night on NBC: Reporters assigned to Barack Obama say that this week Obama has been working out like crazy at a gym and hes also been playing hours of basketball. Meanwhile, John McCain has joined a group of mall walkers.

description: More of your late night jokes (send via the comment link below):

title: From the Pit Wall
description: In tomorrows IHT, and on the IHT web site already on the special IHT F1 page, is the inaugural column of an occasional series called From the Pit Wall, in which the IHT invites Formula One people to have their say. For the inaugural column, Ron Dennis, the director and part owner of the McLaren Mercedes team, adapted for the IHT a speech he made in Bahrain about the past and future of Formula One. He writes extensively about how he views the way any new regulations should be, and thats particularly relevant given that the teams have recently been given three months to come up with a new set of rules.

description: Senator Barack Obama has a tight-knit group of foreign policy aides supported by a huge 300-person bureaucracy, organized like a mini State Department. Related Article

title: Sava Could Fetch Healthy $1 Billion
description: Sava Senior Care is up for sale and could fetch more than $1 billion, The Daily Deal reported citing investment banking sources.

title: Chinas Wind Gearing Up for I.P.O.
description: Chinas Wind Information is planning an initial public offering to raise about 1 billion yuan ($147 million) to support expansion, Reuters reported.

title: Slow recoveries
description: Housing slumps last:

title: Arbel Raises $4.5 Million for Medical Devices
description: Arbel Medical, an Israeli start-up, has completed a $4.5 million second funding round, the company said in a press release. Arbel develops the next generation of medical equipment for removing tumors by freezing.

title: Citi Shows $2.5 Billion Loss, Less Than Expected
description: A year into the tight credit market, and the losses keep coming. The latest come from Citigroup, which said Friday morning that it lost $2.5 billion, or 0.54 cents a share, in the second quarter.

title: B&B Shareholders Approve Rights Issue
description: Bradford & Bingley shareholders approved the banks 400 million pound ($799 million) rights issue at an extraordinary general meeting on Thursday, The Telegraph reported.

title: Barrick Bids for Cadence
description: Barrick Gold, the worlds largest gold producer, raised its bid for the oil and natural gas explorer Cadence Energy by 13 percent to widen its advantage over a competing bid.

title: HireRights Alternative Deal Window Nearing Close
description: The window for HireRight to enter an alternative deal to its merger with U.S. Investigations Services is nearing its close, The Daily Deal reported.

title: New Offshore Bank Limits for U.S. Clients, UBS Says
description: Faced with a federal investigation into its private banking practices, the Swiss banking giant UBS said on Thursday that it would stop offering offshore banking services to clients in the United States.

title: Private Equity Investments in Indias Real Estate Sector Up 3%
description: Real estate and infrastructure management sector saw private equity deals worth $2.32 billion in the first half of 2008, The Hindu Business Line reported. The figure is nearly three percent higher than the comparable period last year.

title: Zentiva Rejects Sanofi Bid
description: Zentiva rejected Sanofi-Aventiss $2.02 billion-offer for the shares of the Czech generic-drug maker that it doesnt already own. Zentiva said the bid, made last week, was too low.

title: Qatar Gets Big Stake in Barclays
description: The Qatar Investment Authority became the largest shareholder of Barclays, the British bank, after just 19 percent of Barclays existing shareholders took part in a 4.5 billion pound ($9 billion) share sale.

title: Virtual Worlds Bring in Real Venture Dollars
description: Virtual experiences are becoming a thing of serious reality when it comes to raising venture capital these days. Citing data from Virtual Worlds Management, BusinessWeek reported that startups selling virtual goods and offering virtual experiences have raised $345 million in the first half of 2008.

title: Spain Broke Law in Endesa Bidding, E.U. Court Says

description: The collapse of Paramount Pictures and Deutsche Banks $450 million film financing deal earlier this week underscores how dramatically the credit crisis is affecting Hollywood.

title: More on Why White House Blocked CO2 Curbs
description: My colleague Felicity Barringer, who covers the environment for our National desk, has been tracking developments related to the White House fight with some Environmental Protection Agency officials over the need to restrict carbon dioxide. You may recall her story last month about how the White House refused to open an e-mail carrying the E.P.A. finding supporting CO2 restrictions. She sends this new dispatch:

title: Paulson to Speak on Economy, Markets on Tuesday
description: Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson will deliver remarks on financial markets and the economy on Tuesday in New York, Reuters reported.

description: Samuel Israel III bilked his investors out of $250 million, but they are hoping to recoup some of their money from one of Wall Streets deepest pockets: Goldman Sachs.

description: Responding to pressure from fund managers and brokerages to clarify how new short-selling restrictions would work, the Securities and Exchange Commission said late Thursday it would grant some leniency to certain market makers, Reuters reported.

title: The Joys of Olympic Sponsorship
description: From Thursdays Sports Business Journal. I especially love the last line. Tell me again why any company should pay millions of dollars to be an Olympic sponsor when a clever marketer like Nike can link itself to the Olympics without paying a penny? For its (reported) $40 million a year to be an Olympic sponsor, Adidas gets the right to dress the officials in the Olympic Village. Whoop-ee!

title: Perella Weinbergs Xerion Said to Jump 24%
description: Perella Weinberg Partners Xerion hedge fund rose 24 percent this year, Bloomberg News reported citing a letter sent to investors. The increase was helped by bets that the value of investment-grade bonds of financial-services firms would fall.

title: Generic Drug Makers in $7.5 Billion Deal
description: Teva Pharmaceuticals Industries, the worlds largest maker of generic drugs, confirmed Friday it would buy Barr Pharmaceuticals of New Jersey for about $7.5 billion in cash and stock. Early reports of such a deal sent shares of Barr soaring Thursday.

title: Boom Times Take Root in Dubai
description: Bathed in the glow of the skylines glitter, the centerpiece of Dubais financial hub seems equal to the thrusting ambitions of the foreign investment bankers rushing to set up shop here.

title: Sex Memoirs? Boring.
description: Sex| A critic ponders why its so stultifying to read a sex memoir in which a woman enlists her ex-lovers to reminisce about doing it. Possible answer from one lover who declined to dish details: Im not against sex, or even sexy stories. But it pales in comparison with the excitement of discovering what it means to be alive and under your own power. [thesmartset.com]

title: Unions Worldwide Target K.K.R.
description: Unions in 23 countries, led by the Service Employees International Union, took the the streets on Thursday to target the private equity industry and one of its largest representatives, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

title: Freddie Mac Said to Consider Big Share Sale
description: Freddie Mac, the government-sponsored mortgage financing company, is considering raising capital by selling as much as $10 billion in new shares, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing undisclosed sources. The report comes as lawmakers debate a proposal from the U.S. Treasury and the Federal Reserve to aid Freddie Mac and its sister company, Fannie Mae.

title: Merrill Chief Struggles Amid Big Loss
description: John A. Thain never said that turning around Merrill Lynch would be easy. We have not seen the bottom, he declared in December, when he took the reins of the troubled Wall Street giant.

title: Banks Increase Borrowing From the Fed
description: Banks direct borrowing from the Federal Reserve at the discount window rose in the latest week, one of the most tumultuous weeks for the U.S. banking system in decades, Fed data showed on Thursday, according to Reuters.

title: Fannie Mae Chief Says He Likely Wont Use Credit Line
description: The chief executive officer of mortgage finance giant Fannie Mae, Daniel Mudd, said on Thursday the company was unlikely to tap emergency credit measures that have been proposed for it by the Treasury department.

title: Bill on Energy Speculation Worries Wall Street
description: Financial industry executives are mustering on Capitol Hill to head off a Congressional effort to rewrite the rules for the nations energy markets, The New York Times reports. title: Guerras Lyrics, Translated into English
description: Translations by Seth Kugel  Nigara en Bicicleta (Niagara Falls on a Bicycle)   I fainted one Sunday morning When I least expected it. I fell hard, like a soursop fruit, onto a sewer grate.  Is it my blood pressure? Or has my bilirubin level gone up?  I got a fever, And started to turn white as a mothball. They took me to a hospital of the people -- supposedly. In the emergency room, the receptionist was listening to the lottery numbers. (30,000 pesos!)  Someone take pity on me! I shouted, losing consciousness, And a nurse approached my ear and said Calm down, Bobby, calm down. [A phrase used to talk to a dog]   She caressed me with her Ben Gay hands and asked me What happened, champ? And I told her, in intimate detail, what had happened to me.  Weve got to check your blood pressure,  but the room is occupied. And, my dear, in this hospital theres no electricity for an EKG.  I opened my eyes like the full moon,  and I grabbed my head, Because its very hard  To cross Niagara Falls on a bicycle.  Dont tell me that the doctors are gone. Dont tell me that you dont have anesthesia. Dont tell me that someone drank the alcohol, And that the thread for stitches  Has been sewn into a tablecloth.  Dont tell me that the forceps are lost, And the stethoscope is off partying, That the x-ray machine has burnt out, And the serum has been used to sweeten the coffee.  I leaned on her shoulders like a lame man leans on his crutch And I told her What should I do, princess? And on a prescription slip she wrote very sweetly Im sorry, champ.  She caressed me with her Ben Gay hands and went on her way, And I heard her clearly when she said to another patient Calm down, Bobby, calm down.  I dropped my eyes to half-mast and I grabbed my head, Because its very hard  To cross Niagara Falls in a bicycle.  SPANISH  Me dio una sirimba un domingo en la maana cuando menos lo pensaba ca redondo, como una guanbana, sobre la alcantarilla ser la presin o me ha subido la bilirrubina  Y me entr la calentura y me fui poniendo blanco como bola (d)e naftalina me llevaron a un hospital de gente (supuestamente) en la Emergencia, el recepcionista escuchaba la lotera (treinta mil pesos!)  Alguien se apiade de mi! grit perdiendo el sentido y una enfermera se acerc a mi oreja y me dijo: "Tranquilo, Bobby, tranquilo"  Me acarici con sus manos de BenGay y me dijo: "Qu le pasa, atleta?" y le cont con lujo de detalles lo que me haba sucedido  Hay que chequearte la presin pero la sala est ocupada y, mi querido en este hospital no hay luz para un electrocardiograma  Abr los ojos como luna llena y me agarr la cabeza porque es muy duro pasar el Nigara en bicicleta  No me digan que los mdicos se fueron no me digan que no tienen anestesia no me digan que el alcohol se lo bebieron y que el hilo de coser fue bordado en un mantel  No me digan que las pinzas se perdieron que el estetoscopio est de fiesta que los rayos X se fundieron y que el suero ya se us para endulzar el caf  Me apoy de sus hombros como un cojo a su muleta y le dije: "Qu hago, princesa?" y en un papel de receta me escribi muy dulcemente: "Lo siento, atleta"  Me acarici con sus manos de BenGay y sigui su destino y o claramente cuando dijo a otro paciente: "Tranquilo, Bobby, tranquilo"  Baj los ojos a media asta y me agarr la cabeza porque es muy duro pasar el Nigara en bicicleta  ***  La Hormiguita (The Little Ant)    ENGLISH  I met her one afternoon. With her guitar she was chasing down boleros She had on jeans And a yellow rose in her hair. What are you going to do? she asked me, smiling. Whatever you want, I responded. We went to the sea and soaked our dreams I winked at her, and a dolphin painted an undulating wave on her breast Then I laughed And we broke the ice And nibbled our fingers Like the viola during a cello solo.  [Chorus] You are like a little ant, Who kisses and nibbles me Who runs across my back  And settles in my beard to study geography.  Youre like a trapeze artist Who swings across my tongue. Your circus of flowers  Picks me up and lets me go, Losing count, Losing count.  And I wanted to weep, but only from my right eye. She spoke of the moon And of Chopin While I played Prelude to a Kiss. Then I laughed, and we broke the ice. We nibbled our fingers Like a viola during a cello solo.  [Chorus]   SPANISH La conoc una tarde con su guitarra cazaba boleros tena puesto un jean y una rosita amarilla en el pelo  Qu vas a hacer, me pregunt, sonriendo lo que t quieras, respond fuimos al mar y mojamos los sueos gui mis ojos y un delfn pint una ola rizada en su pecho  Luego re y rompimos el hielo y rompimos el hielo nos mordimos los dedos como viola en un solo de chelo  [Chorus] Eres como una hormiguita que me besa y me pica que recorre mi espalda y se acuesta en mi barba a estudiar geografa  Eres como un trapecista que atraviesa mi lengua y tu circo de flores me carga y me suelta perdiendo la cuenta perdiendo la cuenta  Y tuve ganas de llorar pero tan slo en mi ojo derecho ella hablaba de la luna y de Chopin y yo tocaba el Preludio de un beso   Si T No Bailas Conmigo (If You Dont Dance With Me)  ENGLISH  The moon with the rosemary, The dawn with a pine grove, The wind with the tide, And the wheat with the canopy.  The night looks for a partner, The party is about to start, If you dont dance with me, I prefer not to dance.  The rain with the orange tree, The fog with the window pane. The basil has some thyme Waiting for her in the rose garden.  Ive seen a starry sky Dancing on the sea.  Ive seen a disheveled sun Dance with a cloud. The butterfly danced With a grain of salt.  The acacia tree with the mill The grass and a thicket of bushes. If you dont dance with me, I prefer not to dance.  The cassava with ginger In a mortar for mashing  Starched each other with kisses Clutched tightly in a waltz. And even the white lily Has someone to dance with.  If you dont dance with me, The night is suspended.  If you dont dance with me, I prefer not to dance. Let a downpour of cassava and tea fall. From the skies a drizzle of white cheese, And to the south a mountain of watercress and honey.  May it rain coffee in the countryside. Comb a tall hill with grain and yams Go down the slope of fluffy rice  And keep plowing with your love.  In the autumn, instead of dry leaves, may my harvest be dressed in pitisal [a bacon-like salted pork]. Plant a field of sweet potatoes and strawberries May it rain coffee.  So that down on the farm, there isnt so much suffering, oh man, May it rain coffee in the countryside. So that in Villa Vazquez, they hear this song, May it rain coffee in the countryside. May it rain, may it rain, oh man, May it rain coffee in the countryside May it rain coffee.  May it rain coffee in the countryside, Let a downpour of cassava and tea fall. So that in Los Montones they hear this song, May it rain coffee in the countryside So that all the children, sing in the countryside, May it rain coffee in the countryside. So that in La Romana they here this song, May it rain coffee in the countryside...  SPANISH  Ojal que llueva caf en el campo que caiga un aguacero de yuca y t del cielo una jarina de queso blanco y al sur una montaa de berro y miel oh, oh, oh-oh-oh, ojal que llueva caf.  Ojal que llueva caf en el campo  peinar un alto cerro de trigo y mapuey  bajar por la colina de arroz graneado  y continuar el arado con tu querer   Ojal el otoo en vez de hojas secas  vista mi cosecha de pitisal  sembrar una llanura de batata y fresas  ojal que llueva caf. Hey doc, I'm calling about a Latin girl I met on a web site.  She tastes to me like a honeycomb, y tiene la llave de mi corazn (and has the key to my heart).  Yeah yeah yeah yeah  I'm from Louisiana, she's from San Pedro de Macoris, You know, the land of baseball players, Where Sammy Sosa lives.  She likes to drink papaya juice and paint Caribbean trees. Oh, we don't have too much in common, But love is blind as you can see.  She tastes to me like a honeycomb, Sweet to my heart, medicine for my soul. Establish your emotions, make a point, you're on the air.  Should I go and visit her? Should I learn Spanish words? Should I cry, should I face, some political concerns?  Should I join a social club, Should I peel a coconut, Movin' in, movin' on, Merengue bachata y son, now (merengue, bachata and son: three Caribbean musical genres). title: Intellectual Dishonesty on Sex Bias?
description: Well, we have no shortage of debate material, thanks to the couple of hundred Lab readers who responded to my request for evidence of bias against women scientists (and my column.). Thanks for your contributions. Let's start with Yolio's complaint that I was guilty of "intellectual dishonesty":  For example, you cite the high proportions of female students in some fields, and neglect to follow up by mentioning the low proportion of female faculty in these same fields. It seems that you are trying to mislead your readers about the true status of women in science.  I realize that omission seems strange, because the Title Niners (as I call the advocates of applying Title IX to science) have been highlighting the percentage of female science professors ever since the much-publicized 1999 report on bias at M.I.T. (In her harsh critique of the report, Judith Kleinfeld of the University of Alaska called that statistic "the single piece of hard evidence" in the entire study.) It can be quite effective in a congressional hearing or press release to point out that women get 15 to 20 percent of doctorates in physics but make up just 5 percent of full professors.   But this year's Ph.D.'s do not instantly turn into full professors, and faculties do not magically turn over every year. In fact, as Gary Becker complains, low turnover has become especially problematic since universities were forced in 1994 (by a federal law banning age discrimination) to end the tradition of mandatory retirement for tenured professors at age 65. So it's taking some time for the recent surge in female students to show up in faculties.  The more relevant question (as the Title Niners acknowledge in the better reports if you read past the executive summaries) is whether there's a "leaky pipeline": whether female grad students go on to get doctorates and teaching positions at the same rate as male grad students.   In my column I cited the example of physics, a field that was singled out for some of first Title IX investigations on campus because it has one of the biggest gender gaps. A 2005 report by the American Institute of Physics pointed to figures (from 2002) showing that women constituted 5 percent of full professors, 11 percent percent of associate professors and 16 percent of assistant professors. The A.I.P. researchers, Rachel Ivie and Kim Nies Ray, write:   Some might look at these numbers and conclude that the pipeline is indeed leaking for women. There are fewer women at the upper levels of academic physics than at the lower levels. However, before we can determine if and where the pipeline is disproportionately losing women, we must look at the pool of available women, or at the lag time between earning a physics degree and advancing to the next level. For example, we cannot expect 20% of the physics faculty to be women if, in the past, women earned a much smaller percentage of physics Ph.D.'s.    The researchers reported that physics graduate students spent seven years, on average, to get their doctorates. When they compared students who entered graduate school in 1996 with the ones who got doctorates seven years later, they found about the same percentage of women (18 percent of the entering students; 17 percent of the Ph.D.'s.)   And when the researchers similarly adjusted for the average time lag between getting a doctorate and reaching each stage of the teaching ladder, they found that women were actually a little more likely to be get teaching jobs. Women made up 12 percent of the hiring pool for assistant professors but constituted 16 percent of the assistant professors. Among associate professors, they made up 9 percent of the hiring pool and 11 percent of the ones hired; among full professors, they were 4 percent of the pool but 5 percent of the ones hired.  That's one study and one discipline. On Monday I'll look at some other disciplines, including chemistry. Let me know if you have any thoughts on the chemistry pipeline, and whether women with chemistry doctorates are being excluded from academia or are choosing careers outside academia. I'll consider statistics from a 2006 report from the National Academy of Sciences and the 2007 Nelson Diversity Survey (recommended in a comment from Female Mathematician). I'll also be dealing with an issue raised by some readers on the pipeline into the top-rated science departments.  Let me know if you have any thoughts on those studies, or any others I should be considering. And here are a couple of other stray questions:   1) Given the slow turnover of faculty and its bad effect on opportunities for young female (and male) scientists, should advocates for more women in science be trying to eliminate tenure? (Some Title Niners have advocated its abolition.)   2) Given the consequences of the law forbidding mandatory retirement of professors, should we think twice about imposing further federal restrictions? Could Title IX become another rigid, one-size-fits-all rule that makes it harder for universities to hire the best young scientists?

The auction, which was meant to help pay the outstanding bills and taxes of the singers estate, brought in $857,688 at Christies on Thursday; the auction house had expected the sale to take in around $1 million. Among the items up for sale were a black satin cape that sold for $47,500 and a red leather furniture set that sold for $40,000. A medical bracelet that Mr. Brown wore right before his death in 2006 was sold to Paul Shaffer, the band leader on Late Show With David Letterman, for $32,000. An appeals court judge in South Carolina had declined an effort to block the sale on Monday by Mr. Browns managers.

Earnings and revenue beat analysts estimates, and the company said it would top its previous full-year forecasts for both measures. Honeywell raised its 2008 profit projection by 5 cents, to $3.75 to $3.85 a share, excluding gains from the pending sale of its aerospace fastener unit to BE Aerospace. title: Laurie Anderson and Lou Reed Onstage
description: In a surprise addition to Lincoln Center Festivals production of Homeland, the performance artist Laurie Anderson and her husband, the rocker Lou Reed, will perform together on Tuesday night for the first time in New York as husband and wife. The couple were married in April. Ms. Andersons Homeland, which was first performed in New York at Zankel Hall in March and runs for five nights, combines poetry, song cycles, spoken word, electronics and live music to explore the political landscape of America, with a focus on the war in Iraq. Ms. Anderson said of the piece, Its one of the more political things that Ive done in quite a while, adding, My work is stories, and we have a very story-savvy government. In addition to Mr. Reed, several musicians associated with John Zorns Masada group will perform, along with other special guests. Mr. Reed is scheduled to appear at subsequent performances as well.

title: Michael Gregg, 78, Editor of U.S. Medical Bulletin, Is Dead
description: Michael B. Gregg, an epidemiologist and former editor of the Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report, a federal medical bulletin that published early warnings of the impending AIDS crisis in 1981, died on July 9 in Brattleboro, Vt. He was 78.

title: Croatian Leader of 1976 Hijacking Is Granted Parole, but Faces Deportation
description: In 1976, Croatian independence fighters hijacked T.W.A. Flight 355 shortly after it left La Guardia Airport. They said they had five bombs on board the jetliner and had planted a sixth in a locker at Grand Central Terminal.

title: Honor Your Word, or This Banker May Call Mom
description: Just a few years ago, it was easy to write off the local community bank as a relic, a quaint reminder of an age when you actually needed to visit a branch to manage your money.

title: Sound-Collage Partners, Mixing Stunts and Spirit
description: Before firing up their decks at the McCarren Park Pool in Brooklyn on Thursday night, DJ Shadow and Cut Chemist cleared the stage for an instructional film, projected onto two backdrop screens. Beginning with a brief history of the 45-r.p.m. record, the film moved on to the logistics at hand. All audio is being delivered via vinyl on eight turntables into four mixers, a voice declared, in the plummy tone of a 1950s studio announcer. That may not sound like an applause line, but at this show it drew exuberant cheers.

title: Signs That Private Jet Sales Are Slowing in U.S.
description: FARNBOROUGH, England  Given the misery of air travel these days, private jet makers may seem to have a built-in selling point, particularly among customers in the United States.

title: Neil Young, Where Politics and Technology Meet
description: When Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young booked a concert tour for the summer of 2006, it was supposed to be an easygoing, no-surprises reunion ticket for the Chardonnay set.

title: Sometimes the Darkest Visions Boast the Blackest Humor
description: After Nature, the big new show at the New Museum, is a strange, lugubrious, wildly uneven dream of an exhibition. Inspired partly by the book-length poem of that title by the German writer W. G. Sebald, it exudes a distinctly European spirit of ruminative pessimism relieved intermittently by moments of black humor and otherworldly fantasy. It lurches from transcendentally thrilling to portentous to kitschy.

title: Hope, and Hints, That Financial Stocks Have Finally Touched Bottom
description: HAVE financial stocks finally fallen so far that they are great investments?

title: Freddie Mac Takes Step Toward Raising Capital
description: The nations two beleaguered mortgage finance giants continued to win back investors on Friday, as Freddie Mac, the smaller of the two companies, took a crucial step toward raising capital.

title: A Player Much Too Alert for the Psychological Coup
description: The Summer North American Bridge Championships of the American Contract Bridge League started on Thursday in the Hilton Hotel, Las Vegas. The Spingold Knockout Teams is the premier event. The defending champions are Nick Nickell, Dick Freeman, Chris Compton, Bob Hamman, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell (although last year Hemant Lall played instead of Freeman, who was recovering from surgery, and Paul Soloway, who died in November, partnered Hamman).

title: McCain Co-Chairman, Under Fire, Steps Aside
description: Former Senator Phil Gramm resigned late Friday as a co-chairman of Senator John McCains presidential campaign, capping a day filled with controversy for Mr. McCain, the presumed Republican nominee.

description: To the Editor:

title: Favorite Tournament Has Duval at His Best
