title: Taking Risks on Mortgages
description: To the Editor:

title: Video Shows Moon From Other Side
description: A NASA spacecraft designed to look for comets turned its cameras homeward, capturing a unique view of the moon passing in front of the Earth as seen from 31 million miles away. The spacecraft, Deep Impact, took shots at 15-minute intervals, which were combined to make the sequence shown below.

title: The Dark Knight Owns Midnight
description: The Dark Knight earned an estimated $18.5 million in gross revenue at its 12 a.m. opening screenings early Friday morning at 3,040 screens, the most ever for midnight shows, The Associated Press reported. The film, directed by Christopher Nolan, moved ahead of the previous record set in 2005 by Star Wars, Episode III: The Revenge of the Sith, which took in $16.9 million at 2,915 screens. Warner Brothers reported that the $18.5 million did not include revenue from subsequent 3 a.m. and 6 a.m. screenings.

title: Black Marks for the Red Cross
description: One thing Americans do not want to hear when they are injured or facing surgery is that blood from the American Red Cross may actually harm them. So it was unnerving, to put it mildly, to learn that the Red Cross, which collects and distributes some 43 percent of blood given to patients in this country, has failed to follow quality-control measures ordered by a federal court 15 years ago.

title: Couric to Stay at CBS, for Now
description: CBS News and Katie Couric have no plans to part company anytime soon, Ms. Couric, right, the CBS Evening News anchor, said on Friday. Ms. Couric, speaking via satellite to reporters at the networks summer television press tour, was asked about her status on the third-place evening newscast, given the reports of her dissatisfaction. She said she was committed to the program and to her CBS colleagues. Im focused on how to serve the five million-plus viewers who watch the CBS Evening News every night, she said. The programs ratings have eroded since Ms. Couric became its anchor in September 2006. In February, Ms. Couric and CBS executives met to discuss a possible departure after the presidential election. On Friday, Sean McManus, the president of CBS News, was also asked whether Ms. Couric would leave then. I can say, and I have said, it isnt true, he answered.

title: Bush, in a Shift, Accepts Concept of Iraq Timeline
description: HOUSTON  President Bush agreed to a general time horizon for withdrawing American troops in Iraq, the White House announced Friday, in a concession that reflected both progress in stabilizing Iraq and the depth of political opposition to an open-ended military presence in Iraq and at home.

title: Restaurants That Lack Calorie Counts Now Face Fines
description: Mark Loersch, who teaches nutrition to high school students, noticed something in a McDonalds restaurant on West 42nd Street in Midtown Manhattan that he had not seen back home in Onalaska, Wis.: calorie counts posted next to the prices. A Big Mac has 540 calories, the sign said.

title: Hearts and Minds at War in a Triple Bill of Plays
description: The Potomac Theater Project has the right actress in the right play for the centerpiece production of its summer residency at Atlantic Stage 2.

title: Lawyer Is Accused of Using Reform Group to Launder Money From Strip Club
description: A lawyer who fervently contested the result of the 2000 presidential election and started an organization advocating voter reform used it to hide profits from another venture, the police say: a strip club that offered more than dancing.

title: Is McCain in the Theodore Roosevelt Mold?
description: To the Editor:

title: Taliban Threaten to Kill Officials Held Hostage
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  The Pakistani Taliban have taken dozens of hostages, including police officers, paramilitary fighters and even state bank officials, and threatened on Friday to begin killing them unless the government released four of their comrades captured last week.

title: Help for Victimized Children
description: Of the some 1.5 million children who will run away from home this year, tens of thousands will spend time working for sexual predators and selling their bodies on the streets. According to one federal estimate, the average age of a child first used as a prostitute is between 11 and 14, but victims as young as 9 are not uncommon. Many of the sexually exploited runaways have been neglected or abandoned by families that will never report them as missing.

title: Verdis Violetta Amplified for a Picnic in the Park
description: If part of the aim of free, informal outdoor concerts is to lure new listeners to a genre, the New York Grand Opera Companys enjoyable performance of Verdis Traviata on Wednesday surely won a few new devotees.

title: Selected Studies: Anemia
description: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies designed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Politics Has Dissidents Talking to A.F.L.-C.I.O.
description: The presidents of several labor unions that quit the A.F.L.-C.I.O. three years ago have been quietly meeting with union presidents in the federation to coordinate their political operations and message for the fall election, a move that labor leaders say could lead to several of the unions rejoining the federation.

title: 4 Killed as Huge Crane Topples at a Houston Refinery
description: HOUSTON  Four workers were killed and six others injured when a giant crane collapsed on Friday afternoon at an oil refinery in southeast Houston, the latest of several recent fatal accidents across the nation involving cranes.

title: A High-Seas Show With Gay Family Values
description: ABOARD THE NORWEGIAN DAWN  If youve ever wondered what became of the belief in musical theaters power to transform lives, take note: for most of this week it could be found a few hundred nautical miles out of New York, chugging north on the way to Halifax, Nova Scotia.

title: Strong Finish Follows Some Good Advice
description: SOUTHPORT, England  The British Open was in need of well-above-average story lines to fill all that air and space usually reserved for Tiger Woods, and Greg Norman and David Duval certainly did their part on Friday.

title: A Record Sale for Beatrix Potter
description: An original watercolor illustration by the childrens author Beatrix Potter has set an auction record for a book illustration, BBC News reported. The final scene from The Rabbits Christmas Party sequence, above, sold for about $580,000 at a Sothebys auction in London, nearly five times the presale estimate. The fine ink and watercolor drawing, which was painted by Potter sometime around 1892, shows rabbits leaving a traditional Christmas celebration. The work, which was purchased by a private British collector, was one of 20 illustrations, books, Christmas cards and letters by Ms. Potter for sale in the auction, which brought in almost $1.5 million.

title: An Ex-Aide, 28, Returns to Fill Bigger Shoes
description: WASHINGTON  During the four years he spent as President Bushs body man, or personal aide, Blake Gottesman acquired an eclectic set of job skills.

title: Joe Brunos Victory Lap: A Satisfied Tour of His District
description: ALBANY  On his final day as a New York state senator, Joseph L. Bruno swanned out of the Capitol on Friday into the blazing midday sun, moving almost daintily down the buildings grand eastern staircase, as if savoring each step.

title: Lottery Numbers
Return of a Precursor, Still Fast and Chilly
description: The short-lived British electro-pop duo Yaz was never revered for its slow songs, which might explain why, on Thursday night at Terminal 5, while the singer Alison Moyet was whispering her way through a particularly theatrical version of Winter Kills, the crowd was feeling chatty.

title: Beckham Most at Home on the Field
description: On Wednesday night in Los Angeles, David and Victoria Beckham attended the ESPY Awards. First time Ive been on the red carpet in a long time, he noted. I like it once in a while.

title: Uncertainties About the Role of Doubt in Religion
description: Belief in God isnt quite the same thing in 1500 and today, writes Charles Taylor in A Secular Age (Harvard University Press, 2007), his formidable exploration of how the conditions of religious belief  and of unbelief, too  have changed for modern Westerners.

title: Baby Penguins Washing Up Dead in Brazil
description: RIO DE JANEIRO (AP)  Hundreds of baby penguins swept from the icy shores of Antarctica and Patagonia are washing up dead on tropical beaches here, rescuers and state officials said Friday.

title: Plans for Denvers Daisies Drown in Disappointment
description: DENVER  It was the sort of civic idea that nobody thought would cause problems.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about Rachel Maddow, the Air America radio host who is being considered for a television program on MSNBC, using information from Ms. Maddow, misstated the location of her fathers service in the Air Force. He served stateside during the Vietnam War years, not in Vietnam.

title: Jo Stafford, Wistful Voice of WWII Era, Dies at 90
description: Jo Stafford, the wistful singing voice of the American home front during World War II and the Korean War, died on Wednesday at her home in Century City, Calif. She was 90.

title: Ban on Sprinter Upheld
description: The High Court in London upheld the lifetime ban imposed on Dwain Chambers in 2003 after the British sprinter confessed to using performance-enhancing drugs. Chambers was seeking an injunction so he could join the British Olympic team in Beijing.

description: SEOUL, South Korea  Foreign ministers of the United States, North Korea and four other countries will meet in Singapore next week for discussions on ending North Koreas nuclear weapons programs, a South Korean government official said on Friday.

description: UNITED NATIONS  Diplomats from the worlds governments met throughout this week on agreements to cut the global illicit trade in small arms, but their work was curtailed in part by the near-boycott of the meetings by the United States.

title: The Challenges of Anemia: Defining It, and Living With It
description: Dr. Allen Nissenson is a professor of medicine and director of the dialysis program for the David Geffen School of Medicine at the University of California, Los Angeles. He has written two medical textbooks on kidney disease treatment and was president of the National Anemia Action Council, a patient advocacy group.

title: Stock Markets Pause After 2-Day Rally
description: Stocks muddled through a mixed session on Friday, ending a tumultuous week on a quiet note.

title: President of Argentina Withdraws Tax Increase
description: BUENOS AIRES  The embattled president of Argentina, Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner, on Friday revoked tax increases on grain exports, a measure that had set off four months of farm revolts, food shortages and nationwide protests.

description: Barack Obamas Middle East tour is under way. Next stop is ... wherever. (Security is really, really, really tight for this trip.)

description: BRUSSELS  When global trade talks ran into the night in Geneva in the summer of 2006, so many negotiators crammed into one room that they had to choose between sweltering with the windows closed or opening them and fending off swarms of insects.

description: WASHINGTON  Felons are asking President Bush for pardons and commutations at historic levels as he nears his final months in office, a time when many other presidents have granted a flurry of clemency requests.

title: Tips for Taking on Anemia
description: Dr. Lawrence Goodnough is the director of transfusion services at the Stanford University Medical Center and was president of the Society for the Advancement of Blood Management, a group that promotes better anemia control. He says that anemia is a serious medical condition, especially for people who suffer fatigue from chronic diseases. Here are the five things he believes everyone should know about managing the most common blood disorder.

title: Four Ex-Convicts Tell of Lives Lost and Found
description: Before the curtain rose on Wednesday evening for The Castle, an oral history drama now at the New World Stages theater, a burly man lingered in the lobby. Gray hair fell in short braids over his collar.

title: Cuba to Grant Private Farmers Access to Land
description: MEXICO CITY  President Ral Castro continued his rollout of changes in Cuba on Friday with the start of a plan to boost the islands sluggish food production by granting private farmers access to up to 99 acres of unused government land.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about the limited success of tactics to reduce air traffic at the New York area airports referred incorrectly to the legal status of new approach and departure routes that the Federal Aviation Administration wants to impose. They are under legal challenge; they have not been blocked in court.

title: Girl, 16, Swimming in Surf Is Lost Off Rockaway Beach
description: A 16-year-old Queens girl swimming with a friend in the rough surf at Rockaway Beach apparently drowned on Friday afternoon, despite the efforts of lifeguards and hours of searching afterward by rescue crews. It would be the first drowning at a city beach this summer, officials said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A review last Sunday about "Rome 1960: The Olympics That Changed the World," by David Maraniss, referred incorrectly to the Rome Games. They were the first commercially televised Summer Games, not "the first televised Olympics." (Olympic events had been televised in various formats since the 1936 Summer Games, which were shown on screens around Berlin.) The error is repeated in the Editors Choice column on Page 18 this weekend.

title: In Dispute With BP, Kremlins Hand Is Seen
description: MOSCOW  BPs billionaire Russian oil partners have characterized their dispute with the British oil giant as a shareholder revolt  in the spirit of Kirk Kerkorians hounding General Motors or Carl C. Icahn holding Yahoos feet to the fire.

title: By Adding Another Reyes, Mets Also Get a Lucky Charm
description: CINCINNATI  When the Mets called up Argenis Reyes a little over two weeks ago, they figured they had picked up a decent contact hitter who could play second base. What they did not realize was that they also got a good-luck charm to match any pendant, shoe-lacing habit or favorite pair of socks.

title: Yusuf Islam Wins Libel Damages
description: Yusuf Islam, the folk singer once known as Cat Stevens, has won unspecified libel damages and an apology from the World Entertainment News Network, a news agency based in London, Reuters reported. The agency published an article in March that claimed Mr. Islam would speak only to veiled women at an awards ceremony. Mr. Islams lawyer, Adam Tudor, told the High Court in London that the article had embarrassed the singer and caused him distress. It was also distributed widely through a Web site, contactmusic.com. Mr. Islam, 59, will donate the money to Small Kindness, a United Nations-affiliated charity, of which he is chairman, that is dedicated to victims of war and conflict.

description: THIS is one of those columns that will make you feel guilty. Or smug. Or perhaps a bit of both.

title: Pope Apologizes for Sexual Abuse in Australia
description: SYDNEY  Pope Benedict XVI, in Australia to celebrate the Catholic Churchs World Youth Day, publicly apologized on Saturday for the sexual abuse of children by members of the Church here and called for the perpetrators to be brought to justice.

title: The Buzz About a McCain-Romney Ticket
description: It was not so long ago that the idea that Senator John McCain would even entertain tapping Mitt Romney, his bitterest primary rival, as his running mate would have seemed preposterous, rating at least 7.0 on the strange-bedfellows scale.

title: Footnotes
description: The Japanese avant-rock group the Boredoms plans a kind of reprise of 77BoaDrum, a composition for 77 drummers that it performed in Brooklyn last July 7 (that is, 7/7/07). This time its all about the eights: At 8:08 p.m., Pacific time, on Aug. 8 (8/8/08), the band will play  what else  88BoaDrum with 88 drummers at the La Brea Tar Pits in Los Angeles. The same day, the band Gang Gang Dance will lead a version of the piece on the Williamsburg waterfront in Brooklyn at 8:08 p.m., Eastern time ... The New York Festival of Song has announced its 2008-09 season. The program opens Sept. 23 with a celebration of Leonard Bernstein and William Bolcom at the newly renovated Merkin Concert Hall at Kaufman Center ... Stockard Channing and Martha Plimpton have joined the cast of the Roundabout Theater Companys production of Pal Joey ... Gwen Stewart will return to Rent. The actress, who played several roles in the original musical, will reprise those roles starting on July 21 and through the shows Broadway closing on Sept. 7.

title: Pope Calls for Unity to Oppose Violence
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Pope Benedict XVI, in Australia for World Youth Day, called on religious leaders of all faiths Friday to find common ground and to unite against those who resort to violence to achieve their ends.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the biologist Edward O. Wilson described incorrectly his forthcoming book, The Superorganism. It is a new book  not an updated edition  that contains new information on termites, wasps, bees and ants, as well as information updated from an earlier book, The Ants. And a correction in this space on Friday misspelled the given name of Dr. Wilsons co-author on both books. As the article correctly noted, he is Bert Hlldobler, not Burt.

title: Court Orders Ohio to Include Libertarian Party on Ballot
description: CINCINNATI  Ohio must include the Libertarian Partys nominees on its ballot in November, a court has ruled, complicating Senator John McCains effort to win conservative votes in a hotly contested state rich in electoral votes.

title: Broken Leg Ends Olympic Dream for U.S. Gymnast
description: NEW WAVERLY, Tex.  With the final four spots on the United States Olympic womens gymnastics team hanging in the balance, an intrasquad meet here Friday at the womens national team training center began with tears.

description: China violates global trade rules by requiring automakers operating there to buy components from local suppliers or face penalties, the World Trade Organization ruled on Friday.

title: Tired Blood Warning: Ignore It at Your Peril
description: Thanks to advertisements for the once-popular tonic Geritol, most people of a certain age know about tired blood, a disorder more accurately called anemia, involving a shortage of healthy red blood cells to carry oxygen to body tissues and cleanse them of carbon dioxide.

title: Sherman L. Maxwell, 100, Sportscaster and Writer, Dies
description: Sherman L. Maxwell, a chronicler of Negro league baseball and, some believe, the first black sports broadcaster, died on Wednesday in West Chester, Pa. Maxwell, known as Jocko, was 100 and had lived most of his life in Newark.

title: Mr. Rangels Many Friends
description: For all his angry denial of any wrongdoing, it is commendable that Representative Charles Rangel is calling for an ethics inquiry into his use of Congressional letterhead to trawl for financial support for an academic center, the Charles B. Rangel Center for Public Service at the City College of New York, which is expected to cost tens of millions of dollars.

title: Israel: 6 Charged in Qaeda Plan
description: Two Arab citizens of Israel and four Palestinian residents of East Jerusalem were charged with planning to set up a network of Al Qaeda in Israel, said Shin Bet, the internal security agency. It said one of the accused, Muhammad Najam, 24, a student at the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, contemplated bringing down President Bushs helicopter as it approached a landing pad in the universitys stadium earlier this year. Shin Bet said Mr. Najam had used his cellphone to film helicopters taking off and landing and that he had inquired on an Internet forum identified with Al Qaeda about bringing down the helicopter. Mr. Bush visited Israel twice this year. There was no suggestion that the men had actually tried to carry out an attack.

Commissioned by the Public Art Fund, the film recorded performances at cafes, on street corners and at train stations.

title: The Starting Line: Closure for Britain and a Loss for China

The British Olympic Association had named only Simeon Williamson to the team after its trials last week because of Chamberss appeal of his lifetime ban for doping. title: The force of F1 poker
description: As I write these words there is a game of poker going on in the Force India motor home a few short steps away from the media center in the paddock. Last year I wrote a story about chess and Formula One and I found that there was a small trend in the paddock of people playing backgammon  of all things. Now the paddock has found its real game of the moment. For several races now, a group of drivers has been meeting to play a private game of poker on the second floor of the Force India motor home in complete private, away from the media.

description: Among the unlikelier announcements made at Wikipedia's conference in Alexandria, Egypt, was the bold assertion on Friday that the online encyclopedia was about to make history in print publishing: creating the book with the most credited individual authors ever -- approximately 90,000.

description: Blogging in the Tampa Tribune, Erik Erlendsson reports Former Lightning coach John Tortorella could be in line to take over the vacant head coaching position with the New York Islanders.

description: How to build a brick patio, from a show on the DIY Network.

title: A Wikipedian Challenge: Convincing Arabic Speakers to Write in Arabic
description: A nagging undercurrent to the Wikimania conference in Alexandria, Egypt, has been the chagrin, even embarrassment, among the Arabic-speaking participants that their version of Wikipedia should be so elementary. It has fewer than 65,000 articles, and ranks 29th among the various Wikipedias, just behind Slovenian, and well behind the artificial tongue, Esperanto.

title: Granite Countertops
description: How to build a granite countertop, a show on the DIY Network.

title: The Sam Adams Project
description: AUSTIN  The Sam Adams Alliance, a nonprofit conservative organization, has started an ambitious project this year to encourage right-leaning activists and bloggers to get online and focus on local and state issues.

title: Under Their Hats
description: Officers from the 46th Police Precinct in the Bronx reveal the personal keepsakes under their hats.

title: A Church, Divided
description: The Presbyterian Church of Astoria, Queens, is divided on its future as housing for the elderly.

title: Hoop Opa!: Greece, Croatia Qualify; Puerto Rico and Germany Vie Sunday for Last Spot
description: Greece and Croatia qualified for the mens Olympic basketball tournament in Beijing next month by winning their respective matches at the qualifying tournament in Athens on Saturday.

title: White House Tips Press Off to Maliki Interview
description: WACO, Tex.  The White House is quick to distribute its point of view in e-mail messages with headings like News You Can Use, In Case You Missed It, and Setting the Record Straight. So it was a surprise on Saturday morning when the White House distributed an article by Reuters that offered an endorsement of Senator Barack Obamas Iraq policy by the leader of Iraq.

title: Obama Campaign on the Ground
description: AUSTIN  Senator Barack Obamas campaign staff members have been the first to admit that Texas would be a pretty tough state for him to win come November, and theyre not just playing the expectations game.

title: Maliki Backs Obamas Troop Withdrawal Plan
description: Update: A spokesman for the Iraqi prime minister has issued a statement saying his remarks were misunderstood and mistranslated, but did not address a specific error. Full statement below.

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu, July 20
description: Its the economy, stupid. Or its the war. Actually, its both on Sundays talk shows (except on ABC, where its the British Open golf tournament).

title: A Modern Bible
description: Jesus and the Leper, Mark 1:40-47 40 And there came a leper to him, beseeching him, and kneeling down to him, and saying unto him, if though wilt, thou canst make me clean. 41 And Jesus, moved with compassion, put forth his hand, and saith unto him, I will; dost thou have insurance? 42 And the leper saith unto him, Yes. I have Empire Blue Cross. 43 And Jesus asked of the leper, Dost thou have the P.P.O. or the H.M.O.? 44 And the leper saith unto him, I have the H.M.O. 45 And Jesus saith unto him, I am sorry, my child, but heal you I cannot, for I only accept Empire Blue Crosss P.P.O. plan. 46 And the leper wept, but Jesus saith unto him, Perhaps another messiah will be along who accepts your plan. 47 And he sent the leper away from him.

title: Same Aide, Grander Title
description: After leaving his job as the president's personal aide two years ago, Blake Gottesman, 28, has returned to the White House. But now he's deputy chief of staff for operations.

title: The Art of Darkness
description: Images from the After Nature show at the New Museum.

title: Your Comments on Encore Careers
description: My Sunday column is about encore careers, or career switches in the second half of life meant to provide personal satisfaction and do some good. Bill Gatess move to his foundation is the best example of that, but by some estimates there are already 4 million to 6 million people in encore careers in the U.S.

title: Gymnastics: Paul Hamm Is In as U.S. Sets Its Teams
description: USA Gymnastics officials on Saturday deemed Paul Hamm fit for the Olympics. Hamm, who broke his right hand at the national championships in May, performed in all six events at an intrasquad competition in Colorado Springs. In a teleconference he said he felt 90 percent healthy.

title: Doherty Back On 90210 This Fall
description: Shannen Doherty will reprise her role as Brenda Walsh in CWs new version of the 1990-2000 series Beverly Hills 90210, with her character now a famous director whos invited back to stage a musical at her alma mater, the Associated Press reports.

title: Swapping Guns for Cash, at Church
description: There was a time, in the 1970s and 80s that handguns were so coveted on the streets of Kings County, that the borough gave rise to a law enforcement legend known as the Brooklyn Bounce. If you were to throw a gun from a window in Bay Ridge or Bushwick, so the legend went, it would be eagerly grabbed before it had a chance to bounce more than once.

title: Correction: A Composer Forever English, Cows and All
description: An article last Sunday about the composer Ralph Vaughan Williams misspelled the surname of his maternal grandfather, who was a partner in his familys ceramics firm. He was Josiah Wedgwood III, not Wedgewood.

title: Obamas Visit Renews Focus on Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Senator Barack Obama arrived in Afghanistan on Saturday, on a high-profile foreign trip in a country that is increasingly the focus of his clash with Senator John McCain over whether the war in Iraq has been a distraction in hunting down terrorists.

title: Revealing Your Roots
description: On a date with a nice fellow, I wore a wig with long hair and bangs  which I wore when I met him at a singles dance. I dont look as nice without the wig; my own hair is thin and unattractive.

title: At Struggling School, Pride Displaces Failure
description: NEWARK

title: To the City, From the Country
description: Journal Square in Jersey City is all hustle and bustle, except on Wednesdays when farmers come to market there. Commuters from the nearby PATH station walk slower, it seems, curious about the likes of purplish green beans and gooseberries.

title: Too Big to Fail?
description: IN the narrative that has governed American commercial life for the last quarter-century, saving companies from their own mistakes was not supposed to be part of the governments job description. Economic policy makers in the United States took swaggering pride in the cutthroat but lucrative form of capitalism that was supposedly indigenous to their frontier nation.

title: Futures Imperfect
description: AS costs for energy and food rise, the impact that speculators have on commodity prices is being debated by politicians and the public. The recent volatility in crude oil prices  increasing to nearly $150 per barrel and then falling to below $130  has only heightened these concerns.

title: The Sweet Spot
description: IT looks like your standard-issue upscale Scarsdale kitchen: a large granite island, Thermador wall ovens, Viking range top with grill and a Sub-Zero refrigerator. A friendly goldendoodle (a mix of golden retriever and poodle) named Muttsy lies at the doorway, barred from the room by a gate, though he freely roams the rest of the handsome 1938 colonial.

title: Wendy Jenks, Fraser Woodford
description: Wendy Alana Jenks, the daughter of Joyce and Allan Jenks of Washington, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Fraser Martin Woodford, a son of Judith and Martin Woodford of Lexington, Ky. The Rev. J. Donald Waring, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Grace Church in New York.

title: Job Insecurity, and No Lack of Hanky-Panky, in an Office Farce
description: Everyone in Scramble! has a quirk (or at least a noticeable distinction). Jane is sometimes so nervous she cant be understood when she speaks. Otis, no longer a young man, is always searching for a word that he cant quite remember. Sam, the brusque Holland Taylor-ish boss, thrives on flinging insults. Johnson, the new guy, is afraid of his own shadow. Temple  well, Temple has really perky breasts. Carter is the opportunist office wolf after her.

title: Giuliani Firm Plans Real Estate Investment Fund
description: Entering the real estate market at a time of profound turmoil, Rudolph W. Giulianis company is planning an investment fund based on commercial and residential properties in New York and Washington, members of the venture said last week.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: An All-Star Sham

title: Letter: Pittsburgh as Theater
description: To the Editor: I got a kick out of the travel sections 36 Hours in Pittsburgh (July 6). Pittsburghers have known for a long time that the only people who dont like our city are those who have never visited. The theater scene here is vibrant. Not to be missed is Quantum Theatre (www.quantumtheatre.com), which since 1990 has been producing works in sites specific to them like a city park, abandoned industrial warehouse or an empty swimming pool in Andrew Carnegies first library building in Braddock, Pa.

title: Rock the Casbah
description: This professor of Middle Eastern history walks into a bar in Fez, Morocco  right from the get-go, Mark LeVines Heavy Metal Islam: Rock, Resistance, and the Struggle for the Soul of Islam is not your typical dry academic slog. (Did I mention hes also a longhaired Jewish rock guitarist whose bio lists gigs with Mick Jagger and Dr. John?) So when somebody in that hotel bar starts talking up the local punk and metal scenes, an incredulous LeVine is hooked. There are Muslim punks? In Morocco? Quicker than you can whistle Rock the Casbah, hes on the trail of Western-influenced underground music movements that have blossomed under authoritarian regimes across the Middle East and North Africa.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report last Sunday about the marriage of Patty Dann and Michael Hill referred incorrectly to Judge James C. Hill of Amelia Island, Fla., who officiated. As the report noted elsewhere, he is the bridegrooms father, not the brides.

title: Given a Shovel, Americans Dig Deeper Into Debt
description: The collection agencies call at least 20 times a day. For a little quiet, Diane McLeod stashes her phone in the dishwasher.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary last Sunday about Tony Snow, the former columnist, television commentator and press secretary to President Bush, misstated, in some editions, the year that President Bush sought re-election. It was 2004  not 2006, which was the year Mr. Snow helped raise money for Republicans running in the midterm elections.

title: Ballet Theaters So-What Season
description: AS long as you dont set your expectations too high, as long as you dont ask ballet to be great or important or seriously beautiful, American Ballet Theater is remarkably efficient at delivering the goods. It does, of course, go further than that, but too sporadically. This is (as Wes Chapman, an assistant artistic director, advised a childrens matinee in May) Americas national ballet company. But would you know that from its performances?

title: As Gas Prices Rise, Police Turn to Foot Patrols
description: SUWANEE, Ga.  People around here are seeing a lot more of Officer Robert Stewart.

title: Finding Solutions, Together
description: An article on June 22 about efforts to address the needs of the growing population of elderly people in Westchester County misidentified the location of a new traffic signal sought by elderly pedestrians who said they needed more time to cross congested roads. It is at Tarrytown Road (Route 119) at Manhattan Avenue in Greenburgh, not on Route 9A in Greenburgh.

title: Events on Long Island
description: COMEDY

title: The Watch List
description: The Dodgers Takashi Saito will miss at least six weeks with an elbow injury, and more if surgery is required. That opens the door for Jonathan Broxton, below, to take over as the closer. He has flourished as a setup man for two and a half seasons, but while he is still striking out more than one batter an inning (48 in 40 2/3) with a 3.32 earned run average this season, he has not been as dominant as he was in 2006 and 2007, when he struck out 196 in 158 1/3 with a 2.73 E.R.A.

title: Diplomatic Impunity
description: As the Israeli ambassador to the United Nations, you are about to leave your post after nearly six years and return to Tel Aviv at a time when Iran is releasing touched-up photographs of its latest missile tests and continuing to enrich uranium in defiance of U.N. sanctions. How seriously do you take their threats? Listen to Ahmadinejad, who denies the Holocaust while planning the next one, who talks about wiping Israel off the face of the map  listen to him, and take him at face value.

title: Looking for Luck
description: ONLY a few months ago, Keith Jacobson, a developer and former investment banker, was in his red metallic kitchen at 173 Perry Street, explaining how he got two apartments at Richard Meiers glass-walled celebrity redoubt on the Hudson in 2004 for a bargain-basement price  $3.74 million for two floors, according to property records. It was good luck and timing.

title: In the N.F.L., Its Time to Get Back to Work
description: After an off-season that closely resembled a soap opera  the Patriots spying scandal, the Steelers family squabble over ownership, and Brett Favres flip-flop over his future  N.F.L. training camps will be a relief. They start this week (the Jets rookies were the first to report, last Wednesday). With the Super Bowl champion Giants opening the regular season against the Washington Redskins on Sept. 4, here is a look at the teams to watch, for better or worse. JUDY BATTISTA

title: More Tag Sale Than Tribute
description: NOBODY ever thinks of Elvis when you say James Brown. And few people attending the Christies auction Thursday of the James Brown collection, 328 items spanning the life of the Godfather of Soul, were likely to have made a connection between two men as unalike posthumously as they were in life.

title: Zelik Mintz, James Peterson
description: Zelik Stewart Mintz was married on Monday to James Nicholas Peterson. Richard G. Ow, a deputy marriage commissioner, officiated at San Francisco City Hall.

title: Murcers Jersey Made a Journey to Outer Space
description: A friendship of a lifetime began through static.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Sunday about the presence of the retired cyclist Greg LeMond at this years Tour de France, a race he won three times, misstated the timing of his last extended visit to the event. It was in 1994, not in 1990. (Although LeMonds third Tour title came in 1990, he competed in the race as late as 1994, when he withdrew during the sixth stage.)

title: Alone in Lead, Norman Looks to Make Golf History
description: SOUTHPORT, England  The last time a golfer did what Greg Norman has a chance to do in the British Open, his name was Old Tom and the American Civil War had recently ended. So it is fitting that here in the land where 100-year-old golf courses are regarded as new, Norman is one step from rewriting his own history, and one of golfs oldest records.

title: Mrs. Corbetts Request
description: Chapter 11: Party Animals

title: Borrowers and Bankers: A Great Divide
description: THE credit crisis has exposed and worsened a dangerous and deepening divide in this country between a vast number of average borrowers and a fairly elite slice of corporations, banks and executives enriched by the mortgage mania.

title: Anatoly I. Pristavkin, 76, Russian Writer, Is Dead
description: Anatoly I. Pristavkin remembered how he and other orphans were forever shuttled about like a flock of little animals during the hell that was World War II in Russia. His scars showed in the suffering children who traipsed through many of his 26 novels, and in the toughness of his opposition to the Soviet authorities.

title: Obama Campaign Confirms Site of Berlin Speech
description: BERLIN  The Berlin beauty pageant is over. And on this Selection Sunday, the angel won.

title: As Oil Slides, Rallies for Dow and S.& P.
description: Oil prices dropped sharply last week, and the stock market rallied after four weeks of losses.

title: Obama and the Far Left
description: To the Editor:

title: Aaron and Mays: Closer Than You Think
description: A great week of All-Star baseball festivities ended fittingly with Hank Aaron and Willie Mays sharing center stage on Wednesday when Bob Costas taped a state-of-the-game panel for his HBO show, Costas Now.

title: Paying Moving-Out Fees in a Rental in a Condo
description: Paying Moving-Out Fees

title: Thievery at the Gates
description: RETURNING to her brownstone in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, after a long weekend out of town, Diane Raimondo was peeved to find the front gate left open. But as Ms. Raimondo approached her house, she realized that the heart-shaped iron gate wasnt open, but gone altogether. Someone had yanked the 60-pound gate right off the metal fence that fronted the house and carted it away.

title: Sunnis End Boycott and Rejoin Iraqi Government
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi lawmakers cleared an important hurdle on Saturday by approving the appointment of six Sunni cabinet ministers after a yearlong boycott by the Sunni political bloc.

title: Correction: Still Out There (in Movie Theaters)
description: An article last Sunday about the movie The X-Files: I Want to Believe misstated the number of years since the end of the television series on which the film is based. It ended six years ago, in 2002, not five.

title: Saves Record Seems to Be Career Closer
description: In a contract year, Francisco Rodrguez, the Angels closer, is chasing a record that possibly no one would want.

title: Eating Skillfully
description: Reader, I ate him. The hapless object of Fuchsia Dunlops confession is a small green caterpillar she discovered in her vegetable steamer one afternoon in Oxford. She nearly tossed him out the kitchen door before remembering that only weeks before in Sichuan, she had munched her way through a menu of timber grubs, bee pupae and sand-crawling caterpillars. Even the English variety looked like food to her after more than 15 years of traveling to and living in China. You are half Chinese, Dunlops friends there sometimes tell her. As I look at them out of my round Caucasian eyes, she admits, I have to acknowledge that, inside me, there is someone who is no longer entirely English.

title: Jill Jortner, Demetris Papademetriou
description: Jill Lori Jortner, the daughter of Cindy and Gary Jortner of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married on Saturday evening to Demetris A. Papademetriou, a son of Andy and Aphrodite Papademetriou of Penang, Malaysia. The Rev. Susanna Stefanachi Macomb, an interfaith minister, officiated at Capitale, an event space in Manhattan.

title: The Long Amen
description: THE REV. DON OLINGER was supposed to have delivered his last sermon months ago. By now, the bulldozers were supposed to have come through and leveled the Presbyterian Church of Astoria, an 86-year-old gray stone building that sits on a tree-lined residential street in that Queens community. Instead, Mr. Olinger has been preaching before members of the congregation every Sunday, just as he has been doing for 14 years. Only next Sunday will he deliver his final sermon in the church, after which the building will be closed permanently, in preparation for its demolition.

title: Hit by Pitch, Molina Starts a Celebration for the Yanks
description: Jos Molina carried his bat all the way down to first base, even though he did not need it. When he reached the bag, his teammates swarmed him, jumping on his back and bouncing in celebration. Without using that bat, Molina had just recorded the winning run batted in for the Yankees, ending a marathon of a game on a boiling Saturday afternoon at Yankee Stadium.

title: 9/11 and 4/11
description: I am reliably told by a Bush administration official that there is an old saying in Texas that goes like this: If all you ever do is all youve ever done, then all youll ever get is all you ever got.

title: Freire Adds Victory to His Lead as Top Sprinter
description: DIGNE-LES-BAINS, France  It turns out Mark Cavendish is beatable after all  by a mountain.

title: Soldier Boy
description: In a half-filled auditorium, a poet was reading a poem about the death of a child. Autumn leaves fell, night descended, the hours became slow and cold and endless; it was pretty sad stuff. Afterward, an audience member came up to say how much hed enjoyed the reading and how sorry he was for the poets loss. I appreciate that, the poet responded, but the thing is, Ive never had any kids. That was just a poem.

title: Rangels Rental Looking Glass
description: THE idea that anyone, let alone Representative Charles B. Rangel, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, could live in more than one rent-stabilized apartment  and be paying less than the increasingly high market-rate rents in Manhattan  may sound shocking today.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: In Vitro We Trust
description: Louise Brown turns 30 on Friday. These days, her name elicits little more than a mystified head shake. Who was she again? Let me refresh your memory: Little Louise was the worlds first test-tube baby, what we now refer to as an I.V.F. kid, or simply the twins down the block.

title: Putting the Fun Into Dysfunction
description: Dysfunction, in its various permutations, was mined by the playwright Christopher Durang well before the term entered the working lexicon of so many of his contemporaries. At the close of Act I of Beyond Therapy, Mr. Durangs zany, somewhat dated 1981 comic rant onstage at Sag Harbors Bay Street Theater, Bruce (Darren Goldstein) lets out a primal cry that echoes his own emotional free fall as well as that of the five other cast members.

title: Inartful
description: Long ago in a social-cultural community that no longer exists  Georgetown in Washington, circa 1971  dowager queens like Polly Wisner would hold small, elegant dinners with government officials and mover-shaker pundits who combined profound disagreements on policy with a civility that sometimes led to friendship.

title: The Old Beer Cans and the Sea
description: THE sand at the southern tip of New York, sad to say, is filthy. That much is clear even from a dozen feet above sea level, on the covered deck that overlooks the beach in Tottenville, the town at the bottom of Staten Island. Walk down to the beach and the picture is no prettier: the remains of a case of Coors Light, some takeout containers, and a scattering of broken glass not yet rendered charming by wear.

title: The Long Wait
description: AT first, Allen Yee was discouraged by how little $400,000 to $450,000 would buy. I felt that  impatient New Yorker  I would find something really fast, said Mr. Yee, who began his hunt for an apartment more than two years ago. I should have had more of a long-term approach in the beginning, so I wouldnt have been so exasperated.

title: East Village Rising
description: For evidence of gentrification in the East Village, one need look no farther than Second Avenue. Once an uninteresting dining scene, that stretch now offers a compelling variety in these restaurants, most of them no more than two years old.

title: Barbara Rutkowski, John Eustice
description: Barbara Eva Rutkowski and John Charles Eustice were married on Saturday at the Most Sacred Heart of Jesus Church in Wallington, N.J. The Very Rev. Felix R. Marciniak, a Roman Catholic priest and the pastor of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Liberty Has Its Moment in History, if Not a Victory
description: History arrived just before sunset Saturday on Arthur Ashe Stadium court, accompanied by summer heat and a soft, swirling breeze that has confounded and crowned more than a few of the worlds best tennis players.

title: Private Dwyers Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Weird, Wild and, Ultimately, Sublime
description: SOMETIME after midnight on a Sunday, the streets of the Myeongdong neighborhood in Seoul were quiet and cold. The young shoppers who flit from Adidas to Tommy Hilfiger to Club Monaco had gone home to study for December exams, and restaurant workers were setting barrels full of leftovers onto the curb to be picked up by early-morning garbage trucks. The city was going to sleep.

title: Conservative Thinkers Think Again
description: Almost anything can happen in an election year, but among conservatives, nearly everyone seems to agree that no matter who captures the White House in November, the movement that has ruled the Republican Party since the 1960s and mostly dominated American politics since 1980 has lost its way. Across the spectrum of the right, writers and thinkers have turned their relentless analysis inward, a kind of political EST seminar aimed at self-transformation.

title: Food and Color to Match a Sunset Kind of Place
description: MOMENTS of grace in restaurantgoing are rare, but heres one: Porch seating, a gentle breeze, enveloping colors of sunset at the Shore. Those same colors echoing in a sublime shortcake of fresh buttermilk biscuit split for a scoop of peach ice cream, a plethora of Jersey blueberries and a cone of whipped cream.

title: Palace Council
description: Hitting the Town

title: Truth, Lies and a Lot of Videotape
description: IN 1977 Brian Hall had just finished his career as a Texas Tech football player, one with a difference: His right foot had been torn off in a childhood accident, but a prosthetic leg allowed him to kick field goals. That peculiar talent earned him a spot on the game show To Tell the Truth. He came away with $167 and a few door prizes but no definitive proof that he had been on TV.

title: Heres Looking at Me, Kid
description: JAMIE LYNN SPEARS is a narcissist, to say nothing of her older sister. So is Hillary Rodham Clinton. Bill, too! Clearly, the word was created with A-Rod in mind. And who can forget Eliot Spitzer? But please, lets forget this months narcissist du headline, Peter Cook, the philandering ex-husband of the model Christie Brinkley.

title: Jean Hanna, Timothy Bickhart
description: Jean Price Hanna, the daughter of Pricie Hemphill Hanna and Colin Arthur Hanna of West Chester, Pa., was married on Saturday in Bryn Mawr, Pa., to Timothy Paul Bickhart, a son of Henrietta Groves Bickhart of King of Prussia, Pa., and the late John William Bickhart Jr. The Rev. Dr. Wesley D. Avram performed the ceremony at the Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church, where he is a pastor.

title: Janine Poreba, Paul Lieberstein
description: Janine Serafin Poreba, a daughter of Elizabeth Poreba and John Poreba of New York, was married on Saturday evening to Paul Lieberstein, a son of Judith Lieberstein and Stanley Lieberstein of Westport, Conn. The Rev. Dr. James G. Speer, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at Battery Gardens, a restaurant in New York, and Rabbi Ari Fridkis participated in the ceremony.

title: The Most Beautiful Hairbrush in the World
description: PROUST had his madeleine to unleash the powerful tide of memory. I had a nine-inch-long Mason Pearson hairbrush, bought when I was 15 at Saks Fifth Avenue, in 1973, for the then gasp-inducing sum of $25. My mother, had she known, would have had a cow; for her, a hairbrush was something picked up at the local drugstore for $1.99. But the two tens and a five, hoarded from nights of baby-sitting and weeks of allowance, passed from me to the saleswoman at Saks without my mothers awareness.

title: Somali Killings of Aid Workers Imperil Relief
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  At a time of drought, skyrocketing food prices, crippling inflation and intensifying street fighting, many of the aid workers whom millions of Somalis depend on for survival are fleeing their posts  or in some cases the country.

title: Morphing Neil Young for the Stage and Page
description: MY, my, hey, hey, Neil Youngs Greendale is here to stay.

title: Last Trains Long Gone, but Station Will Return
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS

title: Dorothy Parker, Longer and Set to Music
description: Dorothy Parker carved her niche in the annals of 20th-century American literature by writing short stories (most famously for The New Yorker in the 1920s and 30s) depicting human vulnerabilities and mocking Social Register priorities, while dropping memorable wisecracks along the way.

title: Means Testing, for Medicare
Killer Children
description: Sprinkle in some Dostoyevsky or Nietzsche or whatever. ... Then sort of wrap it up like Evangelion, the popular animated television series that pits paramilitary teenagers against enemy angels bent on destroying humankind. Worm, the cipher at the center of Natsuo Kirinos disquieting and suspenseful novel Real World and a juvenile killer on the run, is directing Terauchi, one of the four girls who become his accessories, to write a manifesto to fit the crime he has committed. Hed like it to be something creative rather than introspective, a cool and incomprehensible poem or story. Otherwise, his readers might conclude he isnt the disaffected nihilist he imagines himself to be. It doesnt have to be long, Worm tells Terauchi, but it does have to be better than what that killer Sakakibara wrote.

title: True-Lit-Hist-Myst
description: Fact and fiction do not so much blur as bleed into each other in The Suspicions of Mr. Whicher, Kate Summerscales fastidious reconstruction and expansive analysis of the Road Hill murder case, which centered on an infamous crime that had all of England reeling in the summer of 1860. In the early morning of June 29, someone crept into the nursery of Road Hill House, Samuel and Mary Kents grand home in the village of Road, and stole off with their 3-year-old son, Saville. Only hours after the alarm was raised by the nursemaid, the child was discovered, his throat deeply cut and his dead body tossed down the servants outdoor privy. It was, Summerscale says, perhaps the most disturbing murder of its time.

title: Another Meeting? Say It Isnt So
description: Q. Youre expected to attend many meetings at your company, and most of them are a big waste of time. The same people hog the floor with pointless, redundant comments, while others say nothing. The discussion inevitably goes off topic, and you start to feel trapped. Its excruciating. Can anything be done?

title: White Pizazz Without Fizz
description: Elbling, Germanys oldest grape, mostly goes into sparkling wine. Schloss Thorns limestone soil in the Mosel region, a site of an ancient seabed, yields a rare Chablis-style white.

title: Correction: Berlin, the Big Canvas
description: An article on June 22 about the art and food scenes in Berlin misspelled the name of a street. It is Tauentzienstrasse, not Taventzienstrasse.

title: Samuel Beckett, From Everywhere but the Stage
description: SAMUEL BECKETT never goes out of season at the Gate Theater in Dublin. When it comes to Beckett, Michael Colgan, director of the Gate, likes to say, Im more a missionary than a producer. His 1991 Beckett Festival at the Gate reeled in all 19 of Becketts works for the theater, from the 45-second Breath to the two-hour Waiting for Godot. An international sensation, the complete marathon played the Lincoln Center Festival in 1996.

description: PARAMUS, N.J.

description: MONTAUK

title: Western Olympic Ads Cheerlead for China
description: BEIJING  It is becoming increasingly clear which nation global corporations will be rooting for at this summers Olympics: China.

title: Meighan Stone and Seth Amgott
description: ON her first day working in Washington for the One Campaign, an antipoverty group founded by the singer Bono, Meighan Mills Stone was introduced to Seth Amgott, a slender and handsome New Yorker who sat just feet away, frenetically working the phones on behalf of their cause.

title: Yes, Lawyers Have Funny Bones
description: FLEMINGTON

title: The Panda That Roared
description: BEIJING

title: Letters: Rush Is Just Getting Warmed Up
description: In his July 6 profile, Zev Chafets writes that Rush Limbaugh fears being branded a racist, but ignores numerous examples of Limbaughs inflammatory rhetoric. Limbaugh, among other things, claimed Democrats concerned about Darfur were merely courting the black voting bloc; said this year, Democrats will bend over, grab the ankles and say, Have your way with me  to African-Americans and gays; claimed Senator Barack Obamas only chance of winning is that hes black; labeled Obama an affirmative-action candidate; and, according to The Washington Post, often played Movin on Up when referring to Carol Moseley Braun. Chafets writes that serious people have called Limbaugh a serial liar, without actually citing the abundant evidence. For example, after calling service members who support U.S. withdrawal from Iraq phony soldiers, Limbaugh vehemently denied he had done so and, to refute the charge, played a spliced audio clip of his comments, while falsely claiming he was providing the entire segment at issue.

title: The Next Kind of Integration
description: In June of last year, a conservative majority of the Supreme Court, in a 5-to-4 decision, declared the racial-integration efforts of two school districts unconstitutional. Seattle and Louisville, Ky., could no longer assign students to schools based on their race, Chief Justice John Roberts wrote in his lead opinion in Meredith v. Jefferson County School Board (and its companion case, Parents Involved in Community Schools v. Seattle School District No. 1). Justice Stephen Breyer sounded a sad and grim note of dissent. Pointing out that the court was rejecting student-assignment plans that the districts had designed to stave off de facto resegregation, Breyer wrote that to invalidate the plans under review is to threaten the promise of Brown. By invoking Brown v. Board of Education, the courts landmark 1954 civil rights ruling, Breyer accused the majority of abandoning a touchstone in the countrys efforts to overcome racial division. This is a decision that the court and the nation will come to regret, he concluded.

At one end of the bridge, a laminated sign showed gruesome photographs of crocodile victims to discourage passers-by from taking a dip. On the other, a line of mopeds waited their turn to cross the rickety overpass.

description: SYDNEY, Australia  In his final address to hundreds of thousands of young Catholics gathered in Australia on Sunday, Pope Benedict XVI attacked the violence and materialism of the modern age, and called on his audience to build a new age.

description: LOS ANGELES  The only synagogue on the Venice Beach boardwalk has weathered 80 years worth of oscillating economies, winos, shamans and aggressive panhandlers, disintegration of its own community and surf seekers on all manner of speeding wheels. It has stood as much for tolerance as faith in a community where the former is in high demand.

description: The Bush administration has been a waging a fierce battle for the power to lock people up indefinitely simply on the presidents say-so. It scored a disturbing victory last week when a federal appeals court ruled that it could continue to detain Ali al-Marri, who has been held for more than five years as an enemy combatant. The decision gives the president sweeping power to deprive anyone  citizens as well as noncitizens  of their freedom. The Supreme Court should reverse this terrible ruling.

Boys and girls enter national races when they are as young as 5, and by the time they are teenagers, top sprinters are competing before a crowd of 30,000 every year at the National Stadium.

Two days later, last Sunday evening, the Treasury secretary hurriedly announced a rescue plan for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, two companies that dominate the mortgage market.

title: Adventures in Concert Programming
description: THOMAS W. MORRIS, a former executive director of the Cleveland Orchestra and now a consultant to orchestras, is hardly nave about the tradition-bound field of classical music. He realizes that conductors of American orchestras face many pressures to play it safe in choosing programs.

description: Enough of the labyrinthine Iraq war, the interminable mortgage crisis and the plummeting economy. Lets talk about the bloody crossroads where satire goes searching for its target.

He implored the nation to stop burning dirty coal, gas and oil  in just 10 years. In a policy context, thats like sending the nation to destroy the One Ring in the fires of Mount Doom.

title: Me and My Girls
description: Where does a junkies time go? Mostly in 15-minute increments, like a bug-eyed Tarzan, swinging from hit to hit. For months on end in 1988, I sat inside a house in north Minneapolis, doing coke and listening to Tracy Chapmans Fast Car and finding my own pathetic resonance in the lyrics. Any place is better, she sang. Starting from zero, got nothing to lose.

title: Letter: The Leopard
description: To the Editor: I would like to congratulate Adam Begley on his excellent article, Sicily, Through the Eyes of the Leopard (July 6). Having been born in Siracusa, Sicily, and grown up there in the 1960s, I was made to read Il Gattopardo in high school and never appreciated it. Not sure how, but recently I found the old high-school book, reread it and loved it. The article captures, better than any I have ever read, the essence of the book, the author, the land, the people, the contradictions, the culture.

title: The Prince of Frogtown
description: The ditch cleaved frogtown into two realms, and two powerful spirits heldsway, one on each side. One was old, old as the Cross, and the other had aged only a few days in a gallon can. Both had the power to change men's lives. On one side of the ditch, a packed-in, pleading faithful fell hard to their knees and called the Holy Ghost into their jerking bodies in unknown tongues. On the other side, two boys, too much alike to be anything but brothers, flung open the doors of a black Chevrolet and lurched into the yard of 117 D Street, hallelujahs falling dead around them in the weeds. In the house, a sad-eyed little woman looked out, afraid it might be the law. When your boys are gone you're always afraid it might be the law. But it was just her two oldest sons, Roy and Troy, floating home inside the bubble of her prayer, still in crumpled, cattin'-around clothes from Saturday night, still a little drunk on Sunday morning. They were fine boys, though, beautiful boys. They were just steps away now, a few steps. She would fry eggs by the platterful and pour black coffee, and be glad they were not in a smoking hulk wrapped around a tree, or at the mercy of the police. She thought sometimes of walking over to the church to see it all, to hear the lovely music, but that would leave her boys and man unsupervised for too long. Her third son was eleven or so then. He could hear the piano ring across the ditch, even hear people shout, but he could smell the liquor that was always in the house on a Sunday and even steal a taste of it when no one was looking, so it was more real.

title: Paperback Row
description: SPOOK COUNTRY, by William Gibson. (Berkley, $15.) Gibsons first novel since Pattern Recognition abandons science fiction to consider our fragmented post-9/11 world. (Contemporary reality is like an overlapping set of dire science-fictional scenarios, Gibson has said.) His characters  a former rocker turned journalist, a member of a Cuban/Chinese crime family in New York, an amphetamine-addicted cryptographer  converge around a mysterious shipping container moving toward an unknown destination. The country he hoped was still America (as one character puts it) is buffeted by globalization, technology and the threat of terrorism, and finds itself awash in confusion and fear.

title: Letter: Bangkok District
description: To the Editor: I was very distressed that the Travel article 36 Hours: Bangkok (June 29) chose to include a trip to Patpong, the infamous red light district. First, with a mere three days in a city rich with art, culture, religion and food, why would anyone waste their time at strip clubs or buying porn? But more disturbing, why would The Times advocate visiting a part of the city that profits from the sex trade, a business that exploits men, women and children? Visitors who want that experience will find it without a tacit endorsement by The Times.

title: Loss, Impairment, Generosity and Love, With Laughs Intact

And oh, the joy as dancing forks, plates and other household items cavort to the merry tune Be Our Guest and later battle furiously against evil forces.

title: Mr. Fords T: Versatile Mobility
description: WHEN Henry Ford started to manufacture his groundbreaking Model T on Sept. 27, 1908, he probably never imagined that the spindly little car would remain in production for 19 years. Nor could Ford have foreseen that his company would eventually build more than 15 million Tin Lizzies, making him a billionaire while putting the world on wheels.

Its name is absent from the sign listing the stores within; the Starbucks logo can be found at the bottom of the pole that holds up the sign, half-hidden among the weeds.

title: Ask an Expert on Mortgages
description: Eric Tyson, M.B.A., a syndicated columnist and the best-selling co-author of "Home Buying for Dummies," "House Selling for Dummies" and "Mortgages for Dummies," will be answering 3 readers' questions about mortgages a day on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday of next week.   Eric Tyson is a best-selling personal finance book author and has penned five national best sellers (he is also the only author to have four of his books simultaneously on Business Week's business book bestseller list). Eric is a former columnist and award-winning journalist for the San Francisco Examiner.  His "Personal Finance for Dummies", which was a Wall St. Journal best-seller, won the Benjamin Franklin Award for Best Business Book of the Year. His latest book, "Let's Get Real About Money", is an action oriented guide to developing and practicing the best financial habits and strategies.  Mr. Tyson's work has been featured and quoted in hundreds of local and national publications and media outlets including Newsweek, The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, Los Angeles Times, Chicago Tribune, Forbes, Kiplinger's Personal Finance Magazine, Money, Worth, Parenting, USA Today and on the NBC Today Show, ABC, Fox News, CNBC, PBS Nightly Business Report, CNN, and on CBS national radio, NPR's Marketplace Money and Bloomberg Business Radio. He's also been a featured speaker at a White House conference on retirement planning.  In addition to his writing and counseling, Mr. Tyson also taught the nation's most highly attended personal financial management course at the University of California. He has spoken at many corporations and non-profits. Mr. Tyson earned his bachelor's degree in economics at Yale and an M.B.A. at the Stanford Graduate School of Business.

description: Location: Salt Lake City.

title: Playing Backwards
description: Bill Pennington finds that when the going gets tough, the tough go backwards.

title: The Morning Skate: The Hawks Lovefest, the Isles Candidates List and a New Sundin Rumor
description: The Sunday Skate brings us back to Chicago (we wrote about Day 1 yesterday), where Len Ziehm of the Sun Times, reporting from Day 2 of the historic Blackhawks Convention calls the event a lovefest for a team that hasnt made the playoffs in 9 of the past 10 seasons and not since 2002, and yet has their fan base growing again.

title: The Early Word: Maliki Backs Off Support of Obama Plan
description: As Senator Barack Obama continues his trip to the Middle East and Europe, Iraqi Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki has moved to clarify statements that he supports Mr. Obamas plan to withdraw most American troops from Iraq over 16 months.

title: Details, details  at Ferrari
description: Hundreds of journalists attend each Formula One race, and with tight deadlines and often difficult access to drivers and team members due to huge demand, the journalists are indebted at every race to the excellent work of the press officers and other media staff at each of the 10 Formula One teams. Few are as diligent, effective and friendly as the staff at Ferrari.

title: Tapping Retirement
description: Think Tank Central | As housing woes grip the country, more and more people are borrowing against their 401(k)s, the Center for American Progress says. True, loans are up in part because more people have such plans. Still, the trend amounts to robbing Peter, tomorrows retiree, to pay the same Peters bills today. [Center for American Progress]

title: Obama Visits Troops in Kuwait
description: Barack Obama visited, and played basketball with, American troops in Kuwait before heading to Afghanistan and Iraq. (Video via NBC)

title: The Most Intriguing Matchup of the Series
description: Remember the Mike Pelfrey who started the season 2-6? The Mike Pelfrey who seemed like weak link in the Mets rotation and forever seemed in danger of falling off the end of it?

title: Savings and loan memories
description: Overall, Im fine with this article on too big to fail. But I think its unfair to George Bush the elder, because it makes the savings and loan rescue seem like a discretionary decision that Reagan the pure wouldnt have made.

title: McCain Through the Yankee Prism
description: When the New York Yankees and the Arizona Diamondbacks played each other in the emotional World Series in 2001, with the deadly attacks on the Twin Towers still fresh in the nations memory, then-mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Senator John McCain of Arizona attended games together in New York and Phoenix. On Sunday they reprised that buddy act at Yankee Stadium, in circumstances that were much more congenial  and with no direct personal rivalry, political or baseball-related, at stake any longer.

title: Russia Names Its Track and Field Team
description: Russia, the United States main rival for Olympic medals in track and field, announced its athletics team for the Beijing Games today, following the conclusion of the All-Russia athletics trials in Kazan, Tatarstan, on Sunday. The list is in Russian here and in English here. Or you can just read it below.

title: Tanglewood Contemporary Festival: A Carterfest in Good (Though Different) Hands
description: LENOX, Mass.  The Festival of Contemporary Music at Tanglewood is usually a modernist free-for-all, with contemporary classics performed alongside fresh new works, and composers widely spaced in age, stature and style sharing programs. Last summer, that changed: the composer John Harbison, who directed the festival, devoted it almost exclusively to composers born in (or around) 1938, the year of his own birth.

title: Blogging Conference Notes
description: From Al Gore to Bob Barr, the blogging conferences this past weekend in Austin offered an evolutionary sense of the online world as it courses through presidential and local politics in 2008.

title: Chinese Architecture
description: Architecture | A blog takes issue with all the critical praise heaped on Beijings Olympics-inspired architecture. It asks: whats all this stuff cost? The Chinese government is accountable to no one  there are no committees of scrutineers eager to declare political failure for cost overruns. And are we saying totalitarianism can be a vital cradle of innovation? [Things Magazine]

title: Living in Amityville, L.I.
description: Amityville, on Long Island's south shore, is a haven for water lovers, with access to beaches and four private yacht clubs.

description: There seems to be a kumbaya moment occurring on the conservative front, and its one that would apply a salve to Senator John McCains uneven, unsettled relationship with the religious right.

title: Designing a New Model T
description: Young designers offered their visions for a 21st century version of the original car for the masses.

title: Basketball: Nowitzki Helps Germany Claim Final Spot
description: Germany won the 12th and final spot in the Olympic basketball tournament by beating Puerto Rico, 96-82, in the FIBA qualifying tournament in Athens. The Dallas Mavericks star Dirk Nowitzki scored 32 points to lead the Germans, who last made the Olympic field in Barcelona in 1992. Nowitzki, 30, was the tournaments top scorer, averaging 26.6 points in five games. He was 14 the last time Germany played in the Games.

description: More campaign-related opinion for Sunday, July 20:

title: Clinton Put In $1 Million More
description: Updated | 11:35 p.m. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton lent her campaign another $1 million at the end of June, underscoring the difficulty she was having staying ahead of creditors and retiring a mountain of campaign debt, filings with the Federal Election Commission show.

title: Harrington Wins 2008 British Open
description: Padraig Harrington came from two strokes back to defend his British Open title.

title: More on Legal Issues After Layoffs
description: I got a lot of good questions from readers after last weeks pieces about post-layoff activities  specifically disparaging remarks online and starting new businesses that potentially compete with a former employer  that can cause legal troubles for former employees.

Senate Democrats Extend Fund-Raising Lead
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats extended their sizable financial advantage in this years Congressional races in the last quarter, according to new campaign finance data to be made public on Monday.

title: Deep Divisions in Mens Tennis Are Likely to Be Exposed at Trial
description: The executive chairman of the ATP, tienne de Villiers, and his general counsel warned executives at the sports marketing giant IMG that their business would suffer if they testified against the ATP in an antitrust lawsuit, according to a letter written by IMGs senior counsel.

description: Washington

title: Comment Stings Iraqi Leader on Eve of Obama Visit
description: BAGHDAD  On the eve of Senator Barack Obamas visit to Iraq, its prime minister tried to step back Sunday from comments in an interview in which he appeared to support Mr. Obamas plan for troop withdrawal.

title: News Flash From the Cover of Esquire: Paper Magazines Can Be High Tech, Too
description: On the third floor of the Museum of Modern Art in Midtown Manhattan rests a tribute to Esquires glory years  a collection of 92 covers from the 1960s and early 1970s that have become, in the museums words, essential to the iconography of American culture.

title: No Substitute for Victory
description: Ill go out on a limb and say that Barack Obama will be well received when he speaks in Berlin on July 24.

title: Weaker on Paper, but Making a Push
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The baseball version of a teachable moment, Minnesota Twins style, happened a little more than a month into the season. As has often been the case this year, the student was Carlos Gmez, Minnesotas exciting but erratic center fielder.

title: Corrections
description: A report in The Caucus column on Friday about Senator Barack Obamas trips to the gym misstated, in one reference, the name of a fitness center in Chicago where he usually plays basketball. It is the East Bank Club, not the East End Club.

title: Rapper Is Accused in Hospital Fraud
description: The rapper DMX was arrested at a Phoenix shopping mall Saturday on suspicion of giving a false name and Social Security number to a hospital to avoid paying for medical expenses, The Associated Press reported. Sheriff Joe Arpaio of Maricopa County said that when DMX, whose real name is Earl Simmons, went to the Mayo Clinic in Scottsdale, Ariz., in April, he used the name Troy Jones and failed to pay a $7,500 bill. Sherriff Arpaio said his office had been investigating the case before DMX, 37, was arrested in May on drug possession and animal cruelty charges; in that case, the authorities seized 12 pit bulls and dug up the remains of three others at his home in north Phoenix. Sherriff Arpaio said the bond had not been set in the most recent arrest. DMXs lawyer, Cameron Morgan, declined to comment.

title: Rising Value of a Vote in a Struggling Economy
description: Senator Barack Obama is commanding headlines this week from Baghdad to Berlin. But the central front in his war for the White House with Senator John McCain remains communities back home like Warren, Mich.; Columbus, Ohio; and Wilkes-Barre, Pa.

title: Defining a First Ladys Public Image
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton put the first in First Lady: A modern career woman who weighed in on policy in the White House, took on political enemies, and then became a senator and presidential candidate herself.

title: The FedEx Guy, and 2 Movie Producers
description: LOS ANGELES  As the founder of FedEx, Frederick W. Smith has been celebrated as one of the smartest minds in business. So why, at a time when American investors are avoiding Hollywood, does he keep pouring millions into movies?

title: At Busy South Bronx Pool, an Unlikely Team Keeps the Peace
description: He is known by the name tattooed on his left arm: Scorpio. He favors diamond earrings and designer sunglasses. He takes pills to control his angry outbursts, and sometimes carries a pistol, a .22 or a .45, depending on his mood.

title: Molinas Strong Play Underscores Posadas Tenuous Status
description: Every time Yankees catcher Jos Molina throws the ball, it is a reminder of how much stronger his arm is than Jorge Posadas. The proof of Molinas arm strength came when he caught Rajai Davis trying to steal second to end Sundays 2-1 victory over the Oakland Athletics.

title: After 2000 Run, McCain Learned to Work Levers of Power
description: Senator John McCain was all but a sworn enemy of Senator Trent Lott, the former Republican leader.

title: Joseph E. Fields, Conductor, Composer and Pianist, Is Dead at 53
description: Joseph E. Fields, a pianist, conductor and composer who was a former music director and principal conductor of Dance Theater of Harlem, died on July 4 in Scranton, Pa. He was 53 and had homes in Scranton and New York City.

title: Canadian TV Import Draws Viewers
description: With good ratings for the premiere of Flashpoint, a police drama produced with a Canadian television network, CBS says it will consider importing other shows and concepts. The pilot of Flashpoint, which is filmed and set in Toronto, was produced by CTV in Canada last year. With CBS as a co-producer, the show had its debut in Canada and the United States on July 11, making it the first Canadian series to be broadcast simultaneously in both countries since Due South in 1994. On CBS it was the most popular program of the night, with 8.1 million viewers. Speaking at the summer press tour for critics, Nina Tassler, president of CBS Entertainment, said, Its a global playground. One of CBSs shows coming this fall, The Ex List, is based on the Israeli drama Mythological Ex.

title: A Hot Afternoon of Musical Praise
description: Hes been very gracious, Chanelle Haynes, a member of Trin-i-tee 5:7, said early in its set at Central Park SummerStage on Saturday afternoon. Worked us very hard. Very hard. This all-female trio was a last-minute addition to the days gospel revue, and the singers were in a thankful mood.

title: 4 Brooklyn Neighborhoods Lose Power
description: At 4:05 p.m. on Sunday, the National Weather Service extended a heat advisory for New York City, telling residents to avoid sun exposure, drink plenty of fluids and stay in air-conditioned rooms.

title: Duel at the Junior Team Trial, a Ticket to Beijing at Stake
description: At the Summer North American Bridge Championships in Las Vegas the final of the Grand National Teams was played on Sunday. The defending champions from Florida, Michael Becker, Warren Spector, David Berkowitz, Larry Cohen, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell, played against New England, Sheila Gabay, Lloyd Arvedon, Doug Doub, Victor King, Franklin Merblum and John Stiefel.

description: Chicago

description: PARIS

description: DURHAM, N.C.  Anyone who tells you that dance is a universal language has never been to a Japanese dance sampler. Imagine a Japanese game show as a choreographed number, and you get the idea: strangeness rules.

description: What Mary Lou Skok would have given for a cellphone camera in 1936, when she and other United States Olympians were bused to a convention hall in Berlin to hear the chancellor of Germany, Adolf Hitler, speak.

description: Paris
