title: A Playlist by Rick Moody
description: (Photo: Rick Moody (Thatcher Keats))   Rick Moody's most recent book is "Right Livelihoods," a collection of novellas.   Rick Moody's July 2008 Playlist:   Some Songs I Like:  1) Wyatt's Song of Reproach, by Robin Williamson ("The Iron Stone"). Some people are skeptical about the recent work of Robin Williamson, a onetime cornerstone of the Incredible String Band, but I am not one of these people. This is folky, yes, but it has a strange, jazzy feeling to it, like it was arranged and recorded quickly, which it was. But there's a luminous, otherworldly tenderness about the adult work of Williamson, and this is a good place to start.  2) Variant I Processional March, by Frank Zappa ("Wazoo"). Eventually, this became "Regyptian Strut," which was released on Sleep Dirt, after Warner Brothers deep-sixed Zappa's gigantic multi-disc album Lther, including this and many other things. Before all that, Frank was playing a few gigs with an enormous jazz orchestra that he conducted himself. This arrangement features the tambourine of late '60s rock 'n' roll, but it's also got beautiful horn charts, and, like Zappa's best work, is full of off-kilter joy.  3) Bright Phoebus, Blue Murder ("Shining Bright: The Songs of Lal and Mike Waterson"). I owe this discovery to John Wesley Harding, a k a Wesley Stace, with whom I have been singing it recently. It's from that great period of the British folk revival, the mid-'60s, the period that also brought us Martin Carthy, Jackson C. Frank (see below), and, in a way, Simon and Garfunkel.   4) Empty Cupboard, Carla Kihlstedt ("2 Foot Yard"). The most interesting and incisive violin player in America ("Tin Hat," "Sleepytime Gorilla Museum," "Book of Knots") proves that she's also a really awesome singer.   5) A Sweeter Way to Say Goodbye, Hannah Marcus ("From English Planes"). You will have to take my word on this one, because it's not released. Hannah Marcus is one of the finest songwriters working today, the equal not only of Jolie Holland, Fiona Apple, Will Oldham, etc., but, on a good day, the equal of Mitchell, Cohen and, yes, that guy from Minnesota. No, not exaggerating. The lyrics here are brutal and very contemporary, and the music is timeless and understated. And if you want to hear it, you'll just have to write me or Hannah.   6) If 6 Was 9, World Saxophone Quartet ("Experience"). I really like their version of "Mannish Boy," too.   7) Singing Sailors, Jackson C. Frank, Blues Run the Game. From the deluxe CD reissue of one of the finest lost albums of '60s folk music. This expanded edition has some examples of Frank's later songs, from when he had a great variety of personal problems and couldn't put his best foot forward. This song is so sad it's almost impossible to listen to. But it also tells you more about what it feels like to have your best work behind than almost anything else. Anywhere.  8) I Found You, Gene Clark ("Echoes"). With Gene Clark, best known for his time with the Byrds, the lyrics are always elusive, and you have to work hard with the songs to understand. See, for example, "Eight Miles High." Is it about his fear of flying? Acid? The music business? This is a more straightforward love song, of which he wrote a few, but that doesn't stop it, as in some of Brian Wilson's compositions, from hinting at so much discomfort that it shimmers with paradoxes.   9) I Will Be Sad, Billy Tipton Memorial Saxophone Quartet ("Saxhouse"). Another great sax quartet, all women, organized by Jessica Lurie and Amy Denio, two splendid and versatile musicians from the Northwest. They have made a lot of great albums since this relatively early cut, all of them quite wonderful.  10) Ghetto Raga, The Third Ear Band ("Alchemy"). I can't remember where I heard this first, but the Third Ear Band is mostly famous for having scored Roman Polanski's film of Macbeth, a movie that had a great impact on me when I first saw it in high school. The instrumentation was eccentric  percussion, violin, woodwinds  and they played mostly improvised music, which must have sounded unusual to listeners back in Swinging London. But when they got the mood right, as in this long Indian-style drone, the results were eerie and memorable.  11) First Light, Richard and Linda Thompson ("Dreams Fly Away"). There's a band version of this song on the album of the same name, but the band version scarcely hints at the spiritual ambition of the song, which needed to wait until the release of a Linda Thompson greatest hits package for its glory to be apparent. This guitar-and-voices arrangement instead displays the uncanny harmonies of these two astonishing singers at the moment of their devotion to Sufism. It's gospel of a different sort, therefore, with all the drama of that genre.   12) Horizontal Technicolor, David Grubbs ("Two Soundtracks for Angela Bullock"). Nepotism, sure, because I play with Grubbs, and have written lyrics for him, though he doesn't need the help. I admire his challenging, abstract, experimental compositions greatly, however, and this is a particularly compelling example. A long investigation of the inherent properties of the wah pedal. It verges on the terrain of the great drone-metal band Earth, but is, in a way, far more delicate. Perfect writing music.   13) Blackwater's Side, The Clancy Brothers ("In Concert"). My mother played the Clancy Brothers a lot when I was a kid. She's Irish, by derivation. This is a very melancholy ballad, something the Irish do like no one else. "That's not a promise you made to me / When you laid upon my breast. / You could make me believe with your lying tongue / That the sun rose in the West." They don't write them like this anymore.   14) Poppy Nogood And the Phantom Band, Terry Riley ("Poppy Nogood: All Night Flight"). A very, very early tape loop performance by one of the great masters of the form, and the man who single-handedly launched the genre of Minimalism.   15) Mexican Blues, Jolie Holland ("Springtime Can Kill You"). Jolie Holland veers between coy if stunningly virtuosic vocal mannerisms that suggest jazz and tin pan alley and much more direct compositions that come from folk, Old Time and rock 'n' roll. The latter tendency, to these ears, is devastating, and this is one such example. A love song to a friend, "Mexican Blues" is so haunting that it never fails to make me weep. How lucky the friend to be its recipient.  16) Are You Glad to Be In America?, James "Blood" Ulmer ("Odyssey"). A question still worth asking.   17) First Girl I Loved, Incredible String Band ("The Chelsea Sessions"). And now Robin Williamson (see #1, above), as a very young man, writing about when he was even younger. Certainly among the most affecting love songs in the folk music canon, presented in its demo form.   18) Hard Time Killing Floor Blues, Skip James ("Heroes of the Blues"). The whole game of lists is facetious, yes, I agree. It's something for boys to do when they have too much times on their hands. But when I am indulging in the nonsense of list-making, and it occurs to me, with utmost bravado, that it is time to name the best song ever, this is often the song I choose (although "God Only Knows," by the Beach Boys, is close). I have read that Skip James was an unhappy and temperamental person. I submit that he was unhappy and temperamental because what he was able to do with just voice and guitar was so vulnerable and terrifying that it was hard for him to be alive and feel this openness to the horrors of this world. This song does what a song must do, move, edify, illuminate, and without ever being obvious or sentimental about it.

title: Great Lawn: A Bubble of History Bursts
description: Here is an official history of attendance at great public gatherings in Central Park: James Taylor played in Central Parks Sheep Meadow in the summer of 1979, and officials announced that 250,000 people came. A year later, Elton John performed on the Great Lawn, and the authorities said he drew 300,000 people. Then Simon and Garfunkel performed in September 1981, and city officials and organizers reported that 400,000 people had packed into the park. Ten years later, it was announced that Paul Simon drew 600,000. The biggest concert of all, it seems, was by Garth Brooks, on Aug. 7, 1997, at the North Meadow, with a reported attendance of 750,000 people.

title: The Worlds a Stage for Interactive Entertainment as Creativity Glows
description: For a gamer or someone who is merely curious about the future of interactive entertainment, there is still no place better than E3, the annual game industry conference in Los Angeles. The business is surging both financially and in cultural relevance, and over four days at E3 last week it was obvious why: the level of creative talent in games has never been higher, and publishers around the world have finally come to realize that it makes far more sense to spend a few extra millions to create a top-notch game than to rush a subpar product out the door.

title: A Production Venture for a Film Director
description: M. Night Shyamalan is venturing out from behind the camera. Media Rights Capital, an independent film, television and digital studio, has announced the formation of the Night Chronicles, a new financing and production company in partnership with Mr. Shyamalan. He will oversee development and production at the company, which plans to produce one film a year over three years. The films will be based on stories and ideas from the director of The Sixth Sense and most recently The Happening. He will also be an owner of the films copyrights and retain artistic control while Media Rights Capital will engage distribution for each film.

title: Estelle Getty, Golden Girls Matriarch, Dies at 84
description: Estelle Getty, whose portrayal of a crabbily charming octogenarian on the television sitcom The Golden Girls gave new prominence to elderly characters in prime time and endeared her to viewers of all ages, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. She was 84.

title: Rwanda Also Awaits Justice
description: The arrest of Radovan Karadzic brings one of the most-wanted war criminals of the 1990s within reach of an international tribunal. But a year before one of the most serious crimes he is charged with  the massacre of 8,000 Muslims in Srebrenica  however, a horrible slaughter was unfolding in another part of the world, where the wheels of justice have churned even more slowly.

title: Two Oils, New and Unexpected
description: A couple of unexpected new oils can highlight a variety of dishes. Coffee oil, made by extracting the oils of roasted Guatemalan Antigua beans and mixing them with Spanish extra virgin olive oil, has a nutty, coffee aroma and a subtly spicy flavor hinting at espresso. It works on grilled salmon, roasted carrots or duck, and a drizzle will enhance a cheese like ricotta. Try it on your morning toast instead of butter. An 8.4-ounce bottle is $35 at Dean & DeLuca stores and deandeluca.com.

title: At the Movies Announces New Hosts
description: Ben Lyons and Ben Mankiewicz will take over as hosts of the nationally syndicated movie review show At the Movies, Variety reported on Tuesday. The announcement follows the news on Monday that the film critics Richard Roeper and Roger Ebert will not be returning to the Disney-ABC program next season. Mr. Lyons is a movie critic for E!, the entertainment channel, and Mr. Mankiewicz hosts shows for Turner Classic Movies as well as Sirius Satellite Radio. The new season begins the weekend of Sept. 6.

title: Speculators Arent Driving Up Oil Prices, Report Says
description: As Congress debates how to curtail the role of speculators and rein in rising oil prices, a federal task force said Tuesday that it had so far found no evidence that those investors are systematically pushing up the cost of energy.

description: United Airlines and US Airways said on Tuesday that they would cut even more deeply into their flying during the fourth quarter, while JetBlue Airways said it would defer more aircraft deliveries, steps the carriers attributed to record prices for jet fuel.

description: BEIJING  Chinese investigators have found no evidence that fatal explosions on two public buses in the southwestern city of Kunming were terrorist attacks linked to the Beijing Olympics, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said on Tuesday.

title: Savage Loses Advertisers
description: A group of seven Mississippi talk radio stations owned by Telesouth Communications has dropped Michael Savages nationally syndicated radio program over comments the host made last week suggesting that nearly every child with autism was a brat of inattentive parents. Michael Savages comments about autistic children were beyond inexcusable and are unacceptable, the station group said in a statement posted Tuesday on its Web site, supertalkms.com. The cancellation follows the decision on Monday by Aflac, the insurance company, to pull its advertising from the show. On his Web site, Michaelsavage.com, the host posted a letter on Monday in which he iterated the central point he said he had been trying to make on his July 16 program: that autism is too often misdiagnosed in the cases of children, or falsely diagnosed, at least partly as a means of wringing resources. Let the truly autistic be treated, he wrote. Let the falsely diagnosed be free. On July 16, Mr. Savage, above, referred to autism as a fraud, a racket, and asserted that what 99 percent of children with autism most needed was a parent willing to tell them things like, Dont act like a moron. Mark Masters, chief executive of Talk Radio Network, which syndicates Mr. Savages program to more than 350 stations, did not return messages left at his office seeking comment.

Broodmares Legacy

Nearly 20 years after she became the third filly to win the Kentucky Derby, she had yet to produce anything close to a horse of her quality. But there was still some hope out there: an unraced 2-year-old filly named Ocean Colors.

title: Athlete Bio: Carmelo Anthony
description: Carmelo Anthony attended Syracuse for one year, leading the Orange to the N.C.A.A. title as a freshman. He was the third overall pick in the 2003 N.B.A. draft by the Denver Nuggets. The season before Anthony arrived, Denver had a 17-65 record, the worst in the league. In Anthonys rookie season, the Nuggets went 43-39 and made the playoffs. A two-time All-Star, Anthony has averaged at least 20.8 points a game in each of his five seasons, with a high of 28.9 in 2006-7. He was a member of the United States Olympic team in 2004, averaging 2.4 points a game as the team finished with a disappointing bronze medal. At the 2006 FIBA World Championship, the United States again won the bronze medal, but this time Anthony averaged 19.9 points. He scored 35 points against Italy, setting the United States single-game record.

But the entire parliamentary process was tainted by allegations of bribery made on the floor of the house.

title: Athlete Bio: Usain Bolt
description: Usain Bolt of Jamaica has emerged as a contender to be tracks greatest triple-threat sprinter. He holds the world record in the 100 meters, was second in the 200 in the 2007 world championships, and has run close to 45 seconds in the 400, an event that many believe, given his long stride and physical strength, is potentially his best race. Bolt, who turns 22 in August, served notice of his talents as a 15-year-old when he won the world junior championships in the 200 in 20.61 seconds. But he did not become an acknowledged force until June 2007, when he ran a personal-best 19.75 in Kingston, Jamaica, tying him for the ninth-fastest time in the event. He followed that a little more than a month later with a second-place finish in the 200 at the world championships in Osaka, Japan, running 19.91 to the American Tyson Gays 19.76. His meteoric rise was just beginning. In early May 2008, after having run only a handful of competitive 100s, he entered the event in Kingston as a speed workout. He ran 9.76, the second-fastest time in history, behind his countryman Asafa Powells 9.74. Then, on the last day of May, he set the record, 9.72, beating Gay at the Reebok Grand Prix in New York.

title: Gossip Girl Lifts Ban
description: The tumultuous lives of Blair, Serena, Chuck and their wealthy New York friends will return to the Internet after a decision by the CW network to lift a ban on streaming its show Gossip Girl online, TV Week reported. The president of CW Entertainment, Dawn Ostroff, confirmed that her network reversed a decision, made in April, to stop streaming episodes on its Web site, cwtv.com. The network was experimenting with whether the ban would improve the shows Nielsen ratings, but numbers for the show did not rise significantly.

title: Creating a Wave and Riding It to Films Pantheon
description: Jean-Luc Godards name has always inspired both love and hate. Some shout hurrah and some shout humbug, but almost no one disagrees that at a crucial point in film history, he forced audiences to consider that film might, just might, actually be an important art form. (And not necessarily the one they thought it was.) In Everything Is Cinema, Richard Brody reopens the arguments, lifting Mr. Godard out of the 1960s and placing him where he rightfully belongs: ahead of the game.

title: Canada: Railway Posts Decline in Profit
description: The Canadian Pacific Railway said second-quarter profit fell 40 percent and cut its full-year profit forecast as fuel costs rose and a slumping economy reduced traffic. Net income fell to 154.9 million Canadian dollars ($154 million), from 256.7 million Canadian dollars, the company said. Sales rose less than 1 percent to 1.22 billion Canadian dollars. Canadian Pacific, based in Calgary, has been hurt by the economic slowdown in the United States, where it gets a fifth of its revenue. Automakers, builders and lumber companies are shipping less freight. The railroad also lost business because of flooding in the United States and an increase of 34 percent in its fuel costs. The quarter was volatile, the chief executive, Frederick J. Green, said in an interview. Mr. Green, above, said he did not expect a revival in the second half of the year, and the company forecast full-year earnings of 4 to 4.20 Canadian dollars a share, down from its earlier estimate of 4.40 to 4.60 Canadian dollars.

title: High School Musical Drops in Ratings
description: Day 2 of ABCs new reality series High School Musical: Get in the Picture sank further in the ratings on Monday after a low-rated debut one night earlier. It drew just 3.2 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. ABC finished a distant fourth for the night, as neither of the networks other offerings Monday night fared much better. ABC earned only 3.3 million viewers at 10 for The Mole and just 3.1 million at 9 for its new game show Wanna Bet?, from the creators of NBCs Singing Bee. CBS led the night thanks to decent ratings for repeats of its comedy lineup, followed by CSI: Miami at 10 (8.2 million). Fox was a close second with reruns of Bones at 8 (6.4 million) and House at 9 (7.8 million). NBC ranked third, broadcasting American Gladiators at 8 (5.1 million) followed by Nashville Star at 9 (5.8 million) and Dateline at 10 (5.1 million).

He has taken to the comedy-club stage again, both in Los Angeles and at the annual Just for Laughs festival this month in Montreal, where he headlined a stand-up show, as well as performing unannounced at other festival shows around town. title: A Wild One at Shea
description: Even with Johan Santana pitching eight superb innings, even with the Mets leading by three runs heading into the ninth, and even with first place just three outs away, I think it would have been difficult to find anyone in the Shea Stadium press box who did not expect Billy Wagner's unavailability to prove an obstacle, or at least prepare for the possibility.  That is how baseball works, I've learned. It's humbled many, many a player and lowly writers like myself. Just when you think an important development of the day will play only a minor role in the outcome, you see Duaner Sanchez give up three straight hits to begin the ninth. You learn that Wagner was, despite what he suggested before the game, not even close to being an option. You realize that as soon as Shane Victorino homers in the seventh, turning a four-run deficit into a three-run deficit -- a save situation -- the baseball gods are going to interfere. And pretty soon it all happens.  Considering the Mets' lacking a true closer Tuesday, much will be made about Jerry Manuel's decision to yank Santana for a pinch-hitter after eight innings. Santana had thrown at least 105 pitches, his magic number Tuesday, in 10 other starts. Could he have pitched the ninth? Sure. I'd bet on that. And, by that point, with the Mets up by three, the benefits of lifting Santana for a pinch-hitter may not have outweighed the potential reward of him resting the bullpen and finishing off a complete game that would boost the Mets into first place. But if you're Manuel, don't you have to believe that your bullpen could get three outs before the Phillies score three runs? He said afterward that he thought so.   There was so much else I could have gotten into in my story that you'll see online, but I've always been fascinated by coincidences, recurring themes, bizarre things, patterns, etc.   For instance, the last time the Mets lost after leading by three or more runs heading into the ninth inning was on Sept. 20, 2007, in Florida ... when Wagner was unavailable because of back spasms. Or how the Mets have now lost three times when leading after eight innings, twice when Santana has pitched. Or how the Phillies have now scored in the ninth inning in three straight games with the Mets, going ahead twice and nearly winning the third time, in that unforgettable game on July 7. And yet, as I look over the box score once more, it seems a little unfair that Joe Smith, who faced one batter and gave up a fielder's choice on a play that should have yielded an out, was credited with the loss -- and not Sanchez or Pedro Feliciano. Such is baseball, yet again.

title: The Quad Countdown: No. 37 Notre Dame
description: Location: South Bend, Ind.  Nickname: Fighting Irish. Is this nickname offensive? Discuss.  (Photo: Charlie Weis is not the only one anxiously waiting to see how Notre Dame will perform this season. (Bill Haber/Associated Press))   Quick facts: The Irish have won 10 games seven times in the last 30 seasons. Over the same time span, Fresno State also has seven seasons with at least 10 victories, Clemson has six and Air Force and Syracuse have five. I'm just trying to make a point here: outside of the tremendous teams under Lou Holtz from 1988-1993 (including the 1988 national champs), Notre Dame has been rather pedestrian. So why do so many college football fans take such delight in watching the Irish fail? Is hatred of the Fighting Irish something that is handed down from father to son, generation to generation? And why will most loyal readers of the Countdown have a conniption about Notre Dame's ranking on this list?   Tidbit: Let's just get this out of the way. How bad was Notre Dame a season ago? The nine losses were the most in program history. The 0-5 opening was the worst start in program history. The loss to Navy in early November was their first setback in the series in 44 years; Notre Dame's loss to Air Force a week later marked the first time the Irish had lost to two service academies in the same season since 1944. Those two losses contributed to a 1-6 home record, also the worst in program history. The Irish averaged 16.4 points and 242.2 yards per game, two of the worst totals in program history. O.K., we get it. It was the worse year in the long and illustrious history of Notre Dame football. Let's move on to next season.  Tidbit (positives edition): A little more than a week ago, in the Countdown's profile of Michigan, we pointed out the Wolverines' place as the winningest team (869) in F.B.S. history, as well as the program with the highest winning percentage (.743). Notre Dame is second in both victories (824) and winning percentage (.738), and has the fewest losses (279) of any team with more than 100 years' experience. The Irish have 12 recognized national championships, the most of any F.B.S. program.  Tidbit (recruiting edition): According to the good people at Rivals.com, Notre Dame Coach Charlie Weis is a huge upgrade over his predecessor, the current Washington coach Ty Willingham  at least when it comes to recruiting. Willingham's final three classes (2003-5) averaged a ranking of 28th (12th, 32nd and 40th, respectively), while Weis has averaged a ranking of sixth (eighth, eighth and second from 2006-8). On the other hand, Weis's successful two-year stretch from 2005-6 (19-6 over all) was largely accomplished using Willingham's key players, such as quarterback Brady Quinn, wide receiver Jeff Samardzija and running back Darius Walker.   Former players in the N.F.L.: 51  DE Victor Abiamiri (Philadelphia Eagles), WR Arnaz Battle (San Francisco 49ers), DE Bertrand Berry (Arizona Cardinals), OL Jordan Black (Houston Texans), LB Rocky Boiman (Philadelphia Eagles), DT Darrell Campbell (Tampa Bay Buccaneers), TE John Carlson (Seattle Seahawks), K John Carney (Kansas City Chiefs), TE Jerome Collins (Giants), S Deke Cooper (Atlanta Falcons), S Glenn Earl (Houston Texans), OL Jeff Faine (Tampa Bay Buccaneers), TE Anthony Fasano (Miami Dolphins), RB Tony Fisher (Jets), TE Marcus Freeman (Giants), DE Chris Frome (Chicago Bears), OL Mike Gandy (Arizona Cardinals), WR David Givens (Tennessee Titans), RB Ryan Grant (Green Bay Packers), OL Ryan Harris (Denver Broncos), P Ryan Hentrich (Tennessee Titans), WR Carlyle Holiday (Green Bay Packers), LB Grant Irons (Oakland Raiders), RB Julius Jones (Seattle Seahawks), DT Derek Landri (Jacksonville Jaguars), DT Trevor Laws (Philadelphia Eagles), OL Mark LeVoir (St. Louis Rams), DT Lance Legree (New Orleans Saints), OL Travis Leitko (Indianapolis Colts), OL Sean Mahan (Pittsburgh Steelers), LB Corey Mays (Cincinnati Bengals), OL Jim Molinaro (Dallas Cowboys), S Chinedum Ndukwe (Cincinnati Bengals), TE John Owens (Detroit Lions), OL Luke Pettigout (Tampa Bay Buccaneers), QB Brady Quinn (Cleveland Browns), CB Mike Richardson (New England Patriots), OL Mike Rosenthal (Miami Dolphins), CB Allen Rossum (San Francisco 49ers), OL Dan Santucci (Cincinnati Bengals), S Gerome Sapp (Baltimore Ravens), P Hunter Smith (Indianapolis Colts), OL Dan Stevenson (Houston Texans), WR Maurice Stovall (Tampa Bay Buccaneers), OL John Sullivan (Minnesota Vikings), DE Justin Tuck (Giants), RB Darius Walker (Houston Texans), DE Anthony Weaver (Houston Texans), DE Renaldo Wynn (Giants), DE Bryant Young (San Francisco 49ers), S Tom Zbikowski (Baltimore Ravens).  Famous alumni (non-football related): The TV talk show hosts Regis Philbin and Phil Donahue; the Pulitzer Prize-winning author Edwin O'Connor ("The Last Hurrah"); the actor George Wendt; Congressman Peter King of New York; the legendary sportswriter Red Smith.    Team Information  Conference: Independent.  Head coach: Charlie Weis ('78 Notre Dame), 22-15 after three seasons at his alma mater. Weis was a speech and drama major as an undergraduate, perhaps the reason why his sideline outbursts are so  well, colorful. A longtime N.F.L. assistant before taking on the Notre Dame job, coaching 10 years under Bill Parcells (1990-92 with the Giants, 1993-96 with Patriots, 1997-1999 with the Jets) and another five under Bill Belichick (2000-4 with the Patriots), Weis won four Super Bowls as an assistant (1990 with the Giants, 2001 and 2003-4 with the Patriots)  including the last three as offensive coordinator  and participated in another (1996 with the Patriots). Perhaps his most acclaimed coaching job came in 2001, when Weis broke in an unproven, inexperienced quarterback (one Tom Brady) while orchestrating the Patriots offense to a Super Bowl title. When it comes to his tenure at Notre Dame, let's start with the positives: after inheriting a program in disarray following the firing of Willingham, Weis led the Irish to back-to-back B.C.S. game appearances (justified or not) en route to setting a Notre Dame record with 19 victories in his first two seasons as head coach. He created an offense, led by Quinn, that was among the best in Notre Dame history (a program-record 440 points scored in 2005). That 2005 season (a 9-3 finish) earned Weis the National Coach of the Year award. Last fall's 3-9 debacle took much of the shine off his tremendous two-year run, leaving many Irish fans wondering about the direction of the program. Another poor season would place his job firmly in jeopardy. Weis, whose gargantuan $4 million contract (the largest contract in the F.B.S., eat your heart out Kirk Ferentz) runs through 2015, is only a half game better than Willingham (21-15 from 2002-4) through three seasons. Though he is an upgrade over Willingham  especially in recruiting  that record raises some questions. Seat temperature check: humid.  2007 record: 3-9, the most losses in program history. We already rehashed the overwhelming evidence in support of 2007 being the worst season in Irish history (well, Notre Dame history; it still trails the Great Famine by a wide margin), but there were a few bright points in an otherwise forgettable campaign. The sophomore quarterback Jimmy Clausen  the player everyone seems to root against  had one of the better freshman seasons for a quarterback in N.D. history, while the Irish got solid receiving play from the underclassmen Duval Kamara, Robby Parris and George West. The defense received inspired play from end Trevor Laws, as well as typically hard-nosed action from safety Tom Zbikowski. The punting game was also strong, as Geoff Price graduated with the program's second-best career average. O.K., so we're reaching a bit. Though the season may not have begun with national title hopes, the general consensus was that the Irish were still an eight-win team; it wasn't even close, as Notre Dame flopped out of the gate with an 0-5 start, and sat at 1-9 before winning its last two games.   High point: The best of Notre Dame's three wins was a 20-6 victory over U.C.L.A. on Oct. 6, a victory that snapped N.D.'s seven-game losing streak. After losing the next four, Notre Dame beat Duke by 28-7 and Stanford by 21-14 to end the season.   Low point: The Irish lost their first five games by a combined score of 166-46, the worst being a 38-0 loss at Michigan, a game both team entered with an 0-2 record. The rivalry game with U.S.C. was also a 38-0 laugher. Two years prior, the pair played perhaps the best college football game of the decade; this one wasn't as close. The aforementioned losses to Navy and Air Force cemented the 2007 team as the program's worst.  Tidbit (winning streak edition): The Irish enter the 2008 season on a two-game winning streak, their longest streak to start a season since 1993 (seven games). How is that possible, you may ask? See below for more details.  Tidbit (bowl edition): The Irish have lost nine consecutive bowl games (dating back to 1994), the longest string of bowl ineptitude in N.C.A.A. history. Each of the last five losses have come by at least 14 points, including a 27-point loss to L.S.U. in the 2007 Sugar Bowl.   Returning starters: 15 (9 offense, 6 defense).  Key losses  On offense, the Irish only lost two starters off last year's inexperienced unit: tight end John Carlson and center John Sullivan. Carlson picked up where his predecessor, the current Miami Dolphin Anthony Fasano, left off, leading the team in receptions (40) and receiving yards (372). Carlson's three touchdown grabs were good for second on the team. The 38th overall pick in April's draft (Seahawks), Carlson was a terrific fit in Weis's pro-style offense. Sullivan, who played his high school ball in Greenwich, Conn., was a member of the Rimington Trophy watch list in both 2006-7. Despite battling injuries a senior (he missed the season's final three games), Sullivan remained among the nation's top centers, and will be missed on the interior of the Notre Dame line. A sixth-round pick of the Vikings, he is in position to apprentice one season under the All-Pro Matt Birk before battling for the starting job in 2009.  On defense, the losses are bit more severe, especially in the case of the standouts Laws and Zbikowski. Laws led all defensive lineman in the F.B.S. with 112 tackles, while also leading the Irish with four sacks. He was the team M.V.P. for the 2007 season, and deservedly so: he was the lone Notre Dame defender  and perhaps the lone player, period  who excelled week after week despite the team's disappointing results. Laws played end in the 3-4 defense, but at 6-0, 304 pounds, projects as a defensive tackle at the next level. His production, and leadership, will be sorely missed in 2008. He followed Carlson as a second-round pick (47th over all), landing with the Eagles. Though Zbikowski never seemed to recapture the tremendous play he exhibited as a sophomore, he departs South Bend as a two-time all-American and an integral part of a pass defense that allowed only 161.6 yards per game last fall. That total was the best by an Irish defense since 1996. As a senior, Zbikowski finished fifth on the team in tackles with 80, adding two picks. He again served as an asset in the return game, averaging 10.2 yards per return; as a pro, he may make an early impact on special teams. Weis and his staff will attempt to offset the loss of inside linebacker Joe Brockington (108 tackles, a team-leading 8.5 for loss) by committee, though the junior Toryan Smith seems to be the favorite for the starting spot. One underclassman who will not be playing for the Irish in 2008, though he may return next season, is the would-be junior cornerback Darrin Walls, who left school for personal reasons. Walls started 11 games in 2007, making 32 tackles and an interception. He was expected to occupy one starting corner spot.  Tidbit (N.F.L. draft edition): After going from 1998-2006 with no more than two players taken on the first day of the draft, the Irish have had three players go on Day 1 each of the last two seasons: Quinn (1st round, 22nd over all), Victor Abiamiri (2nd, 57th over all) and Ryan Harris (3rd, 70th over all) in 2007, and Carlson, Laws and Zbikowski (3rd round, 86th over all to the Ravens) in 2008.   Players to watch: It all starts at quarterback, where Clausen enters his second season as the undisputed future of the Irish program. Though he may face some competition from the incoming freshman Dayne Crist, Clausen showed enough over the last three games of the season (636 yards, six touchdowns against one pick) to justify his ranking as the best high school recruit in the country in 2007. Thrust into the starting role in the second week (no freshman Q.B. in Notre Dame history had ever started prior to the fourth game of his rookie season), Clausen went through the inevitable struggles, losing his first four starts while struggling to move the ball. While most of his early ineffectiveness can be traced to inexperience, some of the blame must fall upon Clausen's slow recovery from off-season elbow surgery. Clausen ranks second on Notre Dame's freshman quarterback list in terms of passing yards (1,254), completions (138), attempts (245) and completion percentage (56.3 percent). He may not be among the 10 best quarterbacks in the country, but Clausen's projected development in 2008 is a story line to watch. His favorite target is the lanky sophomore wideout Duval Kumara, who at 6-5, 222 pounds, certainly looks the part of an N.F.L. receiver. He played well enough as a freshman  a N.D. rookie record 32 receptions and 4 touchdowns  to project well for the next level. One receiver to remember is the sophomore Golden Tate, who caught six balls for 131 yards last fall, a 21.8 yards-per-catch average. Weis and the new offensive coordinator Mike Haywood need to find ways to get him the ball. Other productive weapons include the senior David Grimes (27 receptions, 224 yards) and the junior Robby Parris (29 for 361). Up front, the Irish return four starters, including the junior right tackle Sam Young, who has started all 25 games since arriving in South Bend in 2006. Though he has started at both tackle spots with the Irish, Young will move permanently to the right side this fall, with the senior Paul Duncan protecting Clausen's blindside. Tight end, all important in the Notre Dame offense, lost a productive senior in Carlson, but the position looks to be in solid shape in 2008 and beyond with the sophomore Mike Ragone (one reception for seven yards in 2007) and the incoming freshman Kyle Rudolph, the nation's top tight end recruit. On the defensive line, the Irish staff hopes the sophomore Ian Williams, a freshman all-American in 2007, can help replace some of Laws's lost production. His 45 tackles a season ago, sixth on the team, was the third-most by a freshman lineman in Notre Dame history. Linebacker looks like a strength, especially with the senior Maurice Crum Jr. returning in the middle: Crum, who had 84 tackles last season, enters his final season with 241 career stops and 37 career starts, most on the team. Crum will get help from the sophomore Brian Smith, who is penciled in at one of the outside linebacker spots. Smith was one of a number of freshman defenders who made an impact a season ago, recording 25 tackles, 1.5 sacks and an interception. Though Notre Dame will need to replace two starters in the secondary, they return two experienced seniors in free safety David Bruton and corner Terrail Lambert. Bruton, in addition to leading the team with three interceptions, is Notre Dame's leading returning tackler (85, 4.5 for loss). Lambert, whose 22 consecutive starts is second only to Crum's 37, has 74 tackles and 4 picks over the last two seasons. With the loss of Zbikowski, and now Walls, Lambert and Bruton will be integral to the success of the entire defense.  Position battle to watch: Losing a starting cornerback like Walls is often difficult to overcome, but corner is one position where the Irish seem to be in pretty good shape. His backups, the junior Raeshon McNeil and the sophomore Gary Gray, were battling for the nickel spot but are now in line to earn a starting job in the Irish secondary. McNeil has played in 22 games over his two seasons in South Bend (nine tackles and a sack last fall), taking snaps at both corner and safety, while Gray missed all of last season due to injury. The real issue for the Irish will be finding a consistent running game, something that eluded them through much of the 2007 season; the Irish finished 117th in the F.B.S. in rushing offense (903 yards). The junior James Aldridge is the team's leading returning rusher after a 463-yard 2007 season, including two 100-yard games. Though he enters the fall atop the depth chart, he will be pushed through camp and into the season by the sophomores Robert Hughes and Armando Allen. Hughes burst onto the scene in the season's final two games, rushing for 246 yards (7 yards per carry) and 2 touchdowns in victories over Duke and Stanford; he became the first Notre Dame freshman back to break 100 yards in back-to-back games since Allen Pinkett in 1982. Allen was second on the team with 348 yards, though he made additional contributions in the passing game (24 receptions for 124 yards) and on special teams (a team-record 704 kick return yards). One of three needs to step up and take the starting job, though Allen seems better suited as third-down or change-of-pace back. If I were Weis, I would give Hughes the rock until he shows the last two games of 2007 were a fluke.   2008 schedule:  Sept. 6 San Diego State Sept. 13 Michigan Sept. 20 @ Michigan State Sept. 27 Purdue Oct. 4 Stanford Oct. 11 @ North Carolina Oct. 25 @ Washington Nov. 1 Pittsburgh Nov. 8 @ Boston College Nov. 15 Navy (in Baltimore) Nov. 22 Syracuse Nov. 29 @ U.S.C.  Game(s) to watch: The usual rivalry games, Michigan and U.S.C. specifically. The Irish have lost the last two to the Wolverines by a combined score of 85-21, while Weis is 0-3 against the Trojans, the last two losses coming by at least 20 points. Notre Dame has to win home games against San Diego State, Stanford and Syracuse, the three most winnable games on the schedule.  Season breakdown & prediction: Like most college football fans, I don't drink the Notre Dame kool-aid. I think they are perennially over-ranked, receive undue acclaim and publicity, and are often unworthy of the attention paid to them by the college football world. The only reason I say this is to dissuade any reader who may think what I'm about to say is biased by a pro-Notre Dame agenda: I think Notre Dame is going to markedly better in 2008, perhaps even  gasp  six wins better. This is due to a number of reasons. One, the definite improvement on offense. Yes, it truly can't get any worse, but the Irish will have a healthy Clausen  who was greatly improved down the stretch  and a deeper, more experienced line, which will help the running game. Losing Laws up front hurts, but the Irish hope the potential group of Williams, the senior Justin Brown and the junior Morrice Richardson can help offset his departed production. At linebacker, an integral part of the 3-4 defense, N.D. has a standout in Crum and a number of talented, athletic underclassmen, which will help make the unit better than it was a year ago. The most important thing to remember about the Irish is that those freshman who struggled through last fall are now sophomores, and the experience they gained while struggling through a 3-9 season will pay immense dividends this coming season and beyond. Most important of all, the athletic department has presented the Irish with a workable schedule. There are a number of no-doubt wins on the docket (San Diego State, Syracuse), many probable victories (Navy, Stanford) and a grab-bag of potential victories. Unlike years past, Notre Dame fans do not look at their team's schedule and automatically project three, even four losses before the season even starts. I believe there is only one game  Southern California  that is a definite loss. As for a prediction, I see the Irish at 8-4, a great step forward after last fall and a sign that, just maybe, the program is in good hands.   Dream season: Wipe away those tears, Touchdown Jesus! The Irish finish the season 10-2, losing only at Michigan State and U.S.C., and earn their third B.C.S. bowl appearance (justified or not) under Weis.  Nightmare season: Despite an improvement on offense and an easier schedule, Notre Dame cannot make more than a two-game improvement off of its 3-9 finish of 2007.  Where do Notre Dame fans congregate: There are dozens of fan sites to comb through, but the Countdown gives you the cream of the crop. For message boards and recruiting sites, check out Irish Illustrated, Blue and Gold, Irish Eyes and Irish Envy. Other good resources include Irish Sports Report and N.D. Nation.   Who is No. 36?: This program went 2-21 from 2001-2, but has won at least eight games four of the last five seasons.

title: Vodafone in $2 Billion Stock Buyback
description: Vodafone Group, the world's biggest mobile phone operator, announced a surprise stock buyback valued at about $2 billion Wednesday, saying a big share price fall Tuesday had left it undervalued.  Its shares rose 3.9 percent in morning trading on the London Stock Exchange.  "The board of Vodafone Group has considered the market reaction to the group's Interim Management Statement, issued on July 22, and has decided to introduce a 1 billion share repurchase programme with immediate effect," the British company said in a statement.   "This action reflects the board's belief that the share price significantly undervalues Vodafone."  Vodafone shares slumped almost 14 percent on Tuesday after the group said its full-year revenue would be at the bottom of a previously stated forecast, denting hopes that it would be weather an economic downturn unscathed. It singled out its business in Spain as being particularly weak.  Vodafone said the buyback would need shareholder approval at its annual general meeting July 29.  "The maximum share price payable for any shares will be no greater than 105 percent of the average of the middle market closing price of the company's share price on the London Stock Exchange for the five business days immediately preceding the trade date on which any shares are purchased," it said. title: Remembering a City Hall Assassination
description: Five years ago this afternoon, a New York City councilman was shot to death inside City Hall by a political rival who accompanied him to a Council meeting, pulled out a pistol and began firing in front of scores of stunned lawmakers and onlookers.

title: Recalling a City Hall Assassination
description: (Photo: The coffin of Councilman James E. Davis of Brooklyn lay in state in the rotunda of City Hall on July 28, 2003, five days after he was shot to death in the Council chamber. It was the first such viewing at City Hall since 1918. (Photo: Ruby Washington/The New York Times) ) Five years ago this afternoon, a New York City councilman was shot to death inside City Hall by a political rival who accompanied him to a Council meeting, pulled out a pistol and began firing in front of scores of stunned lawmakers and onlookers.   The assassination of the councilman, James E. Davis, 41, of Brooklyn, was one of the most tumultuous episodes in the 200-year history of the seat of government, which was built between 1803 and 1812.   The gunman, Othniel B. Askew, 31, had planned to challenge Mr. Davis in the fall for his seat representing central Brooklyn in the Council. Mr. Askew was apparently able to slip his gun into City Hall by accompanying the councilman, who did not have to pass through metal detectors.  (Photo: Councilman James E. Davis (Photo: Gregory P. Mango/Associated Press)) At 2:08 p.m., as they were seated in the balcony of the Council chamber, Mr. Askew fired a silver .40-caliber pistol, hitting Mr. Davis twice in the chest. Mr. Davis, a retired police officer, was carrying a weapon, but it was in its holster, The Associated Press reported at the time.  As pandemonium broke out, a plainclothes police officer, Richard B. Burt, 34, who was assigned to City Hall and was filling in as a member of the detail that protected the Council speaker, Gifford Miller, drew his service pistol and fired it six times into the balcony, striking Mr. Askew five times and killing him.  Amid the chaos, City Hall was locked down, as politicians, city workers, journalists and visitors feared that the gunman might still be loose. Subway trains were rerouted, police units descended on Lower Manhattan and in the first confused moments many New Yorkers, with the events of 9/11 less than two years in the past, wondered if another terrorist attack had occurred.   Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who had been in office only 18 months and was in his second-floor office when the shots rang out, remained calm through the crisis, and immediately ordered security changes that required everyone entering City Hall -- including elected officials and the mayor himself -- to go through security detectors. Previously, officials like Mr. Davis could wave through their guests, a traditional courtesy that had been extended by the police.  (Photo: Othniel B. Askew (Photo: Associated Press/WCBS-TV)) It later emerged that Mr. Askew had contacted the F.B.I. about what he said was a sustained effort by Mr. Davis to intimidate him, promising that if Mr. Askew did not challenge him, he would receive a job with medical benefits. Mr. Askew, who grew up on Long Island, served in the Air Force and worked as a model, also had told law enforcement authorities that Mr. Davis had threatened to reveal he was gay.  Five days after the assassination, Mr. Davis's body laid in state at City Hall as 7,000 mourners gathered.   Meanwhile, maneuvering began to fill the vacancy caused by Mr. Davis's death. The councilman's brother, Geoffrey A. Davis, took his spot on the ballot, but in the November election, Letitia James, a Working Families Party candidate, won the seat. (Ms. James has since become a Democrat.)  The fifth anniversary of the assassination has been the occasion for some reflection. At City Hall -- where the lounge for City Council members was renamed for Mr. Davis in 2004 -- a lunch was held on Friday in Mr. Davis's memory.  On Tuesday night, a prayer vigil was held at St. James Place and DeKalb Avenue, on the edge of the Pratt Institute campus in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn. At the vigil, Mr. Davis, who had won office in 2001 after several unsuccessful attempts, was remembered as something of a maverick.   "Five years ago, almost to this moment, many of us gathered here when we heard this news," said Assemblyman Hakeem S. Jeffries, who organized and led the brief ceremony, which drew about 50 people.   Delia M. Hunley-Adossa, president of the 88th Precinct Community Council, read a poem in Mr. Davis's honor and invoked the African belief that "a person never dies as long as his name is still spoken in the village," while Councilman David Yassky remembered Mr. Davis as a "24/7 City Council member."   Mr. Jeffries recited a favorite slogan of Mr. Davis's -- "Love Yourself" -- and the crowd shouted back, three times, "Stop the Violence." Then William Robinson, a member of Brown Memorial Baptist Church, began to sing "Amazing Grace."   In a phone interview, Ms. James, who succeeded Mr. Davis as the representative for the 35th Council District, which spans the neighborhoods of Fort Greene, Clinton Hill, Prospect Heights and Crown Heights, reflected on his legacy. "He was a very complex figure, but one who spoke truth to power, spoke out against gun violence, could transcend race and socioeconomic status and was a man of great faith," she said.  Ms. James recalled that five years ago, she was a young lawyer studying for a graduate degree in public administration at Columbia and working as an aide to Representative Roger L. Green when she heard the news of the killing. She said her thoughts immediately turned to Mr. Askew -- who, she said, had spoken to her only a couple of days earlier about his dislike for Mr. Davis.   Although she ran against Mr. Davis in 2001 and against his brother in 2003, Ms. James has since patched up relations with the family. She participated in the Friday memorial lunch at City Hall and the Tuesday prayer vigil in Clinton Hill and has supported the James E. Davis Stop the Violence Foundation, founded by his brother, which opposes the sale of video games and music with violent themes.   At City Hall now, all visitors, from the mayor on down, go through security the same way.   "Even now, some people do come into the City Council chamber and glance up at the balcony, a bit warily," said George Arzt, a former press secretary for Mayor Edward I. Koch who, as a lobbyist and political consultant now, is still a fixture at City Hall. "If it can happen once, it can happen again."   Mr. Arzt said he did think security at City Hall had been vastly improved over the last five years (though he thought it took too long for the city to add police protection to 250 Broadway, the office building across the street from City Hall where most Council members have their offices). "This was the best-protected building in New York, everyone thought," Mr. Arzt said of City Hall. "Now it really is."   Annie Correal contributed reporting.

title: Hindsight and Foresight in Iraq
description: Remember when Iraq was a Vietnam-like quagmire? Things may have changed on the ground in Mesopotamia, but this week the two presidential candidates seemed stuck in the bog.   Let's start with this exchange between John McCain and CBS News's Katie Couric, in which he talks about Col. [now Brig. Gen.] Sean MacFarland a pivotal figure in the so-called Sons of Iraq rising in support of Coalition forces in Anbar province:    Couric: Senator McCain, Sen. Obama says, while the increased number of U.S. troops contributed to increased security in Iraq, he also credits the Sunni awakening and the Shiite government going after militias. And says that there might have been improved security even without the surge. What's your response to that?  McCain: I don't know how you respond to something that is such a false depiction of what actually happened. Colonel [MacFarland] was contacted by one of the major Sunni sheiks. Because of the surge we were able to go out and protect that sheik and others. And it began the Anbar awakening. I mean, that's just a matter of history. Thanks to General Petraeus, our leadership, and the sacrifice of brave young Americans. I mean, to deny that their sacrifice didn't make possible the success of the surge in Iraq, I think, does a great disservice to young men and women who are serving and have sacrificed.     Plenty of liberal bloggers feel McCain is mistaking the chicken for the egg, most pointing out this Sept. 2006 interview with MacFarland, which long predated the surge. Here's the relevant part:     With respect to the violence between the Sunnis and the al Qaeda -- actually, I would disagree with the assessment that the al Qaeda have the upper hand. That was true earlier this year when some of the sheikhs began to step forward and some of the insurgent groups began to fight against al Qaeda. The insurgent groups, the nationalist groups, were pretty well beaten by al Qaeda.  This is a different phenomena that's going on right now. I think that it's not so much the insurgent groups that are fighting al Qaeda, it's the -- well, it used to be the fence-sitters, the tribal leaders, are stepping forward and cooperating with the Iraqi security forces against al Qaeda, and it's had a very different result. I think al Qaeda has been pushed up against the ropes by this, and now they're finding themselves trapped between the coalition and ISF on the one side, and the people on the other.    "This is not controversial history," adds Democracy Arsenal's Ilan Goldenberg.   "It is history that anyone trying out for Commander in Chief must understand when there are 150,000 American troops stationed in Iraq. It is an absolutely essential element to the story of the past two years. YOU CANNOT GET THIS WRONG. Moreover, what is most disturbing is that according to McCain's inaccurate version of history, military force came first and solved all of our problems. If that is the lesson he takes from the Anbar Awakening, I am afraid it is the lesson he will apply to every other crisis he faces including, for example, Iran."   Meanwhile, Barack Obama is still consulting his timetables, telling Couric that:    Now, keep in mind that when I talk about timetables, people say that's too specific, with respect to residual force, maybe not specific enough. I think this is an example of a tactical issue. How do you execute a mission that requires commanders on the ground to make that decision? My job as commander-in-chief would be to indicate to them here's our goal, here are the missions that we need to carry out. Now, you tell me what it is that we need in terms of boots on the ground, in terms of equipment, in terms of other capabilities that are gonna be required. The overarching strategy is not something that I can deflect to the general. That's something that I have to make a decision at of, if I am president of the United States.    Which leads Hot Air's Allahpundit into this hypothetical:    If he considers troop levels to be a tactical rather than a strategic issue and therefore something to be guided by the advice of his generals rather than dictated from the top down as C-in-C, how is he able to set even an informal timetable? Petraeus, his would-be Centcom commander, is already telling him that a timetable unmoored to conditions is a bad idea. Is that a strategic or tactical judgment? Does it matter, since he'd have the final say anyway? He's drawing an artificial distinction here in order to avoid having to commit to an estimate of the number of troops he hopes/plans to draw down. Which is fine by me, since it leaves him room to inch away from a total withdrawal later on, but presumably not so fine by the left for the same reason. Imagine, for instance, he tells Odierno that manpower is desperately needed in Afghanistan and therefore he wants to try to free up 50,000 troops by accelerating the handover of provincial security to Iraqi forces. No dice, says Odierno; we can spare 20,000, but those other 30,000 will be needed as back-up for awhile since the Iraqis aren't fully prepared yet for their lead role. 50,000 versus 20,000 is a big deal, sufficiently so to matter to voters, I'd think. We have no sense from his answer what he'd do.

description: So you say youre selling your house? The Wall Street Journal asked on July 14. Hey, it could be worse. You could be selling a Hummer.

title: Hummer for Sale  Highly Negotiable
description: "So you say you're selling your house?" The Wall Street Journal asked on July 14. "Hey, it could be worse. You could be selling a Hummer."  Some people are selling a Hummer. And to get a sense of how bad it is out there when you're pimpin' a big S.U.V. in the era of high gas prices, I went on Craigslist and surveyed the plaintive listings. The bottom line seems to be that if you have a Hummer H2 or even a more fuel-efficient H3 for sale, you're very negotiable. Let's talk, the ads say, but sometimes even that isn't possible.  Adam Renfroe of Troy, Ala., has posted his 2003 H2 on Craigslist for a month and hasn't gotten a single call. "Price Still Negotiable," his ad reads. "If no one calls, I'll just keep it," Mr. Renfroe said, admitting that the price of gas is undoubtedly an obstacle to a quick sale. For now, the white H2 is mostly parked. Mr. Renfroe was asking $25,000, but he may take $22,000, which is about Kelley Blue Book value for a private-party sale of this vehicle in excellent condition with 30,000 miles.  Leno Stenpa of Binghamton, N.Y., is offering his 2006 H3 with 19,000 miles and the luxury package on Craigslist for $26,500, and he said he thinks that after a month and a half he finally has a buyer on the hook. "I bought it for my wife, but she says she doesn't like it because it's too big for her," Mr. Stenpa said. "If I can't sell it, though, she'll have to drive it."   Mr. Stenpa said the car isn't all that bad on gas. "It's not much worse than the Chevy Equinox she's driving now," he said. "People think the Hummer is a gas hog, but it's not  the H3 gets 20-something miles per gallon. Personally, I think this gas thing is killing our country."  A dealer in Memphis is advertising a Hummer "Clearance Blow-Out" on Craigslist, with 18 vehicles to choose from. He claims he can offer "a full list of colors and packages" with as much as $30,000 off the manufacturers' suggested retail price.   Another Tennessee vendor, Robert (who declined to give his last name), has a deal to offer on a 2003 H2 with the luxury package, Bose stereo and a sunroof. He wants $20,999, or any reasonable offer, and will consider a trade. "The large S.U.V. market is plunging, and it's not going to get any better," said Robert, whose day job is as a manager at a General Motors dealership.   Robert added that, paradoxically, he's spending his days selling mostly Avalanches, Suburbans and Tahoes. And why is that? "The media drives it a lot," he said. "They report that big S.U.V.s are taking a beating, so people come in to our dealership looking for great deals."  And, of course, he added, those customers aren't wrong: G.M.'s recent incentives for large S.U.V.s have included 72 months of zero-percent financing, or $6,000 in cash incentives.   So it may not be such a bad time to buy (or sell) a Hummer after all.

title: Elliott Carters Neo-Classical Roots
description: (Photo: The "Carter's Century" exhibition at Tanglewood includes photographs and sheet music from his earlier years. (Michael J. Lutch for The New York Times)) LENOX, Mass. -- Two unusual items in the "Carter's Century" exhibition at Tanglewood got me thinking about a side of Elliott Carter's work that we don't hear much about, even at a lavish festival like the one taking place here.  On the wall over the glass case with the Charles Ives letter at the Visitor Center is a page from Mr. Carter's incidental score for a Harvard Classics Club production of Sophocles' "Philoctetes," dated 1931. The score, written neatly in ink, includes the Greek text under a gently wavering vocal line with a graceful oboe accompaniment. Nearby is a page from an orchestral march, part of another incidental score, this time for a planned but canceled production of Plautus' "Mostellaria" in 1936.  Very little of Mr. Carter's music from before 1950 is performed, and pieces like these incidental scores are scarcely mentioned. I was always under the impression that Mr. Carter had disowned or suppressed most of this early music, allowing only a few representative scores -- the Symphony No. 1 (1942), the "Three Poems of Robert Frost" (1943), the "Holiday Overture" (1944), the rugged Piano Sonata (1946) and a few others -- to represent his early period.  He has, after all, always described his 1950 trip to Arizona as a kind of artistic rebirth. It was there that he hit on the approach to melody and rhythm that propels his String Quartet No. 1 and became his hallmark for the next half century.  But at a Tuesday afternoon panel discussion that brought together three authors of authoritative books about Mr. Carter's music -- David Schiff ("The Music of Elliott Carter"), Jonathan W. Bernard ("Elliott Carter: Collected Essays and Lectures, 1936-95") and John Link ("Elliott Carter: A Guide to Research") -- it emerged that Mr. Carter's attitude toward these works might not be so clear-cut. Mr. Bernard, after beginning his remarks with a passionate defense of them, said that when he told Mr. Carter that he liked his early music, Mr. Carter responded: "So do I. I didn't used to like it, but now I like it again."  (Mr. Carter, who has attended most of the festival events, was not at the symposium either to elaborate or to demur.)  Mr. Carter has offered several reasons for having abandoned his early, neo-Classical, style. One was philosophical: after World War II, he came to believe that if music was to reflect the human condition and psyche, it had to abandon the charm and navet of the prevailing neo-Classical, neo-Romantic and folk-rooted styles. Another was that the technical discoveries he had made during his Arizona sojourn struck him as the only way to continue.  Mr. Bernard proposed a third reason, which embraces these others: Mr. Carter's style change was a necessary career move. Early works like the "Pocohontas" ballet score (1939) had established him as a second-tier Copland, and he knew that he had to develop a style of his own before that reputation began to stick.  The performances at the festival show that it is a simplification to think of the String Quartet No. 1 as a decisive break. Charles Rosen's illuminating performance of the Piano Sonata on Monday pointed up a structural, gestural and spiritual kinship between this work and late Beethoven, but also a harmonic rigor that was pointing to the path Mr. Carter would later take. And the trim, light-textured Sonata for Flute, Oboe, Cello and Harpsichord, in a lively reading by a student ensemble on Tuesday evening, demonstrated that two years after the pivotal quartet, Mr. Carter was still drawn to neo-Classicism.  It gets stranger. Mr. Carter's most recent works, though as technically demanding as ever, have shed much of the harmonic acidity, the stark contrasts and the polyrhythmic complexity that were among his hallmarks between 1950 and 2000. And heard from a certain perspective, some of these new pieces -- "Catnaires" (2006), for example, a perpetual-motion solo piano work given a stunningly virtuosic performance by Sandra Gu on Tuesday afternoon, and "Mad Regales" (2007), a set of six-voice madrigals that had its premiere on Tuesday evening -- can seem like Mr. Carter's stealthy return to his neo-Classical roots.  That makes the revival of the forgotten early works an even more compelling prospect: if Mr. Carter's work is coming full circle (after a fashion), we might as well understand the starting point.

title: Sweet Cupcakes in Washington
description: (Photo: (Photo: Dayna Smith)) I returned from a quick trip to Washington, D.C., recently with two happy eating memories, two suggestions to pass along. And that isn't always the case with food and with Washington, which can delight and disappoint in pretty much equal measures.  I'll start with the cupcakes. They were some cupcakes. They came from Georgetown Cupcake, which bills itself, on its web site, as "D.C.'s first and only cupcakery." I relate that because I love that word: cupcakery. I shall henceforth be calling a popular breakfast spot near my apartment a pancakery, and any plant milling uranium oxide for potentially bellicose purposes a yellowcakery.   In any case I can't say enough good things about this cupcakery. It opened in February. Lucky for me it opened just three blocks from the friend's house where I stay whenever I visit D.C. Even luckier for me she discovered it right away, latched onto it, visits it all the time and had a box of a dozen assorted cupcakes waiting for me when I arrived. I'm not sure that last part makes me lucky, exactly. I think it just makes me, or rather made me, fat.  I initially told her I didn't want one of the cupcakes. I refused to try one. She made me. It was the mocha flavor, with a chocolate-covered coffee bean on top, and it was out of this world. I ate all of it.  Then she told me I had to try the carrot cupcake, and by now I was hearing and heeding her in a whole new way, and after that she told me I had to try the key lime cupcake, and I again followed orders. I would like to say in my defense that I had only a quarter of each of those cupcakes. I would like to say that they were so fine that stopping at a quarter qualifies me for some kind of medal of valor.  These cupcakes beat Magnolia Bakery's by miles and miles. The cake itself is moist and rich, and remains so even after the cupcakes have been sitting around for a day, and the frosting is as creamy and buttery as you could ask frosting to be without becoming so intense it sort of lays waste to you, the way some frostings can. There was a generous amount, but nothing out of control, and each different cupcake was beautifully colored and decorated prettily but sparely.   My friend tells me these cupcakes have become something of a rage in D.C. and that there are often lines out the door of the shop. When I poked my head in there wasn't a line, but there were stacks and stacks of boxes of cupcakes --- in chocolate banana and chocolate hazelnut and chocolate coconut, in lemon berry and lemon --- awaiting pick-up. My friend isn't the only one buying them by the dozen.  My other happy eating experience was at a restaurant. I'll deal with that in one of my next few posts.

title: Eye of the Storm: the Story So Far
description: Mother Nature has clearly awakened from her long slumber. While Hurricane Dollys landfall today along the Texas-Mexico border will get much attention, the reality is that 2008 has already been a very activeyear for catastrophe losses in the United States. In fact, there were a record 109 catastrophes through June 30, according to Munich Re, one of the worlds largest reinsurers. These catastrophes resulted in $9.3billion in insured catastrophe, the highest first-half total since 1994 (the year of the Northridge earthquake). This figure exceeds the total insured catastrophe losses recorded in 2006 ($9.2 billion) and 2007 ($6.7 billion). Tornadoes were the most significant cause of loss during the first half of the year. Historically, hurricanes and tropical storms have caused the bulk of second half losses.

title: Shipyards to Sheratons in Gdansk
description: (Photo: Modern sculptures stand out against the restored Gothic architecture of Gdansk's Main Town. See Slide Show )  It was threatening rain when I walked unchecked into the Gdansk shipyards last Friday, my eyes focused on the beautiful jungle of industrial machinery up ahead. Elaborate steel cranes, painted green, loomed over the rusty carcasses of half-built ships, and inside the sagging brick warehouses, I imagined, were heavy and mysterious tools. My camera batteries were fully charged, and I was hoping to spend the day photographing these historic shipyards, birthplace of the Solidarity movement, which brought down Polish Communism in the 1980s, and now nearly bankrupt.  The security guard running after me had other ideas. I was only a couple of hundred yards into the vast complex when he stopped me and explained, in vociferous Polish that didn't need translation, that I wasn't welcome. And so I turned around and walked away from the Gdansk of my imagination  a postindustrial nightmare wrought in concrete and steel  and toward the Gdansk of reality, a much brighter place.   Gdansk is centered on the Main Town, a neighborhood of arched passageways, gilded ornamentation and stately brick buildings that testify to the city's wealth in the 16th and 17th centuries. Church bells ring out the hours, buskers embark on indie-folk careers in the cobblestone streets and children slurp ice cream cones and clutch helium balloons along the waterfront promenade. Gdansk, it turns out, is a tourist haven, the anchor of three Baltic Sea towns  Sopot and Gdynia are the others  that make up what might well be termed the Polish Riviera. Outside of Poles and a few Germans, who knew this was such a hot spot?   You, my readers, did. Of the 24,000 who voted on my destination this week, more than 56 percent chose Gdansk over Copenhagen and Hamburg (thanks in part to Trojmiasto.pl, a local Web guide that rallied the pro-Gdansk crowd). "It's a delightful place, full of old world charm, that hasn't been American-ized yet like many other parts of Europe," wrote Moe. Others extolled its "wonderful architecture" and "interesting history".   Gdansk was also, many of you noted, inexpensive  though that, too, is changing. Since Poland joined the European Union on May 1, 2004, the Polish currency has been steadily gaining strength, going from 4.9 zlotys to the euro to 3.22. (That's 2.03 zlotys to the dollar, down from 4 zlotys.) Unfortunately, this meant that many of the quaint and comfortable hotels near the Main Town were no longer in my price range.   The "In Your Pocket" guidebook, whose Gdansk edition I downloaded as a PDF from inyourpocket.com (and which I read during my overnight Eurolines bus trip from Vilnius, for 135 Lithuanian lita, or about $62 at 2.17 litas to the dollar), directed me to the Willa Jolanta (www.willajolanta.pl), a modern house in a residential quarter about a mile from the Main Town. My spacious apartment, one of six with kitchenette, satellite TV, Wi-Fi and private bathroom, lacked Old World charm, but cost just 180 zlotys a night, or 162 with a discount for staying a full week. And the owners did my laundry  free!   (Photo: A fruit stand.  See Slide Show )  That milelong trek to the Main Town might seem like a lot, but walking it day after day got me familiar with the city. On my way down Kartuska Street, I'd stop at a cukiernia (bakery) for a pczek (jelly doughnut, 1.50 zlotys) or a 4 zloty basket of blackberries from a sidewalk fruit vendor. If I was in a hurry  or if, as was often the case, it was raining  I'd just hop the creaky but reliable tram (3 zlotys per ride, 12 zlotys for a 24-hour pass), and five minutes later I'd be soaking up Gdansk's 1,011-year history and culture.  Walk through the Highland Gate and you'll pass the city's most important treasures along the Royal Way. A former prison now houses twin museums, one devoted to amber, the other to torture (26 Targ Wglowy; 48-58-301-4733; admission 10 zlotys). The towering brick Town Hall is home to the Gdansk History Museum (46/47 Ulica Dluga; 48-58-767-9100; www.mhmg.gda.pl; admission 8 zlotys). And the 1549 bronze fountain statue of Neptune has become a popular meeting place. Even among the throngs of souvenir-seeking tourists, it's easy to be amazed that all these glories have survived centuries of change and turbulence.  Except that they haven't. The Main Town should not to be confused with the Old Town, which was leveled and rebuilt, Soviet style, after World War II. The history museum had numerous photos of what Gdansk looked like in 1945, after the Nazi invasion and years of Allied bombing: near-total ruin. Ninety percent of Gdansk's Main Town was rubble, and it took decades of craftsmanship to achieve the historic-looking neighborhood visitors see today. How exactly that was achieved was left unclear by the museum, which had minimal English translations.   Video In fact, Gdansk's history seemed more a buoyant atmosphere than a scholarly pursuit, a backdrop for the city's surprisingly vibrant cultural life. The week I visited, the International Street & Open-Air Theatres Festival (FETA) was taking place, and troupes from 14 countries, including Canada and Iran, were performing comedic, pyrotechnic and just plain abstract shows (mostly free!) all around the Main Town. Les Sages Fous, the Canada duo, had a particularly arresting act in which they steered a steampunk boat down Ulica Dluga, encountering a baffling array of deep-sea puppet creatures. And Teatr Wybrzeze (2 Ulica Sw. Ducha; 48-58-301-7021; www.teatrwybrzeze.pl; tickets 20 to 30 zlotys) featured a production of "The Tin Drum," by the Nobel winner Gnter Grass, who was born in Gdansk, then known as the Free City of Danzig.   For a moment, Gdansk felt as it might have in the 16th century, when Shakespearean companies would swing through town, entertaining the masses  and the occasional Grand Tourist.  High culture aside, Gdansk was a fine place simply to eat, drink and make merry. I spent one happy evening at the cozy Caf Kamienica (37/39 Ulica Mariacka; 48-58-301-1230; www.olipar.pl) enjoying a brandy-spiked latte (12 zlotys) while rain slicked the narrow sidewalks outside. Another evening, I cuddled up with a plate of pork chops, cabbage salad and a dark beer (20 zlotys) in Jadalnia Pod Zielonym Smokiem's festive, smoky basement (125 Ulica Szeroka; 48-58-320-7865; www.jadalnia.com.pl).   (Photo: Lunch at Bar Mleczny Turystyczny.See Slide Show )  For lunch, I went for chicken cutlets and mashed potatoes (13 zlotys) at the bargain-basement Communistic cafeteria Bar Mleczny Turystyczny (8/10 Ulica Szeroka; 48-58-301-6013).   (Photo: My kielbasa toast. See Slide Show )  Another time, at a waterfront stand near a future Hilton hotel, I ate toast smeared with lard and topped with sauted onions, kielbasa and sliced pickles. It was the best  and most disgusting  thing I've ever eaten, and it only cost 9.50 zlotys.  Gdansk also served as a gateway to maritime pleasures. Sopot, a small beach resort about 20 minutes north by SKM train (skm.trojmiasto.pl; round trip 6.20 zlotys), is the party spot, where Poles sun themselves during the day by the Baltic (shockingly calm when I saw it), then indulge in beer, vodka and fried fish when it gets dark.   But even Sopot has its touch of history: like other classic spa towns in northern Europe, it was founded in the early 19th century for the wealthy. And up through World War II, it was a favored getaway for German officers, whose affection for it might have earned it a reprieve from destruction. Its fortunes, however, declined after the war, and by 1994, when reader Diana visited, "Sopot had the ghostly feel of a European vacation spot that was once glorious."  Now, like Gdansk, Sopot is resurgent. A 93 million-euro project to redevelop the city center means construction cranes and torn-up streets are as common as bikini thongs and Belgian waffles. A high-end Sheraton (www.sheraton.pl/sopot) just opened alongside the Free City-era Grand Hotel (which counted Hitler and de Gaulle among its guests, and is now a Sofitel). At the end of Europe's longest wooden pier, the 1,690-foot Molo, you can hear pounding dance music emanating from the beachside Copacabana club  the beat of progress.  (Photo: The cafe Jzef K.  See Slide Show )  And yet Sopot also has an intellectual, bohemian side. At Jzef K. (4/1b Ulica Kosciuszki; 48-58-550-49-35; www.jozefk.pl), a cafe named for Kafka's luckless protagonist, the dcor captured perfectly Kafka's world: typewriters and antique TVs hid in the corners, a tree sprouted from a table, and flea market paintings were adorned with cartoon thought bubbles. Over several hours, I nursed a dark beer and flipped through a Taschen book on the history of art from the cafe library.  Around the corner was Galeria Kinsky (10 Ulica Kosciuszki; 48-695-95-1743), a two-story bar in what was once the home of Klaus Kinski, the Sopot-born German actor. Surrounded by red velvet curtains, threadbare Victorian divans and two Polish women I met on Couchsurfing.com, I could easily imagine that not much had changed since the mad movie star's death in 1991.  Still, after days of indulging in history and nights of indulging in less ennobling activities, I desperately wanted to get close to the shipyards. The multimedia Solidarity Museum (1 Ulica Doki; 48-58-769-2920; www.fcs.org.pl; admission, 6 zlotys) offered a great primer on the shipyard protests of the 1980s, after an electrician by the name of Lech Walesa led workers in a strike that created the Solidarity movement, forced concessions from the government and knocked the first cracks in Polish Communism. But it didn't sate me.  So, on Sunday, after another jelly doughnut breakfast, I took to the water, renting a red kayak (15 Ulica Zabi Kruk; 48-58-305-7310; www.kajakiempogdansku.pl; two hours, 20 zlotys) and paddling down Gdansk's waterways, past the promenade and its restored facades, which I saw from below, much as an ancient Baltic trader might have.  (Photo: The shipyards. See Slide Show )  Farther downstream, the canal opened wide, and there, across the wind-rippled waters, were the shipyards. The rusty cranes looked like families of prehistoric animals, with monstrous specimens looming over babies that themselves perched over sheds and gas tanks. I considered crossing the small bay and going ashore, but given that this was probably illegal, I simply snapped a few zoomed photos and turned southeast, toward the narrower channels.  (Photo: A family of swans. See Slide Show )  Soon I was floating through canals shrouded in reeds, paved with lily pads and populated with waterfowl. There were tiny black ducks with bright orange beaks, mottled gray-and-white birds and a brood of swans whose patriarch circled me threateningly until I'd put some distance between myself and his flock. This was not exactly the Gdansk I'd planned on seeing, but it didn't really matter anymore  that figment of my imagination paled in comparison to the real Gdansk, the one I wouldn't have found without my readers to guide me.  Next stop: Harz Mountains, Germany.
