title: Whats So Funny About Nebraska?
description: (Photo: Dick Cavett and Johnny Carson on "The Tonight Show" in an undated photo. (Courtesy of NBC))  Among my growing list of topics promised but not delivered was a report on a comedy festival I attended recently in Norfolk, Neb. (I got an award there, but let that pass.) At the risk of sounding curmudgeonly, attending anything that threatened a forced viewing of a lot of new and largely unknown standup comics would be low on my list of musts; down there between dedicating a statue of Spiro Agnew and a street sale of macram.  But this one, the Great American Comedy Festival, had good promise. Among the reasons for saying yes was that Robert Klein would be there and that these particular aspirants to the jesting trade had been expertly selected. Eddie Brill  himself a comic pro and hunter for talent for Dave Letterman's show  had combed the comic woods, scanning top comedy clubs around the United States for the best available and most promising talent. And he delivered it. Brill confesses that there is something a little silly in treating comedy as a contest, but it can be fun and nobody gets hurt.   (Parenthetically to the point of irrelevance, one of Bill Clinton's lesser legacies to us all has been to make it just about impossible for anyone in public life and in the media to say anything without prefacing it with the now reflexive phrase, "Let me say this..." Who's stopping you?!, I scream at the screen.)  Anyway, let me say this: John William Carson, born Oct. 23, 1925, in Corning, Iowa, continued his growing up in Norfolk, Neb., a town now famous for Johnny Carson. He died on another 23rd -- in January of 2005.  For years I wrote for Johnny, and as I moved on he remained a valued friend. I've never known why I have to convince skeptics of this fact.   When Carson was eight, the family moved to the diminutive metropolis of Norfolk. Smooth and gregarious on camera, Johnny was uneasy with most people. He wasn't with me and our enduring friendship had a lot to do with that.   He was suspicious of journalists and columnists, and their failure to get him to "open up" resulted in some bad press and the frequent label "cold." That military brace, ramrod-straight posture of his was lampooned by those who go by the silly, pretentious term "impressionists." (You know: Rich Little, Will Jordan, David Frye, Monet, Renoir...)  While still writing for John C. in days of yore, I survived saying about him on one of those well-produced Smith & Hemion "Kraft Music Hall" shows a joke that began, "It's often said about Johnny that he has a ramrod up his...spine." During the laugh, I glanced to the side to see if the eminent victim of the roast  and my former boss -- was at least smiling. He was.  It's hard to "roast" someone you really like, but our friendship survived the evening. People, including some on his staff, continued to treat me as a hallucinator with: "You've actually been to Johnny's house? For dinner?" It never stopped.  *****  "Don't for God's sake ever repeat this to anyone or tell him I told you," said the gnomish little bald man in the Cinerama-wide plate-glass specs, "at least while he and I are both alive." The speaker, who was driving, was the legendary agent Irving "Swifty" Lazar. We were heading up whatever "drive" in Bel Air led to Swifty's house, a place that was really a mini-Louvre of priceless paintings, with Picasso one of the smaller names. In Swifty's case, there was major money in book-agenting such huge-selling volumes as Richard M. Nixon's memoirs -- humorously categorized under "non-fiction."  Swifty, driving in disconcerting Mr. Magoo style, delivered a thunderbolt.   "Johnny is very fond of you, you know," he began. And after another "top secret" cautioning, he went on, "I think you ought to know this. Johnny said to me once, 'Cavett's the only one who could beat me. If Dick hadn't been on a network with a short station line-up, he might have.'"  As comics say about such moments, "When they brought me to...and then brought me two more...."  That Johnny had said this was so unexpected and so startling to me  and you don't need a degree in psychiatry to understand this  that I promptly forgot it. (Yes, it came back in due course and it still has voltage for me.)  By the way, none of this should be construed as an attempt to obscure Johnny's later, genuine enthusiasm for Dave Letterman's talents.  "We wish you were on once a week," a member of the Carson staff said to me once. "Johnny's a different man when you come on. He's even happy in the afternoon when he comes to work. And when you're out there with him, he actually leans back in his chair." This touched me, and does now, remembering it.  *****  I was among the judges of the eight finalists in the comedy competition that night in Norfolk. It's the home, quite naturally, of a splendid Johnny Carson Museum, featuring an intriguing collection of photographs, some showing the pre-and post-pubescent lad with his beloved magic apparatus and that then-still-anonymous face that was to become, often painfully for its owner, instantly recognizable everywhere.  Each day of the festival -- it was the first held -- the local papers were splashed with publicity and articles about the hugely successful event. One newspaper had a big color picture of Johnny on the air, at his desk, looking amused by his guest (me) in the swivel chair beside him. I'd never seen the picture before. We both look young and happy and are clearly enjoying each other's company.   The place, a handsome and good-sized theater, was packed for the gala final night's show. There was a good, smart, sell-out audience of sharp local people and, onstage, excellent work by the young aspirants. At the end of the show, to my ear, both Bob Klein and I killed 'em. (The audience, not the aspirants.)  Klein and I reminisced over a western breakfast about what it was like "being on" with Johnny and how much pleasing him and making him laugh meant to a growing comic and his career. And, of course, to quite a few would-be pursuers of the comedy dream, a single smashing appearance with Johnny made a career.   Klein and I recalled how each time you found yourself standing anxiously behind that famous curtain with the vertical colored stripes, nerves would jangle almost audibly. At least a portion of your life flashed before your eyes.  Next, your pulse quickened a bit as you  alone and hidden -- heard the familiar voice say your name and, pushing that curtain aside, and taking one step into the bright lights -- you were in front of America. And Johnny.  I felt sort of sorry for those sharp young comics in Norfolk that they would never have the thrill (do we still say "the rush"?) of meeting Johnny  the career-maker of the day  and making him laugh on the air.  Of all the appearances I did with him -- doubtless they are among that ton of Carson shows NBC so thoughtfully erased  I most remember one in California. He would always have me on the show whenever the latest incarnation of "The Dick Cavett Show" ... um ... completed its current tenure. Often on the following Monday and always with a version of the same joke in the monologue: "Our good friend Dick Cavett is here tonight. Dick's had another show shot out from under him. [Laugh.] I'm always afraid that if the next one doesn't take, it's going to be Armed Forces Radio for Dick." [Laugh with capital "L."]  On such a night I made Johnny laugh, but hard. I had been the first guest out  a huge honor  and so by the end, when it was time for goodnights, and having "moved down" with each new guest, I was the farthest down the couch, cheek to cheek with Ed McMahon.  With about a minute remaining, Johnny began asking each guest what was coming up for him. And each had a big movie, big Broadway show, big something to plug. I didn't. I hoped the clock would run out before my fellow Nebraskan got to me.  Every comic can report a few "gift from the gods" moments. Here came one. "What are you doing, Richard?" he asked with a kindly smile, and I sensed he knew I probably had nothing to brag about.  Then, a miracle bred of panic: I heard myself say, "I'm working on an idea for a sitcom, Johnny. It's a humorous version of 'Gilligan's Island.'" The reaction would have broken a laugh meter.  Several columnists quoted the line, but  since an ear for nuance is not mandatory for such employment  invariably misquoted it as "a comedy version," thus karate-chopping away the line's finesse, if I may so say.  But the important thing was Johnny's reaction. He did that thing where he exploded with laughter that sent him sideways stage left off his chair. I felt like a stock market must feel going through the roof, or the space shuttle blasting off.  For a (comparative) youngster, still making his way in our cutthroat business, a lottery win would have paled by comparison. Oh, how I'd love to have a tape of that moment to wear out in repeated viewings.  *****  Well, our hour is about up. Maybe next time we might explore why, despite all this, anybody in his right mind would want to be a comedian.

title: McCain Says 16 Months Is Pretty Good Timetable
description: First the Iraqi government gave Senator Barack Obama a boost by seeming to embrace his proposal for a 16-month timetable for withdrawing American troops from Iraq. But could Senator John McCain, who built his candidacy in large part on his opposition to a timetable for withdrawal from Iraq, possibly be following suit?   "I think it's a pretty good timetable," Mr. McCain said Friday in an interview on CNN's "The Situation Room,'' before adding that it should be based "on the conditions on the ground.''   For months Mr. McCain, the presumptive Republican nominee, has railed against setting timetables for withdrawing from Iraq, and has criticized Mr. Obama, his Democratic rival, for suggesting one. But in recent days the debate has shifted as Iraqi officials, including Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki, moved closer to Mr. Obama's position.   In the interview on CNN Mr. McCain first seemed to downplay any possibility that Mr. Maliki would actually ask for the United States to withdraw its troops in the next 16 months to two years. "He won't,'' he said, explaining that he knows Mr. Maliki well.   Then, asked why he thinks Mr. Maliki had called 16 months a pretty good timetable, Mr. McCain gave his enigmatic answer.   "He said it's a pretty good timetable based on conditions on the ground,'' Mr. McCain said. "I think it's a pretty good timetable, as we should -- or horizons for withdrawal. But they have to be based on conditions on the ground. This success is very fragile. It's incredibly impressive, but very fragile. So we know, those of us who have been involved in it for many years, know that if we reverse this, by setting a date for withdrawal, all of the hard-won victory can be reversed.''  Democrats exulted, sending around the statement to reporters to suggest he was coming around to Mr. Obama's way of thinking. The McCain campaign did not explain the timetable remark, but said that Mr. McCain's position remained that he wants the troops to withdraw based on conditions on the ground.

title: The House That Her Grandpa Built
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. -- She has a familiar face. A Ruthian mug, with a miniature version of that famous wide-set nose.   Linda Ruth Tosetti, Babe Ruth's 53-year-old granddaughter, who also possesses her grandfather's legendary garrulousness, was in Cooperstown on Friday strolling through the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum in Cooperstown with her husband, Andy.   But more than 200 miles from the Bronx, she had Yankee Stadium on her mind. She was wondering why, in the final year of the old ballpark -- the House that Her Grandfather Famously Built -- the Yankees have not announced any plans to honor him.  "I'd just like them to do something," she said. "Look at what the Mets did naming the rotunda of their new stadium for Jackie Robinson," she said. "What have the Yankees done? It's like they're forgetting their history." She wonders why Babe Ruth Plaza, outside the old stadium, looks so shabby.  She said she has written to Hank Steinbrenner, Brian Cashman and Jason Zillo, the team's lead spokesman, but has heard nothing from them. She toured the stadium in February, believing it to be her last visit before it is razed. "I got all teared up," she said.  Zillo said that last month, Ruth's only surviving daughter, Julie Ruth Stevens, and her family, were at the stadium to present the Babe Ruth Award to Alex Rodriguez. As for anything formal to honor Ruth before the end of this season, Zillo said he wasn't sure what the team's plans are.  Tosetti said that a new documentary about Ruth is being produced and will focus on his charity toward children and to poor people in St. Petersburg, Fla. Along the way, she said, she has learned from autopsy records examined by two surgeons and a dentist that her grandfather did not die of throat cancer but from nasopharyngeal cancer, which starts in the back of the nose, and is most common among Asians. The raspiness heard in his voice in his final years, she said, probably stemmed from damage to his larynx caused by a tumor behind the left side of his face.  She joked that she is learning so much new information about her grandfather through the documentary -- and the campaign to have Ruth's No. 3 symbolically retired throughout M.L.B. -- that before she takes her last breath, "Someone will say, "Linda, did you know your grandfather . ?"

title: Beijing Exhibitions Are Delayed
description: The Chinese government has asked art galleries in Beijing to delay some exhibitions whose content it judged unsuitable until after the Olympic Games, Bloomberg News reported. Among the shows affected are Portraits: Sports, Stars and Society, at Galleri Faurschou, which was to include 38 works by Andy Warhol depicting Olympic athletes, and a display of works by the artist Ma Baozhong at the Xin Beijing Art Gallery, which included oil paintings of the Dalai Lama and the former Chinese president Jiang Zemin. The show by Mr. Ma, 43, comprises 15 paintings that depict important moments in the history of Chinas ruling Communist Party. Among them is 1966.8.31, showing Mao Zedong, above far right, with other Chinese leaders, and 1954.9.21, a painting of a government-sanctioned photograph at the Lama Temple in Beijing, showing Mao with the Dalai Lama and the Panchen Lama. The gallerys executive director, Li Feng, said that it might postpone Mr. Mas exhibition until October or November.

title: Behind a G.O.P. Revolt, Ideology and Politics
description: WASHINGTON  When three-quarters of House Republicans balked Wednesday at a housing bill certain to become law, they were signaling three things at once: an ideological opposition to government involvement in the markets, a fiscal objection to writing a blank check that could cost taxpayers dearly if the condition of the mortgage finance system turns much worse and a political judgment that this was a moment to demonstrate their independence from President Bush.

title: Fox Stays on Top
description: Are You Smarter Than a 5th Grader? and So You Think You Can Dance made Fox the top-rated network on Thursday, drawing 7.3 million and 8.3 million viewers respectively at 8 and 9 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. Not far behind Fox, CBS ranked second as Flashpoint, in its new 10 p.m. time slot, leading that hour with 6.7 million viewers, ahead of ABCs Hopkins (5.2 million) and NBCs Fear Itself (3.2 million). The new CBS crime show, which made its debut earlier this month, followed Greatest American Dog at 8 (6.1 million) and a repeat of CSI at 9 (7.4 million). NBC and ABC finished in a close race for third place for Thursday night, with NBC faring slightly better among adults 18 to 49 thanks to Last Comic Standing from 8 to 10 (4.2 million).

title: Serbs Extradition Is Challenged Over Arrest Details
description: BELGRADE, Serbia   A Serbian prosecutor interviewed Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb leader, on Friday about details of his arrest, Mr. Karadzics lawyer said. The interview was in response to a legal challenge to extraditing Mr. Karadzic to the United Nations war crimes tribunal on charges of genocide, the lawyer said.

title: Most Popular Business News Articles on NYTimes.com
description: Following are the most popular business news articles on nytimes.com from July 18 through July 25:

title: Claims of Molestation Resurface for Judo Official
description: A high-ranking USA Judo official has been accused of drugging and sexually molesting teenage competitors he coached in the late 1970s, accusations that resurfaced last month in Internet postings by one of the sports top athletes.

title: The Aluminum Can, Versatile and Ubiquitous
description: The group exhibitions that flood the New York gallery scene each summer tend toward the amorphous. Their titles are quixotic, their themes inscrutable. Their boundaries, when they exist at all, are elastic. Why is this artist included and not that one? The answers are rarely firm.

title: With Ace of Their Own, Yankees Beat Beckett
description: BOSTON  The Yankees have tried to find their own Josh Beckett for almost five years, ever since he blanked them in their last World Series game. They have yearned for a dominant starter to match an opponents ace, and Friday was a test.

title: Loan Giants Face Cuts on Debts
description: Standard & Poors said on Friday that it might downgrade the subordinated bonds of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, surprising investors who had expected that the securities would be supported by any Treasury rescue plan.

title: Flea Market Is a Success, and Neighbors Are Furious
description: Even as the Brooklyn Flea was being called a watershed addition to the continuing refurbishment of the boroughs brownstone neighborhoods, the markets founder, Jonathan Butler, had an inkling that perhaps it did not square with everybodys idea of what Sunday in Brooklyn should be.

title: Cambodians Rally Around Leader Ahead of Vote
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  A surge of patriotism has swept through Cambodia, bolstering the popularity of Prime Minister Hun Sen as the nation heads into a parliamentary election on Sunday.

title: 'Office' Visit for Russia
description: A version of the award-winning television show The Office will be made in Russia, BBC News reported. As a result of a licensing deal between Channel One in Russia and BBC Worldwide, 24 half-hour original episodes of the series will be produced. The British show, created by Stephen Merchant and Ricky Gervais and starring Mr. Gervais as the nightmare boss David Brent, has been seen in more than 70 countries. The American remake, which features Steve Carell in Mr. Gervaiss role, completed its fourth season in May and won Emmy Awards in 2006 and 2007. Versions of the show also appear in Chile, Canada and France, which in 2006 became the first country to produce a foreign-language version.

title: Comics for a Story by Stephen King, Too
description: N., a previously unpublished short story by the novelist Stephen King, has been adapted into a series of 25 original comic-style video episodes, Mr. Kings publisher, Scribner, announced. Beginning Monday the episodes can be purchased online at Nishere.com and viewed on the Internet or on cellphones. The story will be included in a collection published in November by Scribner, a division of Simon & Schuster.

title: In Paris, Obama Says Pressure on Iran Is Building
description: PARIS  Senator Barack Obama on Friday warned Iran not to wait for a new American president and accept an international proposal now to stop enriching uranium.

title: Oil Exports From Northern Iraq Rise Sharply
description: BAGHDAD  An American agency monitoring reconstruction in Iraq said Friday that oil exports through Iraqs northern pipeline rose more than tenfold over the past year, citing a sharp drop in attacks on the pipeline and new infrastructure built to protect it.

title: China Surpasses U.S. in Number of Internet Users
description: SHANGHAI  China said the number of Internet users in the country reached about 253 million last month, putting it ahead of the United States as the worlds biggest Internet market.

title: Reports on Mine Collapse Criticize Operation and Oversight
description: Family members of miners killed after a huge collapse at a Utah mine last year expressed outrage on Friday after two federal reports showed that the mine had long been dangerous.

title: M.T.A. and Its Debt, and How They Got That Way
description: When Richard Ravitch was named chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in 1979, he inherited a subway system in decay. Trains derailed or collided on average every 15 days. Stations were filthy and crime was rampant. Ridership sank to lows not seen since World War I.

title: As Favre Conjecture Runs Wild, the Jets Try to Contain It
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  On the second day of the Jets quarterback competition, the buzz at training camp was not about the usual suspects Chad Pennington and Kellen Clemens but on a future Hall of Fame quarterback who retired in early March and later changed his mind.

title: A Century Has Passed; His Time Is Still Now
description: LENOX, Mass.  In a 2003 letter to Elliott Carter included in Carters Century, an exhibition of photographs, scores and letters here at Tanglewood, James Levine outlines an ambitious plan to transform the Boston Symphony Orchestra into a first-rate Carter ensemble, with all the composers major works in the repertory. He has made good on that promise: better than good, really, having also commissioned a half-dozen works from Mr. Carter in the four years he has been the orchestras music director.

title: Turning Humiliation Into Inspiration
description: PARADISE VALLEY, Ariz.  Yasmine Hafiz was passing through security at an airport near Washington several weeks ago when a federal agent stopped her. Something strange and metallic had shown up in her carry-on bag during screening. Now she needed to explain what the suspicious object was.

description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  It was once known as the Parrots Beak, a strategic jut of Pakistan that the American-backed mujahedeen used to carry out raids on the Russians just over the border into Afghanistan. That was during the cold war.

title: Stan Lee and Disney Are Joining Forces
description: Leaping platforms in a single bound, Stan Lee is collaborating with Walt Disney Studios Home Entertainment on Time Jumper, a new digital comic book series, the company announced on Friday. The co-creator of such famous characters as Spider-Man, the X-Men, Iron Man, the Fantastic Four and the Hulk, Mr. Lee is developing the new series, which will be distributed by Disney on the Internet and on mobile phones. Time Jumper, about a teenager who can travel through time using a cellphone, will allow users to download single or multiple episodes onto a media platform of their choice. There will also be a print version of the comic. The comic will have traditional elements, like thought and dialogue bubbles, as well as multimedia elements like digital effects, voices and music.

title: 4,000 U.S. Deaths, and a Handful of Images
description: BAGHDAD  The case of a freelance photographer in Iraq who was barred from covering the Marines after he posted photos on the Internet of several of them dead has underscored what some journalists say is a growing effort by the American military to control graphic images from the war.

title: Obama Heads for Paris and London
description: PARIS  Senator Barack Obama came to Paris for a meeting and news conference with the French President, Nicolas Sarkozy, on Friday, the latest stop in his weeklong trip to the Middle East and Europe. Their discussion was expected to concentrate on Iran.

title: Columbus Symphony Cancels Part of Season
description: Struggling to find financing and reach agreement with its players, the Columbus Symphony Orchestra has canceled the first part of its next season. The musicians and management have been seeking to agree on terms through a mediator since the players rejected reductions in their ranks and then large pay cuts. The Columbus Dispatch reported on Thursday that at least 10 concerts had been canceled, with the season expected to start on Dec. 5 at the earliest.

title: Hole in Fuselage Forces Qantas 747 to Land
description: The Australian authorities opened an investigation on Friday into what caused a section of the fuselage of a Qantas airliner to burst open en route from Hong Kong to Melbourne, Australia, forcing the Boeing 747-400 to make an emergency landing in Manila.

title: India: 7 Roadside Bomb Blasts in a Southern City Kill 2
description: At least seven roadside bombs exploded in the southern city of Bangalore shortly after noon, killing two people and wounding at least seven, according to the police and the Indian government. The police said that the citys famed technology sector did not seem to be the target. The explosions, which appeared to be intended to create panic, were set off in crowded middle-class neighborhoods. Police officials in Bangalore declined to speculate on who was responsible.

title: Cyprus: Leaders Set Date for Talks on Reunification
description: The Turkish and Greek leaders of Cyprus will convene for reunification talks on Sept. 3 for the first time since a proposal to unite the divided island was voted down in 2004, the Anatolian News Agency said. Demetris Christofias, left, the president of the Republic of Cyprus in the south, and Mehmet Ali Talat, the Turkish Cypriot leader of the north, met to decide the date to begin the talks. Any decision reached in the negotiations would be presented for public approval in simultaneous referendums on both sides of the island, said the United Nations mission chief in Cyprus, Taye-Brook Zerihoun.

description: NEW DELHI  At least seven low-intensity roadside explosions went off in the southern Indian city of Bangalore shortly after lunchtime on Friday, killing one woman waiting at a bus stop, according to the police and the Indian government.

description: An obituary on Friday about Paul Bentley, a Dallas detective who helped capture the presidential assassin Lee Harvey Oswald, included an incorrect identification from a museum curator, in some editions, for the brand of hat worn two days later by Jim Leavelle, a Dallas police detective photographed escorting Oswald when he was killed. title: Letters: Potty Mouths, Weighing the Risk, and the Banking Industry
description: Re When to Quote Those Potty Mouths (July 13): As we contemplate The Timess role in maintaining a certain level of civility with regard to obscenities or vulgar words, you might reflect on the meaning of civil.When George Carlins seven words are the subject of an opinion of the highest court in the nation and many, including Times editorial writers, complained that the decision violated our civil liberties, it could be argued that The Timess self-censorship actually helps undermine our civil society.As to the editor who worries because The Times goes into schools, it is frightening that any Times editor would think that any of Mr. Carlins words would be any news to a school child.Michael P. MillerPutnam Valley, N.Y., July 13, 2008  Ive been thinking a lot about your column. What I cant accept  in your column and in Times policy generally  is the failure to distinguish between using unfit language and reporting on it.You write as if it would be the same thing for you or a columnist to offer an opinion in unfit language as for a Times writer to report in the third person what a public figure has said that includes accurately quoted unfit language.Surely this is a fundamental journalistic distinction. If there is an argument for ignoring that distinction in this sort of case, the argument needs to be made.The classroom-breakfast table issue is not an argument, if it even is an issue  dont you think most parents and teachers also distinguish between using bad language and speaking seriously about someone elses use of it?Bill Kellers statement about being reluctant to lead the charge to a coarser public discourse is a silly overstatement. The policy has the effect common to most fig leaves, visual and rhetorical, inspiring people to peek underneath, in these cases at other sources of information.Toni H. OlivieroBrooklyn, July 24, 2008The writer is dean of liberal arts and sciences, Pratt Institute.  Putting aside the action that the Rev. Jesse Jackson described, why is the word in question dirty and other words describing the identical part of the anatomy, testicles or gonads, not dirty? Why is this particular word dirty when used in one context, but not others?After all, the group of letters considered dirty, when used as Mr. Jackson used them, are beyond reproach when used to name those small shelled fruit or seeds we gobble down with our beers, or that mad, eccentric character who hangs out at the street corner, or that small, usually square or hexagonal flat piece of metal or word, with a hole through it for screwing onto a bolt.What is there exactly that makes this word, a grouping of four perfectly neutral letters, dirty?Ronald RubinTopanga, Calif., July 14, 2008  You do a fine job of fence-sitting on the issue of reporting offensive speech.I propose two simple rules:Keep it clean (the present well-intentioned Times policy).Dont bowdlerize.If you cant say what they said, dont even say they said it. If its too important to ignore, its too important to censor.When the language is the story, you must report the language.Wittgenstein said it best: What we cannot speak about we must pass over in silence.Kim de RielHavertown, Pa., July 14, 2008  The decision of The Times not to directly quote the Rev. Jesse Jacksons offensive words raises the question: Why not use the technical term castration to indicate what he really said about Senator Barack Obama, as you say The Washington Post did?By removing that specific information from Mr. Jacksons statement, The Times missed the sad irony that one form of physical assault inflicted by lynch mobs on African-American men was castration. Viewed in its full context, the statement demonstrates how badly out of touch Mr. Jackson is with many in the black community (including me, an African-American who participated in the civil rights movement and who worked in his 1988 presidential primary campaign).John Brown ChildsSanta Cruz, Calif., July 14, 2008The writer is a professor of sociology at the University of California, Santa Cruz.  How about letting your grammar slip, and your spelling, to accord with common usage? Would the critical public similarly expect The Times to slide with the times? I think not.It is only where matters of a onetime prudish sensitivity are concerned, and it is only to justify their own such indulgence.But I just want to say that Im with you on where you arrive with it. I dont see The Times as lagging behind current taste, but as upholding the long-standing standard of propriety.Irv ThomasSeattle, July 13, 2008  I hope you will soon write a column about oral and written language. Except for a brief nod to literature and the Internet, all the examples you provide are from oral language (talk, rappers, rock bands, stage, screen, television), and then you extend those examples to written discourse. But oral language is not the same as written language. I have no idea if the medium is the message, but the medium certainly affects the message and audience.Its not a matter of being so prissy were out of touch or standards. Its a matter of accuracy and clarity, while appreciating and understanding the power and relationship between oral and written language and our humanity.Allen BergerSavannah, Ga., July 13, 2008The writer is emeritus professor of reading and writing at Miami University.  One of the reasons given for why The Times doesnt use dirty words whereas The New Yorker does is because The New Yorker is not delivered to middle- and high-school classrooms as 40,000 daily copies of The Times are.Perhaps if The Times did use dirty words, it would be delivering more than 40,000 daily copies. At least the 30,000 unread or barely skimmed copies would be scanned with more interest.Perhaps Id even start believing whats written in it again.Alex DeringPrinceton, N.J., July 14, 2008  I enjoyed your column about the editorial squeamishness regarding reporting the Rev. Jesse Jacksons wish to separate Barack Obama from his testicles.A coven of prudish (old maid) librarians indeed.Do Times (and other) editors really believe that children of an age to read The Times, at this point nearly a decade into a new and increasingly ill-spoken century, arent aware of most of the four-letter Anglo-Saxon adjectives bandied about so freely?To me, its just another example of editorial self-righteousness. In a 43-year career at The Baltimore Sun, they provided me with an abundance of giggles as the editors struggled with euphemspeak  how to report something without actually reporting it. (And they dont want quotes cleaned up! Yuk, yuk!)Robert A. ErlandsonTowson, Md., July 15, 2008  The papers writers and editors do not have to, and likely should not, write such vulgarities  except when such words are pertinent to the story. And in this case, the editors Paul Winfield and Chuck Strum seem to have lost their news sense. The man said it!What was newsworthy was the context and the entire quotation: the Rev. Jesse Jackson using Barack Obamas first name, leaning in sotto voce so that it appeared that Dr. Reed V. Tuckson had to struggle to hear him. Dr. Tucksons attempt to be polite and respectful while awkwardly, it seems to me, hiding shock behind outward stoicism. Mr. Jacksons making the talking down to black people comment, pausing, pulling away, leaning in again and making the nuts comment. And Mr. Jacksons settling back, pausing again, then making the violent gesture.By the end of it all Jackson seemed to be talking to himself rather than to Dr. Tuckson.I say all this having interviewed both gentlemen more than once when I was at United Press International and The Washington Post more than 20 years ago, and in Dr. Tucksons case, having shared a long, nonworking conversation during an airplane flight.The full quotation put in context would demonstrate all and more of what Mr. Winfield and Mr. Strum saw as being most newsworthy: the generational divide in political black leadership, the bitterness and palpable anger, the class-elitism issue, the simultaneous rejection and embrace of homogeneity. It is all there, and more. It is not all there when you leave out the nuts line. The Times editors neglected to consider the intelligence of their readers and the ability of those readers to process all of the pertinent information.So, Im with my former somewhat-of-a-colleague David Remnick at The New Yorker. The Times, The Washington Post and the few crumbs that are left of my hometown Baltimore Sun need to loosen the reins.Doug StevensonBaltimore, July 17, 2008  I was appalled that The Times thinks it is ever all right not to give an exact quote of what someone said. The paper cannot possibly have editorial standards that deem something important enough to print and not relate the words.What would the possible importance be of a quote that cannot be given? We use words to communicate. Adults use blue words to communicate among themselves.Maybe if The Times always used exact language we would avoid more bubbles and recessions, and enough people might understand in advance of disaster and change behavior. Its possible.Stephen J. BoyleJersey City, July 14, 2008  When a public figure uses a dirty word, and its central to the story, The Times has a duty to publish the quote. Otherwise, The Times is just not reporting the news. Citizens have a right to know what these public figures actually said because its germane to our judgment of their character.Should The Times include audio or video clips of these incidents? No, leave that to the tabloids.Should The Times worry about these words showing up in their school circulation? Todays middle and high school kids know and use vulgar and dirty language all the time.I used to teach high school. If The Times had added a line, Caution: coarse language, or something like that to clue me in, I would have used the article to open a discussion with my class about the quote, and about when language like that is appropriate and when its not.Herbert N. Swearengen IIIBlytheville, Ariz., July 13, 2008  When a public figure uses profanity or other demeaning language, the failure to quote him precisely is to falsify the portrait of the speaker.The essence of reporting is to provide the reader with a complete picture of the event. That includes the character of the participants. That means telling the reader what the speaker really is, not want he wants the public to see him to be.In other words, the Rev. Jesse Jackson has a very low, crass opinion of Barack Obama. Mr. Jackson needs to be seen that way, not another.Elihu I. RoseLake Success, N.Y., July 13, 2008  This Times policy serves only its own image, not the larger public civility it claims to be protecting. When a story prints, Cheney to senator: **** off (or however the obscenity is disguised), few readers will not supply the missing word.A basic principle of linguistics: if you have a word in mind and display some symbols to your audience so that the audience realizes what you meant to write, then you have communicated the word to them. Not actually printing the missing letters is a trick to give the illusion of civility, while allowing the unprintable language to be communicated just as clearly as if it were spelled out.This fussy preservation of the appearance of civility amounts to hypocrisy.Charles J. SmithBuffalo, July 13, 2008  So why not draw the line between quoting those who use the bad words and Times writers using them in their own writing?I have been so infuriated by the news media (especially radio and TV) talking to our own soldiers, the heroes people like to point to, and then bleeping what they say.Soldiers have always had foul mouths, and what theyre talking about is inherently offensive. People use offensive language, and they often use it for a very good reason. Let them.David BeanArlington, Mass., July 13, 2008 Please allow me to point out that cut off his nuts is not the same as castrate. Almost all Times editors and readers should know this well. It is an informal expression used almost exclusively in spoken English that is taken to be extreme hyperbole by both speaker and listener.The Rev. Jesse Jackson has no desire to castrate Barack Obama; even to joke about it is absurd. It is an emphatic expression used to express the depth of the speakers anger or outrage.It is also metaphorical, suggesting something like, Id really like to do something strong enough to get Barack Obama to pay attention and listen to what some of us are trying to tell him.By mistakenly treating Mr. Jacksons compressed, metaphorical expression as if it were literal, the Times did a disservice to readers and to Mr. Jackson by making the story confusing and shredding the coherence of what Mr. Jackson was trying to say.Wouldnt it be possible for The Times to simply use asterisks for offensive words? That would preserve the context of the remarks and not assign added meaning to them.As for potty, I find it more offensive than nuts, because it treats readers as if they were children.Chris DrakeHatoyama-machi, Japan, July 13, 2008 Re Weighing the Risk (July 6, 2008): A question you didnt raise is, Why does The New York Times publish the name of a nontorturing C.I.A. interrogator and not publish the names of those whove actually tortured people? Was it because it was easier to get Deuce Martinezs name?It seems to me that the real issue is that The Times, once again, is taking the easy route on digging deeper.Christopher CookPrague, July 6, 2008  In May, you defended The Timess practice of withholding the names of reporters reporting from Zimbabwe and Myanmar. Risk, you know. But now you defend The Timess disclosing of the name of the interrogator of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed. The peoples right to know, you know.But the real basis for decisions whether to disclose is clear: Will it harm the Bush war effort (if it will, yes; if it wont no)?You say that the Times has sometimes agreed, sometimes refused to withhold information when asked to do so by the C.I.A. Why dont you give readers some depth and disclose how many times it has agreed and refused since Iraq was invaded?Steven K. CochranDallas, July 7, 2008

title: McCain, Obama Trade Barbs Across the Seas
description: (Photo: Senator Barack Obama and British Prime Minister Gordon Brown walk on the Horse Guards Parade in London. (Pool photo by Peter MacDiarmid)) LONDON  Senators John McCain and Barack Obama engaged in a trans-Atlantic bickering match of sorts on Saturday, with Mr. McCain devoting the opening minutes of his weekly radio address to criticize Mr. Obama's weeklong trip through the Middle East and Europe.  "This week, the presidential contest was a long-distance affair, with my opponent touring various continents and arriving yesterday in Paris," Mr. McCain said. "With all the breathless coverage from abroad, and with Senator Obama now addressing his speeches to the people of the world, I'm starting to feel a little left out. Maybe you are too."  Mr. Obama, who spoke to reporters after finishing a meeting with British Prime Minister Gordon Brown, dismissed the criticism. He noted that Mr. McCain also had traveled to the Middle East and Europe  and beyond  since becoming the presumptive Republican nominee.  "It is hard for me to understand Senator McCain's argument," Mr. Obama said, standing in front of No. 10 Downing Street. "He was telling me I was supposed to take this trip. He suggested it and thought it was a good idea."  London was the final destination on Mr. Obama's foreign tour that began in Iraq and Afghanistan last weekend. He held a final round of meetings here on Saturday, sharing breakfast with former Prime Minister Tony Blair, holding an hourlong talk with opposition leader David Cameron and going for an outdoor stroll with Mr. Brown.  "We've been through two world wars together. We speak a common language. We share a belief in rule of law and due process," Mr. Obama said, explaining the relationship between the two countries. "We just like the people. There is a deep and abiding affection for the British people in America and a fascination with all things British that's not going to go away any time soon."  With that, Mr. Obama's foreign trip is nearly complete. By nightfall, he is scheduled to take off for Chicago.

title: Track Athletes in the Final Stretch
description: With the Olympics two weeks away, track and field athletes are getting their last tune-ups in before the Beijing Games.  For those in New York City early Sunday morning, the NYC Half-Marathon will include Olympians Dathan Ritzenheim of the United States, Hendrik Ramaala of South Africa, Catherine Ndereba of Kenya, and Madai Perez of Mexico. The race begins at 7 a.m. and a map of the course for spectators is available here. The event is particularly important for Ritzenhein, who qualified for the Olympic marathon but was sidelined this spring because of a a stress fracture in his left foot. He returned to competition earlier this month.  At the London Grand Prix, one of the last pre-Olympic meets, Asafa Powell continued his strong week, although his publicized duel in the 100 meters with Tyson Gay never materialized. On Tuesday, Powell beat the world record holder Usain Bolt in Stockholm. Friday in London, Powell won again. But Gay had pulled out of the race to nurse his ailing hamstring. Powell is scheduled to compete next week in Monaco as well.     Bolt did not compete in the 100 at Crystal Palace, but dominated the 200 on Saturday, winning in 19.76 ahead of the American Wallace Spearmon's 20.27. Bolt still has not decided whether he will run in both the 100 and the 200 in Beijing. "I'd definitely like to double," he said. "I think I could do well in both." That's a bit of an understatement.  In addition to a rare loss by Bernard Lagat in the 1,500, Allyson Felix had a surprising fourth-place finish in the 200 meters on Friday night. Sherone Simpson won the race, saying afterward, "To get a win so close to the Olympics is very good psychologically." Felix pulled out of the 100 on Saturday.   MEN'S BASKETBALL The United States men's basketball team won its first pre-Olympic exhibition, 120-65, over Canada on Friday night in Las Vegas. Dwyane Wade, in his first game action in four months, scored 20 points playing in place of the injured LeBron James. Carmelo Anthony and Michael Redd also had 20 points against the Canadians, who did not qualify for the Olympics. The Americans shot 65 percent from the field, with Redd doing what he was put on the team to do, making 6 of 8 3-point attempts.  The point guard play was interesting to follow. Jason Kidd started the game, played 16 minutes and didn't attempt a shot. He had five rebounds but no assists. Deron Williams and Chris Paul would seem to be in competition for the No. 2 point guard spot, but Coach Mike Krzyzewski put them into the game together in the first quarter. Williams finished with 14 points and 5 assists, while Paul had 11 points and 8 assists.   "When these two guys are in together, either one of them can bring the ball up and either one of them can pressure the ball," Krzyzewski explained. "They seem to like to play with one another. The intelligence of your team is at the highest level when you have two guys like them on the court at the same time. I was telling them that needs to be a strength of our team when the two of them are in together -- we can pickup a little bit better and try to wear some people down."  Krzyzewski was particularly impressed with the team's defense, which forced 24 turnovers." I like the effort we have on the defensive end of the court and after the first 10 minutes, that's the first game we played, we just seemed like we were in synch, we were passing the ball more, and playing much better defense the last three quarters," he said.  Chris Sheridan of ESPN.com charted each defensive possession and was impressed with Team USA's pressure, but still sees holes in the pick-and-roll defense. In Sporting News Today, Mike DeCourcy writes that despite the 55-point win, the game still showed in the importance of James.  Video of the postgame news conference is available at nba.com.  Team USA now heads to China, where it will play four more exhibition games before the Olympic tournament.

It has kept the economy from falling into even worse shape than it is in, but real improvement has proved elusive.

For those of us whose political agenda doesnt begin and end with the goal of bringing down the Cuban government, it is frustrating to see all the Florida politicians (with the single exception of Janet Reno) subservient to what has been a seemingly monolithic voting bloc.

title: Correction: Review of Rome 1960

They were the first commercially televised Summer Games, not the first televised Olympics. (Olympic events had been televised in various formats since the 1936 Summer Games, which were shown on screens around Berlin.)

description: NOT long ago, I wrote that New Yorks last Worlds Fair, in 1964-65, paled in comparison with the 1939 version, but at least did expose Michelangelos Piet to millions and popularized the Belgian waffle. In his new book, The End of the Innocence: The 1964-65 New York Worlds Fair (Syracuse University Press, $29.95), Lawrence R. Samuel rejects similar swipes as dismissive thinking. Instead, he delivers an overdue and well-deserved encomium to a largely denigrated chapter in the citys history.

Seligman & Companys target-date funds would hold. The total would be 65 percent of the portfolio, with an additional 35 percent in fixed-income investments. Such an investors portfolio would not be 75 percent equities and real estate investment trusts.

title: A Leading Role, With Room to Stretch
description: EARLY one especially fine morning last month in Central Park, New Yorkers kept stopping to watch Melissa Leo shoot a scene for a movie called Veronika Decides to Die. There wasnt a lot to see, just Ms. Leo on a park bench trading lines with the English actor David Thewlis, who, like her, is known as an actors actor, which is to say, immensely talented and insufficiently famous. The movie, based on a Paulo Coelho novel and starring Sarah Michelle Gellar, is an indie aimed for release next year. Ms. Leo does a lot of those, and her part is secondary. She does a lot of those too. But, she said later of the character she plays, Its a pretty classic supporting role, with several scenes throughout and her own arc in the film.

The only thing wrong with the sport, he told an interviewer, was that there arent enough sex scandals.

title: Public Slur in 1938 Laid Bare a Games Racism
description: The National Baseball Hall of Fame recently updated Jackie Robinsons plaque to reflect the courage and poise he showed in integrating baseball in 1947. No plaque or distinction will ever be accorded Jake Powell  nor should they  but his racist comment 70 years ago broke the conspiracy of silence that protected segregated baseball.

title: In Zimbabwe Talks, Who Will Get the Real Power?
description: JOHANNESBURG  As negotiators for President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe and the opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai began power-sharing talks on Thursday in South Africa, they confronted one seemingly unbridgeable divide: which man would have the real executive power in a unity government?

title: Nassau System Will Pinpoint Gunfire Sites
description: NASSAU COUNTY police officers responding to a call of shots fired in Roosevelt in June discovered a 21-year-old man dead on the pavement. Potential witnesses would not talk to the police, and it took almost a month for them to track down a suspect in the shooting.

title: Deborah Ellis, Hal Strelnick

title: Called to Help: 28 Years as a Lifeguard
description: WHEN people hear Im a lifeguard, the first thing they usually think of is the television show Baywatch. They ask me if I spend my day checking out women on the beach like the guys on the show. They ask me if real-life rescues always end as happily as they do on TV.

title: Cocaine Sustains War in Rural Colombia
description: PASTO, Colombia  Along with Colombias successes in fighting leftist rebels this year, cities like Medelln have staged remarkable recoveries. And in the upscale districts of Bogot, the capital, it is almost possible to forget that the country remains mired in a devilishly complex four-decade-old war.

title: What Aasha Saw
description: What can fiction offer in this age of instant messaging and quick downloads? Search and click: far away locales zoom into focus on the computer screen, along with helpful links to rental cars. News, history, travel blogs await. And yet all the information in the world cannot substitute for the long slow banquet of a fine novel.

title: Flights First Fatal Trip
description: For the 100th anniversary of powered flight, President Bush in 2003 went to Kitty Hawk, N.C., for a re-enactment of the Wright Brothers feat. September will mark another major centennial in aviation history, though no ceremony has been announced: the first death of an airplane passenger.

title: Recalling a Radical Aesthetic in Minimal Dance and Sound
description: In the art world, as elsewhere, a kind of 1960s nostalgia is back in vogue. That eras experimentation and radicalism certainly seem to underlie Tacita Deans installation at Dia:Beacon. In April 2007, Ms. Dean, a 43-year-old, British-born, Berlin-based artist, shot six subtly different short films of the legendary choreographer and dancer Merce Cunningham, who had just turned 88, as he performed Stillness, in which his minimalist choreography is adapted to John Cages radical, equally minimal 1952 composition 433.

title: A Literary Light
description: At the age of 88, youre newly bedecked with a Nobel Prize and have a new book, Alfred & Emily, whose title refers to your parents, British colonists who raised you in Rhodesia. Here, you tell their story twice  first as a novella in which you dream up happy lives for them and then as a memoir based on the sad facts. It strikes me as a tender book. Its not a question of tenderness. Its a question of justice. I wanted to write about my mother as she should have been if she had not been messed up by World War I.

title: A Library With a Past Ponders Its Future
description: TWO years ago, a lanky teenager named Adolfo Abreu who lives in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx got involved in a campaign to turn the shuttered Fordham Library Center into a youth center. Unhappy about the dearth of activities available to him and his friends, he spent months rallying support for the cause, only to learn in late May that the city was eyeing the former library for use as an animal shelter.

title: After Iowa Raid, Immigrants Fuel Labor Inquiries
description: POSTVILLE, Iowa  When federal immigration agents raided the kosher meatpacking plant here in May and rounded up 389 illegal immigrants, they found more than 20 under-age workers, some as young as 13.

title: Correction: Up Front
description: An illustration with the Up Front column last Sunday was published in error. The Howard Hampton it depicts is the leader of the New Democratic Party of Ontario, not the reviewer with the same name who was profiled in the column, An illustration of the reviewer appears above.

title: Brain Teasers
description: THERE are all kinds of products out there that are supposed to boost your brainpower. Right now, for example, I am wired into a device called the MC Square, which is apparently used by millions of Korean students while studying for their college entrance exams. Its sending a continuous stream of dolphin noises into my ears, along with a droning techno beat, and it works, as far as I can tell, on the principle that whatever is extremely annoying must be good for you.

title: Nothing to Eat
description: Paul Robertss prophetic and well-received 2004 book, The End of Oil: On the Edge of a Perilous New World, anticipated the current energy crisis. Now hes moved on to what we put in our mouths. Robertss new book, The End of Food, which takes into account a vertiginous pile of recent developments  including the so-called tortilla riots of 2007, during which thousands took to the Mexico City streets to protest the rapidly rising cost of maize  may prove no less prescient.

title: Kathleen Kinkade, Founder of Utopian Commune, Is Dead at 77

Twin Oaks, an experimental community near Charlottesville, Va., inspired by the behaviorist ideas of B. F. Skinner, still survives after more than 40 years. Kathleen Kinkade, one of its founders, died there on July 3 at the age of 77.

title: Corrections: For the Record

The surname of the league president is Donna Orender  not Ordener, as it was misspelled in some copies. Ms. Orender said the W.N.B.A.s attendance, relevance and excitement were on an upward trending, not training. And the league goes on hiatus for the Beijing Olympics on Monday, not on Aug. 28.

title: Mind Over Whats the Matter
description: It is very hard to write well about ethics, and especially so in a way that engages and interests that elusive phantom of writers imaginations, the general reader. But Susan Neimans previous book on ethics, Evil in Modern Thought, was widely and favorably reviewed, and the present work is a worthy successor. Neimans particular skill lies in expressing sensitivity, intelligence and moral seriousness without any hint of oversimplification, dogmatism or misplaced piety. She clearly and unflinchingly sees life as it is, but also sees how it might be, and could be, if we recaptured some of the hopes and ideals that currently escape us.

description: So whats it to be, babes on the beach, or bats out of hell?

title: Charles L. Brieant Jr., Longtime Federal Judge, Is Dead at 85
description: Charles L. Brieant Jr., a former chief judge of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York who presided over a raft of controversial and sometimes unusual cases, died last Sunday in Manhattan. He was 85 and lived in Ossining, N.Y.

title: The Breakups That Got Under My Skin
description: IN my early 20s I had a habit of getting a tattoo after a breakup. The first was after my college love, the one boy, among many, who had stayed. He was the person I thought I would marry, if only because I couldnt imagine that someone would finally love me and then leave. I was still virginal in this way when it came to breakups.

A chant of We love Bill! rose from the adoring crowd of 2,000 well-wishers, some of whom wore buttons and waved fans decorated with Mr. Clintons face.

title: Inside the List
description: POPULAR NOTIONS: Larry McMurtry, whose new memoir, Books, is reviewed in this issue by James Campbell, had his first novel, Horseman, Pass By, published in 1961. It quickly jumped to the screen as Hud, the Paul Newman movie. McMurtrys next two novels were also turned into films  Leaving Cheyenne (1963) became Lovin Molly and The Last Picture Show (1966) became, well, The Last Picture Show. For all of McMurtrys critical and filmic success, including the publication of Terms of Endearment in 1975, he didnt place a book on the Times best-seller list until 1985, when the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel Lonesome Dove had a 24-week run in hardcover and inspired a much-admired mini-series. Since then, his novels have appeared here frequently. Reviewing McMurtrys first novel in the Book Review in 1961, the journalist Wayne Gard spotted his talent. Some popular notions of life on a Texas cattle ranch are exploded in this short, realistic novel, Gard wrote. The cow hands ride horses less often than pickup trucks or Cadillacs. And in the evening, instead of sitting around a campfire strumming guitars and singing Git along, little dogie, they are more likely to have a game at the pool hall, drink beer and try their charms on any girls they can find. ... Larry McMurtry has not only a sharp ear for dialogue but a gift of expression that easily could blossom in more important works.

title: Watch the Children, That Subversive Is Back
description: IN 1960 Tomi Ungerer was returning from his native France to New York City, his adopted home, when he realized that three men were walking uncomfortably close to him as he was leaving a terminal at the old Idlewild airport in Queens. One ordered him to drop his suitcases. Then the others latched onto him, hustled him into a car and drove him to a nearby building where they questioned him obliquely about his travel and his political affiliations.

title: Catalysts for Change
description: 1. SPREADING THE WORD: For the last four summers, Dartmouth students have circled the country  13,000 miles  aboard a school bus fueled mostly by waste vegetable oil. The best source? Vats in the back at Chinese restaurants. Weve found a lot of really great grease, says Addie Gorlin, a sophomore majoring in geography and history. The mission is to proselytize about alternative fuel, exchange ideas with local leaders and show off their mobile museum of sustainable living. The 12 students stop at zoo parking lots, pull up at block parties and hang out at state parks (this weekend, theyre in Rainier, Wash.). The clunker of a bus, retrofitted by students, has five 200-watt solar panels, thanks to sponsors, that power the essentials: television, stereo, refrigerator and laptops for daily blogging. The first Big Green Bus tour was organized in 2005 by a pack of Dartmouth ultimate Frisbee players, borrowing the symbolism from Middlebury, whose Project Bio Bus had circumnavigated the year before. Andrew Zabel, a senior majoring in government, is one of this years Big Green Bus organizers. Sixty students applied for the trip. We dont choose based on being an expert, Mr. Zabel says. Its a vehicle for creating an environmentalist  a theater major, a history major, wherever you go in life, to do it through that green lens.

title: Kerouac Got an A
description: AFTER lunch one summer with my grandmother, years ago at her Connecticut farmhouse, she asked me to retrieve an inconsequential item from a closet in my grandfathers study, and something else caught my eye. At first it didnt look like much: a set of three slim ledgers with marbleized covers, perhaps a journal of expenses or a record of household bills. But in it were pages and pages of names, methodically scribed in pen and ink.

description: Andrea Joyce Ching was married on Saturday evening to Benjamin Carl Winkler at Pochron Studios, a loft space in Brooklyn. Daniel Birdsall, a friend who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated.

description: THAT Jenna Didier and Oliver Hess could marry in a once contaminated Los Angeles field and hold a reception below a concrete overpass and still make it all look glamorous is typical of them.

description: IN the cozy lobby of what was once a Catskills hotel, nearly 300 children were sitting in chairs and on the floor, crammed in and anxious. It was Day 3 at Stagedoor Manor, a theater camp in Loch Sheldrake, N.Y., and in just a moment, the campers would learn which roles they would play in shows like Aida and Les Misrables. title: Too Big to Fail, or to Survive
description: CRITICS of the Congressional housing package complain that we are now committing taxpayers to huge new outlays to rescue Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. That view is wrong: Congressional inaction over the past 15 years had already committed taxpayers to the bailout.

title: Ice Free
description: Greenlands ice sheet represents one of global warmings most disturbing threats. The vast expanses of glaciers  massed, on average, 1.6 miles deep  contain enough water to raise sea levels worldwide by 23 feet. Should they melt or otherwise slip into the ocean, they would flood coastal capitals, submerge tropical islands and generally redraw the worlds atlases. The infusion of fresh water could slow or shut down the oceans currents, plunging Europe into bitter winter.

title: Raucous Russian Tabloids Thrive
description: MOSCOW  For decades, Komsomolskaya Pravda served up article after leaden article about Soviet officials meeting with other Soviet officials. Now, reinvented as a tabloid, the newspaper has a rowdier agenda  and a huge audience.

title: Ultimate Study Tool: Testing
description: REREADING class notes with highlighter in hand may not be the best way to study. New research suggests that frequent testing  even self-testing  is a better bet for retaining information.

title: Up to Her Ears
description: WHEN Esperanza Spalding, the jazz singer and bassist, appeared on David Lettermans show in June, Paul Shaffer called her the coolest guest weve ever had. At 23, she has already been sidewoman to the likes of Herbie Hancock and Pat Metheny, and three years ago became the youngest faculty member ever at Berklee College of Music in Boston.

description: PUT on a hard hat, stand on the roof of the building under construction at 211 Elizabeth Street, and look north. You will see an old brick building, across Prince Street, with white ornamentation around the windows. To the right is another old brick building, with a newer brick addition where the cornice used to be. Next to that is a third brick building.

The Afghan president joined President and Mrs. Bush, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and Ambassador Ronald Neumann to dedicate the new United States Embassy. He thanked the American people for all they had done for Afghanistan. I was a senior counternarcotics official recently arrived in a country that supplied 90 percent of the worlds heroin. I took to heart Karzais strong statements against the Afghan drug trade. That was my first mistake.

Later that year, Artforum featured another monumental work, Robert Smithsons Spiral Jetty, an immobile cyclone of boulders jutting out from a desolate coast of Utahs Great Salt Lake.

title: Shelf-Possessed
description: To a common reader, the world of book dealers revolves around a mystery: how can they bear to let their prized objects go? Larry McMurtry entered the business with serious intent around 1960 when he was offered five excellent collections of modern literature for a little over $100 a collection. The writers in question were Ernest Hemingway, William Faulkner, Sinclair Lewis, Edwin Arlington Robinson and John Steinbeck. The volumes lacked Hemingways first book, Three Stories and Ten Poems, published in Paris in 1923 by Contact Editions, and similarly rare items by Faulkner and Lewis, but all the other books were there, and they were there in exceptional condition. Scarcely had he had time to enjoy his good fortune  the collections presumably included not only In Our Time but also Faulkners sub-Joycean caper, Mosquitoes  than McMurtry sold the collection to Rice University for $1,000, yielding a profit of almost 70 percent, which, as he says in a related context, was not to be sneezed at, in those days or these days either.

description: BOSTON  Craig Hansens fastball hummed inside and drilled Alex Rodriguezs left arm in the eighth inning Saturday. By the time Rodriguez grabbed his arm, the fans at Fenway Park were howling. To them, it was retribution because Joba Chamberlain hit Kevin Youkilis once and nearly drilled him three times in the past year, including a brushback pitch on Friday.

description: NEW DELHI  For the second time in two days, small explosions rocked an Indian city, this time in Ahmedabad on Saturday evening, killing at least 45 people. The Indian government said cities across the country had been put on alert for similar attacks.

title: Last Days for a Midtown Fixture With an Orchard Street Feel
description: EVEN down to its name, Judys Better Dresses could have been a fixture on Orchard Street. Everything from its hours (closed on Saturday, the Jewish Sabbath, and for many years open on Sunday) to its racks jammed with conservative but tasteful suits and blouses and coats, all carrying tags with marked-down prices, gives the store a Lower East Side feel.

title: The Sustainable Hampton
description: AN old stone and shingle windmill, atop a bluff near the breezy far end of Long Island, is the symbolic heart of the State University of New Yorks newest campus. Built around 1713, the mill once harnessed wind to generate power. Later, it was a guest house where Tennessee Williams spent a summer in the 1950s. Now it is undergoing reconstruction, its rotting beams replaced and huge blades rebuilt, as the campus takes shape around it. Aptly, Stony Brook Southampton is dedicated mind and body to the pursuit of sustainability.

title: Paperback Row
description: SHADOW OF THE SILK ROAD, by Colin Thubron. (Harper Perennial, $15.95.) The Silk Road is a fretwork of trade routes dating back to 1500 B.C. Here, Thubron, the dean of British travel writers, recounts his 7,000-mile journey along the route in 2003 and 2004, from Xian, China, to the Turkish coastal city of Antioch. At different periods, everything on the known earth had passed this way, Thubron writes: frankincense, rhinoceros horn, cucumbers, musk, dwarfs, lapis lazuli, peacocks, indigo eye-shadow ... even a caged lion or two. Today policemen looking for drugs and bureaucrats protecting borders have replaced the traders. Thubron, who traveled in this area before the collapse of the Soviet Union, compares present with past, making the book moving in a way thats rare in travel literature, Lorraine Adams commented in the Book Review.

title: So You Always Wanted to Be...a Card Dealer
description: NINE miles from the Foxwoods Resort Casino in eastern Connecticut, tucked away in a nondescript office building, is a casino larger than the blackjack, dice and roulette pits at many Las Vegas gambling halls. It is a replica where the nations largest casino trains dealers.

title: The Endless School Year
description: SURE, its 97 degrees outside and nearly the same in Corcoran Hall at George Washington University. Prof. Martn Zysmilich did receive the unfortunate e-mail about the air-conditioning breakdown, but there is serious material to cover. Just eight minutes into a 90-minute lecture, Dr. Zysmilich, a lanky Argentine in brown Pumas who rides his bicycle to class, has filled the overhead screen in Room 106 with graphs showing the distribution of electrons in s, p and d orbitals. He pauses to ask students, some fanning themselves and sipping iced beverages (and one with a wet paper towel plastered on the front of her neck), Can I erase this?

Tad Kubler, 35, the lead guitarist, ventured to Three Kings Tattoo in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, having chosen a bison facing off with a general as his 20th or so tattoo and the inside of his elbow as the perfect slate for it. Craig Finn, 36, the lyricist, vocalist and guitarist, was pacing the bands rehearsal space in Greenpoint and sifting through junk, including a book on baseball stadiums.

A novelist whose books include The Inn at Lake Devine, The Ladies Man and Then She Found Me, which was made into a recent movie starring Helen Hunt and Colin Firth, Ms. Lipman, 57, had spent pieces of many summers on the Cape and thought it was finally time to solidify the relationship.

title: Shockey Goes to Saints, Fans Go to the Keyboard
description: The Giants traded tight end Jeremy Shockey to the New Orleans Saints last Monday for two draft picks in 2009  one in the second round, one in the fifth. A perennial Pro Bowl pick, Shockey had 371 catches for 4,228 yards and 27 touchdowns in 83 regular-season games with the Giants. Kevin Boss, a fifth-round draft choice in 2007, will try to fill his shoes, along with Jerome Collins, Darcy Johnson, Michael Matthews and the rookie Eric Butler. Readers of The Fifth Down, The Timess pro football blog, weighed in on the trade.

He had an insiders knowledge of their egos and frailties. He appreciated that he couldnt succeed with just Martin Luther King Jr. on his team; he needed Everett M. Dirksen, the Senates Republican leader, too. His touch could be light or very firm, as the moment required.

Half of the time, she ends up packing their 2- and 4-year-old daughters into the family sedan and driving 15 minutes from their home in Fairfield, Conn., to Westport, where Mr. Rogers teaches computers and psychology at Staples High School.

In BLACK SECONDS (Harcourt, $24), all it takes is the disappearance of a child. Granted, this is no ordinary kiddie  9-year-old Ida Joner is so sweet and enchanting shes like a child in a fairy tale. Everyone in the village of Glassverket loves Ida, but none more than her mother, who idolizes her golden girl. A sad, fatalistic woman, Helga Joner has always felt that Ida was just too good to be true. ... Too good to last, and when Ida vanishes after setting off on her new yellow bicycle to buy a magazine, the distraught Helga goes to pieces.

title: 36 Hours in Palermo
description: IN its 2,700-year history, the port city of Palermo has undergone three golden ages: the Carthaginians, Arabs and Normans all found glory along its rugged shores. And now, after decades of post-War neglect and mafia corruption, the often overlooked Sicilian capital is poised for a fourth  or at least a well-deserved comeback. Crumbling roads are being repaved, landmarks scrubbed clean and a newfound pride can be felt. But the essential charms of this mysterious and intoxicating city thankfully remain intact. There are still seductive old neighborhoods, a delightful patchwork of architecture (whats the word for Arab-Norman-Spanish-Baroque?), and a belching chaotic mess known as Palermo traffic.

Only 2 percent of colleges and universities use the late-start semester, and a stubborn 15 percent have stuck with the quarter system. Does it make a difference? In fact, the way the academic year is divided has a lot to do with the way students can go about their education.

title: Lewis Hamilton Just Wants to Go Fast
description: ISTANBUL PARK is not really a park but a three-mile-long race-car track situated in a forlorn area of scrubland and solitary, flag-draped Shell gas stations about 40 miles east of Istanbul, off the main highway to Ankara. A development of pink-stucco villas was encroaching on some old farms. It was a Friday morning in early May, two days before the Turkish Grand Prix. At the security checkpoint, my driver, Suleyman, slapped my press credentials against the windshield, and the armed guards hurriedly waved us past, and we rolled down to the entrance. Istanbul Park opened three years ago. To everyone other than the Formula One teams and the attendant pack of journalists, it is an incongruous aspect of the tracks festive design that the 25,000-seat grandstand is rarely full. But the teams dont much care about full grandstands, not when as many as 80 million people watch the race on television. All Formula One needs is a country willing to spend about $150 million to build a state-of-the-art track. Besides, it is a well-known fact in the paddock, the enclave where the teams set up their deluxe motor homes for the five days of a race, that Istanbul Park has been a wash for the Turkish government. Last year, it leased the facility to Bernie Ecclestone, the London businessman whose firm owns the commercial rights to Formula One, including television rights, and disburses the revenues to the teams according to a system he created three decades ago. You could point to the grand prix venues that have popped up in the past few years  in Shanghai, Bahrain, Singapore  and conclude that a glamorous European sport fits the ambitions of these countries, along with towering new skyscrapers and designer hotels. But this gets it only partly right. Formula One needs these new markets so it can make more money, and a country, whatever else it may be, is a market.

Much finer houses have been torched by their owners or else auctioned off to save on taxes. But the place had an extraordinary hold on Miranda Seymours father, and though its a source of mostly unhappy memories, to this day she cant quite bring herself to sell it. Her odd and oddly affecting book, beautifully written, is in part a story of house-love that borders on madness.

title: Children of God

For a few minutes, she was not  as has been speculated about many of the young women of the Fundamentalist Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, or F.L.D.S.  a possible child bride, or a sexual-abuse victim, or a member of an out-of-touch, polygamous religious sect. She was just a kid in a tree, perched serenely above the heads of all the lawyers, reporters and sheriffs deputies  a moon-faced girl with an auburn coxcomb of hair and a mischievous grin.

The Marchmains are everything Ryder is not and aspires to be: grand, hedonistic, emotionally complex. For those who (like myself, at an impressionable age) obsessed over every detail in the 11-part mini-series of the Waugh book back in 1981, Brideshead was a fascinating tour of a dream England, full of beautiful, tortured souls in glorious houses. The story is complicated by class and religion: the Marchmains are staunch Roman Catholics, and Sebastian, Ryders schoolmate and entree to the tangled world, is tormented by his sexuality.

title: Branded
description: Late in 2006, pollsters at the Pew Research Center called up 2,000 Americans and asked a simple question: Which products could people simply not live without? Take the dishwasher, for instance  was it a luxury or an ineluctable necessity of modern life? And did they believe they needed, rather than merely wanted, a clothes washer and dryer? How about a home computer, a microwave oven, high-speed Internet service and air-conditioning? Yes, yes, yes and yes, the nation nodded in assent. In just about every product category, Americans self-professed needs had ballooned since the hand-to-mouth 1990s. Not long ago, we thought of the cellphone as a high-class extravagance; nowadays, we feel naked without it.

title: Will I Am
description: Heavens to Murgatroyd! What could William Shakespeare, bard of Avon, possibly have in common with the cartoon characters Lilo and Stitch, Mickey Mouse and Buzz Lightyear? If you read My Name Is Will, a lusty, pun-drunk first novel by the professional wiseacre and award-winning cartoon producer Jess Winfield (who had a hand in the above-mentioned entertainments), you will indubitably find out. But be vewwy, vewwy careful, as one of Winfields characters (a Shakespeare expert!) warns a wayward student, mimicking the immortal Elmer Fudd. Many of the gags are what Hanna-Barberas hammy mountain lion Snagglepuss would call abdomenable; and if youve never heard the expression Whats in a name, youll get to read it here for the first time  actually, the first, second and third times. Still, if youre up for the lark and could use a comedies-and-tragedies refresher, you might want to invest in a slide whistle and a cowbell before you start reading, to give the goings-on the Looney Tunes accompaniment they deserve.

I nearly walked out in disgust, but I digress.

title: Cause Sought in Blast at Queens Building That Followed Gas Work

title: The Artist at War
description: Bill Mauldin (1921-2003) was my first artist hero, and a new two-volume collection of his wartime cartoons, WILLIE & JOE: The WWII Years (Fantagraphics, $65), edited by Todd DePastino, reminds me why. In 1957, when I was 7, I found my fathers worn copy of Up Front, the best-selling collection of Mauldins regular Stars and Stripes comic panel of the same name, about the travails of two dogfaced G.I.s, Willie and Joe. At the time, I wanted to be a cartoonist and spent many uninterrupted hours almost every day copying and recopying the details in each picture  they were my plaster casts. I learned drawing by faithfully replicating Mauldins comic brush-and-ink vignettes, and I learned a lot about the war, too, but not always what my history teacher wanted me to know.

title: Unesco Adds to Its World Heritage List
description: Unesco this month added 27 sites to its World Heritage list, which now has 878 sites in 145 countries. Nineteen new sites fall into the cultural category. They include the Historic Center of Camagey, an inland village in Cuba founded by the Spaniards in 1528; the Armenian Monastic Ensembles, three structures in northwest Iran that are dedicated to the Armenian Christian faith (the oldest dates from the seventh century); and the Wooden Churches of the Slovak part of the Carpathian Mountain area (Slovakia), which consists of eight structures built between the 16th and the 18th centuries for the Roman Catholic, the Protestant and the Greek Orthodox faiths. New natural sites include Surtsey, a volcanic island in Iceland formed between 1963 and 1967; the Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve in Mexico; and the Socotra Archipelago in Yemen in the northwest Indian Ocean near the Gulf of Aden. For more information on these sites, or to see the complete list, visit www.unesco.org.

title: Silent Treatment

Yet along with these talents Isabelle has a problem thats breaking her fathers heart and driving her mother to expletive-laden distraction. As December opens, she hasnt said a word for nine months.
