title: The Curator
description: When William Davies King, a professor of theater at the University of California, Santa Barbara, starts off his book by telling us about the day he came home and found that his soon-to-be-ex wife had delivered all his possessions to their garage, we feel for him. Love hurts. But gradually, as we discover precisely what these possessions were  an inveterate pack rat, King has over the years collected some 18,000 food labels, 500 bottle caps and 800 distinct envelope linings, plus smaller armadas of matchbook covers and junk mail and paperback book covers, as well as labels for nonfood items like nails and cat litter and tampons  our sympathy shifts slightly. Living with this self-appointed curator and docent probably isnt a bed of roses. Were talking about a man who once collected worn strips of masking tape that he pulled off the floor of a gymnasium, a man who collects the business cards of business card printers, even though he himself carries no business card. Suddenly its easy to imagine how strangely apt it might have felt for his wife to heap onto that pile Kings 53 empty Cheez-It boxes.

title: The Online Legacy of Professor Pausch
description: It was the power of the Internet that propelled computer science professor Randy Pausch to fame around the world after his inspiring last lecture and helped launch his bestselling book. So it seems a fitting tribute to document the many links, videos and other items that make up his online legacy.  (Photo: Randy Pausch and his family. (Randy Pausch))   A Google search of Dr. Pausch's "The Last Lecture" generates more than 9 million links and counting. Here are some of the best.  "Really Achieving Your Childhood Dreams": Video of the original talk at Carnegie Mellon University that started it all.   "The Bridge": A chapter from the book that was cut from the print edition but remains available online.  Best quotes: Wikiquote has compiled a list of the best quotes from Dr. Pausch.  "The Last Lecture" discussion guide: A guide to the book for parents, educators and book clubs.  "The Time Management Lecture": Despite the hype about "The Last Lecture," Dr. Pausch's favorite lecture was this one.  The Alice Project: Educational software that teaches computer programming to children, and the project that Dr. Pausch viewed as his professional legacy.  Dr. Pausch's update page: The blog and Web site where Dr. Pausch kept us informed about his health with humor and honesty, and shared milestones, fun moments and pictures of his family.  Medical summary: Information about his diagnosis and illness, written by Dr. Pausch in December 2007.  Carnegie Mellon graduation speech: A six-minute talk to the university's class of 2008, an event described by Dr. Pausch as "the perfect day.''  Congressional testimony: In a video of his moving testimony before Congress on behalf of the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network, Dr. Pausch holds up a picture of his family, describing his children and introducing Jai as "my widow.'' "We don't have advocates for this disease,'' he said, "because they don't live long enough.''  Time Magazine's most influential: Time magazine named Dr. Pausch one of the world's 100 most influential people in an essay written by CBS News anchor Katie Couric.  (Photo: "It was fantastic beyond my wildest dreams," Pausch said about practicing with the Steelers. (Danielle Hudak/The Pittsburgh Steelers))   Meeting the Pittsburgh Steelers: A video of Dr. Pausch meeting with the football team. The New York Times also reported on the day in "Dying of Cancer, but Full of Life Lessons.'' To see great video of Dr. Pausch playing with the team, watch the 41-minute Diane Sawyer special below.  Answering questions: A five-minute Time magazine video features Dr. Pausch responding to 10 reader questions; he talked about the theme song to "Rocky" and why "Groundhog Day" remained one of his favorite movies.  Wall Street Journal coverage: A new tribute video from Dr. Pausch's friend and co-author Jeffrey Zaslow, as well as several other articles by Mr. Zaslow, including the original report that cast an international spotlight on Dr. Pausch.  PanCan: A public service announcement Dr. Pausch made for the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network.  Oprah appearance: Dr. Pausch reprised his famous lecture in a 12-minute segment on the talk show.  The ABC special: A 41-minute Diane Sawyer segment on Dr. Pausch, featuring his wife Jai and people who say their lives were changed by "The Last Lecture."  Media remembrances: Several news organizations have offered obituaries and tributes to Dr. Pausch. The New York Times called him "a Lou-Gehrig-like symbol of the beauty and briefness of life.'' The Washington Post noted that when Dr. Pausch gave his lecture, there was nothing to suggest the speaker's future celebrity. "There was just a bright, personable guy with a lot of energy, a terminal disease, and something he wanted to say.'' The Los Angeles Times called him a "symbol for living and dying well.'' And Time magazine has a lovely essay called "Life Teacher.''  In his own words: An audio clip of Dr. Pausch reading from the introduction to "The Last Lecture" and other book-related items can be found on "The Last Lecture" Web site.  Fundraising: Donations on Dr. Pausch's behalf can be made to the Pancreatic Cancer Action Network or Carnegie Mellon's Randy Pausch Honorary Fund.  And finally, add your thoughts to the hundreds of tributes left by readers of the Well blog.

title: German Athletes Have T-Shirt Choice
description: Germany and its athletes have been among the more outspoken Olympic participants when it comes to human rights in China.   Chancellor Angela Merkel has taken a hard line on China, saying that she will not attend the opening ceremony. (The former Chancellor Gerhard Schroder is going, reflecting two different approaches to China.) A group of German athletes designed and promoted wristbands that say Sports for Human Rights, with proceeds going to Amnesty International. Yvonne Bnisch, who won a gold medal in judo in 2004, has said she will boycott the opening ceremony to protest human rights violations in Tibet. German businesses even got into the act. The chief executive of Volkswagen, Martin Winterkorn, speaking at a shareholders' meeting in April, urged China to "open up their society." Volkswagen was the first foreign automaker to enter the Chinese market and is a sponsor of the Beijing Games.  So perhaps it should come as no surprise that at a send-off for the German Olympic team Saturday, the German Olympic Sports Confederation was presented with T-shirts with slogans like "Fair Games," "Sport for Human Rights," "Celebrate Humanity," "Free Tibet" and "Free China." According to Agence France-Presse, the T-shirts were given by a group of former German athletes, including Dieter Baumann, who won the 5,000 meters at the Barcelona Games in 1992, and the sprinter Ines Geipel. The shirts will be available to wear at the German House in Beijing, which has been set up by the federation for its athletes, their guests and news conferences.   "We do not want to tell athletes how to behave, but perhaps some of them will wear them in the German House, which has ex-territorial status, to show how they feel," Geipel said.   Germany was among the countries that asked the I.O.C. for clarification on the Olympic Charter's rules on political displays. In an memo released this spring, the International Olympic Committee prohibited athletes competing in the Beijing Games from making political statements in Olympic areas. In particular, the memo stated:   Rule 51.3 of the Olympic Charter provides that "no kind of demonstration or political, religious or racial propaganda is permitted in any Olympic sites, venues or other areas". For the purpose of these guidelines, these areas are defined as every area for which an official Olympic accreditation is required. Compliance with this Rule implies avoiding the display of any sign, banner, poster, piece of equipment or clothing which could be perceived as any kind of demonstration or propaganda.  In rejecting calls for an Olympic boycott in March, the German Olympic Sport Confederation released a statement that described the human rights situation in China as unsatisfactory. That statement also said: "Sport is not a suitable tool to be used to apply political pressure. Sport is not in a position to solve the problems that neither the United Nations nor individual nations were able to resolve despite decades of effort. ... We believe sport is there to promote dialogue and international understanding. Sport builds bridges, not walls."

title: Was That Sandy Koufax?
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. - That man in the booth in front of me at the coffee shop during breakfast Sunday morning: was that Sandy Koufax? It looked a lot like him: good-looking, silver-haired, trim, tan. I've never met Koufax, only seen him from afar, so I couldn't be asolutely certain that this man, sipping coffee, was Sandy.  And if Sandy Koufax were sitting alone in a booth at the Triple Play Caf on Main Street across from the Hall of Fame, what would I do? Intrude on the privacy he's cultivated for so long to ask him some noodgy questions about his career or his friendship with the Mets' owner, Fred Wilpon?  And then I wondered: was I having a Dinky Donuts moment?  "Seinfeld" watchers will recall when Kramer declared that he'd just seen Joe DiMaggio drinking coffee and eating a donut at Dinky Donuts.  "I'm sorry," Jerry said, "if Joe DiMaggio wants a donut he goes to a fancy restaurant or a hotel. He's not sitting in Dinky Donuts."  "Why can't Joe DiMaggio have a donut like everyone else?" Kramer countered.   "He can have a donut," Jerry said, "but not at Dinky."  Turns out they discover that it really was the Yankee Clipper at the Dinky. And he was dunking.  So was it Koufax, or a reasonable facsimile?  At some point, while I wasn't staring at him to assess his Koufaxiness, he slipped away, and I thought my chance to learn his real identity was gone forever.   But as I left, there he stood, sipping coffee, casually chatting with a memorabilia vendor outside the coffee shop.   Wait a minute, I thought, just wait a minute.  That man is. short  not tiny, but 5-foot-9, at best.   Sandy is 6-2.  But he is 72 years old. And there is shrinkage.

title: Lab Ready for Sex Tests for Female Athletes
description: Beijing Olympics organizers have set up a gender determination lab to test female athletes suspected to be males, China's state media reported Sunday.  Experts at the lab, located at the Peking Union Medical College Hospital, will evaluate cases based on their external appearance and take blood samples to test hormones, genes and chromosomes, said Prof. Tian Qinjie of the college hospital, according to the Xinhua news agency.  Gender verification tests emerged in the 1960s when Communist countries in Eastern Europe were thought to be using male athletes in women's competitions. The tests were used at the Olympics for the first time at the 1968 Mexico City Games.  The concept has drawn criticism over the years, largely because certain chromosomal abnormalities may cause a woman to fail a test, even though it gives her no competitive advantage. Also, if a female athlete fails a test she must have a physiological examination, which many consider invasive and a privacy violation.   The ethical implications of the test and the notion of reducing female athletes to their sex chromosomes led to the International Olympic Committee's decision in 1999 to stop requiring chromosome tests for every female Olympian; now the organizing body has the authority to arrange for gender verification if it is called into question.   At the 1996 Atlanta Games, eight athletes failed the tests but were all cleared by subsequent examinations. Santhi Soundarajan, a middle-distance runner from India, was stripped of an Asian Games silver medal in 2006 after failing a gender verification test.   What do you think? Is the possibility of male athletes posing as women in the Olympics great enough to warrant such testing? Or are these tests inappropriate?

title: Are We Raising Generation E?
description: (Photo: Rainwater is utilized at Stony Brook Southampton. (Credit: Maxine Hicks for The New York Times)Arizona State University has the biggest array of solar panels and wind turbines on any campus. (Credit: Vince Palermo, ASU)Jamilka Carrasquillo is a student at the Common Ground magnet school in New Haven, focused on the environment. (Credit: Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)) I can't keep track of what young people are being called these days after a string of "Generation [ ]" labels. But my vote would be Generation E, for energy and the environment, if initiatives at a host of schools around the United States are any indication. I've heard more than a few sociologists and historians opine that we're essentially going to have to grow past our fossil fuel norms and into a new relationship with energy in which environmental considerations are integrated seamlessly into how people make choices related to energy. Maybe this is starting to happen among those who will inherit the consequences of energy decisions being made (or not made) today?  The latest Education Life section of The Times provides a great tour of energy-related actions in academia, from the sustainability curriculum at the newest campus in the State University of New York system, Stony Brook Southhampton, to seven examples of environmental initiatives at schools around the country.  There's plenty going on in secondary schools such as the Common Ground magnet high school in New Haven, and, as I wrote a few days ago, around Kansas City, where ever fewer school buses and cars are idling as they wait to pick up kids.   I still think it would be great if there were a way to harness existing school sports networks -- like football districts -- to create inter-school energy competitions aimed at cutting heating and electricity bills, and related pollution. There's a "Blueprint for a Green School" online.   What are your kids, schools, or communities up to on this front?

title: Travel Narrows
description: Most of us are good at a few things and bad at a longer list of other things. I am a bad traveler and I wonder if others share my infirmity.   In the past couple of months I have taken two trips, one to New Zealand and another to England and Ireland. Both were the result of invitations to give a talk or participate in a conference, but in each case there was ample time left over to do the things that travelers do.   I tried, but I just couldn't get the hang of it.  The manifestations of my incapacity were physical, although its root causes were not. In the course of a week's touring of Ireland, all my usual little ills returned -- mouth sores, intestinal difficulties (a euphemism), clogged nasal passages, and what one might call "strategic fatigue." Strategic fatigue sets in whenever I enter a museum (when I saw that the display case containing the Book of Kells was surrounded by other tourists I didn't have the strength to push myself forward) or when I approach an ancient site (at Clonmacnoise, the location of an ancient abbey, I retreated immediately to the coffee shop and never saw the ruin) or when the possibility of getting out of the car to enjoy a scenic view presented itself (I protested that it would take too much time, or that we needed gas, or something equally feeble).   The one time I tried to be a good sport and a good tourist was at Carrowmore Megalithic Cemetery in Sligo, which, as far as I could tell, consisted of clumps of small rocks placed at inconvenient distances from one another. These rocks were, I was told, tombs and significant stone circles. It was lost on me, but I dutifully trudged around a large circle taking pictures. The reward for my efforts was the discovery later in the day that, sometime during our exercise in archaeological reverence, a backpack containing my wife's clothing and jewelry had been stolen from our rental car. That'll teach me!  It was the fact that my wife was with me on this trip that alerted me to the extent of my problem. She was supposed to have accompanied me to New Zealand, but couldn't make it at the last moment. I attributed my inability fully to respond to the considerable glories of New Zealand to her absence. Had she been here, I told myself, I could have fed off her enthusiasm and taken pleasure from her pleasure. But in Ireland both her enthusiasm and her sense of pleasure were abundantly visible and still I couldn't do much more than go through the motions. It's not that I didn't recognize the beauty of the landscape or the majesty of the monuments. I couldn't rise to the level of appreciation they deserved.  Why not? What's wrong with me? There are two answers to these questions. First, I just don't care about seeing sights. In London, I ended up at Milton's burial place by accident. I was there for a concert. Churches, famous squares, wide rivers, forests, cobbled streets, scenic vistas, castles, grand gardens . . . I go Spiro Agnew one better: when I've seen one, I've seen one too many.  But behind the lack of interest in sightseeing is something deeper and more unsettling. When I ask people what they like about traveling, they usually answer, I enjoy encountering different cultures and seeing how other people live. I am perfectly happy with the fact of other cultures, and I certainly hope that those who inhabit them live well; but that's as far as it goes.   By definition, a culture other than yours is one that displays unfamiliar practices, enforces local protocols and insists on its own decorums. Some of them even have different languages and are unhappy if you don't speak them. To me that all spells discomfort, and I don't see why I should endure the indignities of airplane travel only to be made uncomfortable once I get where I'm going. As for seeing how other people live, that's their business, not mine.  For a while, I tried to attach my feelings about travel to some honorable moral or intellectual tradition. I recalled some poems by Ben Jonson in which he praises Sir John Roe for the Roman virtue of being always the same no matter how extensively he traveled ("his often change of clime, though not of mind.") But I had to acknowledge that the springs of my own sensibilities had more to do with parochialism and sloth than with some noble capaciousness of mind. In the end, I just have to admit that I was born without the travel gene, which probably means that I was also born without the curiosity gene, and that I'll just have to live with it.   Or, rather, my wife will.  Stanley Fish responds to readers' comments.

description: While rain pelted Fenway Park on Sunday, washing away the Yankees batting practice, Xavier Nady left the cramped clubhouse to call his wife, Meredith, from the dugout bench. It has been a whirlwind month for Nady, who became a father for the first time on July 15.

title: Revisiting TVs Golden Years
description: For producers looking to energize television dramas and sitcoms, Virginia Heffernan has a solution: set more shows in the 50s, 60s, 70s and 80s  eras when TV wasnt dying.

title: Board of Screen Actors Guild Backs Negotiators Internet Demands
description: The board of the Screen Actors Guild, Hollywoods largest actors union, backed negotiators demands for greater control over Internet content, indicating any agreement with studios might be weeks away, Bloomberg reports.

title: Were Really Sorry, Says Apple, Really We Are
description: UPDATED 7/28/08 1:55 a.m.  On Sunday evening Apple posted a short update to the MobileMe situation. According to a post from an Apple employee who identified himself as David G., e-mail to the 1 percent of MobileMe users who have been without mail service was turned on again on Saturday and feedback has been cautiously positive. But everything is not perfect, as 10 percent of the mail that these users received between July 18 and July 22 may have been lost. Another update was promised early in the week.

title: We're Really Sorry, Says Apple, Really We Are
description: Apple continued to scramble over the weekend to limit the damage caused by MobileMe, the company's first step into cloud computing, by posting on Friday an additional longer, four-paragraph apology, and acknowledging that the new service was still not problem-free.

title: TV Anchor Refuses to Yield in Battle Against Cancer
description: When Robin Roberts was playing basketball at Southeastern Louisiana University, she suspected there would be no professional league for women. That reality, which pushed her out to the 8 a.m. classes, made her a better student.

title: Freedom From Mildew
description: THE Franklin D. Roosevelt Presidential Library and Museum at Hyde Park, N.Y., the nations first presidential library, is literally falling apart. The roof leaks, the basement floods, asbestos is flaking from old steam pipes, an ancient electrical system could send the whole place up in smoke. This sorry situation is an insult to the person the library and museum honor: the founder of the New Deal, the greatest investment in our nations modern development.

title: In the Majors Worst Division, Title of Best Team Is Relative
description: LOS ANGELES  The Dodgers host the Giants on Monday night, and the Padres visit the Diamondbacks, meaning somebody in the National League West has to win. Which, at this point in the season, pretty well sums up the state of baseballs worst division.

title: Gas Price Follies
description: Add high energy prices to a sagging economy in an election year and politicians will inevitably come up with bad policies, like converting the corn crop into ethanol or John McCains proposal to suspend the federal gas tax  neither will provide real relief at the pump while both are guaranteed to create other problems.

title: Stop Indulging China
description: To the Editor:

title: Favre Delays Arrival in Green Bay to Give the Packers Time to Deal
description: The Packers averted at least one showdown with their disgruntled icon, Brett Favre, when Favre decided not to report for the start of training camp Sunday in Green Bay, Wis.

title: A Vermont Health Project
description: To the Editor:

title: McCain Assails Obama Over Foreign Tour
description: After returning from a seven-country foreign tour, Senator Barack Obama prepared Sunday to turn his attention to the biggest domestic issue facing American voters, an ailing economy. But Senator John McCain remained focused on foreign affairs, offering tough criticism of his rival for the presidency.

title: Harlem Man Who Made Doll-Head Complaint Is Arrested
description: A 27-year-old Harlem man, who spoke out last week about spotting the head of a black doll on the rear antenna of an unmarked police car with two white officers inside, was arrested early Sunday in what his lawyer and a state senator said was a case of unwarranted retaliation meant to intimidate the neighborhood.

title: And Off Broadway
description: The Culture Project, less than two years after packing up and moving from Bleecker Street to Mercer Street, is on the move again. The company will announce Monday that it is headed to the Barrow Street Theater for the fall season, following an unsuccessful attempt to purchase its current home in SoHo. The 12-year-old nonprofit theater, known for its overtly political works, will present In Conflict, based on Yvonne Lattys 2006 book, In Conflict: Iraq War Veterans Speak Out on Duty, Loss and the Fight to Stay Alive, in September. Ronan Noones The Atheist, a solo show starring Campbell Scott, will go up in October. Culture Projects long-term plans, the artistic director Allan Buchman said in a statement, still include the quest for a permanent home.

title: Verizon Begins Competing for Cable TV Customers
description: Cable television subscribers in New York City will have another company to choose from starting on Monday when Verizon begins selling programming, taking on companies like Cablevision and Time Warner Cable.

title: Bad in Berlin, Perfect in Paris
description: Paris

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Dorazio Leads Soulto Arena League Title
description: Matt DOrazio threw seven touchdown passes and ran for another score as the Philadelphia Soul defeated the defending Arena Football League champion, San Jose, 59-56, in New Orleans on Sunday to win its first Arena Bowl title.

title: Recipients Announced for Robbins Award
description: The two recipients of this years Jerome Robbins Award for excellence in dance, prizes that are worth $100,000 each, will be the choreographer Twyla Tharp and the San Francisco Ballet, while the inaugural Floria V. Lasky Award will go to New York City Center. The Jerome Robbins Foundation will present the awards on Sept. 26, before the final program of City Centers annual Fall for Dance festival, which will include a tribute to Robbins, who died in 1998. He established the foundation in 1970 to support dance and theater. Past recipients of the awards include the lighting designer Jennifer Tipton, New York City Ballet and Mikhail Baryshnikov. The Floria V. Lasky Award, named for a lawyer who served as president of both the Robbins foundation and the Frederick Loewe Foundation, acknowledges service in championing the theater and dance and carries a monetary award of $25,000.

title: Youssef Chahine, Egyptian Filmmaker, Dies at 82
description: Youssef Chahine, an Egyptian filmmaker who was a pre-eminent figure in Arab cinema, died Sunday in Cairo. He was 82 and had been in a coma after suffering a cerebral hemorrhage last month.

title: A Deadly Weekend for Swimmers in the Waters Off Brooklyn and Long Island
description: Separate searches continued on Sunday along parts of the New York coastline for two young swimmers swept out to sea, presumably the victims of unusually powerful riptides that have claimed at least four other lives in recent days.

title: Donald Stokes, 94, Auto Tycoon, Dies
description: LONDON  Donald G. Stokes, who was at the heart of the rise and fall of Britains automotive industry in the 1960s as chairman of the British Leyland Motor Corporation, died July 21 at the age of 94.

title: A Means for Publishers to Put a Newspaper in Your Pocket
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The thud of the morning newspaper landing on front porches may one day be replaced with the beep of downloads onto a cellphone.

title: After 113 Years, Club Allows Lower Socks
description: Padraig Harringtons victory at the British Open was not the only recent major golf news in Britain. About a week before Harringtons triumph, Englands Frinton Golf Club announced it was setting aside a 113-year rule requiring members to wear knee-length socks when wearing shorts, according to the BBC.

title: 5 Actors, in 30-Plus Roles, Offer an 80-Day Journey
description: How do you get an elephant onto the tiny stage of the Irish Repertory Theater? Not just very carefully, the director Michael Evan Haney suggests in Around the World in 80 Days, but also very minimally.

title: After Sitting in 2004, Ready to Stand and Deliver
description: LAS VEGAS  LeBron James, Dwyane Wade and Carmelo Anthony were more witnesses to USA Basketballs meltdown at the 2004 Olympics than they were participants.

title: Carlos Sastre Wins Tour de France
description: PARIS  Carlos Sastre has been a contender for the Tour de France victory for so long that few people thought he would ever actually win it.

title: Cant Decide? Look for the Label
description: For a study recently published in The Journal of Consumer Research, 61 college students were led into one of two simulated magazine stores.

title: Iowa Rally Protests Raid and Conditions at Plant
description: POSTVILLE, Iowa  About 1,000 people, including Hispanic immigrants, Catholic clergy members, rabbis and activists, marched through the center of this farm town on Sunday and held a rally at the entrance to a kosher meatpacking plant that was raided in May by immigration authorities.

title: When Short Game Means Saving Minutes, Not Strokes
description: Its said that slow play is the scourge of modern American golf, and I just want everyone to know Im doing my part to help.

description: SUPERGRASS Diamond Hoo Ha (Astralwerks)

title: Obama Returns to Economy as McCain Assails Foreign Tour
description: Senator Barack Obama signaled on Sunday that he would return his focus to the economy after a whirlwind foreign tour, but Senator John McCains eyes remained very much fixed on national security, as he repeatedly attacked his rival.

title: A Team of Hosts for the Emmys
description: Not only will this years Emmy Awards include a new honor for Outstanding Host for a Reality or Reality-Competition Program, but the five nominees in the category will act as hosts for the awards show itself, The Associated Press reported. For this years Emmys show, to be broadcast Sept. 21 on ABC, the host-nominees are, above from top, Ryan Seacrest (American Idol), Tom Bergeron (Dancing With the Stars), Howie Mandel (Deal or No Deal), Heidi Klum (Project Runway) and Jeff Probst (Survivor). Last years Emmys telecast drew just fewer than 13 million viewers, its second-smallest audience on record, while the five reality shows whose hosts have been nominated have a combined weekly audience of around 70 million.

title: Larry Haines, a Star of Search for Tomorrow, Is Dead at 89
description: Larry Haines, a successful Broadway actor who for 35 years played Stu Bergman, one of the convivial neighbors on Search for Tomorrow, which at the time of its cancellation was televisions longest-running soap opera, died on July 17 near his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 89.

title: A Hug for Obama, a Handshake for McCain
description: Senator Barack Obamas audience inside the Capitol this week will number about 200, not the 200,000 who gathered last week in Berlin. And with their own careers tied to his on Election Day, the House Democrats gathered to listen to him will bring more critical scrutiny.

description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Military Says Soldiers Fired on Civilians
description: BAGHDAD  The American military admitted Sunday night that a platoon of soldiers raked a car of innocent Iraqi civilians with hundreds of rounds of gunfire and that the military then issued a news release larded with misstatements, asserting that the victims were criminals who had fired on the troops.

title: As Doctors Cater to Looks, Skin Patients Wait
description: Dr. Donald Richey, a dermatologist in Chico, Calif., has two office telephone numbers: calls to the number for patients seeking an appointment for skin conditions like acne and psoriasis often go straight to voice mail, but a full-time staff member fields calls on the dedicated line for cosmetic patients seeking beauty treatments like Botox.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about a raid at a meat packing plant in Postville, Iowa, in May that captured more than 20 under-age illegal immigrant workers misstated part of the name of a union that has tried to organize at the plant. It is the United Food and Commercial Workers Union, not the International Food and Commercial Workers Union.

title: A DVD Marketing Campaign Horton Would Definitely Hear
description: Horton will be huge, at least if 20th Century Fox has anything to say about it.

title: Brooks Jones, Father of Summerfare, Is Dead at 73
description: Brooks Jones, a producer and director who rejected Broadway to devote himself to regional theater, including starting and directing Pepsico Summerfare at the State University of New York at Purchase, died on July 15 at his home in Westport, Conn. He was 73.

title: More Sneak Peeks at Comic-Con
description: Terminator Salvation, the fourth Terminator film, is not due out until May, but fans were given a peek at some footage at the 39th annual Comic-Con International convention in San Diego, The Associated Press reported. The films director, McG, presented an action-packed clip during a panel on Saturday and offered some details about the release, including a hint that Arnold Schwarzenegger might be back. The T-800 model indeed is part of the mythology of Terminator, McG told the crowd, referring to the machine played by Mr. Schwarzenegger, the governor of California, in the first three films. ... Also at Comic-Con, the writer and director Kevin Smith (Clerks) presented some footage from his new film, Zack and Miri Make a Porno. The comedy, starring Seth Rogen (Knocked Up) and Elizabeth Banks (Meet Dave), has been rated NC-17 by the Motion Picture Association of America, though Mr. Smith said he was hoping to have the rating changed to R. He told a crowd on Saturday that he edited and resubmitted the movie three times and that another hearing was scheduled for Aug. 4 to evaluate his latest cut.

title: Revered by the Castros and Their Opponents
description: EL COBRE, Cuba  The most bizarre offering that the Rev. Jorge Alejandro has witnessed at Cubas most cherished shrine came from the man who bent down and began clipping his toenails. One by one, the man deposited them at the altar, among the many other mementos left by the faithful for the Virgin of El Cobre, widely considered the mother and protector of Cubans.

title: Jets New Video System: A Home Page for Football
description: After the Nebraska football program installed a new video system last season, one coach said it saved his marriage.

title: Lottery Numbers
Hatred Said to Motivate Tenn. Shooter
description: A man who the police say entered a Unitarian church in Knoxville during Sunday services and shot 8 people, killing two, was motivated by a hatred for liberals and homosexuals, Chief Sterling P. Owen IV of the Knoxville Police Department said Monday.

title: Improving Ballot Design
description: To the Editor:

title: In Firm Control, Cambodias Premier Is Poised for Election Victory
description: CHBAR MORN, Cambodia  Prime Minister Hun Sen appeared headed for an expected election victory on Sunday after what experts said was the least violent political campaign in Cambodias recent history.

title: Be Careful of Shepherds Who Dress Like Liberace
description: ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y.  Its common for opera buffs to learn to love an obscure work through a fine recording, all the time fantasizing about what a full production might be like.

title: Superhero Suits on Sale
description: More than 1,000 pieces of Hollywood history, including Tobey Maguires Spider-Man costume, below, will be put up for auction Thursday and Friday. Profiles in History, a company that specializes in Hollywood memorabilia, will hold the auction, which includes film and television superhero costumes and props relating to Superman, X-Men and Spider-Man. In addition to the sleek suits, 35 lots of visual-effects creatures made for the screen by the Stan Winston Studio will go on sale, including a full-scale animatronic male velociraptor from Jurassic Park III. The auction includes a handwritten manuscript by Ian Fleming, Charlton Hestons tablets from The Ten Commandments and a costume from Ben-Hur.

title: Ma, Pa and Half Pint Now Sing on That Prairie
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Laura, Nellie and Almanzo. Charles and Caroline Ingalls. The wide open land, the unforgiving climate, the death of a baby boy. The characters and stories of Little House on the Prairie have delighted readers and television viewers for generations, but now they are being put to a test not unlike a cruel Midwestern winter: Will they thrive in the forbidding world of new American musicals?

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article in some editions last Monday about Alix Dejean, a Harlem street photographer, included an erroneous identification from Mr. Dejean for the type of film he used to shoot pictures of teenagers in beach chairs in front of a housing project and of other scenes in the neighborhood. The film was Kodak Vericolor III, not Kodachrome.

title: Former Employees of Google Prepare Rival Search Engine
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In her two years at Google, Anna Patterson helped design and build some of the pillars of the companys search engine, including its large index of Web pages and some of the formulas it uses for ranking search results.

title: Think Again
description: The stereotype of a rock drummer may be more party animal than star athlete, but the stamina it takes to play for a concert tour is no joke, according to the results of the Clem Burke Drumming Project, a study conducted by scientists at the University of Gloucestershire and the University of Chichester in Britain. Mr. Burke, the drummer for Blondie, has been participating in the study for eight years, allowing his heart rate, oxygen levels and other statistics to be monitored during his performances. The BBC reported that Mr. Burkes heart averaged 140 to 150 beats per minute and peaked as high as 190. The numbers are comparable to that of athletes, but while they might reach that level once or twice a week, a drummer on tour is likely to do it almost every night. One goal of the research is to help develop programs enticing overweight children not interested in athletics to find alternate ways to stay fit.

title: Worried Banks Sharply Reduce Business Loans
description: Banks struggling to recover from multibillion-dollar losses on real estate are curtailing loans to American businesses, depriving even healthy companies of money for expansion and hiring.

title: Teardrops on Her Pillow? Not for This Torch Singer
description: The singer Lina Koutrakos deconstructs the oldest cabaret clich in the book in Torch, her sagacious new show at the Metropolitan Room. If that loaded title conjures images of a lovelorn diva masochistically wallowing in mistreatment and rejection, Ms. Koutrakos is anything but a self-pitying crybaby.

title: Caution: Product Placement
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Temporary Fix
description: So the big housing bill has passed Congress. Thats good news: Fannie and Freddie had to be rescued, and the bills other main provision  a special loan program to head off foreclosures  will help some hard-pressed families. Its much better to have this bill than not.

title: Roger Hall, a Spy With a Sense of Humor, Is Dead at 89
description: The letter arrived for Second Lt. Roger Hall at Camp Plauche, La., signed by Gen. George C. Marshall and ordering him to report to Washington for an assignment of a secret and hazardous nature. Thus began Mr. Halls career as a spy, an agent in the Office of Strategic Services, the World War II precursor of the Central Intelligence Agency  and his career as a humor writer as well.

title: Say So Long to an Old Companion: Cassette Tapes
description: There was a funeral the other day in the Midtown offices of Hachette, the book publisher, to mourn the passing of what it called a dear friend. Nobody had actually died, except for a piece of technology, the cassette tape.

title: Leftover Ad Space? Exchanges Handle the Remnants
description: Joe Zawadzkis traders spend their days in front of two computer screens, feeding their systems with data and trying to perfect their trading algorithms.

title: Will the Real Big Brown Show Up at the Haskell?
description: Michael Iavarone owns racehorses, so forgive his optimism. He says that he has never felt better about Big Brown and that he fully expects him to demolish a compact field on Sunday afternoon in the $1 million Haskell Invitational at Monmouth Park in Oceanport, N.J.

title: Trooper Death Is Detailed in New Report
description: At 7:28 a.m. on April 25, 2007, in a quiet corner of the Catskill Mountains, an indoor motion alarm went off at a vacant farmhouse, a half-mile from where a van driven by a suspect in the shooting of a New York State trooper the previous day had been found abandoned.

title: Stumping for Boss at Fenway and Hall
description: BOSTON  A signature moment of Goose Gossages career came at Fenway Park in 1978, when he closed out the Boston Red Sox to end a thrilling division race for the Yankees. On Sunday, when Gossage gave his induction speech at the Hall of Fame, a group of Yankees sat riveted to the television in the Fenway clubhouse to watch him.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary and a headline on Sunday about a founder of an experimental community near Charlottesville, Va., misstated her given name. She was Kathleen Kinkade, not Katherine. (As the obituary noted, she was known as Kat.)

title: Santana Gives Bullpen Day Off
description: When Johan Santana came out to pitch the ninth inning Sunday, there was no music for him. None of the heavy metal chords and none of the flashing displays designed to send fans into a frenzy and hitters into a panic. He did not need anything out of a public-address system.

title: At Baseball Hall of Fame, Links Are Cherished
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.  It was a day of connections Sunday at the annual induction of the newest members of the National Baseball Hall of Fame.

title: Land Dispute Moves Memorial for 9/11 Victims Across a Pennsylvania Road
description: SHANKSVILLE, Pa.  It is on just a quarter-acre of land, which everyone agrees is too small, and it has always been called the temporary memorial.

title: Dependent, Independent, Metalcore, Emo: Its All Punk to Them
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  You guys are supporting a very independent band, Ben Liebsch of the emergent emo band You, Me, and Everyone We Know told a crowd of 100 or so from a small stage on a remote slice of asphalt in the parking lot of Nassau Coliseum here on Saturday afternoon. There are lots of dependent bands playing elsewhere.

title: A Come-From-Behind Victory in the Wagar
description: LAS VEGAS  The winners of the Wagar Womens Knockout Teams final at the Summer North American Bridge Championships here in the early hours of Saturday morning were Lynn Baker of Austin, Tex.; Karen McCallum of Exeter, N.H.; Lynn Deas of Schenectady, N.Y.; Beth Palmer of Silver Spring, Md.; Irina Levitina of Hackensack, N.J.; and Kerri Sanborn of Stony Point, N.Y.

title: U.S. Aid to Colombia
description: To the Editor:

title: Democracy Group Gives Donors Access to McCain
description: As Senator John McCain waited to speak at the annual awards dinner of the International Republican Institute, a democracy-building group he has led for 15 years, lobbyists and business executives dominated the stage at a Washington hotel ballroom.

title: Red Sox Exhale in Blowout; Yanks' Streak Is Snapped
description: BOSTON  They have spent the better part of this decade punishing Yankees pitchers and tilting the axis of a one-sided rivalry. David Ortiz and Manny Ramrez are the thunder in the middle of the Boston Red Sox lineup, and the Yankees savor those rare games when they disappear.

title: Sastre Wins Tour de France
description: PARIS  Carlos Sastre has been a contender in the Tour de France for so long that few people thought he would ever actually win it.

title: Recent Triathlon Deaths Have Experts Searching for Answers
description: WHEN 60-year-old Donald Morehouse and 52-year-old John Hobgood Jr. died in different triathlon events last weekend, they became at least the seventh and eighth triathletes to die during competition this year. Those deaths came just one week after Esteban Neira, 32, died during the New York City Triathlon.

title: After Delay, KKR Finds a Way to Go Public
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the storied private equity firm, is again preparing to become a public company on the New York Stock Exchange, the firm said Sunday.

title: Fans of L.E.D.s Say This Bulbs Time Has Come
description: When the Sentry Equipment Corporation in Oconomowoc, Wis., was considering how to light its new factory last year, the companys president, Michael Farrell, decided to try something new: light emitting diodes, or L.E.D.s.

title: Nadal Wins and Keeps Closing on No. 1
description: TORONTO  His play and his peers are increasingly testifying that Rafael Nadal is the worlds best mens tennis player. But for the time being, the rankings and Nadal himself continue to rate Roger Federer No. 1.

title: Indiana Jones and the Temple of Absurdly Implausible Excess
description: Has the phrase jump the shark jumped the shark? Or, more to the point, should we be saying that it has nuked the fridge?

title: For Many Student Athletes, Game Over
description: MOUNT VERNON, N.Y.  Student athletes in maroon and gold uniforms filled their water coolers with more than $19,000 in donations last weekend by standing on street corners here to ask friends, neighbors and strangers alike to help revive the school districts $1.1 million athletic program, which was eliminated last month in budget cuts.

title: Ramrez Ends Silence and Dares Red Sox
description: BOSTON  Manny Ramrez was standing behind a blue curtain that separated the Red Sox clubhouse from the trainers room. He was off limits to reporters, whom he had already dodged, and was continuing his silent stance regarding his feud with the organization.

title: After a Racial Incident, Redemption or Payback?
description: As George Pelecanoss storytelling style increasingly takes on a blunt economy like Elmore Leonards, his central concerns become ever more clear: He writes about manhood. He dramatizes the ways in which masculinity and morality converge. His male characters are caught up in the continuing struggle between virtue and street swagger, and there is never any question as to where Mr. Pelecanoss heart is. When a little boy reaches out to a grown man for fatherly guidance, and the grown man accepts that mission, all is right in this authors world.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article last Monday about concerns over new voting technologies being introduced for the November elections, using information from a voting rights advocate, misidentified the location in Maryland where polling places ran out of ballots in the 2006 election and voters had to use random pieces of paper. It was Montgomery County, not Baltimore.

title: A Fresh Start With Pakistan
description: Pakistans new civilian prime minister, Yousaf Raza Gilani, is in Washington this week for what we are sure will be a difficult set of meetings.

title: A Verdi With More Laughs and Death
description: The history of Verdis Forza del Destino is almost as convoluted as its sprawling plot. The musicologist Philip Gossett has added another twist, with a new critical edition of the opera, which received a first-rate, semi-staged performance at the Caramoor International Music Festival on Saturday. Will Crutchfield conducted the Orchestra of St. Lukes and a noteworthy young cast as part of the Bel Canto at Caramoor series.

title: Officials Ask Qantas to Inspect Oxygen Canisters
description: SYDNEY, Australia  Air safety authorities in Australia investigating why a section of fuselage of a Qantas airliner burst open at 29,000 feet asked the airline on Sunday to inspect oxygen canisters aboard all of its 747s.

title: Indias New Partnership: Bollywood and Hip-Hop
description: NEW DELHI -- Is Bollywood ready for Snoop Dogg?

title: Back to the 60s in a Bebop Mode
description: The pianist Dan Nimmer has a crisp, orderly, ebullient style, and over the last few years he has put it through its paces. As a member of the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra and the assorted small groups of that orchestras director, Wynton Marsalis, Mr. Nimmer routinely covers a lot of territory, from the antiquarian to the ultramodern. For the audiences that know him, or think they do, hes an engagingly adaptable musician.

title: After 13-Year Gap, Late-Night Train Returns in Harlem
description: The clock struck midnight, and all was quiet at the 145th Street subway station on the No. 3 line, as it was every night. The rats started to emerge, hissing and squeaking and scurrying along the tracks, pouncing on the nightly feast: shreds of meat, mounds of melted candy bars and puddles of cola  a days worth of litter.

title: Not Yet on Broadway
description: Nice Work if You Can Get It, the new musical with songs by George and Ira Gershwin that stars Harry Connick Jr., had been expected on Broadway in the spring, but it might be a bit further off. A pre-Broadway production of the show, with a book by Joe DiPietro (I Love You, Youre Perfect, Now Change), that was scheduled for December at the Colonial Theater in Boston has been postponed, The Boston Globe reported. Earlier, Kathleen Marshall, who worked with Mr. Connick on The Pajama Game and was initially on board as the director and choreographer, had dropped out of the project.

title: Mr. President? Not Quite, but Quite Presidential
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Barack Obama has stood before a lectern adorned with a faux presidential seal.

title: Facing a Wave of Violence, India Is Rattled
description: NEW DELHI  Over the past several years, terrorist attacks in India have become an everyday presence in everyday places. The targets seem to have nothing in common except that they are ordinary and brazenly easy to strike.

title: Wheres the Bounce?
description: WASHINGTON  It is a question that has hovered over Senator Barack Obama even as he has passed milestone after milestone in his race for the White House: Why is he not doing better?

title: Board of Screen Actors Guild Backs Negotiators Demands
description: The board of the Screen Actors Guild, Hollywoods largest actors union, backed negotiators demands for greater control over Internet content, indicating any agreement with studios might be weeks away.

title: Be Afraid. Please.
description: Life is full of disappointments.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and auctions of four-week bills and one-year bills on Tuesday.

title: Chimpanzee Exploitation
description: To the Editor:

title: A Ball Marks the Spot
description: Kathy, Cristina, Elise and Anne tee off from a par 3. Kathys ball comes to rest on the green after having created a pitch mark partly on the green. Cristinas ball creates a pitch mark on the fringe and comes to rest on the fringe. Elises shot makes a pitch mark on the fringe and rolls onto the front of the green. Annes ball makes a pitch mark on the fringe and rolls into a front bunker.

title: From Most Valuable Jet to the Most Improved
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y.  Coach Eric Mangini saved his highest praise so far at training camp for Leon Washington, who won the team most valuable player award last season and followed it with the award for most improvement in the off-season.

title: Fuel Subsidies Overseas Take a Toll on U.S.
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  To understand why fuel prices in the United States have soared over the last year, it helps to talk to the captain of a battered wooden freighter here.

title: Policing Days Behind Them, Investigators Lend Skills to Child Welfare Agency
description: Stella Porsenna, a child protective specialist for the New York City Administration for Childrens Services, was striking out trying to track down a man who had drug problems and a history of abusing the mother of his 1-year-old daughter. So she turned to George A. Flores, a retired New York City police officer. With a quick check of law enforcement databases, Mr. Flores discovered that the man was due in criminal court on a trespassing charge in September.

title: Dark Knight Wins Again at Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES  Batman fever continued over the weekend, with ticket sales for The Dark Knight far outpacing the competition and breaking a fresh batch of box-office records.

title: Political Dissension Troubles Liberian Groups on Staten Island
description: Most of the thousands of Liberians living in New York fled their homeland during more than two tumultuous decades of coups and civil war. And though their lives were shattered, villages torn apart and relatives killed, they arrived, like other immigrant groups, with their cultural and religious traditions intact.

title: A Giveaway in Arkansas: Two Bridges, Old and Plain
description: CASH, Ark.  Neither could be confused with the Brooklyn Bridge or the Golden Gate. Only an engineer could truly love them. They seem devoid of romance, save perhaps the bleaker kind that attracts girls of song who, with men named Billy Joe, throw something off them.

title: A Media Powerhouse Everyone and Nobody Knows

title: Out in the Pasture
description: Early most evenings, the dogs and I walk across the pasture in front of the house. Its a piece of ground I like to think I know well. Ive fenced it twice, kept chickens and pigs in it, ridden horses over it and watched the weather come across it for a decade now. I mow it a couple of times every year, and when the snow is good I ski around it. And yet every time I walk across that acre and a half, its topography surprises me: its lifts and hollows, the long slope down to the eastern fence line. title: The Cadillac of Walkers
description: (Photo: Stephanie Mead, 87, resident at the Atria senior home in Connecticut, with a state-of-the-art walker. (James Estrin/The New York Times))   More than a dozen years ago, my late mother was considered a fashionista among the limited mobility set because her walker was customized with tennis balls on its back legs. The fuzzy yellow balls, scored with a utility knife for a snug fit, were intended to work rather like shock absorbers, smoothing her ride and eliminating the annoying tap-tap-tap of the walker's legs hitting the floor. She carried her possessions in a wicker basket secured to the handlebars with shoe laces.   (Photo: The walking cane, tricked out and individualized. (James Estrin/The New York Times))   Today, such a walker would mark my mother as a nerd, a penny-pincher or, worse yet, someone whose neglectful children had failed to provide her with the next new thing. Spend some time at an assisted living community these days and it's clear that the Cadillac of walkers -- will our generation call them the BMWs of walkers? -- is no longer a jury-rigged contraption of found objects, but rather a "rollator," a "rolling walker" or a "walker with a seat."  There are many brands -- I claim no expertise and welcome reviews from those who do. But all have more or less the same features. Most important is a seat that folds down, permitting longer excursions with time-outs whenever mom or dad needs a rest. Some of the seats even have hidden storage compartments, like old-fashioned piano benches. (What's inside? Eyeglasses. Romance novels. Oranges. Lottery tickets. Keys. Large-print "Reader's Digests.")   The handlebar is padded for arthritic hands, and there are hand brakes to lock the wheels in place when sitting down. While walkers have rotating wheels only on the front legs, these newfangled beauties, in metallic blue or English racing green, have four wheels that pivot, making it possible to walk on rough sidewalks or grass -- an off-road experience. Accessories include cup holders, food trays and an array of storage pouches.   (Photo: Residents of Atria Senior Home in Stratford, Conn., with the latest in mobility devices. (James Estrin/The New York Times))   Prices are reasonable: as little as $85 for a Costco Web site special, or as much as $275 for a model that will support a 400-pounder. Online orders can be placed with individual manufacturers, soup-to-nuts shopping sites like Amazon or medical supply companies, which carry many brands. Start here. Or here. Or here.

title: Congress Confronts Final Week of Work
description: WASHINGTON  It's the last week before the long summer recess, but Congress is hardly all sunshine and smiles as it tries to wrap up some major business before the August break.   In both the House and the Senate, lawmakers are engaged in an increasingly bitter fight over how to address the high price of gasoline  a recognition that some very unhappy constituents are waiting for them back home in a major election year.  "A member just has to go home to know what is the No. 1 economic issue in a country where people are concerned right now about what to do about the economy," said Representative Roy Blunt, of Missouri, the No. 2 Republican.  Chances of a deal on energy policy, however, are slim.  And even as lawmakers seem ready to clash until the last boarding call for the last flight home, the focus has already shifted in many ways to the presidential race  a point underscored by Senator Barack Obama's planned visit with House Democrats on Tuesday.  Still, with fall politics driving the debate, House Democrats will push forward this week with a bill intended to curb speculation in the oil-futures market. Republicans continue to press their demands for lifting a ban an off-shore oil drilling and for vastly increasing domestic energy production.  And the Democrats continue to push back, saying oil companies should drill on existing leases of federal land and that the focus should be on alternatives to fossil fuels.   "Our position is that we ought to drill, we ought to drill where we've given leases that exist," the majority leader, Representative Steny H. Hoyer, Democrat of Maryland, said. "We really do believe that we ought to drill, we ought to drill now and we ought to drill where there is not controversy and where we do have leases."  In the Senate, the fight over energy policy raged through the weekend. Democrats hoping to muscle their way past the stalemate sought to take up a bill that would nearly double federal spending on home energy subsidies this year, with an increase of $2.5 billion in assistance. Republicans blocked that effort, insisting on keeping a bill on oil speculation on the floor so that they could continue a broader debate about energy policy.  The energy fight will pause briefly in the Senate for a procedural vote on a bill that the Democrats constructed in an effort to break the vice-grip that Senator Tom Coburn, Republican of Oklahoma, has placed on many pieces of legislation, using the rights of a single senator to hold up any bill by placing a "hold" on it.  Mr. Coburn has come to be known as the Senate's Dr. No. And the bill the Democrats pulled together, including several pieces of legislation authored by Mr. Coburn's fellow Republicans, is being called the Tomnibus. It is unlikely that Democrats will succeed in changing Mr. Coburn's tactics.  But the Democrats' maneuver did succeed in getting front-page attention for Mr. Coburn today in both The New York Times and The Washington Post, though whether Mr. Coburn was embarrassed, as the Democrats hoped, also seemed unlikely given his defiant remarks.  Of course, amid all the political squabbling and rhetorical re-hash, there is actually a government to run.  The House this week is also planning to debate a bill to finance military construction and the Department of Veterans Affairs  the first appropriations bill to make it to the House floor this year. And the House leadership is also hoping to act on at least one of several major pieces of legislation awaiting completion including a bill to overhaul the Consumer Products Safety Commission and another bill reauthorizing the financing and operations of Amtrak, the subsidized rail road company.  But with just days to go before the recess, and the party conventions fast-approaching, running the government will not get in the way of larger political objectives for November. House Democrats this week also expect to take up a bill to aid women who win discrimination lawsuits against their employers, substantially increasing the amount of damages that can be sought and taking other steps to reduce pay disparity.  The bill, called the Fair Pay Act, is a corollary to a measure that was blocked in the Senate in April seeking to overturn the Supreme Court ruling against Lilly Ledbetter, an Alabama woman who sued the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company but lost when the court found she did not file her complaint in time. Ms. Ledbetter had been paid as much as 40 percent less than male counterparts doing the same job, according to her supporters.  To be sure, pay parity for women is a matter of deeply held principle for Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other lawmakers. But the politics of the issue are also unmistakable.  In April, when Republicans blocked the Ledbetter measure, Democratic leaders did not convene the Senate until 5 p.m. so both of the party's presidential candidates, Mr. Obama and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton could return to Washington. Both spoke in favor of the legislation, countering arguments by several Republicans that the bill would simply encourage costly litigation.  And with women voters likely to play a crucial role in the outcome in November, Democrats have made clear that pay equity will be a major topic in both the presidential race and congressional campaigns around the country.

title: Campaign Mystery
description: In his Chicago Sun-Times column, Robert Novak tackles the question that's befuddling much of punditland: Why isn't Barack Obama ("a magnetic candidate supported by a disciplined, well-organized campaign") trouncing John McCain ("wooden, with a campaign that appears to be in shambles") in the polls? But beyond waving at the notion that American voters are uncomfortable with the idea of "a young, inexperienced African American as their president," Novak doesn't provide an answer. He writes:     In locking up the nomination this year, when he had been counted out after the disintegration of his campaign structure, McCain showed more fortitude than skill. He was blessed by a weak field of Republican competitors, who eliminated each other and left McCain as the last man standing.  But Obama is no Huckabee, Giuliani or Romney. He is the most spectacular campaigner of his generation, with appeal well beyond Democratic ranks. That he lingers below the 50 percent mark is a mystery among politicians of both parties. It is particularly troubling to Democrats who recall past Democratic candidates taking a huge lead over the summer before being overtaken or nearly overtaken by a surging Republican opponent.  In 1976, Jimmy Carter took a 33-point summer lead over President Gerald Ford and won in a photo finish. In 1988, Michael Dukakis led George H.W. Bush by 17 points after being nominated in Atlanta before he lost the election. Al Gore and John Kerry were ahead of George W. Bush in the summer.  Clearly, Obama has not yet closed the deal with the people to accept a young, inexperienced African American as their president. Obama had virtually clinched the nomination when white working men in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia poured out to vote and carried their states comfortably for Hillary Clinton. It was not because of unalterable affection for her.

title: Iranian Leader Hints at Cooperation
description: The nuclear disagreements between Iran and the West have been communicated in many ways -- military exercises, diplomat-packed negotiating rooms, lengthy government reports and short, bellicose statements from their leaders. So why not a prime-time interview on American television?  In a talk with Brian Williams of the NBC "Nightly News" at his compound in Iran, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran acknowledged recent American moves meant to thaw relations with his country, and hinted that Iran could be persuaded to change its course as a result. Here are his words to an American audience:   "Today, we see new behavior shown by the United States [...] My question is: is such behavior rooted in a new approach? In other words, mutual respect, cooperation and justice. Or is this approach a continuation in the confrontation with Iranian people but in a new guise?  "[...] If the approach changes, we will be facing a new situation, and the response from the Iranian people will be a positive one."   The interview took place at a moment best described as "fluid" -- the word of an energy market analyst reacting to Iran's weekend announcement of many more uranium-enrichment centrifuges. Iran has maintained that its program is peaceful, and NBC reported today that he Mr. Ahmedinejad flatly stated more than once that "we are not working to manufacture a bomb." He also said that "nuclear weapons are so 20th-century," according to Mr. Williams.  Still, as Iran continues to enrich uranium while Western powers urge it to stop, the United States has sent signals of a less confrontational stance with steps like sending an envoy to international nuclear talks with Iran and by considering whether to open a diplomatic post in Tehran. Meanwhile, at the moment there are no American aircraft carriers in the Gulf.  Whether something "positive" can now happen at a pace that is acceptable to Washington remains to be seen. After the talks in Geneva earlier this month with the American envoy in attendance, the Iranian foreign minister lauded the "positive step," the positive atmosphere and the "new positive approach." But in substance, the meeting ended where it began, at a deadlock.   Iran's stance in Geneva, as characterized by a document it distributed at the talks, remained the same. The New York Times obtained a copy [pdf] and described it this way:  The six powers were hoping that Iran would accept a compromise formula to pave the way to formal negotiations. For six weeks, Iran would not add "any new nuclear activity," refraining from the new installation of centrifuges that enrich uranium, and the United States and other powers would not seek new United Nations sanctions.  But both in their paper, and throughout the talks, the Iranians did not discuss the formula, called a "freeze for freeze." As a result, they left the impression that they wanted to lure the parties into an open-ended, cost-free, high-level negotiating process.  "The paper calls for a huge exercise in talking," said one senior European official. "If you were to try to implement it, it would take a minimum of several years."   Last week, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said that she had tired of all the stalling and that Iran ought to get serious. Whether she thinks Mr. Ahmadinejad's latest remarks were a shift will be key.

title: Apple Weighs In on the MobileMe Mess

title: Apple Weighs in on the MobileMe Mess
description: Last Thursday, in my weekly e-column, I blasted Apple for the way it's been handling the disastrous opening of its MobileMe service. Two weeks after launch, at least 20,000 customers still had no way to send or receive e-mail.   The worst part, though, was Apple's smug silence on the issue. What was causing the problem? How come a fix was taking so long? What was being done to solve it? When would it be fixed? What kind of resources were being spent on a resolution? Did Apple understand the disruption this problem was causing those thousands of people and small businesses?  Apple wouldn't say.   There was a terse note on the MobileMe support site: "1% of MobileMe members cannot access MobileMe Mail. We apologize for this service interruption and are working hard to resolve the problem." But otherwise, there was no communication whatsoever, no acknowledgment of people's growing desperation, even two weeks after MobileMe's launch.  And then, on Saturdaywell, knock me down with a feather. Apple performed a complete 180-degree reversal. The most opaque, uncommunicative tech company on the planet suddenly became transparent and informative.   At Steve Jobs's direction, the company has launched a new blog that's exclusively dedicated to the MobileMe mess.  In the first posting alone, Apple identifies the specific cause of the MobileMe problem (blockage from a bad mail server); what's being done to solve it (24/7 coordinated efforts); current status (e-mail service restored, but e-mail older than Friday is still missing, and one-tenth of messages sent between July 16 and 18 may be forever lost); the severity of the original problem (70 bugs fixed); and estimated time of completion (end of the week).   More amazingly, the blog acknowledges, for the first time, the emotional toll of the experience. "It's been a rocky road, and we know the pain some people have been suffering."  I'll bet good money that Apple has never before used the words "pain" and "suffering" to describe one of its products.  What made Apple change its stance? Was it the thousands of people on its support boards, clamoring for accountability? Did my column have anything to do with it? Or was it just Steve Jobs coming back from vacation?   I can't remember any tech company ever willing to bare its ugly internal problems quite so publicly, and with so frank an admission of the distress it was causing. [UPDATE: I overstated that. Readers have pointed out similar notes from other companies, like this one, that do document internal problems, although without the acknowledgment of customer suffering.] These days, my e-mail is filled with notes from customers, expressing relief and a huge stress reduction.  It would have been a lot better if MobileMe had worked great from Day One. It would have been better if Apple had been this candid from the beginning.  But at least Apple has finally provided what thousands of people have been aching for: honesty, transparency, and, above all, a sympathetic ear.

title: Yahoo and the Icahn Effect
description: What's in store for Yahoo's shareholders now that the Web company has reached a truce with Carl Icahn?   That is anyone's guess, but a look at companies in similar situations shows that the stock gains that the outspoken investor often brings with him -- call it the "Icahn effect" -- can be quite volatile, at least in the short term.  Yahoo's stock got a boost in May after Mr. Icahn said he was going to shake things up at the Internet company and try to sell it to Microsoft. But he recently abandoned his proxy fight, agreeing to get three board seats instead.   At DealBook's request, FactSet SharkWatch analyzed the stock performance of public companies that Mr. Icahn has targeted with activist campaigns since 2000.   In some cases, Mr. Icahn's target ended up getting sold or going private. That often delivered big premiums to shareholders.  But when the company stayed public and independent -- which could be Yahoo's fate -- here's what FactSet found.  In the first month after Mr. Icahn started his campaign, the stock prices of the companies he targeted from 2000 to 2008 popped an average of 8 percent. That included 32 companies and 35 campaigns: Mr. Icahn launched three campaigns against Visix and two against ImClone Systems.  The average increase jumped to 17 percent after six months, while the number of companies dropped to 21. (Eleven of the companies ceased to be public, such as Register.com and Morton's Restaurants.)  A year after Mr. Icahn started agitating, the average gain declined for companies that weren't sold, broken up or taken private. Of the 16 public companies that remained, the one-year increase averaged 8 percent, FactSet said.  In 2007, Mr. Icahn claimed to have created more than $50 billion of shareholder value in the previous two years through his rabble rousing. Fortune crunched the numbers and said they seemed to jibe with his claims.  Investors in Kerr-McGee, the oil and gas producer, more than doubled their money from the time Mr. Icahn got involved to when the company was sold to Anadarko.  These days, Yahoo's shareholders might be happy just to get that 8 percent mentioned above.  After the first month of Mr. Icahn's campaign, Yahoo's stock was down 7 percent. More recently, after Yahoo posted mixed second-quarter earnings last week, it was down 19 percent.

title: Ask About New York City's Waterfront
description: (Photo: Roland Lewis) Roland Lewis, the president and chief executive of the Waterfront Alliance, will be answering City Room readers' questions this week about land use, environmental concerns and preservation of New York and New Jersey's waterways and harbors.   Readers are invited to submit their questions in the comments box below.  Since 2000, the Waterfront Alliance has been working to transform the New York and New Jersey Harbor and Waterways to make them clean and accessible, a vibrant place to play, learn and work, with transportation for all.   Mr. Lewis, a lifetime New Yorker, has worked in the field of community development since 1984, when he began as a program associate at the Trust for Public Land. A graduate of Columbia University, he went on to earn his master's in city and regional planning and a Juris doctorate from Rutgers University in 1988. This was followed by nine years as a law partner in the firm of Dellapa, Lewis and Perseo, whose clients included nonprofit corporations, civic groups, churches, cooperative corporations and private real estate developers. Starting in 1997, Mr. Lewis became the executive director of Habitat for Humanity-NYC. He led the organization for 10 years, guiding it to become one of the top producers in the region and a nationally emulated model of Habitat urban success.  In the spring of 2007, Mr. Lewis took the helm of the the Metropolitan Waterfront Alliance, a newly incorporated nonprofit group dedicated to the improvement of the New York and New Jersey harbor and waterways.  In addition to his professional experience with community development, he has also been active with many nonprofit community organizations. He served as co-chairman of Housing First! and is now on the board of the New York Foundation.  He lives in Flatbush, Brooklyn, with his wife and four children.

title: Summer Time-Wasting Widgets From Hulu.com
description: Since it officially started in March, Hulu, the joint video venture between NBC and Fox, has been streaming thousands of hours of TV shows and films on Hulu.com and the sites of its major syndication partners, like AOL Video and MySpace TV.   But Monday, the Hulu experience becomes considerably more ubiquitous. The Los Angeles-based Web site, which served up 88 million videos in June, according to ComScore, is introducing several widgets in its Hulu Widget Gallery.   The Hulu Player Widget lets people search for and watch Hulu videos from any Internet page.    Hulu has been struggling to convince other major programmers to contribute material to the service. Its major selling points are the growing traffic on Hulu.com, a clean and uniform video watching experience and now, broad reach across the Web.  Eric Feng, Hulu's senior vice president and chief technical officer, calls this "hyper distribution."   "Just like it's antiquated to have to be home at 7 p.m. on Tuesday to watch a show on live television, it's just as antiquated to say that people have to come to Hulu.com to watch the same program," Mr. Feng said.

title: McCain Has Growth Removed
description: Update | 6 p.m. BAKERSFIELD, Calif.Senator John McCain said here Monday that the small spot that his dermatologist removed from his upper right cheek near the temple will be biopsied "just to make sure everything is fine.''   "By the way, I, as I do every three months, I visited my dermatologist this morning,'' Mr. McCain said outside an oil pump here, where he was talking about energy. "She said that I was doing fine, took a small little nick from my cheek, as she does regularly, and that will be biopsied just to make sure that everything is fine.''   Mr. McCain, who wore a band-aid over the spot earlier, had taken it off, revealing a small dark area on his upper right cheek. His left cheek is puffy and scarred from surgery he had in 2000 to remove a melanoma, and lymph nodes from his neck.     "But I want to again urge all Americans to wear sunscreen, particularly this summer, stay out of the sun as much as possible, wear sunscreen, and if you ever have any slight discoloration, please go to your dermatologist or your doctor and get it checked up on,'' he said. "Melanoma is a preventable occurrence. It really is. It is one of the most preventable occurrences. But remember, a lot of the damage that people see from the sun when they're young sometimes comes back later in life. And that's the end of my lecture from the American Dermatology Association today. Thank you all very much.''   Asked if his doctor was confident that it was nothing major, he said. "sure, absolutely.''   Michael Yardley, spokesman for the Mayo Clinic in Scottsdale, Arizona, issued the following statement on Monday:  "This morning, as part of his commitment to monitor his dermatological health on a regular basis, Senator John McCain visited the Mayo Clinic in Scottsdale, Arizona, for a routine examination. As a precaution, a biopsy was ordered of a very small area on Senator McCain's right cheek. This is a routine minor procedure."
