title: Man Sought in Daughters Kidnapping
description: (Photo: Clark Rockefeller and his daughter, Reigh, 7. (Photo: Boston Police Department)) Updated, 7:44 p.m. | The New York City police are searching the city's streets and area harbors for a man, Clark Rockefeller, who is believed to have snatched his 7-year-old daughter, Reigh Rockefeller, from a Boston street and brought her to New York.  According to the Boston Police Department, a private social worker called the police shortly after noon on Sunday to report that Mr. Rockefeller had kidnapped the child after arriving for a supervised custodial visit. Mr. Rockefeller and his wife, Sandra L. Boss, divorced last year.   The Boston police described Mr. Rockefeller as a man in his 50s with blond hair, standing 5 feet 6 inches tall and weighing about 170 pounds. The social worker told the officers that Mr. Rockefeller grabbed his daughter, put her into a black sport-utility vehicle and sped away. Reigh was described as being 4 feet tall, with blond hair and blue eyes, and wearing a pink and white sun dress and red shoes. The Boston police issued, then canceled, an Amber Alert after determining that Mr. Rockefeller was heading with the girl to New York.  Law enforcement authorities in New York said they believed that Mr. Rockefeller arrived in Manhattan on Sunday night with his daughter, with the intent of ferrying her to Bermuda by boat. Harbor patrols were searching marinas in an effort to find the father and daughter, the authorities said.  The Boston police have a warrant out for Mr. Rockefeller's arrest on charges of custodial kidnapping, assault and battery, and assault and battery with a dangerous weapon.  Public records show that Clark Rockefeller and Reigh's mother, Sandra L. Boss, 41, lived together most recently in the Beacon Hill neighborhood of Boston in a home valued at $2.3 million.  The Boston Globe reported that Ms. Boss is a partner, based in London, for McKinsey & Company, the management consulting company, and that she is also interim chairwoman of the board of trustees of The Mount, Edith Wharton's home and estate in Lenox, Mass., in the Berkshires.   Ms. Boss graduated from Stanford in 1989, with a degree in American studies, and holds an M.B.A. from Harvard. According to a biography on McKinsey's Web site, she led a McKinsey study, commissioned by Senator Charles E. Schumer and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, on New York's competitiveness with London as a global financial center. Before joining McKinsey, she worked for Merrill Lynch in debt markets and for Trammell Crow Ventures.  Ms. Boss filed for divorce on Jan. 17, 2007, in Suffolk County Probate and Family Court, and on Nov. 30, 2007, she successfully petitioned Probate and Family Court to legally change her daughter's name from Reigh Storrow Rockefeller to Reigh Storrow Mills Boss, according to public records and The Boston Herald. The child's father signed off on the name change as J. Clark Rockefeller. The divorce is final, but the records from the court proceedings were sealed at the couple's request.   In telephone interviews on Monday, Amy Fitch and Michele Hiltzik, senior archivists at the Rockefeller Archive Center in Sleepy Hollow, N.Y., which maintains the records of the Rockefeller family associated with Standard Oil, philanthropy and politics, said there was no indication that Clark Rockefeller was a descendant of William Avery Rockefeller, the father of John D. Rockefeller Sr. and William Rockefeller.   (John D. Rockefeller Sr., the oil tycoon, and his son John D. Jr., the philanthropist, made the Rockefeller name famous. The five sons of John D. Rockefeller Jr. -- John D. III, Nelson, Laurance, Winthrop and David -- continued to extend the family's name. Nelson A. Rockefeller was governor of New York and vice president of the United States under President Gerald R. Ford. Winthrop was governor of Arkansas. David, the only one of the five brothers still living, was head of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and has been a major fixture in New York life for decades.)  In 2004, The Valley News, in Lebanon, N.H., reported that Mr. Rockefeller refused to confirm whether or not he was related, directly or otherwise, to the famed Rockefeller family. "Maybe I am, maybe I'm not; it's not something that I would either confirm or deny," Clark Rockefeller responded, according to the paper. "I just don't want anything to do with the whole question."  The newspaper was trying to determine Clark Rockefeller's lineage after he reportedly wrote a $110,000 check to the town of Cornish, N.H., in exchange for a deed to a historic church.  Eric Konigsberg contributed reporting.

title: Behind the Madness | Costume Designer Janie Bryant
Did Obama Overstay?
description: Dan Schnur was the national communications director for John McCain's presidential campaign in 2000. (Full biography.)  At many levels, Barack Obama's overseas tour could have been categorized as a political victory before it even began. The Iraqi prime minister had just announced support for a timeline similar to Mr. Obama's plan for early American troop withdrawal, the Bush Administration had sent a representative to multination talks with Iran, and a growing military and political consensus had emerged as to the need for a greater military presence in Afghanistan.   (Photo: Barack Obama played basketball with American troops in Kuwait, on July 20, before flying to Afghanistan. (Army Sgt. Brooks Fletcher/US Army, via Associated Press)) In other words, the three most important pillars of Mr. Obama's international platform had been endorsed from a variety of unexpected sources. That's a pretty good way to start a trip designed to deal with questions about a candidate's understanding of foreign policy and national security.  But as every junior political operative knows, it's all about the photos, which means that the real value of Mr. Obama's trip was the visual reinforcement of too-good-to-be-true images he accumulated along the way. Many American voters read about his policy and political achievements in print. But a much larger audience saw footage of the Democratic nominee meeting with Hamid Karzai, president of Afghanistan, and Iraq's prime minister, Nuri Kamal al-Maliki; taking a helicopter ride with Gen. David Petraeus; and sinking a three-point shot on a basketball court on a United States military installation in Kuwait.   Before Mr. Obama's plane left American airspace 10 days ago, polls showed that voters strongly preferred John McCain when it comes to foreign policy and national security matters. By the time Mr. Obama returned home this past weekend, that steady stream of photos with military and political leaders probably raised voters' comfort level with him on this front.   Iraq and Afghanistan are the two foreign policy matters of greatest and most immediate concern to American voters, so it was of critical importance that Mr. Obama visit those two countries. Despite some verbal gymnastics on questions related to his opposition to the United States troop surge, this part of the trip was a home run. But the weeklong journey was actually three separate trips, each with a different impact on the American electorate. The trip's second segment, which took Mr. Obama to Jordan and Israel, was essentially a draw. His visit to Israel was an exercise in diplomatic survival at best: no setbacks but no real gains either. And the scenic backdrop of his news conference in Jordan was probably offset by the reporting of his ride to the airport in King Abdullah's Mercedes 600 Series sports car.   The third part of the expedition  Germany, France and England  was the least helpful to him. Indeed, as the week wore on, the beneficial news coverage that Mr. Obama received on earlier stops began to fade. Just as the United States news media had reacted to Hillary Clinton's complaints and "Saturday Night Live"'s parodies last spring by toughening up on Mr. Obama during the final weeks of the primary campaign, another mini-backlash developed as this trip reached its final destinations. By this past weekend, news stories used words like "defend" and "rebut" to characterize Mr. Obama's own statements about the trip. The candidate himself began to acknowledge that many voters might not see the benefits in his being out of the country for such an extended period.   The controversy over the campaign's decision to cancel a visit with wounded American troops in Germany didn't help matters, especially given the photograph that emerged of the candidate heading into the hotel gym at the Berlin Ritz-Carlton. But the bigger problem is that it wasn't as clear what the final stops were designed to accomplish. Voters understood that Mr. Obama went to Afghanistan and Iraq to show them that he was prepared to be their commander in chief. But his visits to London and Paris didn't seem quite so urgent. Proving his foreign policy knowledge in the world's hot spots was necessary: playing diplomat in Western Europe looked premature.  For most of the week, Mr. Obama deftly walked a fine line between statesman and show-off, between interloper and leader. On balance, he took great strides toward addressing voter concerns about his national security capabilities. Score the week a win for the Democrats, but like many tourists who traveled overseas this summer, Mr. Obama may have stayed too long.

title: Do We Dewey?

If I want to know whats eating my hosta leaves (slugs or deer, most likely), intuition tells me Ill find the answer more quickly at a Barnes & Noble, where I can head straight to Gardening, Disease and Pest Control, than at a library, where I have to consult a computer database before tracking down 635.049 and its neighbors.

title: Photo Exhibition Brings Distant Frescoes to Moscow
description: Ferapontovo Monastery, in the Vologda region 300 miles north of Moscow, is way off the beaten track for most tourists. But for those curious about the luminous 15th-century frescoes in the monasterys Cathedral of the Nativity of the Virgin, there is an exhibition of remarkable photographs on display in Moscows Shchusev State Museum of Architecture through the end of August.Profoundly theological in their content and execution, the frescoes depicting biblical prophets, saints, New Testament parables, Jesus and the Last Judgment, were painted by Dionisy the Wise,widely regarded as one of the greatest Russian iconographers. The frescoes, along with the monastery itself, are on Unescos World Heritage list, and are especially notable for their terracotta and blue hues that seem more Mediterranean in style than northern Russian.Which makes it all the more amazing thatthe 300 or so images in The Light of Dionisys Frescoes exhibition at the Shchusev Museum are photographs,the work of Yuri Kholdin, a photographer who spent over 10 years studying and capturing the frescoes, using analog cameras and shooting at specific times of day, with as little artificial light as possible. The result is a collection of images that are so detailed and true to the originals that they look like the real thing. The fact that they are hung in the museums Aptekarsky Prikaz wing, which looks and feels like a monastic chamber, only enhances the effect. Several times, I wanted to reach out and touch them, to feel the texture I could so clearly see.Kholdin died a year ago at age 52, in an accident while photographing the skyscrapers of Moscow City, the Russian capitals new business district. His widow, Yekaterina Danilova, an art historian with theological training who wrote the texts that accompany the images, has continued his work promoting the frescoes. Kholdins love of the art form was reflected in his creation of a foundation called Frescoes of Russia.In an interview about his work, which was distributed at the exhibition, Danilova discusses Kholdins time studying Renaissance art in Italy and his interest in Kazimir Malevichs Suprematism, which was influenced by icons. Its possible to see the influence of both in Kholdins approach to photographing the frescoes. One American visitor at the exhibitions July 22 opening compared the photographs of the frescoes to the work of the Italian Renaissance painter Giotto. The close-ups of fresco details  an angels face, a pitcher on a table  are reminiscent of Suprematist compositions.For more information on Kholdins work see his Web site, www.dionisy.ru, for now in Russian only.

title: Inside Sadr City
description: (Photo: Hanna al-Kassem, a patient at Imam Ali Hospital in Sadr City in May. Ms. al-Kaseem was wounded during fighting between the Mahdi Army militia and American and Iraqi forces. (Photo: Moises Saman for The New York Times))   Video This blog post is part of a series examining the people and places in Sadr City, the poor Baghdad neighborhood that is the center of the support for the radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr.  BAGHDAD -- In the first years of the war, reporters would rush to the scene of car bombings. Now the American and Iraqi military block access to bombing sites until the damage can be cleaned up and the victims evacuated. One result of this policy is that the immediate aftermath of attacks in Iraq are no longer seen on television or in newspapers. To be sure, violence is down in Baghdad and many other cities in Iraq, but it has not disappeared.  Today, when many reporters and photographers hear a large explosion in the city they head to the nearest hospital to document the dead and wounded as they are brought to morgue or emergency room. In Sadr City, that means traveling to one of four hospitals. The video and photos in this post, gathered from numerous visits to the area's oldest hospital, depict graphically conditions inside a health care facility in the hours after an attack.    (Photo: An Iraqi man, wounded during clashes between the Mahdi Army and American and Iraqi forces in April, in a hallway at the Imam Ali Hospital. (Photo: Moises Saman for The New York Times))   The largest health center in Sadr City is Imam Ali hospital, located deep in the northern part of the poor neighborhood. Built in the 1970's, it was originally called General Saddam Hospital, but has since been renamed for the son-in-law of the Prophet Muhammad. A smaller hospital in Sadr City for women is named after Muhammad's daughter, Fatima. Imam Ali was revered by Shiites, and his assassination in 661 led to the Sunni-Shiia split that still divides Muslims.   The 300-bed hospital employs 45 doctors, but at least 2 million people live in the densely packed neighborhood. Doctors said they had received 300 dead and 1,400 wounded earlier this year before a ceasefire was declared. The pact between the radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr and the Iraqi government has slowed violence in Sadr City, but it has not stopped it all together.  Doctor Yaarrub Anlwan, 40, a specialist in general surgery, said that although the situation is better now than it was under Saddam Hussein, he feels pessimistic about the future. "For 30 years this population was poor. And they don't have any education. They are neglected in many civilian life conditions," Dr. Anlwan said. "We need more time for the construction of the person, before the construction of the buildings."  Most hospitals in Iraq operate under the Ministry of Health. Teaching hospitals report to the Ministry of Higher Education and are usually better equipped, Dr. Anlwan said. Imam Ali Hospital reports to the Ministry of Health. The Health Ministry has also been accused in the past of funding Shiite militias and using their facilities to kidnap and kill Iraqi civilians.

How (Much) I Spent on My Summer Vacation
description: Spiraling gas prices were causing me to anguish over my familys planned summer vacation trip to Utah. Bite the bullet and go anyway? Or should we cancel?

title: Should Gas Prices Nix Vacation Plans?
description: Spiraling gas prices were causing me to anguish over my family's planned summer vacation trip to Utah. Bite the bullet and go anyway? Or should we cancel?   I finally decided to turn off the gas-price hysteria on the local TV news and turn on my own brain. I got out my calculator.  The vehicle we were going to drive averages around 20 miles a gallon. Naturally, we would have preferred a more fuel-efficient ride, but for hauling eight people our options were limited. We could have traded it in for a more fuel-efficient model, but that would have cost thousands just in sales tax, registration and license fees -- not to mention the beating I would have taken on the trade. Paying thousands to save hundreds seemed like voodoo math. Turns out I wasn't even talking about hundreds.  The drive was 800 miles, round-trip from Los Angeles. The last time we did it, about a year ago, regular unleaded cost about $3.09 a gallon. Now, gas prices in my area are around $4.39 a gallon. That's a significant increase, no doubt about it. But how much would it really add to my gas bill for the trip?  The answer was surprising: about 50 bucks. It will cost me about $175 for gas this year, compared with $124 last year.  Would it have been worth scuttling the vacation over that amount? C'mon. That's less than the cost of a lunch for our group.  O.K., nobody is making light of out-of-control gas prices here. But $50 more wasn't going to make or break our trip. Why be in panic mode?  We decided to see if we could cut costs in other areas to offset even that increased amount. We found it was pretty easy. First, we looked for a cheaper hotel. That was simple. A lot of hoteliers are hurting these days, and bargains abound, especially for those traveling on off-peak days. But weekend travelers can find bargains, too. For instance, using Web sites like Travelocity and Kayak we found a four-star hotel in Las Vegas for just $58 a night (there were others, as well) mid-week. My son was able to book that rate for the weekend as well. We spent a lot more than that on hotels last year. For the whole trip, we wound up spending about $100 less than we did last year.   The real pain, for me, was when gas doubled from $1 to $2 a gallon -- then went up another dollar to $3 last year. From a mathematical standpoint, the percentage of the increases is getting smaller, if that's any consolation.  I sure don't want to dissuade anyone from parking their gas guzzler if they have the option of driving a more economical vehicle or taking public transportation. These things make sense and are responsible actions. But before canceling an important family get-together, much-deserved vacation or even a weekend getaway, do the math. The numbers may surprise you.

title: Police Investigate Officer in Video
description: Updated, 6:03 p.m. | The New York City Police Department said on Monday afternoon that it had placed a police officer on modified assignment after a widely circulated YouTube video showed the officer appearing to violently shove a participant in the Critical Mass bike ride, causing the cyclist to fall off his bike.   The video, made on Friday evening and widely circulated after it was cited on Gothamist, shows the officer rushing toward the cyclist, wearing a white T-shirt and a backpack, as he pedaled down Broadway between 46th and 47th Streets:     (For background on how the video reached YouTube, see this update.)  The Police Department has not identified the officer or provided any further details about the episode on the tape, but Deputy Commissioner Paul J. Browne, the top police spokesman, said in a statement on Monday, "The officer has been placed on modified assignment pending further investigation of the incident."   Modified assignment is not a form of discipline, but is used when the Police Department is investigating possible misconduct.   Many Critical Mass bike participants have been arrested in the past, resulting in protracted litigation and court decisions, but recently, relations between the New York riders -- part of a worldwide network of urban cyclists -- and the police had shown signs of improvement.   The rides began roughly a decade ago, in San Francisco, and in early years they sometimes resulted in free-for-alls.   The New York rides -- organized by Time's Up, an environmental advocacy organization, and held on the last Friday of each month -- gained momentum in 2004, when scores of riders were arrested in August 2004, as part of the protests at the Republican National Convention. Nine more cyclists were arrested the following month, and this time, the cyclists also complained that police officers had sawed through locks and seized their bikes.  Things came to a boil in October 2004, when the city went to court to try to require Critical Mass to obtain a permit to conduct its monthly rides, arguing that the intense concentration of cyclists disrupted traffic. A federal judge denied the city's request on technical grounds, and also barred the city from seizing bikes of people who were not charged with breaking the law.   Still, some cyclists continued to get arrested, and the bicycle became an unlikely symbol of defiance of authority. Cyclist-police relations were worsened with revelations, in 2005, that the Police Department had conducted secret surveillance of numerous protest groups, including Critical Mass, around the time of the convention.  In February 2006, a state judge again rejected the city's efforts to restrict the rides, but urged both sides to talk to each other, writing, "The social compact and the realities of living in a crowded place demand patience, mutual respect and self-restraint."  The city did not give up. In June 2006, the Police Department proposed rules that would require parade permits for bicyclists traveling in groups of 20 or more -- and for any bicyclists or walkers taking to the streets in groups of two or more. The city backed down slightly, amid a storm of protest. In January 2007, the city finally adopted rules requiring parade permits for bicyclists and others who take to the streets in groups of 50 or more for processions, races and protests. Meanwhile, there have been signs in recent years that the ride's popularity has declined.

title: The Caped Decider?
description: The politics of Batman: Mystery writer Andrew Klavan has taken a decent amount of ribbing online for his suggestion, on the op-ed page of The Wall Street Journal, that President Bush and Bruce Wayne's alter ego (you know, the $314 Million Man) have a lot in common. Klavan wrote on Friday:     There seems to me no question that the Batman film "The Dark Knight," currently breaking every box office record in history, is at some level a paean of praise to the fortitude and moral courage that has been shown by George W. Bush in this time of terror and war. Like W, Batman is vilified and despised for confronting terrorists in the only terms they understand. Like W, Batman sometimes has to push the boundaries of civil rights to deal with an emergency, certain that he will re-establish those boundaries when the emergency is past.  And like W, Batman understands that there is no moral equivalence between a free society -- in which people sometimes make the wrong choices -- and a criminal sect bent on destruction. The former must be cherished even in its moments of folly; the latter must be hounded to the gates of Hell.  "The Dark Knight," then, is a conservative movie about the war on terror.     Klavan was mocked by bloggers like Isaac Chotiner of The New Republic, but other bloggers are seriously discussing his thesis.  "Insofar as it's possible to view an action movie that had the biggest three-day-opening in cinematic history as a comment on the current national-security debate, 'The Dark Knight' weighs in strongly on the side of the Bush administration," writes Spencer Ackerman of The Washington Independent. "Confronting the Joker, a nihilistic enemy whose motives are both unexplained and beside the point, the Batman faces his biggest dilemma yet: whether to abuse his power in order to save Gotham City. Again and again in the movie, the Batman's moral hand-wringing results in the deaths of innocents. Only by becoming like the monster he must vanquish can Batman secure a victory that even he understands is Pyrrhic."   But Steven Taylor, a political scientist at Troy University, thinks "The Dark Knight" works better as a critique of President Bush's approach to the war on terrorism -- rather than a celebration of it. He writes at Outside the Beltway:    Klavan's view that one can actually look at Batman as even a useful allegory about the war on terror illustrates perhaps the key problem with what has been the underlying logic in much of the Bush administration's approach to counter-terrorism, i.e., that it is that it is all very simply: just punish the bad guys. There are two basic assumptions inherent in the overall approach: 1) whatever the good guy does in pursing the bad guy is ultimately good and is justified because the good guy only wants good, and 2) the good guy only using his powers against the bad buys. It assumes above all else that it is easy to identify the bad guys, as in movies (or the comics) where they wear costumes and they are quite obvious in their malefaction.    Matthew Yglesias sides with Taylor's perspective. "I think Cheney would look at the movie and say 'see -- this is what we're doing,'" Yglesias writes on his blog for The Atlantic. "I look at the movie and say 'see -- if you were fighting a comic book bad guy and you were a comic book hero then your policies would make sense.' "

title: Comedy Central Accepts Political Ad
description: For the first time, Comedy Central's "Daily Show" with Jon Stewart and "The Colbert Report" will be broadcasting a political advertisement, one promoting Senator Barack Obama.  Tony Fox, a spokesman for Comedy Central, said he did not know why the cable channel had not accepted political advocacy advertising before, but said of the decision to do so now: "Political advertising in an election year is good business."  He also said that this particular spot, produced by members of MoveOn.org Political Action, the liberal action group, was humorous and would be a good fit with Comedy Central's young, politically sophisticated audience. It is entitled "It Could Happen to You" and features Rider Strong, the former star of "Boy Meets World," and Amber Benson of "Buffy the Vampire Slayer."  MoveOn will spend $150,000 to run it for one week on Comedy Central and MTV, which had not accepted political advertising for more than a decade but reversed that policy a month ago. Both MTV and Comedy Central are owned by Viacom Networks, which has generally weathered the current advertising downturn better than some of its competitors.   Richard Greenfield, a media analyst at Pali Research in New York, said the move showed the growing importance of MTV on the media landscape.  "Advertising is weak across the media landscape, but MTV is continuing to be resourceful in capitalizing on a political campaign," he said, adding that the company is "making a sharp decision to take the dollars while they were available."  MoveOn said its commercial was "in part" a response to an anti-Obama commercial that ran last week on MTV by Let Freedom Ring, a conservative advocacy group. It said it also wants to try to increase turnout among young voters.  "It Could Happen to You" was selected by members of MoveOn.org in a contest for 30-second pro-Obama videos and was voted the funniest. The title refers to the possibility that voters could catch Mr. Obama's message of hope, making fun of "hope" as if it were a contagious disease.  The spot is to run both nationally and on local cable in Washington, D.C., where political journalists are likely to see it and promote it for free.

title: Grow Your Own
description: "Edible landscape" seems to be going head to head with "staycation" as the most popular catch phrase of Summer 2008. Lawns may not be disappearing before our very eyes, but citizens are definitely swapping out blades of grass for bushels of beans in increasing numbers.  Take me for instance, a bona fide city dweller: As a follow up to my  column in March on the reclamation of urban and suburban land for agricultural use, I've spent the last several weeks putting theory into practice, literally getting my hands dirty (and whatever other clich I can unearth) in the interest of urban agriculture.   (Photo: My backyard, before and after. (Allison Arieff))   Two months ago, I learned about My Farm, run by mortgage-broker-turned-farmer Trevor Paque. My Farm is essentially an urban take on community-sponsored agriculture (CSAs). With CSAs, individuals essentially invest in rural farms to help support their operations and are given a weekly box of fresh produce in return. With My Farm (and similar operations found in cities including New York and Portland, Ore.), you can grow food in your own backyard with the assistance of urban farmers like Paque. In one day, he created our 120-square-foot backyard farm  landscaping with found materials from the yard, installing a drip-irrigation system and planting heirloom seeds. Now he comes once a week to harvest a box of organic and ridiculously local produce for us  plus an additional box, which he sells to another family in our neighborhood.   This costs us about $100 a month, and has allowed us to replace our water-dependent grass patch with an edible landscape. After just three months in business, Paque has a waiting list of over 200 people and is scrambling to keep up with demand.   Urban agriculture has been around since at least the 18th century, but it's an idea whose time has truly come  now  in the United States. The reasons range from the fact that our hands are always found glued to computer keys and not even occasionally in the dirt, to the scary existence of industrially grown tomatoes that may (or may not) cause salmonella, to the fact that a drive to the market can now cost more than the food you purchase there.   Though some may see this as a "lazy locavore" trend  wherein couch potato clients, glass of biodynamic Syrah in hand, observe the hard labor of city farmers while lounging with their laptops  the urban agriculture movement seems to me to be slowly transcending its elitist associations. It is truly growing into something that is wholly about collaboration, community and connection to food, to neighbors, to land.  That's certainly been my experience both in my yard, as neighbors and friends come by to help harvest (and to eat), and in my city. Earlier this month, my family spent a Saturday at San Francisco's Civic Center Plaza, helping to plant a 10,000-square-foot Victory Garden sponsored by Slow Food Nation, a nonprofit organization that will be celebrating American food through art, music, lectures, tastings, school programs and the like over Labor Day Weekend. More than 250 volunteers and nearly a dozen Bay Area gardening organizations dedicated their time to plant the first edible garden in front of San Francisco's City Hall since 1943. Designed by John Bela of the arts collective REBAR and curated by the artist/gardener/activist Amy Francheschini of Victory Gardens 2008+, this public installation aims to demonstrate the potential of a truly local agriculture practice while producing high-quality food for those in need.   (Photo: Slow Food Nation's victory garden in front of San Francisco City Hall. (Courtesy of Scott Chernis/Scott Chernis Photography))   This day was social networking of the best sort. Participants got some dirt under their fingernails, ran into old friends, ate an organic lunch and left weary but happy. It was as much about community creation as food cultivation. I hope to see this sort of urban (and suburban) intervention replicated across the country. (It will be a shame if the city of San Francisco can't find a way to either keep the garden here or find a suitable space to relocate it.)  This isn't just a California thing, nor does it require vast amounts of open space. At PS1 in Long Island City, N.Y., the architecture firm WORK AC eschewed that art institution's traditionalUrban Beach concept for an Urban Farm.  Planters at PS1, part of WORK AC's Urban Farm"/>Planters are part of WORK AC's Urban Farm project. (Elizabeth Felicella)"This came out a desire to combine urbanism with ecology," explains Work Architecture Company principal Dan Wood, who with his partner, Amale Andraos, and their architecture students at Princeton have concluded that the urban farm is really the holy grail of making things sustainable. WORK AC's take is particularly urban, featuring things like a mobile phone charging station, speakers that emit farm-animal sounds and "Gaia" soil made from recycled Styrofoam and pectin gel. Food harvested from the project is used at PS1's caf, thus reducing food miles to a whopping 300 feet.   When I spoke with Wood and Andraos recently, it was evident that this project is the result of an intricate network of people and places. They spoke excitedly of the great advice they'd received, for example, from Michael Grady Robertson of the 50-acre Queens County Farm Museum (which I bet you didn't know existed) in New York and from their solar panel installer, who'd honed his craft in Alaska. Andraos stressed that they really wanted this typically rural thing to offer to city dwellers all the things that attract them about city living: social interaction, play, excitement, fun.  If all of this has helped plant a seed of inspiration, why not enter Readymade's Second Annual Garden Challenge. The DIY bible Readymade, which inspires its readership toward the execution (or at least vicarious realization) of creative ideas on small budgets, invites readers to submit ideas for transforming their own outdoor spaces in innovative ways. (E-mail ideas to shana@readymademag.com by Aug. 1.) I've no doubt they'll be hearing from hordes of less-than-lazy locavores.

title: R.N.C. Creates Facebook Parody Site for Obama
description: Here's an entry you would not expect to see on Barack Obama's official profile on the social networking site Facebook: "Barack Obama is now friends with Antonin 'Tony' Rezko."  But that's the first item on Mr. Obama's "FriendFeed" on BarackBook.com, a Facebook parody site created by the Republican National Committee that it says will go live on Tuesday. According to the R.N.C, the site is intended to showcase some of Mr. Obama's "notable associations."   And highlighting Mr. Obama's relationship with Mr. Rezko, the Chicago real estate developer who was recently convicted in federal court of corruption and money laundering, is just the beginning. Mr. Rezko was an early political backer of Mr. Obama and donated large sums to his campaigns. (Mr. Obama has since severed ties with Mr. Rezko and given much of the money he raised to charity.)  An early glance at the R.N.C. mockup shows Mr. Rezko with his own profile page that lists links to Mr. Obama and other "friends" of the Illinois senator. Other "BarackBook" friends include, Eric Holder, a Washington lawyer and member of Mr. Obama's vice presidential selection team, and William Ayers, one of the founders of the radical group Weather Underground.  Each profile is set to include videos, news articles and sections like "Facts About Me and Barack," "My Donations and Bundling for Barack" and "What Barack Says About Me." The R.N.C. says it plans to continue updating BarackBook between now and the election. (Notably, the Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright, Mr. Obama's controversial former pastor, does not yet have a profile.)  Users of Facebook  the real one  may be able to install an application on their personal page with links to BarackBook.  Alex Conant, a spokesman for the R.N.C. called the planned site "an interactive way to learn more about Obama's poor judgment."  But in using a faux social networking site to highlight what it considers to be some of Mr. Obama's more controversial acquaintances -- past and present -- the R.N.C. is also opening itself up to the inevitable comparisons between the Obama campaign's online efforts and those of his rival, Senator John McCain.  While there is no single metric for success on the Internet, there are some leading indicators. For example, Mr. Obama has about 1.2 million Facebook friends, while Mr. McCain has fewer than 200,000. But the Republicans are making an effort to catch up in the e-campaign. Last week the R.N.C. launched a new Internet browser toolbar to collect "micro-donations" from supporters.  And as the Republicans are trying to point out with their twist on Facebook, having lots of friends can have its downsides.

description: Anyone hoping for signs the market in Spain is leveling off will be disappointed by the latest round of numbers. The number of house sales dropped by 34 percent in May compared to a year earlier and mortgage borrowing dropped by more than 40 percent, according to the National Statistics Institute.

title: In the Shadow of M.M.A.
description: Ryan Reser says that judos popularity could use help. But what seems to befuddle Reser is how judo, the sport he will represent the United States in at the Olympics, can wallow in obscurity while mixed martial arts has exploded into the mainstream in the past few years.

title: A French Cyclists Long Ride
description: Anyone who has marveled at 41-year-old Dara Torress longevity in swimming should also consider the French cyclist Jeannie Longo-Ciprelli, who  two months shy of her 50th birthday  will compete in Beijing in her seventh consecutive Olympics.

title: A Longhorn Gets a Chance to Fulfill Expectations
description: In Texass preseason practices last year, defensive end Brian Orakpo was unstoppable.

title: Robert Novak Has Brain Tumor
description: The columnist Robert Novak has a brain tumor and will stop writing and making television appearances, at least temporarily.

title: How to Make a Frittata
description: There is a technique to making a frittata that is always the same, no matter what the filling. Use this recipe to take advantage of an easy-to-prepare meal that can be a vehicle for leftovers of many kinds.

title: Execution by Military Is Approved by President
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush on Monday approved the first execution by the military since 1961, upholding the death penalty of an Army private convicted of a series of rapes and murders more than two decades ago.

title: Footnotes
description: Chuck Berry withdrew from two sold-out weekend concerts in Spain unexpectedly, organizers said Monday, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Berry, the rock n roll pioneer, who turns 82 in October, was scheduled to perform in Estepona on Spains Mediterranean coast on Saturday and in the northern city of Leon on Sunday. An explanation for the decision was not given. ... Its Bad for Ya, George Carlins last recorded concert, from March, will make its CD debut on Eardrum Records on Tuesday. ... The Cake Eaters, the first directorial effort of the actress Mary Stuart Masterson, captured the best feature jury prize at the 13th annual Stony Brook Film Festival on Saturday. ... The Womens Project theater company has announced its fall season. Highlights include a production of Virginia Woolfs Freshwater, the first time the play will have been performed professionally in New York. It will be directed by Anne Bogart and run Jan. 15 through Feb. 15.

title: Sharpton Faces Trial for Protest of Bell Verdict
description: Al Sharpton is set to go to trial in September after rejecting, for the second time in three weeks, an offer from the district attorneys office to plead guilty to disorderly conduct for protesting the Sean Bell verdict in exchange for no jail time.

title: Hate for Liberals and Gay People Drove Gunman, Police Say
description: A man who the police say entered a Unitarian Universalist church in Knoxville, Tenn., on Sunday and shot eight people, killing two, was motivated by a hatred for liberals and gay people, Chief Sterling P. Owen IV of the Knoxville Police Department said Monday.

title: White House Predicts $482 Billion Deficit
description: WASHINGTON  The White House predicted Monday that President Bush would leave a record $482 billion deficit to his successor, a sobering turnabout in the nations fiscal condition from 2001, when Mr. Bush took office after three consecutive years of budget surpluses.

title: Exploring the Bozo Mystique, and Defining Funny on Their Own Feminine Terms
description: Judi Lewis Ockler maneuvered into a black Victorian blouse, plucking the puffed velvet sleeves into place. She rummaged through her gym bag for a long green cloak and a pair of yellow socks with daisies. Then she pulled out a pink polka-dot baggie for the final touch: a red nose.

title: Tyrone Power, Giving the Women Something to Sigh About
description: When the 22-year-old Tyrone Power makes his entrance in the last minutes of a fusty melodrama called Girls Dormitory, its as if all the lights on the soundstage had gone on at once. Listen closely, and you can almost hear the collective sigh of the original audience of 1936: this sincere young man, with the perfectly arched eyebrows, penetrating gaze and blinding smile, seems to have stepped off a cloud.

title: Building a Church Brought Tatis Back
description: MIAMI  The revelation comes in fragments.

title: Mortgaged to the World
description: Shelter Island, N.Y.

title:
N.F.L. Hopeful
Cant Have It All
description: WASHINGTON  Caleb Campbell, a member of West Points class of 2008 and a seventh-round draft pick of the Detroit Lions, woke up one day last week expecting to sign a $295,000 contract that afternoon. He was anticipating the teams season opener in September against the Atlanta Falcons.

title: Bombers and Ethnic Clashes Kill 61 in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Three women wrapped in explosives killed dozens in Iraq on Monday, shaking the country as chaos and ethnic violence erupted in the volatile northern city of Kirkuk, where tensions had already run high between majority Kurds and ethnic Turkmens.

title: Trying to Move on Without Knowing Next Move
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The Green Bay Packers first training camp practice began on this sunny Monday morning without the N.F.L.s most reluctant retiree, Brett Favre. But even the Packers with All-Pro tunnel vision could not avoid reminders of the Favre saga everywhere they looked.

title: Arrests Increase Tensions Between Palestinian Factions
description: JERUSALEM  Tensions between the main rival Palestinian groups, Hamas and Fatah, spread from Gaza to the West Bank on Monday with reports of the Fatah-dominated Palestinian Authority security forces detaining more than 50 activists and academics associated with Hamas.

title: Cities, Police and Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: Clearing Up a Blurry Work Life
description: As the founding editor and lead blogger for Lifehacker, the popular site that offers tech tricks, tips and downloads for getting things done, Gina Trapani has become a go-to source for people who have become overwhelmed by the demands and complexities of modern technology. Ms. Trapani, who is also a computer programmer, is the author of "Upgrade Your Life" (Wiley, 2008), a wide-ranging reference on how everyday Joes and Janes can use the tools of a master geek to get things done smarter and faster on and off the job.

title: The Claim: Thunderstorms Can Set Off Asthma Attacks
description: THE FACTS

title: Beneath the Hall, a Baseball Vault Full of Treasures
description: COOPERSTOWN, N.Y.

title: Bank Shares Retreat, Giving Up Gains
description: A sell-off of stocks accelerated in late trading Monday as investors moved out of shares of investment and commercial banks, many of which have given back all of their gains from last week.

title: A Major Tuneup for a Sports Machine
description: MOSCOW  The Podolsk Olympic training center located outside Moscow was built more than a half century ago to develop the athletes who would transform the Soviet Union into an athletic superpower.

title: In Beijing, Blue Skies Prove Hard to Achieve
description: BEIJING  Less than two weeks before the Olympics, Beijings skies are so murky and polluted that the authorities are considering emergency measures during the Games beyond the traffic restrictions and factory shutdowns that, so far, have failed to clear the air, state media reported on Monday.

title: Calculating Economics of an Eye for an Eye
description: In the Albanian canon, a 15th-century handbook detailing the rules of revenge that is still in circulation, a mans relatives are expected to take their blood back if he is shot. In Iran a death can be compensated with blood money: 100 camels in early Islam; thousands of dollars today. A girls life is worth only half of a boys. So is an eye; a tooth, one-twentieth. In Sicily there is an oral tradition describing various methods of revenge: tying a mans feet to his neck so that when he moves, he strangles himself; handcuffing a victim to a bonfire of olive wood; throwing him into a sty with hungry pigs.

title: For Elderly, a Little Fall, a Big Worry
description: Shes 88 and tripped and fell yesterday, the emergency room doctor told me when I answered the page. She was on the floor about 15 hours when her family found her.

title: G.M. Cuts Jobs as Part of a Production Curb
description: DETROIT  General Motors will eliminate shifts at two truck plants and lay off 1,760 workers to further reduce production of slow-selling pickups and sport utility vehicles.

title: 10 Things to Scratch From Your Worry List
description: For most of the year, it is the duty of the press to scour the known universe looking for ways to ruin your day. The more fear, guilt or angst a news story induces, the better. But with August upon us, perhaps youre in the mood for a break, so Ive rounded up a list of 10 things not to worry about on your vacation.

title: McCain Has a Spot Removed From His Face
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif.  Senator John McCain said on Monday that his dermatologist had removed a spot from his right cheek, and that while it did not appear to be serious, she would perform a biopsy just to make sure everything is fine.

title: Past Time for Speaking Out
description: Two weeks before he goes to the Beijing Olympic Games, President Bush remains unacceptably silent about Chinas crackdown on basic human rights. Emboldened by the complicity of Mr. Bush and other leaders, China is harassing or locking up critics, threatening journalists and selectively denying visas.

title: Write-Down Is Planned at Merrill
description: Only 10 days after stunning Wall Street with a huge quarterly loss, Merrill Lynch unexpectedly disclosed another multibillion-dollar write-down on Monday and sought to bolster its finances once again by selling new stock to the public and to an investment company controlled by Singapore.

title: Injury at Tanglewood
description: A concertgoer at Tanglewood was struck by lightning but not seriously injured on Sunday, the police in Lenox, Mass., said. As storms were approaching around 1:15 p.m., Berkshire County sheriffs deputies cleared the area and asked people to seek shelter in the performance shed and Ozawa concert hall, said Bernadette Horgan, a Tanglewood spokeswoman. One man, whose name was not released, was struck before he could reach the shelter.

title: After Bombing, Turkish Leader Urges Unity
description: ISTANBUL  Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, eight government ministers and thousands of mourners stood as burial prayers were said at a local mosque on Monday for 10 of the 17 victims of Sundays double bombing. The coffins, like many houses in the area around the bombing site, were draped with Turkeys red-and-white flag.

title: Michael Berniker, 73, Record Producer, Dies
description: Michael Berniker, a prolific record producer whose diverse projects won nine Grammy Awards over four decades, died on Friday in Great Barrington, Mass. He was 73.

title: 'Nottingham' Postponed
description: Robin Hoods heroic reputation will remain intact for now. Production on the film Nottingham, which would have put a revisionist spin on the legend of Sherwood Forest, has been postponed indefinitely, Reuters reported. Universal Pictures said the film, which was to star Russell Crowe, above, as a good Sheriff of Nottingham under the direction of Ridley Scott, was delayed because of the possibility of an actors strike and because of concerns over the script and location issues. Production had been scheduled to begin next month. The script, by Ethan Reiff and Cyrus Voris with a rewrite by Brian Helgeland, was not where the studio wanted it to be, Universal said, and the films forests need to be green, which they are not now. Nottingham was scheduled to be released in November 2009.

title: Ryanair Shares Tumble on Earnings Report
description: PARIS  Ryanair said Monday that 2008 was stacking up to be a dismal year for airlines, as the company, Europes biggest no-frills carrier, warned that it might post its first annual loss as a public company.

title: Bringing Microscopes Down to Size in Quest for More Compact Labs
description: In the drive to miniaturize laboratory tools, to create a so-called lab on a chip, the conventional light microscope has been a stumbling block. Microscopes require lenses and, above all, space to focus and magnify images.

title: Qantas Defends Handling of Accident
description: SYDNEY  Qantas Airways officials said Monday that an air safety directive issued by the United States Federal Aviation Authority with a warning about how oxygen cylinders were attached to Boeing 747 aircraft did not apply to the plane that was forced to make an emergency landing last week with a hole in its fuselage.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A Man in the News article last Tuesday about Radovan Karadzic, the former leader of Bosnian Serbs arrested on July 21 on longstanding war-crimes charges for atrocities committed in the Balkans conflict of the early 1990s, referred incorrectly to a British statesman who had helped draft the 1995 Dayton agreement that ended the conflict. At the time he worked on the agreement, he was Lord Owen, a former foreign secretary; he had been known as David Owen when he held that post.

title: The Story Behind Kennedys Surgery
description: When Senator Edward M. Kennedy disclosed on May 20 that he had brain cancer, three days after suffering a seizure, doctors did not list surgery as a possibility. A news release from Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston left the impression that radiation and chemotherapy were the main options for his pernicious type of cancer.

title: Big Tobacco, Meet Big Philanthropy
description: Is it possible that the tobacco industry has met its match? After years of watching public-health groups and governments struggle to rein in the multinational tobacco companies, it was good to hear that Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York City and Bill Gates have joined forces to combat the smoking epidemic threatening many low- and middle-income countries.

title: Fire Destroys Historic English Pier
description: A fire on Monday devoured a historic seaside pier that stretched nearly a quarter of a mile into the sea and was an iconic destination for English holidaymakers for more than a century.

title: Knicks Trade Balkman, Former First-Round Pick
description: Two years after the Knicks drafted Renaldo Balkman to a chorus of boos and barrage of pundits mockery, they traded him Monday to the Denver Nuggets for guard Taurean Green, forward Bobby Jones and a second-round draft pick in 2010. The Knicks also gave the Nuggets an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: Can Obama Run the Offense?
description: Lets see if Ive got this straight. Barack Obama is a United States senator, a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee and his partys candidate for president of the United States  and yet it was somehow presumptuous of him to meet with foreign leaders last week during his trip to the Middle East and Europe.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about the dedication of a bench on Sullivans Island, S.C., to commemorate slaves and their history  an action inspired by a remark by the writer Toni Morrison  misidentified the location of Fort Sumter. It is in Charleston Harbor near Sullivans Island; it is not on Sullivans Island.

title: Asparagus and Parmesan Omelet or Frittata
description: This is a favorite omelet of mine. I make folded French omelets for one or two, and larger frittatas for a crowd.

title: Doctor and Patient, Now at Odds
description: A growing chorus of discontent suggests that the once-revered doctor-patient relationship is on the rocks.

title: For the Record
description: In her column last Wednesday, Maureen Dowd wrote that a Democratic lawmaker privately asked Gen. David Petraeus why there werent more Democrats in the military, and he replied, There are more than you think. Col. Steven Boylan of the generals public affairs office in Baghdad, which was not contacted for comment, says the quotation is in error as he never made nor would make such a statement.

title: Chopin's Heart to Stay Undisturbed
description: Frederic Chopins heart will remain unmoved. The Polish government has refused to allow geneticists to perform DNA testing on the alcohol-preserved organ, which is nestled inside a column in the Holy Cross Church in Warsaw, The Associated Press reported. The Polish geneticists said testing might establish whether Chopin suffered from cystic fibrosis, which can cause some conditions that afflicted him, including fevers, respiratory infections and delayed puberty. The government said experts found that the chances of successful testing were low, and that in any case it would not shed any meaningful light on Chopin or his work, The Associated Press said. Tuberculosis has long been believed to be the cause of his death.

title: Beach Closings Down Last Year
description: WASHINGTON  There were fewer beach closings and health warnings to swimmers last year than the year before, when beach pollution reports reached a record, an environmental group reported on Tuesday. But the Natural Resources Defense Council said its study, based on data collected by the Environmental Protection Agency at more than 3,500 beaches, showed that American beaches continue to suffer from serious water pollution that puts swimmers at risk.

title: One Russert Job Is Filled by NBC
description: NBC named Mark Whitaker on Monday as its next Washington bureau chief, succeeding the late Tim Russert. Mr. Whitaker, the former editor of Newsweek, has been a senior vice president of NBC News since 2007. The appointment has been widely expected because of Mr. Whitakers extensive journalism credentials. He will fulfill the off-camera duties that had been handled by Mr. Russert, including overall management of the bureau and oversight of political coverage as well as the Meet the Press Sunday discussion program. He said he recognized that he had big shoes to fill. In a telephone interview Mr. Whitaker said: Im honored to get the chance. Were in the middle of a historic election, the economy is going through its worst time in a generation and there are big changes on the world scene. He called NBCs Washington staff the best in television. Mr. Whitaker, 51, said he would commute between New York and Washington in the next month while the NBC News president, Steve Capus, is in Beijing for the Olympics. After that he will supervise NBCs coverage of the political conventions in August and September.

title: Olympic Dream Stalls in Iraq
description: Just in case the bureaucrats and politicians fail to do the right thing, Laura J. Hagen was at her computer Monday, composing a letter, trying to say the right thing.

title: Intra-Species Dining, but Not on the Food Channel
description: How to perk up an exhausted entertainment genre? A little cannibalism, it turns out, does the trick.

title: Money for Colombia
description: To the Editor:

title: In Detainee Trial, System Is Tested
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba  On the surface, the proceedings unfolding inside a makeshift courthouse on a hill here resemble an American trial. A judge wearing a black robe presides. There is a public gallery and a witness stand. Prosecutors present witnesses, and defense lawyers cross-examine them. Objections are made and ruled upon.

title: New Brand Logos Reflect Shift at G.M.
description: WHEN the Insignia, a new car from the General Motors brands Opel and Vauxhall, was introduced last week at the British International Motor Show in London, it came, fittingly, with some new insignias.

title: Jamiel A. Chagra, 63, Drug Kingpin, Dies
description: HOUSTON  Jamiel Alexander Chagra, an El Paso drug dealer and gambler who was accused but never convicted of masterminding the assassination of a federal judge in 1979, died on Friday in Mesa, Ariz. He was 63.

title: Its Always Happy Hour for Several Species in Malaysian Rain Forest
description: The human species now has drinking partners.

title: Houston Resists Recycling, and Independent Streak Is Cited
description: HOUSTON  While most large American cities have started ambitious recycling programs that have sharply reduced the amount of trash bound for landfills, Houston has not.

title: A New Way to Generate Mortgages
description: The financial establishment came together Monday in search of a new way for banks to come up with cash for home mortgages. Regulators, bankers and traders, led by Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., all pledged to do their best to get a covered bond market going in the United States.

title: Aging: Women May Live Longer With Dementia
description: Even though women tend to live longer than men, new research suggests that after age 90, they are more likely to have dementia than men who live to the same age.

title: Phillies Will Pass on Ramrez
description: The Red Sox have a difficult chore in trying to trade an unhappy Manny Ramrez, and they will not find a home for him in Philadelphia. While the Phillies were mentioned as a possible landing spot for Ramrez because of his strong relationship with Manager Charlie Manuel, General Manager Pat Gillick harpooned the idea Monday.

title: Another Amenity Vanishes as Carriers Shut Lounges
description: AIRPORT lounges are the latest casualty of the current crisis in the airline industry.

title: The Biggest Issue
description: Why did the United States become the leading economic power of the 20th century? The best short answer is that a ferocious belief that people have the power to transform their own lives gave Americans an unparalleled commitment to education, hard work and economic freedom.

title: Another Vatican Conspiracy, This Time Without a Code
description: The Eternal Citys true tragedy was precisely that it was condemned to live eternally, Emilio Caldern writes of Rome in The Creators Map. Whatever.

title: While Celebrity Fades, Place in History Doesnt
description: NORFOLK, Va.  A group of Columbus Clippers is playing poker in the cramped clubhouse at Harbor Park, their bodies hunched over a table and the cards pressed to their faces. None are recognizable, except the one with the bald pate and blond goatee. That is Mike Bacsik, a journeyman pitcher better known as the man who gave up Barry Bondss 756th home run  the one that broke Hank Aarons career record.

title: Cuts for Drug Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: Officer Investigated in Toppling of Cyclist
description: A New York City police officer was stripped of his gun and badge on Monday after an amateur video surfaced on the Internet showing him pushing a bicyclist to the ground in Times Square during a group ride on Friday evening.

title: New Steps in Private Space Travel
description: The cloak of secrecy was lifted from a two-fuselage airplane that may someday lift passengers toward space. Sir Richard Branson, the founder of the Virgin companies, and Burt Rutan, the aircraft designer, unveiled White Knight Two, an all-composite plane created to carry a smaller, rocket-propelled craft, SpaceShipTwo, into the sky between its two fuselages. The smaller ship will be released and then will fire a rocket engine that will take it into suborbital space. SpaceShipTwo is still under development.

title: Lawyers in Rural Japan: Low Supply, Iffy Demand
description: YAKUMO, Japan  There was no inherent reason that this northern Japanese town, population 19,743, had never had a lawyer until now. It had its share of people with debts, disputes over property, wrangling over inheritances  enough disharmony, certainly, to keep at least one lawyer busy.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An art review on Friday about two exhibitions of Icelandic art, using information provided by Scandinavia House, the site of From Another Shore: Recent Icelandic Art, misstated the title of a work by Katrin Sigurdardottir that is on display there. It is Haul, not Cargo.

title: The Jetpack: From Comics to a Liftoff in the Yard
description: OSHKOSH, Wis.  To rise off the ground wearing a jetpack is to feel the force of dreams. Very, very noisy dreams.

title: Sound of Music Villa Opens for Business
description: The von Trapp familys villa opened to the public for the first time, as a hotel and museum, over the weekend in Salzburg, Austria, Agence France-Presse reported.

title: Police Seek Boston Man in Daughters Abduction
description: The police searched New York Citys streets and waterways on Monday for a man who is believed to have kidnapped his 7-year-old daughter in Boston and whisked her to New York, possibly with the intention of sailing with her to Bermuda on his yacht, Serenity.

title: Bush Praises Pakistan Just Hours After U.S. Strike
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush on Monday praised Pakistans commitment to fighting extremists along its deteriorating border with Afghanistan, only hours after an American missile strike destroyed what American and Pakistani officials described as a militant outpost in the region, killing at least six fighters.

title: Taiwan: Typhoon Kills One Before Heading for China
description: Typhoon Fung-Wong crossed the middle of Taiwan, killing one person and injuring five, and closing schools, businesses and financial markets. The storm then headed for the coast of China, where the authorities in Fujian Province evacuated more than 200,000 people in preparation for its arrival early Tuesday morning.

title: Thai and Cambodian Leaders Begin Talks
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia  The foreign ministers of Thailand and Cambodia met Monday to begin what they said would be protracted talks over a disputed mountaintop temple where soldiers from both nations have confronted each other since early this month.

title: There Was Smoke  and Fire
description: It was hardly news that President Bushs Justice Department has been illegally politicized, but it was important that the Justice Department finally owned up to that sorry state of affairs. An internal investigation released on Monday found that the departments top staff routinely took politics and ideology into account in filling nonpolitical positions  and lied about it.

title: Drug Trials Deepen Dilemma on Preventing H.I.V. Transmission in Breast-Feeding
description: For a mother infected with the virus that causes AIDS, breast-feeding presents a life-and-death dilemma. Using formula protects her child from H.I.V. But mixed with dirty water, it increases the chances that the child will die of diarrhea or malnutrition. In poor countries, most mothers still breast-feed, because it is traditional, because formula is expensive  and because using formula announces to local busybodies that a mother is probably infected.

title: Tension Mounting in Serbia on Eve of Nationalist Rally
description: BELGRADE, Serbia  Tension was mounting here Monday on the eve of a rally called by an ultranationalist party that some feared could turn violent over the likely extradition of Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb leader arrested last week on war crimes charges.

title: CBS and NBC Split the Night
description: CBS and NBC finished in a virtual tie for first place in Sundays ratings, according to Nielsen estimates. While CBS drew its largest audiences early in the night with 60 Minutes at 7 (9.2 million) and Big Brother at 8 (6 million), NBC led during the latter portion of the night with Dateline from 9 to 11 (7.5 million). Both networks broadcast reruns during the other time slots. ABC was third overall as Week 2 of High School Musical: Get in the Picture continued to struggle at 8 (3.1 million). ABCs lineup also included repeats of Extreme Makeover: Home Edition at 9 (5 million) and Desperate Housewives at 10 (3.1 million). Fox finished fourth for the night with reruns of its Sunday-night animated comedy shows, although among adults 18 to 49, the network edged ahead of CBS and NBC for first place in that age group.

title: At This Summer School, Those Who Teach, Learn
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y.  While the children of this upscale suburb go to camp or travel abroad, many of their teachers are spending summer vacation in school, taking students seats.

title: Whales Lower-Pitch Sound Has Experts Guessing
description: The song of the blue whale, one of the eeriest sounds in the ocean, has mysteriously grown deeper.

title: J. Murdoch Ritchie, 83, Yale Biophysicist, Is Dead
description: J. Murdoch Ritchie, a biophysicist at Yale who used a potent neurotoxin derived from shellfish to help trace the way nerve cells conduct electrical impulses and famously asked the Central Intelligence Agency to share its supply of the poison with scientists, died on July 9 in Hamden, Conn. He was 83.

title: Report Faults Aides in Hiring at Justice Dept.
description: Senior aides to former Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales broke Civil Service laws by using politics to guide their hiring decisions, picking less-qualified applicants for important nonpolitical positions, slowing the hiring process at critical times and damaging the departments credibility, an internal report concluded on Monday.

title: Concern About a Light Suspension for Dutrow
description: Representative Bobby L. Rush, chairman of the congressional subcommittee that took horse racing to task for its lax policies regarding performance-enhancing drugs during hearings last month, sent a letter Monday to the Kentucky Horse Racing Authority asking why the trainer Rick Dutrow Jr. was given only a 15-day suspension for a positive test on one of his horses when its rules seem to call for a stiffer penalty.

title: Rough Night for Mussina Is Even Worse for Yanks
description: If the Yankees could have simply showed off the new guys on Monday, a capacity crowd might have left Yankee Stadium happy. Outfielder Xavier Nady homered for his first hit in pinstripes, and Dmaso Marte pitched a shutout inning.

title: Climate Experts Tussle Over Details. Public Gets Whiplash.
description: When science is testing new ideas, the result is often a two-papers-forward-one-paper-back intellectual tussle among competing research teams.

title: Unidentified Flying Threats
description: London

title: Pacific Region May Show the Future of Coral Reefs in More Acidic Oceans
description: The gradual acidification of the oceans through increasing absorption of atmospheric carbon dioxide is thought to be potentially bad news for coral reefs. As seawater pH falls, the saturation level of carbonate ions in the water also declines. Since reefs are made up of calcium carbonate (from coral skeletons and other sources) they should be slower to form and faster to fall apart.

title: Reforming Clemency
description: To the Editor:

title: Eye of the Beholder (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: China Emerges as Major Player in Global Trade Talks
description: GENEVA  As seven years of global trade talks approach another climax, China is emerging as a central player  and coming under heavy criticism from the United States and others for its tactics.

title: Defending a Congressman
description: To the Editor:

title: Chance of an Obama-Clinton Ticket Is Seen as Increasingly Unlikely
description: WASHINGTON  When Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton abandoned her bid for the presidency and endorsed Senator Barack Obama in June, she made clear that she was interested in becoming his running mate, and Mr. Obama and his associates signaled respectfully that she would get full consideration.

title: Mirror, Mirror (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Syrians See an Economic Side to Peace
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  Like most Syrians, Samer Zayat has no love for Israel. He was a little uneasy when Syria announced in late May that it was holding indirect talks on a peace settlement with its old nemesis.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about the budding industry to turn waste products into motor fuels misspelled the name of a New Hampshire company that aims to turn crop waste into ethanol. It is Mascoma, not Macoma.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: International

title: Lottery Numbers
Breaking a Contract Not Unusual in Europe
description: Joseph S. Blatters comment several weeks ago that one of the sports top players was shackled as a modern-day slave drew mostly rebukes from around the world. The pronouncement by Blatter, the president of FIFA, came as the European bazaar for players swirled nonstop with a new season approaching.

title: New 'Tristan' From Bayreuth
description: A new production of Wagners Tristan und Isolde will be directed by his great-granddaughter at the Bayreuth Festival in 2015, Agence France-Presse reported. The Society of Friends of Bayreuth announced that Katharina Wagner, 30, would direct the new production, which is scheduled to be conducted by Christian Thielemann. Ms. Wagners father, Wolfgang Wagner, who has led the festival for 57 years, is scheduled to step down at the end of August. Ms. Wagners production of Die Meistersinger von Nrnberg also was the first live transmission of a performance from the Festspielhaus theater in Bayreuth on Sunday. The public screening attracted about 38,000 people. The performance was also broadcast live on the Internet for the first time.

title: No Longer Young, Nick at Nite Plans to Show It Can Be Nimble
description: Nickelodeon, the premier cable channel for children, is so old that many of its original viewers have children of their own. The 29-year-old network is now trying to produce programs that the first generation of Nickelodeon parents can watch with their children.

title: Ex-Manager at Siemens Is Convicted in Bribe Case
description: FRANKFURT  A German court convicted a former manager at the engineering and electronics company Siemens of misuse of funds on Monday in the first verdict stemming from a bribery scandal at the company.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A television review on July 12 about Foyles War, part of Masterpiece Mystery! on PBS, misspelled the surname of the detective played by Helen Mirren in Prime Suspect, to whom Detective Christopher Foyle of Foyles War was compared. She is Jane Tennison, not Tennyson.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about the IntercontinentalExchange misstated part of the name of the regulator of the companys London futures market. It is the Financial Services Authority, not the Financial Securities Authority.

title: For a French Cyclist, the Long Ride Has Not Stopped

title: The Underappreciated Omelet
description: A vegetable omelet is one of the most satisfying meals I can think of, particularly when youre dining alone or with just one other person. Yet though theyre incredibly easy to make and the ingredients are usually at hand, many of us hardly ever think of having omelets for dinner. Perhaps thats because eggs have gotten such a bad rap: they do contain dietary cholesterol. But scientific research has made it abundantly clear that saturated fat -- mostly from full-fat dairy products and red meat -- is really the villain behind our own rising blood cholesterol levels. And eggs have their nutritional virtues. High in protein and low in calories, theyre are a good source of vitamins B12 and E, riboflavin, folate and iron.

Mr. Aronofsky, who directed Requiem for a Dream and The Fountain, recently finished work on The Wrestler, which stars Mickey Rourke and Marisa Tomei. Mr. Self, whose screenplay credits include Road to Perdition, also wrote the coming Wolf Man for Universal. The original RoboCop (1987), which starred Peter Weller as a corruption-fighting cyborg cop in Detroit, was directed by Paul Verhoeven and written by Michael Miner and Edward Neumeier. title: The Lede: A Year After the Bridge Disaster
description: (Photo: Construction crews prepared for the final pour of concrete to connect the I-35W bridge project's central spans over the Mississippi River last week in Minneapolis, Minn. (Photo: Sherri LaRose-Chiglo/St. Paul Pioneer Press, via Associated Press) )   (Photo: The entire span of the Interstate 35-W bridge over the Mississippi River collapsed last Aug. 1, a disaster later traced to a design flaw. (Photo: Photo: Allen Brisson-Smith for The New York Times))   An eerie thing happened a few days ahead of the one-year anniversary of the Minnesota bridge collapse on Aug. 1. Instead of the calendar announcing that it was time to look back on the disaster last summer that left 13 people dead, a 1,200-pound chunk of concrete did the honors:  [A] 6-foot-by-9-foot section fell Saturday from the Maryland Avenue bridge onto two vehicles, choking traffic on Interstate 35E for more than eight hours as crews inspected the overpass that shuttles nearly 140,000 motorists per day through downtown St. Paul.  Luckily, no one was hurt, and the overpass itself was quickly declared "structurally safe," The Associated Press reported.   Besides that crumbling concrete in Minnesota, though, there was another bracing moment in the run-up to the anniversary.  On Monday, the American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials unleashed all the shock and awe it could muster in an effort to foster a "national commitment to increasing bridge investment" aimed at preventing another collapse, whether because of deterioration and deferred maintenance or because of obsolete or flawed design, as was found to be the case with the I-35W bridge.   (Photo: Ed Rendell, the governor of Pennsylvania, leading a news conference beneath a once-dangerous bridge on Monday. (Photo: American Association of State Highway and Transportation Officials))   To make its point, a news conference headlined by Gov. Edward G. Rendell of Pennsylvania was held -- where else? -- under a bridge, one in north Philadelphia that was closed for two days in March so that a widening crack could be mended. (It, too, is structurally sound, they say.)  "The current generation of baby boomer bridges are showing their age, and they're going to require significant investment," Pete Rahn, the association's president and director of the Missouri Department of Transportation, said at the news conference. "We must act now."  Governor Rendell added his own take on the urgent message: "We simply can't wait. We need solutions, not rhetoric."  A report released by the association raised further alarms in its fine print: One out of every four bridges now in use in the United States is classified as "structurally deficient," as the I-35W bridge was before it failed. That's about 152,000 bridges, a number that will only rise, according to the report:  Within the next 15 years almost half of the nation's bridges will exceed 50 years of age, exceeding the life span for which they were designed. Even now, one in five are over 50.  Fixing every bridge flagged with structural issues would cost about $140 billion, the report said -- or nearly double the $80 billion that Governor Rendell said is spent annually on all kinds of transportation infrastructure around the country.  Would the huge expense be worth it? To answer that requires a definition of the term "structurally deficient," which Matthew Wald, who covers transportation issues for The New York Times, provided last year:  It means, engineers say, that the bridge can no longer carry the load it was intended to support. In many cases this means nothing, because bridges are generally designed for higher loads than the traffic imposes. In some cases, transportation officials put up signs warning away heavy trucks, or even close lanes to limit the number of vehicles.  But bridge collapses are extremely rare, and when one occurs, it is usually because a barge or truck has hit its supports.  Another part of the answer, of course, depends on what else the country may need the money for. And next year's budget priorities will be decided at a time of record federal deficits nearing a half-trillion dollars, the White House predicted on Monday. "The bleak outlook for the budget will crimp the ability of the next president to carry out ambitious spending plans," The New York Times reported.  There was more bad bridge-repair news on the front page of The Wall Street Journal on Monday. The Transportation Department's Highway Trust Fund is straining as Americans cut back on driving because of the slowing economy and rising gasoline prices, the paper reported. Taxes on motor fuel provide the money earmarked for the fund, a setup that had worked well for decades.   Now, the Transportation Department is trying to build support for a cash infusion, a goal already on the radar of Congress. Last week, a bill that would inject $8 billion of general tax money into the fund cleared the House despite sharp objections from the White House, which cited the mounting budget deficit among other problems. From Congressional Quarterly:  "This bill is both a gimmick and a dangerous precedent that shifts costs from users to taxpayers at large," the White House said. "Moreover, the measure would unnecessarily increase the deficit and would place any hope of future, responsible constraints on highway spending in jeopardy."   A Republican supporter of the bill, John Mica of Florida, was just as sharp in characterizing the situation he was trying to address. "The highway trust fund is basically busted," Mr. Mica told The Associated Press. "This is a national crisis."  The bill passed by a "veto-proof" margin -- 387 to 37 -- in the House, but has yet to reach a vote in the Senate. If the bill becomes law despite the president's opposition, the United States will be taking a step in the right direction for the bridge-repair advocates. But their $140 billion goal will still be many steps away on this particular anniversary.  An earlier version of this post incorrectly referred to Ed Rendell in a caption as the "former" governor of Pennsylvania; he remains in office.
