title: Windows Down to Save Fuel?
description: In his July 29 Science Times article "10 Things to Scratch From Your Worry List," John Tierney urged readers not to waste the summer consumed by guilt about their cars' supposed "planet-destroying A/C," because an Edmunds.com report had concluded that "the aerodynamic drag from opening the windows cancels out any fuel savings from turning off the air-conditioner."  Mr. Tierney is on solid ground: Edmunds, a site that offers car-buying guidance, and Consumer Reports did not see much of a fuel-economy impact of either running the air or rolling down the windows in separate 2005 tests.   But like many controversies of this type, the windows-vs.-air-conditioning question refuses to die. There are many opinions, some with scientific pedigrees.   Having an environmental perspective may affect your thinking here. The online Grist magazine clearly doesn't like auto air-conditioning very much, and Umbra Fisk, a columnist, concludes that "rolling down windows wins the efficiency contest hands down." And that's because "The physical weight of the air-conditioner adds to the drag of the car, and running it takes power from the engine; both reduce your gas mileage  So all in all it would be best to not even have A/C in your car."  She'd get an argument from the Society of Automotive Engineers, which in a 2004 test was not particularly friendly to the A/C-off crowd, concluding that rolling down the windows can have "a significant real impact on fuel consumption." The size of the effect depends to some extent on temperature, vehicle speed, wind velocity and direction and is relatively larger for lower-drag vehicles like sedans than for S.U.V.'s, the group said.   But the Energy Department, in its online fuel economy tips, advises motorists to "turn off the air-conditioner and roll your windows down" at slow speeds, when there will be less aerodynamic drag.  That's the basic message from Slate, too. "The rule of thumb is to keep the windows down while on city streets, then resort to air-conditioning when you hit the highway," said a July 2008 "Green Lantern" column. "Every car has a speed at which rolled-down windows cause so much drag as to decrease fuel economy more than a switched-on A/C. As you might expect, however, that milestone speed varies widely from car to car  and in some cases, it may be well north of posted speed limits."  In fact, driving with the windows down at highway speeds will cost you 9 cents a gallon, or more than $70 a year in a 15-gallon car that is filled up once a week, warns Dailyfueleconomytip.com.   And so, like the Kennedy assassination, the windows-vs.-A/C question defies any attempt to lay it to rest. Mr. Tierney also said we shouldn't worry about "carcinogenic cellphones," because, as he points out, there's no definitive scientific link. But that didn't stop the director of the University of Pittsburgh Cancer Institute from issuing a warning about that very subject just last week.  Jim Motavalli will be posting regularly about fuel economy, green cars and alternative fuels. He is the author of "Forward Drive: The Race to Build 'Clean' Cars for the Future," among other books. He is also the executive editor of New Mass Media newspapers, a contributor to E/The Environmental Magazine and a radio host on WPKN-FM in Connecticut.  Recent posts:  Hummer for Sale ... Highly Negotiable  Moving Chryslers With Cheap Gas

title: Royals Have Something to Cheer About
description: There is a buzz coming from Kansas City that even a -74 run differential and a record of 50-59 can't seem to suppress. On a team with question marks across the diamond, they have a true star in the making and now the clock is ticking to see if they can build a team around him in time to put him to good use.  Joakim Soria, the team's 24-year-old closer, has pitched only 117 innings at the major league level yet has 1 2/3 shutout innings in an All-Star game and has earned the controversial nickname "The Mexicutioner." Some have questioned how appropriate the nickname is, but Soria, a native of Monclova, Mexico is a fan of it and so are Royals fans who have been snapping up Mexicutioner t-shirts.  (Photo: Joakim Soria has 29 saves and a 1.47 E.R.A. for the Royals. (Orlin Wagner/Associated Press))   To get the scoop on the closer who allows 0.69 baserunners per inning and sports a 1.47 earned-run average, I felt it would be best to reach out to the three writers who most closely follow the Royals to get their take on Soria, his nickname and his future.  Each writer was sent the same five questions and here are their replies:  1. On a scale of 1-10, how frustrating is it to have an exciting closer on a team that doesn't win very often?  Joe Posnanski Columnist for The Kansas City Star Well, the other guys may disagree with me ... but I find it to be the opposite of frustrating. For years, the Royals were lousy and they had terrible closers, and the way I observed things that seemed much more frustrating. In those days, the Royals could lose about 25 different ways. With a great closer, the possibilities have dwindled by one or two. In Kansas City, you are thankful for small things.    Rob Neyer Columnist for ESPN.com and Royals fan Frustration Number: 2. When it comes to the Royals, I learned a long time ago to take my small pleasures wherever I might find them. I still recall single, impressive-but-meaningless Mike MacDougal strikeouts from five years ago.  Rany Jazayerli Author of the Royals blog RanyontheRoyals.com, Royals fan and dermatologist I'd say about a 3. It's frustrating to see any great player wasted on a bad team, but I'd much rather have a bad team redeemed by a great closer than a great team undermined by a bad closer (see also Indians, Cleveland.) You have to understand, from 1996 to 2005 the Royals had the worst record in one-run games over a ten-year stretch in major league history. Soria is the first closer we've had in a dozen years who doesn't give me ulcers in the ninth inning. It's frustrating that he's on pace to throw about 70 innings, which is a criminal waste of resources. But the fact that I could go to bed before last night's west coast game was over and sleep easy - that's a nice feeling. I almost forgot what that felt like.  2. What are your thoughts on the Mexicutioner nickname and the t-shirts that celebrate it (especially considering its genesis on Rany's blog)?  Posnanski I like the name, though I must say that it has a cottage industry in town to take credit for it. That part's annoying, especially because it does seem that Rany came up with it. In any case, the name is fun.  Neyer I'm thrilled for Rany's blog, but I'm not wild about the nickname's undertones (even though Soria supposedly doesn't mind at all).  Jazayerli I think I'm more in shock than anything else, that a nickname that started on my blog has become the industry standard inside of two months. All credit for that has to go to Bob Dutton, who inserted the nickname into his game recaps at every opportunity until the name caught on. The only concern I'd have with the Mexicutioner is if Soria was offended by the name, but he's evidently not. The t-shirts are overtly commercial, but the design is pretty cool.  3. If given the choice of Dan Quisenberry, Joakim Soria or Roberto Hernandez, who would you have close?  Posnanski Tough call. As a reporter, I must say that Roberto Hernandez was one of the most stand-up guys I have ever been around. No matter what happened during the game -- and it was often bad -- he was always there at his locker with a beer at his feet, and he took the blame.  As a baseball fan, I love watching Joakim Soria pitch. Love it. He seems impossible to rattle, he throws every pitch for strikes, he has that amazing curveball. He's the most fun closer the Royals have ever had, with the possible exception of Al Hrabosky.  But from the heart, it's Quiz. He is, in my mind, the most underrated closer in baseball history. He probably should have won two Cy Young awards. His Hall of Fame case is every bit as good, and in some ways better, than Bruce Sutter's. And yet Sutter is in the Hall and Quiz didn't get enough votes to even stay on the ballot.  Neyer That's easy. Quiz, because he could give you two or three innings rather than just one. But you left out Jeff Montgomery, who's the second-greatest reliever in franchise history.  Jazayerli Quisenberry, for the innings, as well as the panache of having a closer who throws 83 with a tailwind. Although if I can force the opposing team to use Roberto Hernandez as their closer, it's a tough call.  4. In his blog a while back, Buster Olney said Soria has a demeanor similar to Mariano Rivera. With his new nickname, is a fist-pumping lesson something he would benefit from?  Posnanski The amazing thing is that from the first day he pitched in Kansas City, Soria has resembled Rivera. They have similar body types, their set up is almost identical, and so on. I don't think Soria needs a fist pump. I do wish that when he came in the Royals would play Van Morrison's "Gloria" and have people spell "S-O-R-I-A" as he walks to the mound. But nobody listens to me.  Neyer The nickname's plenty.  Jazayerli What makes the Mexicutioner nickname work is that it fits Soria's personality - he's lethally efficient, but he's not emotional about it. It's nothing personal; it's just business. If he started acting like Jonathan Papelbon on the mound, I'd check him for drugs.  5. How likely is it that the Royals will build a contending team in time to benefit from Soria's success?  Posnanski It's the million dollar question. The Royals seem to me to finally be showing some signs of life, especially with their pitching. But they aren't close right now.  Neyer The Royals have Soria locked up through 2014! Assuming they exercise all the options (which of course they won't do if he's not healthy and pitching effectively). A lot could happen between now and then. I suspect they'll contend, if marginally, at some point between now and 2014. But I'm disheartened by the Royals' almost complete lack of good hitters in their farm system.  Jazayerli The Royals have options on his contract through 2014. There's always a chance he'll get hurt between now and then, but at some point in the next six seasons the Royals have to get their act in gear. Don't they? (Rob, don't answer that.)

title: Royals Have Something to Cheer About
description: There is a buzz coming from Kansas City that even a -74 run differential and a record of 50-59 cant seem to suppress. On a team with question marks across the diamond, they have a true star in the making and now the clock is ticking to see if they can build a team around him in time to put him to good use.

title: Dodging Witches and Wild Boar in Germany
description: (Photo: A pine forest in the Harz Mountains.)  Deep in the forests of Germany's Harz Mountains, twilight is a time of magic. The light turns gray and ambient, and the colors  the green of moss, the brassy gold of pine needles, the violet of the wild blueberry bushes  pop out against the tall, brown, branchless trunks of pine trees. There's a stillness. The daytime hikers have returned to their villages, and the nocturnal animals have not yet woken. This is when you can almost believe the legends about Harz  that witches fly to the 3,747-foot-tall peak of Brocken, the tallest mountain in northern Germany, and that a strange creature called the Brocken Spectre patrols the misty trails.  But when you are lost in the Harz, having hiked  as I had  12 miles through thick pine forests and up 1,000-foot peaks, twilight can be disorienting, terrifying. The old, overgrown logging trail I was following didn't correspond to any on my topographical map, and though I could see the slanted red roofs and half-timbered facades of a distant village through a break in the trees, I had no guarantee this path would ever lead there.   Also, I was hearing things. A long, unearthly moan from the valley. The heavy crunch of a large mammal struggling through forest. And then, in the tricky light of evening, I saw the black haunches of what looked like a hefty wild boar bounding into the woods. Witches I could handle; wild animals, not so much. I had plenty of water, a flashlight, warm clothes, a knife, a hunk of bread, some cheese and four bars on my cellphone, and yet I was scared. I had never felt more alone.  Video Which was, after all, exactly why I'd come to the Harz, a national park almost smack in the middle of Germany that straddles the old East-West divide. After 10 weeks of interacting with strangers, making new friends, navigating Old Towns, inspecting fine restaurants and evaluating European civilization at the dawn of the third millennium, I'd had enough of, well, civilization itself.   The Harz Mountains offered the perfect escape: 860 square miles of hills, forests, lakes and rivers, with folksy villages nestled in the valleys where I could find soft, inexpensive beds every night at the ubiquitous pensions. By day, I'd embrace nature on foot; by night, I hoped, I'd find fellowship with other wanderers.  Better still, I'd be following in the bootsteps of Johann Wolfgang von Goethe and Heinrich Heine, who visited in the late 18th and early 19th centuries and wrote about the area  Goethe by sending his Faust to a celebration of witches atop the Brocken, Heine with a travelogue called "The Harz Journey."  From Gdansk, I took a series of four Polish and German trains (85.85 euros, or about $136, at $1.58 to the euro) to Quedlinburg, a medieval German city I planned to use as my base. As in most 1,200-year-old cities, Quedlinburg has both an Old Town and a New Town  only here the latter dates not from the modern era but from the early 12th century. No surprise that this compact tangle of cobblestones, half-timbered houses and sunlit market squares  which survived World War II unscathed  is a Unesco World Heritage Site.  But I only stayed in Quedlinburg long enough for a 17.70-euro schnitzel dinner at the tree-shaded Restaurant Benedikt (Marktkirchhof 18, 49-3946-526652) and a night at the suburban Pension Weingart (Friedrich-Jahn-Strasse 27, 49-3946-8617, www.pension-weingart.de; single, 35 euros).   In the morning, I left most of my belongings  at the Theophano Hotel (Markt 13/14, 49-3946-96300, www.hoteltheophano.de), pricey at 69 euros a night but the only affordable hotel with Internet access, then filled my backpack with supplies  maps and water-purification tablets, 17 euros from Bergwerk (Plkenstrasse 51, 49-3946-915085, www.bergwerk-quedlinburg.de); bread, cheese, sausage and beer, about 7 euros from local shops  and caught the 2-euro, 20-minute train to Thale.  Thale sits at the edge of the Harz, where the Bode River spills out from a steep, green-swathed gorge that's sometimes referred to as the Grand Canyon of Germany. That nickname makes it sound challenging  but it's not. Moms in pumps, dads with expensive cameras, bored-looking teenagers and even some truly elderly people were marching up the wide gravel-dirt-and-rock path that ran alongside the river. At times, it grew steep, and with 30 pounds on my back I was certainly sweating. But compared with my camping expedition to the Beartooth-Absaroka Wilderness in Montana last summer, this seven-and-a-half-mile stretch of picture-perfect forest, backed by the roar of the river, was, as they say, a walk in the park.  This stage ended at Treseburg, where I got my first, and possibly best, taste of a Harz village. This was a small place, just a few clusters of dark-wood houses hugging a couple of roads near the river. A church, a bridge, some kids wading in the water. A museum devoted to weathervanes. A mural on the side of a house showed Treseburg as it was in the 11th century, a walled town high on a hill. Another house was a vacation rental for two to four people, at 12.50 euros a person. I drank a 2.30-euro beer at a cafe and marched on.  After Treseburg, things got hairier. A sign warned of moose. The trail became steep, and was intercut with roads made for logging trucks. There was no one else around. The afternoon sun bore down, and I stopped frequently to glug my purified water.   (Photo: Wild raspberries abound on trails through the Harz. )  Once, I stopped and looked to my right. There, along the bank of a small creek, were raspberry bushes. I removed my hat and started filling it with the ripe, red fruit, and only when I was stuffing myself with my discovery did I wonder: How did I know to stop there? Pure chance? A subconscious sense of smell? Was I getting close to nature already, or was this some witch's trick?   [Note added Aug. 8, 2008: I later learned from reader comments that wild berries in central Europe can harbor the fuchsbandwurm, a potentially deadly parasite. Those raspberries and blueberries may be tempting, but should be avoidedor harvested and turned into safe, delicious jam.]  (Photo: A moose warning sign outside Altenbrak.)  The sky was starting to darken when I arrived in Altenbrak, three miles farther on. I needed a place to sleep and eat, and luckily, there were pensions everywhere, tidy houses bearing the sign "zimmer frei" room available. Unluckily, despite the claims of the signs, the zimmers that evening were mostly nicht frei  not free  and it wasn't until I reached the Pension & Restaurant Zum Harzer Jodlermeister (Sankt Ritter 26A, 49-39-45-65680, www.zum-harzer-jodlermeister.de) that I found a room that was both available and affordable (after I bargained them down to 35 euros from 45).   My zimmer was small and clean, with a soft single bed, a minibar, a slanted roof and a spacious bathroom where I showered off the day's sweat. On the patio cafe, I drank a big pilsner, ate a massive platter of schnitzel and pasta with a mushroom cream sauce, and finished with apple strudel and vanilla ice cream  20.60 euros in all, but I needed the calories. By 10 p.m., I was dead asleep.  (Photo: An antique dollhouse.)  The next three days unspooled pretty much the same way. A big breakfast (bread rolls with butter and jam or cold cuts, hard-boiled eggs, yogurt, apples), a look around town (the antique dollhouse collection at Altenbrak's Heimatmuseum, the waterfall outside Knigshtte) and then off I'd tramp into the wilderness.   The farther I got from Thale, the wilder the land became. Often, I'd follow a trail for miles along a stream, stepping carefully over fallen logs and around mud puddles, and then, in an instant, find myself in a Narnia-like wood, carpeted with roots and electric-green moss, the only sounds the birds and a roaring wind. Then I'd take a few more steps and learn that the wind came from cars racing along a small highway.  Often, though, I was alone for what felt like hours, wandering down paths that even the loggers had long abandoned. At these times, I didn't care if I'd made wrong turns, or if the signs pointing me to Elend or Trageburg had utterly vanished. This was nature, oblivious to my presence but providing me with such enjoyment: the bees and butterflies in the wildflowers, the frigid water from the streams, the raspberries and, in the higher altitudes, the blueberries.  But there was a fine line between solitude and loneliness, and more than once I wanted nothing more than to be back in Brooklyn, cooking dinner for my pregnant wife, Jean. But it was also when I was most isolated that I was most happy to run into people. Near the shore of the Rappbodetalsperre lake, searching in vain for a picturesque spot to eat lunch, I found an old man on a motorcycle, clearing a field in which he and his friends planned to hunt wild boars for sport. Later, after I'd passed a fruitless two hours looking for a bridge across the lake, I happened upon a couple from Bremen  she in Fila polo shirt, he in wraparound sunglasses  who couldn't remember where they'd parked their convertible.  "I know where it is," the man clarified. "I just don't know how to get back there."  With every step, I also discovered something about myself: I can walk  and walk and walk and walk. At the end of a 20-mile day, my feet would be sore, and my shoulders would ache from the weight of my pack. But after a night in the super-soft beds of Knigshutte's Pension Knigshof (Friedensstrasse 22, 49-3945-452146; www.am-felsen.de; single, 35 euros), I'd be ready for another near-marathon. Four days and 50 miles later, only the little toe on my right foot was blistered.  If there was a challenge in my westward trek, it was finding food. I had expected to buy locally produced bread, cheeses and meats in every village, but often there were no bakers or butchers. (What do locals do for groceries? They drive.) Still, I found ways to fill my belly at noon. Three miles from Altenbrak, I stumbled on Stemberghaus, a museum devoted to charcoal (www.harzkoehlerei.de), once one of the Harz Mountains' main industries; the snack bar sold local beer (schwarz, of course) and bratwurst. I ate well.  (Photo: A rich blend of split yellow peas and bacon. )  And west of Elend  whose name means misery  I found Kukki's Erbsensuppe (www.kukki.de), a roadside stand where a man was ladling a thick stew of split yellow peas and bacon out of a mobile field kitchen (2.50 euros a bowl, with discounts for more than three bowls). This was perfect Harz food  rich, hearty, just what you need to climb a mountain, but it was also a reminder of Germany's recent past: Kukki, the boss, had opened shop 19 years ago, soon after the border  less than a mile to the west  had ceased to be.  In fact, it was quite easy to forget that this entire area was once a high-security zone, with troops patrolling the land-mine-ridden hills. Today, there's just a small monument marking the old point where east met west, along with a trail that follows what used to be the border. As I marched along it  uphill for two miles  I was glad I'd loaded up on erbsensuppe.  My ascent of the Brocken, however, was anticlimactic. The path was well-marked, though I could have just as easily followed the hundreds of tourists making the four-mile climb. Within two hours  with blueberry breaks  I reached the Brocken's plateau, where witches supposedly fly every April 30. I bought bratwurst and French fries from a kiosk, and knocked back a celebratory shot of Schierker-Feuerstein, a peppery, 70-proof tonic made in the nearby village of Schierke.   I admired the view  the plains stretching out north, the suddenly tiny hills I'd trekked through to the south  and then it was time to descend, not on foot but by the train that many of the Brocken's visitors had ridden up and would ride back down.  (Photo: The steam train.)  It was an old steam engine, built in the 1950s and lovingly maintained, and it dripped water and puffed smoke as trains of yore are supposed to. It swirled down around the Brocken, and coasted through the woods that I'd crossed with so many thousands of heavy steps. The smell of coal and steam, the hoot of the whistle and the inimitable chugga-chugga, the breeze from the wide-open windows  they made the 16-euro journey fun. Still, as 90 minutes rolled past without my sweating, I couldn't help thinking I should've walked.  Next stop: Amsterdam.

title: Obama Claims 'Wild Bill' Heritage in a Challenge to McCain
description: (Photo: Wild Bill Hickok (Photo courtesy Adams Museum)) SPRINGFIELD, Mo. -- Barack Obama, genealogical gunslinger?  The Democratic candidate today invoked a distant  possibly apocryphal  cousin, Wild Bill Hickok, and suggested that he and John McCain forget the dreary debate-about-where-they-will-debate and just strap on six-shooters and meet at 60 paces.  (Note to the literal minded: The candidate was joking. We think.)  "If Senator McCain wants a debate about taxes in this campaign, I'm ready," he told an audience here. "Wild Bill Hickok had his first duel in the town square here. And the family legend is that he is a distant cousin of mine."  Sensing a hike of the collective eyebrow in the audience, he quickly added: "I'm serious, I'm serious. This is part of the family legend. I don't know if it's true, but I'm going to research it."   Earlier in the campaign, Mr. Obama found out that he is a distant cousin to Mr. Cheney, a source of more than a few punchlines for the two of them. But Wild Bill Hickok was a new one.  Wild Bill lived in an era when a homicidally inclined fellow with an itchy trigger finger could become quickly famous. As it happens, Wild Bill fought his first quick-draw duel here in Springfield, shooting Davis Tutt outside a saloon, apparently over a gambling debt or a woman or both.  "I'm ready to duel John McCain on taxes," Mr. Obama said, smiling broadly. "Quick draw."  History, alas, also offers a caution or three for the aspiring duelist. The citizenry of Springfield was not enamored with Mr. Hickok plugging a citizen in plain daylight. Soon after, he lost a close election for marshal.  Eleven years later, the curtain dropped more definitively on his political career, as a gunslinger shot Wild Bill dead while playing poker at Saloon #10 in Deadwood.

title: Big Divide Found in Internet Access
description: New Yorkers are a diverse bunch, but when it comes to broadband connections at home, there are two distinct groups: The haves and the have-nots. According to a report released today by the citys Broadband Advisory Committee, 26 percent of low income households have broadband connections at home compared to 54 percent in moderate-to-high income households.

title: Richard Nixons Search for a New York Home
description: Updated, 4:55 p.m. | Blackballed by a blue-blooded Manhattan co-op, former President Richard M. Nixon never did take up Lewis Rudins offer to join the real estate moguls celebrity roster in his high-rise at 215 East 68th Street, or at any of what Mr. Rudin called a dozen fine apartment buildings on the East Side and a dozen on the West Side that his company owned and managed in New York in the 1970s.

title: Nixons Search for a New York Home
description: (Photo: Former President Richard M. Nixon and his wife, Pat, in 1990. (Photo: Associated Press))  (Photo: The sales brochure for the Nixon town house, at 142 East 65th Street, in 1979. See the PDF. ) Updated, 4:55 p.m. | Blackballed by a blue-blooded Manhattan co-op, former President Richard M. Nixon never did take up Lewis Rudin's offer to join the real estate mogul's celebrity roster in his high-rise at 215 East 68th Street, or at any of what Mr. Rudin called "a dozen fine apartment buildings on the East Side and a dozen on the West Side" that his company owned and managed in New York in the 1970s.  But Lester J. Tanner and his wife at the time, Marcella Tanner, did live there. And thereby hangs a tale, one that has escaped telling until now because, for one thing, the Tanners, who alone with the Nixons were privy to the story, never told it before.  It's a tale of how the disgraced former president, a Republican who was undone by his cover-up of the Watergate burglary and money-laundering scandal, found a refuge in Gotham. It's about how Mr. Nixon landed in the fancy town house once owned by the esteemed federal judge Billings Learned Hand, thanks to sympathetic Democrats -- sympathetic, that is, not to a widely despised political pariah but to a former chief executive of the United States shabbily treated by a city known for its hospitality to the downtrodden.   The story emerged after The New York Times published an article just last week, on July 21, about the Rudin Management Company's practice of offering precious rent-stabilized apartments or below-market deals in his buildings to well-connected friends, particularly public servants, past and present. David N. Dinkins, the former mayor, Howard Safir, a former police commissioner, and Thomas Von Essen, a former fire commissioner, are among the tenants in the 33-story luxury rental high-rise at 215 East 68th Street.  That prompted Mr. Tanner, 84, a trial lawyer with an eventful life of his own, to write with the following story.  Mr. Tanner related that in May 2006, on the occasion of a documentary film on the civic boosterism of Mr. Rudin, who died in 2001, Mr. Tanner reached out to Mr. Rudin's son, William, recalling how the elder Rudin had championed Mr. Nixon's efforts to become a New Yorker once again. (Before winning the White House in 1968, Mr. Nixon had lived in a 12-room apartment at 810 Fifth Avenue, where Nelson A. Rockefeller was a neighbor. Mr. Nixon sold the apartment for a reported $326,000.)  President Nixon announced his resignation on Aug. 8, 1974, and settled at Casa Pacifica in San Clemente, Calif. But within five years he was seeking to move back to New York, and on July 28, 1979, The Times broke the news that he had put down a deposit on a nine-room penthouse at 19 East 72nd Street, at Madison Avenue, that was selling for $750,000.  The seven-member co-op board informally approved the sale, only to backtrack days later after shareholders revolted, objecting that the Nixons would bring notoriety to the exclusive building, not to mention Secret Service disruptions. On Aug. 2, 1979, Mr. Nixon and his seller agreed to break their deal.  (Photo: Lewis Rudin, the real estate mogul, in 2000. (Photo: Bill Cunningham/The New York Times))  Enter Mr. Rudin. Furious at the picture it presented of "the worst type of bigotry," as he put it, the developer told The Times, "I'm ashamed as a New Yorker and I apologize to the Nixons." He offered the former president his choice of an apartment in any of two dozen buildings the Rudins owned and managed "and the Nixons are welcome in any of them if the space is available."  But the Nixons weren't interested in renting; they wanted to buy.  Mr. Tanner had also read of the Nixons' ignominy and, like Mr. Rudin, was appalled. Like Mr. Rudin, too, he and his wife were lifelong Democrats. Mr. Tanner had even been a delegate for Senator Robert F. Kennedy before his assassination in 1968.  As a G.I. in World War II, Mr. Tanner had been taken prisoner by the Germans and was being held in the Ziegenhein stalag in January 1945, when the Nazi commandant demanded at gunpoint to know which of the American soldiers were Jews. As. Mr. Tanner recalled it, their brave officer, Master Sgt. Roddie Edmonds, defied the camp commander, saying the Geneva Convention forbade the request, and Mr. Tanner and his fellow prisoners were spared, to be liberated shortly afterward.  In 1960, Mr. Tanner was instrumental in persuading the New York Stock Exchange to permit the listing of Mesabi Iron, its first noncorporation. Later, in 1992, Mr. Tanner represented an American Airlines executive, Barbara L. Sogg, in her gender-discrimination lawsuit against the airline.   At the time of Mr. Nixon's housing woes, the Tanners were living in a 5,000-square-foot, 12-room town house at 142 East 65th Street. The four-story, 20-foot-wide, 1871 building on a tree-lined block between Lexington and Third Avenues came with an impeccable pedigree. For about 60 years until his death in 1961, it had been the home of Judge Learned Hand, who was known for his wise jurisprudence, and who took epic walks from East 65th Street to the federal courthouse in Foley Square. Judge Learned Hand (Learned and Hand were family surnames) was also the jurist for whom Archibald Cox, the first Watergate special prosecutor, ordered fired by Mr. Nixon, had once served as a law clerk.  Mr. Tanner represented the Learned Hand estate in the sale of the house and got the opportunity to buy it himself from Edward Gudeman, an undersecretary of commerce in President John F. Kennedy's administration, for $320,000 in 1971.  Next door to the Tanners was David Rockefeller (in a double-wide town house of 40 feet), and over the garden wall on East 64th Street lived Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the historian and an assistant to Mr. Kennedy, the man who defeated Mr. Nixon in the 1960 presidential election.  As it happened, the Tanners were ready to downsize and had put the house on the market through Sotheby Parke Bernet International Realty Corporation, as the entity was known at the time. A glossy brochure titled "An Elegant East Side Townhouse" featured black and white photographs and promoted the property's six wood-burning fireplaces and proximity to Bloomingdale's, Bergdorf Goodman and Tiffany & Company. The asking price was $690,000. An Exxon oilman was ready to take it in a complex exchange of properties, structured to minimize taxes, that drove the selling price to $750,000, when Mr. Tanner read about Mr. Nixon's co-op debacle.  Agreeing with Mr. Rudin that their fellow New Yorkers had acted abominably, Mr. Tanner wrote the former president in California offering to sell him his house for the same $750,000. There was no board to nix the deal, Mr. Tanner stressed. And it would be done in confidence -- they were, after all, both lawyers and they could work it out between themselves.  But Mr. Nixon had not been idle. Moving quickly, he had already visited another co-op, on which he had put down a $92,000 deposit on a 12-room apartment at 817 Fifth Avenue, at 63rd Street, on sale for $925,000 -- marked down from the original $1 million asking price -- by Abe Hirschfeld, the quirky developer, parking-garage magnate, and, later, short-lived publisher of The New York Post. He had himself bought the apartment, covering the building's entire seventh floor, only two years earlier for $225,000.  Mr. Hirschfeld, who died in 2005, lost no time publicizing the deal, arranging for a reporter and photographer from New York Magazine to tour the apartment for the issue of Sept. 3, 1979. "Everyone wants to see the place where Nixon will be living," said the obliging Mr. Hirschfeld. The picture spread even featured a floor plan. The Secret Service, which was still guarding the former president, was horrified.  When Mr. Nixon got his letter, Mr. Tanner recalled, he responded quickly, telephoning himself.  "I'm coming in; I'm excited, I want to see the house," Mr. Tanner recalled Mr. Nixon saying.  But what about the Hirschfeld contract? Mr. Tanner asked.  Don't worry about that, he said Mr. Nixon replied. After all the publicity, the Secret Service would never permit him to live there.  But what about the $92,000 deposit? Mr. Tanner recalled persisting.  Mr. Nixon said he was ready to forfeit it, explaining, "I don't want any litigation."   "He desperately wanted to come to New York," Mr. Tanner said. "It was the place that had rehabilitated him after 1962." That was the year Mr. Nixon lost the election for the California governorship to Edmund G. (Pat) Brown and wrote his own, premature, political obituary, telling the press, "You won't have Nixon to kick around anymore."  Sure enough, a few days later in August 1979, on the Tanners' doorstep at 142 East 65th Street, stood three generations of Nixons: the former president and his wife, Pat; their eldest daughter, Tricia, who was then living on Fifth Avenue and 70th Street with her husband, Edward F. Cox; and Tricia's and Edward's baby son, Christopher.  Marcella Tanner remembers it well. She said Mr. Nixon appeared in the doorway with Christopher on his shoulders. "Not the way one thought of President Nixon," she said. Tricia was particularly enthralled, Mrs. Tanner remembered, repeating: "I love the house. It wraps its arms around you."  Pat Nixon, on the other hand, looked nervous, Mr. Tanner recalled, still bearing the scars of Watergate and incessantly chain-smoking.  Mr. Nixon was quickly at home, Mr. Tanner added, telling his hosts: "A town house in Manhattan is like oceanfront property. It never loses its value."  Mrs. Tanner ran to get her copy of Mr. Nixon's 1962 book, "Six Crises," and asked him to autograph it. He obliged, and the Nixons left.  Mr. Tanner drew up a sales contract while Mr. Nixon broke his contract with Mr. Hirschfeld. Dated Sept. 4, 1979 [pdf], it listed the seller as Marcella Tanner and the buyer as "Richard Nixon residing at La Casa Pacifica, San Clemente, California."  ("My residences have always been in my wives' names," Mr. Tanner explained. "I believe it makes for a happier marriage.")  Indeed, the Tanners were married for 39 years before their amicable divorce in 1988. He has since remarried.  Shortly before the closing, set for October in 1979, Mr. Tanner said he was awakened one midnight by a ringing phone and picked it up to hear Mr. Nixon's voice.  "Pat can't sleep," he heard Mr. Nixon say. "She's sure we'll be rejected."  "I told you not to worry," Mr. Tanner reassured him. "I don't need anybody's approval."  "I told her that," Mr. Nixon persisted. "She doesn't believe me."  He asked Mr. Tanner to speak to Mrs. Nixon and explain it to her once more.  There was one more hitch before the closing, Mr. Tanner recalled. Mr. Nixon was having trouble selling Casa Pacifica and needed the funds to buy the Tanners' town house. Mr. Nixon asked if the closing could be delayed.  Absolutely not, Mr. Tanner said.  Amazing, he recalled thinking. After all the funny money that changed hands during Watergate, Mr. Nixon was strapped for cash. He ended up, Mr. Tanner recalled, getting a loan from the Key Biscayne Bank of his friend Charles (Bebe) Rebozo, who had been drawn into the Watergate entanglements.  The sale went through, with The Times on Oct. 5, 1979, once again breaking the story of another Nixon home purchase in New York.  The neighbors had mixed emotions. "There goes the neighborhood," Mr. Schlesinger said, jokingly. Others, though, ripped out the flowers Mr. Tanner had planted, forcing him to hire guards to protect the house until the Nixons moved in.  The Tanners moved out, taking a room at the Harvard Club while they looked for an apartment, but they were having trouble finding one.  Now it was Mr. Tanner's turn to ask Mr. Nixon for a favor, and he called him in California. "Lew Rudin said he would give you any apartment," Mr. Tanner reminded the former president. Mr. Nixon should say he was buying the Tanners' house and maybe Mr. Rudin would offer the Tanners an apartment.  The next day Mr. Tanner heard from a surprised Mr. Rudin. Ron Ziegler, the former White House press secretary, had called with the request. But Mr. Rudin was skeptical. "I don't believe it," he told Mr. Tanner. Everyone knew the Nixons were buying the Hirschfeld apartment.  But Mr. Rudin was persuaded enough to invite Mr. Tanner to his office to examine floor plans. Mr. Tanner chose apartment 12L at 215 East 68th Street, one of the biggest in the building, a rent-stabilized three-bedroom, three-bath affair with a maid's room, large dining room, living room and foyer, at $1,800 a month.  Still, in the lease dated Jan. 1, 1980, the cautious Mr. Rudin inserted an unusual clause. It was only valid if the signing leaseholder actually sold his town house to Mr. Nixon.  William Rudin, Lew's son, said Wednesday that he recalled Mr. Tanner's 2006 letter detailing the elder Rudin's efforts to help Mr. Nixon find a home. "Mr Tanner, I'm sure remembers everything that happened," William Rudin said. "I'm sure it's a true story. That's who my father was. That's why he was Mister New York."  Postscript: Although Mr. Nixon presented the picture of a happy life in the town house in a long interview given to Julie Baumgold for the June 9, 1980, issue of New York Magazine, the Nixons lived at 142 East 65th Street, for fewer than three years. In 1981, they bought a million-dollar modern house in Saddle River, N.J. And in 1982 they sold the town house to the Syrian ambassador to the United Nations for about $2.5 million, according to Mr. Tanner. The Nixons used the same Sotheby's sale brochure Mr. Tanner had prepared. Only this time the headline had been changed from "Elegant" town house to "Historic." Mr. Nixon died on April 23, 1994, at age 81.  As for the Tanners, after their divorce, Mr. Tanner bought a co-op apartment at 860 Fifth Avenue, where he later served as chairman of the board and still lives with his second wife. Mrs. Tanner stayed at 215 East 68th St., although when the rent reached $2,600 a month about 1991, she traded down to a two-bedroom unit now going for under $3,000 a month.  "It was a favor to Nixon, not to us," she said. "But I'm very happy."

title: McCain: No New Taxes (Redux)
description: AURORA, Colo.  Senator John McCain, whose recent suggestion that an increase in the Social Security payroll tax would not be off the table infuriated some fiscal conservatives, sought to reassure people here Wednesday that he opposes tax increases.   "I want to look you in the eye: I will not raise your taxes nor support a tax increase,'' he said here Wednesday at a town-hall-style meeting at the Wagner Company, a Caterpillar dealer. "I will not do it.''   Mr. McCain has been attracting criticism from the right ever since he said that "nothing's off the table" when he was asked Sunday on ABC's "This Week With George Stephanopoulos" whether raising payroll taxes would be an option for Social Security.   Pat Toomey, the president of the Club for Growth, an influential anti-tax group, called the statement "shocking" and issued an open letter to Mr. McCain asking him to clarify his stance and to "reaffirm your commitment to eschew all tax increases." And an editorial in The Wall Street Journal  called Mr. McCain's statement a "blunder,'' and added that: "Such mistakes also help explain the continued lack of enthusiasm for Mr. McCain among many conservatives.''   Mr. McCain has resisted being drawn out in any detail on what he things should be done to shore up Social Security, except to call for convening a bipartisan group to fashion a solution. At his meeting Wednesday, he criticized his Democratic rival, Senator Barack Obama, for supporting raising the payroll tax on high earners.   "On Social Security, he wants to raise Social Security taxes,'' Mr. McCain said. "I am opposed to raising taxes on Social Security. I want to fix the system without raising taxes. That's a debate that we should have openly in good faith. But we need to sit down together, my friends. You expect us Republicans and Democrats to sit down and fix social security so that future generations of Americans can have the same benefits that present-day retirees have.''   He did not elaborate how he might preserve the same benefits for future generations without raising payroll taxes.   Mr. McCain kept up his criticism of Mr. Obama. "The bottom line is that Senator Obama's words, for their eloquence and passion, don't mean all that much,'' he said. "And that's the problem with Washington. It's not just the Bush administration and it's not just the Democratic Congress. It's that everyone in Washington says whatever it takes to get elected, or score the political points of the day.''

title: Hispanics and Catholic New York
description: Many people, if asked when Hispanics began to reshape the Catholic Church in New York City, would probably put the date around 1950, when Puerto Rican migrants began arriving in Manhattan in large numbers. But in fact, Hispanics had exerted a powerful influence on religion and society in New York more than a century earlier, an important insight that emerged from a panel discussion on Tuesday night at the Museum of the City of New York.

title: Hispanics and Catholic New York
description: (Photo: Father Flix Varela, a 19th-century social reformer in New York, was honored on a postage stamp in 1997. (Photo: United States Postal Service))   Many people, if asked when Hispanics began to reshape the Catholic Church in New York City, would probably put the date around 1950, when Puerto Rican migrants began arriving in Manhattan in large numbers. But in fact, Hispanics had exerted a powerful influence on religion and society in New York more than a century earlier, an important insight that emerged from a panel discussion on Tuesday night at the Museum of the City of New York.  The panel discussion -- part of an exhibition, "Catholics in New York, 1808-1946," that is on view through Dec. 31 -- was billed as a talk on Latinos and the future of Catholic New York. The most informative parts of the 90-minute discussion focused on little-known aspects of social, religious and urban history. Rafael Pi Roman, the host of WNET's "New York Voices," moderated the discussion.   Anthony M. Stevens-Arroyo, an emeritus professor of Puerto Rican and Latino Studies at Brooklyn College and a distinguished scholar at the City University of New York, spoke first and gave a thorough recap of Hispanic Catholic life in New York through World War II.   He gave a quick overview of the life of Father Flix Varela, the Cuban-born priest who fled Spain in 1823 after the king, Ferdinand VII, waged a campaign of repression, and settled in New York, by way of Baltimore and Philadelphia. Here, Professor Stevens-Arroyo said, Father Varela founded the Church of the Transfiguration, on Mott Street in what is now Chinatown -- "which as you recall is perilously close to what became Five Points," the notorious immigrant slum at the center of the film "Gangs of New York." Father Varela also got involved in the temperance movement.   In 1837, Father Varela became vicar general of the diocese of New York, but he was passed over for bishop in favor of John J. Hughes, who was elevated in 1842 and became the first archbishop of New York in 1850.   "John Hughes was Irish through and through, knew his people, knew the system, knew how to use the resources of the church to get more resources for the church," Professor Stevens-Arroyo said.  Archbishop Hughes helped finance the construction of St. Patrick's Cathedral by buying up the land around it, knowing that it would become much more valuable after the grand Gothic edifice was completed. The archbishop also founded a savings bank for immigrants, offering 3 percent interest while investing the bank's assets at returns of 6 to 8 percent.  Yet despite Archbishop Hughes's accomplishments, "the bond between the hierarchy and the faithful" was not widely felt outside of the ranks of Irish Catholics.  Most Latino immigrants in New York in the 19th century were exiles or merchants, and the first Catholic parish for them was founded in 1859; through a series of mergers it is now known as St. Peter-St. Paul-Our Lady of Pilar.  Among the more prominent Hispanics in the New York region in the 19th century were the Civil War general George G. Meade, who was born in Spain and was the Union commander at Gettsyburg; Joseph II, the deposted Bonapartist king of Spain; the revolutionary Jos Mart; and the Puerto Rican nationalists Ramn Betances and Eugenio Mara de Hostos.  Some of the Hispanics of the time worked as cigar rollers. "They would read, in a loud voice, from the best novels of the time," while doing their often-tedious jobs, Professor Stevens-Arroyo said, and in so doing were exposed to works of philosophy and nationalist liberation, disguised as novels.  It was a time, Professor Stevens-Arroyo said, when Italian, Slovak, Polish and Spanish-speaking immigrants had their own "national parishes," separately run and governed from the "territorial parishes" operated by the Irish-dominated church establishment. The "national parishes" were responsible for recruitment of their own priests and nuns; some of them competed for financing with the mainstream church.   Discrimination within the church was rife. Cardinal John McCloskey, the fifth bishop and second archbishop of New York, "told Polish people they didn't need a parish but a pig shanty," Professor Stevens-Arroyo said, while Archbishop Michael A. Corrigan, the McCloskey successor, told Mother Cabrini -- later the first American to be canonized -- that "the best thing she could do for Italians was to tell them to stay in their own land."   By the early 20th century, Catholic outreach to Hispanics had begun to improve a bit. Cardinal John M. Farley took part in a synod in Puerto Rico in 1917 and Catholic settlement houses for Hispanic immigrants began to emerge, including Casita Maria, in Harlem, which later moved to the Bronx.  Political power also began to shift in the neighborhood. As Professor Stevens-Arroyo noted, Vito A. Marcantonio, the liberal Congressman for the area who famously championed the rights of minorities and was known for his involvement in the American Labor Party, gave public support to Pedro Albizu Campos, the Puerto Rican nationalist who was jailed at one point for sedition.   (Photo: Cardinal Francis J. Spellman in 1964. (Photo: Edward Hausner/The New York Times)) A turning point, Professor Stevens-Arroyo said, was Cardinal Francis J. Spellman's decision, in 1939, to remove the diocesan priests from St. Cecilia's, a largely Puerto Rican parish in East Harlem that had been originally founded for German immigrants, and to replace them with a Redemptorist pastor.   Cardinal Spellman's decision, Professor Stevens-Arroyo said, had two reasons behind it. He had seen the work of the Redemptorists, a missionary order, during a cruise to Puerto Rico, and believed that they could effectively preach to the Puerto Rican population. In addition, Cardinal Spellman believed that the evangelization of Puerto Rican Catholics would help prevent the spread of Communism.   Msgr. Lorenzo Albacete, a distinguished Puerto Rican theologian, scientist and writer, spoke next. He spoke of the "special relationship" between New York City and Puerto Rico, and quipped, "I have aways felt New York City to be part of Puerto Rico."  He added, "It is here where our flag was designed, where 'Lamento Borincano' was first heard, where the terrible nostalgia of growing old without being able to return to San Juan was expressed."  Monsigor Albacete said that Spanish-speaking Catholics could reshape the faith in the same way that the confrontation of Roman Christianity and European invaders shaped the faith in the dark ages. "The future of the church on Earth is shaped by the encounter between human freedom, human history, and the attractive power of God's love and mercy," he said.  Sister Veronica Mendez, a longtime Puerto Rican activist in East Harlem and a member of the Sisters of Our Lady of Christian Doctrine, spoke next, offering three "snapshots" of her childhood. Her family left Puerto Rico for New York in 1944. She recalled being baptized at age 6 -- a very different tradition from Irish Catholics, who believed in baptism immediately after birth, lest the child die without being cleansed of original sin. For Puerto Ricans, the celebration involved in baptism was important.   Sister Veronica also recalled being uncertain about which Mass at St. Cecilia's to attend as a child: the English or the Spanish. "For a long time in New York, the Spanish church was the basement church," she said. "That was the way we celebrated Mass."  She recalled: "A third snapshot: I'm sitting in my Catholic school class and sister is teaching and she's teaching us the importance of the name of Jesus and how out of reverence, we bow our heads every time we hear the name of Jesus." The teacher then said, "'And did you know there are some people who have such little respect for the name of Jesus that they give it to their children?'"  As the audience laughed, Sister Veronica recalled, "I remember wishing the floor would open up and swallow me."  She pointed out that Jesus is a common name among Hispanics, and is not seen at all as inconsistent with the Catholic faith.   David Gonzalez, a metropolitan reporter and former foreign correspondent for The New York Times, traced the movement of Hispanic Catholics across the Bronx in the 1960s and 1970s -- often keeping just ahead of the fires that ravaged the borough. Mr. Gonzalez, who graduated from Cardinal Hayes High School before attending Yale and Columbia, recalled the deteriorating conditions that made the Bronx a notorious symbol of urban demise, but he also traced the involvement of Latino Catholics in the revival of the borough -- and of New York itself.  For example, there was Astin Jacobo, the unofficial mayor of Crotona, who died in 2002. Mr. Jacobo was the custodian of Mr. Gonzalez's grammar school but so much more. In 1983, Mr. Jacobo confronted Mayor Edward I. Koch, demanding improvements in basic city services like sanitation.   Barbara Gonzalez, the chairwoman of the Centro Altagracia de Fe y Justicia, a Catholic advocacy and social justice organization based in Washington Heights and Inwood, offered a strong testimonial of her faith.  "I'm excited, I'm encouraged, by the fervent passion that our young people are demonstrating," she said.   Along with New York history, one theme of the panel discussion was the impact of evangelical and Pentecostal Christianity on the Catholic Church in the United States. A study by the Pew Hispanic Center last year found that about one-third of all Catholics in the United States are now Latinos; that more than half of Hispanic Catholics identify themselves as charismatics; and that many of those who are joining evangelical churches are Catholic converts.

title: A Salmonella Smoking Gun
description: The governments investigation into the Salmonella outbreak that began as a mystery focused on tomatoes has turned up the smoking gun, or at least one of them. From The Associated Press:

title: A Salmonella 'Smoking Gun'
description: The government's investigation into the Salmonella outbreak that began as a mystery focused on tomatoes has turned up the "smoking gun," or at least one of them. From The Associated Press:  The salmonella strain linked to a nationwide outbreak has been found in irrigation water and a serrano pepper at a Mexican farm, federal health officials said Wednesday.   While serrano peppers have stood in the shadow of jalapeos for weeks as far as the inquiry goes, the Food and Drug Administration decided to issue a warning on both types of peppers on July 9, when officials seemed to shift their attention away from tomatoes.   Last week, the agency announced that it had traced the Salmonella strain to jalapeos grown in Mexico, though not at the same farm as the tainted irrigation water. There's no word on a third possible culprit: cilantro, an ingredient often found in salsas and other Mexican condiments that the 1,307 people in 43 states who were sickened seemed to have in common.   Even today, tomatoes have not been completely ruled out as a cause of outbreak, which looks to be of complicated origin. A health official quoted by Bloomberg News put today's serrano discovery in context:  "We have a smoking gun, it appears," said Lonnie J. King, an official with the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta, during the hearing. "It also appears likely that more than one food vehicle has been involved in this outbreak."  The latest break in the case emerged during a Congressional hearing concerning missteps in the investigation, "The Recent Salmonella Outbreak: Lessons Learned and Consequences." One of the lessons, though, was for lawmakers, not health officials: It's harder to shoot -- or at least criticize -- the messenger when they are carrying the best news so far in the inquiry.

title: Obama Ponders the Diner Menu
description: LEBANON, Mo. -- Never let it be said that Barack Obama is a slow learner. The Team Obama bus caravan was wandering around rural Missouri Wednesday and pulled into the Bell Restaurant (a diner, as defined by this New Yorker but who am I to argue with a Show Me Stater), which advertises itself as offering B.B.Q., Steak and Seafood.  The candidate, who is sparing in consumption of almost everything, and has taken grief in the press for not letting his waist expand as the campaign season progresses, wanders in and immediately and loudly announces:  "Well, I've had lunch, but I'm thinking maybe there is some pie."  (He and his daughters had a back-and-forth in their Access Hollywood interview about the only sweet he likes: pie.)  At the diner, he then drops that hankering for pie, and sets to the business of chatting up waitresses, signing napkins and shaking hands with the 11 paying customers. These are mostly retired men in caps nursing their fifth or sixth cups of coffee. They are not a verbose lot.  "How you guys doin'?" the candidate asks a table of four.  "Pretty good," one answers.  "What sort of work you do?" the candidate asks.  "Retired," says one. "Not much," says another.  O.K.   The candidate moves toward the kitchen, trailed by a beaming waitress or two. The food question hangs there. "Well, I should order something," he says, adding a caveat: "Now, I've had lunch."  He settles on fried chicken; in his telling, he's become a junk-food dog. "The healthy people, we'll give them the breasts," he tells the waitress. "I'll eat the wings."   Word now is out that a presidential candidate is in. People crowd by, cell phones held aloft. Darrel Martin, the stocky white-haired owner with a tight pompadour, pushes on through.  "I came up here doing 80 on the interstate, yes I did," he announces, looking with just a touch of disgust at four large cops standing next to him. "I knew every trooper with a radar gun would be here."  This is the Republican red belt of Missouri, but celebrity tends to trump all. Even the Republicans smile and worry about "going goofy" with the candidate.  As the candidate headed for the door, a bag of fried chicken under his arm, waitress Mary Anderson picks up the phone.  "Barack Obama was here," she tells the caller. "But now he's leaving. So that's what is going on at Bell's."

title: For Your Displeasure
For Your Displeasure
description: Ed Kilgore of The Democratic Strategist says Barack Obama is almost certain to "displease a significant number of people" when he picks his running mate: "If it's true, as the CW holds today, that Obama's pretty much down to a choice of Kaine, Evan Bayh, Joe Biden, or Kathleen Sebelius, there's not a name in that group who wouldn't displease a significant number of people."   Daniel Larison of The American Conservative says that Rasmussen Reports has turned up an unusual finding in some recent polls: "According to the three surveys, 18-29 year olds are now relatively less willing to support a black candidate than voters from other age groups. While resistance to supporting a black candidate has dropped in every other age group since February, and overall stands at just 8 percent, it remains basically unchanged among the youngest voters," Larison writes. He adds:     While older generations report slightly increased unwillingness among friends, family and co-workers (which is the pollster's way of trying to get around respondents who self-censor), approximately one-fifth (22%) of 18-29 year olds state their own unwillingness to vote for a black presidential candidate. When asked about the willingness of friends, family and co-workers, the figure for "no" rises to 31%, which is the largest percentage in any age group.

title: Hillary and Bill (Not That One) Together Again
description: After endorsing her former rival, Senator Barack Obama, during the primaries, New Mexico Gov. Bill Richardson is back in Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's corner, this time to help Mrs. Clinton retire her remaining campaign debt.  (Photo: Gov. Bill Richardson and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton at a Democratic presidential debate in November. (Photo: Jae C. Hong/Associated Press)) Mr. Richardson announced on Wednesday that he would be the host for two fund-raisers for the New York senator in New Mexico next month. The events will take place in Santa Fe and Albuquerque on Aug. 17.   Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Richardson, who was also a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination before dropping out of the race in January, will attend both fund-raisers.   Some Clinton supporters considered Mr. Richardson's endorsement of Mr. Obama a snub to Mrs. Clinton and former president Bill Clinton. The three had been longtime political allies, and Mr. Richardson served as energy secretary during the Clinton administration.  In a statement, Bill Burton, a spokesman for the Obama campaign, signaled his support for the fund-raisers as did Clinton spokeswoman Kathleen Strand.   "Senator Clinton is grateful for Governor Richardson's and Senator Obama's efforts to assist with retiring her campaign debt and she is looking forward to continuing to campaign for Senator Obama and help ensure victory for Democrats throughout the country this fall," Ms. Strand said.  But some of her backers have indicated that they are unsatisfied with the pace of the Obama campaign's fund-raising efforts on Mrs. Clinton's behalf. As of the end of June, Mrs. Clinton was still saddled with $12 million in unpaid bills from the primary season.

title: Google Energy Guru Pushes Congress to Insulate America
description: [UPDATE 7/31: See additional context on Googles own energy thirst below.] David M. Herszenhorn, who covers Congress, sent me a note from Washington today on an interesting hearing held to explore the role of efficiency in cutting Americans expensive energy appetite.

title: Google Gurus Plan to Cut Energy Use
description: [UPDATE 7/31: See additional context on Google's own energy thirst below.] David M. Herszenhorn, who covers Congress, sent me a note from Washington today on an interesting hearing held to explore the role of efficiency in cutting Americans' expensive energy appetite.   Here's David's report:   WASHINGTON - Dan Reicher, Google's guru of all things related to energy and the environment, came to Capitol Hill on Wednesday with some ideas on how to keep Earth from overheating and poor families from freezing this winter in the face of sky-high prices for heating oil.   A central proposal, laid out in testimony before the Joint Economic Committee, was a national program aimed at cutting heat and electricity bills in 10 million low-income homes over a decade. The existing federal "weatherization" program saw its Energy Department budget eliminated recently. The hearing was called "Efficiency: The Hidden Secret to Solving Our Energy Crisis."   Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York and chairman of the joint committee, said he planned to include the weatherization proposal in a bill later this year. "I am very interested in the low-income home weatherization program," he said. "And I'm going to put in some legislation to move it up."   Over in the main part of the Capitol, lawmakers have been locked in a bitter stalemate over energy policy, with Republicans pushing for increased oil exploration, including expanded offshore drilling. Democrats, meanwhile, insist that drilling should be limited to existing leases on federal lands. Both sides say efforts to produce energy from renewable sources should be vastly increased, but they disagree on how to do so.  Mr. Reicher offered an array of ideas to a mostly receptive panel of lawmakers. In addition to weatherizing 10 million homes for low-income Americans, which he said would cost about $2 billion annually, he also said Congress should establish a mechanism called the Energy Efficiency Resource Standard that would set efficiency resource targets for electricity and gas suppliers over a given period of time.  He also called for a national "renewable portfolio standard" to increase the amount of electricity produced by sources other than fossil fuels. Some two dozen states have a hodgepodge of such requirements now for their utilities. This issue has divided Congress deeply in recent years. Other proposals included a greater focus on boosting fuel efficiency, the improvement of electric cars and increased tax incentives for the construction of energy-efficient buildings.  Perhaps Mr. Reicher's most intriguing comment, though, was his observation on the role that information technology will play in helping solve the nation's energy problems. "The increasing interplay between energy hardware and information software -- and the corresponding rise of the Internet and the connectivity it brings -- adds to the potential to make and to use energy more productively," Mr. Reicher said. "From smart meters and smart appliances to smart homes and a smart grid, we are poised to significantly advance our ability to monitor and manage energy."  Presumably Google foresees a role in helping consumers or companies do this. It's already aggressively pursuing investments in what it calls "Renewable Energy Cheaper than Coal." Mr. Reicher directs climate and energy initiatives at Google.org, the company's philanthropic arm, which has been capitalized with more than $1 billion in Google stock to address the issues of climate change, global poverty and global health.  UPDATE, 7/31: Google, of course, is large and fast growing user of energy. The company has been building large data centers -- warehouse sized buildings with rows upon rows of computers that can deliver search results, YouTube videos, email and a growing array of digital goodies -- around the United States and the world. Google does not disclose its own energy use or carbon "footprint." (Yahoo does disclose its carbon dioxide emissions.)  Collectively, data centers accounted for 1.5 percent of all electricity used in the United States in 2006. Even though Google is believed to have one of the largest collections of data centers of any company, its energy use likely accounts for a small fraction of that total.  In his testimony, Mr. Reicher addressed the company's electricity appetite: "At Google we have been working to lower the cost and increase the deployment of renewable energy, and to accelerate the deployment of plug-in vehicles. We have also been working to increase our use of clean power and energy efficiency at Google data centers and offices in the U.S. and other countries. Together with other technology companies and organizations, Google launched the Climate Savers Computing Initiative last year to reduce the power consumption of computers and servers."

title: Ludacris Raps About Obama, Upsetting Many
description: (Photo: Ludacris (Photo: Mario Anzuoni/Reuters))   Ludacris has a crush on Obama, and all would be well today if he had created a song as inviting as some other musically-inclined supporters.   Instead, in the song, "Politics," he did what he does best when matched with a booming bassline -- rapping without regard for anyone who might be offended. (You can listen to it here).  Offended, as it turns out, is precisely how many people should feel, according to a wide range of commentators -- including Senator Obama's spokesman.   "This song is not only outrageously offensive to Senator Clinton, Reverend Jackson, Senator McCain, and President Bush," a spokesman, Bill Burton, said in a statement. "It is offensive to all of us who are trying to raise our children with the values we hold dear."  At a time in the presidential campaign when both sides stand accused of going too negative, Ludacris -- who once bragged in a song that he was "from the school of hard knocks, sneak peeks and low blows" -- most certainly did.   Senator Clinton was called "irrelevant" and also a nasty name common in hip-hop lyrics but not in the remarks of presidential candidates. Senator McCain was the recipient of something that could be a schoolyard joke or an especially repulsive malediction, depending on the audience: "McCain don't belong in any chair unless he's paralyzed."   President Bush was also declared irrelevant, as well as "the worst of all 43 presidents" and "mentally handicapped." Reverend Jackson got off relatively easy as a "slick" politician.   Of course, this is precisely the kind of performance that won Ludacris fans around the world, three Grammy awards and Hollywood appeal. It also earned him a place on Senator Obama's iPod, a detail reported in June that Ludacris bragged about in the song:  With a slot in the president's iPod, Obama shouted him Said I handle my biz and I'm one of his favorite rappers  He was referring to a Rolling Stone interview in which Mr. Obama mentioned Ludacris, Jay-Z and Russell Simmons as "great talents and great businessmen." He also said that "it would be nice if I could have my daughters listen to their music without me worrying that they were getting bad images of themselves."   Both points were reiterated today by Mr. Burton, "While Ludacris is a talented individual he should be ashamed of these lyrics." But the campaign was apparently referring to the misogyny and materialism, and not Ludacris' bold prediction that would suit it just fine: "The first black president is destined and it's meant to be."

title: Bad V.P. Picks
description: Dan Schnur was the national communications director for John McCain's presidential campaign in 2000. (Full biography.)  Correction Appended  As the short lists of potential running mates for John McCain and Barack Obama grow shorter, an intriguing but somewhat unexpected question has emerged: Who would be the worse selection? Mitt Romney or Tim Kaine?   Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, and Gov. Tim Kaine of Virginia seem to have emerged as among the most likely vice presidential choices for their party's nominees. But both men exacerbate the greatest weaknesses of Mr. McCain and Mr. Obama, respectively, rather than addressing them.   Conventional wisdom correctly suggests that Mr. McCain could benefit from a running mate who adds credibility on economic issues and excites the Republicans' conservative base. Mr. Romney's accomplishments in the private sector would be valuable in a discussion of jobs creation and economic growth, but he was attacked relentlessly in his campaign for Senate against Ted Kennedy for the layoffs and downsizing that occurred in companies he had acquired. At a time when voters are worried about their own job security, those same criticisms could pack greater punch this year.  Mr. Romney's ability to motivate the G.O.P. base is even more of an open question. While Mr. McCain is still trying to shore up his support among conservatives, there's no evidence that Mr. Romney, who lost those voters to John McCain and Mike Huckabee in the primaries, would help close the sale. Already, several religious conservative leaders have come forward warning that naming Mitt Romney would be counterproductive. Indeed, Mr. McCain can still rally these voters on his own by talking about national security, tax cuts and energy policy, or by scaring them about Barack Obama. But it's hard to see how Mr. Romney makes that rally any easier.  The attraction of Tim Kaine as Mr. Obama's running mate is demographic. Mr. Kaine is Catholic, speaks fluent Spanish and has successfully reached the working-class voters who eluded Mr. Obama in the primaries. But his resume is even thinner than Mr. Obama's. Indeed, Mr. Kaine's previous experience as a lieutenant governor and a mayor of Richmond does nothing to bolster Mr. Obama's credentials on national security or foreign policy. Mr. Obama may have helped himself in this area during his recent tour of the Middle East and Europe, but there are a number of Democratic Senators -- most notably Joe Biden of Delaware and Jack Reed of Rhode Island -- who can give him much more help in this area.   Both Mr. Romney's and Mr. Kaine's backers make the case for their selections by pointing to their ability to help in key swing states. Mr. McCain has targeted Michigan, where Mr. Romney's father was governor, and the Obama campaign is pouring resources into Virginia. But unless you count Al Gore in 1992 (which you shouldn't because Bill Clinton would have carried Tennessee no matter what), neither party's running mate has helped their ticket in a critically contested state since Lyndon Johnson helped John F. Kennedy carry Texas. And it's a good rule of politics to assume that when something doesn't happen for 48 years, it's not much of a rule.  Pundits and political backseat drivers point out that a vice presidential nominee rarely makes much difference to the voters one way or another. Both Mr. Romney and Mr. Kaine could end up having an impact -- just not the type that their would-be bosses want. Mr. McCain and Mr. Obama have correctly identified what they need in their running mates. Now all they have to do is find someone who actually fits the bill.  A previous version of this article misstated the dates when Tim Kaine served as mayor of Richmond. Mr. Kaine was mayor from 1998 to 2000, not "three years ago."

title: Once More, With (a Little Less) Feeling
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Senator John McCain waded once more Wednesday evening into the fraught question of whether he would consider raising payroll taxes to shore up Social Security.   Mr. McCain told donors at a fund-raiser here that "in any negotiation that I might have, when I go in my position will be that I am opposed to raising taxes.''   It was far less absolute than his insistence earlier in the day at a stop in Colorado that: "I want to look you in the eye: I will not raise your taxes nor support a tax increase.''    At the fund-raiser, Mr. McCain said: "I am opposed to raising taxes -- I am opposed to raising taxes. Senator Obama wants to raise your taxes. He wants to raise your taxes. And in any negotiation that I might have, when I go in my position will be that I am opposed to raising taxes. But we have to work together to save Social Security. This young man standing right in front of me  Social Security benefits won't be there for him when he retires. Is this right for us to lay on to the next generation of Americans the burden that we've imposed on them? No.''   Mr. McCain also criticized his rival, Senator Barack Obama, on Iraq, and noted that he had "no military experience whatsoever.''   "What puzzled me was when Senator Obama announced his policy concerning Iraq before he left, having not having been there in more than 900 days,'' he said. "And he got a briefing from General Petraeus and General Petraeus told him that his policy of setting a date for withdrawal is dangerous for America and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff on television, our highest ranking military officer, said it would be a dangerous course. Now for somebody who's had no military experience whatsoever, I would strongly recommend that Senator Obama at least listen, at least listen to our military leaders and devise a policy before you leave.''

According to the group, listeners were invited on eight different radio and television shows to enter phone-in competitions that they had no chance of winning. The group also said that some shows had been recorded so that no viewer could win competitions that appeared to the audience to be live, while other shows encouraged audience members to phone in to programs even after contestants had been chosen. The spa is located in  and only available to  guests of the Greenwich Hotel in TriBeCa, owned by Robert De Niro; his son Raphael; and two developers, Ira Drukier and Richard Born. Mikio Shinagawa, the designer who created the space, brought in most of the materials and craftspeople from Japan (cabinetry by John Houshmand was one exception). The lantern-lighted pool area, right, and lounge, above, are framed in wood from a 250-year-old farmhouse; the rest of the spa has traditional plaster-and-straw walls. Construction took more than two years, in part because Mikio would go to Japan every two weeks and bring things back  some worked, some didnt, Mr. Drukier said. We had the ability here to step back, see how things looked, and change what we didnt like. You really dont get a chance to do that very often in this business. Ms. Gura, a professor at the New York School of Interior Design, spent hundreds of hours interviewing designers (most older than 70) and digging up images of projects like the Denning & Fourcade 1980s interior with cloisonn elephants, left. The books, which have chapter headings like Anglophiles and Sybarites, include some projects that are not necessarily my taste  at heart, Im a modernist, Ms. Gura said. But I wanted to show the whole range of traditional rooms, and the influential modernist ones that were absolutely perfect reflections of their time.
