description: Two officials of a construction company that did work for the city were charged on Wednesday with cheating workers out of more than half a million dollars and inflating payroll figures to bilk money from the city.

title: A Senate Lion Brought Down
description: Any member of Congress should be able to see the larger lesson in the indictment of Senator Ted Stevens, the Alaskan patriarch accused of concealing more than $250,000 in home improvements and furnishings allegedly bestowed by the states chief power broker.

title: Neither Fire Nor Big Flood Will Deter This Hard Drive
description: External hard drives make it easy to expand a computers storage space and perform backups to get your computer system up and running after a crash or hardware failure.

title: In Newark, More Weariness Than Anger at Sentence
description: NEWARK

title: Put Arm (A) Into Sleeve (B)
description: THATS not a dress, my mother says about garments she considers too complicated. Thats a contraption.

title: Craft, Contrast and Compulsion: One Choreographers Three Cs
description: This week two dance companies are alternating at the Joyce, each showcasing the work of a single choreographer, Robert Battle (Battleworks) and Larry Keigwin (Keigwin & Company). Both these choreographers are upwardly mobile and already known here, but this is a neat way of bringing further New York attention to them. Here I attend to Mr. Battles contribution.

title: Follow the Lights to Upstate New York
description: Shandells, a lighting studio in Millerton, N.Y., specializing in antique lamps and lampshades handmade from vintage wallpapers and fabrics, is selling all items in stock at a 15 percent discount from Aug. 6 to 16. Lamps will be about $300 to $765 a pair, and lampshades, about $55 to $235.

title: Teach Your Children Well
description: To the Editor:

title: Democrats Call for Contempt Charges Against Rove
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats on both sides of the Capitol assailed the administrations handling of the Justice Department yet again on Wednesday, and a House committee recommended contempt charges against Karl Rove, who was President Bushs top political adviser.

title: Mets Look on Bright Side After Losing Division Lead
description: MIAMI  The Mets final push for postseason glory and Thursdays nonwaiver trade deadline are intertwined. The difference is, the Mets remained more hopeful of regaining first place in the National League East, which they vacated after their 7-5 loss to the Florida Marlins, than of swinging a deal that would improve those odds.

title: EADS Plans More Cost Cuts as Weak Dollar Hurts Position
description: PARIS  Under continuing pressure from a sagging dollar, EADS, the parent of the aviation giant Airbus, said Wednesday that it would extend a restructuring program and step up outsourcing in order to save another 1 billion euros, or $1.56 billion.

title: Bridge Collapse Mural
description: On Friday a public mural will be unveiled in Minneapolis to mark the first anniversary of the Interstate 35W bridge collapse. The project, Building Bridges, Not Fences, brought together 50 young artists, ages 9 to 17, to design and create the mural. All of the youths, except one who is a sister of a survivor, were on a school bus that was involved in the collapse. The mural is intended to give voice to their experiences as survivors and is supported by three community organizations: Hope Community, Waite House Neighborhood Center and Intermedia Arts. The mural will be unveiled at Intermedia Arts.

title: Gov. Patersons Budget Emergency
description: Across the country, states are slashing their budgets as tax revenues dwindle. New York, with its heavy dependence on Wall Street, is far from immune to the nations economic slide, as Gov. David Paterson this week made abundantly clear.

title: Tuned For Perfection, With a Lust for Gold
description: Mark Levine had read thousands of words about Michael Phelps and how his unusual proportions have helped make him this eras dominant swimmer. That background didnt matter much, because when Levine visited the U.S. training center in Colorado Springs and saw the elongated torso and short legs that compose Phelpss 6-foot-4 frame, the sight still came as a slight shock.

title: Bonding Humanity and Landscape in a Perfect Circle
description: LOS ANGELES  For those who find consolation in visionary architecture, this city has always been a powerful antidepressant. Its wealth of 20th-century treasures, mostly private homes, reminds us that it is possible to find quiet corners of enlightenment in dystopian times.

title: Ah, Korfball. We Remember You Well.
description: Think you know your Olympics trivia? Think again. John Tayman takes a look at the politicking, pandering and popularity contests of Games past.

title: Beyond Fiery Gates, All That an Inferno Allows
description: At the start of The Gargoyle, a transportingly unhinged debut novel by Andrew Davidson, the books caustic narrator explains the fiery accident that destroyed what had once been his extremely beautiful body.

title: Melena Ryziks Tour Diary: Almost Famous?
description: The rock star life it wasnt. From the moment I began working on this story, following 23-year-old Sean Carlson as he planned his first-ever tour from his home  actually, his fathers home  in L.A., it was clear that I would not be experiencing the perks that people usually imagine when they think of bands on the road. Instead of a plush custom-made Pimp My Ride-worthy vehicle, the tour would be criss-crossing the country on a vintage Blue Bird school bus, complete with narrow brown vinyl seats, pinchy windows and no air-conditioning. (The one concession to modernity: air cards, for Internet access.)And instead of one band and a roadie or two, there would be three or four groups, plus the crew of four, a couple of photographers, some members of a Philly art collective, a merch girl, an anarchist bookstore guy and a video blogger  sometimes more than two dozen people  all traveling side by side. To conserve money and promote eco-consciousness, Sean and his crew of merry punkers had the bus converted to run on bio-diesel  which meant that late each night they went on a messy scouting trip to score grease. (Their D.I.Y. ethos, and their lack of cash, prevented them from buying it.)I followed the tour from its first day, when it stopped in Brooklyn to pick up several of the bands  the headliners, Matt & Kim, and their friends Team Robespierre  then drove to the first shows in Baltimore and Washington, D.C. I caught up with it again for a couple of gigs in Texas, and for the final two nights back in New York City. To answer everyones first question: no, the veggie oil-fueled bus didnt smell like French fries. Especially at the end, it smelled likes boys and sweat and whiskey. Ok, so it was a little bit rock star.

title: What to Ask About Birth Control in Women
description: Confronting medical issues can be difficult, and because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: Young Singer on a Hot Streak
description: Miley Cyrus, left, the star of the Disney Channels Hannah Montana, is only 15, but she already has had two No. 1 albums. Breakout (Hollywood) reached the top of the Billboard chart this week with 371,000 sales, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Her last album, Hannah Montana 2: Meet Miley Cyrus  a two-CD set with one disc credited to her and the other to her alter ego  opened at No. 1 last summer. (She also sang most of the songs on the first Hannah Montana soundtrack, which topped the chart in 2006.) The country duo Sugarland reached No. 2 this week with its new Love on the Inside (Mercury Nashville), selling 314,000 copies. The soundtrack to the Mamma Mia! movie, on Decca, held at No. 3, with 168,000 sales, and Kid Rocks Rock N Roll Jesus (Atlantic) moved up two spots to No. 4 with 93,000. Lil Waynes Tha Carter III (Cash Money/Universal) fell three spots to No. 5, selling 85,000 in its seventh week out; its total sales are now just under two million.

title: Connecticut Accuses 3 Ratings Firms of Slighting Government Debt
description: The attorney general of Connecticut accused the nations three big ratings firms on Wednesday of systematically underrating debt issued by local and state governments.

title: This Time, a 007 Duet
description: The 007 franchise is doubling up on its soundtrack. Jack White and Alicia Keys, above, are the latest in a long line of pop stars to add their voices to the James Bond film series. Mr. White, the White Stripes front man, and Ms. Keys, the R&B singer, have recorded the theme song for the next Bond installment, Quantum of Solace, The Associated Press reported. The song, Another Way to Die, was written and produced by Mr. White, who also plays the drums and sings with Ms. Keys on the track, which will be the first duet theme song for a Bond movie. Madonna, Duran Duran, Tina Turner, Nancy Sinatra and Paul McCartney have all contributed to previous Bond soundtracks. Quantum of Solace, which stars Daniel Craig, will be released in November.

title: Proposed Sunscreen Labels on Hold for Now
description: SUNSCREEN is the hot potato of over-the-counter drugs.

title: Organs Make News
description: Two pieces of organ music are getting a second chance. An unpublished prelude and fugue for organ by Samuel Barber will be performed by Paul Jacobs on Sept. 12 at 10th Presbyterian Church in Philadelphia. The piece received its only pervious performance in 1928 when it was played by the organist Carl Weinrich at the Curtis Institute of Music. Barbara B. Heyman, a music historian, discovered the work at the Library of Congress in 1984 as part of the research for her biography of Barber. She then invited Mr. Jacobs to perform it. He will also reintroduce Barbers Prelude and Fugue in B minor in his dedication program for the churchs new four-manual Walker digital organ, a gift from C. Everett Koop, the former surgeon general and a former church elder. ... On July 18 in Leipzig, Germany, Balint Karosi, a Boston organist, won the International Johann Sebastian Bach Competition, becoming the first American to win the prestigious competition.

title: Deaths Draw Attention to Triathlon Swim
description: WHEN 60-year-old Donald Morehouse and 52-year-old John Hobgood Jr. died in different triathlon events last weekend, they became at least the seventh and eighth triathletes to die during competition this year. Those deaths came just one week after Esteban Neira, 32, died during the New York City Triathlon.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on July 16 about the history of corruption and lax oversight in the crane industry in New York City misstated the given name of a former official of the crane and heavy equipment operators union who testified in a federal union corruption case in 2006. He is Joseph Coriasco, not John.

title: Powerful Angels Up Next
description: Whatever region the Angels represented  California, Anaheim or Los Angeles  they loved to torment the Yankees under Joe Torre. No other American League team had a winning record against the Yankees during Torres 12 seasons as manager, including two that ended with playoff defeats in Anaheim.

title: Shorts Crack the Code
description: FIRST came Casual Fridays, that dread episode in the history of fashion, with their invitation for men to trade in suits for Dockers and to swap a proper shirt and tie for an open neck and a daring flash of masculine dcolletage.

title: The System: The State Requests a Gold
description: When youre the No.1 product of Chinas sports-industrial complex and its first-ever track star, youd better deliver. Jim Yardley, The Times's Beijing bureau chief, takes a look at the Chinese machine that creates -- and controls -- champions like Liu Xiang, the countrys best hurdler and the undisputed centerpiece of Chinas entire Olympic team, who has been forced to cope with the pressure and expectations to win for the glory of his country.

title: Gold-Medal Paydays
description: For gold-medal hopefuls like gymnasts Nastia Liukin and Shawn Johnson, theres just one big chance to make it as a marketing darling. Mimi Swartz, author of Power Failure: The Inside Story of The Collapse of Enron, and a regular contributor to PLAY, takes an amusing, up-close look at the scramble to hit Olympic paydirt.

description: Music

title: Amazon Music on an iPod
description: Q. Do digital songs from Amazon.com work on an iPod, and if so, how do you get them onto the thing from the Web?

title: The Laws Cops Cant Enforce
description: Mesa, Ariz.

title: Obama Camp Sees Potential in G.O.P. Discontent
description: Chuck Lasker, a political blogger and Internet consultant in Indiana, hosted a gathering last week of 20 people he calls whispering Republicans  party members like him who support Senator Barack Obama, a Democrat, for president. Over iced tea and brownies, the renegades took turns explaining why they liked Mr. Obama and recalling the strange stares from other Republicans.

title: 'Talent' Proves Popular
description: Americas Got Talent drew its largest audience of the summer on Tuesday, lifting NBC to No. 1 in the nights ratings. According to Nielsens estimates, 13.6 million viewers tuned in to the show, a talent competition, at 9 p.m. It followed an 8 p.m. installment of NBCs Celebrity Family Feud (7.5 million), which finished third in its time slot behind CBSs NCIS rerun (8.5 million) and ABCs Wipeout (9.7 million). ABC managed to edge past NBC for first place among adults 18 to 49. ABC got a boost at 10 from its rebroadcast of Primetime: The Last Lecture (7.6 million), which featured an interview with the Carnegie Mellon computer science professor Randy Pausch, who died of cancer last week. CBS finished third for the night, followed by Fox.

title: Seeing the Dermatologist
description: To the Editor:

title: Shopping for a First Apartment With Michael Bargo
description: MICHAEL BARGO, a 25-year-old interior designer, has only recently moved from a studio to a one-bedroom apartment, so he knows well what its like to live in a small New York City space that must be multifunctional and good-looking.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article by The Associated Press on Wednesday about a speech by President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran to the Nonaligned Movement of nations meeting in Tehran misidentified the country that the United Nations has penalized for refusing to halt enrichment of uranium. It is Iran, not Iraq.

title: The Nimble Exploit Little Efficiencies
description: IT has been a bruiser of a summer for small businesses that must use the roads every day.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: An article on Tuesday about the federal takeover of IndyMac Bank referred incorrectly to the maximum amount of insurance available from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation for individual accounts. While the F.D.I.C. insures deposits in nonretirement accounts like checking and savings accounts to a maximum of $100,000, the maximum for retirement accounts is $250,000.

title: Terrible Timing for a Hotel Boom
description: A record number of hotels are opening this year, and the timing could not be worse.

title: Conservationists Fault British Museum Plans
description: Heritage groups in London are upset over plans by the British Museum to build an exhibition center in the northwest part of the museum, which they say will destroy important period details of the building, The Times of London reported. The museum, the most popular cultural institution in the city, attracted more than six million people last year. It has commissioned Richard Rogers to produce the new center, in the rear of the building, at an estimated cost of $258 million. The center would provide 183,000 square feet for conservation and exhibitions and accommodate more visitors. Groups are concerned that the expansion would damage period details of the 19th-century Robert Smirke building, including the King Edward VII galleries, the marble staircase that leads to the back of the building and the well-known Arched Room, as well as some of the views from the building. The museum hopes to open the new center by 2011, pending permission from the local authorities.

title: Perry, With Hint of Reluctance, Slips Into Big Shoes of Woods
description: AKRON, Ohio  Another big event, another huge purse, another week without Tiger Woods. This week it is the W.G.C.-Bridgestone Invitational, the last of the seasons three World Golf Championship events. It begins Thursday with a field of 80 of the worlds best golfers chasing $8 million at Firestone Country Club.

title: Italian Design on Display in Las Vegas
description: A retrospective of Italian furniture design may not have been uppermost in your mind when you planned a trip to Las Vegas. But why limit your aesthetic life to casinos, Elvis impersonators and a fake Eiffel tower, even if in these economically challenging days its the only one you can afford to visit?

title: 3 Children Are Shot Fleeing Melee
description: DALLAS  A mother who tried to flee a violent melee at an apartment complex here was stopped by gunfire early Wednesday morning, when her car was sprayed with bullets that wounded three of her children.

title: Deal on a Security Agreement Is Close, Iraqis Say
description: BAGHDAD  Iraq and the United States are close to a deal on a sensitive security agreement that Iraqi officials said on Wednesday satisfies the nations desire to be treated as sovereign and independent.

title: An Online Hoax Becomes a Source About a Suspect
description: It was not hard, in the end, to figure out that the Web site was a hoax, however tantalizing the site was for reporters eager to fill out details on the fugitive life of Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader reincarnated as a hippie guru of alternative healing.

title: Amgen Told to Reword Drug Label
description: The Food and Drug Administration has ordered Amgen to change the labels for its flagship anemia drugs in a way that could further restrict their use in treating patients with cancer.

title: Motion Gaming Adds a Mission That Blends Learning With Fun
description: Call it the Wii effect  video games using motion-sensitive wireless controllers like the ones that come with Nintendos Wii game console. Vtech Electronics uses a similar device in its educational gaming console that came out this week, the V.Smile V-Motion Active Learning System.

title: Court Votes to Postpone an Execution in Alabama
description: Thomas Arthur, a death-row inmate in Alabama, was granted a last-minute reprieve by the State Supreme Court on Wednesday evening after another convict confessed to the murder for which Mr. Arthur was to be executed.

title: The Dining Room Takes to the Streets
description: THERE were 10 for dinner last Friday night, invited by Calvin Tsao and Zack McKown, partners in an architecture practice that has its offices on Vandam Street in Manhattan. A few of the guests were collaborating with the architects on a master plan for a city in China, 10 kilometers away from the epicenter of the recent earthquake, and they were exhausted from working nonstop. Still, they came, by subway and then on foot, meeting in the lee of the Manhattan-side tower of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: A Glint in Your Step
description: THE status sneaker, once a utilitarian object with a sole of rubber, is now practically fit for the Court of St. Jamess. With such a warrant, is it any surprise that todays haute cobblers would want to get into the game? Picking up on the silver and gold tones recently trotted out by Supra, Nike, Converse and others, fashion houses like Dior, Lanvin, Pierre Hardy and Gucci have come out with metallic sneakers, slip-ons and even low-heeled jazz shoes.

title: Libya: Two Swiss Detainees Released
description: Libya has released two Swiss citizens who had been held for 11 days after the arrest in Geneva of Hannibal Qaddafi, the youngest son of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. Mr. Qaddafi and his wife were arrested on July 15 after two employees accused them of mistreatment. They were allowed to return to Libya after posting bail two days later. The two Swiss citizens were detained on July 19, accused of violating Libyan immigration laws. The Libyan government ordered Swiss companies to close offices in Libya and warned Swiss citizens not to travel there.

title: Trying to Curb Global Heat, U.N. to Turn Up Its Own
description: UNITED NATIONS  The United Nations has long been accused by its detractors of generating hot air. Starting in August, a glance at the thermostat in the Secretariat building will provide confirmation.

title: All Their Worlds a Staging
description: WHILE the Internet has changed the way people buy and sell homes  its a lot easier to tour a house on your computer, in your pajamas, than it is to see it in person  one thing hasnt changed: houses sell faster when they stand out from the competition. And one of the best ways to set your house apart, real estate experts say, is to borrow a trick from professional set designers and stage your home.

title: A Trial That Raises the Issue of the Dangers in Discovery
description: Even though they are on opposite sides, prosecutors always have to share some of their evidence with the defense. But in trials involving violent crime, prosecutors often fear that information could leak out in this process, which is called discovery, and be used to hurt people.

title: How to Give Your Child an Allowance, the Mobile Way
description: Nowhere is it written in stone that all teenagers must at some point run up their parents cellphone bills with 3,000 peak minutes, 5,000 text messages and enough new ring tones to fill the overnight slot on a college radio station.

title: S.I. Attempts to Get People Off the Boat and on a Bus
description: When the ferry docked at Staten Island, a wave of tourists funneled down the ramp and made a U-turn to board the same boat they had just gotten off.

title: Law Firm Seeks Publicity for Socit Gnrale Class-Action Suit
description: PARIS  American lawyers seeking to bring a class-action lawsuit against the French bank Socit Gnrale over its billions of euros in unexpected losses came to France on Wednesday looking for publicity, and plaintiffs.

title: Guggenheim Series
description: James Levine, Nico Muhly and Isaac Mizrahi are just a few of the artists scheduled to take part in the fall season of Works & Process at the Guggenheim Museum. This years programs, which blend performance and discussion to give audiences insight into the creative process, feature several new commissions, including a world premiere by Mr. Muhly and a piece celebrating the 70th birthday of the composer Charles Wuorinen with Mr. Levine conducting. Other highlights include a performance of Prokofievs Peter and the Wolf by the Juilliard Ensemble with narration by Mr. Mizrahi. The season begins Sept. 8.

title: Lawyer Says Donaghy Will Not Meet N.B.A.s Investigator
description: Tim Donaghy will not meet with the N.B.A.s investigator who is examining the leagues antigambling policies and officiating program.

title: A Hidden Toll on Employment: Cut to Part Time
description: The number of Americans who have seen their full-time jobs chopped to part time because of weak business has swelled to more than 3.7 million  the largest figure since the government began tracking such data more than half a century ago.

title: City Comptrollers Mayoral Bid Leads Spending
description: As New York Citys chief accountant, Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. has issued a flurry of recent audits scolding city agencies for overspending. And this week he warned that the city must tighten its belt to address gaping budget deficits over the next few years.

title: United Sues Pilots, Saying Job Action Canceled Hundreds of Flights
description: United Airlines sued its pilots union on Wednesday, asking it to halt slowdowns that it said had led to the cancellation of hundreds of flights in the last 10 days.

title: Marlins May Try to Land Red Sox' Ramrez
description: When Manny Ramrez of the Red Sox flied out to the center-field warning track in the eighth inning on Wednesday night, the broadcaster ruminated about whether Ramrez had played his final game for Boston. While it seemed probable that Ramrez will remain with the Red Sox, speculation was ablaze about his future.

title: Accounting Board Delays an Asset Rule
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, under pressure from banks and auditors, voted unanimously on Wednesday to delay a new accounting rule that is aimed at forcing banks to put more assets on their balance sheets rather than hide them in so-called special-purpose entities.

title: A Farm Boy Reflects
description: YAMHILL, Ore.

title: Gene-Hunters Find Hope and Hurdles in Schizophrenia Studies
description: Two groups of researchers hunting for schizophrenia genes on a larger scale than ever before have found new genetic variants that point toward a different understanding of the disease.

title: Double Dutch Gets Status in the Schools
description: The rhythmic clicking of double-dutch ropes smacking the tennis court the other day at the Grand Street Campus High School in Bushwick drew 13-year-old Stephanie Moronta like a sirens call. She edged closer to the ropes, rocking back and forth on her heels before lunging into the whirling center.

title: Deciphering the Menu of Birth Control Options
description: Dr. Daniel R. Mishell Jr., is professor of obstetrics and gynecology at the Keck School of Medicine of the University of Southern California. Since 1970, he has been editor of the journal Contraception. Dr. Mishell introduced the first pregnancy test to the United States that did not involve the killing of rabbits, a technique still in use today.

title: Lawyers for Detainee Assert Coercion
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba  A secret government document submitted at the trial of the first detainee to face a war crimes trial confirms the detainees account of having been sexually humiliated while interrogated by a female government agent, defense lawyers said at the tribunal here on Wednesday.

title: The Messaging Abilities of a Smartphone, but With a Younger Audience in Mind
description: The BlackBerry may rule the office park, but the Sidekick rules the skate park. The updated Sidekick, aimed at adolescents and above, offers a full keyboard along with e-mail and instant messaging capabilities that rival some higher-end smartphones.

title: Corrections: For The Record
description: A listing of credits on Tuesday with a television review of Lords Children, an installment of the Wide Angle series on PBS, omitted a producer. Tamara Rosenberg is listed as the reversioning producer for Wide Angle.

title: Paper Your Floors as Well as Your Walls
description: Papyra  a new rug for Danskina by Ulf Moritz, a textile design professor at Design Academy Eindhoven in the Netherlands known for his fabric and wallpaper  is an update on the 1970s shag carpet.

description: To the Editor:

description: Q. Ive been trying to plant moss between the paving stones on my terrace, but it keeps dying. What am I doing wrong?

title: Struck by New York
description: Rosendale, N.Y.

title: The Emotional Toll of Parkinson's Disease
description: Dr. Irene Richard, a movement disorder neurologist and researcher at the University of Rochester, is an investigating senior medical adviser to The Michael J. Fox Foundation, an organization committed to improving the lives of people with Parkinsons disease. Dr. Richard is an expert on the mental and emotional aspects of the illness and is leading a national study looking into whether medications might help treat depression related to Parkinsons disease.

title: Bush Signs Sweeping Housing Bill
description: WASHINGTON  President Bush signed into law on Wednesday a huge package of housing legislation that included broad authority for the Treasury Department to safeguard the nations two largest mortgage finance companies and a plan to help hundreds of thousands of troubled borrowers avoid losing their homes.

title: Cyclists Will Test the Air in Beijing
description: Just four days ago, the greatest cyclists in the world were racing up the Champs-lyses. A week from Saturday, they will be playing the role of the canary in the coal mine, inhaling the formidable mix of oil particles, industrial smoke and Gobi Desert grit in Beijing.

title: When Tanning Gets Out of Hand
description: ABOUT one third of American adults had at least one sunburn in 2004, 2003 and 1999, according to telephone surveys of about 700,000 people by the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Among people who said they had been burned in the previous year, two thirds had more than one sunburn, according to an article last year in the CDC Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report.

title: At a Fork in the Road, Cuba Follows Two Paths
description: HAVANA  When President Ral Castro spoke last week at the old military garrison where he and his older brother Fidel began the Cuban revolution 55 years ago, the younger Mr. Castro looked minuscule compared with the outsize banner looming over him of his bearded predecessor.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about the lack of a national database in the United States to track how people fare after receiving artificial joints misstated the financial history of one medical device manufacturer, Sulzer Orthopedics. While Sulzer, faced with lawsuits from patients implanted with one of its artificial hips, threatened to file for bankruptcy protection, it did not do so.

title: A Duel to the Finish in the Spingold Teams
description: First, look only at the West hand. With both sides vulnerable, your partner opens one spade in the third position, and your right-hand opponent makes a takeout double. What would you respond?

title: Bluff Called, Karadzic Awaits Trial in U.N. Cell
description: THE HAGUE  Radovan Karadzic, the former Bosnian Serb leader who was transferred early Wednesday from Serbia to a jail cell near here, will appear in public court on Thursday for the first time to answer charges of genocide and war crimes.

title: Hiram Bullock, 52, Soulful Guitarist, Dies
description: Hiram Bullock, a soulful and adaptable jazz and rock guitarist who was a member of the original band for Late Night with David Letterman, died last Friday in Manhattan. He was 52.

title: Dr. Daniel Bukantz, 90, a Champion Fencer, Dies
description: Dr. Daniel Bukantz, who was a national champion and Olympic fencer, and a longtime Olympic fencing referee while pursuing a career in dentistry, died Saturday at his home in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 90.

title: Despite Calls to Halt, Iran Says It Will Continue Its Nuclear Program
description: Speaking just days before a deadline set by world powers for Iran to reply to proposals to curb its nuclear ambitions, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the countrys supreme leader, said Wednesday that Iran would continue with its path of nuclear development, which includes the enrichment of uranium.

title: A Volatile Session Ends on an Up Note
description: Despite a sharp rise in oil prices Wednesday, stocks rallied after the promise of more support from the Federal Reserve gave investors confidence that financial firms would work through their problems.

title: Its Why We Read, Online and Off
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dance of Environment and Economics in the Everglades
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla.  When Florida officials announced a plan last month to save the Everglades by buying United States Sugar and its 187,000 acres, they knew that the success of their plan could be defined by Alfonso Fanjul and his brother J. Pepe Fanjul.

title: Town Hall Meeting for 'Baby Borrowers'
description: NBC News will host a televised town hall meeting about the networks reality show The Baby Borrowers next week. The series followed five teenage couples who experienced life in fast-forward, taking care of babies, toddlers, teenagers and elderly people over a three-week period. Because the show separated babies and toddlers from their parents and temporarily placed them with strangers, it has come under scrutiny from critics. (The series finale was shown on Wednesday.) Some of these critics will be included in the town hall special, NBC said on Tuesday, along with experts in adolescent psychology and teenage pregnancy. The teenage couples and the actual parents of the children will also be in attendance. The meeting will be broadcast on Aug. 6, with Hoda Kotb, the Today show co-host, and Dr. Drew Pinsky, the television personality whos also a professor of psychiatry, as hosts. NBC is soliciting questions for the town hall broadcast on nbc.com.

title: Weighing the Health Benefits of Birth Control
description: Unveiled in 1960, the birth control pill revolutionized contraception. Yet despite an abundance of birth control options today, almost half the pregnancies in this country are unintended, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, more than in any other developed nation. Whats the reason?

title: Fiscal Woes of the Past Prod Paterson to Act Early
description: ALBANY  It was early 2002. Wall Streets profits had collapsed after the 9/11 attacks, unemployment was on the rise and tax revenue was plummeting.

title: Amid Salmonella Case, Food Industry Seems Set to Back Greater Regulation
description: Food industry leaders set to appear Thursday before a House committee say they will testify about what they view as mistakes in the federal response to the continuing salmonella outbreak as well as fundamental failures in the nations food safety system.

title: Corrections
description: Front Page

title: Phoenix Club Expels Member Over His Press Interview

title: Scrabble Scuffle
description: Why didn't Hasbro buy Scrabulous instead of suing to shut down the popular online imitation of Scrabble on Facebook? "Once again, here is an embattled industry -- is this case board game manufacturers, getting walloped by a digital tidal wave," writes Blaise Zerega, the deputy editor of Portfolio magazine. "And the reaction? Lawsuits. Sounds a lot like Napster and Music." Zerega also writes:    There are many, many other examples from film (Kazaa) and book publishing (Google). to name but two. Just think how NBC is going to react when people start streaming the Beijing Olympics from their mobile phones to the web -- so much for being the exclusive broadcaster.  But as the past few years have shown, the embattled industry may be the short term winner by shutting down a site or two. But eventually the digital tidal wave overtakes them. The only way for such an industry to survive is to invest and embrace.   A commenter on Zerega's column counters that Hasbro shouldn't be expected "to negotiate with thieves," writing: "Whatever we may think of the record industry or the game industry or anybody else for that matter doesn't change a fundamental principle: you're not allowed to simply take other people's stuff without permission and reimbursement."  (Thanks, Hit & Run!)

title: Icahn Scores Big With ImClone Bid
description: He may not have made a mint on Yahoo, but Carl Icahn, the billionaire financier with a knack for shaking things up, looks set to hit the jackpot on ImClone Systems.  Bristol-Myers Squibb on Thursday offered to buy ImClone for $60 per share, which is nearly double what Mr. Icahn paid for his stake in the drug maker about two years ago, according to data from regulatory filings. Mr. Icahn became ImClone's chairman in October 2006 after an intense proxy battle, which included the kind of acerbic letters to shareholders that he sent in its more recent feud with Yahoo's board.   If the ImClone sale goes through at the offered price, it would represent a hefty payback for Mr. Icahn's troubles.  ImClone makes the cancer drug Erbitux. The drug has had an up-and-down history: It was initially rejected by the Food and Drug Administration -- stock trades around that time led to the prosecution of Martha Stewart -- but has since turned into a steady performer.  In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission in September 2006, Mr. Icahn indicated that the total purchase price for the nearly 11.7 million shares owned by him or his funds was $390.5 million. That suggests he paid an average of about $33.46 each for the ImClone shares.   Confusingly, Mr. Icahn told The New York Times in October 2006 that most of the ImClone shares he owned at the time were acquired when the stock was selling below $20. At least two filings with the S.E.C. list transactions in which his funds paid per-share prices in the high $20 to low $30 range for ImClone stock.  In any case, Mr. Icahn clearly paid far below what Bristol-Myers offered for ImClone on Thursday. At $60 per share, Mr. Icahn's stake is worth about $700 million, nearly 80 percent above his total purchase price as reported to the S.E.C.  And he may do even better than that: ImClone's shares jumped to $64 apiece in early trading Thursday, as investors seemed to be hoping for a higher bid.  Go to Article from The New York Times>>

title: Can Crumbling Himalayas Protect Bangladesh From Rising Seas?
description: Scientists in Bangladesh have been reappraising forecasts of eventual inundation of sprawling, crowded delta regions as seas rise in a warming world. According to several reports, a fresh satellite analysis shows that new lands formed by sediment carried from the crumbling Himalayas are adding to Bangladeshs land area  at least for now.

title: Dot Earth: Bangladesh, Sediment and Sea Level
description: (Photo: Sediment from rivers is adding land area to Bangladesh. Can this counter rising seas? (The New York Times)) Scientists in Bangladesh have been reappraising forecasts of eventual inundation of sprawling, crowded delta regions as seas rise in a warming world. According to several reports, a fresh satellite analysis shows that new lands formed by sediment carried from the crumbling Himalayas are adding to Bangladesh's land area -- at least for now.   As wire stories circulated overnight, I sent out some queries to sea-level experts and will report back on how this battle between new sediment and rising seas will play out.   Sea level is not uniform globally. Juneau, Alaska, is rising, for instance. The land there is rebounding, freed of the weight of ice-age glaciers. When I visited Juneau last year, biologists told me that a fight is brewing over whether protected coastal wetlands should no longer be protected once they are dry. (Coastal property owners say the new land is theirs.)  The fate of Bangladesh's lowlands will be determined by a mix of changes in the height of the Indian Ocean, subsidence of deltas as aquifers are drained and newly deposited sediments compress, and the addition of all that Himalayan soil.  In checking out the news from Bangladesh, I noticed that the Dutch have been advising Bangladeshis to do as the Dutch do -- use engineering to work with the flow of sediment and accelerate the accretion of new lands. A recent article in The New Nation -- "Can Bangladesh Trap Silt?" -- is worth a look. All of this serves as a useful reminder that humans are not some static element in the climate puzzle, but a dynamic, responsive and innovative one -- at least once a human community gets a strong signal that action is needed.   When I wrote with James Kanter last year about the report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change on impacts from global warming, I made sure we noted how the consequences for humans change significantly when adaptation is taken into account (boldface added):    Without such adaptations, it said, a rise of 3 to 5 degrees Fahrenheit over the next century could lead to the inundation of coasts and islands inhabited by hundreds of millions of people. But if steady investments are made in seawalls and other coastal protections, vulnerability could be sharply reduced.  Bangladesh has already proved to be one of the world's most resilient countries in the face of flood threats, as Secretary General Ban Ki-moon pointed out here. It sounds as if the country is getting geared up to find ways to exploit the eroding Himalayas as a way to counter the erosion of its coasts.  Adaptation can buy time and cut losses in the short run. But in the end, many experts note that unabated greenhouse-gas emissions essentially mean there will be no new normal climate or coastline to adapt to -- in Bangladesh or anywhere else.

title: Have Camera, Will Trespass, on Brooklyns Waterfront
description: Nathan Kensinger generally does not ask for permission when he photographs the decaying remnants of Brooklyns industrial waterfront. Since 2003, he has wandered into shuttered factories, padlocked basements and forbidding warehouses. He often goes along with other photographers who have an adventurous bent. He hasnt been arrested, yet, but he doesnt want to tempt fate, either.

title: City Room: Photos of Brooklyns Waterfront
description: The Domino sugar refinery has been on the East River for more than a century. Part of the plant is now a landmark, but the windows in this view will be demolished. (Photo: Nathan Kensinger) Slide ShowNathan Kensinger generally does not ask for permission when he photographs the decaying remnants of Brooklyn's industrial waterfront. Since 2003, he has wandered into shuttered factories, padlocked basements and forbidding warehouses. He often goes along with other photographers who have an adventurous bent. He hasn't been arrested, yet, but he doesn't want to tempt fate, either.   Mr. Kensinger's photographs are now on view in a small exhibition, "Twilight on the Waterfront: Brooklyn's Vanishing Industrial Heritage," that opened on June 17 and runs through Aug. 30 at the central branch of the Brooklyn Public Library.   His subjects range from the Domino sugar refinery in Williamsburg, part of which was declared a landmark in 2007; the ruins of the Greenpoint Terminal Warehouse, which were ravaged by arson in 2006; and the haunting remains of Dead Horse Bay, where a 17th-century Dutch mill once stood.   Mr. Kensinger, 29, grew up in the Mission District of San Francisco, within view of the Navy Yard, and now lives near the Gowanus Canal; water has long been a source of fascination. He studied documentary filmmaking at Hampshire College in Amherst, Mass., where he graduated in 2001, then worked on a still-unfinished documentary for two years, before moving to Brooklyn.  In recent years, Mr. Kensinger said in a phone interview, he has spent more time photographing, though he still focuses on documentary filmmaking and cinematography. He also works as a location scout for "Law & Order: SVU," a job that came about, he said, because of his knowledge of the city's more arcane locations.   He usually takes nothing more than a single digital camera -- he uses a Nikon D80 -- with just one lens. He explained:    I really have to keep the equipment pretty light because most of these spaces are off-limits. To gain access to them, I can't really carry a lot of heavy equipment. I might be climbing a fence or climbing a wall, which makes it difficult to carry a lot of stuff with me. It's very difficult to gain access to those sites. A lot of them I gained access to as they were being demolished. They don't want people taking photographs -- not only for safety reasons, but also maybe because they don't want to encourage preservationists.   Some hazards were involved. "I really don't like the guard dogs," Mr. Kensinger said. "There's definitely a degree of danger to the whole enterprise, but I think the rewards of seeing these spaces that no one else is able to see is worth my while. There's certainly danger with buildings decaying, floors collapsing, stepping on nails. I stepped on a 10-inch nail one time. It was not so fun." (Without revealing too many specifics, Mr. Kensinger said he carefully prepares before each shoot, scouting out security procedures and determining the best ways to get access.)  Mr. Kensinger is part of a movement of adventure urban explorer, who wander -- and document -- the city's forbidden places. As "Children of Darkness," a 2007 article in The Times, explained, these explorers include artists like Miru Kim, who takes photographs of herself, naked, posed in abandoned tunnels and structures throughout the city and elsewhere.  Such photographs seem to have found an audience. Mr. Kensinger's work is featured in "Click! A Crowd-Curated Exhibition" at the Brooklyn Museum, and through his Web site, he has found like-minded photographers and explorers. "Every week, I get e-mail from people who have tips or want to come out and shoot with me."   Although the National Trust for Historic Preservation named the Brooklyn industrial waterfront one of America's 11 most endangered places in 2007, Mr. Kensinger said he did not expect most of the structures he has photographed to be saved.  "The Landmarks Preservation Commission we have right now is working as hard as it can to save some of these structures, but I feel like the opposition is coming from developers and really also from the city government, which is very pro-development," he said.

title: Quest for True Blu-ray Quality via Satellite
description: High-definition, Blu-ray discs offer consumers what is now the ultimate in picture quality: its programming is recorded in the 1080p format, delivering 1,080 lines of information, progressively scanned. If you own a large-enough 1080p flat panel TV, you'll be able to see the difference between its picture and that of a high-definition image transmitted by your local TV station, cable or satellite.  Until now, 1080p programming could not be transmitted because the signal contains too much information to squeeze into the available bandwidth. Instead it's only been available on recorded media, like Blu-ray. So the programming you get with an antenna or cable is usually sent in the less-high-definition 1080i (for interlace) resolution.   Which is why Thursday's announcement by Dish Network that they will start showing 1080p content is potentially significant. In its news release, the company says that in addition to a host of 17 new national high-definition channels, it will also offer pay-per-view movies in 1080p. The first, available on Friday, is "I Am Legend," the Will Smith sci-fi film.  While the satellite company may be the first to sell 1080p content, they're not the first to announce it. Those honors go to DirecTV; on Monday the company said it would introduce an additional 30 national high-definition channels by the middle of August, bringing its high definition total up to 130 (Dish says it will have 100 high-definition national channels by Friday). And DirecTV announced it will also offer 1080p pay per view programming later this year.   Both companies imply that their 1080p offerings will look as good as Blu-ray discs. DirecTV says its titles are in "the same format used by Blu-Ray HD DVDs." Dish is even more direct, (so to speak), calling its offerings "Blu-ray disc quality."  But are they Blu-ray quality? Resolution is not the only factor that determines picture quality. Another is bit rate, the number of bits per second that are being transmitted down the pipe to consumers.   All digital television is compressed, reducing the amount of space the signal needs, while trying not to cut picture quality. But when a transmission gets too compressed -- if a program provider needs extra space for more channels, for instance -- the result can be a picture that breaks up into little squares or gets the "mosquito effect," a sense that a swarm of bugs is circling around an object in motion.  Bit rate is a subject that the cable and satellite providers never discuss, but anyone who watches the various services can see that some channels are considerably softer looking than others. Fast-moving action, as found in sports programming, requires more bits (less compression). Program providers may "borrow" bits from one channel and give them to another.  Pete Putman, a well-known television engineer and owner of ROAM Consulting, and his colleagues often check bit rates, and he's found that CBS, when viewed over the air, generally offers the highest, around 17 megabits a second for their high definition programming. The new digital converter boxes now being used by Dish and DirecTV use a more advanced compression scheme, and Putman believes that they are sending out high-definition programming at around 6 to 8 megabits a second.   Requirements may eventually change. As Consumer Electronics Daily, a trade paper, reported today, Fujitsu asserts that it has found a way to reduce the bit rate for the compression schemes now used by DirecTV and Dish. The company reportedly has filed more than a dozen patents on picture coding that one day may bring the high-definition compression rate down to 4 megabits a second.  But for now, Putman believes that for a 1080p picture to look like Blu-ray, program providers will have to increase their bit rate to 16 or 18 megabits a second. Do they have the capacity to do that? And if not, will the Blu-ray camp call foul?  "We'll have to see what comparisons are made and what comes out of it," said Andy Parsons, head of the Blu-ray Disc Association.

title: North Korea: U.N. Food Program Warns of Famine
description: The United Nations World Food Program warned on Wednesday that successive poor harvests and flooding a year ago had resulted in millions of North Koreans facing hunger on a scale not seen in the North since a famine in the late 1990s. The World Food Program plans to begin providing food to 6.4 million of the country's 23 million people by the end of this year. It is currently feeding 1.2 million North Koreans. The majority of families surveyed by the program's researchers have cut protein from their diets and are surviving on cereals and vegetables. One of the leading causes of malnutrition among children under 5 years old is diarrhea resulting from increased consumption of wild foods.

title: Carl Icahn to Sit Out Yahoo Meeting
description: Carl Icahn has been a busy blogger. The latest posts on his Icahn Report, which appeared Thursday morning, comprise of a critique of the financial press and an explanation of why he dropped his proxy fight with Yahoo. He also said that, after months of highly public feuding with Yahoo, he won't be making an appearance at its upcoming shareholder meeting.  His media commentary was inspired by an article published last week in The Wall Street Journal, which seemed to question his combative management style.  "The article states that I often exert an 'outsized influence' as a board member, implying that this is somehow reckless and counter to the best interests of stockholders," Mr. Icahn wrote. "Major shareholders, particularly those who serve on boards, should actively question decisions a company makes many business journalists don't seem to get this important point, and I have never understood why"   Elsewhere in the post, he said: "Historians will marvel at why the press wont write more about the egregious abuses and mismanagement at corporate boards in America."  Then Mr. Icahn focused on his recent settlement with Yahoo, in which he dropped his fight to gain control of the Internet giant's board and instead agreed to take three seats for him and his allies.   "Last week, I realized it was impossible to gain enough support from the large institutions to win a majority of the Yahoo! directorships," Mr. Icahn wrote. "Realizing I could not gain control, I saw no point in spending the final two weeks in a debilitating fight."  Mr. Icahn went on to say that having a minority board presence is not ideal, but that he had worked out a deal with management "that any meaningful transaction, including the strategy in dealing with that transaction, will be fully discussed with the entire board before any final decision is made."   But those hoping to catch a glimpse of the corporate agitator at the upcoming Yahoo shareholder meeting will be disappointed: Mr. Icahn said he would not be attending. "It will not do shareholders or Yahoo any good to have the annual meeting turn into a media event for no purpose," Mr. Icahn wrote.  Go to the Icahn Report>>

title: Gates Plans Post-Gates Pentagon
description: (Photo: (Photo: Jim Young/Reuters))   By announcing today that military combat tours would be shortened from 15 to 12 months, President Bush was implementing a major recommendation that his Pentagon chief made months earlier.   In a profile earlier this year in The New York Times Magazine, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates is quoted telling a group of soldiers' wives at Fort Hood last November that he would seek to shorten the tours by the end of 2008, when President Bush's tenure in office (and presumably his own) would be drawing to a close. But he was thinking beyond that date as well, speaking of hopes that troops might spend as long as three years at Stateside bases between combat tours.  As it turned out, the thought was just one element of his long-term vision for the military. As The Washington Post reports today, Mr. Gates approved a new National Defense Strategy last month, a step called "unusual" for someone who probably has only six months left in office. (Would he stay on after January to serve in, for example, an Obama administration? "Inconceivable," he says.)  Even so, Mr. Gates, who has had the ear of two presidents named Bush, is clearly trying to influence the next administration with his strategy paper. From the Post article:  In a foreword to the document Gates acknowledges that a new president will soon reassess threats and priorities. Gates wrote that he perceives this document as a "a blueprint to success" for a future administration.  Some have argued that a defense strategy produced in the last year of the first Bush administration by a Pentagon headed by Dick Cheney served as a blueprint for the current one, so Mr. Gates's hope may be based in at least some precedent.  The new strategy document, however, reportedly focuses mainly on battling terrorists and other "irregular" foes, rather than potential military threats from China, Russia or any other nation that could challenge the United States as the sole superpower, the Pentagon's chief worry in Mr. Cheney's day as Secretary of Defense. In another contrast to the earlier strategy, Mr. Gates is rather straightforward in the new document about downgrading the importance of the immense combat capabilities of his department, in favor of taking full advantage of the nation's so-called "soft power":   "The use of force plays a role, yet military efforts to capture or kill terrorists are likely to be subordinate to measures to promote local participation in government and economic programs to spur development, as well as efforts to understand and address the grievances that often lie at the heart of insurgencies," the document said. "For these reasons, arguably the most important military component of the struggle against violent extremists is not the fighting we do ourselves, but how well we help prepare our partners to defend and govern themselves."   The approach sounded similar -- at least in broad outlines -- to the one laid out in a RAND study of how to end terrorism, released earlier this week. And it will probably attract the same criticism -- that it is unwise to shift away from conventional warfare. Critics may comfort themselves with knowing that both documents may be dismissed just as lightly by whoever succeeds Mr. Gates, and his boss in the White House, in January.

title: It's the Software, Not You
description: A couple of weeks ago, I spent a long weekend trip to New York City with my kids. We took a bunch of taxi rides over the three days, and discovered that the taxis are equipped with touchscreen credit-card payment systems.   As you complete the transaction, a final screen offers to save you time with shortcuts for adding a tip.  The thing is, the software for these systems come from two different companies. In some cabs, you're offered buttons that add 15%, 20% or 25% tip--perfectly understandable.  But in the other half of the taxis, the tip buttons say $2, $3 and $4. That's it, no matter how long or short the ride was.   Considering the huge range of fares, those options are almost never exactly what you want. A percentage makes infinitely more sense.  It reminded me suddenly of the touchscreen kiosks at Delta. Now, I actually like Delta quite a lot, and think they're doing a lot of things right lately. But the kiosks--oh, man.  You come up, you swipe your credit card. That alone ought to tell the kiosk who you are, and it should therefore know what flight you're checking in for.   But no, it plays dumb. It asks you to key in your destination. So you type in "SAN" for San Francisco. And it asks you: San Francisco, San Diego, or San Juan? Oh, I don't know--how about THE ONE YOU HAVE A RESERVATION ON!?   (Yes, yes, I know--you might have more than one reservation on Delta. But come on. Let's say you have flights today at 3 pm, tomorrow at 5 pm, and next Friday at 8 pm. As you swipe your credit card, today, at 1:30 pm, does it really think you're checking in for anything but the first one?)  But O.K. You tap San Francisco. And now--I kid you not--it wants to know what time of day the flight departs!   Are you kidding me? It doesn't know the airline's own flight time? Come on--it already knows what flight I'm on, so what's the point of this exercise? For God's sake, just check me in!  Whenever I encounter badly designed software like this, I stand there, slack-jawed, mind boggling, and wonder what on earth the designers were *thinking.* Not, obviously, about elegance, intelligence and simplicity.  Years ago, I read about a software designer at Palm named Rob Haitani. In designing the address-book program for the PalmPilot, he favored placing the "Add" button (to input a new person's contact information) at the bottom of the tiny 160-pixel-square screen, but relegating the "Delete" command to a pull-down menu.   His fellow designers argued that those commands are equivalent, and should therefore be displayed with equal prominence. Haitani, however, disagreed. You add people to your address book all the time. But you delete people only rarely--when the die, move away or break up with you. So Add should be prominent, and Delete should be hidden to save screen space.  That's intelligence.  Maybe it's a laziness thing, or a cost-saving thing. After all, it's less effort to make the end user jump through a bunch of hoops than to make your own software more intelligent.  All of these thoughts go through my mind every time I see the standard Windows software-installation wizard, seven screens long.  You don't really need seven screens of options to install a program, do you? Why can't it assume that you want the standard setup and get on with it?   Surely 90 percent of the time, people, YES, want the program in their Start menus; YES, want the typical installation; NO, don't want icons on the desktop; YES, agree to the legalese. And to accommodate the weirdos who wants something different, provide one single Installation Options button. And then get on with it. One screen, not seven.  Why do software designers want their work to appear more complex instead of less? I just don't get why they don't get it.  So the next time you're frustrated by software complexity, take heart; much of the time, it's not you. It's them. It's designers who have something on their mind other than software intelligence.

title: College Students Behaving Badly
description: Many people associate property crime and other delinquent behaviors with low social status and a lack of education. But new research has identified a surprising risk factor for bad behavior -- college.  Men who attend college are more likely to commit property crimes during their college years than their non-college-attending peers, according to research to be presented at the annual meeting of the American Sociological Association in Boston this weekend.  Sociologists at Bowling Green State University in Ohio examined data from the National Longitudinal Study of Adolescent Health, which tracks education, crime levels, substance abuse and socializing among adolescents and young adults. Beginning with 9,246 students who were seventh through twelfth graders in the 1994-1995 academic year, the survey followed the students again in 1996 and 2001. The study defined "college students" or "college-bound youth" as those who were enrolled full-time in a four-year college for at least 12 months by the third wave of the survey. "Non-college students" were defined as those respondents who either did not attend college through the course of the study or were not enrolled full-time at a four-year university.  During adolescence, the prospect of attending college was positive. The researchers found that college-bound youth were less likely to be involved in criminal activity and substance use during adolescence than kids who weren't headed for college.  But college attendance appears to trigger some surprising changes. When male students enrolled in four-year universities, levels of drinking, property theft and unstructured socializing with friends increased and surpassed rates for their less-educated male peers.  The reason appears to be that kids who don't go to college simply have to grow up more quickly. College enrollment allows for a lifestyle that essentially extends the adolescent period, said Patrick M. Seffrin, the study's primary investigator and a graduate student and research assistant in the department of sociology and the Center for Family and Demographic Research at Bowling Green State University.  College delays entry into adult roles like marriage, parenting and full-time work. Instead, college students have lots of unstructured social time. Other studies have linked unstructured socializing or "hanging out" with higher levels of delinquency and risk taking.   "College attendance is commonly associated with self-improvement and upward mobility," Mr. Seffrin said. "Yet this research suggests that college may actually encourage, rather than deter, social deviance and risk-taking.''

title: American Cookbook Project
description: (Photo: (Gerik Parmele/Associated Press))   For the past five years, the Smithsonian Institution Traveling Exhibition Service (take a breath) has been sponsoring "Key Ingredients: America by Food," a toothsome exhibition that is traveling across the country through February 2013. (Click here to see a schedule.) You can view the online companion anytime you want, however, to trace the 500-year history of our nation's eats or map the best roads for food-related traveling.   The most ingenious feature may be "The American Cookbook Project: Recipes and Stories from Across the USA." Over the last few years amateur foodie genealogists have been posting their favorite family recipes along with short tales about how they were created.   You may not find the BBQ sauce of our forefathers on your first dip. In fact, you'll have to sift through a lot of lines like "my sister and I were bored and hungry so we just mixed the sauce she had it warm I had cold and we weren't bored anymore" before you find the really tasty stories.   But there is a nice range of national flavor. One woman writes: "My older sisters would make the rolls for the family. I was the youngest of 13 children, and I am the only one left alive. I am now over 90 years old. I feel like this family recipe is one that should be preserved for future generations. I grew up right where I live today, in the Double Branch area south of Butler, Missouri, and my family is still farming in this area." Another writes: "My father was widowed in 1951 with 5 children. He liked to bake cakes and pies! I remember him making this recipe during the holidays. It calls for nickel candy bars, a tube pan and waxed paper, items you won't find around most households today"   And, of course, these stories come with some deliciously down-home recipes.

title: Been Legislating Too Long
description: Are there too many elderly members of the United States Senate? Michael Carey, a former editorial page editor of the Anchorage Daily News, says just that in an article about Ted Stevens published on that newspaper's op-ed page.  "If Ted Stevens had retired in 2002, when he was 78 years old, it's doubtful he would have come under the scrutiny that produced this federal indictment," Carey writes. "If Ted had been a private citizen in 2003, Bill Allen could have turned the Girdwood chalet into a mansion and nobody would have cared. But Ted Stevens wasn't about to retire. In an e-mail, he told me that a doctor he knew said there was no reason humans couldn't live and function well to age 120. Apparently that's what he was intended to do." Carey continues:    As a much younger candidate for the Senate, Stevens repeatedly hammered incumbent Ernest Gruening as too old. His attacks in 1968 were blunt, personal and quite jarring -- especially as the "aged" Ernest Gruening was younger then than Stevens is now.  Stevens did not break the law because of his age. Rather, his lengthy service seems to have convinced him that his U.S. Senate seat was private property, his and his alone. He's among some senators of both parties who have the idea they are senator for life.  In fact, the Senate is becoming an old folks home. In 1928, Furnifold Simmons of North Carolina was the oldest senator, age 74. Today, 16 senators are 74 or older -- almost one-sixth of the entire body. If Mark Begich wins this Senate seat, he will, at age 46, become the third-youngest senator.

title: M.T.A. Details MetroCard Problem
description: Updated, 2:48 p.m. | New York City Transit officials say a faulty encryption device was to blame for the widespread breakdowns in MetroCard vending machines on Monday and Tuesday. The problems left thousands of subway and bus riders unable to use credit and debit cards to purchase MetroCards during peak hours of the morning and evening rush on Monday, and again during the Tuesday morning rush.  Transit officials said on Thursday morning that an encryption device used to encode transmitted data for customer security was not working. The one functioning encryption device could not handle the load during peak hours, Paul J. Fleuranges, a spokesman for New York City Transit, the arm of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority that runs the subways and buses, said in an e-mail message.  The system's 2,245 MetroCard vending machines are programmed to cancel credit and debit transactions after too much time has passed without bank authorization, Mr. Fleuranges said.  The problem was discovered following the Tuesday morning rush and another device was activated to distribute the workload, Mr. Fleuranges said.  Officials said they have asked the private contractor who provides the interface from the agency's data center to the banks to add a feature that will send out a warning signal when an encryption device goes down.  "This will allow New York City Transit to take immediate action to prevent possible future outages," Mr. Fleuranges said.  Officials did not immediately identify the contractor, or say who operates the encryption devices: the contractor, the agency or the bank.  New York City Transit said in a statement on Thursday afternoon:   During three separate rush periods (Monday a.m. and p.m., and Tuesday a.m.), M.T.A. New York City Transit's MetroCard Vending Machines (MVMs) and MetroCard Express Machines (MEMs) had difficulty processing credit-and debit-card sales transactions, inconveniencing thousands of our customers. As customer usage increased, it took an increased period of time to receive authorizations for card usage from our bank. In such cases, the machines are programmed to cancel the transaction after too much time has elapsed without authorization.   After an investigation, it was discovered that one of the encryption devices was not operating. The devices are required by Credit Card Industry security protocols and are necessary to process transactions. The one functioning device could not handle the load during peak usage periods.   Normally the system is served by at least two encrypters (sometimes three). In this case, however, our monitoring system told us that two were active when in fact only one of them was working. This "false positive" was the main reason why it took so long to identify the cause.   Following Tuesday's a.m. rush period, when this issue was identified, another device was activated to distribute the workload and, as we expected, the change corrected the "time out" issues encountered over those three rush hours.   To eliminate a recurrence of this issue, we have requested that the contractor who provides the interface from the M.T.A. data center to the bank that authorizes credit-and-debit-card transactions investigate the addition of a triggering feature that will display a warning message when only one encryption device is active. This will allow NYC Transit to take immediate action to prevent possible future outages.   It should be noted that on Wednesday, with the problem corrected, we processed 211,000 credit/debit purchase requests at MVMs (about 20,000 above the normal figure) and successfully processed 99.98 percent of them. Only 35 attempted transactions didn't succeed, and only 14 of those "timed out."   The problems began occurring early Monday morning and became widespread from about 8:30 to 10:30, near the end of the morning rush, prompting the transit agency to issue a service alert warning riders of the problems.  The problems also caused confusion among transit workers and station agents, some of whom gave customers conflicting instructions on using the machines. The disruptions began again in the evening rush and again on Tuesday morning. Transit officials characterized the problem as "unprecedented in magnitude."   The Daily News reported that problems with the machines continued on Wednesday evening at Grand Central Terminal and at the 53rd Street and Lexington Avenue station. Mr. Fleuranges said those problems were resolved and were not related to the encryption issue.  The systemwide failure highlighted the increasing dependence New Yorkers have come to depend on debit and credit cards in their daily commute and the problems that can emerge with even small technical glitches. Credit and debit cards are used in about 30 percent of MetroCard transactions, accounting for about 62 percent of vending machine revenue, according to the agency.

title: Griffey Jr. on Way to the White Sox
description: (Photo: The White Sox would presumably return Ken Griffey Jr. to center field. (Al Behrman/Associated Press))  Ken Griffey Jr. has approved a trade to the Chicago White Sox from the Cincinnati Reds. According to multiple media outlets, the Reds would receive pitcher Nick Masset and infielder Danny Richar in exchange for Griffey.   Griffey, who has never played in a World Series, may have a chance with the White Sox who lead the American League Central by one and a half games.  The deal is awaiting confirmation from the commissioner's office because more than $1 million is changing hands in order to split Griffey's remaining salary. Griffey is in the last year of a 9-year, $116.5 million deal. There is a $16.5 million option for 2009, with a $4 million buyout.   Since Griffey has 10 years of major league service, including five with the same team, he had the right to quash the deal.   The White Sox have Carlos Quentin in left field and Jermaine Dye in right so they would presumably return Griffey to center, a position he has not played regularly since 2006. Nick Swisher, the center fielder, and Paul Konerko could share time at first base. Jim Thome is the designated hitter.  Griffey, who has 608 career homers, is batting .245 with 15 homers and 53 runs batted in.

title: McCain Camp Says Obama Is Playing the Race Card
description: Updated | 4:17 p.m.:  RACINE, Wis.  Senator John McCain's campaign accused Barack Obama of playing "the race card'' on Thursday, citing his remarks that Republicans would try to scare voters by pointing out he "doesn't look like all those other presidents on the dollar bills.''  "Barack Obama has played the race card, and he played it from the bottom of the deck,'' Rick Davis, Mr. McCain's campaign manager, said in a statement. "It's divisive, negative, shameful and wrong.''  Mr. Davis was alluding to comments that Mr. Obama made Wednesday in Missouri when he reacted to the increasingly negative tone, and negative ads that have been coming his way from the McCain campaign in recent days.  "So nobody really thinks that Bush or McCain have a real answer for the challenges we face, so what they're going to try to do is make you scared of me,'' Mr. Obama said Wednesday in Springfield, Mo., in remarks that he echoed throughout the day. "You know, he's not patriotic enough. He's got a funny name. You know, he doesn't look like all those other Presidents on those dollar bills, you know. He's risky. That's essentially the argument they're making.''   Mr. Obama has made similar statements about the lines of attack against him before, and was even more direct last month when he said: "We know what kind of campaign they're going to run. They're going to try to make you afraid of me. He's young and inexperienced and he's got a funny name. And did I mention he's black?''  The McCain campaign's decision to make the charge now that Mr. Obama was playing the "race card" comes as it has adopted a far more aggressive, negative posture towards Mr. Obama in recent days, trying to tar him as arrogant, out of touch and unprepared for the presidency with a series of statements by Mr. McCain and a series of negative ads  some of which have been condemned as misleading.   Mr. McCain said Thursday that he agreed with Mr. Davis's statement. "I agree with it, and I'm disappointed that Senator Obama would say the things he's saying," Mr. McCain said on his campaign bus here, according to The Associated Press.   Robert Gibbs, a spokesman for the Obama campaign, said: "This is a race about big challenges -- a slumping economy, a broken foreign policy, and an energy crisis for everyone but the oil companies. Barack Obama in no way believes that the McCain campaign is using race as an issue, but he does believe they're using the same old low-road politics to distract voters from the real issues in this campaign, and those are the issues he'll continue to talk about."   By making the accusation that Mr. Obama was playing the "race card,'' Mr. McCain's campaign, of course, was itself explicitly injecting race into its campaign against the first black man ever to become a major party's presidential nominee.  And the McCain campaign was echoing one of the more sensitive and divisive arguments that arose in Mr. Obama's primary battle against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton. Many black leaders, and voters, criticized Bill Clinton for equating Mr. Obama's victory in the South Carolina primary with the Rev. Jesse Jackson's victory in the 1988 primary, which they saw as an attempt to diminish Mr. Obama's success. Mr. Clinton later complained in a radio interview that Mr. Obama had "played the race card on me.''  The new discussion of race comes as Mr. McCain is schedule to address the National Urban League on Friday in Orlando.   Related: McCain Says He Is Proud of 'Celebrity' Ad

title: McCain Says He Is Proud of 'Celebrity' Ad
description: Update | 4 p.m.: RACINE, Wis.  Senator John McCain said here Thursday that he was "proud" of his campaign's commercial likening Senator Barack Obama to celebrities like Britney Spears and Paris Hilton.   Mr. McCain  who has not taken questions from his traveling press in a week  made the remarks after a young woman at a town-hall-style meeting here asked him if he had "flip-flopped" from his earlier pledge to refrain from mudslinging. She asked specifically asked about the new Britney Spears commercial. "I was like, Oh-Kayyyy,'' she said of the ad, stretching out the word, apparently to indicate skepticism.   "Campaigns are tough, but I'm proud of the campaign we've run,'' said Mr. McCain, whose campaign has broadcast a series of negative ads about Mr. Obama.   "All I can say is we're proud of that commercial,'' he said.    The Obama campaign announced today it was setting up a new Web site called McCain's Low Road Express to debunk ads and statements by the McCain campaign and e-mailed a video of Mr. Obama discussing the ad today during a campaign event in Cedar Rapids. "Given the magnitude of our challenges when it comes to energy and healthcare and jobs and our foreign policy, you'd think that we'd be having a serious debate," Mr. Obama said during But so far, all we've been hearing about is Paris Hilton and Britney Spears. I mean I do -- I do have to ask my opponent, is that the best you can come up with? Is that really what this election's about? Is that what is worthy of the American people? Even the media has pointed out that senator John McCain who started off talking about running an honorable campaign has fallen back into the predictable political attacks the demonstrably false statements."   Here is the full exchange from the McCain town-hall-style meeting:   "First of all, Senator McCain, I just want to commend you on your service for our country'' the young woman said. "But, earlier this year, in April, you had made comments about, like, the mudslinging, how it had been affecting other campaigns, and how you didn't want to do that. But recently, especially last week when Obama went to Europe, it seemed like there was a lot of campaign ads that you put out that were doing that. And the one yesterday, comparing him to Britney Spears and Paris HiltonLike, I was like, Ok-Kayyyy. So it seems like, to Americans like me and other people, like you may have flip-flopped on what you had said earlier. What is your response to that?"   Mr. McCain replied: "Well, first of all, um, let me say that there are differences, and we are drawing those differences and I have said earlier, I admire his campaign. But what we are talking about here is substance, and not style. And what we're talking about is who has an agenda for the future of America. Campaigns are tough, but I'm proud of the campaign that we have run, I'm proud of the issues that we have, trying to address with the American people, and again, I would hope that Senator Obama would join me so that we could discuss this as he said he wanted to quote, "duel" over taxes, I believe it was yesterday. So all I can say is that we're proud of that commercial, we think Americans need to know that I believe that we should base this campaign on what we can do for Americans here at home, and how we can make America safe and prosperous and that's the theme of our campaign. I thank you."
